name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the discussion on the Commission statement on the decision taken on the European Semester package, including the 2016 Annual Growth Survey (2016/2927 (RSP)).

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, last month we had a fruitful exchange of views on the 2016 European Semester on the basis of the report drafted by Mr Sant Today, I am pleased to present a package which starts the 2017 European Semester adopted by the Commission last week. The European Semester has become a key mechanism for the coordination of economic policies at EU level. It has played a crucial role in triggering and supporting urgently needed economic reforms in Member States, and in the current context of a gradual but all-too-moderate recovery, there is no time for complacency. The messages included in the 2017 Annual Growth Survey, and more generally in the Autumn Package, are a reflection of the new impetus that the Commission has given to economic governance, building on the experience of the last few years. The aim is to identify where challenges remain and where the EU and Member States should focus their efforts. In particular, faster progress on the implementation of structural reforms, in line with the country-specific recommendations, is needed to boost jobs and growth and to foster economic, social and territorial cohesion. As we have seen from the Commission’s autumn economic forecast, economic growth in Europe is expected to continue at a moderate pace. Recently, we have seen some labour market gains and rising private consumption but, at the same time, there are a number of risks to growth and a weakening of supportive factors like low oil prices. However, the economic recovery is proving quite resilient. The EU’s GDP is now higher than before the crisis. All Member States are set to grow next year. Investment is starting to increase, supported in part by projects financed under the Investment Plan for Europe. Labour market developments are also more encouraging. Employment is expected to grow faster this year than at any time since 2008, though unemployment still remains high.  Public finances continue to improve. In the EU, both average public deficit and the government debt-to-GDP ratio will continue to fall over the next two years. However, political uncertainty, slow global growth and weak global trade weigh on our growth prospects and we face a number of economic and social challenges. Unemployment is still high. Disparities persist across and within countries, both as regards economic performance and in terms of social challenges. Public and private debt levels remain high in some Member States and act as a drag on growth. In the financial sector there are still high levels of non-performing loans in several Member States. The Annual Growth Survey 2017 builds on the priorities set out in President Juncker’s State of the Union address, as well as on the Bratislava road map. The over-arching message from the annual Growth Survey is that we have to redouble efforts along the virtuous triangle of boosting investment, pursuing structural reforms and ensuring responsible fiscal policies, and in doing so we have to focus on social fairness and delivering more inclusive growth. A new element this year is a communication on the fiscal stance of the euro area. The letter of intent that accompanies the State of the Union speech announced that the Commission will propose a positive fiscal stance for the euro area in support of the monetary policy of the European Central Bank. The communication provides the Commission’s views on the appropriate euro area aggregate fiscal stance in the context of the institutional architecture of the Economic and Monetary Union. Of course, such an orientation should build on the legal frameworks set by the Stability and Growth Pact and take into account the broader fiscal sustainability concerns. The recommendation on the economic policy of the euro area highlights five areas for action: reforms that favour growth and productivity; a supportive fiscal stance; job creation and social fairness; strengthening the banking sector, and completion of our Economic and Monetary Union. The draft Joint Employment Report shows that employment and the social situation are gradually improving, while stressing clearly that there is, nevertheless, no room for complacency. The main challenges concern notably high levels of inequality; still high rates of youth unemployment and of those not in employment, education or training; long-term unemployment; and the under-representation of women in the labour market. The unprecedented inflow of asylum seekers and other migrants also calls for comprehensive integration policies. The package also includes the 2017 Alert Mechanism Report, which screens Member States for risks of macroeconomic imbalances and identifies countries for in-depth reviews. Thirteen in-depth reviews are announced in the Alert Mechanism Report, namely for Bulgaria, Croatia, Cyprus, Finland, France, Germany, Ireland, Italy, the Netherlands, Portugal, Slovenia, Spain and Sweden. The results will be included in the country reports that the Commission will issue towards the end of February 2017. The reduction of the number of in-depth reviews compared to the last year, when 19 such reviews were carried out, reflects the recent progress made in addressing imbalances. Also, a number of vulnerabilities persist. The Commission also issued opinions on the draft budgetary plans received from the euro area Member States. We received those budgetary plans in October, and the findings have been summarised in a chapeau communication. This year, with regard to the Member States under the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact, we found that for five countries – Germany, Estonia, Luxembourg, Slovakia and the Netherlands – their draft budgetary plans are compliant with the requirements of the Stability and Growth Pact. For four countries – Ireland, Malta, Austria and Latvia – the draft budgetary plans are broadly compliant. For six countries – Belgium, Italy, Cyprus, Lithuania Slovenia and Finland – the draft budgetary plans pose a risk of non-compliance. Concerning the Member States under the corrective arm of the Stability and Growth Pact, for France, the draft budgetary plan is found to be broadly compliant with the requirements of SGP. For Spain, the draft budgetary plan which was submitted under the no-policy-change scenario, is found to be at risk of non-compliance. Also for Portugal, the draft budgetary plan is found to be at risk of non-compliance. Portugal, however, is expected to correct the excessive deficit this year and to transit to the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact next year.  Spain and Portugal have also submitted reports on actions taken in the response to the Council decisions to step up the excessive deficit procedures. The Commission has in the meantime assessed the possible partial suspension of European structural and investment funds and engaged in a structured dialogue with the European Parliament. Taking into account the measures that Spain and Portugal have taken, the Commission’s view is that the excessive deficit procedure should be kept in abeyance at this point for both countries. Accordingly, the requirement for a proposal by the Commission to suspend part of the European structural and investment Funds is no longer present and there will be no such proposal by the Commission.  This autumn package is there to assess the EU and euro area dimension of the European Semester. In the coming weeks and months, the work will focus more on the country-specific dimension of the process. The Commission will present its country-specific analysis, including the in-depth reviews under the macroeconomic imbalances procedure and the country reports, towards the end of February next year.  In the run-up to the country-specific recommendations, scheduled for May next year, the Commission plans to intensify dialogue with the Member States and the social partners to develop a common understanding of successful reform implementation.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for the statements. Let me first of all underline one thing: the Commission is the guardian of the Treaty and it has the responsibility to act within the legal framework – not to change it or cause hesitancy about the rules. That is why it is important that all actions regarding the Stability Pact are consistent with what has been legislated in this Chamber.  I will make three points. The recovery we are seeing is moving at a slow pace. It is to a high degree dependent on a unique monetary policy that is not sustainable in a long—term perspective, but it is also based upon the credibility of the Stability Pact and the stability of public finances. Do not risk that, Commissioner, by calling the Stability Pact and its rules into question.  Secondly, reforms and the consolidation of public finances are the best way to avoid austerity. Wherever you use deficits as a way to avoid structural reforms, you enter into austerity because austerity comes from spending more money than you have. As soon as you do that, you are creating problems for investment, for growth and for jobs. We can see this on the European map. Thirdly, budgets must be improved with quality. Member States must give priority to the spending that is most important before they increase the deficits. They must give priority to the important things and not have an excuse, in the end, for above minus 3%, for squeezing in the most important spending. They – and all of us – need to do it the other way round.  We want to fight austerity and unemployment with growth and structural reforms. We do not believe in deficits and increased debt burdens. We think that Europe shall go forward.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the communication on fiscal stance approved by the Commission is the best response to the advance of the populists, because the populists' most valuable ally is precisely blind and dogmatic austerity. And it is on the rubble that austerity left behind that the new political order promoted by the populists thrives. It is no coincidence that Trump in America today promises a large investment plan of a trillion dollars: in the face of the new US activism, the European Union cannot remain helpless. The European Commission is right and I want to thank Commissioner Moscovici for his fundamental work. We need to move to a more expansive eurozone fiscal policy and the countries that have budget surpluses today have a duty to invest more. But we also need a major European initiative to support a more ambitious economic policy. Parliament is therefore right to define at this time the nature of Europe's fiscal capacity. For our group, the Commission's new approach to fiscal stance is a necessary turning point. I want to say clearly to those who are aiming at sabotaging this turning point - and I am referring in particular to Schäuble - that for us this fiscal stance is an impassable red line, on which we condition our support for this Commission and we will not tolerate any sabotage. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 149 (8)))

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – Mr Pittella, I think we all agree that we need to fight austerity. The question is, in which way? I would like you to explain where you have seen that we can have reduced austerity through increased deficits, increased debt burdens, rising interest rates and political uncertainty. Where have we seen that? Austerity comes from overspending, spending more money than you have. Reforms and growth come from strategic and responsible budgeting. So please explain where you have seen that increased deficits and increased debt burdens have given growth and unemployment. I have seen things the other way around.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- I only know, my colleague Hökmark, that the austerity policy, which aimed to reduce the debt, did not reduce it, for a very simple reason, which even elementary school children know: if you reduce the State's revenues, whyyou compress investment spending, you don't reduce debt but increase it.Indeed, the aggregate debt of the euro area has increased and not decreased.Only through a serious investment policy - colleague Othmar is right about this - can a serious investment policy, founded and aimed at large tangible and intangible infrastructures, the environment, the energy transition and human resources, can reduce debt, makingwealth, jobs and, therefore, the income of the state.

name: Sander LOONES
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - In a few months we will be celebrating 25 years of the Maastricht Treaty. That Treaty stipulated how the Member States are responsible for their social policy, for their economic policy and that they must conduct that policy within the budgetary framework that we have agreed together. It is up to the European Commission to ensure that those rules are complied with, that everyone remains within the boundaries and to impose sanctions when necessary. Well, colleagues, I think we should go back to the logic of the Maastricht Treaty. The accounts must be in order and the Member States that refuse to cooperate must be held accountable for their responsibility. We must also be able to impose sanctions on these Member States, and if necessary expel them from the eurozone when necessary. But what do we see? That the European Commission does not appear to be planning to celebrate the Maastricht Treaty today, but rather intends to bury the Treaty. What she proposes does not fit within the agreed framework. The Commission imagines itself as a kind of European Ministry of Finance. It proposes matters for which it has no competence, but above all it proposes matters that are not sensible. Our structural problems, as Mr Hökmark has already said, will not melt away. We cannot buy growth on credit. In the short term that may help us, in the long term it just creates more problems. It is also perfectly possible to save and grow smartly. We see this in countries such as the Netherlands, Germany and Austria. That is precisely the path that we must follow with this European Union.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - I thank the Commission for the explanation. You rightly conclude that we need policies that lead to more employment, social fairness, convergence and a positive investment climate. If we want to improve our competitiveness, we need faster completion of internal markets. Our funds must also be used to finance growth-stimulating and cross-border projects. But how? A budget surplus seems likely. I have two questions about this. First, how does the Commission motivate Member States to spend a budget surplus on the collective? After all, we cannot expect a country to invest its space in the budget if other countries do not comply with the rules of the European Semester. These rules must therefore become enforceable. Second, how does the Commission intend to achieve a so-called spillover effect? Let's make Europe the most competitive research and innovation region. Only an ambitious economic and monetary policy, in combination with a complete internal market, will produce the best results.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, the economic and social priorities that you raise are absolutely insufficient. The recommendations once again insist on measures that we have already seen how, year after year, they have failed. In terms of employment, they are a new call to the precariousness of working conditions and the lives of workers. The incentives for hiring end up turning entrepreneurs into subsidies, which only serve to avoid paying their social contributions. Improvements are called for in training systems, while at the same time cuts are applied to all public policies. The elements of social protection have not yet materialized. We have been waiting two years for a minimum income proposal. In short: these measures are the repetition of your mistakes. Year after year we note in this Parliament the failure of these measures; the same measures that have led us, among others, to Brexit, the disaffection of citizens, the advancement of the politics of the extreme right, precisely as a result of that disaffection. What they propose is not how to grow, but rather a Dada manifesto, more structural reforms, flexibility, and so on. Have you learned anything since the beginning of this crisis? Of course, it seems not. Make big capitals pay taxes. Make an effective investment program. Promote a sustainable production model. Improve productivity. Make a real social pillar. This is not the way. They only want to benefit big capital and dismantle social Europe.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, thank you Vice President for your presence. I will focus on your Communication on the tax position. There are three statements in the Communication that I believe are correct: first, that the recovery is fragile - I believe that no one can doubt that; second, that basing our entire growth strategy on foreign demand is a suicidal strategy, given the context; and third, that we cannot trust everything to monetary policy being the solution to sustain growth. But then, one thing happens: you make an effort to present a proposal for an expansive fiscal position, but I have to tell you that it is too little, that it comes too late and that it is not consistent with the rules that we have, which is something that you they do not recognize. Too little, obviously, because practically what they are asking is to go a little further than the fiscal position this year, not much further. Too late because the damage done by the austerity policies throughout all these years is very high. And too inconsistent because it is a bit difficult to see how such a policy is consistent with the current governance standards that we have. The whole process lacks consistency, I have to tell you. The strict implementation of the budget recommendations that you made last year assumed a regressive fiscal position of 0.3%, even though you predicted that the fiscal position would be neutral. In other words, the coherence of all the forecasts for last year is absolutely evident. And that for me has three implications or shows three things: first, the volatility and uncertainty of the entire process that we are starting today; second, the endemic procyclicality of the Stability and Growth Pact; and, third, the persistent over-optimism of their forecasts. And, later, in relation to Communication, I also have to tell you something else, that they do not finish breaking a taboo that is very important: what geographical distribution of the aggregate fiscal position and the measures to be taken should be carried out. The calculations that we can see would imply that, for example, Germany, from the current 0.6% surplus should go to a negative fiscal position of 0.5%; or if Germany goes to a neutral fiscal position, that means that certain countries - for example, Spain - would not comply with the recommendations and forecasts that you have made. But it would be nice if you indicated that geographical distribution. Therefore, and by way of conclusion, Mr. Vice President, I have to tell you that, although it is too little and too late, I hope it turns out well, but the omens are not very good. The German minister and the Spanish minister, incomprehensibly, have already said that they do not agree. I believe that this Parliament must send a clear message that it is important that this year the fiscal position is expansionary because, if not, the recovery will not come. We are going to ask you to also advance, as I was saying, in the regional distribution, to indicate what regional distribution there must be. And finally, you have to recognize that the current rules of governance do not work and that the entire economic policy strategy of the last few years has been a failure.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: for the EFDD Group. - Mr President! Once again, I am witnessing the EU's grandiose plans - plans that have not worked before and will not work this time either. We who criticize the construction of the United States of Europe dismiss you with contempt as populists. But let me remind you that it is the ordinary, little people that you dismiss. It is the ordinary, small people who go to work, who toil every day to be able to pay their tax money. These are the ones you so contemptuously call populists. There are ordinary people who are worried about their everyday lives, how they will manage, how the family will make the money enough for each month. These are ordinary people who, unlike you, realize that your dream does not work in practice. It is people who realize that member states actually differ fundamentally, not least in terms of economic conditions. Therefore, a common currency and a common economic policy is a complete utopia that will never work. Now you predict that the economy will grow and that next year will be better. It's kind of like I'd predict that it's going to snow in an hour. It's just guesses and hopes. You have completely lost the trust of ordinary people, as evidenced by the declining turnout every time we have elections to the European Parliament. As long as you continue to pursue this as an elitist project and do not put your ear to the ground and listen to the little man's worries and despair, this project called the European Union is doomed to fail.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. –Mr Chairman, Vice-President Dombrovskis! Last week, the European Commission completed its assessment of the Member States' budgetary policies and presented a package of economic and social priorities that, together with the economic data from the 2016 autumn forecast, will usher in the European Semester for the coming year. However, the European Semester does not meet with sustainability among the member states. Some do not adhere to the European Semester and the Stability and Growth Pact and do not have to incur any consequences for this: Contrary to what was announced in the summer, the Commission is now refraining from freezing structural funds for the deficit sinners Spain and Portugal - from sanction exemptions for Quite apart from latent refusals of budget restructuring like France and Italy. Others criticize the European Commission for setting wrong priorities and not taking vigorous action against deficit sinners. It is stated - especially from the German side - that the European Commission is single-handedly setting financial policy goals for the monetary union for the next semester, for which there is no legal basis, and at the same time is trying to change the entire architecture of financial policy coordination in the euro zone . The German side is receiving support from the Slovak Presidency, which is calling for a reform of the Stability Pact. The aim is to make the pact simpler and easier to understand. I quote the Ecofin President: If rules are nonsensical, you have to change them instead of circumventing them, otherwise you will destroy the rules. The credibility of the semester and the Stability Pact, and thus of the entire set of coordination rules, is at stake, unless it is already gambled away. If Member States in surplus are due to If macroeconomic imbalances are subject to a preventive component of the Stability Pact and countries that are subject to excessive deficit procedures have been getting away with unsanctioned procedures for years, flexibility can quickly be interpreted as a lack of principles.The entire eurozone continues to suffer from excessively high national debt, as the current autumn forecast confirms.With a few exceptions, however, budget consolidation is not progressing because the governments do not want to and do not have to implement any unpopular structural measures because they indirectly finance the ECB.That will not change if one or two Member States invest more.These investments do not solve the structural and financial problems of the others.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Mr President, with fears of a new round of crisis, embarrassment over Brexit and the election of Trump, the forthcoming elections in various countries with growing popular controversy but trapped in a reactionary direction, competition is intensifying worldwide and in the Union. In such a climate of contradictions, really, what is the value of single economic governance and the European Semester? And yet they retain their value. Convergence or divergence or even centrifugal forces, some relaxation with reforms proposed by the Commission or austerity, as Germany and others insist, are only about financing investment capital and not restoring what the people have lost. Any policy mix presupposes new permanent popular sacrifices described in the European Semester. Everyone agrees with them. For example, Greece of three or even four memoranda that is preparing for new strikes. The people must organize under their own flag and not the capital for overthrow. The change of managers simply leads to new frustrations.

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: - Mr President, Vice-President Dombrovskis! Let me first of all recap what the Commission has given us in terms of figures from the Member States: with regard to preventive budgetary surveillance, four Member States do not fully comply with the requirements of the Stability Pact, and six Member States are on the verge of attesting that they have not complied with the requirements becomes. In addition, there are three Member States that have already had to be required to take significant corrections to address non-compliance. Ladies and gentlemen! What does this balance tell us? This balance sheet is clearly negative and it worries us about fiscal stability, the immense debt and the structural problems of many member states in the euro area. The balance sheet shows that the Commission is called upon in its control function as guardian of our mutually agreed rules that determine and secure our cooperation, and more than ever. A positive fiscal policy stance for the euro zone is no way out. A fiscal policy course for the euro zone is not even legally secured by our existing economic policy framework. Structural problems are not solved by adding up certain key figures, at most they are concealed by this. But concealment would not help anyone. Above all, this would certainly not help the credibility of our political actions. More specifically, I would like to ask you today, Mr Dombrovskis: why does the Commission not apply the rules that we have before you create further confusion and disperse responsibilities? And what is the legal basis for a positive fiscal policy course? Does this legal basis even exist? What are you doing to ensure a return to competitiveness in each Member State? (The speaker is I have agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), "blue card" question.- A simple question: is there, in your view, any responsibility for what you have said in German economic policy, namely in Mr Schäuble's policy, and in this country's attempt to Germanize European economic policy?

name: Burkhard BALZ
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I have seldom heard - you said it was a simple question - such a stupid question here in this house.“Germanization of economic policy” is pretty much the worst thing that can be done.I believe that Mr Schäuble has acted extremely responsibly - as a real European by the way - in recent years.From my point of view, one should not point with individual fingers at individual countries, neither in the direction of Germany nor in the home country from which you come.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, we welcome the Commission because we are starting now to adapt economic policy to the real needs, economic, social, political needs, of the European Union and the euro area. We can also recognise that the European Parliament proposals adopted in the last Annual Growth Survey (AGS) report were also taken into account. We are now starting to have an economic policy driven by the European strategy for growth and jobs, we are having a policy mix giving more attention to investment, we are paying attention to the role of demand and reducing social inequalities, and we are developing a euro area stance with more focus on supporting growth. These are positive elements.  Nevertheless, we are still falling short of a real virtuous circle in the euro area, because for this we need to have much higher investment to tackle social inequalities, thus increasing growth, and with higher growth it will be easier to reduce our public debt. Of course fiscal discipline is important but this is not enough. We need to have this virtuous circle in the euro area. And for this we need to complete the economic and monetary union with a banking union and fiscal capacity. All members of the euro area need to have these conditions and we believe this is really a central task for the Commission when the White Paper is being prepared.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, the famous 'European Semester' is a mechanism for undoing the sovereign rights of national parliaments to freely shape their state budgets. It is a tool for enforcing partial austerity and violent fiscal adjustment. And when Brussels shows that they are trying to become autonomous from Berlin politics, giving, as now, a few crumbs of growth, then Schäuble brings them back to order. Schäuble, who once again in an orphan way, challenges the Greek people impoverished by the memoranda, demanding new reductions in salaries and pensions. So it is time, Mr Dombrovskis, for Greece to proceed with the entry of German compensation into the Greek state budget. For this reason, we are organizing an electronic vote by which we finally demand the registration in the state budget of Germany's debts to Greece. An electronic vote that will put the Greek Parliament before its responsibilities and will force the Greek government to do the obvious, to register, that is, here and now the German compensations in the Greek state budget of 2017 under discussion.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, the recovery in the EU is gaining ground. There are a number of positive developments signalling the recovery. However, recovery remains fragile. Indeed Member States need to continue to pursue structural reforms to make their economies more competitive and build confidence in their economic and business environment. But we again face broader uncertainty. The election of Donald Trump in the USA as President reflects the resurgence of protectionism and opposition to TPP and TTIP. It means that the benefits of openness and free trade are again under serious threat. We cannot afford this. We must uphold openness and facilitate the further integration of EU companies in global value chains. We need this as a source of jobs for Europeans.  Finishing CETA is a way to press the USA to keep up openness. It could not have come at better time as it creates immediate market opportunities for American companies, which will have to find alternatives against protectionism in the USA. That is why I urge the Commission and Parliament to finish CETA as soon as possible and to continue the implementation of the key reforms in this report.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, you said, among other things, that you want to integrate European companies in the global market and I agree with you as a former entrepreneur.But I ask you: do you think that with this rigid policy of capping the deficit at 3%, new investments can be developed?Don't you think that flexibility is needed?How was this 3% deficit calculated?How do we know the optimal number?Not four, why not two?

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: blue-card answer. – We have to have sound economies in order to be involved in global value chains in Europe in a global economy. The economies that are in deficit cannot be part of it, because they will just create and continue spreading the deficits around. I think that the involvement of European companies in the creation of jobs for Europeans has to be made on sound ground.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, Mr Dombrovskis, blind unilateral austerity, that is, the Schäuble doctrine, does not bring growth. It disintegrates Europe by sharpening social and regional inequalities and feeds the populists of the Far Right. The Commission needs to take bolder steps towards a shift towards economic growth across Europe, by boosting investment and demand, especially from eurozone countries such as Germany, which have large budget surpluses, by easing but and the modification of the Stability and Growth Pact, so that we can finally grow and reduce unemployment, especially in the countries of southern Europe, which are plagued by huge unemployment, especially of young people. Mr Dombrovskis, the doctrine of 'austerity-austerity' kills growth, fuels unemployment and strengthens the far-right agenda for the disintegration of Europe and a huge social setback. You have a historic duty and responsibility to prevent this and we in the European Parliament have it. Therefore, stop exposing yourself as a Commission to the bullying of Mr Schäuble, who wants to replace the Commission in its institutional role with automated mechanisms and technocrats, such as the ESM. We expect strong responses to this bullying.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Mr President, when we are looking at the Growth Survey, we need to be considering its distribution and effect, not just figures. So does the Commission really feel that Member States have policies in place which will reduce inequality? This means dealing with issues such as corporate taxation and the top end of income, tax levels, pay ratios etc. In terms of reducing poverty, part of our 2020 Strategy, what progress does the Commission feel is being made? How many Member States have a genuine living wage policy in place? We know this is not the same as a minimum wage. What recommendations is the Commission making in this area? The report mentions effective social security and benefits schemes. We recognise that these are essential, but too many of these schemes have no factual basis when we actually look at the amounts paid. So, again, what recommendations are we making? What progress is there? On decent jobs, workers’ participation and the role of trades unions are important, so does the Commission believe that its policies and recommendations on labour market reform are enhancing such participation or threatening it, as is often reported? Lastly, on climate change, does the Commission believe that Member States have really incorporated action on this into their strategies on investment and skills development?

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since I entered this Parliament, that is to say in my last term, I have dealt with all the issues related to the semester and I find it mind-boggling that in two and a half years, almost three, no the dogma linked to this austerity which is intrinsic in the treaties, which is intrinsic in this project, which in my opinion cannot be completed and unreformable from both a technical and political point of view, which is called Union economic and monetary. Unfortunately, we know how, technically, the euro is an unsustainable currency, which creates imbalances and causes, in fact, the total destruction of what is the social and economic reality in Europe. If we look at the surplus that Germany has accumulated this year, we see that it amounts to almost 9%, that is, 300 billion. By now Germany has become the China of the world and all this thanks to the euro, that is thanks to a currency that is undervalued for its economy and that allows it to generate this monstrous trade surplus in the face of the monstrous deficits that are generated in the countries of the South. Here, this is something that cannot be read in your texts and that, objectively, should instead be emphasized more. So what happens? When you say that you have growth, growth in Europe is due to monetary policies that have significantly devalued the currency and, in fact, due to a situation also linked to energy prices, which are very low. . When this disappears, there will be no more growth and the structural problems will still emerge. However, I am truly astonished that the single currency project is religiously defended. You cannot continue in this direction, because the greatest economists in the world are saying it: if we do not focus on the problem of political and above all technical unsustainability of the single currency, we will not be able to move forward and there will be an uncontrolled dissolution of the area.And the blame for this will lie solely with the Commission and all the populist and demagogic parties that continue to support the euro.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, once again, the European Semester is faced with a failure. The majority of countries have never respected the rule of the Stability and Growth Pact and the Commission still does not dare to do anything against the huge German budget and trade surplus. It is easier to be strong with the weak than weak with the strong. Let Germany lead by example and pay its historic debt to Greece. Your economic and budgetary coordination policy continues to produce the same result: macroeconomic indicators are still in the red. Which explains the inexorable rise of Euroscepticism, but you still continue in a frantic headlong rush. Mr. Moscovici even goes to the French regions to dispense your propaganda on the economic benefits of the European Union. Despite the disastrous results of the permanent destruction of wealth and jobs, you want to try the experiment of economic federalism and, moreover, every commissioner dreams of being the finance minister of the euro zone. What a sham to see that the French budget for 2017 has been deemed generally compliant by your services, when everyone knows that it is only a fanciful budget based on unrealistic economic statistics. The same causes will give the same effects: massive unemployment, austerity which kills domestic demand, free trade, the laxity of the ECB, the laissez-faire of States in the face of multinationals and private banks, privatizations, deregulation of the labor market and massive immigration. All this policy will lead the Europeans to bankruptcy! Your European Semester is just palliative care. As long as you keep the euro as the single currency, we will have austerity!

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the European Union, in order to ensure a policy of strict fiscal discipline in the Member States, implements the following tools: Europe 2020 Strategy ten years, Multiannual Financial Framework six years, Stability and Convergence programs three years deep, budget plans on an annual basis and the European Semester on a semi-annual basis. If it implements a tool on a monthly basis, then no country will be able to avoid the complete abolition of its national economic sovereignty. The European Union has not been able to anticipate the economic crisis, mass immigration, the rise of terrorism and Brexit, let alone deal with them effectively. Europe does not need Member States' financial control systems. It needs policies tailored to the needs of citizens. And to put it in military terms, centralized control and centralized command are the hallmarks of a bad commander. The failure of a bad commander is due to him and not to the staff he manages.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Mr President, I welcome the Annual Growth Survey 2017 and I fully support the three-pillar approach which puts the focus on investment, structural reforms and responsible fiscal policy.  However, after three years of being involved in this type of policy approach we see that growth, economic growth, has returned to Europe but it is still very fragile. But I do not know whether this is a reason to blame the Commission or the European Union in general. I would say that there are limits to what the EU can do, given the very small size of the budget and also the fact that many of the constraints on growth which we identify right now are in areas that are under the direct control of Member States. Let me just mention a few of them.  First of all, high debt levels both in banks and in enterprises. Then, low investment in innovation, knowledge, and education. Number three, this is still an insufficiently conducive environment for business activities that would make Europe an attractive, the most attractive, place for investment across the whole world. So there are a number of things that have to be done by Member States. I would like to call on the Commissioner to increase the role of country-specific recommendations and to make sure that they are treated seriously by Member States because otherwise we can, of course, exchange reproaches in this House but without actually any tangible results in terms of higher growth and more jobs.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I think that the Commission - slowly but, I hope, surely - is about to take a turn. I see two reasons for this, two facts which mark this turning point. The first was the recognition that Spain and Portugal had taken effective action and that a suspension of structural funds was not necessary. I believe that the action of this Parliament in this direction has been decisive and I welcome it. Let us continue this structured dialogue with effective results. The second fact is this communication on the aggregate position of the euro area and the "euro area" recommendation which recognizes, in parallel with the renewal of the Juncker plan, that the aggregate position is essential if we want to stimulate growth and support investment to where it needs to be. For this, I also believe that the message that the President of the European Central Bank sends day after day - and he did it again yesterday - that monetary policy needs to be supported by an aggressive aggregate fiscal position, is of good quality. But if we welcome these two elements in your 2017 Annual Growth Survey, then two consequences must be drawn when it comes to specific recommendations for the euro area. First, we don't want any structural reform. We want "new generation" structural reforms, which boost human capital, for example. We also want all the consequences in fiscal matters to be drawn, in particular to support investment, but also to fight more effectively against inequalities, which remain a major concern. Finally, in the medium term, it will also be necessary to draw the consequences of this analysis. First, the Stability Pact needs to evolve and, above all, the roadmap that you need to set in motion with the White Paper on the reform of the European Union at 27 the need for budgetary capacity for the euro zone and for the completion of the tools enabling the Economic and Monetary Union to effectively serve the interests of the member countries of the zone must not be overlooked.(The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: blue-card question. – Would Ms Berès agree with me that France currently faces the worst of all economic worlds, in that it is locked in a currency that is entirely unsuited to its needs and that reduces room for fiscal manoeuvre, and also has a governing party which has imposed an anti-business culture which is seeing stagnation and growing unemployment? Is that the reason that nobody thinks the Socialists will have a candidate in the last round of the French presidential elections?

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: answer "blue card".- I did not know that I was dealing with an expert in national policy.I see that, Sunday after Sunday, or Thursday when people vote on Thursday, we go from surprise to surprise and that the result of last Sunday does not preclude another surprise for tomorrow.I also note that it is at the initiative of France that the question of the debate on investment and the completion of the banking union has been able to take on its full dimension in the European debate, and I am delighted that.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: –Mr President! Commissioner! While speaking in this debate, I would like to point out that the economic recovery in most EU countries, especially in the south of the euro area, is weak and uneven, and what is more, it is stimulated mainly by the loosening of the ECB's monetary policy, as well as fiscal policy and external factors, but of a temporary nature. such as, for example, low oil prices. Against this background, my country, Poland - not belonging to the euro area - shows stable and balanced economic growth, which this year will reach 3% of GDP, and in 2017 - 3.6% of GDP, while maintaining a responsible budget policy, which is reflected in the deficit of the financial sector public less than 3% of GDP. Tax efficiency is also improving: from the four main taxes it will increase from 13.5% to 15.3% of GDP, an increase of two percentage points. And the lowest in 27 years is also unemployment, which, according to the Central Statistical Office's classification, will not exceed 8% this autumn, and will be below this level in 2017. Therefore, it can be concluded that the condition of the economies and public finances of the EU countries using their own currencies is clearly better than those of the euro area.

name: Sylvie GOULARD
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, I am delighted, as other speakers have said before me, to point out that you have adopted this year an aggregated approach which seems to be a good thing because, indeed, this what matters most is that we are interested in the interests of the euro area as a whole. On this, I want to say, as one of the former six-pack rapporteurs, how disappointed I am with your use of it - well, when I say "you" I'm not sure. to address myself completely to the only person who is, in this case, concerned since it is the college which makes decisions. The intention of the legislator, when we drew up the six-pack, was to make the rules less likely to be interpreted, not to say twisted, based on compromise or political compromise. I would like to remind you, as a Frenchwoman, that article 6 of the declaration of the rights of man and of the citizen, the great declaration of the rights of man and of the citizen of the end of the 18th century, quite simply provides that "the law must be the same for all". As a pro-European Frenchwoman, I would really like the Commission to stick to a reading that does not give any freebies to countries because they are supposed to be big. Greatness consists in respecting one's commitments. Secondly, in this debate - moreover, you have seen the crowds that this brings together in this Parliament - we get the impression that everyone is not speaking to other Europeans but to their own public opinion. We are beginning to witness the evils of a double demagoguery. In some countries, demagoguery consists of insisting on the severity of the application of the rule without worrying about the consequences, and in others there are supporters of flexibility who end up losing sight of the fact that the goal was anyway. to have rules. There has been a great change in Europe between the time when everyone was trying to come and contribute something to the construction of Europe and the one in which we live, where each one practices demagoguery using his own opinion.Therefore, Mr. Vice-President, I cannot encourage you enough to stand firm and take a close look at the laws in matters of finance, even when they conceal a certain number of pitfalls because, in fine, growth andemployment will only come from sound public finances and carried out in a spirit of humanity and flexibility, but without complacency.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, this report represents the first step in yet another cycle of unacceptable economic blackmail against national states and their budgetary policies. The report's content represents yet another anthem to neoliberal policies that have underpinned the austerity imposed on workers and the poor, while the profits of large companies are growing. In Portugal, the October 2015 elections created conditions for a policy change that reversed many measures imposed by the troika, easing austerity. Despite all the pressures, threats of fines, or the suspension of structural funds, this small relief from austerity, with an increase in the minimum wage, pensions, a decrease in the tax burden on labor and, be amazed, with the suspension of privatizations, the Portuguese economy did not sink. Economic growth increases and the public account deficit has improved. Of course, for the European Commission, this matters little, as the economic governance that supports the euro and EMU represents, above all, an instrument designed to impose its neoliberal agenda on workers and peoples.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Mr President, the European Semester programme rolls on year after year, always failing to meet its objectives. Eurozone growth crawls along in the slow lane as usual, 0.3% in the three months to September, 1.6% year on year. The EU-wide figures are slightly better thanks mainly to the UK outperforming its continental partners, this in the face of warnings that a Brexit vote would plunge Britain into immediate recession. During this debate you will focus on many economic indices. I would like you to direct your attention to just one. I will call it the betrayal index because it tracks the lives blighted by youth unemployment. In Britain, with its own currency, the index stands at a bad enough 13%. In most European countries that surrendered their currencies it is far, far worse: 24% in France, 37% in Italy, 43% Spain and Greece. The ideology behind the euro has locked southern Europe into permanent economic stagnation. In these countries, whatever the time of year, it is always the winter semester.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have waited years for a Commissioner to have the courage to come here and say: we are wrong! Europe was wrong: economic policy, monetary policy, foreign policy was wrong. We hoped in vain for that day to come but now we have stopped hoping. So I ask the Commissioner but also all of you: has unemployment decreased in recent years? I'll answer for you: no. Has the public debt gone down? No. Are European citizens richer and more optimistic? No, they are poorer. Have you done anything to combat Islamic terrorism? No. And then we say no to this Europe; let's say no to your crazy policies that have made us invade by thousands of illegal immigrants. I will vote no on December 4th. No to that reform of the Italian Constitution that will make everything up to you, the big business banks, the financial lobbies, the strong powers that command this European "Soviet Union". We want to be free and masters in our own home, not slaves to these Brussels bureaucrats.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr President, the coordination of fiscal policies and joint action in the framework of the European Semester has proved to be more than necessary for the long-term and sustainable development of the European Union. It is important to pursue smart fiscal consolidation, stimulate investment, implement structural reforms and build the single market. There is a lot more room for investment and growth, and a lot of work ahead of all of us, from building a single digital market, an energy union to a stimulating ecosystem for innovation and start-ups. We want an Europe that inspires, that is a role model and a global leader, that grows much more than 1 to 2% per year. It takes more. We need more determined and faster implementation and more togetherness. For example, we are now leaders in the circular economy. But if we don’t accelerate, China and the US will overtake us as new technologies become cheaper and the competitiveness dilemma is resolved. And these countries are faster in passing regulations and adjusting to the market. We lose because of slowness. We need too much time for new regulations that follow new trends, cross-sectoral linkages and new business models. We need too much time for a stronger connection between science and the economy and the implementation of other reforms, crucial for entrepreneurs and innovators. Vice President Dobrovskis, so I'm asking you what do we intend to do in that area?

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, we welcome the Commission's recommendation for a moderately expansionary fiscal stance in the euro area. This is a necessary recommendation that we have been urging for some time. The still too modest performance of the recovery, which remains exposed to international economic and political uncertainty, highlights the risk of a vicious circle, between low growth expectations and low investments, which can compromise the growth potential itself and transform the impact of the crisis from cyclical to structural. A greater role of fiscal policy is needed to stimulate investment, especially if we want to rely less on monetary policy stimulus in the future. To those who speak of excessive loosening of the rules I would like to remind 1) that in recent years the deficit of the euro area has collapsed from 6.2% to 1.5% in a few years; 2) that, if anything, the Commission's recommendation is proof that our rules need to improve, as country-specific recommendations would lead to a lower fiscal stance than the Commission itself deems necessary in the current macroeconomic environment. It is therefore necessary to work for a fiscal capacity of the euro area and improve our rules, starting with a revision of the matrix and the opening of a debate on a differentiated treatment between investments and current expenditure in the stability pact. Parliament will be actively involved in this debate, just as it has contributed to a wise choice that we welcome towards Spain and Portugal. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 149 (8)))

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: blue-card question. – I asked the leader of the Socialist Group earlier today where he had seen that increased deficits and debt burdens had given rise to growth and jobs instead of more austerity, and he really did not give any examples. So maybe I could ask my colleague here where he has seen that an economic strategy with increasing debts and deficits has given rise to growth and jobs, and not to austerity, because in reality this is what we see. Where we have had lax budget policies, we have seen increasing interest rates and rising unemployment.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: blue-card answer. – I would like to mention not only the current US economic policy, but also what Germany did at the beginning of the last decade, when it implemented very ambitious structural reform at the same time as fiscal stimulus, one of the elements at the basis of the current very excellent performance and competitivity of the German economy. Both American and European history give excellent examples, and we do not need to be Keynesian. I do not want to be Keynesian. I want to be pragmatic – as you are – to see that in the current macroeconomic context not to accept any kind of fiscal stimulus is not very logical.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - (The speaker speaks without a microphone) ... Looking at the growth rates of the last ten years: the EU as a whole 1.74%, the euro zone 0.83% or, if you exclude Germany and the Netherlands, 0.57%. It has just been pointed out that all countries outside the euro zone are doing better. Why has unemployment dropped to a record level in Germany? It has never been as low as it is now in the past 25 years. Why do we have satisfactory growth? Why does Mr. Schäuble have a budget surplus? Yes, that's because of the exchange rate. Mr Valli said it: we have an unsustainable exchange rate that is too high for one country and too low for the other. And the consequence would be a devaluation of those countries that cannot stand the strong euro. Instead, we are now making restrictive budgetary policies, restrictive wage policies and restrictive social benefits - that is the consequence. So you try to compensate for the devaluation by destroying the individual countries. This is not the way of the future. I predict for you: we will discuss the same topic again in the same way over the next year, if this euro is still around.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Mr President, the Council, Commission and Parliament have put together new rules for macroeconomic and fiscal coordination within the European Union. I believe these are not the most elegant rules but they are good ones. It is quite important to follow the rules for the time being, instead of trying to find different exemptions, and to explore all possibilities to use the exemptions and flexibility. They do not matter as much as the high level of debt and the deficit because they are, after all, creating great pressure on national budgets, leading to cuts in expenditure, including social expenditure, and an increase in taxation that is harming the economy and increasing unemployment. I believe that, for the time being, it is difficult to argue that an increase in budget deficits will increase economic growth, unlike the good and responsible governance that will create more certainty for economic agents. Last, but not least, let me talk a little about unemployment. Looking at the recent statistics, I can see that five Member States have unemployment below 5%, 12 below 7%, and still seven above 10%. Among all the groups – you can see small states, big states, eurozone members and non-eurozone members, rich and poor – it shows that this is not a matter of a European economic and social model, but is a matter of responsible and good economic policies. We have a lot of inspiration around us and we should just follow them.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President Dombrovskis, it is really extraordinary that some voices from the right in this Parliament question the Commission, even from a legal point of view, for committing this crime of proposing a moderately expansionist fiscal policy, as if the European Union were obliged to eternal austerity. They are the ones who said that the expansionary monetary policy of the European Central Bank violated the mandate, that the suspension of funds for Portugal and Spain was legally mandatory. We know that none of this is true. The question that we must address to the Commission is what is it going to do so that this fiscal policy stance is not just words and corresponds to the reality of policies. The budgets it has just made possible do not guarantee these objectives, the recommendations that the Commission itself issued in July do not guarantee these objectives, so what can the Commission do and will it do so that the expansionary fiscal policy corresponds to the reality of the policies of the Member States? Members.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the European Semester must be credited. This process has to be taken seriously in its multiple dimensions and cannot be used exclusively for political debate, but rather function as a real coordination system at the service of the people. We cannot continue to see contradictory messages that only drive citizens away from European institutions. On Monday you announce sanctions for Member States for non-compliance with the deficit, but on Tuesday they lift those same sanctions, washing their hands of their responsibilities, on Wednesday they praise economic performance, but on Thursday they criticize the sovereign debts, on friday and saturday we are all caught up in statistical projections and, fortunately, on sunday we rested. Commissioner, I am very concerned about this lack of planning, as it is the unemployed, the most disadvantaged and especially the youngest who are going to pay and who are going to be called upon to pay for this lack of a global strategy that only presents us with nice figures in the short term , calling into question the European social model. To achieve the goals of the 2020 Strategy, we must have a real coordination of economic and social indicators and invest in the productivity of our companies, not with a view to increasing working time, but in the construction of new and intelligent ways of working, enhancing the your human capital. Commissioner, let us not lack ambition and courage to move in this direction.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: - Mr President, there are fellow Members who criticize the Semester. I believe that, in a monetary zone, coordinating the rest of the actions is not only adequate, but also highly necessary. But having the instrument, we have to get the policies right, with their orientation and also with their ambition. And I think it is very important, as stated in the Annual Growth Survey presented by the Commission, that it is necessary to carry out a more ambitious fiscal policy, that monetary policy is not enough. But you are missing from your speech, Mr Dombrovskis, something that is essential for me: to have employment at the heart of European policy, not as a consequence, but as an objective, a true objective. We need to increase domestic demand, and it is necessary to increase wages, wages that in the last decade, according to Eurostat data, have seen their purchasing power reduced by more than 10% accumulated. We need to recover the dignity of employment to re-link millions of citizens, of workers, with the essences of their social model, because employment is much more than an economic policy, it is the umbilical cord by which many citizens feel or not part of a society. Let us increase wages, increase the policies that coordinate quality employment and also give a reason for hope, within the framework of the European Semester, to millions of citizens who want employment, but want it of quality and with decent salaries.

name: Peter JAHR
text: -  Mister President! In its paper the Commission speaks of a magic triangle of economic policy and calls on the Member States to invest in these three areas. She understands this to mean promoting investment, continuing structural reforms and ensuring responsible budget policy. I would like to ask the Commission to add a fourth point to the magic triangle, which is to reduce bureaucracy. I mainly speak here as a colleague, a member of parliament for rural areas, and if you look at why some things are not moving forward in rural areas, then it is superficially about small and micro-entrepreneurs. We agree: jobs are created by entrepreneurs, and most small entrepreneurs - if they already have innovative ideas, and they have enough entrepreneurial ideas - then often fail because of the bureaucracy. That means that the effort to get investment funding, the control effort is still far too great. Here you clearly have to start a campaign to reduce bureaucracy in rural areas, because rural areas can only function if regional economic cycles arise. The rural area is characterized by small parts, and it is also characterized by small businesses. We need these companies, we need these ideas, and that simply mustn't get lost in the bureaucratic jungle. So I would like - a little in contrast to previous speakers - to spread the thesis that it does not only fail because of money. Sometimes it also fails due to excessive bureaucratic hurdles.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Mr President, I think it is counterproductive to refer to Brexit and the Trump election as a sign of the times that justifies reconsideration of policies followed on the European Semester rules. These rules were defined technically, even when sometimes they were interpreted politically. They helped prevent a recurrence of 2008 but they have not led to a stable, significant and sustainable recovery in Europe. They failed technically and this is generating a political backlash. Employment remains at historically low levels, economic growth anaemic. Investment has not revived in the public and private sectors. The rules embedded in the European Semester process are the main contributors to this state of affairs. They were defined in a period when the situation was completely different to the one we are in now. The benchmarks they set no longer fit our circumstances. Some of them were anyway set arbitrarily and had no logical or existential justification. The rules themselves were instrumental in driving down public investment. In turn private investment, which piggy-backs on public investment, was negatively affected. What is urgently needed in Europe is a recognition that, independently of Brexit and Trump, the rules set by the Stability and Growth Pact should be revised.

name: Paul TANG
text: - We have one coin.That also requires one policy.I am also pleased that the Commission is looking at the impact of fiscal balances on the euro area as a whole.Is it stabilizing or not?The Commission also concludes and recommends that an additional EUR 50 billion should be spent.This shows that the Commission has embarked on a new course and that is right.Investment expenditure is necessary for economic growth, now and in the future, and the Netherlands and Germany certainly have room.It is a new course that is not followed by everyone.Wolfgang Schäuble has already written an urgent letter and appears to ignore that advice, despite the historically low interest rates.But he is left alone.He is increasingly reminiscent of the old miser Scrooge from Dickens's Christmas story.It will be Christmas soon and I still hope that Wolfgang Schäuble and the hawks will repent.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, of course I welcome the Commission's decision to loosen the grip a little to support growth. It is clear that the fact of giving up sanctioning Spain or Portugal, for example, will allow these countries to start off on a better footing. Nevertheless, several expert reports tell us that, to return to the level of growth before the crisis, we will still need many years, the recovery is only timidly expected for 2018. Therefore, calling for a expansionary fiscal policy in the euro zone, we obviously hope that this will allow a faster and more substantial recovery of the economy. This is what President Barack Obama said last October. What we are still experiencing today is the result of austerity measures that have been taken in the past by the European Union. The proof is that today the Americans have followed seven years of growth, while Europe is still facing a weak and fragile economic recovery. Easing austerity measures must therefore go hand in hand with a public investment plan that is more ambitious than the plan proposed by the Commission. The Juncker plan is certainly an important first step, but it must be accompanied by a productive public investment plan worthy of the name, if we really want to revive the economy and support businesses.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - When considering the adoption of the decision on the European Semester package, including the 2017 Annual Growth Survey, the question of whether the current rules of the Stability and Growth Pact are being applied effectively and whether the link between structural reforms, investment and fiscal responsibility has been strengthened is very important. . The rise in economic growth in the euro area is still too low to speak of the much-needed increase in job creation, especially for young people. It will be necessary to promote the implementation of structural reforms more effectively, to encourage investment, in particular under the new European Fund for Strategic Investments, and to take better account of the economic cycle in individual Member States. In the group of countries where there is a risk of non-compliance of the budget plan for 2017 with the rules, in addition to Slovenia, Belgium, Italy, Cyprus, Lithuania and Finland are also from the preventive phase. The risks of non-compliance are also identified by the Commission in Spain and Portugal. At the end of 2015, the consolidated gross debt of the Slovenian government amounted to EUR 32 billion, or 83% of gross domestic product. Such a high public debt certainly cannot contribute to increasing new jobs and boosting the economy.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I will begin my remarks with two key words: social responsibility. If Europe's policy is not subordinated to this need, we will not have the chance to remain a united Europe, we will not be able to be competitive in the global market. Mr Stiglitz scientifically explained to us that the 3% deficit threshold and the 60% government debt were taken from the air. There is no calculation to show that 3% is the optimal threshold. I worked in industry and I know what deficit means, I know what investment means. When you make investments you need to increase the deficit. However, it is important to make operative and intelligent investments, which will cover your deficit in the next stage. This is the key to solving it, ensuring jobs, quality of life. We need to stimulate SMEs, rural development and agriculture. Commissioner, financial responsibility is also needed. Tax evasion and all deductions from payments to the budget must be pursued. But we need institutions to support the euro, because otherwise we cannot coordinate 19 states with the same currency.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe's fragile recovery over the past year, with GDP back to pre-crisis levels, must not be misleading: unemployment and poverty levels remain too high in many regions 'Europe and the levels of inequality reduce the potential for growth. I do not share President Juncker's call for states with less fiscal space to pursue growth-friendly fiscal consolidation. Putting limits on investment for growth in some states and allowing them fully in others will only increase economic disparities within the European Union. I take the example of my country, Italy, which has experienced two very serious earthquakes in the last year and which each year allocates around 6 billion euros of its budget to immigration: adopt the same economic recipe for all Member States, without taking into account the peculiarities of each of them and their particular historical period, it does not mean to err but to persevere in error, which is diabolical.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, the Commission is dogmatically pursuing a policy of deepening, neoliberalism and austerity, ignoring the fact that it is leading large sections of the population to impoverishment. How else to perceive the dithyrambs in the employment comments included in the European Semester package? Obviously for the Commission it is a success to prosper the numbers and not the citizens. Inequality is rising in the South. Poverty affects more than 20% of the population, while this percentage is 27.3% in Spain, 28.5% in Italy, 27.8% in Cyprus, 37.5% in Greece. At the same time, youth unemployment continues to skyrocket. In the above countries the percentage of unemployed young people exceeds 30%. More tragic is the case of Greece where the percentage of unemployed young people reaches 52.4%. The policies of austerity and the memoranda of the European Semester are nothing more than a ruthless attack on the workers and on the sovereignty of the peoples of the Union.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank you very much for this debate on the European Semester and to recall, really, that the main aim of the European Semester and the economic policy priorities which we are setting within the Semester is to strengthen the EU’s economic recovery and make it more sustainable.  That is why we need to see the measures we are taking as a package of measures and not just pick one or another or a third element and discuss that without an overall context. That is why I would re-emphasise that there is a triangle of measures, a triangle of priorities, which we are proposing and all of those priorities are important: namely, to facilitate investment, to pursue structural reforms to modernise our economies, and to continue with responsible fiscal policies. And all of those elements are important if we are to ensure sustainable economic recovery. Something which is also important in the context of the European Semester is ownership by the Member States. That is why we need to have a deeper engagement with the Member States, but also with the social partners and other stakeholders in Member States so that we really see that our policies are followed through. And nowhere will we see it better than in the context of the implementation of country-specific recommendations. There have been many debates, also in this Parliament, on the level of implementation of country-specific recommendations. We discussed it last month and once again we see somewhere between limited and some progress in implementation. So certainly more work is needed in this regard. Then a number of questions were asked on the Communication on a positive fiscal stance for the euro area, including its legal basis. And there I would just reiterate what is said in the Communication itself, and which I also outlined in the introductory statements, namely that such orientation should build on the legal framework set by the Stability and Growth Pact and take into account broader fiscal sustainability concerns.  This is something which is very clearly outlined in the Communication itself, so the main logic is indeed that those Member States which are in excessive deficit will still need to pursue the adjustment path towards medium-term budgetary objectives in the preventive arm of the Stability and Growth Pact and should continue to do so, whereas those Member States which have fiscal space should utilise it to stimulate the demand side of the economy and in particular to stimulate investment. So that is the overall logic of this proposal. A number of other questions were raised, including on how to motivate Member States, and I think once again that this motivation is first and foremost with engagement of Member States and strengthening their ownership on quality of public spending. This is something we also agree on and underline in our Communication: that the quality of public spending is as important as its quantity. A question was raised on climate change objectives. This is also reflected, for example, through our work on investment, on the European Structural Investment Fund where 20% is now earmarked for sustainable – sustainable from an elemental point of view – development on reducing bureaucracy. This is also an important work strand which we are pursuing, among other things, through our REFIT initiative and a number of sector-specific simplification proposals which we are putting forward. So once again, when we are working we always have to keep our mind on the main goal: to strengthen Europe’s economic recovery and to make it more sustainable. And I am looking forward to constructive cooperation with this Parliament towards the next steps of the European Semester.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I am glad to see that the European Commission is, slowly, but I hope with a sure step, changing economic policy, adapting it to the real needs of the Union. I hope that the European Semester 2017 package will be the first step of many in this regard. On the one hand, it has recognized, thanks to the efforts of the European Parliament, that structural funds should not be suspended for Spain and Portugal. The opposite would not only have been irresponsible, but profoundly unfair to a citizenry that has already suffered the unspeakable. On the other hand, the Commission is finally moving to an expansionary fiscal policy for the euro zone, asking countries with budget surpluses for more investment. And an even stronger bet is made on the Investment Plan. But unfortunately something essential is still missing: the creation of quality employment with decent wages. We need to increase domestic demand, and for this we must increase wages which, in the last decade, according to Eurostat, have seen their purchasing power reduced by more than 10%. Only by putting the fight against inequalities at the heart of the European Semester can we build a stronger and more social Europe under the rubble of populism and austerity.
