name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - Increasing competitiveness and developing the economy requires stimulating investment. The Commission's investment plan envisaged the mobilization of additional investment of at least EUR 315 billion over three years and the return of investment to pre-crisis levels. Although the Commission is trying to prove the success of the European Fund for Strategic Investments, I think it is important to emphasize that the Fund raises a number of issues. On the one hand, in the case of all financial resources and financial instruments, so-called outsourced from the EU budget, the control powers of the EU institutions are reduced, and the possible market-distorting effects are not known. On the other hand, the conditions and criteria for obtaining funds are much more opaque compared to other areas of implementation, which is only further strengthened by the reference to bank secrecy. Furthermore, the Investment Fund’s approach is strictly focused on the financial return of projects, ignoring broader or indirect socio-economic-political aspects. I consider it essential to improve the investment climate to support European investment. We need to increase the predictability of the regulatory environment, expand and diversify funding sources, reduce administrative burdens and identify further challenges that are the main obstacles to investment recovery.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Since the crisis, investment data have shown a very different picture. Unfortunately, the discussion of the proposals for the semester has shown that investment remains hampered by both regulatory and non-regulatory challenges. That is why it is important to mention that the identification and removal of investment barriers are in any case part of the efforts to improve the framework conditions and to reduce administrative barriers and regulatory bottlenecks. I welcome the fact that, in this cycle, the European Commission has once again begun to identify policy areas and instruments that can provide an overview of the main challenges hindering investment at national level. However, I also believe that the analysis of the challenges identified in the Annual Growth Survey must continue in the context of the European Semester. I believe that it is time to re-launch a dialogue with the Member States, including in the form of thematic discussions within the Council and Council committees, in order to identify these challenges and possible steps and measures to overcome them, otherwise the European Semester process will not he will be able to fulfill the role we intended for him in his creation.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - I welcome the fundamental thrust for the economic policy direction 2017. The Commission is increasingly recognizing that the austerity course that has been strictly pursued up to now is a neoliberal wrong path. According to the Commission's plans, social justice and investment should be a priority for the next year. But nice words are not enough: behind the right analysis for the euro area there is still the wrong rule-based policy. More investment cannot work if the countries continue to have to adhere to the strict rules of the Stability Pact. In order to stimulate the economy, investments in the future, such as spending on education, must no longer be subject to strict fiscal rules. We cannot save ourselves from the crisis. Neither can we stimulate demand when wages are stagnating. Across Europe, wages must grow at the same rate as productivity and inflation. What is needed is an economic policy direction for the Union that is not based on rigid growth rates. Instead, the well-being of the population must be brought to the fore.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Emmanuel Maurel, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards access to anti-money-laundering information by tax authorities (COM(2016)0452 – C8—0333/2016 – 2016/0209(CNS)) (A8—0326/2016).

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, taxes have been the adjustment variable for too long for those, individuals and multinationals, who benefit from globalization. States, too, for too long have looked away from what we might call "a tax hit-and-run". The international financial system but also commercial relations - we have often spoken of it here - are riddled with gigantic flows of money laundering and tax evasion. The two phenomena often use the same channels, and only great efforts in terms of transparency make it possible to fight against these scourges for public revenues. It is precisely this spirit that has guided the reform project we are debating today. First, a substantial improvement will be made to European policy in this area with the new directive against money laundering and the financing of terrorism. It will provide new tools, among which - and it was eagerly awaited - a central and comprehensive register of all beneficial owners of companies and trusts. This information will be collected in each state by specific intelligence units. For the sake of clarity and efficiency that we, parliamentarians, share, the Commission, in the person of Pierre Moscovici - whose never-ending efforts with parliamentarians I welcome here to try to fight against this scourge of tax evasion - , considered that the tax authorities of each State should have direct and horizontal access to this data, and in particular to the central register that I mentioned earlier. It is therefore this measure which is being debated today and which will be implemented within the framework of the Union's administrative cooperation directive. The initiative deserves to be supported. It goes without saying that our tax administrations, in the context of their investigations, must be able to have direct access to the information necessary for their investigations. With the colleagues of the ECON committee, we wanted to guarantee this achievement, but we want to add an additional point. In the unanimous opinion, and as the Commission itself admits in its communications, faced with these essentially globalized phenomena, the most effective weapon for us is the automatic and compulsory exchange of information between the states. I wanted, along with all the shadow rapporteurs whom I thank here, that we propose the sharing of information between European states. A very simple example makes it possible to represent the stake which is capital. To prosecute cases of tax evasion by French or German taxpayers, for example, the tax authorities in our countries have a crucial need to know if they are hiding behind trusts or letterbox companies in another Member State. It is therefore important that this other Member State has access to this information and gives it to France or Germany. Only in this way will we be able to fight effectively, of course, against tax evasion. This project therefore also makes the reform consistent with its instrument, the administrative cooperation directive, which is an instrument for sharing information between States. So much for progress, this is what we offer you. I would still add one last point. In tax matters, as you know, it is always the Council which has the last word. As much as the Twenty-eight have a hard time agreeing on a generous policy of welcoming migrants, when it comes to taxation, the members of the Council systematically manage to take a position before the Parliament of so as to neglect our opinion and the position of MEPs. I think this has to stop and, if the vote is as unanimous as possible - that is what I want - then we will send a clear message to the Council. It's time to reaffirm in front of our fellow citizens, who are legitimately scandalized by what is happening with tax evasion cases, that we want to make this fight for a fairer redistribution an absolute priority.Thank you, dear colleagues, and thank you also to the shadow rapporteurs who have helped us so much.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, Rapporteur Emmanuel Maurel, Ladies and Gentlemen, First of all allow me to address my very sincere congratulations to the rapporteur and to all those who were involved in the elaboration of this report because the work that has been done was very fast, it is of very high quality and it will allow very great progress. It is clear from the public debate, as was said by Emmanuel Maurel in his introduction, that fairness, equal treatment and social justice are very strong demands of our fellow citizens, both at the national level and at the national level. European level. Taxation is one of the areas where justice is absolutely necessary. This is even truer after the recent scandals that we have known - I am thinking of the most recent ones, the Panama papers or the Bahamas Leaks -, which revealed that, despite the progress that we have made, particularly in terms of tax transparency , tax evaders and anyone looking to evade taxes can still hide behind the opacity of offshore structures and trusts to circumvent the rules and to avoid any taxation, which is simply odious for our fellow citizens today . This Commission, as you mentioned - I thank you for having underlined it, Mr Rapporteur - has taken a step that I would describe as gigantic in terms of taxation by presenting and having adopted concrete proposals to improve transparency. and the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion, both for individuals and companies. The Union has made transparency its standard. We are pioneers in the implementation of international standards. I was talking about this last night with the Secretary General of the OECD, Mr Gurría, and all of our Member States are committed to these new initiatives. After the automatic exchange of financial data, this referred to as DAC 2, tax rulings, DAC 3, and country-by-country reports, DAC 4, the next barrier to break down is transparency in terms of beneficial owners. This will be DAC 5. The G20 also recognizes this and called for action on this. The information on beneficial owners that we are talking about today is essential in the fight against corruption and its corollary, money laundering. The directive that is on the table allows us to move forward. Once adopted, it will give tax authorities the much needed access to information on the beneficial owners of these opaque structures and trusts with little-known activities. The tax authorities of each Member State will be able to access the data which is currently collected under European anti-money laundering rules, in particular the information resulting from customer due diligence obligations and the information contained in the national registers of beneficial owners. With access to this information, tax authorities will be able to identify who is actually behind an opaque company or structure and respond quickly to situations of tax fraud and evasion. This access will allow a real leap forward in cross-border tax cooperation within the European Union and will give a valuable tool to the Member States which need it to protect the integrity of their tax systems and to fight against fraud and schemes. of tax evasion. I now come to the report by Mr Maurel and the amendments adopted by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. It is truly an excellent report which recognizes the directive as a major step in the advancement of our fight and I welcome it greatly. This report proposes a number of amendments. I come back briefly on some of them without being exhaustive, in the first place to underline that, in many cases, the Commission fully agrees with the suggested developments. Secondly, we believe that the objectives pursued by certain amendments would be better addressed in the context of other initiatives. I will take two examples, if I may, Mr Rapporteur. Several of you have called for further extending the scope of this directive and making it even more ambitious. I therefore particularly note the request to provide, as of now, for an automatic exchange of information on the beneficial owners. Like you, I consider that fraudsters exploit our internal borders and therefore that transparency must apply beyond our borders. In its communication of 5 July, the Commission therefore undertook to examine how cross-border access to national information of Member States on the beneficial owners of trust companies can be done and this, in complete security. This issue will be covered by a separate proposal, as soon as more information is available on the G5 pilot project and taking into account international developments. In this perspective, it will also - this is my second remark - to take into account the result of the discussions on the proposed revision of the fourth anti-money laundering directive which already includes the interconnection of the registers of beneficial owners in the European Union. . These remarks do not call into question most of the amendments but suggest an approach which, in the same spirit, with the same objective, may be a little different or which, in any case, uses complementary vehicles. Our work is far from over. In reality, it never will be, but we must be in the race because the imagination of those who want to defraud or those who practice planning aggressive tax does not stop.You know my personal commitment, my conviction: it is that this revolution of transparency in which we are only just beginning.The Commission welcomes and I personally welcome the constant support of the European Parliament, its determined action on these issues of transparency and the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion.Together, I believe that we are really making things happen in an area where our fellow citizens see both the need and the usefulness of Europe.In these complicated times, there aren't that many.All the more reason to continue and pull this thread to the end.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Stronger cooperation and enforceable international agreements are the only effective answer to the fears that globalization and internationalization have unleashed. Only then will we be able to protect our way of life and our social welfare states. I am really convinced of that. A good example of this is taxation. Only by working together can we close the net around tax evaders and tax havens and tackle aggressive tax planning. In recent years, the realization also seemed to have grown at a global level that there should at least be limits to the cutthroat tax competition with which countries steal each other's income, but with Trump as future tax evader in chief and the British in Brexit rules the waves mode, the international movement to an abrupt end. That is precisely why the European Union must assume its responsibility and fully assume its role in tax cooperation and transparency, both at a global level and within our own internal market. Today's bill fills a small but important gap in existing cooperation on tax matters between Member States and will help to expose opaque Panama Papers intermediates. Yet much more is needed to bring about real tax justice within the European Union. I am thinking, first of all, of the common list of tax havens. It must absolutely not become a watered-down compromise and must be accompanied by real sanctions. Second, I am thinking of the taxable corporate tax base. It must be harmonized within Europe. Third, the race to the bottom on corporate tax rates must be stopped. Mr President, colleagues, democracy is under pressure at all policy levels, both supranational and national, due to increased inequality and division in our western societies.Please let us not kid ourselves that we are going to settle that discontent with the old national recipes of tax sovereignty that we shoot at each other's pigeons until there is nothing left to redistribute and policy.(The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the "blue card" procedure.- Dear colleague, first of all I want to emphasize that we have a good report here and I agree with what our rapporteur said.But you, among other things, have said that we must limit taxation.Do I agree with the fight against evasion, but I do not understand how you want to limit taxation as long as, in the context of subsidiarity, the tax issue belongs to the Member States?Maybe you can explain.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: "blue card" answer.- Above all, I would like to emphasize that in Europe we all need to work much more closely together.The priority of the European Commission, but also of us as the European Parliament, now lies in drawing up the common list of tax havens, linking sanctions to this list and to that CCCTB.The next discussion that could ever be held may indeed be about imposing a limit, but then we have to agree on that here in this Parliament.The member states themselves, who may decide on this with unanimity, must also be able to reach an agreement on this.

name: Peter SIMON
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President! First of all, I would also like to thank our rapporteur for a really meaningful report which clearly highlights the importance of transparency in this field. Transparency: One of the main demands, as we have called in the results of the TAXE special committees on Lux Leaks, as we are now calling for in the Panama Papers Committee of Inquiry. But we will only achieve transparency in this area if we structure the exchange of information about the beneficial owners of companies in such a way that it is actually clear in all Member States who owns a company. I understand, Commissioner Moscovici, that you are referring to the revision of the fourth money laundering directive, but that does not help us at the moment. We don't know if it will come in this form and how it will come when. I am with you that if we have a network of business registers, an automatic exchange of information may no longer be necessary. But that's just a maybe. We should therefore insist at this point in the procedure that we come to an automatic exchange of information on the beneficial owners of companies between the Member States. Because if you do not commit to anything here, then, I predict, the same thing will happen as happened with the question of the exchange of information on tax rulings of multinational companies. For decades, the member states were obliged to exchange the information. Did you do it? They never did. Only the obligation to exchange moves member states to provide each other with information - information that is necessary to combat tax fraud, information that is necessary and imperative to combat money laundering. So we should be more ambitious at this point. So we should try To oblige Member States to do so too.Because only transparency guarantees us that we will achieve more fairness in the tax area, less money laundering, and anyone who weakens transparency is playing into the shadow economy, money laundering.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr President, the Commission's proposal for a new anti-money laundering directive is a good one, as is Mr Maurel's draft report. However, I would like to draw attention to two things. Firstly, trusts, the importance of which has already been recognized in previous speeches, which is very good. It seems that there are still loopholes in the proposal, such as the possibility of marking business leaders as owners if the real owners are not known. In addition, it would continue to be possible to hide holdings through trusts if their trustees are, for example, in Panama or other non-EU tax havens. My second concern relates to the ownership of listed shares, which has been discussed too little in the fight against money laundering. Many EU countries use nominee registers for share ownership, where the identification of beneficial owners depends entirely on the banks that manage them. In addition, it is often possible to use remote brokers as intermediaries, which may be located in other EU countries. When these remotes through remote brokers are chained, there is an increased risk that identifying the true owners will not work as it should. The best option is a direct share ownership model, where shareholders are registered in a centralized public register. Work should be done to make this a pan-European model.

name: Nils TORVALDS
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Mr Vice-President Moscovici, best rapporteur! We have before us a reasonably decent report which our group will support, but at the same time I cannot help but point out that if the Commission and the Council had listened to Parliament two years ago when this subject was last discussed, we would have been much longer. in this question. Then I can not help but point out that this proposal came from the Commission after the terrorist attacks in Paris. At that stage, the Commission either had no idea or did not want to know that we actually have a serious money laundering problem in Europe. One of the holes through which money slips is actually about casinos, especially casinos in the southern parts of Europe. Between 60 and 80 percent of the money that rolls into the casinos, we have no idea where they actually come from. When we also know that those who manage the gaming tables have a share in the amount of money that goes through the casino, we understand that there is also no greater desire to control where the money comes from. For that reason, I believe that the Commission should take a serious look at the money laundering, at the illegal transactions, that are actually taking place in our casino world. All effective action in this sense will not succeed if we do not address these issues. Then I think that in another respect we are a bit on the wrong path, or in the wrong order. When we have finalized the report on the so-called Panama Papers, we may have another reason to return to this matter.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group - Mr President, we naturally support all measures aimed at better access to information and better cooperation between the tax administrations of national states. In this sense, the inclusion of the entire information collection typified in the framework of the fight against money laundering in terms of administrative cooperation represents a positive step. We underline, however, that it seems essential to us that this information is exchanged automatically for this change to actually have practical effects. Regarding the fight against money laundering, however, it is important not to entertain illusions. In our opinion, it is not possible to combat this phenomenon by relying only on the due diligence duties of private companies and the financial system. As has been criticized by many organizations, the results of the fight against money laundering have been residual over the past few decades. This is due to the conflicts of interest of the entities that are responsible for reporting suspicious movements; this is due to money laundering and the legal instruments that were developed by developed countries in the name of liberalizing the economy; so it is, finally, because the big financial groups, those too big to fail and where the overwhelming majority of legal and illegal funds go, actually rule national governments and European institutions. In other words, money laundering, as well as tax evasion and fraud, are one of the visible faces of the liberal economy and the capitalist system. In this sense, the recovery of public control over banks and the financial system is also an indispensable condition for a more effective fight against these phenomena as well as for a better functioning of the economy.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, last week Nobel Prize-winning winning economist Professor Joseph Stiglitz gave evidence to our Panama Papers Inquiry Committee and he was also kind enough to spend some time meeting informally with a group of Green MEPs and staff. He was very clear about the importance of ensuring that corporations pay their fair share of tax, but also about the fact that there are still many obstacles in our way, the most obvious being continued secrecy and the jurisdictions that offer this to the rich and powerful.  The Anti-Money-Laundering Directive is key to tackling not just tax avoidance but the web of secrecy, money-laundering and criminal activity that is perpetuated by secrecy jurisdictions, such as the various UK overseas territories whose hidden activity was revealed in the Panama Papers. The revision to the Directive on Administrative Cooperation with regard to anti-money-laundering information that we are debating here today is therefore very welcome. I am pleased that we have cross-party agreement on this file and that Parliament has agreed that the Commission should have been more ambitious in its proposal.  While this revision to the directive is an important step forward, we believe that there continue to be several loopholes that could be used by tax-dodging experts to circumvent the automatic exchange of information, thereby undermining its effectiveness. As an example, synthetic tax residence certificates are readily available in countries such as Panama and the Bahamas to avoid reporting to the Union authority. To counter this, any previous residence in the EU within the last 10 years should be deemed as an indication of current residence, and a tax clearance certificate should be used to establish actual residence.  I welcome the fact that we have agreed on a strong and united position from this Parliament on the automatic exchange of information between Member States’ tax authorities, as well as our Green call for the Commission to have access to the information exchanged. We emphasise to the Council and Commission our clear view that making the information readily available in this way increases our ability to fight tax fraud.  I am delighted that we have agreed a strong and united position. I hope we will now progress towards making all such tax information public, as well as ensuring that the whistleblowers whom we currently rely on to cast light into the dark corners of the world’s financial system will be properly protected.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the revision of the directive by the European institutions is good but it is still not enough to combat, in my opinion, the problem of money laundering, corruption and tax avoidance efficiently. In my opinion, we need to act on two key points to implement coherent legislation. The first point - some colleagues have already reiterated - is that sharing information is not enough to combat this problem but it must become an obligation, otherwise the States will never implement it. The second point is fundamental: we must understand the preponderant role of the banking system in facilitating this type of criminal behavior. Until we increase control over banking transactions and the banking system and we do not have a system of common and heavy sanctions at European level, which go as far as the withdrawal of the license, we will not solve this problem. The scandals of recent years have invited us to act and this is our task. Well the directive as a first step but it is not enough. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 149 (8)))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – You mentioned the non-obligation to exchange this kind of information and I truly agree with you. But you know the tax administration’s access to anti-money laundering information differs considerably throughout the European Union. Do you not think it might be time for the European Commission to standardise this exchange of information?

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Absolutely: it is necessary.It is necessary to impose a common standard for this information exchange obligation.However, a major problem that the Commission must solve at the same time is the budget available to local tax administrations: that is, very often national tax administrations do not have the resources or the staff necessary to process this type of information.And this is also the fault of the austerity that is imposed, in some cases, on government and state administrations.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the Maurel report has the merit of showing the will of the European Union to fight against tax evasion. In particular, I endorse its objective of improving the exchange of information between the tax authorities of the Member States. However, I doubt that the fight against tax evasion is really a top priority for the Union, as the report claims. In fact, it was not until repeated scandals involving Commissioners or former Commissioners that the Union began to move: SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers, BahamasLeaks, while waiting for the next soap opera Brussels Papers or TurkishLeaks. As for the European Central Bank, it should not be counted on to supervise the morality of banks, because the European Court of Auditors has just revealed that it is in the grip of serious conflicts of interest. In this regard, it is surreal that Amendment 9 of the report asks the Commission to analyze - and I quote - "the possible role played by the banking system in facilitating money laundering". The involvement of the banks is not a hypothesis but a certainty revealed by the Panama Papers scandal. As for entrusting their surveillance to the Commission, that amounts to entrusting the wolves to their pack leader. In this regard, I will end by recalling that in response to the question I asked last week in Brussels, the Nobel laureate in economics Joseph Stiglitz described Jean-Claude Juncker as "the architect of tax evasion in Europe".

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, it is quite right that we have measures that prevent terrorist funds being used to terrorise the citizens of Europe. It is also quite right that governments should seek to prevent aggressive tax avoidance and that is why we have international organisations working on both money laundering and tax avoidance.  These proposals include provisions that make banks and financial institutions give information to tax authorities. These proposals therefore make banks an extension of the tax authorities, i.e. their police. Furthermore, the creation of lists of European citizens’ assets is very concerning to those who believe in independence and freedom and liberty of the individual. It reminds me a little bit of the quote by the Irish writer C. S. Lewis: ‘the safest road to hell is the gradual one – the gentle slope, soft underfoot, without sudden turning, without milestones, without signposts’. My concern here is that there are no provisions in this directive or in the legislation that we seek that stop phishing exercises by tax authorities against legitimate individuals. There are no provisions here to prevent privacy being taken away bit by bit and slowly but surely. We must all seek to prevent money laundering and aggressive tax evasion but it must not be at the expense of the privacy and liberty of individuals doing absolutely nothing wrong.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Madam President. Colleagues! Across Europe, we have a problem or challenge with so-called offshore. Offshore is a way for individuals to hide their income. Either to launder illicit funds, or to finance terrorism, or simply to avoid paying fair taxes. We have adopted a law - a Europe-wide law - a directive that will establish a so-called register of true beneficiaries, which will show which individuals are behind any company throughout the European Union. This is a very serious tool that will help in the fight against this illegal money. But, colleagues, we must also remember that when we fight money laundering, when we fight terrorist financing and when we fight tax evasion, we must always put weight in the cups - what are we doing to promote this fight? , but so that we do not unnecessarily violate the individual 's right to privacy. It is nowhere written where this line should be drawn, but it is important to understand that we must always put it in the weight cups. Because at the same time we need to make illegal activity even more difficult, we must ensure that it is not easy to evade taxes, but we cannot enter that second ditch, i. that is, simply openly ignore, say, the interests of the 99% of the population who are really honest and do everything the way it should. Thank you for your attention!

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Madam President, I would like to reiterate to Mr Moscovici the support of all socialists for an agenda to fight against tax evasion as ambitious as the one that is being launched. As a result of the Luxleaks scandal, I would like to remind you, ladies and gentlemen, the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings, country-by-country reports, has been introduced; It has been proposed to limit the abuse of transfer pricing to ensure that profits are taxed where they occur; and, finally, the harmonization of the corporate tax base has been resumed. It is a very ambitious agenda, certainly, and this directive that we are dealing with today with the report that Mr Maurel has presented to us aims to guarantee the access of tax administrations to the information handled by financial institutions. But up to here, so to speak, my compliments, Mr. Moscovici. I would also like to point out to you some reproaches that I think this directive, in particular, lacks. In the first place, in my opinion, a series of exceptions to the automatic exchange of information survive in this Directive, which in my opinion are not justified since the Luxleaks and Panama Papers scandals and in the context of the social alarm that everyone is experiencing. the world. Secondly, I believe that the list of agents that intervene in the information must be expanded, because it is not only the banks, there are many financial agents, notaries, a lot of civil organizations that also have to intervene in this information. And finally, it must be remembered that so many reforms to the Directive on administrative cooperation would require a recast text, that it is time to do so. I need to remember that the Council has to issue an opinion on this matter and should not leave the European Commission aside in this matter of fiscal coordination.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Those who hide their property obviously have something to hide. We have now seen it in the Panama Papers, we have seen it in the Lux Leaks scandal, we have seen it in the Bahamas Papers, that some citizens go to every possible effort to hide their property and to disguise their income. We know that illegal activity, money laundering, terrorist financing, mafia business, and tax evasion use exactly these types of mechanisms. We have to do something about that. The rule of law is challenged here, when one sees the efforts being made to hide income and property from - even just the view - of the tax authorities. It is therefore right for the European Parliament to take action here, and it is therefore right that this automatic exchange of information should be called for. Because we can no longer accept that large amounts of money are evaded for the legitimate purposes that the state wants to fulfill with them. I therefore ask all of you to support this report. I think it is a good initiative and it is not that often that such good initiatives come from the European Parliament.

name: Cora van NIEUWENHUIZEN
text: Much of the most terrible things in this world are linked to money laundering and cannot even live without it. Whether it concerns terrorist financing, drug trafficking, people smuggling: they all use money laundering. That is why it is very good that Mr Maurel has written this report and that the European Commissioner has made this proposal in order to at least take a step towards the exchange of information on this between tax authorities. After all, we must do everything we can to stop money laundering. This must of course be done in an international context. The working conditions for the Commission have not improved in this regard, but I would nevertheless appeal to the Commissioner to show in the Panama Papers that it is necessary and yet to do his utmost to be able to tackle this again internationally, because only in Europe we cannot make it. However, there are other shortcuts I would like to point out. I am very pleased that in the ECON Committee my amendment has been adopted, which provides for the scope to be extended also to the so-called virtual currencies. After all, there are now so many billions in circulation in digital currencies such as bitcoin, of which, for example, more than 10 billion are in circulation this year alone. So you want to prevent criminals from now being able to use the anonymous bitcoins and all kinds of other currencies to escape again. After all, it's not just about the bitcoin: you also have litecoin, peercoin, namecoin, quarkcoin, Zcash and even, you don't believe it, dogecoin. The name alone should raise eyebrows. I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to take this over.

name: Rina Ronja KARI
text: - Madam President! If there is one thing that we have learned from the many revelations about tax havens, it is that tax havens and money laundering are best in the dark. They live best hidden from the public. We therefore also know that one of our strongest cards against tax evasion and against money laundering is openness and publicity about tax matters and not least about ownership. The proposal we are voting on today is a good thing, it should be welcomed. There should be no doubt that we must provide the tax authorities with all the best tools to investigate and stop tax havens and money laundering, but unfortunately we still need to rectify a number of important elements. Here we should first and foremost look at giving the public access to information about who the real owners of the companies are. After all, it is the public that has been the driving force in uncovering the major tax havens. Our welfare is suffering from the lack of payments and it is time to get beyond the steppes with effective tools. Today's proposal is fine, but it does not in itself solve the problems.

name: Werner LANGEN
text: - Madam President! I would first like to praise the rapporteur - he has presented a good report - but I would also like to thank the Commissioner for taking the initiative after two decades of stagnation and, in particular, fighting for more transparency in tax matters. Transparency is the key to more fair taxation and more tax honesty. That is why I would like to ask you, Commissioner, to press for the automatic exchange of information. That is the most important tool. You just didn't fully endorse that. I know that the Member States block this - for whatever reason - probably because they themselves have something to hide with their own tax rules. But it is urgently necessary to automate this exchange of information and thus enable first access and not just make it available on request. However, I would also like to ask the Commission to be a little more progressive in evaluating the money laundering directive. The two institutions that do the evaluation only check whether the laws have been implemented, they do not check whether implementation is progressing. It is the same with the black lists on behalf of the Commission - the Commission is a member of the Financial Action Task Force, and the Commission is therefore involved itself. I hope that more initiative will be taken there to finally get the Member States on the right track.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam  President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for an excellent report. For too long we have seen in many countries and globally a blind eye turned to tax evasion and money laundering: crimes that make up the dark web of our current system used for terror finance, organised crimes by corrupt people and organised criminals.  Therefore we need transparency. Transparency is key. We need automatic cooperation between our tax authorities and our law enforcement authorities, and we need to exchange information of high quality. But secondly, we also need to see our banks and all intermediaries take responsibility for their own operations and businesses. The banks carry out due diligence and they need to be a barrier to illegal economic activities that they have been facilitating, without any real consequences to their business, for too long. Let me give one example. In 2015 Nordea Bank in Sweden was fined the maximum administrative fine of only EUR 5 million after ‘major deficiencies’ were found in the bank’s work to prevent money laundering. In the same year Nordea made a high profit, many times the fine that they actually got. So I want to thank the rapporteur for underlining two key principles: exchange of anti—money-laundering information between our tax authorities needs to be mandatory and automatic and we need to step up the fight against this.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - It is not the first time that we in this Parliament are talking about illegal tax evasion and tax avoidance. On the contrary, we have talked about it many times. It is my sincere belief that if we choose more transparency, more cooperation, more information exchange, we can fight that battle and that we can also win that battle. The Ministers of Finance, including our Minister of Finance Johan Van Overtveldt, have already taken a decision on the file before us. They have an agreement about this directive. That is an excellent thing, because from 2018 the tax authorities will be able to obtain additional information, information from services that are engaged in combating money laundering. That is very important, because those are exactly the means, that is the funding that is used for major crimes, including terror. It is therefore excellent that the tax authorities will also be able to consult this information. Finally, we do have some questions about some of the latest amendments that are being tabled here in this Parliament, but this is a good proposal. This is an excellent thing in principle.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: - Madam President, Mr Moscovici, my speech will be mainly political because my colleagues have already appreciated the gaps, the weaknesses, but also the benefits of a text, which, without a doubt, my group and I are going to support. Because it is a text that is necessary in the short term. It is a minimal text, at least, and it meets one of the great requests of society. And that's where I wanted to go. Look at you, on this issue of avoidance, tax evasion, all the issues related to that, but, above all, also money laundering, even the democratic system itself is putting its credibility at risk. And that is where an ambition to go much further is lacking. Cooperation will not be long enough and it is also very imperfect. You have to force it, automate it and start thinking about making a tax system, a comprehensive and integrated tax surveillance, above voluntary exchange. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member!I very much agree with you when you say that there is a need for integrated supervision, because I myself think that there are not only companies or evil companies, evil advisers and evil banks in this picture, but - I say now without a sign - certainly tax authorities.and many times governments are also involved in this whole round of tax evasion.And my question is, do you think that this current report addresses this aspect, and therefore the negative role of tax authorities and governments?

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: "blue card" response.- Let's see, it is a small first step, which is based too much on the good will of the States.The goodwill of the States does not exist when, for example, in tax resolutions what we do is camouflage the law, saying: "Well, we are going to make the agreements verbal so as not to have to transmit written agreements."So it is a small step insufficient, but at the moment, let's at least do this.Let us never lose the north: in the end it will have to be a supranational entity that ensures full validity.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, the proposal for a directive on the access of tax authorities to information on combating money laundering is now more relevant than ever. As we have spent several years in the vortex of the economic crisis, the European Union and its Member States are called upon to end the vicious circle of corruption and opacity. Having now realized the increased possibilities that exist thanks to technological progress, it makes sense to discuss proposals for increased access of the tax authorities to the transactions attempted in order to prevent criminal acts. However, this does not mean that we have the right to be indifferent to issues of violation of the fundamental rights of European citizens. We must therefore be careful and ensure that these rights are respected by achieving the necessary balance between the interests of society as a whole, and the protection of personal data and privacy, on the one hand.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, the document we are discussing today is yet another step by the European Commission to effectively fight tax fraud and money laundering. As tax-related criminal practices are of a cross-border nature, they can only be tackled by joint international cooperation in tax matters. In this respect, I welcome the proposal by the Commission to give national tax authorities access to anti-money-laundering (AML) information. It is only with this information, and especially the information on beneficial owners, that Member States will be able to successfully address money laundering and tax evasion practices. Moreover, I support the amendment of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) to take the Commission proposal a step further so that anti-money laundering information is automatically exchanged with other Member States and with the Commission. Only close cooperation within the EU and on the global level can bring us further to preventing revelations such as the ones described in the Panama Papers from happening again. On another note, however, I want to criticise the fact that the Council has once again reached a political agreement on a tax-related matter before the consultative decision is made by the European Parliament. This, unfortunately, is not only against the rules but also undermines the spirit of good cooperation that the European institutions should have.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Finally, after the Panama Papers, Bahamas Leaks, etc. scandals, the Council and the Commission recognize that there is a link between combating fraud and tax evasion and combating money laundering and terrorist financing. Against the onshore and offshore secrecy from which crime lives, there is a need for transparency in the financial and business sectors, more synergies and more exchange of information between law enforcement agencies, including tax authorities, which this Commission proposal establishes. Unfortunately, the Member States reached an agreement in the Council, without listening to Parliament, but they will have to confront what we recommend in this report by Emmanuel Maurel. It is important to pay attention to its proposals that broaden the scope of matters and amount of data on which there should be an automatic and mandatory exchange of information, including on beneficial owners of companies and other legal entities that must be included in the public access register. To this end, we are working on revising the fourth anti-money laundering directive. The information in question must also be made available to the Commission, by virtue of its powers to apply State aid rules. It is essential to break the frontiers of investigating financial crime in the European Union. Tax authorities and others must cooperate in conducting cross-border inquiries.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President! Detecting and prosecuting money laundering crime is a very difficult task which requires the cooperation of many state authorities and services, as well as international cooperation in the field of information exchange. The idea of ​​harmonization at the EU level with regard to tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information is right, as it allows for the removal of some of the obstacles that hitherto limited the effectiveness of tax authorities. However, I would like to highlight some of the proposals in the report, or otherwise the absence of these proposals, which may hinder rather than facilitate the work of the Member States' tax authorities. I mean, among others the issue of the banking system, mutual funds or economic activity. It is a pity that this directive concerns the Member States, and we cannot speak of a directive on a global situation.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - I welcome again the European Commission's proposal and this report for more transparency by promoting the automatic exchange of information between Member States' tax authorities on money laundering.Recently, the President of the USA, Mr. Obama, in the last tour in Europe, declared that there is a global elite that does not feel obliged to declare its income, to pay taxes, just like ordinary citizens.That is why I believe that the European Commission has an obligation to act for the same level of transparency globally and, first and foremost, to form an ally in this fight against the new US administration.

name: Sirpa PIETIKÄINEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, this is one step in the long-standing struggle and work of the Commission and Parliament against bad tax practice, tax evasion and a thousand billion in tax losses. In that respect, we can welcome the proposal that has been made and the agreement reached so far in Parliament. But, as we heard earlier, it is really unfortunate that the Council and the Member States are not only refusing to have a normal dialogue and debate in this context, but have long been a cornerstone in developing good tax governance and transparency. The next step we would need is a real automatic exchange of information on the basis of the real beneficial owner directly from the payer through banks and other financial institutions directly to the taxpayer of that country. For this, we also need European tax identification data, and I know that this issue has also been in the Commission's preparation for a long time, and it would be nice to get it from there quite soon. We also need to work on reforming the Accounting Directive and the Accounting Directive so that the tax footprint and most-favored-nation treatment are reported there, and thus transparency also contributes to good governance on this basis.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - Recently, we have taken quite a few measures that close the possibilities for tax evaders. We have decided not to those who try to gain personal benefits at the expense of others by supporting the system. I hope that we will not stop on this path and that there will be no need for another scandal to remind us that we must persevere. We finally started to realize that it is very important who is actually the actual owner of the business. Hiding behind complicated connections, behind straw companies and various procurators is a fog that we can dispel with regulations. Finally, it has also become clear that the tax authorities need to work together, that they need to be connected if we want to step on the toes of tax fraudsters. This exchange must be self-evident and must be automatic. And last but not least, we have finally come to the realization that we need healthy tax competition. We do not need excessive taxes that stifle companies, nor do we need individual arrangements that give selected companies special benefits. Of course, the consolidated tax base is one of those instruments that could contribute to this. And last but not least, let’s also ask ourselves why we do all this. We are doing this so that we can have more money and more resources, which will mean a more social Europe.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, this is been a very interesting and also a very necessary debate. There has been virtual unanimity that we need to do something in the interest of citizens to establish fairer play for everybody. Citizens feel that governments, democracy, are not serving them at this point in time. In the whole area of tax collection there is obviously a misfit, with citizens paying every single penny and powerful individuals and companies often not paying at all. Even worse, money goes to money laundering and financing terrorist activities. So obviously, as has been said, there is need for a central register, there is need for transparency, there is need for country-by-country reporting, and this is a necessary first step to ensure that there is fair play for everybody.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the revelations that have emerged thanks to SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks and Panama Papers confirm the need for greater tax transparency and greater cooperation between jurisdictions. The link between tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering makes it essential to resort to synergies at national, European and international level. Systematic access by the tax authority to information on anti-money laundering will allow greater transparency and faster data processing, avoiding slowdowns and dysfunctions in administrative cooperation between financial institutions. I am in favor of extending the automatic exchange of information to virtual currency exchange services and DIGIT wallet service providers. In my opinion, however, an accurate analysis of the possible role played by the banking system and financial operators in money laundering is lacking. Indeed, it would be advisable for the Commission to intervene with an ad hoc proposal, which provides for greater controls and transparency on banking and financial transactions and severe penalties up to the withdrawal of the operating authorization.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, in order to tackle tax evasion and evasion, the European Commission aims to enable tax authorities to have systematic access to information on combating money laundering. However, the measures to be taken by the Commission to combat tax evasion need to be more drastic. As the Panama Papers and Lux ​​Leaks scandals have shown, the number of multinationals who make huge profits and evade taxes and hide their funds in tax havens is not declining at all. The only solution, therefore, to the problem of tax evasion practices is to tax the profits of companies in the place where the profits are made, so that companies stop resorting to tax havens, thus damaging state budgets.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, committing fraud and money laundering and money laundering is a practice that is practiced internationally. In order to deal with this phenomenon, states must take strict and effective measures while cooperating with the European Union, in order to avoid both tax exemption and the access of multinational companies to tax havens. In this regard, the exchange of information related to tax data is necessary. However, care must be taken not to violate the rights of legal citizens. Another point to note is that states should not impose exorbitant taxes, because that is what pushes citizens and companies to evade taxes. This is the case in Greece, where unbearable taxes have been imposed in the context of the implementation of the measures of the memoranda. Finally, the tax system must be controlled and the European Union must not allow high-ranking officials - as has happened so far - to cover up such illegal activities.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - It is very important that we adopt amendments to the directive on tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information, as the rapid, transparent and automatic exchange of financial account information for tax purposes is crucial in the effective fight against tax evasion. Scandals surrounding the concealment of offshore assets go hand in hand with tax evasion as well as money laundering, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities. The access of tax administrations to data varies greatly across the European Union, so I welcome the establishment of a central register that can be accessed by the tax administrations of all Member States. Financial institutions will now be able to identify the beneficial owners in cases where the account holder is an intermediary structure. I propose that the Commission draw up a report for the six-month period in 2017 on the effects of this directive in the Member States, given that Member States must publish the laws, regulations and administrative provisions necessary for this directive by 31 December this year at the latest.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all my thanks to my colleague Maurel for his report. Money laundering of illicit origin is a fraudulent activity now conducted on a global scale and, as evidenced by various investigations, this activity is closely linked to tax evasion and avoidance but also to organized crime and the financing of terrorism. Maximum transparency in tax matters is therefore essential and it is the task of the European Union to ensure that the tax authorities of the Member States have equal and reciprocal access to information on the subject, so as to be able to effectively carry out all the necessary monitoring and enforcement actions. And it is clear that there is a need for greater cooperation between the competent authorities of the Member States, based on an automatic and mandatory exchange of information on anti-money laundering. In particular, I consider it essential that information and documents on beneficial ownership of accounts by natural and legal persons, businesses and trusts are exchanged. We can no longer accept that financial crimes are committed using intermediary structures, or benefiting from unclear or inadequate rules and practices.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, never before has the outrage against corruption and money laundering from illicit businesses been so widespread, and never before has administrative cooperation been so necessary to exchange information. But, above all, never before, after the Panama Papers scandal, have the deficiencies of the current situation been revealed. Therefore, the Commission must be required not only to take the initiative, but to confront the Council to ensure that all countries carry this commitment to transparency to the maximum, including in the information not only financial institutions, but also notaries and trust holders - in addition to registrars -, forcing them to pass on information to the Commission regarding their tax agreements - the so-called tax rulings - and, above all, avoiding large corporations that do not pay taxes and ensuring that, before the end of the legislature, the objective is met that companies pay money where they make their profits.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, I support any initiative aimed at financial consolidation of the state without additional burden for citizens and companies.In this sense, the fight against tax evasion and money laundering is very important because otherwise the burden of filling the budget falls exclusively on honest citizens and entrepreneurs who abide by the law and are forced to pay for other people's crime.That is unacceptable.However, I must express my regret that in this House we are talking about taxes and fiscal consolidation exclusively from the position of increasing control, and not the tax relief of citizens and companies.Taxes, which are extremely high and complicated in some Member States, should be reduced and simplified, and penalties for non-payment should be tightened.In this way, we would discourage non-payment and make it easier for companies to do business, employment and investment in research and development.Additional tax repression can only have negative effects.

name: Pierre MOSCOVICI
text: member of the Commission. - Madam President, Ladies and Gentlemen, Mr Rapporteur, once again I would like to thank you all for your comments and for the impetus that this Parliament is giving collectively to our common action on taxation. I check once again what is for me a constant conviction, namely that our two institutions, beyond the differences in sensitivity and position that may arise here or there, are generally on the same length of time. wave, quite simply because we have the same objective: more transparent, more efficient and at the same time fairer taxation. I therefore welcome the level of ambition that some of you have mentioned and that Mr Maurel's report has perfectly reflected. I can assure you that this directive will create the conditions for setting up a mechanism for cross-border access to information on beneficial owners, a mechanism which many of you are keen on. In this way, brick by brick, we are building a solid defense structure against fraud and tax evasion in Europe, which is a robust systemic response against external threats to the tax bases of Member States, a path towards more tax fairness for all citizens and all European businesses. The political pressure, in the good sense of the word, exerted by the Parliament, particularly by its ECON committees and now PANA, is decisive for the success of our initiatives. I will perhaps make a few more specific comments in response to the comments made by parliamentarians. I have noted your request for an automatic exchange of information and I share this objective. As I said, the Commission will propose such an exchange in a separate proposal as soon as we have enough information, precisely on how best to proceed. This will be done in coordination with the development of the anti-money laundering directive currently discussed by this Parliament, as well as by the Council. Several of you have pointed out that there are still activities or structures that are beyond transparency. I of course agree with you. The Commission is working on this and will continue with your help to extend this transparency as much as possible. Several of you, including Mr. Kofod, mentioned the liability of banks. In the Commission, we consider not only that the responsibility of the banks exists, but that all those who facilitate aggressive tax planning must be included in the field of our vigilance. We have launched a public consultation - as I said - on this subject in order to determine the best way to bring these facilitators of all kinds, from all origins and from all origins, face to face with their responsibilities. As regards the agreement in the Council, I take good note of your remarks on the fact that the Council did not wait for Parliament's opinion to agree on a general approach on this particular subject. Fortunately, our work will continue on increasing transparency through other legal instruments. So there is obviously a major utility in the debates taking place here. I am happy, as always, to continue this work, happy to be able to do it in close coordination and in partnership with the European Parliament to achieve, in Europe, the fairer tax system that our fellow citizens expect. To that extent, I am also very happy to welcome this report, which constitutes an important stage in our common struggle, and, once again, the remarkable quality of this debate, which really moves things forward.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: protractor. - Madam President, I am going to conclude very quickly because it has been a very rich and very interesting debate. I nevertheless welcome - because it is not so often - the unanimous nature of Parliament, which wished to send a certain number of clear messages, to the Council first of all because - you have understood it correctly, Mr. Commissioner - it is becoming quite unbearable for parliamentarians that, on these specific questions of taxation, the Council always manages to try to circumvent our opinion or to pretend not to hear it. This is not your case and, moreover, there is something comforting for you as for us, it is that there is on the part of the parliamentarians on all the benches of this hemicycle a support for your action never denied - I said earlier - in order to move towards more tax justice and, at the same time, a form of demand. That is why we have tirelessly insisted, whether on the right of this Chamber or on the left, on the necessary automatic exchange of information because, as my colleague Peter Simon said very well - I believe in the discussion - as we saw in the tax rulings, if there was not this requirement, the States were not doing their minimal work. Finally, and I will end there, I really thank colleagues for the quality of this debate. To those who hesitate, to those who doubt and say "yes, but Europe cannot go faster and further than other countries in the world", I recall the excellent hearing we had with the award Nobel, M. Stiglitz. Above all, he shouldn't be a master thinker, but he said something that I think is essential. He said that in tax matters - and this is very important - Europe, on its own, can bring about great progress for the world. From that point of view, it was a great encouragement to continue our work.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- A serious fight against money laundering is one of the main tools to defeat both terrorism and organized crime of various kinds.Access by national tax authorities to relevant information is therefore absolutely vital and, as also argued in the report, should therefore be made automatic and mandatory.Thanks to our contribution, the final text also includes a sanctioning mechanism for banks that facilitate money laundering, in order to discourage the underlying phenomenon and make recourse to it more "expensive" and difficult.The fight against money laundering is a front that sees us at the forefront and we will therefore continue to do everything in our power to contribute to its triumph.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2 to 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. This is also the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - Reducing tax evasion and avoidance, including in relation to money laundering, must be an absolute priority for the European Union and its Member States. The big cases known as Swiss Leaks, Lux Leaks, Panama Papers and Bahama Leaks show that tax evasion and money laundering are a global phenomenon. Detecting them, and in particular effectively suppressing them, therefore requires improved cooperation, coordination and the involvement not only of the EU, but of virtually the whole world. However, it is also important to further increase the transparency of banking and financial transactions. In case of reluctance and concealment of bank secrecy, there should be harsh sanction mechanisms in case of suspected suspicions, which will force every single bank to cooperate. It is necessary to facilitate the activities of repressive forces operating in this area and to actively assist in the detection of the real recipients of illegally obtained funds. We really must not relax in this. Quality material equipment and the related use of state-of-the-art information and communication technologies must be a matter of course. Only these will make it possible to trace money laundering activities at an early stage.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Tax fraud and evasion damage the economies of the Union and its Member States. They are closely linked to corruption, non-transparency and crime in the form of money laundering, support for terrorism and organized crime. Their persistence is the result of an insufficient fight against the tax havens that enable and encourage such unfair practices. I support the proposal to amend the Council directive regulating tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information. Sufficient personnel and material equipment of tax and customs authorities, mandatory automatic exchange of information, international cooperation of authorities in the field of taxation, strict legislation for the banking and financial sector, including tracing of real owners of companies is a means to achieve international tax transparency. Member States are required to bring their legislation into line with this Directive by the end of next year at the latest.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is Voting Time.(For the results and other information on the vote: See Minutes)

name: Urmas PAET
text: rapporteur. – I have one oral amendment for paragraph 6, and this oral amendment is to delete from paragraph 6 the words ‘with the assistance of a deputy HR’.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Voting time is over.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: The next item on the agenda is the Explanations of vote.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report concerns possible strategic cooperation between Europol and Ukraine, including on the exchange of personal data.It must be said that this year Parliament approved the new Europol regulation and also new regulations regarding the protection and exchange of personal data.When these regulations come into force in 2017, the Parliament will enjoy an enhanced role, being able to express an opinion and not just consensus as is currently the case.For this reason I have decided to abstain.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I have voted against this Agreement for two key reasons. The first is that I understand that the Europol Agency does not act with the transparency and guarantees that an institution of this type requires. In particular, agreements with third countries do not establish minimum standards in terms of data protection and judicial guarantees, in addition to not being clear about the competencies of the different bodies and the rights to which an investigated person or person would be subject. stopped. On the other hand, the occurrence of this type of Agreement with Ukraine is not accidental, and obeys the strategy of stressing the relationship between the Union and Russia, to which I oppose, in addition to being Ukraine a country with institutions taken over by far right since the coup in 2014, there has been a substantial deterioration in human rights conditions. For both reasons, I have voted against an opaque police agreement without guarantees and, also, with a State with so few democratic guarantees.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against increased cooperation between Europol and Ukraine for a number of reasons. We in Sinn Féin have concerns in relation to the operational oversight, or lack thereof, Europol is subject to. We oppose enhanced cooperation particularly when the human rights or justice standards of the state in question are dubious. Given the situation in Ukraine and coupled with the unaccountable, opaque, nature of Europol, we continue to oppose these strategic cooperation initiatives.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Ukraine and Europol. This agreement provides for the exchange of information, including personal data. This means that information could be exchanged in the areas of expertise, general situation reports, the results of strategic analyzes, as well as information on criminal investigation procedures and crime prevention methods. The agreement provides for participation in training activities, advice and assistance in specific criminal investigations. The agreement is particularly important given that Ukraine is a key partner of the European Union in the Eastern Partnership, and it is security and the fight against crime that are key and necessary issues in order to achieve the key objectives of the partnership. This agreement could also have a positive impact on closer cooperation between EU and Ukrainian citizens in other areas, such as freedom of movement. I support the conclusion of this strategic and operational cooperation agreement with Ukraine, as it would help to strengthen the fight against organized crime and facilitate closer international cooperation in the field of trafficking in human beings and other related criminal law. I am convinced that closer cooperation between the EU and Ukraine is mutually beneficial and necessary.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the draft Council Implementing Decision approving the conclusion by the European Police Office (Europol) of the Agreement on operational and strategic cooperation between Ukraine and Europol, as I consider security and the fight againstcrime are a key condition for fully achieving the goals between the EU and Ukraine.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - This is the proposed approval of an agreement between Europol and Ukraine on operational and strategic cooperation, which includes the exchange of information, including personal data. Such information could include specialist knowledge, general situation reports, results of strategic analysis, information on criminal investigations and methods of crime prevention, participation in training and the provision of advice and support in individual criminal investigations. According to Europol, Ukraine is playing an increasingly important role in the fight against organized crime, in particular drug and economic crime, human trafficking and smuggling, and mobile organized criminal groups. I voted in favor of the report because this exchange of information will enable the EU, the Member States and Ukraine to fight and prevent organized crime, terrorism and other forms of international crime more effectively.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - In order to improve efficiency in preventing and combating serious forms of crime, Europol has initiated the procedure for concluding an agreement on operational and strategic cooperation with Ukraine. The terms of cooperation governed by the operational and strategic agreement provide for exchanges of information which may include expertise, general reports, results of strategic analyzes, information on criminal investigation procedures and information. on methods of crime prevention, participation in training activities, as well as the provision of advice and support in specific criminal investigations. In addition, the agreement contains provisions relating to the exchange of personal data. This is unacceptable. In addition, the conclusion of this agreement is part of the more or less hidden perspective of Ukraine's potential membership of the European Union. We are opposed to this idea. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As a UKIP MEP, I was elected on a mandate of Britain's withdrawal from the European Union and opposition to Europol. Likewise, we do not support the European Union concluding agreements with third countries. Consequently, I voted against.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ The current conflict situation in Ukraine has also spilled over into other areas of concern both for Ukraine and other adjacent European countries. According to Europol itself, Ukraine is playing a much larger role than before in the issues of organised crime, drug trafficking, and human smuggling. Which is why the exchange of valuable information between the triad of the EU, the Member States, and Ukraine will allow a higher efficiency combat against these problems. This agreement would open the door not only to the exchange of information but also the possibilities of training and crime preventing activities to start battling the issues before they even spawn. The report also underlines the importance of further implementing all the previous security agreements established between the EU and Ukraine in order to enhance international cooperation on such matters.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the operational and strategic cooperation agreement between Ukraine and Europol.The purpose of this proposal is to approve the Agreement on Operational and Strategic Cooperation between Europol and Ukraine, which provides for the exchange of information, including personal data.According to Europol, Ukraine is growing in importance in the fight against organized crime, in particular drug-related and economic crime, trafficking in human beings and smuggling, as well as mobile (traveling) organized crime groups.I therefore support greater exchanges of information to enable the EU, the Member States and Ukraine to prevent and combat organized crime, terrorism and other forms of transnational crime more effectively.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The proposal aims at the proposed approval of an operational and strategic agreement between Europol and Ukraine and provides for the exchange of information, including on personal data. This information may include expertise, general status reports, information on the results of strategic analysis, information on investigative procedures and crime prevention methods, and participation in training activities, as well as advice and support for specific investigations. The present proposal serves criminal cooperation in the fight against organized crime and terrorism, so it is essentially in European and thus Hungarian interest to give Member States' police forces a better chance of preventing and detecting crime in Ukraine, which is known to be intertwined with organized crime networks. However, the question rightly arises as to whether, if the influence of organized crime in a state penetrates to such levels of government, data exchanges and operational information do not fall into the hands of organized criminal circles that are currently being prosecuted. They see this as providing guarantees for this, so I supported the adoption of the motion.

name: Gerard BATTEN
