text: in writing.- I voted for my colleague's text on cod stocks.This is an informal agreement with Union ministers.Cod fishermen in the North Sea would be forced to land all their catch - and not just cod.The agreement would remove limits on the number of days a vessel can spend in a fishing area in exchange for the implementation of the "dumping ban" of unwanted fish at sea.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ As a result of the serious depletion of four of Europe’s cod stocks in the early 2000s, the EU imposed strict rules on the fishing industry through a recovery plan in 2004. The new regulation amends and updates the existing Regulation of 2004 and 2008, in the aim countering problems currently existing in the plan, as well as to align the provisions of the Regulation with the Treaty of Lisbon. I voted in favour of the amendments to the Regulation because it is important the EU regularly revises and evaluates its regulatory measures to protect Europe against any further depletion of one of the its most important resources.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the long-term plan for cod, which has been stuck for far too long in the interinstitutional pipes. The negotiations on this report, which have been going on since 2012, have indeed set a legal precedent between the Council and the Parliament. It was not until the referral and a judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union to put an end to the conflict of interpretation of the Lisbon Treaty between the two institutions. At issue is the sensitive issue of quotas, for which the treaties grant the Council the sole decision-making prerogative. The European Parliament is the co-decision maker on other fishing regulations. As the multiannual plans closely touched on quotas, the European Parliament was therefore threatening to encroach on the Council's prerogatives in this area. The Court of Justice finally ruled partially in favor of Parliament, ruling that Parliament's determination of environmental principles applying to quotas was compatible with the Treaties. Furthermore, I am delighted that this regulation puts an end to the effort regime for these fisheries, maintaining only the quota regime, which is good news because the dual regime was absurd for professionals and without environmental added value.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - In accordance with the guidelines of the European People's Party, I, along with my Fidesz colleagues, supported the adoption without a vote of the Dodds report on the long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks. This step approved the legislative text finalized in the second reading agreement between the EP and the Council. New legislation is needed as the old fishing plan used a complex catch system. In practice, this has led to a deterioration of the cod stock. The new rules are more flexible in terms of TACs and fishing quotas and streamline the rules on landing obligations. Progress has also been made in tightening discards for unusable fish. 30% of the Earth's seas are overfished, and marine fish stocks are at risk. It is therefore understandable that, in order to maintain marine fish stocks, the European Union is forced to restrict sea fishing accordingly. Therefore, the Common Fisheries Policy must pay much more attention to sustainable fish farming, ie aquaculture, and in particular freshwater fish farming. A significant part of the fishponds in Hungary are located in Natura 2000 areas. These fish farms pose no threat to the natural values ​​of these areas. Moreover, in many cases it is due to our closed system of fishponds that the unique wetland associations they have created or preserved are. Consequently, freshwater aquaculture must be given priority and as much EU support as possible.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the "Motion for a resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) no.1342/2008 on the adoption of a long-term plan for cod stocks and fisheries exploiting those stocks ”.I am of the opinion that the above-mentioned motion for a resolution is needed in order to initiate the second reading legislative procedure and to reach a consensus at the level of the relevant legislative institutions of the European Union and to establish a long-term plan for cod stocks and fisheries exploiting those stocks.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the long-term cod fishing plan recommended by Diane Dodds MEP.Undoubtedly, rational cod fishing planning will help protect this species from extinction in the Baltic Sea.It is worth noting that cod fishing is one of the main and most important in the Baltic Sea, so in the long run the balance between the conservation of this species and the restrictions on fishing must be taken into account.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I supported the recommendation to allow cod fishing to be above a level acceptable for achieving sustainable cod stocks, and these measures should take effect from 1 January 2017 for the Kattegat, Skagerrak, North Sea, Eastern Channel, west ofScotland and the Irish Sea.The aim of these measures is to ensure that the cod reach regain its abundance, which will enable sustainable fishing.At the same time, I believe that each EU Member State should find its own way to protect itself from unwanted catches in order to keep cod stocks above acceptable levels.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- Draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of an EU Regulation of the Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No.I supported Regulation (EC) No 1342/2008 establishing a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks.The aim of this proposal is to align the Regulation establishing a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks ("cod plan") with the new rules of the TFEU.The powers currently conferred on the Commission under that Regulation have been reclassified into delegated and implementing measures.The main objective of the plan is to ensure the sustainable exploitation of the cod stock in the geographical area of the Kattegat, the North Sea, the West of Scotland and the Irish Sea on the basis of maximum sustainable yield.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- An introduction of delegated acts is made in the following areas: adaptation of fishing mortality rates and associated levels of biomass in the stock to scientific discoveries, adjustment of fishing effort in the event of exclusion or re-entry of a group of vessels inEffort regime, specification of the rules on the method of calculating fishing capacity and the adaptation of maximum capacity levels and, finally, the establishment of rules on a calculation method that allows Member States to adjust fishing effortmaximum allowable in relation to quota management and after effort transfers.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It is an important step in the right direction towards establishing a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks. I support the fishing industry, since they are the first one who want to have fish in the future. Therefore, a sustainable path is a win-win situation for all parties.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- Council Regulation No. 1342/2008 of 18 December 2008 was adopted before the entry into force of the TFEU and therefore confers decision-making powers on the Council (Articles 10 and 11).As the FEU Treaty no longer provides for this possibility, the Commission has therefore suggested an amendment to this regulation.The main purpose of the proposal is to improve and clarify the provisions of the Regulation.It implements the principles of the new common fisheries policy and supports its application.I therefore voted for this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- In July 2016, the Council and Parliament reached an agreement on this proposal.The swift implementation of this regulation is to ensure the swift implementation of the revision of the rules on the sustainable exploitation of cod stocks.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- On 12 September 2012, the Commission presented a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation 1342/2008 in order to adapt and clarify the provisions of Regulation 1342/2008.On 19 December 2012, without transposing all the provisions of the proposal for a Regulation, the Council adopted a Regulation designating Article 43 (3) TFEU as the legal basis and adopting amendments to Articles 9 and 12 of Regulation 1342/2008.just away.With my vote, I followed the group's position on the issue.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report because I understand that it is an adjustment and adaptation of regulations.An introduction to delegated acts is made in the following areas: adaptation of fishing mortality rates and associated levels of biomass in the stock to scientific discoveries, adjustment of fishing effort in the event of exclusion or re-entry of a group of vessels under the regimeof effort, specification of the rules on the method of calculating fishing capacity and the adaptation of maximum capacity levels and, finally, the establishment of rules on a calculation method that allows Member States to adjust the maximum fishing effortadmissible in relation to quota management and after effort transfers.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1342/2008 establishing a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks. The goal of the updated regulation is to allow North Sea cod fishermen to land every catch more easily. The regulation removes limits on the number of days a vessel can spend in a fishing area and thus removes all obstacles to complying with the landing obligation in full. I voted in favour because I believe that this update of the 2008 Regulation establishing a long-term-plan for cod stocks will make it fully compatible with the new Common Fisheries Policy (CFP).

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- The objective of this text is to modify the rules that set limits on catch quantities, amend the fishing effort regime and reinforce the measures to deal with discards.Aiming to give fishermen greater flexibility, it removes the obstacles of introducing obligations into the plan.It also makes the rules on catch limits more flexible and the need for Member States to adopt timely measures to minimize and, where appropriate, eliminate discards is appropriate.For all these reasons, I have voted in favor.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this new cod plan, since it simplifies the landing of catches and updates the 2008 one, burdened by the limitation of fishing effort that reduced the time that sailors could fish. With the application of the discard veto, this limit was turned into an unnecessary tool. Adapted the proposal to the new Common Fisheries Policy, this new Regulation therefore introduces a provision that obliges the Council to set the Total Allowable Catch (TAC) based on the maximum sustainable yield (MSY) and establishes that in setting the quotas in cases of insufficient data the precautionary approach must prevail. This update of the management plan for cod and the fisheries that exploit it is necessary, although it is expected to have a short life until the approval of the multi-year North Sea Plan. All this does not prevent it from accepting with prudence the impact that the landing obligation may have on the sustainability of the fishing fleets that exploit them.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because the decision adopted is in line with the position of the Council.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The Commission's original proposal foresaw the introduction of delegated acts in the following areas: adaptation of fishing mortality rates and associated levels of stock biomass to scientific discoveries;adjustment of fishing effort in case of exclusion or re-inclusion of a group of vessels in the effort regime;specification of rules concerning the method of calculating fishing capacity and adjusting maximum capacity levels;and establishment of rules on the method of calculation that allows Member States to adapt the maximum authorized fishing effort in relation to quota management and following effort transfers between effort groups.Despite the general agreement with the Commission proposal, there should be a stricter definition of the circumstances under which the Commission can approve delegated acts

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the regulation establishing a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks. The issue was appealed by the European Parliament and the Commission to the Court of Justice as we found the Council's choice to split the proposal for a long-term plan for cod stocks to be illegitimate. The ruling annulled the Council regulation and the co-legislators are therefore required to adopt a new text by the end of the year in order to ensure legal certainty. Following the Court's ruling, the PECH commission adopted a mandate for negotiations with the Council and the file was closed. The agreement, which implements the principles of the new common fisheries policy and supports its implementation, was approved by the commission. The S & amp; D Group actively contributed to the rapid adoption of the plan in order to ensure legal certainty for fishermen: we made sure that the plan in question respects the principles of the CFP reform.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This report amends the current plan governing long-term stocks, which were not doing enough to ensure recovery of fish mortality and had little stakeholder support. The amendments will increase cooperation between fisheries, industries and scientists and is intended as a stopgap until a multi-species plan is introduced. This moves us towards the more sustainable fishing environment that we urgently need. It is interesting to note that while the Brexiteers have been howling about EU fishing quotas back in the UK, the report was adopted unanimously in the European Parliament’s Fisheries Committee, even though it was led by a pro-Brexit MEP.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation concerning a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting this species.It was a recommendation to approve the Council's position, and an agreement between the Council and Parliament has already been adopted this summer.The purpose of the new regulation is in particular to achieve the sustainable exploitation of cod stocks in selected areas.The amendment follows on from the regulation on the recovery of the reduced cod stock, which was adopted in 2008. I think that close monitoring of the individual fish stocks and adjusting their fishing opportunities is very important for the conservation of biodiversity.And the right balance between maintaining populations and achieving the maximum possible yield is then a key tool.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Dodds report for supporting the position of the European Court of Justice, which reiterates the European Parliament's powers as a co-legislator by annulling the Council's decision to adopt only partially some of the proposals to amend the Regulation that manages the plan for the stocks of thecodfish.Based on this jurisprudence, it is now possible to revise a long-term plan for these stocks and for the fisheries that exploit them, ensuring legal certainty for operators in the sector.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I am voting in favor of amending the Council Regulation on the adoption of a long-term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries that exploit those stocks.There is a clear need to ensure the consistent implementation of all Council decisions, especially when it comes to fisheries policy.Overfishing of cod can endanger the stability of marine flora and fauna and significantly affect the related industry.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the recommendation for second reading on the Council 's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No.Amending Regulation (EC) No 1342/2008 establishing a long - term plan for cod stocks and the fisheries exploiting those stocks.Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation NoRegulation (EC) No 1342/2008 (COM (2012) 0498) is intended to improve and clarify the provisions of the current Regulation in order to better implement the principles of the new Common Fisheries Policy.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - I voted in favor of this report because the fight against fraud, tax evasion and money laundering must be a priority of the European Union. It is a question of justice, of fairness: it is a question of politics. In recent years, most citizens of the European Union have faced an unprecedented economic crisis. In these same years, cases of tax fraud have emerged with increasing frequency - that of the Panama papers speaks for everyone - scandals that have also involved former Commissioners of the European Union. It is finally time to clarify, it is time to strengthen cooperation and allow the transfer of tax information that can quickly lead to investigations. European citizens who pay taxes are often forced to close their businesses. They are not afraid of transparency, nor of controls: they are afraid of being governed by scammers and tax evaders, they have mistrust in institutions which, instead, protect their interests and seem to lend their side to large multinationals. Europe must choose and must do so with facts.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I supported this addition to the directive because I believe that the EU's role in the fight against organized crime that knows no borders is extremely important. In this case, the fight against tax evasion and money laundering is being fought, and here, in short, the role of individual nation states can never be sufficient. Ie. coordination at central European level, clear rules for access by financial and police authorities to information on the tax returns of individual entities make sense in my opinion. Today, strengthening the access of financial authorities to information from tax reports in the individual Member States will lead to a more effective fight against this form of organized crime in the future. So the proposal is the right one, and although I am not in favor of strengthening the EU and transferring other powers to Brussels, this story is about something else, it is about the fight against organized crime.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin. Vótáil mé le mo ghrúpa sna vótaí seo go léir, is tábhachtach an t-ábhar é agus bhí áthas orm a bheith páirteach sa díospóireacht anseo sa Pharlaimint ó chianaibh; agus feisirí ó gach taobh den teach beagnach ar aon ghuth faoi thábhacht an ábhair seo. Caithfimid troid i gcoinne na caimiléireachta i gcoitinne, go háirithe mar a bhaineann sé le héalú ó cháin a íoc. Bíonn ar dhaoine aonaránacha gach aon euro de cháin a íoc agus ag an am gcéanna feicimid gur féidir le daoine cumhachtacha agus comhlachtaí móra éalú gan aon cháin a íoc; agus cuid den airgead seo ag dul go sceimhlitheoireacht, agus mar sin de. Dá bhrí sin, tá gá le comhaontú idir na tíortha chun troid i gcoinne an ruda mhíchirt seo, agus a luaithe agus a tharlóidh sé is fearr. Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: –Mr President!I voted against this report for two main reasons.First of all, money laundering is a concept that is largely imprecise and used for propaganda purposes.Money that is dirty in one country is not dirty in another.There is no objective measure of which country has the correct interpretation, and it is very similar with tax laws.It is therefore natural for citizens and entrepreneurs to move their activities to places where taxes are lower, because businesses are run to generate income, and tax is a cost for entrepreneurs.Thus, states compete with each other with tax systems and should compete to know which tax system is more efficient for the economy.This should not be unified, but should be allowed for entrepreneurs to shift their business from disadvantaged to favorable systems.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Mr President, I feel that this report rather neatly demonstrates the difference between internationalism and supranationalism. Internationalism, the cooperation among sovereign countries, is impossible to argue with, and the idea that tax authorities should share information in order to crack down on illegal behaviour on tax evasion is uncontroversial. But every time this Parliament gets its hands on the subject it always starts inserting a different agenda to do with tax harmonisation and with treating jurisdictions with lower tax, or tax havens as they are invariably called here, as being intrinsically illicit rather than being, as they are, a spur to the rest of us to keep tax rates within a manageable level. By all means, let us have cooperation among tax authorities. Let us make it global rather than just continental and let us not leave it to the same bumbling Brussels institutions that gave us the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy, Schengen, the euro and all the rest of it. That is the difference between internationalism and supranationalism.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The following report deals with the revision of the directive on the automatic exchange of information in tax and tax matters.I believe it is of paramount importance to implement mechanisms that ensure transparency and make money laundering complicated.A step in this direction would certainly make the exchange of information mandatory and automatic, to avoid the repetition of episodes such as Luxleaks and Panama papers.For the reasons set out above, I have decided to vote in favor.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, because it represents an improvement in the requirements regarding access to information by the tax authorities.With the development of all the tax scandals produced in recent years: Luxleaks, Panamaleaks, Bahamaleaks ... the public has become aware of the tax practices of the main players in the financial system.This proposal is born from the pressure of public opinion to act in this area and allow access to relevant tax information for tax evaders.Access to information by the competent authorities is a necessary step, in order to implement the principle of paying taxes where wealth is created and carry out actions against tax havens.It is for all this that I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which amends an existing Directive on Administrative Cooperation by Financial Institutions in the field of taxation. The goal of the changes is to enable tax authorities to consistently access anti-money-laundering information. Specifically this concerns access to the mechanism, procedures, documents and information on the true beneficial owners that hide behind shell companies and trusts. It also improves the requirements for customer due diligence procedures in accordance with the fourth Anti Money Laundering Directive. This information will be compiled in central registers and Member States will be obliged to share this information with tax authorities in the EU. I fully support maximum transparency across the EU in order to combat money-laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing. - I welcome the adoption, today in plenary, of the report by my socialist colleague Emmanuel Maurel. Tax fraud and tax evasion are unacceptable practices. Equality before taxes is a top priority. Therefore, it is essential to strengthen the legislation and restore tax justice. Last July, the Commission presented a legislative package intended to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This report responds to the main limitation of these proposals: only national access to these data was planned; in other words, the Luxembourg tax authorities could know that a French person was the beneficiary of a passive company in Luxembourg, without ever informing France. We understand the very insufficient nature of such a proposal! In the fight against aggressive tax fraud, evasion and tax optimization, the tool unanimously recognized as the most effective is the compulsory and automatic exchange of information. I am delighted that Emmanuel Maurel has succeeded in securing a good majority around this ambitious proposal. The Council, which alone decides on taxation, must listen to the European Parliament when it is consulted and put an end to a practice which undermines our social contract.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information.I support the European Commission's intention to ensure fairer, more efficient taxation based on greater tax transparency in the European Union.The importance of the EU's tax transparency agenda is confirmed by recent media reports of large-scale concealment of funds in tax havens.From this information, there are areas where additional measures are needed to strengthen the EU and international transparency framework.Tax authorities need to be able to obtain information on the beneficial owners of intermediate structures more easily, as well as other information needed for the due diligence of customers, in order to successfully detect cases of tax evasion.I believe that this initiative will contribute to a more effective fight against money laundering.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by the tax authorities to information on combating money laundering, as I believe that automatic and mandatory exchangesinformation between tax authorities to combat money laundering is an extremely important step.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - The EU has already made significant progress in recent years in improving tax transparency and strengthening cooperation between the tax authorities of the Member States. Recent changes to anti-money laundering legislation address the links between money laundering and tax evasion, as well as the challenges of prevention. Information leaked to the media, such as the Panama Papers, which exposed the large-scale secrecy of offshore funds, highlighted areas where further action must be taken. The report calls for tax offices across the EU to have access to information on who really owns bank accounts, as well as account balances or income such as interest and dividends. In addition, the EU Parliament wants to go one step further than the Commission and demands that this information should also be exchanged between tax authorities across the EU. The tax authorities' access to this information ensures that they are better able to carry out their monitoring obligations. I voted in favor of the report because I believe that it is essential to further strengthen the transparency framework, both at EU level and at international level.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The proposal aims to amend Council Directive 2011/16 / EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation by introducing a provision allowing tax authorities to have access to specific information relating to the fight against money laundering. for tax purposes. This is a measure that we support, especially since we voted for the anti-money laundering directive, as well as for the directive on the exchange of tax information. For its part, in addition to approving the Commission's amendments, Parliament's report calls for the date of entry into application of the new provisions not to be January 1, 2017, but January 1, 2018. It is also called for the establishment of a public register of companies which would guarantee access to information, and the obligation for Member States to automatically transmit tax information which may be of interest to another Member State within 3 months after its collection . I voted in favor of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that such matters should be considered as sovereign tax matters. International agreements, where necessary, can be made at intra-governmental level without recourse to EU legislation. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because it is important for the EU to pursue an ambitious program to fight tax fraud and tax evasion with a view to achieving fairer and more efficient taxation within the Union.Greater tax transparency is a central element of this program.In order to guarantee this, the priority must be to strengthen cooperation between tax authorities across the Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information.The scandals at Swissleaks, LuxLeaks, the Panama Papers and the Bahamas Leaks raise serious doubts about the EU's ability to combat tax evasion and money laundering.We are also increasingly confronted with giant multinational corporations that enjoy 'privileges' and evade taxes.It is therefore necessary to ensure reforms in this area that provide greater transparency not only at EU level but also at international level.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The report addresses the fight against tax evasion and avoidance and is a follow-up to the 2011 Council Directive on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. The Swissleaks, Luxleaks, Panama Papers and the Bahamas leaks, which are unique examples of a global phenomenon, have highlighted the urgent need for greater tax transparency and much closer judicial coordination and cooperation. This Directive emphasizes the need for the Commission to analyze the potential role of the banking system and financial service providers in facilitating money laundering. Due to its increased powers in the field of finance and banking, the Union could intervene through a regulation on stricter supervision and transparency of banking and financial transactions. I voted in favor of the Commission's action against money laundering and tax evasion. At the same time, the root cause is the financial liberalization of the 1990s, which, if maintained, will always make it possible to avoid taxation and money laundering, even to a lesser extent than before.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ The Directive will place mandatory requirements on Member States on sovereign tax matters and personal information that could, just as easily, be agreed at an intra-governmental level, rather than via the EU. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This directive implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters within the Union.As such, it ensures that information on financial account holders is communicated to the Member State in which the account holder resides.That is why I voted in favor of this text, after having voted for the directive on the fight against money laundering, as well as for the directive on the exchange of tax information.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- This is the first Commission directive intended to strengthen the fight against money laundering following the revelations of the Panama Papers.The purpose of the directive is to allow the tax authorities of the Member States to have access to data relating to customers and final beneficiaries collected in the context of the fight against money laundering.I obviously approved this point.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as it is a further step towards eradicating tax fraud.Specifically, this modification will grant the tax authorities greater access to information on the active beneficiaries of the intermediary entities in order to more effectively identify and address tax evasion.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Tax evasion is a very topical problem, a theme made even more central by the inquiries related to the "Panama papers" which have rightly caused a sensation in world public opinion and within the Union, also due to the important figures involved. The Maurel report, which I supported today with my vote, represents a joint response by the European institutions to tackle the persistence of the phenomenon of tax evasion. The new measures aim to strengthen the Commission's proposal by allowing the tax authorities of each Member State to access, and share, all information on bank account holders, with particular attention to their income, interests and dividends. The new legislation aims to identify tax evaders, making ineffective those tools, legal devices and entities, which are now used to cover up these illegal operations. We must not forget that there are very strong links between tax evasion, money laundering, the financing of terrorism and organized crime. Therefore, updated and strengthened legislation is needed, capable of aiming at an ever more effective collaboration between EU member countries to combat tax evasion and its consequences.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, in turn in favor of the Commission's proposal to oblige the exchange of information on money laundering between Member States, in order to combat money laundering and tax evasion.The final date of entry into force is 2017, considered more realistic by practically all parties.The amendments made by Parliament also oblige the exchange of information on the beneficial owners of companies, making evasion difficult through the use of shell companies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this report on access to information by tax authorities against money laundering.More transparency, clarity and, above all, cooperation between tax authorities is necessary.There are mechanisms that must be put in place, the fight against money laundering is essential in the Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I am voting for the amendment of Council Directive 2011/16 / EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation.Fitting in a post "Panama Papers" context, it introduces a provision allowing tax authorities to have access to specific information relating to the fight against money laundering for tax purposes.Taking into account the fact that we have always voted for the texts making it possible to fight against tax evasion and money laundering, we support these new proposals which will offer the administrations of the Member States the possibility of automatically accessing money laundering information.in order to strengthen the fight against tax evasion.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The theme of the report is certainly interesting and noteworthy.Nonetheless, I am not convinced that an advisory opinion from the EU can make an effective contribution in the fight against money laundering and in preventing cases such as "Luxleaks" and the "Panama papers".For these reasons I expressed myself with an abstention.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the creation of a public registry of companies containing the relevant tax information has been included in the report, in addition to reiterating that the fight against tax fraud and avoidance it is an absolute priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as it sets out Parliament's position on the Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU on access to information in the fight against money laundering.To ensure fairer and more efficient taxation in the European Union, the European Commission is pursuing an ambitious agenda to combat tax evasion and avoidance.One of the most important items on this agenda is greater tax transparency.2016February 2In the Action Plan to Strengthen the Fight against Terrorist Financing adopted in 2016, the Commission committed itself toto present in the first half of the year a proposal for amendments to the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive aimed at further tightening up anti-terrorist financing rules.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2-5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agree with the report and I also supported it, as past media revelations have shown money flowing into offshore tax havens and it has become clear that tax authorities need more powers and greater access to information about who the economic owners of these companies are.It is also important that the tax authorities are given the appropriate tools to be able to access this information properly and to cooperate within the framework of European legislation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report.The automatic and mandatory exchange of data between tax authorities against money laundering is a new step forward in the fight against tax evasion and tax evasion.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the amendments proposed by my colleague and rapporteur Mr Maurel because I think that combating tax evasion and tax avoidance is a political priority for the European Union. In this regard, a skilled staff is needed in order to facilitate a rapid and complete exchange of information.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European Commission is pursuing a program against tax evasion and avoidance to ensure fairer and more effective taxation in the EU. Significant progress has been made in strengthening tax transparency and cooperation between tax administrations across the Union. Member States have agreed on new rules for the automatic exchange of information on tax rulings and reporting on tax matters. The EU Tax Transparency Program is of key importance for identifying and addressing tax evasion effectively, as tax authorities need wider access to beneficial owner information of intermediary entities and other relevant information on the matter customer due diligence. This requires the effective and rapid implementation of the global standard for the automatic exchange of financial information for tax purposes, applied by Directive 2014/107 / EU, which also ensures that information on financial account holders is transmitted to the Member State. where the account holder resides. In the absence of anti-money laundering information, tax authorities will not be able to monitor, verify and confirm whether financial institutions properly apply the Administrative Cooperation Directive.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report is part of the European Commission’s proposal to amend the Directive on administrative cooperation in tax matters.This proposed amendment aims to facilitate access by tax authorities to specific information relating to the fight against money laundering.It is also requested to set up a public register of companies in order to promote the transmission of tax information between the Member States.We believe that this data exchange will help remove administrative obstacles that hamper the effectiveness of the work of national authorities in the fight against tax evasion.This is the reason why I voted in favor of this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - This initiative aims to extend the access of tax authorities to information on combating money laundering in order to achieve the objectives of monitoring the application of the Directive on administrative cooperation by financial institutions. Combating tax evasion and tax avoidance has always been a priority for the European Union, increasing tax transparency as a key objective in the fight against money laundering. Given that tax administrations' access to information differs significantly in some regions of the Union, this proposal becomes appropriate in order to strengthen efforts against tax evasion. I am in favor of the report on the access of tax authorities to information on combating money laundering, as I believe it is essential to strengthen cooperation between the tax authorities in the Member States in order to combat fraudulent actions which are detrimental to the Union budget.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- This report constitutes Parliament's position on the revision of Directive 2011/16 / EU on access by tax authorities to information on the fight against money laundering.Parliament was consulted on this text.Thanks to this directive, the exchange of information relating to the fight against money laundering will be automatic between the Member States.The aim of this reform is to strengthen tax transparency and make the fight against money laundering more effective in the European Union.The Luxleaks and Panama Papers scandals have shown many flaws in this area.We must therefore act accordingly.I voted in favor of this report

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report which allows automatic access by Member States' tax authorities to information on money laundering. Systematic access by tax authorities to anti-money laundering information will allow for greater transparency and faster identification and processing of data, avoiding slowdowns and dysfunctions in administrative cooperation by financial institutions. The Directive will apply to taxes of any kind levied by or on behalf of a Member State or the territorial or administrative divisions of a Member State, including local authorities, as well as to virtual currency exchange services and digital wallet service providers. . Member States will have to ensure that all information exchanged and obtained is subject to timely investigations, regardless of whether such information was obtained from the authorities upon request, through a spontaneous exchange of information or through public leaks.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The Directive will place mandatory requirements on Member States on sovereign tax matters and personal information that could, just as easily, be agreed at an intra-governmental level, rather than via the EU. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which will help to fight money laundering and the large scale secret offshore funds which have hit the headlines in the past year. I am a firm believer that corruption and money laundering must be fought. The purpose of this report is to enable tax authorities to consistently access anti-money laundering information for the performance of their duties in monitoring the proper application of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation by Financial Institutions. Tax authorities of a Member State shall automatically exchange the documents and information on anti-money laundering with any other Member State.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The directive implementing global standards for the automatic exchange of tax information is under review and the proposal introduces the possibility for national tax authorities to access anti-money laundering information.This will help fight the financing of terrorism, corruption and other criminal activities.In the intentions of the colleague's report, the exchange of information should be automatic and mandatory, in order to ensure maximum transparency.Thanks to our contribution, the report also includes a sanctioning mechanism for banks that facilitate money laundering, such as the withdrawal of the banking license.I therefore voted firmly in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We abstain from the vote, as a very important amendment tabled by the European People's Party was not voted in favor, so we can not vote in favor of the report.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on the tax authorities' access to information on combating money laundering.Especially after the turmoil caused by the economic crisis in most Member States of the European Union, the importance of combating opacity and illegal economic activity has now been realized.That is why I voted in favor.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Abstention vote for this report aimed at strengthening anti-money laundering rules at European level.The legislative intervention, while laudable in its intentions, leads to the damage done (see Panama Papers and similar) and will not be decisive in preventing new cases.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - In the light of what emerged from the Panama Papers or often raised in the news, it is a priority for the Union to take political and diplomatic action against operations that conceal practices of tax fraud, evasion and money laundering and therefore my approval is clear to the provision. For an effective fight against phenomena such as evasion, avoidance and aggressive tax planning, a stubborn implementation of a community standard for the automatic exchange of information on the holders of financial accounts and of the disputed intermediaries is essential. While waiting and hoping that this format will reach global application, States are invited to produce information of the same quality, precisely, only through the compatibility of the same and the connected reading systems does the automatic standard become functional. . Certainly, the work of the authorities is dictated and proceeds along the pavement of transparency implemented by citizens. They must comply not only with legality, but act in accordance with the provisions of the rules on transparency in order not to further complicate an already impervious framework in its existence. However, citizens' freedoms must be kept intact and far from Parliament to set up repressive systems against fundamental rights or that discourage economic activities through bureaucratic snares.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. – I supported the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards access to anti-money-laundering information by tax authorities and noted no objections.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the provision as I find it very useful that tax authorities are allowed to have systematic access to anti-money laundering information for the performance of their functions of monitoring the correct application of the Directive on administrative cooperation by the institutionsfinancial.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call for political and diplomatic action aimed at eliminating offshore centres at global level. I believe that the Swissleaks, Luxleaks, Panama Papers and Bahamas Leaks revelations are individual manifestations of a global phenomenon which, as stated by the report, have confirmed the paramount need for greater tax transparency and much closer coordination and cooperation between jurisdictions. Mandatory automatic exchange of tax information is recognised internationally as the most effective instrument in the achievement of international tax transparency, and as the EU we need to see that it is implemented diligently. Union rules on the prevention and combating of money laundering have over time incorporated changes in international standards, with the aim of strengthening Member State coordination and responding to the challenges faced at global level. In this sense, I am increasingly concerned with the interlinking links between money laundering, the funding of terrorism, organised crime and tax evasion and avoidance. Time is ripe to see to this.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - I have spoken in favor of the Maurel report. Following the recent scandals such as Luxleaks or the Panama Papers, a European response in the fiscal field was highly anticipated. The aim of this report is to facilitate greater and more effective control that can limit and combat corruption, money laundering, tax avoidance and evasion in Europe. We are well aware that a measure in this sense is necessary, even in the fight against terrorism, as greater control makes it difficult for armed terrorist groups to deal with and move large sums of money. An important feature to underline is the new possibility for an automatic and mandatory exchange of information between tax authorities and banks in order to ensure greater transparency, and also a sanctioning mechanism that provides for the withdrawal of the banking license in the event of a proven charge of money laundering. black money.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, because it represents an improvement in the requirements regarding access to information by the tax authorities.With the development of all the tax scandals produced in recent years: Luxleaks, Panamaleaks, Bahamaleaks ... the public has become aware of the tax practices of the main players in the financial system.This proposal is born from the pressure of public opinion to act in this area and allow access to relevant tax information for tax evaders.Access to information by the competent authorities is a necessary step, in order to implement the principle of paying taxes where wealth is created and carry out actions against tax havens.It is for all this that I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The amendments to the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive, proposed by the Commission in July 2016, are important to improve the identification of money laundering, corruption, terrorism, financing and other criminal activities. The aim of this report is to allow tax authorities to have constant access to anti-money laundering information in order to allow them to exercise their prerogatives in monitoring the correct application of the Administrative Cooperation Directive by financial institutions. I believe that this is a fundamental issue to be addressed at this delicate moment in the fight against terrorism. Compared to the Commission text, we have managed to integrate it in order to make the exchange of information between tax authorities on anti-money laundering matters mandatory and automatic. This was the positive result of our negotiations and I therefore vote with conviction in favor of this text.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - Disclosures in cases such as "Swissleaks", "Luxleaks" and "Panama Papers" confirmed the fundamental need to increase fiscal transparency and intensify coordination and cooperation between institutions. Given the global nature of anti-money laundering, this cooperation is essential for an effective fight against these practices. European Union rules on preventing and combating money laundering have integrated changes to international standards in order to strengthen coordination between Member States in response to global challenges, especially due to the links between money laundering, terrorist financing and organized crime. and tax evasion. We voted for a more efficient automatic and mandatory exchange of information in the field of taxation, in support of achieving international tax transparency. Combating tax evasion and avoidance is an absolute priority for the Union.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The proposal to amend the tax authorities' access to information on the fight against money laundering was preceded by the revelation of tax fraud and money laundering practices leaked by the press. What has happened has highlighted the need for greater tax transparency and closer judicial coordination and cooperation. In this context, political and diplomatic action should be sought to eliminate offshore centers at the global level. One of the European Union's basic priorities is the fight against tax evasion, including money laundering. The amendment highlights the strengthening of coordination between Member States on EU legislation on preventing and combating money laundering. The purpose of the amendment is to allow public authorities continuous access to information and documents related to the fight against money laundering in order to ensure maximum transparency and to monitor the proper application of the Directive and to seek closer cooperation with financial institutions. This Directive shall enter into force on 1 January 2018.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I abstained from the vote on tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information.The regulation aims to ensure that tax authorities have consistent access to anti-money laundering information.Currently, access to such information varies across the EU.Accordingly, the changes would give tax authorities access to customer information as part of the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive.The abstention is justified by the remarks made in the arrangements with the Council of the European Union.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Automatic and mandatory exchange of anti-money laundering information between tax authorities is a new step forward in the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering in the EU.  I am favour of this report as it improves tax transparency by enabling tax authorities in the EU to have access to national anti-money-laundering information. This initiative also facilitates the proper application of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation by Financial Institutions and does not impinge majorly on Member State sovereignty in this regard.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This report aims to consult the European Parliament on questions of transparency of the European and international tax system.The finding is clear: tax authorities need better access to information from intermediary entities in order to be able to identify and effectively eliminate tax evasion.This report therefore proposes that tax authorities should be able to systematically access information relating to money laundering.Considering that this report clarifies and improves the efficiency of the anti-fraud system in tax matters, I voted in favor.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ The Directive will place mandatory requirements on Member States on sovereign tax matters and personal information that could, just as easily, be agreed at an intra-governmental level, rather than via the EU. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on access by tax authorities to information relating to the fight against money laundering in order to enable these authorities to obtain the information necessary to ensure the correct application of thelegislation on administrative cooperation by financial institutions.Recent events have shown us the need to strengthen tax transparency in order to fight fraud.To achieve this, tax authorities must in particular be able to systematically access information enabling them to identify the beneficial owners of financial transactions.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2-5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing.- Imposing the sharing of tax information, automatic and mandatory, between states was at the heart of Emmanuel Maurel's report.The Commission, in its legislative package intended to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism, did not propose it, even though it is a tool unanimously recognized and considered to be the most effective for countering optimization practices.and tax evasion.This fight was won in the hemicycle.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this report.This is a draft amendment to Directive 2011/16 / EU, on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation.This project implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters within the European Union.The central improvements of this directive consist in allowing tax authorities to access specific information in the context of the fight against money laundering for tax purposes.States would be forced to provide a response within three months.A business register would also be made available to the public.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - In times of economic crisis, where incomes are shrinking and taxes are being levied, the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, including in relation to money laundering, is vital. The revelations in the SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers and Bahamas Leaks cases, which are isolated manifestations of a global phenomenon, confirm the absolute need for greater tax transparency and much closer coordination and cooperation between jurisdictions.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2 to 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which should increase transparency for banking and financial transactions. This is an issue on which my constituents in Wales feel strongly, particularly as governments bailed out the banks during the financial crisis but made massive cuts in public services.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We support all measures aimed at improving access to information and cooperation between tax administrations in national states. In this sense, including the entire collection of typified information in the context of the fight against money laundering in terms of administrative cooperation represents a positive step. We underline, however, that only in cases where this information is exchanged automatically can practical results be obtained. Regarding the fight against money laundering, however, it is important not to entertain illusions. It will not be possible to combat this phenomenon by relying only on the due diligence duties of private companies and the financial system. As has been criticized by many organizations, the results of the fight against money laundering have been residual over the past few decades. In other words, money laundering, as well as tax evasion and fraud, are one of the faces of the liberal economy and the capitalist system. In this sense, the recovery of public control over banking and the financial system is a necessary condition for combating these phenomena more effectively and for a better functioning of the economy.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The main objective of this initiative is to give tax authorities consistent and continuous access to money laundering information.Reducing tax evasion and avoidance, including in relation to money laundering, must be an absolute priority for the European Union and its Member States.Repressive forces in this area need to be facilitated and actively assisted in identifying the real beneficiaries of illegally obtained funds.Quality material equipment and the related use of state-of-the-art information and communication technologies must be a matter of course.Only these will make it possible to trace money laundering activities at an early stage.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I abstain because the report is belated and only expresses a "consultative" opinion.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - I am in favor of the tax authorities' access to information on combating money laundering, as well as in times of economic crisis, where incomes are shrinking and taxes are being levied, the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, inter alia, in relation to money laundering is vital. The revelations in the SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers and Bahamas Leaks cases, which are isolated manifestations of a global phenomenon, confirm the absolute need for greater tax transparency and much closer coordination and cooperation between jurisdictions.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the outcome of the report, as automatic and mandatory exchange of anti-money laundering information between tax authorities is a new step forward in the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering in the EU. Hence, I strongly support the exchange of AML information between tax authorities to be mandatory and automatic. Tax administrations’ access to AML information differs considerably throughout the EU. Even when this access is granted, authorities often still encounter significant barriers that hinder the effectiveness of their work against tax avoidance and evasion. The amendments to the Fourth Anti-Money-Laundering Directive, proposed by the Commission in July 2016, are important to improve the identification of money-laundering, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities. Tax authorities should also have access to such information in order to maximise their capacity to tackle tax evasion and avoidance.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2-5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2 to 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report with the intention of supporting the fight against tax evasion and money laundering.This fact, alone, should prompt political and diplomatic action with the goal of eliminating offshore financial centers around the world.Therefore, tax authorities need to be able to quickly and fully access information on money laundering and have sufficient and duly qualified personnel to carry out this task and the ability to exchange such information automatically and obligatorily, to take advantage ofmaximizing synergies resulting from cooperation at national, international and Union level.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate the automatic exchange within the framework of the consultation procedure, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide the information beyond financial institutions, in line with the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, has been lost. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public registry of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance Tax is a top priority for the Union. We Spanish socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, at the same time that we continue to demand the communitarianization of tax policy.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I am in favor of the legislative changes introduced to this important text, which I was able to follow personally in the Committee on Legal Affairs.This reform also allows national tax authorities to have access to mandatory information under anti-money laundering rules.It is a significant step forward given that the skills and competences of tax authorities vary a lot from country to country: with the amendments to the fourth anti-money laundering directive, it will be possible to improve cooperation between tax authorities and better identification of movements at risk of evasion, avoidanceand economic crime.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to anti-money laundering information, because the fundamental aim of the initiative is to enable tax authorities to have greater access to anti-money laundering information, in application of the directive on administrative cooperation between financial institutions, which constitutes the regulatory framework for many of the EU actions in the field of tax transparency. The mandatory exchange of anti-money laundering information between tax authorities is a new milestone in the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering in the EU. The link between tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering requires the greatest possible recourse to the synergies resulting from cooperation at national, European and international level between the different authorities involved in the fight against these crimes and abuses. The emergence of scandals such as SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks and Panama Papers have confirmed the absolute need for greater tax transparency, closer coordination and cooperation between jurisdictions. I therefore shared the invitation to the Commission to analyze the possible role of the banking system and financial operators in promoting money laundering.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- As a MEP of the Family Party, I am fighting for new and full tax justice and transparency.That is why I voted in favor of tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - Disclosed "Panama Papers" leaked from Mosack Fonseca in Panama showed how its lawyers assisted their international clients with money laundering and non-payment of taxes. As a consequence of this and other tax scandals, the European Commission has launched an ambitious program to combat tax evasion. At the November plenary session, the European Parliament adopted new legislation to counteract such practices more effectively. The new rules will provide tax authorities with the ability to access information about companies and require them to exchange data. Combating tax evasion is the overarching goal of achieving a more efficient and fair tax system in the EU. In this context, increased tax transparency is essential, as well as enhanced cooperation between tax authorities in the EU. Access by tax administrations to anti-money laundering information varies considerably between Member States. Even when access is granted, authorities often face numerous obstacles that limit the effectiveness of their activities. The new rules are essential to better detect money laundering, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The fight against money laundering is a central task that the European Economic and Monetary Union has been facing for years.The exchange of information between tax authorities makes it possible to fight money laundering in the European Union even more effectively and to drive back criminal organizations.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this directive because it seeks to place mandatory requirements on EU Member States on sovereign tax matters that could, just as easily, be agreed at an intra-governmental level, rather than at EU level.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this proposal, which will allow tax authorities to have access to vital information about company ownership so we can take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, in turn in favor of the Commission's proposal to oblige the exchange of information on money laundering between Member States, in order to combat money laundering and tax evasion.The final date of entry into force is 2017, considered more realistic by practically all parties.The amendments made by Parliament also oblige the exchange of information on the beneficial owners of companies, making evasion difficult through the use of shell companies.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which will allow tax authorities to have access to vital information about company ownership so we can take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing.- "LuxLeaks", "SwissLeaks", "Panama papers" ...
