All these scandals highlight the unacceptable practices of tax evasion and fraud, and above all, our duty to fight them.The initial proposal of the European Commission on these subjects was too timid.Indeed, the only national access to information on the holders of bank accounts of European territories did not allow the use of the most effective weapon at our disposal for the fight against money laundering and for more transparency: theautomatic and compulsory exchange of information.Emmanuel Maurel's report, for which I voted, responds to this lack by recommending the establishment of an automatic and compulsory mechanism for the exchange of data between the tax authorities of the European Union and shows the way towardstax justice and tax equality, which must be our priorities.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2-5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. Accordingly, professional interest in the subject has grown internationally in recent years. The legislative process is showing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to researchers. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally harmonize and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- We voted in favor of the report, as it strengthens the effort to combat the trafficking of black money.Under the report, the tax authorities of each Member State will be able to exchange, within three months of their collection, documents and information on taxable persons / account holders.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I vote in favour of this report on the European Commission’s proposal to enable tax authorities in the EU to have access to national anti-money-laundering information. One area identified by the Commission in its recent efforts to boost tax transparency is to ensure that tax authorities have greater access to data provided under the EU’s anti-money-laundering rules, particularly information on beneficial owners, such as checking the identity of customers and monitoring account activity for suspicious transactions. Anti-money-laundering information will now be included in mandatory automatic exchanges between national tax authorities, transmitting documents and information within six months of their collection to a Member State in which a beneficial owner is a taxpayer.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- The fight against money laundering and tax avoidance needs to be improved.It is obvious that national authorities also need information from other EU member states for this.The demand for an automatic exchange of information between the authorities of the EU member states is absolutely necessary.At the same time, it is important to ensure that the national authorities can process this information with adequately qualified personnel and that the data is treated confidentially.As a result, the report makes good proposals for improving European administrative cooperation with the aim of combating tax fraud and money laundering.I support these concerns and have voted for the report.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2 to 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. The report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important task now, which is why I supported the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The rapid exchange of anti-money laundering information between tax authorities at a national and international level should be mandatory in order to aid the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering in the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending the directive as regards tax authorities' access to information on the prevention of money laundering, as I consider it necessary to ensure more efficient, clearer and fairer taxation in the European Union.I support measures to give the tax authorities access to all the information necessary for those authorities to carry out their duties effectively.This provides access to the mechanisms, documents, procedures and information that are indispensable in order to strengthen the European and international transparency framework, and to prevent money laundering.In addition, information needs to be exchanged automatically between tax authorities and international cooperation in this area needs to be strengthened.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The Panama Papers revelations showed once more how essential it is to ensure proper exchange of information on bank data. With these new rules, tax authorities with anti-money laundering responsibilities in any EU country will have to automatically share information such as bank account balances, interest income and dividends with their counterparts in other Member States. I believe automaticity is the only way this sharing of information can work. Money laundering, terrorist financing, organised crime and tax evasion are all interlinked and recognise no borders, which is why tax authorities need to have equal access to anti-money-laundering information in all Member States.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Emmanuel Maurel on access by tax authorities to information relating to the fight against money laundering.This report aims to change the rules on administrative cooperation for more efficiency, by introducing enhanced cooperation between European authorities.As this is a phenomenon that transcends borders and affects all European countries, it is only through a European approach that this problem will be solved.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which aims to allow tax authorities systematic access to information relating to money laundering activities.The recent scandals show that the fight against money laundering must be stepped up and that tax authorities must have access to this information, so that financial institutions correctly apply the law in force, and in particular the Directive onadministrative cooperation of financial authorities.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I support the calls in this report for a more effective fight against tax evasion and avoidance.I hope that this report will provide further impetus to increase tax transparency and thus create more fairness in the payment of taxes.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on anti-money laundering information, because the Panama Papers scandal showed that some of the most egregious tax evaders are able to get away with it by concealing information about who truly owns a company. With this proposal, the EU will allow tax authorities to have access to this vital information, and thereby we can take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- The fight against money laundering and tax avoidance needs to be improved.It is obvious that national authorities also need information from other EU member states for this.The demand for an automatic exchange of information between the authorities of the EU member states is absolutely necessary.At the same time, it is important to ensure that the national authorities can process this information with adequately qualified personnel and that the data is treated confidentially.As a result, the report makes good proposals for improving European administrative cooperation with the aim of combating tax fraud and money laundering.I support these concerns and have voted for the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I was very pleased to support the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to anti-money laundering information, as the role of bank accounts and companies based in tax havens and non-cooperating jurisdictions proved to be the common denominator in the huge range of generally uncovered and created transactions that conceal tax fraud, capital flight and money laundering practices. This in itself should trigger political and diplomatic steps to eliminate offshore centers at the global level, but unfortunately the Council has been inactive for too long. At the same time, the observed link between tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering calls for full use to be made of the synergies resulting from domestic, EU and international cooperation between the various bodies involved in the fight against these crimes and offenses. Issues such as the transparency of beneficial ownership or the extent to which entities, such as the legal professions, are covered by the anti-money laundering framework in third countries are crucial to strengthening the Union institutions' capacity to tackle tax avoidance and money laundering.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2 to 5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour to this amendment of anti-money-laundering directive since it states clearly the obligations of tax authorities of all Member states to collect and automatically exchange fiscal information about beneficiaries and account holders within three months period.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing. - Thanks to today's fact-finding press, it is becoming increasingly difficult to sweep under the rug the fact of the international prevalence and huge volume of tax abuses. Data from Swissleaks, Luxleaks, Panama Papers and Bahamas leaks make it clear that much greater tax transparency, as well as closer judicial coordination and cooperation, is needed to effectively combat this type of global phenomenon. There is no doubt that significant progress has been made in the last few years, but much remains to be done, for example, it is appropriate for large multinationals to publish their tax data on a country-by-country basis. An important statement of the Directive is that the Commission should analyze the role that the banking system and financial service providers can play in facilitating money laundering. Sufficiently dissuasive sanctions are also needed, up to and including the withdrawal of authorizations. For my part, I have supported all actions so far in relation to money laundering, tax evasion and corruption, and I will continue to do so.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards tax authorities' access to information on combating money laundering. Combating tax evasion and avoidance, including in relation to money laundering, is an absolute priority of the Union, which needs to ensure effective control by the relevant institutions carrying out comprehensive checks, which could not happen. without access to information - direct, timely and complex. Information regularly introduced into harmonized ICT systems between Member States will improve the functioning of all levels of administrative cooperation. The proposal for a directive also states the importance of exchanging up-to-date information, which will contribute to an effective investigation. The Directive, annexed to the national law of each Member State, should support and make much more reliable the work of public institutions in the fight against tax fraud.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ We should support and adopt the Commission’s proposal to amend Directive 2011/16/EU so that tax authorities with anti-money-laundering (AML) responsibilities in any EU country can have consistent access to AML information, procedures, documents and mechanisms in other Member States. In this sense, it is important to note that including AML information in mandatory automatic exchanges between national tax authorities will be an important step in the fight against tax avoidance and evasion because it will improve tax transparency. Nevertheless, I call on the EU to extend the scope of AML information available to national tax authorities with regard to virtual currency exchange services and custodial wallet providers to limit money laundering in the digital age.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The report approved today aims to allow tax authorities to have systematic access to anti-money laundering information and to carry out their functions of observation on the correct and appropriate application of the directive on administrative cooperation. This is in order to strengthen the EU and international transparency measures, so that the tax authorities are able to have as much information about customers as possible, also preventing tax evasion phenomena. In order to be able to provide for mechanisms of this magnitude, it is necessary for the Member States to exchange information and documents relating to financial movements in a fully automated manner. Directive 849/2015 / EU will allow them to access this information while monitoring the correct application of the rules on the automatic exchange of tax information. Finally, access to this information will ensure that tax authorities are better prepared to fulfill their monitoring obligations, thus being able to prevent tax evasion and tax fraud.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing.- The recent cases revealed by the "LuxLeaks" or the "Panama papers" have brought to light too many breaches of European legislation on money laundering, tax fraud and tax evasion.I therefore voted in favor of this report, which proposes new measures to strengthen the transparency framework.The aim is for tax authorities to have access to all the information they need, particularly with regard to the identification of the beneficial owners of offshore companies.Thus, we are committed to taking concrete action against financial crime.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on access by tax authorities to information relating to the fight against money laundering. The proposal in question consists in allowing tax administrations to automatically access information relating to money laundering in order to strengthen the fight against tax evasion, in particular after the problems of information exchange revealed by the “Panama” case. papers ”. The access of tax administrations to information on money laundering varies considerably from one Member State to another. Even when such access is granted, authorities sometimes face major obstacles that hamper the effectiveness of their work in combating tax evasion and fraud. In order to ensure effective monitoring of the application by financial institutions, it is therefore necessary that the tax authorities have access to information relating to the fight against money laundering.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- This directive implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters within the Union.As such, it ensures that information on financial account holders is communicated to the Member State in which the account holder resides.This is a measure that we support, we who voted for the anti-money laundering directive, as well as for the directive on the exchange of tax information.I am in favor of this project, which can only be positive for the fight against money laundering.I logically voted for.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, because it represents an improvement in the requirements regarding access to information by the tax authorities.With the development of all the tax scandals produced in recent years: Luxleaks, Panamaleaks, Bahamaleaks ... the public has become aware of the tax practices of the main players in the financial system.This proposal is born from the pressure of public opinion to act in this area and allow access to relevant tax information for tax evaders.Access to information by the competent authorities is a necessary step, in order to implement the principle of paying taxes where wealth is created and carry out actions against tax havens.It is for all this that I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This report seeks to make exchanges between the authorities of the Member States more agile and faster and, therefore, it is possible to better fight against money laundering.In this sense, the report recalls that the fight against tax evasion, particularly in connection with money laundering, is one of the main challenges for the European Union.Proof of this is that recent events have confirmed that today it is essential to implement greater fiscal transparency together with greater international coordination and cooperation.I vote in favor of the report, as the global nature of money laundering requires an efficient and effective response, which can only be achieved through international cooperation.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- The fight against money laundering and tax avoidance needs to be improved.It is obvious that national authorities also need information from other EU member states for this.The demand for an automatic exchange of information between the authorities of the EU member states is absolutely necessary.At the same time, it is important to ensure that the national authorities can process this information with adequately qualified personnel and that the data is treated confidentially.As a result, the report makes good proposals for improving European administrative cooperation with the aim of combating tax fraud and money laundering.I support these concerns and have voted for the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which aims to find new solutions to combat the concealment of offshore funds through increased transparency.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Council Directive 2011/16 / EU11, as amended by Directive 2014/107 / EU12, applies from 27 January 2016 to 27 Member States and from 1 January 2017 to Austria. This Directive introduces a global standard for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in tax matters within the Union. It ensures that the Member State in which the account holder is resident is informed of information on the holders of financial accounts in order to combat tax evasion, tax evasion and aggressive tax planning. Cases such as Swissleaks and Panama papers have reaffirmed the need for greater tax transparency and closer coordination among institutions, and given the global nature of anti-money laundering activities, international cooperation is key to combating such activities effectively and efficiently. The existence of automatic, mandatory and constant exchange of information in the field of taxation between different competent authorities is key to ensuring maximum transparency and obtaining a basic instrument for preventing and combating fraud of all kinds. Mandatory automatic exchange of information on tax issues is internationally recognized as the most effective instrument in the service of international tax transparency at the level of the G20, OECD and European Union countries. I consider the fight against tax evasion and avoidance to be an absolute priority for the Union, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal will make further progress in the fight against tax avoidance and tax evasion. For too long, Member States have turned a blind eye on tax evasion, leaving the circulation of huge flows of funds undetected.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Those who avoid paying tax always focus on less transparent regimes and exploit their weaknesses. In order to limit such possibilities and to ensure a level playing field between Member States, a common set of rules is needed to enable tax authorities to fulfill their monitoring obligations. Tax fraud and evasion damage the economies of the Union and its Member States, are closely linked to corruption, non-transparency, money laundering and terrorist support crime and organized crime. I therefore supported the motion for an EP resolution amending the Council directive regulating tax authorities' access to anti-money laundering information. Sufficient personnel and material equipment of tax and customs authorities, mandatory automatic exchange of information, international cooperation of authorities in the field of taxation, consistent legislation for the banking and financial sector, including the tracing of real owners of companies is a means to achieve international tax transparency. Member States are required to bring their legislation into line with this Directive by 31 December 2017 at the latest.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- Following the various tax evasion scandals, the Commission presented last July a legislative package aimed at combating money laundering and the financing of terrorism.In this context, the report recommends an automatic and compulsory exchange of information on bank account holders between tax administrations.Fraud as well as aggressive tax avoidance and optimization are scourges for the economy which must be firmly combated through a coordinated effort by all Member States;that is why I am voting in favor of this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by the tax authorities to information on combating money laundering, for the reasons I have set out in detail in my speechat the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 22 November 2016, as well as because this report is substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.Its objective is to give tax authorities systematic access to information relating to the fight against money laundering.The Directive, by ensuring the disclosure of information on financial account holders, applies the global standard for the automatic exchange of information in this area.In addition, when this holder is an intermediate structure, it allows financial institutions to examine this structure and identify its beneficial owners.We endorse these measures for tax transparency and improving the efficiency of the work of tax authorities.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Access to anti-money-laundering information by tax authorities. Cooperation, in the form of information exchange, is crucial for Member States to be able to combat tax fraud, tax evasion, and money laundering. With scandals such as the Panama Papers, Luxleaks and Bahamas Leaks, to name a few, taking over the world, it is necessary to develop a new set of measures for greater tax transparency. One of those measures includes automatic exchange of tax information and hence, one reason for my positive vote. Finally, yet importantly, the exchange should go hand in hand with improved technology that can trace money-laundering activities.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- This report deals with the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU, reinforcing the idea that combating tax evasion and tax avoidance is (or should be) an EU priority.The Luxleaks, Panama Papers and other scandals confirm the need for greater fiscal transparency and cooperation between jurisdictions.It has therefore been established that the tax authorities of the Member States will automatically exchange, within three months of their collection, the documents and information communicated with any other Member State if the beneficial owner of a company or any other holder of aan account is a taxpayer in that Member State.In addition, it was also decided that access should be granted to the Commission to carry out its tasks, on a confidential basis.I voted in favor.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - The Commission, the European Parliament and the Member States are in the process of finalizing a major reform aimed at better monitoring and repressing corruption, money laundering and the financing of terrorism (so-called "AMLD I" directive). The Commission proposed that the information thus collected should be accessible to national tax authorities. This concerns in particular access to the central registers of beneficial owners of companies and trusts that will be set up in each State. With this report, I have obtained, through fruitful negotiations with the other political groups, that each state automatically shares information with the other countries concerned. In order to combat this essentially globalized phenomenon, the automatic and compulsory exchange of information is considered by all experts to be the most effective weapon at the disposal of public authorities. By voting for this report and garnering near unanimity in Parliament, I hope that it can serve as a useful instrument of pressure on European governments, which are still very hesitant about tax transparency.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- In order to enable a more efficient fight against tax evasion and avoidance and thus to achieve an increase in tax transparency, I agree to the proposal in the present form.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor.Tax authorities must be able to obtain more easily the information needed to detect tax evasion.I hope that this will help the responsible authorities to prevent tax evasion more effectively and increase tax transparency.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - The Commission proposal aims to amend Council Directive 2011/16 / EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. It introduces a provision allowing tax authorities to have access to specific information relating to the fight against money laundering for tax purposes. The report takes up this proposal by specifying certain elements. Thus, he stresses that to be effective the tax authorities must have "sufficient human resources and qualified to carry out this task." The report promotes "an automatic, compulsory and continuous exchange of information between the various authorities competent in the tax field". The transmission deadline is set at three months after the information has been collected. Tax avoidance systems such as that revealed in the "Luxleaks" case are specifically called into question. Finally, the report sets as an objective "the extinction of offshore centers on a global scale". I vote for this text without illusion as to its effects.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report is the result of a consultation procedure of the Parliament, following the proposal of the European Commission which should modify the directive (2011/16 / EU) on administrative cooperation in the fiscal field allowing the tax authorities toaccess information on the fight against money laundering.This amendment establishes a global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters within the Union.The recent scandals in this area have highlighted gaps in the exchange of tax information and have highlighted the measures to be taken to support tax transparency at European and international level.Having already voted for the Anti-Money Laundering Directive, as well as for the Directive on the exchange of tax information, I voted for this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Combating tax evasion and tax avoidance, including in connection with money laundering, is an absolute priority for the European Union.The mandatory automatic exchange of information on tax matters is recognized at the international level, within the framework of the G20, the OECD and the European Union, as the most effective instrument for achieving international tax transparency.In order to achieve the objectives of this Directive, it is necessary for the Commission to study the possible role of the banking system and financial operators in facilitating money laundering.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Report, which aims to tackle corrupt practices and illegal, abusive money laundering. We have seen with the Panama Papers scandal that we need to come down hard on those unscrupulous individuals who abuse the system to the detriment of the taxpayer.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- Following the various scandals, including those related to the Panama Papers, it was essential that such a report be adopted.The aim is to allow an automatic exchange between national tax authorities of information on the holders of bank accounts.Having access to records that record all of the beneficial owners of bank accounts, their income from interest and dividends, it will be easier to fight tax evasion and money laundering.It is after all about better arming those responsible for upholding the rule of law in the EU.But, as we see from the Panama Papers Commission of Inquiry, the fight does not end there.Cooperation between Member States and coordination at European level must continue to be strengthened.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which gives its green light to a proposal that will allow the exchange of sensitive information concerning money laundering between tax authorities.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Commission has proposed to the Council the adoption of a Directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access to tax information by the tax authorities.Before adopting the proposal, the Council must consult Parliament.In its report, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs proposes that Parliament approve the proposal with 22 amendments and ask the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly.I voted accordingly.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text makes it possible to introduce a certain number of measures useful in the fight against money laundering.I therefore vote in favor.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on anti-money laundering information, because the Panama Papers scandal showed that some of the most egregious tax evaders are able to get away with it by concealing information about who truly owns a company. With this proposal, the EU will allow tax authorities to have access to this vital information and we can take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on access by tax authorities to information relating to the fight against money laundering.This practice, which consists of playing on the origin of the funds collected, allows criminals or terrorist organizations to meet their needs financially;it is therefore essential for the European Union to strengthen cooperation between its Member States to put an end to it.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - Access by tax authorities to anti-money laundering information differs significantly between Member States. Even when this access is guaranteed, the authorities still face significant obstacles that undermine the effectiveness of their work in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance. For these reasons, it is of fundamental importance to support measures aimed at guaranteeing the identification of these practices, often linked to corruption, financing of terrorist organizations and other criminal activities. The revelations that emerged, for example thanks to Luxleaks and Panama Papers, confirmed the absolute need for greater tax transparency as well as closer coordination and cooperation between national jurisdictions. That is why I supported the proposal to establish a central register complete with all beneficial owners of companies and trusts. I am also convinced that tax authorities must have horizontal access to information that can maximize the capabilities to tackle tax evasion and avoidance. An automatic and mandatory exchange of anti-money laundering information between the tax authorities of the different Member States is therefore a fundamental step in the fight against tax evasion, avoidance and money laundering. The gravity and persistence of these phenomena require immediate political action.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposal as I believe that the aim of this initiative is to allow tax authorities to have systematic access to anti-money laundering information.An automatic, mandatory and constant exchange of information on tax matters between the various competent authorities is essential, in order to ensure maximum transparency and have a basic tool to prevent and combat all types of fraudulent behavior.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 15 February 2011 the European Council issued Directive 2011/16/EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation. I have voted for this report that amends this Directive offering tax authorities anti-money laundering information.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - The dissatisfaction that European citizens have felt with the EU in recent years is not an inexplicable phenomenon. This can be largely explained by the fact that the main burden of dealing with the financial and economic crisis has been and continues to be borne by ordinary people. Meanwhile, influential, well-to-do figures are evading legal and financial responsibility through offshore centers, such as those revealed in the Panama Papers. In this context, I expressed my support for this resolution because it outlines the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, including in relation to money laundering, as a top priority for the EU. I hope that, once this struggle has been put on the agenda in the EU, concrete policy actions will follow to eliminate global offshore centers.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up.- The Directive on the access of tax authorities to information on combating money laundering applies to all types of taxes levied by or on behalf of a Member State or its territorial or administrative subdivisions, including local authorities, and virtual foreign exchange servicesand providers of digital wallets in custody.In order to achieve the objectives of this Directive, the Commission should assess the role that the banking system and financial operators can play in promoting money laundering.By virtue of its enhanced powers in the field of financial and banking regulation, the Union could therefore take action through an ad hoc proposal on increasing control and transparency for banking services and financial transactions and through possible sanctions.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because it is necessary for one of the European Union's priorities to continue to be to combat fraud and tax evasion, which is causing money laundering, which is so harmful to Member States' budgets.As we are considering an issue that affects not only Romania, but all European states, we voted to ensure a transparent environment, for the access of tax authorities to the financial information of persons and companies suspected of such acts, noting that these suspicions must bejustified, to prevent abuses.Moreover, an important aspect of the report is the proposal to improve the international cooperation of tax institutions by exchanging essential information to combat these activities, which often have a cross-border aspect.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. - I supported the report adopted through the consultation procedure, which aims to improve the fight against tax evasion, avoidance and aggressive tax planning. It is the mandatory automatic exchange of information in the field of taxation that is internationally recognized as the most effective tool in the effort to achieve international tax transparency. The report confirms that there are strong reasons for further expanding administrative cooperation between tax authorities to cover beneficial ownership information, and that the automatic exchange of beneficial ownership information can be integrated into the binding tax transparency framework already in place by the EU. The reality of these considerations is that all Member States are already participating in a pilot project to exchange information on beneficial owners and trusts. At the same time, however, only well-functioning tax authorities will use the information effectively obtained for better tax collection.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I am in favor of combating tax evasion more effectively and I am in favor of increasing tax transparency.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- This report deals with the automatic transfer by national financial authorities of data relating to money laundering activities.Indeed, as it stands, there is no obligation for the Member States of the European Union to share this type of information, which poses a problem in cases where the movements of money are cross-border.I voted in favor of this text because there is a need to apply more financial transparency at European Union level in the fight against money laundering - it is also a duty to our fellow citizens.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The directive lays down rules to combat tax evasion and aggressive tax policies.The aim is to prevent the emergence of offshore centers.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I support the draft directive that has been tabled.The fight against tax evasion and avoidance needs to be more effective and efficient.Tax evasion and avoidance are cross-border in nature, so action at national level alone is not enough.Adequate access to anti-money laundering information by tax authorities is needed to combat aggressive tax practices and to limit the scope for large-scale concealment.The implementation of the envisaged measures will enable the tax authorities to perform their duties properly.It is noteworthy that tax evasion and evasion deprive state budgets of billions of revenue each year and distort competition.It is therefore necessary to coordinate the fight against tax abuse at both EU and international level and to further expand administrative cooperation between tax administrations.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The revelations in the SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks, "Panama Papers" and Bahamas Leaks cases, which are isolated manifestations of a global phenomenon, confirm the absolute need for greater tax transparency and much closer coordination and cooperation between jurisdictions. In addition, the link between tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering requires international co-operation to make the fight against such activities effective and efficient. The report, which I voted in favor of, obliges the tax authorities in charge of combating money laundering, in any country of the European Union, to automatically share information such as bank account balances and interest income, and dividends, with their bond authorities in the other Member States. This will ensure maximum transparency and will be a key tool in preventing and combating fraudulent behavior of any kind.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal because I believe that the only way to prevent the concealment of offshore funds is to ensure that the European Union draws up a tax transparency program between Member States, which allowsan automatic and mandatory exchange of information.Accepting this proposal would also allow tax authorities to have faster access to information to prevent the crime of money laundering, corruption and terrorist financing.However, I believe that we should not exceed in the exercise of these functions, since we must also respect the data protected by the right to privacy.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Recent media leaks exposed the large-scale concealment of offshore funds. The main new element of the report is that the tax authorities of a Member State shall automatically exchange the documents and information on AML with any other Member State. As a substitute member in the ECON Committee, I supported this report because I believe that better cooperation is essential to ensure that Member States can counter money-laundering practices better.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this proposal, which amends Directive 2011/16 / EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation, by introducing measures to enable the tax authorities to have consistent access to information on money laundering. The affair of the Panamanian documents, which revealed a large concealment of money on the so-called offshore accounts, has shown us that we need to insist on greater transparency and control. Offshore companies operate in legal transactions without major assets, and personal data, an open giro account and a mailbox are sufficient for their registration. They mainly open in countries where low tax rates are in place. Due to the way of doing business in these countries, the founders of these companies are allowed to transfer money abroad and thus avoid paying taxes. This disrupts the tax system of the country of residence of the users of these services and leads to large tax fraud. The purpose of the report is to enable the tax authorities to have constant access to anti-money laundering information in the performance of their duties in monitoring the proper application of Directive 2011/16 / EU, and the automatic exchange of documents and information is required.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - This directive implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters within the Union. As such, it ensures that information on financial account holders is communicated to the Member State in which the account holder resides. In addition, Directive 2011/16 / EU provides that, where the account holder is an intermediary structure, financial institutions examine this structure and identify and report its beneficial owners. The proposal aims to amend Council Directive 2011/16 / EU on administrative cooperation in the field of taxation by introducing a provision allowing tax authorities to have access to specific information relating to the fight against money laundering to taxpayers. tax purposes. It is also called for the establishment of a public register of companies which would guarantee access to information, and the obligation for Member States to automatically transmit tax information which could be of interest to another Member State within three months. after their collection. I support these effective measures against fraud and money laundering and therefore vote in favor of this report.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The fight against money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance must continue to be a priority of the European Union. It is in everyone's interest that tax authorities have the most effective tools to do their job better, recover important resources (especially in times of economic difficulty such as the one we are going through) and ensure greater fiscal equity for all citizens. This report supports the Commission's proposals to amend the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive and the Administrative Cooperation Directive in order to facilitate the identification of perpetrators and access to information for tax authorities. Furthermore, thanks to the commitment of our group, the report requires that the exchange of information between the tax authorities becomes mandatory and automatic. Currently the rules for access to anti-money laundering information vary considerably between Member States and, even when such access is formally guaranteed, the cooperation of financial institutions is unsatisfactory and the authorities face significant obstacles which limit the effectiveness of their activity. It is therefore only right for the Commission to take action to improve the regulatory framework and for the European Parliament to support these efforts.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The fight against tax evasion and avoidance, including money laundering, is an absolute priority for the Union. The findings in the Swissleaks, Luxleaks, Panama and Bahamas documents, which are individual manifestations of the global phenomenon, have once again confirmed that greater tax transparency and much closer coordination between jurisdictions is of the utmost importance. Given its global character, international cooperation is key to combating such activities effectively and efficiently. Council Directive 2011/16 / EU11 introduces a global standard for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in tax matters within the Union. It shall ensure that the Member State in which the account holder is resident is informed of information on holders of financial accounts in order to combat tax evasion, avoidance and aggressive tax planning. Tax authorities need quick and complete access to AML information and sufficient staff with the appropriate skills available. This approach should be the result of a mandatory automatic exchange of information. Without such an approach and appropriate staff, these bodies would not be able to monitor, certify and audit that financial institutions are properly implementing Directive 2011/16 / EU by correctly identifying and reporting the beneficial owners of intermediary structures.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Naturally, we support all measures aimed at better access to information and better cooperation between the tax administrations of national states. In this sense, including the entire collection of information typified within the framework of the fight against money laundering in terms of administrative cooperation represents a positive step. We underline, however, that it seems essential that this information be exchanged automatically, so that this change will, in fact, have practical effects. Regarding the fight against money laundering, however, it is important not to entertain illusions. In our opinion, it is not possible to combat this phenomenon by relying only on the due diligence duties of private companies and the financial system. As has been criticized by many organizations, the results of the fight against money laundering have been residual over the past few decades. In other words, money laundering, like fraud and tax evasion, are one of the visible faces of the liberal economy and the capitalist system. In this sense, the recovery of public control over banks and the financial system is also a condition for a more effective fight against these phenomena, as well as for a better functioning of the economy.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ The automatic and mandatory exchange of anti-money laundering information between tax authorities is a new step forward in the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering in the EU. The main objective of this initiative is to enable tax authorities to consistently access the information for the performance of their duties in monitoring the proper application of the Directive on Administrative Cooperation by Financial Institutions. I consider this to be a crucial step to improve the identification of money-laundering, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities. I firmly believe tax authorities should also have access to such information in order to maximise their capacity to tackle tax evasion and avoidance through the Commission’s Directive on Administrative Cooperation. I would like to congratulate S&D rapporteur, Emmanuel Maurel, on passing the main objective of making the exchange of anti-money-laundering information between tax authorities mandatory and automatic with the support of a wide majority of political groups.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The European Commission is pursuing an ambitious program against tax evasion and avoidance in order to ensure fairer and more effective taxation in the EU. Improving tax transparency is a key element of this program. Member States have agreed on new rules for the automatic exchange of information on "tax rulings" and on country-by-country tax reporting by multinational corporations. Recently, leaks in the media that revealed a large-scale cover-up of offshore funds confirm the importance of the EU's tax transparency program. Without access by the tax authorities to such anti-money laundering information, the effectiveness of the monitoring of financial institutions in relation to the application of the Administrative Cooperation Directive would be significantly reduced. In the absence of this information, the authorities in question will not be able to monitor, verify and confirm whether financial institutions apply the Directive properly. For these reasons I have decided to vote in favor of this resolution.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - The Council Regulation aims to ensure that tax authorities have consistent access to anti-money laundering information so that they can carry out their duties of monitoring the correct application of the Administrative Cooperation Directive by financial institutions, such as trusts. Currently, access to anti-money laundering information varies across the EU. Therefore, the amendment would provide tax authorities with access to the beneficial ownership mechanisms, procedures, documents and information and underlying customer due diligence procedures as part of the 4th Anti-Money Laundering Directive. I have no objection to the changes made by the Commission to the Directive on Administrative Cooperation. Nevertheless, Parliament included elements of automatic exchange of information on anti-money laundering in its consultation, which was neither the aim of the original Commission proposal nor the Council compromise and was not taken into account. I have therefore abstained from voting.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on access by tax authorities to information relating to the fight against money laundering.Following the various tax evasion scandals, we have given our consent for the tax authorities in the Union to automatically share information on the holders of bank accounts.These measures are essential in the fight against money laundering and tax evasion, which are closely linked to the financing of terrorist activities and organized crime.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing.- The most recent cases concerning the processing of information in the Union justify the adoption of measures that reinforce the transparency framework, since the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance, including in connection with money laundering, is an absolute priority forthe European Union.In order to combat tax evasion, it is necessary to provide tax authorities with more and better information, namely, on the beneficial owners of intermediary entities.In order to achieve the objectives of the present directive, the Commission still needs to study the possible role of the banking system and financial operators in facilitating money laundering. This report aims to provide tax authorities with more and better information withas a clear objective the fight against tax evasion, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning.For the above, I support this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ The Directive will place mandatory requirements on Member States on sovereign tax matters and personal information that could, just as easily, be agreed at an intra-governmental level, rather than via the EU. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - Today I voted for the report by my colleague Emmanuel Maurel on the directive on the fight against money laundering. This report contains ambitious elements to create a European register of subsidiaries so that tax administrations can combat the scourge of money laundering and tax evasion. This report goes further than the Commission’s proposal for there to be an automatic exchange of tax data via this register to better track capital flows within the European Union. Equality before taxes and tax justice are top priorities for Socialist MEPs. And I welcome the adoption of this report, which offers concrete solutions. The European Parliament will now have to negotiate with the Council of the Union, representing the Member States, to arrive at a final text. Socialist and Democratic deputies will maintain a firm line so that the proposals in Emmanuel Maurel’s report are ratified.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- This report is in line with everything that we have been defending in the European Parliament, allowing tax authorities to consistently access information on anti-money laundering, in order to improve their performance in monitoring the application of the Directive onAdministrative cooperation by financial institutions.As we know, access to this information by the tax administration differs considerably within the EU.Even when this access is guaranteed, authorities often encounter significant barriers that hamper the effectiveness of their work against tax fraud and evasion.The amendments proposed by the Commission to the Directive are important to improve the identification of money laundering, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities.The automatic information exchange is also mandatory.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of this reform of the Administrative Cooperation Directive to allow access and exchange of information related to money laundering, and that in the anti-laundering Directive financial institutions are obliged to provide. Although it has been possible to incorporate, within the framework of the consultation procedure, that the exchange is automatic, the opportunity to expand the list of those obliged to provide information beyond financial institutions has been lost, in line with the Anti-Financial Directive. money laundering, such as: notaries, representatives, trusts, etc. On the other hand, it is very positive that, at the request of the PSOE, the report has included the creation of a public register of companies containing the relevant tax information, in addition to reiterating that the fight against fraud and avoidance tax is a top priority of the Union. We Spanish Socialists hope that the Council will take this report into account and incorporate these achievements, while we continue to demand the communitarianisation of tax policy.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - The fight against tax evasion must be a priority for the European Union and its Member States for several reasons. First of all, this tax evasion has negative repercussions on the public finances of the Member States, preventing them from carrying out, in particular, strong social policies to reduce poverty. This is all the more unacceptable given that the European Union is struggling to achieve the objective of reducing poverty that it had set itself through the Europe 2020 strategy. This fight must also be one of our priorities because the links between money laundering, terrorist financing, organized crime and tax evasion are real. This is why I voted in favor of this proposal, which obliges tax authorities in the EU to automatically share information on the holders of bank accounts such as bank balances or even income on interest and dividends. It will now be important to measure the effectiveness of these measures and, if necessary, to make the necessary changes to limit as much as possible this fraud, which is so harmful for our society.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- The fight against tax evasion and money laundering is a very important task of the modern state.Especially in a global world where various states and quasi-state entities offer a wide range of "tax haven" services.I therefore unequivocally support the draft resolution that has been tabled.At the same time, I would like to emphasize that the EU and the Member States must make every effort to ensure that the exchange of tax data between countries does not become a tool for human rights abuses or commercial espionage.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: in writing. - Emmanuel Maurel's report provides for an automatic and mandatory exchange of information covered by the AMLD directive between the tax administrations of the Member States. The fight against fraud, avoidance and aggressive tax optimization is a top priority for the European Union. However, the legislative package aimed at the fight against money laundering and the financing of terrorism, presented by the Commission last July, does not meet the challenge, in that it limits access to information collected only from national tax administrations. By recommending a compulsory and automatic exchange of information between Member States, this report urges the Commission, the Council and national public authorities to adopt more ambitious measures to combat money laundering. It embodies Parliament’s re-affirmed desire to guarantee the principle of equality before tax and to protect our social contract. Accordingly, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - This report concerns an amendment to Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access to anti-money laundering information by tax authorities. These amendments that were approved by the European Parliament will allow tax authorities to combat tax evasion and fraud more effectively, while also making tax authorities' control obligations more effective. The new approved rules will come into force in early 2018 and establish, among others, measures that authorize access to data on the beneficial owners of certain entities and on the duty of care towards their customers. I also endorse the position that access to data should result from the mandatory automatic exchange of information and the relevance of Member States to include that data in a centralized public register of companies, trust funds and other similar structures. In view of the above, my vote was in favor of the approval of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, in turn in favor of the Commission's proposal to oblige the exchange of information on money laundering between Member States, in order to combat money laundering and tax evasion.The final date of entry into force is 2017, considered more realistic by practically all parties.The amendments made by Parliament also oblige the exchange of information on the beneficial owners of companies, making evasion difficult through the use of shell companies.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the Council proposal for a directive on access to information for tax authorities to combat money laundering.The recently uncovered scandals of offshore funds have emphasized the importance of measures for a European and international transparency framework.The aim of the report is to enable the tax authorities to give constant access to anti-money laundering information so that they can perform their tasks and address tax evasion effectively.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, because it represents an improvement in the requirements regarding access to information by the tax authorities.With the development of all the tax scandals produced in recent years: Luxleaks, Panamaleaks, Bahamaleaks ... the public has become aware of the tax practices of the main players in the financial system.This proposal is born from the pressure of public opinion to act in this area and allow access to relevant tax information for tax evaders.Access to information by the competent authorities is a necessary step, in order to implement the principle of paying taxes where wealth is created and carry out actions against tax havens.It is for all this that I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it calls for the EU to be able to transfer our personal tax information between different countries.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - All the latest revelations, from 'Luxleaks' to 'Panama Papers' to 'Bahama Leaks', clearly show that we are dealing with a global phenomenon that requires greater tax transparency and much closer cooperation between jurisdictions. I therefore clearly endorse the proposal to amend the Money Laundering Directive presented by the Commission in July this year. We have succeeded in incorporating a strong requirement in the directive so that the fight against tax evasion and avoidance becomes an absolute priority for the Union. As there appears to be a direct link between tax evasion, tax avoidance and money laundering, it is essential that competent authorities have the opportunity to cooperate effectively. The directive therefore calls on the Member States to make the most of the synergies resulting from national, Union and international cooperation between the authorities involved in the fight against crime and abuse. An important aspect is the automatic, mandatory and continuous exchange of information in the field of taxation introduced by this Directive, which should apply from January 2018. This will ensure maximum transparency and provide the authorities with a basic tool to prevent and combat fraud of all kinds. As the problem of tax evasion is global, international coordination is indispensable for the effective fight against money laundering.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Disclosures in cases such as LuxLeaks and the Panama Papers show that the European Union urgently needs better fiscal transparency in order to meet the challenges of money laundering, tax evasion and tax avoidance. Directive 2011/16 / EU provides tax authorities with access to information, procedures, documents and mechanisms for carrying out their anti-money laundering tasks. This ensures that information on the holders of financial accounts is communicated to the Member States in which the account holder is resident. The Commission's proposal to amend this Directive is fundamentally right to state that without adequate access to anti-money laundering information, tax authorities cannot assess whether financial institutions correctly identify and report beneficial owners. Parliament's report goes a step further and proposes that the prevention of money laundering requires the rapid, constant, mandatory and, above all, automatic exchange of information between Member States. In addition, due to the global nature of anti-money laundering activities, cooperation between tax authorities is essential, making the most of integration at national, European and international levels. As Parliament's report confirms and in some respects further strengthens the Commission's proposal, I supported it in the vote.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: in writing. - Money laundering legitimizes money from illegal activities which then enter the market and distort healthy competition. Systematic tax evasion is thus perpetuated, depriving Member States of valuable tax revenues and suffocating state budgets. It is necessary to immediately withdraw the 500 euro banknotes in the European Union. Also, in my country Greece we must immediately adopt mandatory electronic transactions and use of plastic money over 300 euros. Only in this way will we be able to make effective tax planning which, under certain conditions, could lead to a substantial reduction in taxation.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The fight against money laundering and tax avoidance needs to be improved.It is obvious that national authorities also need information from other EU member states for this.The demand for an automatic exchange of information between the authorities of the EU member states is absolutely necessary.At the same time, it is important to ensure that the national authorities can process this information with adequately qualified personnel and that the data is treated confidentially.As a result, the report makes good proposals for improving European administrative cooperation with the aim of combating tax fraud and money laundering.I support these concerns and have voted for the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Large tax frauds are carried out using sophisticated cross-border and cross-border schemes.In order to detect them, it is important that control authorities have access to all relevant data.European cooperation in this area will help to detect them more quickly and save taxpayers' money.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on anti-money laundering information, because the Panama Papers scandal showed that some of the most egregious tax evaders are able to get away with it by concealing information about who truly owns a company. With this proposal, the EU will allow tax authorities to have access to this vital information and we can take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the proposal for a Council Directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU with regard to tax authorities' access to information to combat money laundering.This directive implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of information on financial accounts in tax matters (hereinafter “global standard”) in the Union.I am against the automated exchange of information.This violates banking and tax secrecy.In its basic program, the AfD advocates restoring banking and tax secrecy.The freedom of the citizen from automated surveillance is important to us.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The European Commission is implementing an ambitious program against tax evasion and avoidance.Recent media leaks that have revealed large-scale concealment of extraterritorial funds confirm the importance of the EU's tax transparency program.It has become apparent that tax authorities need greater access to information on anti-money laundering (AML) and on the beneficial owners of intermediaries, all with the aim of identifying and preventing tax evasion.An important new element of the report is the introduction of automatic exchange of AML data between the tax authorities of the Member States.I support this Report because the successful collection of information on tax liabilities and the prevention of money laundering will contribute to more efficient tax collection and fairer and more efficient taxation in the European Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to information on the prevention of money laundering.In the effective fight against tax evasion, the rapid, transparent and automatic exchange of financial account information for tax purposes is crucial.Scandals surrounding the concealment of offshore assets go hand in hand with tax evasion as well as money laundering, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities.Tax administrations' access to data varies greatly across the EU, so I welcome the establishment of a central register that can be accessed by tax administrations in all Member States.From now on, financial institutions will be able to identify the beneficial owners in cases where the account holder is an intermediary structure.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- The fight against money laundering, as well as transparency in banking and other transactions are our position.The report moves in the right direction and promotes the exchange of banking information between Member States within a period of 3 months.We voted in favor of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - In times of economic crisis, when incomes are shrinking and taxation is continuous, the fight against tax evasion and avoidance, including in relation to money laundering, is vital. The revelations in the SwissLeaks, LuxLeaks, Panama Papers and Bahamas Leaks cases, isolated but not unique manifestations of a global phenomenon, confirm the absolute need for greater tax transparency and much closer coordination and cooperation between jurisdictions.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. “Money laundering has become one of the most lucrative and large-scale businesses in the world today. According to the IMF, the volume of money laundering accounts for 2-5% of the combined GDP of all countries on Earth. As a result, professional interest in the subject has grown steadily in recent years. The legislative process is producing more and more results at both international and national levels, giving law enforcement a lot of extra work and offering more and more research topics to theorists. Such is the case with the current innovative proposal, which I myself welcome, and I am pleased that this report contains a series of measures aimed at effectively combating money laundering by criminal organizations. The proposed initiatives will finally coordinate and integrate existing standards and create a more targeted and focused, risk-based approach across the EU to combat money laundering more effectively. Unfortunately, the interconnection of registers is essential for the usability of this information due to the cross-border nature of business transactions and the interconnection of the internal market. The registers should therefore be interconnected as a matter of urgency and made available to public authorities and obliged entities. So this is our most important thing to do now.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report approving the Commission's proposal to amend Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards tax authorities' access to information on the fight against money laundering. I support the amendments proposed by the report, which emphasize that, given the global nature of the fight against money laundering, international cooperation is the key to an effective and efficient fight against such activities. The Luxleaks, the Panama Papers and the Bahamas leaks have indeed made it clear that there is a need for greater tax transparency and much closer judicial coordination and cooperation. For this to really happen, like the report, I urge the tax authorities to get the right support. The fight against tax evasion and avoidance, including its link to money laundering, must remain a top priority for the Union, but positive results cannot be long in coming.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - Recent media reports on the so-called The Panama Papers highlighted the very serious problem of money laundering and tax havens. This, and other similar scandals, made the European Union and the Member States aware of the need to strengthen cooperation in the fight against tax crimes. Thanks to the amendments to Directive 2011/16 / EU regarding access by tax authorities to anti-money laundering information, the European Union can make significant progress in combating tax avoidance and tax evasion. Member States cannot turn a blind eye to tax evasion, thereby allowing huge amounts of money to flow in the uncontrolled manner. Therefore, the tax authorities must have access to information on the extent of illegal money flows. In order to achieve this goal, the exchange of information between EU and national authorities is extremely important. At the same time, the right to privacy of EU citizens must be preserved.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The aim of this initiative is to enable tax authorities to have constant access to information on combating money laundering. This would allow them to effectively monitor the proper application of the Administrative Cooperation Directive by financial institutions. The access of tax administrations to information in this area differs considerably across the European Union. The amendments to the Fourth Anti-Money Laundering Directive, proposed by the European Commission in July 2016, are important to make it easier to identify fraud, corruption, terrorist financing and other criminal activities. Tax authorities should have access to such information in order to maximize their ability to combat tax fraud and evasion. At the same time, the automatic and mandatory exchange of information to combat money laundering between tax authorities is a new step forward in the fight against fraud, tax evasion and money laundering in the EU. I therefore consider it justified to support this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
