text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to information relating to the fight against money laundering.Its author specifies, for example, in this update, that the role of vehicles, accounts and companies established in tax havens and non-cooperative countries and territories is the common denominator of a vast set of transactions, generally detected atposteriori, which hide practices of tax evasion, tax evasion and money laundering.This fact, in itself, must prompt political and diplomatic action aimed at extinguishing offshore centers on a global scale.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal for tax authorities to access anti-money-laundering information has been initiated through the introduction of a new measure. I voted in favour of the proposal, which falls in line with the Commission’s agenda against tax evasion and avoidance, with a view to delivering fairer and more effective taxation in the EU. As a result of recent media leaks such as the Panama Leaks, the exposure of large-scale concealment of offshore funds proves that further measures still need to be taken to reinforce EU and international transparency initiatives. I believe that by providing greater access to information to tax authorities, effective identification of tax evasion can be achieved.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - Tax fraud and tax evasion are unacceptable practices against which the European Union can play a decisive role. The report by my colleague Emmanuel Maurel aims to strengthen legislation in order to restore tax justice in Europe. In July 2016, the European Commission presented a legislative package intended to combat money laundering and the financing of terrorism. This package reformed in particular the directive known as AMLD, which reinforced controls on a series of transactions, by creating central registers in each Member State, with the list of the beneficial owners of companies and trusts. But this crucial information was not always accessible to tax authorities. The second part of the package therefore gave tax administrations direct and horizontal access to this information. Emmanuel Maurel's report initially proposed going further, recommending an automatic and compulsory exchange of information between member states. This provision was unfortunately excluded from the agreement during the pre-vote Council. I voted for this report, and I welcome its adoption.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the draft European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to information on the prevention of money laundering. I believe that adequate cooperation is needed both at the level of the institutions of the European Union and at the level of the institutions of the Member States in order to combat the criminal mechanism of money laundering. The novelty introduced by this report, which allows the tax authorities of the Member States to automatically exchange money laundering documents, contributes to the necessary strengthening of the Union's preventive apparatus. Also, the provision of a longer period for the entry into force of the directive sets a realistic framework for the implementation of the planned mechanisms. Thorough cooperation at European Union level is of paramount importance in order to combat economically organized crime. I expect joint measures to be taken in this direction and call for more effective action in establishing the European Public Prosecutor's Office, whose task is to establish a single European mechanism to prosecute perpetrators of financial crime, including money laundering.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that it is possible to strengthen the financial systems of EU countries by combating money laundering.I also think that this is a serious step in the fight against organized crime.It is worth noting that tax evasion and money laundering are similar crimes, so I agree with the idea that the authorities involved in combating these crimes should communicate more closely with each other.In view of the growing number of cross-border crimes, cooperation between EU authorities must be strengthened so that information reaches its addressees quickly and in an organized manner, which will help to prevent crime.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- This report is of an advisory nature.Parliament is asked for an opinion and the legislative proposal can reject, accept or propose amendments.The Council has no legal obligation to respect Parliament's opinion, but it also cannot take a final decision until it has consulted Parliament.The purpose of this European Council Regulation is to allow tax authorities to have constant access to information related to money laundering in relation to their duties to monitor the correct application of the Administrative Cooperation Directive (DAC) of financial institutions, eg foundations.The current situation is that access to money laundering information varies from one Member State to another, and this proposal would allow tax authorities to have access to mechanisms, procedures, documents and information, emphasizing in-depth consumer analysis as a basic procedure.So I voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to information on the prevention of money laundering. In the fight against tax evasion and to avoid problems, as shown by the Panama Papers, and in view of the need to improve the transparency of tax payments, the Commission has proposed that EU tax institutions be given access to national information on money laundering. To combat this, the EU tax institutions have decided to do so with the help of Directive 2011/16 / EU. The directive provides for established approaches and established procedures for better (co) operation (such as information exchange, control and mutual information). One part of the improvements is the Commission's efforts to speed up transparency in order to provide tax institutions with greater access to business owners' data and to enable people involved in certain financial acquisitions to be verified.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, in turn in favor of the Commission's proposal to oblige the exchange of information on money laundering between Member States, in order to combat money laundering and tax evasion.The final date of entry into force is 2017, considered more realistic by practically all parties.The amendments made by Parliament also oblige the exchange of information on the beneficial owners of companies, making evasion difficult through the use of shell companies.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- The fight against money laundering and tax avoidance needs to be improved.It is obvious that national authorities also need information from other EU member states for this.The demand for an automatic exchange of information between the authorities of the EU member states is absolutely necessary.At the same time, it is important to ensure that the national authorities can process this information with adequately qualified personnel and that the data is treated confidentially.As a result, the report makes good proposals for improving European administrative cooperation with the aim of combating tax fraud and money laundering.Because I support these concerns, I voted for the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe in and support this report which wants to reinforce anti-laundering measures and combat tax evasion more efficiently. It is essential to bring EU citizens nearer to the European Union and national authorities.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - This report is part of a procedure for consulting Parliament following the Commission proposal which should amend Directive 2011/16 / EU on administrative cooperation in the tax field, in order to allow tax authorities to benefit from systematic access to information relating to the fight against money laundering. This directive implements the global standard for the automatic exchange of financial account information in tax matters within the Union. As such, it ensures that information on financial account holders is communicated to the Member State in which the account holder resides. In addition, Directive 2011/16 / EU provides that, where the account holder is an intermediary structure, financial institutions examine this structure and identify and report its beneficial owners. This is a measure that we support, especially since we voted in favor of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive and the Tax Information Exchange Directive. For its part, in addition to approving the Commission's amendments, Parliament's report calls for the date of entry into application of the new provisions not to be January 1, 2017, but January 1, 2018. I have therefore voted for this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- Unfortunately, the proposed regulations do not convince me that they will help to ensure equal anti-money laundering in each Member State due to the diversity of economies and the practice carried out.Parliament has included in its consultation elements that were not the aim of the original Commission proposal or the compromise prepared by the Council.That is why I voted against the project.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The observed link between tax evasion, avoidance and money laundering makes it necessary to make the most of the synergies resulting from domestic, EU and international cooperation between the various authorities involved in the fight against such crimes and abuses.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, in turn in favor of the Commission's proposal to oblige the exchange of information on money laundering between Member States, in order to combat money laundering and tax evasion.The final date of entry into force is 2017, considered more realistic by practically all parties.The amendments made by Parliament also oblige the exchange of information on the beneficial owners of companies, making evasion difficult through the use of shell companies.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- In order for tax authorities to be able to effectively control the application of due diligence procedures set out in Directive 2011/16 / EU, tax authorities need access to anti-money laundering information.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16/EU as regards access to anti-money-laundering information by tax authorities. The new rules will enable and oblige tax authorities with anti-money laundering responsibilities in any EU country to share automatically information such as bank account balances, interest income and dividends, with their counterparts in other Member States. I voted in favour because I believe that efforts made in transparency are the only way to fight against tax evasion. Moreover, links between money laundering, the funding of terrorism, organised crime and tax evasion highlight the need for close cooperation and coordination among EU countries.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- There is a broad consensus in the Union on the need to take more far-reaching measures to reinforce both Community and international transparency frameworks.Thus, the purpose of this text is to provide the tax authorities with greater access to information against money laundering so that they can correctly carry out their work, in compliance with the application of the 2011 Directive on administrative cooperationin the field of taxation.In the interest of continuing this cooperation against money laundering, I have voted in favor of this report.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - The directive implementing global standards for the exchange of information on taxation has been revised allowing national tax authorities to access the information necessary to effectively combat money laundering, terrorist financing and other illegal activities. Parliament's amendments strengthened the Commission proposal by requiring the exchange of information to be made automatic and mandatory. In particular, with our amendments we denounced the need - following recent scandals such as Luxleaks, Swill Leaks, Panama Papers - for coordinated action at EU level to combat the problem of money laundering, organized crime, the financing of terrorism, and tax avoidance and evasion on a European scale. We strongly supported the request to facilitate the automatic and mandatory exchange of information and stressed the importance of strengthening the sanctioning mechanism against banks that facilitate money laundering, whose banking license should be revoked in the most serious cases of violation. Our amendments were included in the final text, which was generally balanced. We believe that the revision of the directive is a step in the right direction, which is why we voted positively both in committee and in plenary.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, because it represents an improvement in the requirements regarding access to information by the tax authorities.With the development of all the tax scandals produced in recent years: Luxleaks, Panamaleaks, Bahamaleaks ... the public has become aware of the tax practices of the main players in the financial system.This proposal is born from the pressure of public opinion to act in this area and allow access to relevant tax information for tax evaders.Access to information by the competent authorities is a necessary step, in order to implement the principle of paying taxes where wealth is created and carry out actions against tax havens.It is for all this that I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on anti-money laundering information, because the Panama Papers scandal showed that some of the most egregious tax evaders are able to get away with it by concealing information about who truly owns a company. With this proposal, the EU will allow tax authorities to have access to this vital information and we can take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because the role of intermediaries, accounts and companies located in tax havens and non-cooperative jurisdictions appears to be a common denominator in a large number of operations, which are generally discovered later and behind which tax fraud, capital flightand money laundering practices.This fact alone should give rise to political and diplomatic intervention with the aim of eliminating offshore centers worldwide.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The European Parliament examined at first reading a draft directive aimed at establishing automatic access for all Member States' tax authorities to specific information relating to the fight against money laundering for tax purposes for a maximum period of three months after their collection. This access concerns both the implementation measures and the data relating to the beneficial owners. The exchange of this information between tax authorities was already provided for by Directive 2014/107 / EU on the automatic and compulsory exchange of information in the tax field. However, this data exchange could not be applied systematically, which ultimately prevented the identification of the actual beneficiaries of the fraud. It is therefore a question of better fighting against tax fraud and what is called aggressive tax planning. Any information obtained by a tax authority must be processed within the time limit prescribed by national law and any failure to process this data must be justified. I'm not sure this will lead to a big revolution in tax evasion, but it can help advance transparency. So I voted in favor.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Naturally, we support all measures aimed at better access to information and better cooperation between the tax administrations of national states. In this sense, including the entire collection of information typified within the framework of the fight against money laundering in terms of administrative cooperation represents a positive step. We underline, however, that it seems essential that this information be exchanged automatically, so that this change will, in fact, have practical effects. Regarding the fight against money laundering, however, it is important not to entertain illusions. In our opinion, it is not possible to combat this phenomenon by relying only on the due diligence duties of private companies and the financial system. As has been criticized by many organizations, the results of the fight against money laundering have been residual over the past few decades. In other words, money laundering, like fraud and tax evasion, are one of the visible faces of the liberal economy and the capitalist system. In this sense, the recovery of public control over banks and the financial system is also a condition for a more effective fight against these phenomena, as well as for a better functioning of the economy.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Since the aim of the proposal is to combat tax evasion and avoidance more effectively, in order to achieve an increase in tax transparency and fairer and more effective taxation in the EU, and thus also to increase tax transparency, I approved this proposal.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution to give the green light to a proposal that will allow the exchange of sensitive information between tax authorities regarding money laundering.With this new proposal, Europe will make further progress in the fight against tax avoidance and evasion.The initiative aims to allow tax authorities to have access to all information in order to tackle the shadow economy.The main objective of our group was to make the exchange of information between tax authorities mandatory and automatic.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on anti-money laundering information, as the European Union is globally placed to take a lead role in tackling tax evasion and avoidance, where Member States are not large enough to act individually. The Panama Papers scandal showed that some of the most egregious tax evaders are able to get away with it by concealing information about who truly owns a company. The EU’s proposal will allow tax authorities to have access to this vital information and we can therefore take another vital step forward in the fight for tax justice.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that there should be a focus on eliminating offshore centres at global level. This tax havens have been identified to be the major sources of tax fraud, tax evasion and money laundering practices. Aggressive tax planning can only be addressed with an efficient information exchange system on an international level. I also believe that tax authorities need to have adequate information and communications technology in order to trace money-laundering activities. As a liberal I believe in the importance of transparency, and an automatic, mandatory and continuous exchange of information between authorities can only help to combat fraudulent behaviour of all kinds.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing - I supported the legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council directive amending the directive on access to information by the tax authorities for the purpose of combating money laundering. This fight must be an absolute priority for the EU. Detections in connection with Panama Papers, Bahamas Leaks, etc. they are proof of the need for greater transparency in the field of taxation and, of course, closer cooperation between national criminal authorities. Practices such as money laundering cross national borders, so I believe that exchanging and sharing information is absolutely crucial. We need the individual tax authorities to communicate and cooperate with each other, which will lead to increased transparency. Especially today, when the public is very sensitive and responsive to any non-transparent and dubious financial activities, especially in relation to public procurement, effective legislation is essential. It is often the non-cooperating authorities and the companies involved in tax havens that are the common denominator of tax fraud.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - We have today approved the revision of the directive that implements global standards for the automatic exchange of information on taxation matters. This revision introduces the possibility for national tax authorities to access anti money laundering information in order to combat terrorist financing, corruption and other criminal activities. Through the amendments of the Parliament this revision has even improved. Indeed, the rapporteur introduced the possibility that this exchange of information was automatic and mandatory. The amendments I tabled to the text denounced the need for coordinated action at EU level following the recent scandals such as LuxLeaks, SwissLeaks and Panama Papers, as well as the need to respond unambiguously to the problem of money laundering, to the financing of organized crime, tax avoidance and tax evasion on a European scale. I also reiterated the request to promote the automatic and mandatory exchange of information to ensure maximum transparency and requested to introduce a sanctioning mechanism for banks that facilitate money laundering, such as the withdrawal of the banking license. As this is a text in favor of greater transparency and security, I have expressed my positive vote.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - Luxleaks, Swissleaks, Bahamas Leaks, Panama Papers. These cases are nothing more than the result of our poor tax policy and low tax transparency. They are often still linked to tax evasion, tax avoidance and, last but not least, terrorist financing and organized crime. I am convinced that these illegal activities are not only evidence of insufficient EU activity in the field of taxation, but also an impetus for our further activity. I see the main problem as the poor access of the tax authorities of the individual Member States to information and their mutual exchange. All EU tax authorities must have quick and easy access to all anti-money laundering information and relevant documents. If we have a single market, common borders and interconnected financial systems, it is inconceivable that direct access to this information would not work within the EU. Only in this way can we prevent further similar scandals and ensure more transparent and effective taxation in the EU.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Maurel report because it agrees with the need to combat tax evasion effectively in the European Union.To this end, the report stipulates the need to ensure that tax authorities have quick and complete access to anti-money laundering information and the need to have enough qualified personnel to carry out this task to be able to exchange them.information.It is also worth noting the rapporteur's own proposal on behalf of the European socialist group that this exchange of information be automatic and mandatory between Member States, which should include this data in a “centralized public register” of companies, trust funds and other structures, constitutinga new, more proactive approach to tackling tax evasion.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- The revelations of Swissleaks, Luxleaks, the Panama and Bahamas documents, which are only isolated examples of the global phenomenon, have confirmed the urgent need for greater fiscal transparency and closer coordination and cooperation between judicial authorities.The new rules thus provide for the mandatory automatic exchange of information on bank account balances, interest income and dividends between the authorities responsible for preventing money laundering and tax evasion in the Member States.The resolution further emphasizes that the link between money laundering, terrorist financing, organized crime and tax evasion calls for the necessary close cooperation and coordination between EU Member States.I believe that the proposed directive brings effective and proportionate measures against tax evasion, which is why I voted in favor of the Report on the proposal for a Council directive amending Directive 2011/16 / EU as regards access by tax authorities to information on the prevention of money laundering.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of this report in light of the rapporteur’s measured appraisal of the European System of Central Banks and the euro system’s monetary policy. In particular I appreciate that price stability, transparency and the economic policies of the European Union provided a keystone for such a report in a welcome return to a stocktaking objective of the exercise. Above all, from an Irish perspective I am pleased to see Brexit and its implications occupying a central position in this report. The integrity of the single market must remain respected in this transition, and I am hopeful that the necessary rules and regulations will be established in order to maintain financial stability throughout this process. In supporting this report I am confident that the combination of sound fiscal policies and ambitious reform programmes will guide economic policy for the EU.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this report because I also consider it important to maintain both monetary and price stability.Undoubtedly, there are a number of economic terms and institutes that the ECB directly monitors in its activities, so it is correct.On the other hand, I just want to call on the ECB not to become a political body, because that would undoubtedly be to the detriment of the whole monetary and fiscal category that it is in charge of.She should maintain strict expertise, independence, impartiality, but at the same time not engage in those political processes, because that is to her detriment.I have a bit of a feeling that she hasn't avoided this risk much lately.I can appreciate price stability, inflation, the prevention of the risk of deflation or even quantitative easing, which already has its results, I would just like the ECB not to be a political body.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report deals with analyzing what the European Central Bank did during the year 2016. It is clear to all that today the biggest problems for the Member States, in economic matters, are the too high rate ofunemployment and a growing rate of inflation, the cause of which can be attributed to the imposition of a system of fixed exchange rates, linked to the adoption of the single currency.However, these aspects are not mentioned in the report at all, while the unconventional measures adopted by the ECB to address the above issues are widely praised.Since it is extremely evident that the measures put into practice by the Central Bank have had no positive effect and, on the contrary, have favored speculation in the financial markets, I have decided to vote against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report as it falls too short in criticizing the functioning of the European Central Bank during the financial year 2015. It points out some substantial criticisms of the activity of the ECB during this period, the role of super interest ratesreduced, the impact of Quatitative Easing, etc.However, the report goes on to call for the need for "structural reforms" so that the same monetary policy can work.We need a different monetary policy that calls into question the "independence" of the ECB and allows it to function to finance public debt and not just debt markets, where the financial system blackmails states.The report does not criticize the current structure, nor its undemocratic operation and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This report outlined the main activities of the European Central Bank over the past year. I voted against this report, as Sinn Féin has a fundamentally critical view of the activities and functioning of the ECB. The report is largely uncritical of the ECB’s monetary and macro-economic policies, and it calls for ECB policy to be accompanied by Member States implementing further structural reforms and increasing competitiveness.  The ECB has over the past year flooded the markets with cheap money that only fuels speculative bubbles. Sinn Féin has an entirely different view of how to conduct monetary policy based on funding investments in the real economy in order to promote growth that benefits the majority of people and not only large banks and corporations. The report was also largely uncritical of the undemocratic nature of the ECB, while we believe it must be fundamentally reformed and held accountable.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.Socialists and Democrats generally support the expansionary monetary policies implemented by the ECB so far.However, we believe that the ECB alone can stimulate aggregate demand only if it is complemented by ambitious and socially balanced investments and structural reform programs at Member State level.We also call on the ECB to do more to ensure that this liquidity reaches the real economy and SMEs in particular and, finally, to be vigilant, so that the low interest rates of the banks benefit the real economy more..

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the European Central Bank in 2015. annual reports. The euro area is still characterized by high unemployment, low inflation and large macroeconomic imbalances, including current account deficits. In addition, euro area countries are experiencing weak productivity growth due to a lack of investment, a failure to implement structural reforms and weak domestic demand. I agree with the view of ECB President Draghi that a single monetary policy alone cannot drive growth in aggregate demand and that it must be complemented at Member State level by sound fiscal policies and broad-based and socially balanced structural reform programs. Socially balanced structural economic and labor market reforms should also take full account of the demographic situation in Europe and promote more balanced demographic policies. It is also important for the ECB to carefully assess the risk of future new asset and housing price bubbles arising from the ECB's policy of extremely low (negative) interest rates, given the significant increase in lending and the disproportionate rise in real estate prices, especially in some major economies. in cities. I support the position that national economic policies should be coordinated, especially in the euro area, for economic growth.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015, because I believe that monetary dialogue is important in ensuring transparency in monetary policy.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- On the basis of the annual report of the European Central Bank, the European Parliament annually takes stock of the activities of the European System of Central Banks and the monetary policy of the Eurosystem.The main tasks of the ESCB, including ensuring price stability and supporting the general economic policy of the Union, form the central themes of the ECB's annual report and Parliament's response to it.In the 2015 calendar year, the main topics were the recovery of the euro area economy, persistently low inflation, the effects of low interest rates and the decision of the ECB to expand its asset purchase program.I approved the report, which also takes a critical look at the actions of the ECB, and I hope that the ECB will take note of these criticisms.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This report formulates relevant reservations concerning the ECB but it in no way calls into question its action while the ECB embodies the abandonment of monetary sovereignty by nation-states as well as the promotion of counterproductive and destructive austerity policies.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The European Central Bank has focused in recent years on propping up the euro, a currency entirely unsuited to the needs of a 21st-century economy and the diversity of economies from Germany to Greece. This report fails to comprehend the nature of the problem, and furthermore calls for more European Union, so I voted against the final report. I did, however, support various amendments which sought to highlight the problems within the ECB.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which reminds us of the federal role of the ECB and which establishes that the euro zone continues to suffer from a high unemployment rate, too low inflation and macroeconomic imbalances.This text also agrees that monetary policy alone is not able to revive the economy and that it must be accompanied by serious fiscal policies and structural reforms.Indeed, I reiterate my call for the creation of a euro area government.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Central Bank in 2015.annual reports.The 2015 ECB report notes that the euro area is still characterized by high unemployment, low inflation and large macroeconomic imbalances.The euro area is also facing very weak productivity growth, driven by a lack of investment and high government debt.In view of these problems in the euro area, I therefore agree that sound fiscal policies and socially balanced and productivity-oriented structural reforms are the only way to achieve a sustainable economic recovery.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing.- The presentation concerns the 2015 Annual Report of the European Central Bank.The report emphasizes that the euro area continues to be characterized by high unemployment, excessively low inflation and significant macroeconomic imbalances, including current account deficits.Productivity growth in the euro area is very low, due to declining investment since the beginning of the crisis, lagging structural reforms and weak domestic demand.In essence, the report calls for monetary integration, which we do not agree with because, on the one hand, it does not have the economic conditions, as is clear from some of the amendments, and, on the other hand, it forces an integration that we reject for our part.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst critical in parts (on for example TARGET2 imbalances) this non-legislative report nevertheless also calls on the ECB and Commission to act to shore up the ECB system rather than plan to disband it, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. - This annual report by the ECON committee on the actions of the ECB moves away from the usual commentary and looks at both the macroeconomic situation and the latest measures taken by the central bank. Conventional monetary policy instruments are thus reviewed (lowering rates last March), but especially unconventional tools (extension of quantitative easing until March 2017, TLTRO II, etc.). However, real reservations are expressed in this report: on the transmission to the real economy of QE, on the risks of asset bubbles (real estate in particular), on the risks of zero interest rates on the economic model of life insurance , on the bond crash in the event of a rate hike, on the delicate management of an exit from QE (tapering), etc. In other words, this is not an ode to Mario Draghi and therefore a blank check to the ECB. That is why I did not vote against this report, although I remain opposed to the fundamental guidelines of the EU in monetary matters.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which gives a general assessment of the ECB's monetary policies, with clear references to the asset purchase program (APP), main refinancing operations (ORM) and operations of Longer-term targeted refinancing (TLTRO I and II). The report highlights that the euro area continues to suffer from high unemployment, excessively low inflation, large macroeconomic imbalances, including current account imbalances, and very low growth in the economy. productivity, consequence of lack of investment. This clear reference to the lack of investment is a point on which we have insisted. The report calls for the completion and full progressive implementation of the Banking Union, the construction of a Capital Markets Union as well as a solution to the issue of non-performing loans to improve the effectiveness of the single monetary policy and mitigate risks arising from a shock in the financial sector.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report due to the important role of the European Central Bank, however, I want to highlight my concern about the effects that negative interest rates can have on savers.I also want to insist on the need to strengthen the Economic and Monetary Union, specifically, to complete the Banking Union.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The euro area continues to suffer the negative effects of the economic crisis, important consequences which can be seen in the persistence of high unemployment rates, extremely low inflation and the presence of large macroeconomic imbalances. The ECB has tried to intervene over the last few years by softening its monetary policy by reducing intervention rates to unprecedented levels. The Tremosa i Balcells report, which I supported today, welcomes the work done by the European Central Bank over the past year, in particular by approving the expansionary monetary policies it has adopted. The support for the action promoted by President Draghi, however, is combined with the awareness of the need for a wider action to accompany these policies. First of all, we need to focus on support for investments at Community level and on socially sustainable programs of structural reforms, involving all Member States. The main objective must be to revive employment and aggregate demand. The ECB needs to do more to ensure that liquidity reaches the real economy, ensuring that banks take advantage of low interest rates to favor loans to SMEs which are not only the backbone of the European economy but also a great hope for a quick recovery.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against this report, in my opinion, excessively complacent with the activity of the European Central Bank.I consider that the ECB clearly overstepped its functions during 2015 by using the means at its disposal to exert political pressure on the Greek Government.In addition, the policy of quantitative expansion and the purchase of bonds through secondary markets has been a gift to financial institutions that has not resulted in benefits for society and has not been able to solve the economic problems that it intended.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: in writing. - The European Central Bank does not have the same powers or the same mandate as the American Central Bank and it is regrettable. The objectives of the FED are full employment, price stability and moderate interest rates in order to stimulate growth. The ECB, on the other hand, has the sole mandate of containing or stimulating inflation so that it reaches, but does not exceed, two percent. Even if we can welcome the fact that the ECB wants to curb budget deficits, it is clear that today, despite the massive buyout of assets from Member States, it has not succeeded in this task, which risks , in the medium term, to plunge our countries back into a new crisis that is devastating for the prosperity of our citizens. Reading the ECB report is difficult, but it is regrettable that it does not envisage more flexibility in monetary policy. Einstein said a century ago, "Doing the same thing over and over again and expecting different results is a sign of dementia." Hopefully the ECB hears this wise advice.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I want to congratulate my fellow group member Ramón Tremosa for his report on the 2015 Annual Report of the European Central Bank.The work carried out by the ECB and its President must be promoted to safeguard the powers of the euro and the strength of our currency.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting for the ECON committee report on the action of the ECB.Indeed, while the report is of definite interest in the fight against money laundering, it does not fundamentally call into question the action of the European Central Bank, the source of the abandonment of monetary sovereignty by States and politicians.austerity.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Given the ineffectiveness of the economic policies implemented by the ECB to face the market crisis, given the banking crisis that is destroying Italian savings due to measures such as the "Bail In" and the economic forecasts of another yearrecession at the European level, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it assessed Parliament's assessment of the European Central Bank in 2015. annual report. In its report, Parliament emphasized that the euro area was still characterized by high unemployment, low inflation and high macroeconomic imbalances, including current account imbalances, and that the euro area was facing very weak productivity growth due to investment failures, structural reforms and weak domestic demand. Parliament also noted that high levels of government debt, in particular high levels of non-performing loans and the still undercapitalised banking sector in some Member States, continue to fragment the euro area financial market, thus reducing opportunities to help the most vulnerable economies. Finally, Parliament recalled the federal nature of the ECB, which does not provide for the possibility for Member States to veto decisions, which allows the ECB to take decisive action to overcome the crisis.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given new responsibilities in many areas, so even more attention will be paid to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the Central Bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro, and thus in the right context. the ECB’s policy. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operations last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to higher inflation and then excessive exchange rate increases. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015, as the main task in these times is to ensure price stability and support basic economic policies.The 2015 Annual Report therefore focuses backwards on the main elements of the ECB's activities, namely monetary activities.It also offers balanced interim monetary policies and focuses on structural reforms and the dangers of low interest rates.During the discussion, I also pointed out that the policy of low interest rates also has some negative effects, and that pension systems across countries will soon have serious problems, especially those linked to guaranteed profitability.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report, which welcomes the efforts of the European Central Bank so far, but also gives the opinion that the ECB alone cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is complemented by investment and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs at Member State level.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2015 particularly because it stressed the lack of investment, the failure in carrying out structural reforms and the weakness of the internal demand in the euro area identifying the right problems we must deal with. Furthermore, it supported the recent ECB’s work by underling some priorities which concern the Parliament.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European Parliament reiterates how the euro area suffers from high unemployment and low inflation and productivity growth. Furthermore, the high public debt and the huge number of non-performing loans in the banking sector of some Member States lead to a fragmentation in the financial market which reduces the flexibility in supporting the most fragile economies. However, the ECB is recognized for the effective adoption of measures to bring inflation back to the medium-term objective of 2% and, through the asset purchase program, it is noted that the real economy has improved, with consequent strengthening of loans to businesses and households. The European Parliament agrees with President Draghi that monetary policy cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is accompanied by sound fiscal policies and ambitious reform programs in each Member State. The ECB is also invited to pay attention to a too prolonged period of policy at a low interest rate, which could jeopardize financial stability; and to assess the risk of a new real estate bubble resulting from such low interest rates. It recalls that the independence of the ECB in the conduct of its monetary policy is central to the objective of maintaining price stability.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report expresses reservations about the effectiveness of the monetary policy of the European Central Bank (ECB), which consisted in lowering the refinancing rate and the deposit rate as well as strengthening quantitative easing in order to combatagainst the risks of deflation.These reservations relate in particular to the transmission into the real economy of liquidity resulting from the massive repurchase of assets on the financial markets, which risk creating speculative bubbles.However, our position goes far beyond the simple criticisms made in this report.In the absence of an exit from the euro zone, we wish to implement a profound modification of the statutes of the ECB which would aim to include growth and exchange rate objectives as well as to take away its autonomy from the Member States.This is the reason why I abstained on this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The euro area continues to be affected by the very low rate of inflation, some significant macroeconomic imbalances, but also a high level of unemployment, despite all recent efforts. Also, the annual report of the European Central Bank for 2015 indicates that the level of productivity is very low, which suggests the lack of investment, but also the non-implementation of structural reforms. I welcome the measures taken by the European Central Bank to reduce the inflation rate to 2% in the medium term and also support programs aimed at longer-term refinancing operations aimed at the real economy, which have helped to improve the financial situation. I spoke in favor of the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015, as I believe that the ECB has always been concerned with meeting its commitments to ensure the financial stability of the euro area.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - The world economy continued to recover gradually in 2015, although global economic growth was slightly more moderate than the previous year. 2015 was a year of recovery for the eurozone economy. However, inflation remained on a downward trajectory. Although the risks of extreme events have finally been avoided, I believe that in the future we need more clarity and legal certainty in the process of providing liquidity by the Central Bank to euro area institutions. I support the EP's motion for a resolution on the "European Central Bank Annual Report 2015". We face uncertainties about the prospects of the world economy. We continue to face disinflationary forces. And we face questions about the direction Europe is heading and its resilience to new shocks. In this context, a commitment must be made to respecting citizens' rights in order to increase trust among them. Structural reforms that directly facilitate investment and jobs need to be promoted.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I gave my positive vote to the report on the 2015 Annual Report of the European Central Bank, as I consider the necessary adoption of structural resources to be of crucial importance, the development of which is a cornerstone of the stimulus and protection policyimplemented by the ECB.Although the economy is recovering, it has emerged from years of crisis and still shows all its fragility.From this perspective, the actions implemented by the ECB are a valid bulwark for the financial world and a sure contrast to the volatility of the markets.It should be emphasized that the distorting effects of a "hard Brexit" and the US scenario of Trump's election militate against an economic and financial equilibrium of the euro zone.Consequently, I welcome the report and the ECB's commitment to "do whatever it takes" to defend the euro, which I believe it is actually doing.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst critical in parts (on for example TARGET2 imbalances) this non-legislative report nevertheless also calls on the ECB and Commission to act to shore up the ECB system rather than plan to disband it, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it provides a balanced assessment of the interplay of monetary polices and structural reforms and the risks of low interest rate policies. Its aim is to take stock of the activities of the European System of Central banks (ESCB) and the Eurosystem’s monetary policy.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The report, for which I decided to vote in favor, evaluates the work of the European Central Bank (ECB) in a positive way for 2015. Despite the expansionist monetary policies implemented by the ECB, they aim to stimulate growth and creation of jobs, I regret that the latter have not been accompanied by an adequate level of investment, thus having limited effects on the real economy. I believe that the negative interest rate policy has had positive effects on the solidity of banks but that it is necessary to carefully evaluate the consequences of this unconventional monetary policy on individual savers and on the financial equilibrium of pension systems, as well as in terms of development of speculative bubbles, particularly in the real estate sector. I believe that an efficient, diversified and integrated capital market must be built by fully implementing the Banking Union and aiming for a true Capital Markets Union. I regret that, despite the ECB's timely commitment to this effect, there is still an important gap between the lending rates granted to SMEs and those granted to larger companies. In this regard, I agree with the report's invitation to strengthen the relationship between the injection of liquidity by the Central Bank and the disbursement of loans to the real economy.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and recall that monetary dialogue is important in ensuring transparency in monetary policy vis-.-Vis both Parliament and the general public.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- The vote on the European Central Bank (ECB) Annual Report for 2015 focuses on the activities of this particular institution over the past year.Although no errors or irregularities have occurred, we have expressed many objections to the structure and procedures of the ECB and therefore its mode of operation does not find us in agreement.That is why I decided to vote no.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Dismal report by the European Central Bank on common monetary policies.Negative rating.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. Uncertainty is, undoubtedly, the worst of all evils. However, I tend to recognize it as the perfect condition to encourage man to discover his own abilities and therefore I approve the framework presented by the ECB regarding 2015 and foreseen for the future. In its work to maintain monetary stability and promote the smooth functioning of the payment system, the ECB expects inflation close to 0.2% for 2016 and rising in 2017. This wish becomes difficult to achieve due to the unfavorable macroeconomic situation . While there is no doubt the need for structural reforms aimed at tackling stable unemployment and low productivity, in addition to what has been listed, the level of risk that the ECB's budget is reaching in implementing the established programs is equally unquestionable. The impact of these operations on the real economy is also puzzling. Proof of this is the lack of follow-up on the restart of investments and consumption. Together with the foregoing, it saddens to observe the gap existing between the rates of financing granted to banks and businesses.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2015 and noted no objections.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the annual report as I agree with the basic elements represented in the text concerning the activities of the ECB.The report also provides a balanced assessment of the interactions between monetary policies, structural reforms and the risks of low interest rate policies.There is no lack of references in the report to the negative effect caused by the high unemployment rate in the euro area and to the very low level of productivity growth largely due to the lack of investment and structural reforms.I agree that the single monetary policy cannot by itself be able to stimulate demand and growth if it is not complemented by sound budgetary policies and structural reforms by the Member States.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Factors like the failure to carry out structural reforms and the weakness of internal demand, the huge number of non-performing loans and a still undercapitalised banking sector in some Member States, are still fragmenting the euro area financial market, thus reducing room for manoeuvre to support the most fragile economies. As the report states, there are structural and socially-balanced reforms in the economy and the labour market should also take full account of the demographic deficit in Europe in order to tackle deflationary pressures and create incentives for a more balanced demographic structure that would make it easier to maintain an inflation target of around 2%.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing.- Every year Parliament is called to vote on the report on the ECB and this year I am forced to disagree and express myself negatively towards the report presented as it only partially analyzes the work of the Central Bank.The analysis appears to be not very objective, praising the work of the ECB without raising any real criticism against it.I would also like to emphasize that the ECB should consider an opt-out mechanism as soon as possible which would allow Member States to leave the Eurozone if such a move is deemed necessary.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report as it falls too short in criticizing the functioning of the European Central Bank during the financial year 2015. It points out some substantial criticisms of the activity of the ECB during this period, the role of super interest ratesreduced, the impact of Quatitative Easing, etc.However, the report goes on to call for the need for "structural reforms" so that the same monetary policy can work.We need a different monetary policy that calls into question the "independence" of the ECB and allows it to function to finance public debt and not just debt markets, where the financial system blackmails states.The report does not criticize the current structure, nor its undemocratic operation and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The report provides an overall positive assessment of the ECB's monetary policies with clear references: Asset Purchase Program, main refinancing operations and targeted longer-term refinancing operations. The report points out that the euro area continues to suffer from a high level of unemployment, an excessively low level of inflation, large macroeconomic imbalances, including current account imbalances, and a very low level of productivity growth, which it is the result of the lack of investment, the inability to implement structural reforms and the weakness of domestic demand. This clear reference to the lack of investment is a point on which we, as a group of Socialists and Democrats, strongly insisted, and I believe it is a central point in our struggle. In addition, the report also calls for a step-by-step completion and full implementation of Union Banking, the Capital Markets Union, as well as a solution to the problem of non-performing loans to improve the effectiveness of monetary policy and mitigate risks. resulting from a shock in the financial sector. I therefore believe it to be an acceptable text, although further steps could be taken to underline, in line with the Commission's proposals, the need for a positive fiscal stance.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - The motion for a European Parliament resolution reflects the annual activity of the European Central Bank in 2015. The report assesses in a balanced way the ECB's annual activity, its monetary policy, the risks to its policy of maintaining low interest rates and the need for structural reforms. The primary objective of the European Central Bank is to maintain price stability by creating a stable investment environment. In 2015, high unemployment, excessively low inflation, macroeconomic imbalances and low productivity growth were serious problems in the euro area, leading to lagging structural reforms, declining investment and weakening domestic demand. Increasing the competitiveness of the European economy and sound fiscal policies can be achieved primarily through socially balanced and, above all, effective structural reforms that directly boost investment and job creation.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the report because there are a number of problematic issues in the report that require specific discussion and clarification.An example is the incomprehensible issue of the reasons for introducing negative rates, vague expressions or differences resulting from the approach to establishing the banking union, which, in my opinion, must be subject to a more critical assessment than the one presented in the report.What I take positively about the report is the balanced and sensible way of discussing the ECB's policy.I believe that the report contains too many doubts and inaccuracies.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for further need for investments and socially balanced structural reform programmes at Member State level to stimulate aggregate demand. As the euro area continues to suffer from unemployment, structural reforms are necessary to tackle such a reality. Liquidity needs to reach the real economy, we need to invest in SMEs and make sure that the low interest rates that the banks are benefiting from are translated into more loans. As these aspects are all covered in the report, I voted in favour.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. - The activity of the ECB has been deleterious since its inception, that is, since the launch of the monetary union in a non-optimal currency area. Austerity, unemployment, privatization, selling off the strategic assets of member countries in difficulty, cuts in investments, wages, workers' rights, closure of small and medium-sized enterprises: these are just some of the tangible effects that millions and millions of European citizens have paid on your skin. The ECB's responses were inadequate in terms of timing and methods. From Quantitative Easing to low interest rates, every measure imagined to be an immediate and temporary response to the lack of liquidity and access to credit has turned into a swamp of quicksand, with a real deterioration of macroeconomic conditions, which has in turn prompted the need to appeal to structural reforms and the Capital Markets Union. These are described as lifesaving for citizens, while they do nothing but guarantee the profitability of banks and financial entities. The consequences in political, economic and social terms of the euro and the ECB's diktats are very serious and it is not possible to support those who actually induce poverty to save the euro and the profits of the banks. For these reasons, my vote is against.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This report constitutes the response of the European Parliament to the annual report of the European Central Bank and raises as many essential subjects as are the reforms necessary for European monetary policy, the management of low interest rates and finally the completion of the marketsof capital.I voted in favor of this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst critical in parts (on for example TARGET2 imbalances) this non-legislative report nevertheless also calls on the ECB and Commission to act to shore up the ECB system rather than plan to disband it, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the activities of the European Central Bank (ECB) for the year 2015. This text notably emphasizes the importance of implementing the banking union and a capital markets unionin order to strengthen the effectiveness of the single monetary policy and mitigate the risks resulting from a shock in the financial sector.Furthermore, it is important to remember that monetary policy alone cannot solve the structural problems of the European economy.Therefore, Member States must carry out the necessary reforms and implement sound fiscal policies allowing the recovery of growth and employment, in particular by ensuring access to finance for SMEs.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given a new role in many areas, so even more attention will be paid to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the Central Bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro, and thus in the right context. the ECB’s policy. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operations last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to higher inflation and then excessive exchange rate increases. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I abstained on this report.This report by the European Parliament's ECON committee deals in depth with the policies of the European Central Bank, both its conventional (lowering rates) and unconventional tools, and mentions numerous reservations.The Front National wants, at a minimum, a review of the ECB’s missions as defined by the treaties and also of its independent status.In addition, the program of the National Front consists, in fine, of a nationalization of monetary and banking policies.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - This report is the European Parliament's response to the European Central Bank's (ECB) annual report for 2015. I am pleased to see that Mr Tremosa's report addresses the ECB's policy in a sensible way. It was high time we saw critical language on problematic issues, such as the low and even negative interest rate. However, for me and my group, there are important elements in the report that contradict our ideas. We do not agree with the asset purchase program aimed at long-term refinancing operations, and we do not understand why the policy of negative interest rates was imposed. It is important to emphasize that we have a much more critical view of the banking union and differ from the opinion expressed in the report. Due to the strengths and weaknesses of the report, I abstained.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- The ECB, as one of the key institutions of the EU, must act in the interests of the citizens of the Union, their well-being and their well-being.It must not place the protection of the common European currency above people.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given a new role in many areas, so even more attention will be paid to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the central bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro. place the ECB’s policy in context. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operation last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to higher inflation and then excessive exchange rate increases. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report on the final vote. I believe that austerity policies have been partly responsible for the weak and uneven ‘recovery’. The report does not call for building a sustainable economy but talks instead about growth and jobs. Wales needs to transform its economy and it can only do that with the right investment and on the basis of sustainability.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Today, the real objectives of the Banking Union are clearer for more people. Created under the false argument of giving solidity to the financial system and taking care of systemic banks, considered “too big to fail”, it was nothing more than a maneuver designed to remove from the public sphere, national states and their governments, under public control and scrutiny , democratic, any possibility of intervening in the system. Its real objectives are to impose banking concentration on a European scale, thus aggravating the problem that it is supposed to solve. In the Portuguese case, the situation is stark. With the centralization of all supervisory and resolution functions at the ECB, the largest banks ended up being sold to foreign groups at a bargain price, leaving the loss to the taxpayers, since the resolution fund has only been financed by the State Portuguese. Of course, this Banking Union will not solve any of the economies' problems, with or without the deposit guarantee system. Because this Banking Union is an expression of the dominance of the financial system over the political power of the EU.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - In principle, I do not see a problem in expanding expansionary monetary policy as practiced and proposed by the ECB, but the ECB alone cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is complemented by the necessary investment and ambitious and socially balanced structural reforms at Member State level.The ECB can also do more in the area of aid to small and medium-sized enterprises.Given the current situation in the world, it is very sad that the effects of the ECB's measures on the real economy have been very limited, and banks have been able to gain access to finance at virtually zero or very low cost.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against the ECB report, which is too biased and unrealistic.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- The ECB, as one of the key institutions of the EU, must act in the interests of the citizens of the Union, their well-being and their well-being.It must not place the protection of the common European currency above people.That is why I am voting against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I generally support the expansionary monetary policies implemented by the ECB until now but I am of the opinion that the ECB alone cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is complemented by investments and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programmes at Member State level. I am also of the opinion that the ECB can do more to make sure that liquidity reaches the real economy and the SMEs in particular and to be vigilant that the low interest rates banks are benefiting from are translated into more loans to the real economy. Moreover, I support the report as it calls for a step-by-step completion and full implementation of the Banking Union, the building of a Capital Market Union as well as a solution to the issue of non-performing loans to enhance the effectiveness of the single monetary policy and mitigating the risks arising from a shock in the financial sector.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given new tasks in many areas, so even more attention will be paid to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the Central Bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro, and thus in the right context. the ECB’s policy. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operations last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to an increase in inflation and then an excessive rise in the exchange rate. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report bearing in mind the consequences for the European economy that Brexit may bring, as well as the disparity at the state level in reference to economic growth and the reduction in unemployment rates.Similarly, we must bear in mind that despite the efforts made, some countries of the Union still continue to exceed the deficit targets set.We must bear in mind that the single monetary policy, by itself, cannot stimulate aggregate demand if it is not complemented by sound fiscal policies, ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs at the level of the Member States.In this context, we must complete the full implementation of the union, as this would constitute a decisive step to improve the effectiveness of the single monetary policy and mitigate the risks arising from a shock in the financial sector.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the Socialists, the emphasis on structural reforms - classified as socially sustainable - that was initially included in the draft report has been lowered. Furthermore, the federal nature of the ECB is recognized and support is reiterated for the promise made by its President in July 2012 to do everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. Monetary policy is not enough. The Union needs to activate an expansive fiscal policy that supports growth and jobs. The revision of the European Fund for Strategic Investments represents an opportunity to carry out a long-term bond issue - taking advantage of negative interest rates - that allows to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bio-industry or infrastructure, among others.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. - I share the tone of the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, which expresses a very positive view of the work of the ECB, in particular on monetary policies in support of growth and the financing of long-term operations. It is also important for me to underline the serious economic difficulties of the euro area reflected in the report, primarily employment, low inflation, macroeconomic imbalances, low productivity, the severe lack of investment, the delay in structural reforms in countries and a extreme weakness in demand.
