It seems important to me that the priorities of the S & amp; D group in support of the expansionary monetary policy pursued by Mario Draghi are well represented, in particular for reiterating that the choices of the ECB, alone, cannot correct the incompleteness of the euro zone and that they must therefore be accompanied by socially balanced investment and structural reforms.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the ECB's Annual Activity Report 2015, because I believe that monetary policy and particularly the unconventional quantitative easing measures put in place by the ECB are in line with the price stability objectives and consistent with its mandate, but above all because they have been decisive in preserving the integrity of the Eurozone, protecting it from deflation and contributing to the economic recovery, which is still uncertain in many Eurozone states. This report is at the same time an opportunity for the European Parliament to take stock of the policy mix of structural reforms and fiscal policies implemented in the Eurozone, noting, nevertheless, the need for a greater orientation of the same to growth, through investments public and private companies that strengthen territorial cohesion, as well as the effects of monetary policies on the European financial system, which is now much stronger in terms of capital, leverage, financing and risk-taking. As stated by President Draghi, the Common Equity Tier 1 of the significant banking groups in the Eurozone is now over 14%. Finally, the issue of bank profitability remains open and above all that of completing the Banking Union, through the creation of the third pillar (EDIS) and the creation of a final public backstop within the second pillar.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I abstained from voting on the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015.Not because the report itself was so inadequate - no, I am concerned with the fundamental work and increasing politicization of the ECB.I reject that because it damages fiscal stability in the euro area - and thus ultimately all citizens.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The European Central Bank (ECB) has succeeded in keeping inflation low in recent years and has contributed to the recovery of the European economic area.Your plant purchase program has also played a central role in the positive development of the European economy.In the future, the ECB should continue its measured policy of the steady hand and not burden the European market with over-regulation.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. Whilst the report is critical in parts (e.g. on negative interest rates and TARGET2 imbalances) it nevertheless calls on the ECB and the EU Commission to act and welcomes the ECB in doing ‘whatever it takes’ to save the euro.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report, which outlines measures that need to be taken to address the fragile economic situation of the euro area, provide jobs and growth and address excessively low inflation. I furthermore welcome that the report provides an analysis of the potential economic impact of Brexit.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - For once, Parliament's report does not give satisfaction to the policies of the European Central Bank. He is even extremely reserved, among other things, on the impact of unconventional measures on the real economy, which still suffers from a strong investment deficit, and on that of a very low interest rate policy, even negative, prolonged for too long, on the poor quality of the counterparties offered as collateral in refinancing operations, on the risks of bubbles, particularly in real estate, or of bond crashes in the event of a sudden rise in rates ... He is worried about rightly so about the complexity of implementing the abandonment of the unconventional policy, which cannot last indefinitely. But the proposed courses of action remain desperately stuck to the institutional and political model which is at the very source of the problems. I mean here the greater convergence of budgetary policies and economies, the independence of the ECB, the limitation of its objectives ... That is why I abstained.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted against this report, in my opinion, excessively complacent with the activity of the European Central Bank.I consider that the ECB clearly overstepped its functions during 2015 by using the means at its disposal to exert political pressure on the Greek Government.In addition, the policy of quantitative expansion and the purchase of bonds through secondary markets has been a gift to financial institutions that has not resulted in benefits for society and has not been able to solve the economic problems that it intended.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which outlines measures that need to be taken to address the fragile economic situation of the euro area, provide jobs and growth and address excessively low inflation. I furthermore welcome that the report provides an analysis of the potential economic impact of Brexit.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given a new role in many areas, thus giving even more attention to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. It is to be welcomed that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the Central Bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro. the ECB’s policy. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operations last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to an increase in inflation and then an excessive rise in the exchange rate. At the same time, the ECB should immediately address these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- We voted against the report, because it emphasizes that, despite all the incomplete strategies of the European Central Bank, the solutions it provided were sufficient and what is needed now is for the Member States to continue or deepen their structural reforms, to deepen and complete them.banking union and to harmonize the monetary policy of the Member States.Our approach is in the exact opposite direction.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this balanced report that outlines caution as well as some positive steps that need to be taken in a number of fields by the ECB. It highlights the reality of how persistently low interest rates are a growing problem, given their potential to undermine monetary policy transmission mechanisms. It also correctly identifies that the negative effects from this could be risks to private savings, a damaging reduction in bank profitability, impediments to the sound functioning of pension funds, inflation of asset bubbles and governments feeling less pressure to carry out structural reforms. On a more positive note, the report broadly supports the ECB’s actions to deal with the difficult economic outlook, especially its endeavour to return to a sound level of inflation, and calls for the completion of the banking union and the establishment of a capital market union.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- This report is the European Parliament's answer to the ECB's 2015 annual report. In general, it should be emphasized that this report is surprisingly critical of the ECB's policy.So z.B. the risks of low interest rates expressly and particularly emphasized.However, the text has some points that I expressly cannot support.He sees the expansionary monetary policy of the ECB in line with the mandate of the central bank, welcomes Draghi's statement to “do everything possible” to save the euro, and is positive about the banking union.Since this is nevertheless one of the most critical statements by Parliament on the current policy of the ECB, I abstained from the vote in order to honor this positive development.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - The European Central Bank will be given a new role in many areas, so its role will be enhanced and more attention will be paid to its activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with the European Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the central bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro, and thus put it in context. the ECB’s policy. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operation last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to higher inflation and then excessive exchange rate increases. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ The European Central Bank cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless its measures are accompanied by investments and structural reform programmes at Member State level. The ECB should do more to ensure that liquidity reaches the real economy and the SMEs. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the adoption of the European Central Bank's Annual Report for 2015 (2016/2063 (INI)), taking into account its contribution to the "defense" of the euro and ensuring the financial stability of the euro area. A single monetary policy alone cannot stimulate demand if there are no good fiscal policies and socially balanced structural reform programs at Member State level. It is necessary to ensure a more favorable financing rate for small and medium-sized enterprises and reduce the existing disparity between financing rates for SMEs and those for larger companies, then between interest rates on small and large loans and reduce differences in lending conditions for SMEs in different countries. euro area. Monetary policy measures that make investments in the euro area attractive need to be continued. The ECB should closely monitor the risk of a re-emergence of the bubble in the property and real estate markets due to the policy of extremely low (negative) interest rates. The independence of the ECB and its role in preserving financial stability should be respected. Unfortunately, the negative impact of high unemployment, excessively low inflation, large macroeconomic imbalances, current account imbalances, low productivity growth and a lack of investment continues in the euro area.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I am of the view that it draws attention to important points such as the possible negative effects of unconventional monetary policy measures and negative interest rates, which may punish savers and pensions funds. Although the growth in the euro area remains low due to high public and private debt growth, this report also stresses that ECB operations show a positive impact on lending to the real economy.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Ramon Tremosa on the 2015 report of the European Central Bank.The report notes that 2015 was a year of some economic recovery in the euro area.The ECB has contributed to this in two ways: on the one hand, through effective monetary policy decisions and, on the other, through program flexibility, adjusting measures to the economic situation.I support this report, which forms part of the European Parliament’s oversight mission over the activities of the European Central Bank.I am delighted that this text was adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text, which relates to the report on the activity of the European Central Bank in 2015. It provides a balanced assessment of the interaction of monetary policies and structural reforms as well as of the risks linked to policiesat low interest rates.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I reject this report.It is to be welcomed that he is critical of the ECB's current monetary policy, but I cannot support the call for the completion of the banking union, in particular the deposit guarantee, and the creation of a transfer union.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, but we must also acknowledge that the ECB alone cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is complemented by investments and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programmes at Member State level. We also call on the ECB to do more to make sure that liquidity reaches the real economy and SMEs in particular.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- This report is the European Parliament's answer to the ECB's 2015 annual report. In general, it should be emphasized that this report is surprisingly critical of the ECB's policy.So z.B. the risks of low interest rates expressly and particularly emphasized.However, the text has some points that I expressly cannot support.He sees the expansionary monetary policy of the ECB in line with the mandate of the central bank, welcomes Draghi's statement to “do everything possible” to save the euro, and is positive about the banking union.Since this is nevertheless one of the most critical statements by Parliament on the current policy of the ECB, I abstained from the vote in order to honor this positive development.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I could not support the European Parliament's resolution of 22 November 2016 on the European Central Bank's 2015 Annual Report. Although we read in the text that the euro area continues to suffer from high unemployment, too low inflation and high macroeconomic imbalances, as well as current account imbalances, and that the euro area also faces very low productivity growth due to low investment. (by 10 percentage points below the pre-crisis state), unimplemented structural reforms and weak domestic demand, but the culprit is missing. In my opinion, this is clearly the policy of the European Central Bank, and in particular of the European governments, which have blindly followed the policy of austerity to get to the very bottom of economic growth. With colleagues from the GUE / NGL, I therefore suggested that the European Parliament insist that the ECB must take democratic accountability for its decisions and that its decisions must be subject to coherent democratic scrutiny. However, this request was reprehensibly ignored.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given new responsibilities in many areas, so even more attention will be paid to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the central bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro, and thus put it in context. the ECB’s policy. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operation last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger money supply would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to higher inflation and then excessive exchange rate increases. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the ECB Annual Report, reflecting GUE/NGL’s and my personal fundamental objection to the monetary policy adopted by the ECB.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- According to the report, deepening monetary integration can cure all problems.But if that were true, it would have helped so far, but we are not seeing this in the real world, but the fact that the EU unemployment rate is between 4.6% and 24.9%, according to official figures.Member States, real growth is around one and a half per cent, investment is subdued.Overall, severe macroeconomic imbalances, characterized by low inflation and current account deficits, dominate.In the banking sector, high levels of bad credit and undercapitalisation are particularly prevalent in some Member States.Apparently from the above, you need to look for another cure for the ailments at the roots.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the ECB's annual report for 2015. I believe that the European Central Bank's commitment in August 2012 to "do whatever it takes" to protect the euro has made a significant contribution to ensuring the financial stability of the euro area. I believe that a well-functioning, diversified and integrated capital market will support the transmission channels of the single monetary policy. In this regard, I call for the gradual completion and full implementation of the banking union and for full compliance by the Member States with related legislation, as well as for the establishment of a capital markets union, as this is a decisive step towards increasing the efficiency of the single market. monetary policy and to reduce the risks arising from shocks in the financial sector. It is crucial to address the problem of non-performing loans for the most severely affected national banking sectors in order to restore the smooth functioning of the monetary policy transmission mechanism for the whole area. I believe that the ECB needs to examine how monetary policy differs between Member States with centralized and concentrated banking sectors and those with a more diverse network of local and regional banks, as well as between countries that rely more on of banks or capital markets to finance the economy.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, the European Central Bank’s (ECB) annual report for 2015 stresses that the euro area continues to suffer from a high level of unemployment, excessive low inflation, low level of productivity growth, lack of investment and large macroeconomic imbalances. To this point, ECB continues to underline the urgency of much-needed structural reforms and sound fiscal policies in the euro area. The report also expresses caution in a number of fields such as low interest rates, a damaging reduction in bank profitability, inflation of asset bubbles and impediments to the sound functioning of pension funds. Therefore, on the basis of the European Central Bank’s (ECB) annual report for 2015, I urge the EU to put pressure on Member states in order to implement vital structural reforms as soon as possible. Furthermore, I call on the EU to facilitate the completion of banking union and to encourage the establishment of a capital market union. I certainly believe that these actions would be a decisive step towards improving the effectiveness of the single monetary policy and ensuring the financial stability of the euro area.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- The report highlights that the euro area continues to suffer from the negative impact of high unemployment, inflation and macroeconomic imbalances and a still very low level of growth.In light of these issues, the measures adopted by the ECB to bring inflation back to the medium-term objective of 2% appear to be consistent with the terms of its mandate.The ECB contributed to the sentiment by countering risks to the integrity of the euro area, mainly related to events in Greece in the past year.Based on the implementation of targeted programs for the long-term refinancing of the real economy, financial conditions have improved, favoring a recovery in lending to businesses and households in the euro area.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I abstained on the annual report of the European Central Bank for 2015. The traditional report of the ECON committee on the action of the ECB makes few value judgments favorable to the policy put in place, and the tone is intended to be shade. The advice delivered is not an ode to Mario Draghi and the ECB. However, the model I advocate goes far beyond these simple criticisms. I am in favor of a renationalization of monetary policy and banking supervision, around a common euro currency accompanying the transition to national currencies. At the very least, I call for a reform of the treaties in order to modify the mandate of the ECB (inclusion of the objectives of growth, employment, exchange rate policy) as well as its status (autonomy and not independence vis-à-vis - vis-à-vis States), and I call for the possibility of directly monetizing the debt (amendment of article 123 TFEU). These options for another monetary policy are not reflected in this report, although several groups, besides ENL, are in favor. In this it is only representative of a part of the opinion of Parliament, and certainly not of the most electorally dynamic part.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The traditional ECON committee report on the action of the ECB moves away from the simple commentary on the institution's 2015 report and focuses on both the macroeconomic situation and the latest measures taken by the central bank, includingtherefore included during the year 2016. These options for another monetary policy in the Union do not find echoes in this report, although several groups, besides the ENL, are in favor.In this it is representative of only part of Parliament's opinion, and certainly not the most electorally dynamic.Given the current project, I abstained.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report as it falls too short in criticizing the functioning of the European Central Bank during the financial year 2015. It points out some substantial criticisms of the activity of the ECB during this period, the role of super interest ratesreduced, the impact of Quatitative Easing, etc.However, the report goes on to call for the need for "structural reforms" so that the same monetary policy can work.We need a different monetary policy that calls into question the "independence" of the ECB and allows it to function to finance public debt and not just debt markets, where the financial system blackmails states.The report does not criticize the current structure, nor its undemocratic operation and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- This report is the European Parliament's answer to the ECB's 2015 annual report. In general, it should be emphasized that this report, which I was in charge of as shadow rapporteur for our group, is surprisingly critical of the ECB's policy.So z.B. the risks of low interest rates expressly and particularly emphasized.However, the text has some points that I expressly cannot support.He sees the expansionary monetary policy of the ECB in line with the mandate of the central bank, welcomes Draghi's statement to “do everything possible” to save the euro, and is positive about the banking union.Since this is nevertheless one of the most critical statements by Parliament on the current policy of the ECB, I abstained from the vote in order to honor this positive development.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is carried out annually and assesses the activities of the ECB.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The negative impact of the high unemployment rate, excessively low inflation and large macroeconomic imbalances continues in the euro area, and due to the consequences of lack of investment and non-implementation of structural reforms, a low level of productivity was recorded. This report discusses the ECB's Annual Report for 2015, which focused on the recovery of the euro area economy, continued low inflation, the effects of low interest rates and the ECB's decision on an asset expansion program through the purchase of securities. The report notes that the high level of public debt and the still under-capitalized banking sector in some Member States are causing fragmentation of the euro area financial market. The solution to this problem lies in good fiscal policies and socially balanced productivity-oriented structural reforms, because a single monetary policy cannot stimulate aggregate demand if it is not accompanied by good fiscal policies and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs at Member State level. The report provides a balanced assessment of the interdependence of monetary policy and structural reforms and the risk of low interest rate policy, so I supported it.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ Monetary policy alone is not the appropriate tool to solve the structural problems of the European economy. Sound fiscal policies and socially balanced structural reforms oriented towards increasing productivity are the only way of bringing about sustainable economic improvements in these Member States.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the annual report of the European Central Bank for 2015, for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 21 November 2016, and because this report is not complete and substantiated..

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I abstained for this report.This text concerns the annual review of the activities of the European Central Bank (ECB).Unlike the 2015 report for 2014, the European Parliament decided this year to take a somewhat more critical approach towards the ECB.The rapporteur therefore asks questions about the macroeconomic situation in Europe, and the latest measures taken by the Central Bank.It makes few favorable value judgments about the policy in place and expresses some relevant reservations.However, it does not go far enough to question the existence and the way the ECB works.It also remains blind about the consequences of austerity policies and the abandonment of monetary sovereignty by member states.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed a favourable vote for the Report on the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2015. Supporting the report represents our commitment to reducing unemployment, government deficit, macroeconomic imbalances, and the debt-to-GDP ratio in the euro area. 2015 represented a year of recovery for the euro area economy and, therefore, the report represents a means to encourage European institutions to further cooperate and strengthen consumer confidence to boost spending, which in turn represents resuming hiring and investing. The report by the ECB shows areas of weakness that need improvement.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- This report on the ECB's activity for 2015 again supports the idea that monetary policy will only reach its fullness if it is complemented by sound fiscal policies and ambitious structural reform programs.In addition, the program of loans at almost negative interest rates, without any conditionality, mostly served to consolidate banks' balance sheets, having little or no effect on the real economy.Now this view is again wrong.As long as we do not adopt a truly expansionary and distributive monetary policy, which supports investment by MSMEs and job creation, through low interest rate bank loans, to peripheral Member States that face greater difficulties in accessing thethe objectives of a sustainable economic recovery will not be achieved.I voted against.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The report takes a critical look at the activities of the ECB.However, since he calls for the completion of the banking union on the one hand and the introduction of a transfer union on the other, I reject this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Central Bank in 2015annual report.I appreciate the efforts and policies of this institution to ensure the financial stability of the euro area.However, we must not forget to continue to address other issues that are sensitive for Member States, business and all citizens: bank profitability, lending to SMEs, reducing the risk of shadow banking, providing liquidity to Greece, the risk of asset and housing price bubbles, and so on.t.This concern is also reflected in the EP resolution, so I hope that the European Central Bank will be able to find the best balanced fiscal policy solutions that will contribute to European economic growth and financial stability.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- This annual report acknowledges that "the effects on the real economy (of the actions of the ECB) have been very limited".But without questioning their logic.The report defends the independence of the ECB.He even calls on governments "to avoid statements questioning the role played by the institution within the framework of its mandate".Clearly, the ECB does what it wants and it is forbidden to complain!Above all, the report does not propose to directly finance the real economy and prefers to continue fueling speculative bubbles by bailing out the banks.I vote against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - This annual report reviews conventional monetary policy instruments as well as unconventional tools. Written in a civilized tone, this report highlights few value judgments favorable to the policy implemented by the ECB. Reservations are clearly expressed on the transmission to the real economy of quantitative easing (QE), on the questionable quality of the collateral provided in return for liquidity, on the non-conditionality in terms of lending to the real economy of certain programs, on the risks of zero interest rates on the economic model of life insurance, on that of bond crashes in the event of a rate hike, on the delicate management of an exit from QE (tapering), on the necessary sharing of tasks with the EBA, etc. Even if this opinion does not praise the actions of the President of the European Central Bank, Mario Draghi, our criticisms of the economic model of the ECB would go far beyond the simple reservations expressed in this report. That's why I abstained on this one.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The euro area continues to experience a high level of unemployment, excessively low inflation and major macroeconomic imbalances, including the current account balance, and that, in addition, the euro area is facing a very low level of growth productivity, which results from the lack of investment - 10 percentage points below the level recorded before the crisis - and the absence of structural reforms, as well as the scarcity of domestic demand. The high level of public debt and in particular the high volume of non-performing loans and the persistence of an undercapitalized banking sector in some Member States continue to cause a fragmentation of the euro area financial market, thus reducing the room for maneuver that would support the most fragile economies. Sound fiscal policies and structural reforms that are socially balanced and geared to increasing productivity are the only way to bring about sustainable economic improvements in these Member States. Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the ECB’s annual report for 2015 as the ECB is critical in defending the stability of the euro.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- The situation remains worrying.The euro area continues to suffer from a high unemployment rate, too low inflation, a very low level of productivity growth and a lack of structural reforms.Added to this is a high level of public debt and an under-capitalized banking sector.It was therefore essential that the ECB continued the extraordinary measures in order to bring inflation back up to the medium-term target of 2%.The ECB today is fulfilling its role of doing everything to defend the euro.But that alone will not be enough.We need to strengthen structural reforms in the EU, implement the Banking Union and create a Capital Markets Union.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which calls on the European Central Bank to do more in order to make sure that liquidity reaches the real economy and SMEs in particular, and to be vigilant that the low interest rates banks are benefiting from are translated into more loans to the real economy.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The European Central Bank has submitted its report for 2015. In its draft resolution, the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs seeks to address the economic problems of the euro area: high unemployment, excessively low inflation, significant macroeconomic imbalances, declining levels of investment, lagging structural reforms and consequent very low productivity growth. It supports the ECB President's view that without sound fiscal policies at Member State level and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs, the single monetary policy alone will not be able to stimulate aggregate demand. It stands for the rapid, gradual completion and full implementation of the banking union. It is concerned about the risk of a wealth and real estate bubble due to an extremely low (negative) interest rate policy and recommends that the ECB take appropriate action. I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The advice given to us is not an ode to Mario Draghi and the ECB, the criticisms and reservations are there. However, the model we advocate would go far beyond these simple criticisms. We are in favor of a renationalization of monetary policy and banking supervision, around a common euro currency accompanying the transition to national currencies. At the very least, we call for a reform of the treaties in order to modify the mandate of the ECB (inclusion of the objectives of growth, employment, exchange rate policy) as well as its status (autonomy and non-independence vis-à-vis - vis-à-vis States), and we demand the possibility of directly monetizing the debt (modification of article 123 TFEU). These options for another monetary policy in the Union are not reflected in this report, although several groups besides the ENL are in favor. In this, it is representative of only part of Parliament’s opinion, and certainly not the most electorally dynamic.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- Some remarks in this report with regard to the ECB's policy are relevant, but there is no overall questioning of the ECB.I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which highlights the main financial-economic trends in the euro area in 2015. In addition, it stresses that single monetary policy alone cannot boost the economy: structural reforms are needed, in the banking sector and in the capital market union.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the ECB's 2015 annual report.It allows us to put into perspective the situation in which the European Union, and more particularly the euro zone, finds itself: excessive unemployment, economic indicators, in particular fiscal deficits, which are still very worrying.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I welcome Mr Ramon Tremosa's report, in particular the fact that it addresses policies that maintain extremely low interest rates, which can lead to a lack of consolidation of public deficits in some Member States.I am particularly pleased that the report emphasizes the preconditions laid down by the European Court of Justice for Central Banks to buy government bonds issued by euro area Member States, and I consider it important to coordinate national economic policies, especially with regard to the euro area.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ On 1 June 1998 the European Central Bank was established with the main task of maintaining price stability in the euro area and thus preserving the purchasing power of the single currency. It is the central bank of the 19 Member States of the EU who have adopted the euro. I have voted for this 2015 annual report regarding the European Central Bank which states that the euro area is facing a very low level of productivity growth and will continue to do so due to the high level of unemployment, excessive low inflation and large macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up.- The single monetary policy must be complemented by sound fiscal policies and ambitious, socially balanced structural reform programs at Member State level.Simple monetary policy is not the right tool to solve the structural problems of the European economy, and the expected economic recovery does not replace essential structural reforms.We emphasize that a functioning, diversified and integrated capital market would support the transmission channels of the single monetary policy.In this context, we call for a gradual end to the banking union and full compliance with the relevant legislation by the Member States, as well as for the construction of a capital markets union, as this would be a decisive step in improving the effectiveness of the single monetary policy andmitigate the risks arising from a shock in the financial sector.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I supported this report by vote, which summarizes extremely well the problems encountered by the ECB the previous year, as well as the reforms needed for economic growth.In this regard, I welcome the contribution of the European Central Bank and the role it has played in ensuring the financial stability of the euro area, defending the single currency and stimulating employment.Last but not least, I voted in favor of this report because it draws the European Commission's attention to the need to improve its practices for supervising the shadow banking sector (non-bank loans), as it is a growing phenomenon.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the report, which is adopted annually and comments on the ECB's work.It can be stated that so far it is fulfilling its task well of ensuring the monetary stability of the euro area and participating in ensuring the financial stability of the euro area.Among other things, the report rightly points to the problem of poorer access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises in some Member States, which could lead to further distortions of competition if the ECB bought large corporate bonds on the capital market.The report also sends an important political signal in support of the gradual completion and full implementation of the Banking Union.However, I emphasize that the discussion of this report must not lead to an attempt at political interference in central bank decision-making.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- This report is very critical of the ECB.However, he calls for the completion of the banking union and advocates a transfer union.It is for this reason that I have spoken out against this report.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- This report serves as a review of the activities of the European Central Bank and should also enable it to set its future orientations and objectives.His ideas are neither in line with the democratic accountability of the ECB, nor against current methods of financing which encourage the formation of speculative bubbles.That’s why I decided to vote against.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The report notes that due to the economic downturn, unemployment in the EU is still high, inflation remains low and public debt is high.The report draws attention to the need to gradually complete the banking union and points out that the recovery from the economic crisis is geographically uneven across Member States, which hampers faster growth.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- It should be noted that there are too few favorable factors that could stimulate economic recovery, as so far the European Central Bank's policy is focused only on austerity.The emergency measures taken by the ECB were not effective and had negative consequences.It should be noted that the single currency has not undermined the financial stability of the euro area.The euro area is still characterized by high unemployment and low inflation.In addition, the euro has led to balance of payments imbalances and excessive surpluses in some countries, but the Commission has not taken any action so far.Against this background, I believe that it would be appropriate to draw up an alternative plan for a orderly and controlled withdrawal from monetary union and, in the absence of such a plan, to provide for a withdrawal procedure for any Member State wishing to withdraw from monetary union.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The ECB 2015 report highlights that the euro area continues to suffer from high unemployment, extremely low inflation and large macroeconomic imbalances, and that it also faces a very low level of productivity growth due to a lack of investment. , non-implementation of structural reforms and weak domestic demand. I voted in favor of the report, which emphasizes that a single monetary policy alone is not enough to stimulate aggregate demand, but must be complemented by sound fiscal policies and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs at Member State level. The report also criticizes the gap between financing rates provided to SMEs and those for larger companies. The ECB needs to do more to ensure that liquidity reaches the real economy and SMEs in particular. In view of the proposal for Britain to leave the EU and given the low growth rates, geographical disparities in the eurozone and the lack of investment in the real economy, the debate on the completion and full implementation of the banking union in the EU and the completion of work on Capital market union, in order to improve the effectiveness of the single monetary policy, is as relevant as ever.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that, although the euro area continues to face a negative period due to high unemployment, worryingly low inflation and continuing macroeconomic imbalances, the ECB is acting firmlyfacing the crisis.In fact, at the launch of the FPA in March 2015, conditions slightly improved and this allowed loans to households and businesses in the euro area to resume.In June 2016, the ECB launched a series of long-term refinancing (TLTRO II), but for this to be successful, structural reform for individual Member States and full implementation by the Banking Union are required.At the same time, it seems right to ask the Commission to ensure greater vigilance regarding the vulnerability of the banking sector.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – As a substitute member in the ECON Committee, I supported this report because it provides a good assessment of the interplay of monetary policies and structural reforms and the risks of low interest rate policies. The text as finally adopted takes a balanced assessment of the asset purchase programme (APP) of the ECB. It does not call for an expansion but requests an impact study concerning secondary markets for public debt.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The primary task of the ESCB (European System of the Central Bank) is to ensure price stability and to support the Union's general economic policy. With the extraordinary measures adopted by the ECB, inflation would rise to the level of the medium-term target of 2%. This will also increase the profitability of banks and their readiness to improve lending activities. The report focuses on the basic elements of the ECB's activities, ie monetary policy. This is significant because the 2014 report was delayed in Parliament as the rapporteurs decided to focus on the Union's economic policies and not on the work of the ECB itself. The Eurosystem should assign credit ratings that complement those assigned by private agencies in order to assess the suitability of public debt securities for APP. The text as finally adopted conducts a balanced assessment of the program's purchasing assets (APP) from the ECB, but requires a secondary market impact assessment for public debt. In line with the EPP's priorities, this Report provides a balanced assessment of monetary policy and structural reforms, as well as low interest rate policy risks.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - The report makes few value judgments favorable to the policy implemented (on the contrary, §2 and 6), and the tone is intended to be nuanced. Reservations are thus clearly expressed on the transmission to the real economy of QE, on the foreclosure effects it induces, on the risks of asset bubbles (in particular real estate), on the dubious quality of the collateral provided in counterpart of liquidity, on the non-conditionality in terms of lending to the real economy of certain programs, on the risks of zero interest rates on the economic model of life insurance, on that of bond crash in the event of an interest rate hike, on the delicate management of an exit from QE (tapering), on the necessary sharing of tasks with the EBA, etc. The criticisms and the reservations are there. However, the model that I am defending would go well beyond these simple criticisms. Indeed, I would like to see an essential renationalization of monetary policy and banking supervision, around a common euro currency accompanying the transition to national currencies. I therefore prefer to abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - I share this report because, while it approves the monetary expansion policy put into practice by the European Central Bank, on the other it underlines the fact that the ECB alone cannot be able to sufficiently stimulate aggregate demand, but it is essential that is accompanied by ambitious and socially balanced investments and structural reforms by the Member States. The euro area continues to be characterized by a high unemployment rate, too low inflation and poor productivity growth. All important signs of a lack of investment, a lack of adequate structural reforms and a weakness in domestic demand. The report also rightly criticizes the fact that the ECB's expansionary action has had limited effects on the real economy, because banks have used cheap credit to fix their accounts rather than to finance economic and productive activities. . I therefore join the appeal to the ECB to monitor more closely to ensure that the resources it puts in place are translated into financing for the real economy and, in particular, for SMEs.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The ECB cannot stimulate demand on its own, investments are needed and ambitious and socially balanced structural reforms at Member State level. In the euro area, the negative impact of high unemployment and large macroeconomic imbalances continues. Only good fiscal policies and reforms aimed at increasing productivity can drive sustainable improvements in the economy in the long run. I am concerned about the potential consequences of negative interest rate policies for individual savers and the financial balance of pension systems, and about the emergence of bubbles in the asset market. Negative effects on income could lead to an increase in the household savings rate, which would harm domestic demand. I call on the ECB to carefully assess the risk of a recurrence of the bubble in the property and real estate markets. The ECB's current policies weaken the link between ensuring central bank liquidity and lending to the real economy. Despite the limited effects on the real economy, banks could access financial resources at almost no cost, thus directly subsidizing their balance sheets, while the volume of these subsidies is not monitored or disclosed. The demographic deficit in Europe should also be borne in mind when tackling deflationary pressures, creating incentives to establish a more balanced demographic structure. The danger of negative investment expectations in the event of demographically unfavorable trends must not be ignored. I welcome the publication of the minutes of the Council meeting and urge the ECB to continue its efforts for transparency.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Today it is clear that the Banking Union created to give strength to the financial system and to deal with systemic banks, dubbed too large to fail, was nothing more than a maneuver designed to remove from the sovereignty of States and national governments the ability to intervene and to impose a set of merger operations between financial institutions, thus aggravating the problem that it was supposed to solve. In the Portuguese case, the situation is stark. With the centralization of all supervisory and resolution functions at the ECB, the largest banks ended up being sold to foreign groups at a bargain price, leaving the loss to the taxpayers, since the resolution fund has only been financed by the State Portuguese. As is evident, the Banking Union will not solve any of the economies' problems, with or without the deposit guarantee system. Because the Banking Union is an expression of the dominance of the financial system over the political power of the EU, which has long since resigned from defending the interests of the citizen to dedicate itself to serving the interests of those who control political power in Europe.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- The euro area continues to suffer from the negative effects of high unemployment and large macroeconomic imbalances.The 2015 annual report focuses on the basic elements of the ECB's activities, namely monetary policies.It provides an assessment of the interactions between monetary policies and the structural reforms implemented by the various member states.I believe that the creation of a Capital Markets Union, as well as better cooperation between national economic policies within the EU, can be a decisive step in improving the effectiveness of the single monetary policy, while also reducing the repetition of damageresulting from a shock in the financial sector, comparable to that of 2008. I voted in favor of approving the ECB's annual report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- The report reasonably discusses the policy of the ECB.Nevertheless, due to the report's promotion of an extremely expansionary ECB policy (asset purchase program, targeted longer-term refinancing operations), as well as my serious doubts about the positive effects of Mario Draghi's statement and a more critical approach to the further enlargement of the banking union than expressed in the reportI have chosen to abstain.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015. The European Parliament was able to take stock of the activities of the European System of Central Banks (ESCB) and of the monetary policy of the Eurosystem.This report shows that monetary policy is not enough to get out of the crisis.The Union needs structural reforms, strong national budgets and responsible fiscal policies in the Member States for growth in the euro area to generalize and for unemployment to fall in all Member States.It also testifies to the usefulness of Parliament in monitoring the Union's institutions.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Despite its undoubted benefits, the euro area continues to experience high unemployment, excessively low inflation and major macroeconomic imbalances, including the current account balance. In addition, this area faces a very low level of growth, resulting from a worrying lack of investment - 10 percentage points below the level recorded before the crisis - and the absence of structural reforms, as well as the scarcity of domestic demand. The high level of public debt and, in particular, the high volume of non-performing loans and the persistence of an undercapitalized banking sector in some Member States, continue to cause a fragmentation of the euro area financial market, thus reducing the room for maneuver which would support the most fragile economies. I believe that only by applying sound fiscal policies and structural reforms that are balanced and geared towards increasing productivity will sustainable economic improvements be achieved in the most fragile Member States, such as Portugal. Therefore, my vote is in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst critical in parts (on for example TARGET2 imbalances) this non-legislative report nevertheless also calls on the ECB and Commission to act to shore up the ECB system rather than plan to disband it, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - Mr President, this annual report positively assesses the generality of the ECB's monetary policies. Stresses, however, that the euro area continues to experience a high level of unemployment, excessively low inflation and major macroeconomic imbalances, including the current account balance, and that, furthermore, the euro area is faced with a very low level of productivity growth, which results from the lack of investment - 10 percentage points below the level recorded before the crisis - and the absence of structural reforms, as well as the scarcity of domestic demand. It also notes that the high level of public debt, and in particular the high volume of non-performing loans and the persistence of an undercapitalized banking sector in some Member States, continue to cause a fragmentation of the euro area financial market, reducing the margin maneuver that would support the most fragile economies. For all these reasons, sound fiscal policies and structural reforms that are socially balanced and geared towards increasing productivity are urgent.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this dossier on the annual report on the activities of the ECB, as it supports the expansionary monetary policy that the euro issuing entity has been developing. Thanks to the socialists, the initial emphasis in the draft report on structural reforms, which qualify as socially sustainable, has been lowered, in addition to recognizing the federal nature of the ECB and reiterating support for the promise made by its president in July 2012, on doing everything possible to safeguard the stability of the euro. However, it is true that monetary policy is not enough, so it is necessary for the Union to activate an expansionary fiscal policy that supports growth and employment, with the review of the European Fund for Strategic Investments being the occasion to carry out an issue of long-term bonds, taking advantage of negative interest rates, with which to relaunch the financing of projects that generate jobs in sectors such as energy, bioindustry, or infrastructure, among others.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the 2015 annual report of the European Central Bank.In this report, the European Parliament underlines its fears that the ECB will downplay the link between the provision of central bank liquidity to banks and lending to the real economy.Banks must take their share of the responsibility in reviving our economy.This report also underlines the need to put in place structural reforms given the average results recorded by some euro area countries, particularly in terms of employment.On this point, I am very clear: these reforms can in no way weaken workers.On the contrary, it is particularly crucial to secure the professional paths of our European workers and to provide support to people who are unemployed.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- The activity report of the European Central Bank is a rather non-controversial document.However, it needs to be backed up by proposals such as an assessment of the ECB's response to the crisis and safeguarding the stability of the euro, as well as a call for greater focus on the finalization or assessment of highly concessional commercial banks and the persistence of illiquid bank assets.At the same time, I would like to emphasize that the amendments tabled by colleagues criticizing the euro as a factor hindering economic recovery are more dictated by populism than by delving into the problem.It would be good if such provisions did not appear in the final document.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted against this report, in my opinion, excessively complacent with the activity of the European Central Bank.I consider that the ECB clearly overstepped its functions during 2015 by using the means at its disposal to exert political pressure on the Greek Government.In addition, the policy of quantitative expansion and the purchase of bonds through secondary markets has been a gift to financial institutions that has not resulted in benefits for society and has not been able to solve the economic problems that it intended.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted for the 2015 annual report of the European Central Bank, in which the European Parliament takes stock of the activities of the European System of Central Banks.The central themes of the report are price stability on the one hand and support for the Union's economic policy on the other.The main focus in 2015 was the recovery of the euro area economy, continued low inflation and the impact of low interest rates.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report as it falls too short in criticizing the functioning of the European Central Bank during the financial year 2015. It points out some substantial criticisms of the activity of the ECB during this period, the role of super interest ratesreduced, the impact of Quatitative Easing, etc.However, the report goes on to call for the need for "structural reforms" so that the same monetary policy can work.We need a different monetary policy that calls into question the "independence" of the ECB and allows it to function to finance public debt and not just debt markets, where the financial system blackmails states.The report does not criticize the current structure, nor its undemocratic operation and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as it calls for the EU Commission to legislate new rules.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - The European Central Bank plays a very important role in the EU, which additionally becomes particularly important in times of crisis. Europe is currently struggling with many problems, such as high unemployment in the euro area, market imbalance, the impact of the Russian embargo, low economic growth, low investment levels, insufficient internal demand or the fragmentation of the financial market. The ECB can contribute to combating these unfavorable phenomena by introducing financial instruments and by introducing targeted products into its offer. In addition, every effort should be made to ensure the proper functioning of the single monetary and fiscal policy and to ensure a stable environment conducive to investment. It is also very important to properly monitor and control the effectiveness of the actions taken in order to better select solutions and carry out reliable evaluations of the use of funds. In addition, when making decisions with a pan-European financial impact, it is also necessary to take into account their potential impact on individual customers and the sustainability of pension systems. The problems that the ECB has to face also include the impact of its current interest rate policy on local and regional banks and savings banks and the issue of risk in the insurance and pensions sector. For this reason as well, detailed monitoring and forecasting and impact assessment are essential.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual qualityrepresentative action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - Although 2015 was a year of recovery for the euro area economy, the euro area continues to suffer from high unemployment, excessive inflation and significant economic imbalances, including current account imbalances. Nevertheless, I supported the resolution because I think that in 2015 the European Central Bank (ECB) managed to restore consumer confidence to support consumption, business confidence to restore job creation and investment, and banks' confidence to increase credit. I also consider it positive that the strengthening of confidence in 2015 played a key role in supporting the recovery and the return of inflation to our target level, below but close to 2%. I am pleased that the dynamics of credit growth in the euro area have started to increase and our employment continues to grow. On the other hand, however, I must point out that the euro area has so far failed to cope with the very low level of labor productivity growth that results from the lack of investment. I am aware that the euro area is currently facing some uncertainty, especially with regard to the outlook for world economies and the future direction of Europe. Nevertheless, I believe that the ECB will be able to guarantee price stability in the period ahead and thus the achievement of the Union's objectives.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Parliament's report on the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015 notes that high levels of public debt and a number of bad loans in the banking sector continue to undermine the euro area financial market, while highlighting some important facts about the current financial situation. Among other things, the report draws attention to the worrying practice of the ECB, which reduces the link between providing liquidity to central banks and lending to the real economy by providing liquidity to banks at negative interest rates and removing repayment requirements if they do not reach their benchmark. He also points out that banks with very low costs can access funds to subsidize their balance sheets, while the effects on the real economy would be minimal, and that these subsidies are not subject to strict conditions regarding the implementation and purpose of investments. However, despite many important findings, the report does not address some other current issues, such as the need to promote a more sustainable economy, and does not include a requirement to set up mechanisms to channel funds into investments with a long-term positive impact on society and the environment. abstained in the vote on this report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- This report is the European Parliament's answer to the ECB's 2015 annual report. In general, it should be emphasized that this report, which I was in charge of as shadow rapporteur for our group, is surprisingly critical of the ECB's policy.So z.B. the risks of low interest rates expressly and particularly emphasized.However, the text has some points that I expressly cannot support.He sees the expansionary monetary policy of the ECB in line with the mandate of the central bank, welcomes Draghi's statement to “do everything possible” to save the euro, and is positive about the banking union.Since this is nevertheless one of the most critical statements by Parliament on the current policy of the ECB, I abstained from the vote in order to honor this positive development.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The euro area still suffers from a number of problems, such as high unemployment, too low inflation, low growth and high public debt.Parliament therefore calls on the European Commission to prepare a proposal that will improve macro-prudential oversight and risk mitigation policy instruments in shadow banking.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not approve the resolution of the EU Parliament on the 2015 annual report of the European Central Bank.The EU Parliament welcomes the fact that “the ECB categorically declared in August 2012 that it would“ do everything ”to defend the euro, which has made a significant contribution to maintaining financial stability in the euro area”.It is absolutely wrong to welcome this “whatever it takes”.The ECB has thus exceeded its mandate by acting on fiscal rather than monetary policy.It did not preserve financial stability, but set the euro area on the wrong path.This irregularity exposes all savings assets in the euro zone to the risk of complete devaluation.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The euro area continues to be negatively affected by high unemployment rates, excessively low inflation (below the 2% target) and large macroeconomic imbalances. Aggregate demand cannot be stimulated by the ECB's single monetary policy alone, but without sound fiscal policy and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs. Some Member States may use low (negative) interest rates to delay structural reforms. The rapporteur is concerned about the potential consequences of a policy of negative interest rates for individual savers and the financial balance of pension systems, and emphasizes that the end of this policy of extremely low (negative) interest rates should be managed properly, prudently and in a timely manner. I support this Report and welcome the European Central Bank's categorical promise in August 2012 to "do whatever it takes" to defend the euro, which is key to ensuring the financial stability of the euro area.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015. When the European Central Bank decided in 2012 to do its best to hedge the euro, it made a very important contribution to maintaining financial stability in the euro area.With the eventual withdrawal of the United Kingdom from the European Union, the euro area will face a negative risk.I support the President of the European Central Bank, Draghi, who emphasizes that a single monetary policy is not enough for stable growth in the EU if it is not followed by systemic measures and structural reforms at Member State level.Slovenia is one of those countries that has been talking about structural reforms for years, but unfortunately has not yet adopted them.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The report emphasizes that, despite the European Central Bank (ECB) 's incomplete strategies, the solutions it has provided have been sufficient and what is needed now is for Member States to continue or deepen their structural reforms, to deepen and complete them. banking union and to harmonize the monetary policy of the Member States. He fears new real estate bubbles and at the same time criticizes the ECB for its negative interest rate loans. Our disagreement with the above approach is vertical. We voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The ECB, as one of the key institutions of the EU, must act in the interests of the citizens of the Union, their well-being and a dignified life, and must not place the protection of the common European currency above the people.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - The role of the ECB will be further enhanced, as it will be given a new role in many areas, so even more attention will be paid to the Bank's activities. That is why I consider it important to work even more closely with Parliament so that real democratic control can take place. I welcome the fact that, as in previous years, this year's report insisted on the fact, clearly enshrined in the Treaties, that the central and sole role of the central bank is to keep the exchange rate stable, including the single currency, the euro. place the ECB’s policy in context. I also consider it important to acknowledge the fact that, without the ECB's long-term refinancing operation last year, Europe would have had to face much greater exchange rate fluctuations. As a result, it is likely that a much larger supply of money would have accumulated in the markets, possibly in the form of often bad stocks, which could have led to higher inflation and then excessive exchange rate growth. At the same time, I see that the ECB should immediately start taking these one-off money market operations as soon as tensions in the banking sector ease and if economic indicators of inflation allow this decision. Looking to the future, I agree with the importance of the introduction, which should well reflect the diversity within the national banking sector.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament's report on the European Central Bank's Annual Report for 2015, as I welcome the work of the European Central Bank to protect the euro, which has proved essential in preserving the financial stability of the euro area. I also agree with the report that without proper fiscal policy at Member State level and ambitious and socially balanced structural reform programs, a single monetary policy alone will not be able to stimulate aggregate demand. I now endorse the call for the ECB to carefully assess the risks of an asset and real estate bubble due to extremely low negative interest rate policies, especially in some large cities, and to submit proposals specifically with the European Systemic Risk Board on this issue. to develop macro-prudential recommendations to address it. I also agree with the statement that, in order to ensure that monetary policy and Parliament are more transparent to the general public, it is extremely important to continue the monetary dialogue.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up.- Parliament's annual report on the document presented by the European Central Bank covers the ECB's monetary policy activities - such as interest rates and monetary operations.However, it does not cover specific issues related to the supervisory function of the ECB in the context of the banking union.I believe that the ECB alone, without support, cannot stimulate the applications submitted, unless they are complemented by ambitious investments and programs, carried out at Member State level.In this context, I am voting in favor of the document.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015. The euro area continues to suffer from high unemployment, too low inflation as well as still significant macroeconomic imbalances, including excessive current account imbalances . In addition, it faces a very low level of productivity growth, which stems in particular from the lack of investment - ten percentage points below the pre-crisis level -, from a lack of structural reforms and weak domestic demand. The high level of public debt, and in particular the huge volume of non-performing loans in the banking sector, as well as a banking sector which is still under-capitalized in some Member States, still lead to fragmentation of the financial market in the euro area, which reduces the room for maneuver to support the most fragile economies. Only a solid fiscal policy and socially balanced structural reforms geared to boosting productivity can deliver lasting positive economic development in these Member States.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The ECB Annual Report describes the activities of the European System of Central Banks and reports on the Eurosystems’s monetary policy of the previous year. This year’s report stresses that although the ECB’s operations show a positive impact regarding assisting in real economic growth in the euro area, high public and private debt and the insufficient implementation of growth-enhancing reforms remain at the heart of the ECB’s set-backs. I voted in favour of the draft report for 2015, as it has proven to be an important mechanisms in evaluating the ECB’s performance and activities, providing foresight as well as hindsight into both the positive and negative policies and practices of the Bank, which, in the case of negative practices, if left unchecked, can have disastrous effects on the EU economy.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. - In light of the data, albeit modest, of economic growth, I would like to encourage the ECB to continue developing a program of structural reforms in the EU member states. I also stress the importance of a solid strengthening of the competences of the Single Supervisory Mechanism. In agreement with the monetary policy programs, the completion of the Banking Union would allow for a glimpse of competitiveness growth in the coming years, to bring inflation back to the 2% target. Policies to revive the economy must absolutely be combined with the fight against unemployment, which must be considered an urgent issue and which continues to be among the causes of the slow economic recovery. Although it has dropped from 2015 levels, sizeable disparities remain between European states, with 24% unemployment in Greece and 6% in Germany, even more alarming when considering the data on youth unemployment. It is essential to deal with the consolidation of public deficits in a timely manner, underlining the key role of governments, giving impetus to growth policies and support for the disadvantaged, from research to integration policies.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the report on the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2015.
