I believe that the report for 2015 is more systematic, transparent, and better identifies the merits of the program of the European Central Bank compared to the one from 2014.The emphasis on European monetary policy and the insistence on the independence of the European Central Bank in its implementation is the key to maintaining price stability in the Member States of the European Union.Also, calling on the European Central Bank to assess risk and prevent the recurrence of bubbles in the property and real estate market that threatens due to the policy of extremely low interest rates is needed to avoid a new financial collapse.Finally, calling on the European Central Bank to respect the principles of proportionality in the conduct of monetary policy is a commendable request.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I am satisfied with the fact that the rapporteurs approached the topic of the European Central Bank and the policy it implements with extreme sensitivity.It is particularly encouraging to see critical observations on problematic points such as the effects that very low (or negative) interest rate policies can have.However, I cannot agree with some of the elements contained in the report, in particular the assertion that the European Central Bank's extraordinary expansionary policy, such as asset purchases, targeted long-term refinancing operations, etc., is consistent and complementary to its mandate.So I abstained.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Central Bank's annual report for 2015. The annual report focuses on the ECB's monetary policy activities and deals only with actual annual developments at the ECB. The low interest rate policy pursued by the ECB has yielded some results. Releasing additional money for economic growth was a good decision. However, further insistence on low interest rates would not be good. Last but not least, it also poses a major threat to pension funds, for which interest is a means of preserving and increasing assets. It seems that precisely those countries that have not made the necessary reforms in the past have been stunted by economic growth. This is very dangerous, because the next crises, if they come, which they certainly will, will be even less prepared than before. Slovenia is certainly one of such examples, as can be seen from the reports of the European Semester. The strength of the European monetary system also depends on the strength of each individual national system, no matter how small. The problems in the banks faced by the states were not only the result of the crisis, but above all of the negligent, often deliberately harmful conduct of individuals or certain interested groups. The ECB should promote accountability within its remit. Given the reactions in connection with the rehabilitation of the Slovenian banking system, the ECB unfortunately acted too reluctantly.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report, in my opinion, excessively complacent with the activity of the European Central Bank.I consider that the ECB clearly overstepped its functions during 2015 by using the means at its disposal to exert political pressure on the Greek Government.In addition, the policy of quantitative expansion and the purchase of bonds through secondary markets has been a gift to financial institutions that has not resulted in benefits for society and has not been able to solve the economic problems that it intended.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- This report is the European Parliament's answer to the ECB's 2015 annual report. In general, it should be emphasized that this report is surprisingly critical of the ECB's policy.So z.B. the risks of low interest rates expressly and particularly emphasized.The text also has some points that I expressly cannot support.He sees the expansionary monetary policy of the ECB in line with the mandate of the central bank, welcomes Draghi's statement to “do everything possible” to save the euro, and is positive about the banking union.Since this is nevertheless one of the most critical statements by Parliament on the current policy of the ECB, I abstained from the vote in order to honor this positive development.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I think this report is a good compromise among European Parliament sensibilities. The ECB’s action in response to the financial crisis was necessary to get credit flowing into the real economy. However, its effects will fade if national governments in countries like France, Spain and Italy do not reduce their excessive debt levels and implement reforms that generate growth and jobs. The ECB should be aware that increased banking concentration is one of the factors diminishing the effects of its monetary policies. The German banking system with a wide network of small banks should be the role model for the Eurozone.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - The traditional report on the action of the ECB moves away from a simple commentary on the institution's 2015 report and focuses on both the macroeconomic situation and the latest measures taken by the central bank, including therefore during 2016. Reservations are thus clearly expressed on the transmission to the real economy of QE, on the crowding-out effects it induces, on the risks of asset bubbles, on the dubious quality of collateral. provided in return for liquidity, on the non-conditionality in terms of lending to the real economy of certain programs, on the risks of zero interest rates on the economic model of life insurance, on that of bond crash in the event of an increase in rate, on the delicate management of an exit from QE, on the necessary sharing of tasks with the EBA, etc. In the end, the advice given to us is not an ode to Mario Draghi and the ECB, the criticisms and reservations are there. However, the model we advocate would go far beyond these simple criticisms. We are in favor of a renationalization of monetary policy and banking supervision, around a common euro currency accompanying the transition to national currencies. I chose to abstain.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Concerning the possible secession of the United Kingdom from the European Union, President Draghi rightly stated that “the extent to which the economic outlook is changing will largely depend on the timing, course and final outcome of the negotiations ahead.So far, the euro area has been resilient, but due to this uncertainty factor, the baseline scenario could change in a negative direction, ”the document said.I voted in favor of the group's position in the final vote.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I am in favor of a well-functioning, diversified and integrated capital market that can support the transmission of the single monetary policy.Addressing non-performing loans in the worst-affected national banking sectors is particularly important in order to restore a smooth transmission of monetary policy across the euro area.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against this report, in my opinion, excessively complacent with the activity of the European Central Bank.I consider that the ECB clearly overstepped its functions during 2015 by using the means at its disposal to exert political pressure on the Greek Government.In addition, the policy of quantitative expansion and the purchase of bonds through secondary markets has been a gift to financial institutions that has not resulted in benefits for society and has not been able to solve the economic problems that it intended.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the European Central Bank Annual Report for 2015. The Report stresses that the euro area continues to suffer from a high level of unemployment, excessive low inflation and large macroeconomic imbalances. The Report underlines the federal nature of the European Central Bank, which rules out national vetoes, enabling it to act decisively in addressing the crisis. In addition, it notes that the APP would have a higher impact on the European economy if it was accompanied by effective and socially balanced structural reforms designed to increase the competitiveness of the European economy. I voted in favour because I believe that a well-functioning, diversified and integrated capital market would support the channels of transmission of the single monetary policy.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - In compliance with the provisions of article 284 of the TFEU, the Annual Report of the European Central Bank is presented to the European Chamber. On this occasion, the central issues have been the recovery of the Eurozone economy, low inflation, the effects of low interest rates and the ECB's decision to expand its Asset Purchase Program. The analysis that the European Parliament makes here of this report is certainly valuable, since it focuses on the core elements of the ECB's own activities, such as monetary policies - breaking with the practice of covering general economic policies that on previous occasions it led to delays and complications in parliamentary procedure. The present text, for which I voted, provides a balanced assessment of the relationship between monetary policies, structural reforms and the risks of low interest rates; Also, the ECB's Asset Purchase Program, not asking for its expansion, but requesting a study of the impact it would have on public debt.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I voted against this Parliament report on the ECB's 2015 Annual Report because it expresses a completely distorted and shortsighted view of reality. This is mere pro-ECB and pro-Euro propaganda, which seems to totally ignore the real causes of the problems and the clear failure of monetary policy to counter the crisis. On the contrary, the text celebrates the success of monetary policy and attributes the problem of the lack of economic recovery to the Member States, to be condemned for not having fully implemented the absurd and unsustainable structural reforms imposed by the Commission. The report is clearly unbalanced and even incomplete, as it does not make any critical observations regarding the controversial role of the ECB in the Troika and especially regarding the conflicts of interest and the strong asymmetries of the new banking supervision function. Our amendments were not included which stressed that the cause of the crisis and the high unemployment rate in the EU was to be attributed to the adoption of the single currency, called for the introduction of the opt-out to allow each Member State to exit the Eurozone and regain their sovereignty, and denounced the ineffective and counterproductive impact of the ECB's unconventional policies in countering the crisis, finally criticizing the Banking Union and Capital Markets Union projects, and insisting on the need for introduce the structural reform of banks.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted against this report as it falls too short in criticizing the functioning of the European Central Bank during the financial year 2015. It points out some substantial criticisms of the activity of the ECB during this period, the role of super interest ratesreduced, the impact of Quatitative Easing, etc.However, the report goes on to call for the need for "structural reforms" so that the same monetary policy can work.We need a different monetary policy that calls into question the "independence" of the ECB and allows it to function to finance public debt and not just debt markets, where the financial system blackmails states.The report does not criticize the current structure, nor its undemocratic operation and that is why I have decided to vote against it.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ With my S&D and EPLP colleagues, I voted in support of this report because it expresses its concerns on the potential consequences that the actual negative interest rates policy could have for individual savers, pension schemes and in terms of the development of asset bubbles and asks the European Commission to come forward with proposals to improve macro prudential oversight and the policy tools available for mitigating the risks in the shadow banking.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because the ECB is in favor of the framework for simple, transparent and standardized securitization and the resulting lower capital requirements, which will revitalize both securitization markets and the financing of the real economy.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written. - I voted against the report on last year's annual report of the European Central Bank. The report strongly supports the policy of the European Central Bank, sees the failure of the Member States in structural reforms underlying Europe's economic problems and encourages the building of a banking and capital market union. In my opinion, attempts to correct euro casting defects will only exacerbate the current situation. The basic flaw of the single currency is that there are too many different economies involved. The role of the European Central Bank is hopeless as it tries to keep inflation close to the 2% target. Overall growth in the euro area has been non-existent. The periphery of the large euro area - including Finland - has been hit by a debt spiral, internal devaluations, high unemployment and severe austerity. The best option would be a controlled dismantling of the euro area, with all or at least some of the Member States reintroducing national currencies alongside the euro.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The report on the activities of the European Central Bank in 2015 - adopted by 16 votes of majority - apparently contains some interesting reforms from a social point of view and rightly criticizes the tendency of the ECB to align itself with the German position despite disastrous consequences. Unfortunately, this report is not critical - even complacent - vis-à-vis the monetary policy of the ECB. This is a weak compromise between the PPE, S & amp; D and ALDE groups: the main focus is on the "structural reforms" to be undertaken and on "competitiveness" - hackneyed and empty words. At the very least, the ECB should have been asked to set employment targets instead of its obsessive desire to fight inflation alone. For Europe to move forward, we need a new monetary policy and, again at a minimum, democratic control of the ECB. This report does not draw satisfactory conclusions. I voted against.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - Today, it is clear that the Banking Union created to give strength to the financial system and to deal with systemic banks, dubbed too big to fail, was nothing more than a maneuver aimed at removing from the sphere of national governments any possibility of intervening and imposing a set merger operations between financial institutions, thus aggravating the problem it was supposed to solve. In the Portuguese case, the situation is stark. With the centralization of all supervisory and resolution functions at the ECB, the largest banks ended up being sold to foreign groups at a bargain price, leaving the loss to the taxpayers, since the resolution fund has only been financed by the State Portuguese. Of course, this Banking Union will not solve any of the economies' problems, with or without the deposit guarantee system. Because this Banking Union is an expression of the dominance of the financial system over the political power of the EU, which has long since resigned from defending the interests of the citizen to dedicate itself to serving the interests of those who, in fact, rule Europe.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The report supports the extraordinary measures and monetary policies taken by the ECB in the face of the ongoing financial crisis.The implementation of the single monetary policy is explicitly mentioned and in this context the gradual completion of the banking union and the capital markets union is called for.However, since I oppose such a transfer union, I voted against this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Over several years, the ECB has taken action to keep the eurozone from further upheaval. However, we must be clear that the ‘structural reforms’ that we need are not more austerity, or more blindly applied ‘budgetary discipline’. What we need is sensible social public investment for inclusive and sustainable growth. The eurozone and the EU as a whole must be built on social solidarity across borders. Regardless of what the outcome of Brexit might be, we must maintain our core values and stick to the principles of the internal market and a social Europe.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I support the role that the ECB has of defending the euro. I support the gradual implementation of the full Banking Union and I also believe that the distortion of competition has to be avoided. As a liberal I support transparency, so I believe that there has to be more information on asset purchases. In this time of economic and political turmoil, the credibility of the European Central Bank is fundamental in order to make the European economy work. I believe that the ECB has to analyse the different situations across Member States before the implementation of new monetary policies, and thus analyse which Member State relies more on banks or capital markets for the financing of the economy, in order to prevent bad impacts on those economies. I agree that single monetary policies alone cannot stimulate aggregate demand unless it is complemented by efficient fiscal policies and socially balanced reform programmes at Member State level.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the ECB's Annual Report for 2015. The resolution emphasizes the federal nature of the ECB, which has made it possible to take firm action against the crisis and recognizes that the extraordinary measures taken by the ECB to bring inflation back to 2% in the medium term are in accordance with the terms of his mandate. The resolution emphasizes that there are still discrepancies between the financing rates granted to SMEs and those granted to larger companies. The EP points out that the constant need for balance sheet adjustments affects, inter alia, the availability of credit for SMEs in some Member States. The EP notes the ECB Presidency's recognition of the distributional effects of ECB policies with an impact on inequalities and notes the ECB's assessment that reducing credit costs for citizens and SMEs, coupled with stimulating employment in the euro area , could partially offset these distributive effects.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - As every year, we have voted on the report on the ECB. This year the report is particularly controversial: clearly aligned in favor of the ECB, the text makes only a partial examination and makes no criticism. All the unconventional policies of the ECB are labeled as successful policies and the total independence of the Frankfurt bank is emphasized several times. On the contrary, the ability of states to carry out structural reforms is repeatedly questioned and the possible failure of policies not envisaged by the treaties is blamed on themselves. No criticism of the role of the ECB in banking supervision, much less the Troika. As I did in the ECON committee, I voted negative on this report with particular attention to the fact that the ECB's unconventional policies have not only proved useless as they have not helped the real economy, but have also been harmful when, by injecting liquidity in the market, they favored speculative activity by banks and increased the risk of speculative bubbles.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- The report on the European Central Bank's annual report looks at the EU's economic situation and expresses the European Parliament's position on the issue.I have chosen to support the report because I agree with the vast majority of the recommendations made.I think that the EU's clear economic priorities should be to ensure a sufficiently resilient eurozone and an intact single market.It is clear that the euro area is currently facing the challenge of high unemployment, low inflation and macroeconomic balance.I agree that strong budgetary policies and socially balanced structural reforms, which will increase the overall productivity of the European economy in particular, will help to improve this situation.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I did not support the European Parliament's report in response to the European Central Bank's 2015 Annual Report.Although this report was a pleasant surprise with its approach and content, it nevertheless contained a number of elements with which I do not agree.One of the positive elements of the report was, in particular, the fairly critical approach to the European Central Bank's policy.To the negative ones, in turn, justify the bank's controversial step to reduce the interest rate to a negative level, or elements of the central bank's expansionist policy.It is for these facts that I have decided to abstain in the final vote.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I support the Annual Report of the European Central Bank for 2015.The European Central Bank is the umbrella body in the conduct of monetary policy in the European Union.It is important that this body has independence in the operation and implementation of measures aimed at creating a stable banking system and maintaining inflation and interest rates.However, as the report itself has well identified - economic development and growth measures cannot depend solely on monetary policy, a number of other mechanisms need to be engaged to create a sound foundation for future economic growth.I support the idea of the existence of an independent body at European level that determines the credit rating of the Member States due to repeated errors in the work of private credit rating agencies.I agree that the work of the European Central Bank should be as transparent as possible and that there must be a publicity of work to the extent that it does not interfere with normal work.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - The report, which is presented annually by the ECB to Parliament, illustrates the measures and policies adopted by the same institution in the monetary field during 2015. In this document, all the ECB's unconventional policies are identified as successful policies. Instead, the ability of states to carry out structural reforms is called into question and the possible failure of policies not foreseen by the treaties but implemented by the ECB is blamed on them. Again, we find no criticism of the ECB's role in banking supervision. We at the M5S have presented amendments that highlight how, not only, the unconventional policies adopted by the ECB have proved useless because they have not helped the real economy, but also have been harmful. The injection of liquidity into the market has, in fact, favored speculative activities by banks and therefore increased the risk of speculative bubbles. It is also necessary for the ECB to put an end to an excessive interpretation of its founding treaty, taking on more functions than originally envisaged as in the case of participation in the Troika and more recently of EU banking supervision (SSM). I have therefore voted against this report.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 Annual Report of the European Central Bank for the Body because I believe that it provides a balanced and realistic assessment of the impact of monetary policies and structural reforms and the risk of low interest rate policy.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: - Mr President, the financial crisis has shown two things: first, that financial concentration is a very dangerous thing, and second, that only strong regulation can protect consumers' interests. This report seems to forget both lessons. I am a strong supporter of the standardization of products, but in this respect, the report is very vague. Bet on restricting sales targets and providing more and more demanding information to consumers, but that is not enough. It is important, but it is naïve, we think that we can eliminate the risk as long as banks sell products that consumers are not able to decipher. Let us be honest, this report does not prevent new bankruptcy victims, and so many people in Europe have lost their life savings. On the contrary, this report, for example, by removing restrictions on competition in retail services, will result in the formation of huge financial conglomerates and the creation of more institutions, too large to fail. For all of this, I voted against. We should have learned, and we did not.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - As far as financial retail services are concerned, I really perceive a very significant risk here, and that is the risk of unavailability of information and distrust of consumers or clients of financial services in these services. We must overcome this mistrust. I supported this report because I think it very truthfully names the European Commission's efforts and its proposals to resolve the difficulties in this key sector or in one of those key sectors of the banking sector. We must overcome the fragmentation of financial services that is caused today by the fragmentation of legal systems. Indeed, the 28 legal systems present a very fundamental problem, for example for resolving cross-border disputes or for determining jurisdiction, for example for courts to resolve disputes arising from these legal relationships. There are a number of difficult moments. The difficulty of the issue, the unavailability of information, we should address this, monitor global developments, but I do not think that the Commission will be idle on this, so I supported this report.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The following report addresses the creation of a single European market for retail financial services.The report completely lacks a critical analysis of the consequences that the implementation of a single European market would bring.Contrary to what is described in the report, in fact, the consequences would be very negative especially for private investors and SMEs, who would see their accessibility to the markets very restricted.Because I believe that what has been said above does not represent a solution at all, but creates and amplifies the macroeconomic imbalances already present on a large scale in the European economy, especially damaging small investors.These are the reasons why I voted negatively.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up with the Commission, as different measures are proposed to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved, to end the practice of canceling payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State, limit abusive commissions at ATMs, and in defense of the euro as the main currency of the financial services market, so it is a very progressive and pro-European report, which can have a decisive influence on the next legislative proposals of the Commission on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove, both in committee and in plenary, the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, but I am congratulated that this has not been successful.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it represents a continuation of the financial deregulation that prevails in the financial system of the Union.This Green Paper presents the initiative to regulate retail financial products at the transnational level.Instead of seeking greater transparency and security for potential consumers, the report leaves the creation of all kinds of products in the hands of the financial system.Rather than simplify, it is left to be done, allowing a diversity and complexity of financial products that can undermine the interests of European consumers, as has happened in the past with preferred shares.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – I voted against this report (a response to a Commission proposal) because I believe it weakens consumer protection when it comes to the investments of ordinary people. It also promotes the exclusion of those consumers who are not digitally ‘literate’. There are a lot of negative elements in both the Commission’s proposal and this report, which promotes competition in the marketing of these products, fails to recognise significant differences in the nature of complex products in different countries, and will provide advantages for the largest multinational financial institutions. The report aims to ‘level the playing field’ for various financial instruments across the EU and to facilitate the marketing of financial products across borders. But the financial products on the market vary significantly in complexity and in different countries. They are impossible to compare, and proposals in this report would create further advantages for multinational corporations in aggressively marketing their products across borders. By promoting complex financial products at the same level as standard products, consumer protection is significantly weakened.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.The developments of the single market for retail financial services in a digitalized world will only work if we ensure a sufficient level of consumer protection through better information and greater transparency.We call on the Commission to come up with a coherent action plan including concrete legislative proposals to create a European market in which consumer protection and transparency have their place.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.This initiative is timely, given the need to be proactive at all stages of policy-making in order to respond effectively and appropriately to changes in this innovative market.If we want new legislation to work well in a rapidly changing market, we must be proactive here and now.The Green Paper is necessary because the current rapid digitalisation of financial markets opens up new opportunities.Properly used digitization could be the impetus needed to start removing the remaining cross-border barriers to retail financial services.It is now possible to connect financial services providers across Europe with European consumers.This rare opportunity to create a single market should not be missed.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, because I consider it extremely important to promote positive developments in the retail financial services market by creating a competitive environment and maintaining a level playing field for all stakeholders.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- The aim of this report is to further develop the internal market for retail financial services.In doing so, it is important to identify the specific barriers that consumers and businesses face when using the internal market and to find solutions to overcome these barriers.Digitization creates important impulses that can help remove such obstacles to cross-border activities.I voted in favor of the draft because the development of a single market for retail financial services has not progressed sufficiently.It is therefore of particular importance that the choice of offers, transparency and competition are improved across borders for the benefit of European consumers.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The aim of this Green Paper is to launch a debate on how the European retail financial services market could be opened up further. The main recommendation is to establish mutual trust, in particular by ensuring the protection of consumers and the free activity of businesses in their cross-border activities. We oppose this desire to further expand the Single Market because it has proven to bring more problems and disadvantages than benefits, in particular because of economic, cultural and regulatory disparities. We therefore fear that the establishment of the single market for retail financial services will cause serious damage to our national economy and that future market disparities will be corrected by even more technocratic administration and control in Brussels. Moreover, cross-border purchases of retail financial services are a serious threat to our banking sovereignty and to the future of our citizens if the euro disappears. This single market wants to give itself the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer, but it is above all an additional channel that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not to leave the area. euro or the European Union. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for greater harmonisation of financial services, and therefore I had no choice but to vote against it.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because the presentation of this Green Paper seems to me to be an appropriate choice.Indeed, the construction of the single market for retail financial services remains at an embryonic stage.We are still today in the presence of 28 different and uncompetitive markets.Digitization is a factor that should allow us to remove barriers to cross-border activity and I welcome the upcoming launch of a public consultation with stakeholders in the sector.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.The EU retail financial services market is still underdeveloped and highly fragmented, with low levels of cross-border transactions, for example, and effective action is needed to realize the full potential of the single market and foster innovation for the benefit of end-users.Against this background, I welcome the Commission's initiative in drawing up a Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The report is on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services. It starts from the premise that financial exclusion is a widespread and serious problem across Europe, making it very difficult for people to live because they do not have adequate access to at least the most basic financial services. Therefore, the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services focuses mainly on financial services offered to citizens seeking cross-border services. In his view, determined efforts should continue to be made to break down borders and curb existing protectionist tendencies that hamper innovation in retail financial services. I do not agree with the report. Brexit has proven that unfounded integration has its limits, crossing it can lead to disintegration. The main problem is that while they want to centralize everything and bring it under the control of Brussels, Brussels bureaucrats are not responsible for the economic and social problems caused by this centralizing integration. (For example, for the indebtedness of the peripheral countries, or for the decline in living standards.) We say no to any further such integration efforts, the Union's vest must be re-buttoned from the beginning.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ Calls on the Commission to become further involved in consumer protection in financial services, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The aim of this Green Paper is to launch a debate on how the European retail financial services market could be opened up further.For the moment, cross-border purchases of these services remain very limited and most of them are already available in national markets.The main recommendation is therefore to establish mutual trust, in particular by ensuring the protection of consumers and a certain freedom for businesses in their cross-border activities.This single market wants to give the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer, but it is above all an additional channel that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not to leave the areaeuro ... or the European Union.I voted against this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which is the EP's contribution to the Commission's Green Paper on retail financial services aimed at preparing the action plan to be proposed in 2017, while supporting the priority of the Commission which is to identify the specific barriers consumers and businesses face and ways to overcome them. The report stresses the need to ensure good consumer protection through additional actions aimed at empowering consumers to make informed decisions, increasing the transparency of retail financial products and removing barriers, costs and related or the withdrawal of a product. In this perspective, the report calls for full implementation of the various laws already adopted (mortgage credit directive, payment accounts directive, payment services directive 2, MiFID regulation, directive on the distribution of insurance) and calls on the Commission to take further initiatives, including a proposal for an EU savings account, and to encourage the financing of sustainable and green investments.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report to support the European development of retail financial services.The approach of this report seems very timely to me, and developing a more efficient market will allow more innovation and promote the entry of new players into the market.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The retail financial services market is still underdeveloped and highly fragmented within the Union, with a low number of cross-border transactions. The need to promote efficient action in this area has therefore prompted the Commission to present a Green Paper on retail financial services, which is welcomed by the Ludvigsson report, which I supported today. The text underlines the importance of a dynamic approach to policy making, including continuous monitoring of their implementation at the national level and highlighting the main challenges in advancing the retail financial services agenda. The capacity to collect and analyze data at Union level needs to be strengthened, giving greater emphasis to the empirical aspect in impact assessments. We need to ensure that there are no unjust differences between the Member States that join the euro or not, by supporting the maintenance of a level playing field and guaranteeing true collective financial inclusion. The future of the European retail financial services market must be coordinated with the agendas of the Digital Single Market, the Capital Markets Union and the Single Market strategy; this is the only way to aim for job creation, sustainable growth and financial stability.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against this proposal for the liberalization of retail financial services.Although the objective of giving more power of choice to consumers, and lowering the price of products may seem laudable, the legislation moves towards deregulation that favors the single market but does not offer guarantees of standardization and transparency of the products thatthey are put on the market.In this way we can hope that the large multinationals can sweep away the smaller suppliers, and that derivative financial products whose risk is very difficult to assess will be imposed on safer products.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I want to thank Olle Ludvigsson for his work on this report on the Green Paper on retail financial services.The initiatives based on this Green Paper should be compatible with the intensification of the fight against tax fraud, tax avoidance and evasion and money laundering, including further efforts towards the development of a common tax identification number.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I voted against the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.Proposing the creation of yet another single market, in this case relating to retail financial services, this proposal represents a deadly threat to our banking sovereignty.Clearly, if the euro were to disappear, retail financial services contracted in other countries would be subject to currency exchange risk and many households would see the amounts of loans to be repaid vary widely.In addition, the establishment of the single market for retail financial services could cause serious damage to our national economy.It seems obvious that future market disparities will be corrected by even more administration and technocratic controls in Brussels.We refuse it.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have voted against this own-initiative report on financial services for private individuals.There are major problems associated with this area.The differences between the countries' systems are large, and it will be difficult for citizens to get an overview and make the right choice.There is a great risk that transnational companies will dominate the market with aggressive marketing.I do not believe that the interests of consumers are sufficiently protected.That is why I choose to vote no.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this own-initiative report whereby Parliament expresses its position regarding the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up by the Commission, with a view to the action plan to be presented in 2017. The report proposes differentmeasures to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature.Also included is a proposal on creating a European savings account and increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments.From the Spanish Socialist Delegation, we also celebrate the approval of our amendments to eliminate cross-border barriers, limit abusive commissions at ATMs and in defense of the euro as the main currency in the financial services market.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as it sets out Parliament's position on the Commission's Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.Parliament welcomed the Commission's Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, the definition of which covers both insurance, and the lively and productive debate that this Green Paper has so far stimulated.Parliament is of the opinion that digitalisation will continue to provide new opportunities for competition, cross-border activity and innovation for consumers, investors, SMEs and other businesses.However, he emphasizes that digitization is not enough to create a viable European retail financial services market.In Parliament's view, many obstacles, such as the diversity of tax, social, legal, contractual, health and consumer protection regimes, as well as linguistic and cultural differences, cannot be removed by digitalisation alone.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I endorsed the above-mentioned Green Paper, as it is the European Parliament's response to the European Commission's Green Paper.The strategic goal in the document is to decide how the European financial market should be further opened up in order to bring better results for consumers and businesses, while providing equal protection for consumers and investors.These goals will be achieved through digitalisation, diversification of providers and the need to provide better opportunities for SMEs.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report.I believe that the further development of this single retail market for financial services in the digital world will only work if a sufficient level of consumer protection is ensured through better information and transparency.The Commission must propose a consistent action plan, including concrete legislative proposals to create an EU market in which well-protected consumers have equal opportunities and access to transparent and well-valued products.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on the Green Paper on retail financial services because I shared with the rapporteur the idea of developing the retail financial services market at EU level. Indeed, a genuine European internal market for retail financial services will have an important impact both on consumers and competition: the former will have more choices and the latter will lead to lower prices.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - There are three main reasons why the Green Paper was presented at the right time. First of all, because level 2 measures must be made to be fair and adequate and that implementation is monitored at national level. Furthermore, to date, little progress has been made in building a single market for retail financial services and, due to a large number of barriers, cross-border activity is still limited. This is neither good for consumers nor for innovative businesses, or for the general functioning of the European economy. Finally, if well managed, digitization could create the momentum needed to start removing the obstacles to cross-border activity. There is a need to advance the retail financial services agenda by strengthening the Union's capacity for data collection and analysis, making identification in practice and creating and maintaining a level playing field. It is also necessary to eliminate unnecessary differences between EU member states and those that do not belong to it. For the single market to be truly effective, its integrity must be kept within this essential element. Finally, it is vital to ensure that everyone is included. Financial exclusion must be drastically reduced.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This Green Paper aims to strengthen the European market for retail financial services such as current accounts, retirement savings solutions, financing of real estate projects and personal and property insurance. This project would increase competition between financial institutions for the purchasing power of customers. To achieve this, this text recommends establishing mutual trust by ensuring the protection of consumers and the liberalization of banking / insurance activity in cross-border areas. On the contrary, we consider that the establishment of the single European market highlights above all the economic, legislative and regulatory disparities that exist between the Member States. We therefore rightly fear that the European Commission will correct these disparities by strengthening European regulations and legislation to the detriment of our national sovereignty. Therefore, this single market is above all a further step in the economic, monetary and financial integration of the European Union. I therefore opposed this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up.- The retail financial services market at Member State level is fragmented and still underdeveloped.As a result, immediate action is needed to foster innovation and improve these financial services.With regard to the number of cross-border transactions, this is low, which is why it is necessary to establish a comprehensive legislative framework that requires the necessary consumer protection.This could also lead to greater opportunities for increased competition at national level.I spoke in favor of this report because I believe it is essential to build a single market for retail financial services in order to provide consumers with better financial services and products, a wide range of options and improved access to financial services.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - Retail financial services are an essential part of the daily lives of EU citizens. These include personal bank accounts, payments, personal loans, mortgages, savings, pensions, investments and certain insurance products. They facilitate citizens' participation in the economy, allowing them long-term planning and protecting them in unforeseen circumstances. I support the EP's motion for a resolution on the "Green Paper on Retail Financial Services". In recent years, great efforts have been made to create a single market for financial services in the EU, but the integration of retail financial services does not seem to have reached its maximum capacity yet. For example, one of the advantages of the single market should be increased competition. However, in some markets, competition is not effective, especially in the payments and banking sectors. In other words, consumers cannot benefit from cheaper or higher quality services in other EU Member States. Without sustained efforts, European financial markets risk remaining fragmented. An improved market in the retail financial services sector would also create new market opportunities for suppliers, supporting growth in the European economy and creating jobs.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up with the Commission, as different measures are proposed to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved, to end the practice of canceling payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State, limit abusive commissions at ATMs, and in defense of the euro as the main currency of the financial services market, so it is a very progressive and pro-European report, which can have a decisive influence on the next legislative proposals of the Commission on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove, both in committee and in plenary, the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, but I am congratulated that this has not been successful.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. - The Commission published in December 2015 a Green Paper and a public consultation to assess the feasibility of a European retail financial services market. The Commission's objective is to identify the remaining obstacles to cross-border activities in the field of retail financial services, taking into account the digitization of these services and technological developments. This report is therefore the European Parliament’s contribution to the reflection on the creation of a European market for retail financial services. A European retail financial services market will have very positive consequences for consumers, investors, SMEs, fin-techs and businesses. However, it seems hardly achievable in the current state of affairs. Many barriers, which cannot be overcome only by the digitization of services, persist such as regulatory (different tax, social, health, ...), geographic and cultural (languages) barriers. It is also important not to rush into legislative work so as not to create duplication with the European legislation which has recently been created in the field. I voted in favor of this report for which I am the rapporteur for the EPP.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- After careful reflection and discussion in plenary, I gave my positive vote to the report on the Green Paper on retail financial services.I am convinced that the reason why retail financial services at the EU level are still underdeveloped is the lack of transparency of transactions, which negatively affects consumer confidence.It follows that with great difficulty I imagine a development of coordination with the digital single market, first of all due to the lack of respect for the principles of cooperation and exchange of information and privacy profiles.However, I am convinced that coordination with the digital single market is a necessary and useful path, given the ease with which communication exchanges take place in the digital world.Robo-advisory, which represents the most modern fintech outpost, will soon be a reality.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Calls on the Commission to become further involved in consumer protection in financial services, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it seeks to address the specific barriers that consumers and firms face in making full use of the single market and ways in which these barriers could be overcome, including by making the best use of new technology. But the report considers that the diverse obstacles, such as contract and consumer protection regimes and different languages and cultures, that hinder the full excess to the single market cannot be overcome solely by means of digitalisation.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The report on the Commission's Green Paper does not analyze the negative repercussions of the liberalization of the retail financial services sector, either from the macroeconomic point of view or from that of financial stability.It is not taken into account that, instead of creating a real improvement in competition in the sector, the configured market will favor the production of standardized and increasingly complex instruments, difficult to access to small investors and SMEs.The proposed solution therefore risks exacerbating existing macroeconomic and financial imbalances within the eurozone, especially in the absence of effective preventive safeguards for investors.This is an intervention that would bring nothing to the real economy and which, on the contrary, risks being harmful.I therefore voted absolutely against.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Retail financial systems, in each national context, offer citizens a range of essential services. However, as there is currently no European-wide market, it is difficult for consumers in one Member State to purchase products supplied in another Member State. The creation of a single market, through digitization, would make it possible to overcome the differences in price and choice within the Union, facilitating cross-border transactions for the benefit of both consumers, who would benefit from a wide range, and businesses, which could make their products available anywhere in the Union. I believe that for the realization of this ambitious project it is essential to guarantee consumers enhanced protection, guaranteeing them adequate information and greater transparency. I therefore voted in favor of the report as I believe it is essential that the Commission, in preparing an action plan for 2017, seeks to identify and remove the barriers that hinder consumers and businesses from cross-border opportunities. In this regard, I believe it is essential, in order to achieve a fairer single market, to improve the use of new technologies as well as to strengthen the fight against fraud and tax evasion.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and stress the importance of ensuring that there are no unnecessary or unfair differences between Member States belonging to the euro area and Member States that do not belong to the euro area.For the single market to be truly effective, its integrity must be maintained in this vital area as well.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.Although the original aim of this exhibition was to promote innovative services in the light of modern times and for the benefit of citizens, there are failures and limitations that lead to the marginalization of citizens who do not have access to new technologies.As the protection of citizens is a priority, I decided to vote against.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Negative vote for this report which expresses strong support for the activities of the European Commission without taking into account the criticisms raised.It is also not mentioned that the opening of financial services to a single market could bring to their knees companies that have their headquarters in Member States with a more fragile economic situation such as Italy.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - Among the well-known challenges that Europe has a duty to face is undoubtedly that of making its financial system as clear as possible and close to savers and businesses. I therefore consider the adoption of the Green Paper to be an important step in this regulatory mosaic in progress. The aim is to open up the European market for retail financial services, thus achieving better results in terms of utility and protection for consumers and businesses. In fact, a progressive approach to the users of these services is sought by removing the numerous obstacles encountered in the single market since it is underdeveloped and highly fragmented. Certainly, the dynamics of high concentration and scarce competition, characteristics of this market, do not make it attractive due to the limited possibilities of choice and an unsatisfactory cost-benefit ratio. The Green Paper will be a harbinger of solid consumer protection, also extending to digitization and financial technological innovation, producing revolutionary services rich in potential thanks to which reduction in transaction costs and greater comparability of products are achieved. Through these methods it will be possible to obtain a wider inclusion of savers, start-ups and SMEs facilitated, thus, in accessing finance and opening up to cross-border markets.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services and noted no objections.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because it highlights one of the major issues concerning retail financial services, namely financial inclusion and education.In order to achieve the completion of the capital market union, it would be necessary to guarantee all consumers equal opportunities to access essential financial services, including through non-digital channels in order to avoid financial exclusion.Furthermore, in the current context increasingly linked to the financial market, it is necessary for the protection of consumers to guarantee and promote correct and in-depth financial education that allows citizens to better evaluate the investment opportunities proposed.Finally, in encouraging the digitization of financial services, it is appropriate to take into account both the new advantages and the new risks, which can affect both consumers and the technological infrastructures of the sector.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I consider that unjustified discrimination based on residence, unjustified price differences, and unfair and unjustified geoblocking practices applied to common retail financial products between Member States require action hinders progress in this sector. I concord with the ambitions of the rapporteur to breaking down barriers and curbing existing protectionist tendencies that block innovation in retail financial services; whereas a true single market will make the EU attractive as the hub for innovative financial services. I believe that the rapid transformation brought about by digitisation and fintech innovation not only has the potential, if prudently managed, to create new and often better financial products for consumers and to contribute to financial inclusion, including by means of lowering transaction costs and easing access to finance, but also involves key challenges in terms of security, data protection.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it represents a continuation of the financial deregulation that prevails in the financial system of the Union.This Green Paper presents the initiative to regulate retail financial products at the transnational level.Instead of seeking greater transparency and security for potential consumers, the report leaves the creation of all kinds of products in the hands of the financial system.Rather than simplify, it is left to be done, allowing a diversity and complexity of financial products that can undermine the interests of European consumers, as has happened in the past with preferred shares.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - While supporting the Commission's priority to identify the barriers consumers and businesses face and ways to overcome them, especially in the use of new technologies, the report adopted in the ECON committee insists on the need to ensure consumer protection through further action to enable consumers to make informed decisions, to increase the transparency of retail financial products and to remove barriers to consumption and any unjustified costs related to them or to withdrawal from a product. To this text, the contribution of the Group of Socialists and Democrats was decisive in order to strengthen consumer protection but trying to maintain specific safeguards to facilitate cross-border transactions and the development of new digitalisation services. I therefore consider this text a very important act of the institutions towards consumers in order to increase their confidence in the markets.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - Legislation must work well in the context of a constantly changing market; therefore, we need to think about these solutions in an active way. In terms of most retail financial products, we are still dealing with 28 different and not so competitive national markets, with cross-border activity still limited. This is to the detriment of consumers, businesses and the overall functioning of the European economy. There is enormous potential that is not yet exploited. In order to make progress on the retail financial services agenda, some major challenges need to be addressed. We voted to build a stronger capacity to collect and analyze data at EU level more efficiently, but also to create and maintain a level playing field. Building a functioning single market in the field of retail financial services is an important project. It is, at the same time, a project that is worth all the effort and that will create real added value.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - Retail financial products are becoming increasingly complex and care must therefore be taken to ensure that consumers recognize and compare safely sustainable and simple products in the range of products available to them. It is also important that consumers enjoy the same legal protection everywhere in the EU, and the motion also emphasizes the importance of financial education, which raises consumer awareness. Initiatives based on the Green Paper are in line with the international fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and money laundering, including the intensification of efforts to introduce a common tax identification number. The challenges of the proposal are to strengthen data collection and analysis capacity at EU level, to create and maintain a level playing field and to put identification into practice. The main points of the proposal are digitalisation, product comparison, the creation of green financial products and the issue of the lack of financial services, such as the various tax, social, judicial, health, contracting and consumer protection systems in the Member States.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - Effective development directions and concrete actions are needed to unlock the full potential of the Single Market and facilitate innovation for the benefit of end-users. The Green Paper, while respecting the principle of proportionality, focuses mainly on financial services for citizens in need of cross-border services. The main aim is to ensure that the retail financial services market works for the benefit of all. Actions to remove barriers and limitations must be guaranteed. I also believe that cooperation between the Member States within the EU is an important issue, with due regard to the subsidiarity principle, in supporting retail financial services companies wishing to make better use of cross-border business opportunities. Therefore, I voted in favor of the Green Paper on retail financial services as I share the rapporteur's view that the EU market for retail financial services is still relatively underdeveloped.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as I believe that in a developing single market and in a digitalised world we also need to identify the specific barriers that consumers and firms face in order to set out ways how to overcome them. We need to ensure good protection of consumers in order to empower them to make informed decisions which are complemented by increased transparency and this is duly noted in the report, as well as a legislative framework which enables equal opportunities to all consumers and access to well-valued products.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: in writing. - The Green Paper on Retail Financial Services highlights the need to create an EU market in which consumers are well protected, have equal opportunities and access to simple, transparent and good value for money products, in a harmonized legal framework on standardized default options for the most commonly used EU financial products. It also supports the strengthening of the international fight against tax fraud, tax avoidance and tax evasion, as well as money laundering, including further efforts to develop a common tax code. However, there are growing concerns about the emergence of new retail financial service providers, such as in the case of insurance, and the growing complexity and engineering of retail financial products. Citizens do not always understand clearly and fully the products they subscribe to, while it would be advisable for them to be complete, simple, safe and standardized. Furthermore, if digitization continues to create new opportunities for consumers, investors, SMEs and businesses in terms of competition, cross-border activity and innovation, it will not solve problems related to the safety and protection of consumers and their investments. For these reasons, my vote is against.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- The process of developing and growing innovative small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups needs to transpose and implement this legislation, avoiding duplication and duplication, as well as creating and maintaining a level playing field for all stakeholders, including operators.traditional and new operators, with rules as neutral as possible in terms of technology and business model.On the other hand, I believe that steps need to be taken to ensure that the same service is regulated by the same rules, in order to avoid distortions of competition, especially with the emergence of new retail financial service providers.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ Calls on the Commission to become further involved in consumer protection in financial services, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this report following the publication of the Commission Green Paper drawn up to assess the feasibility of a European retail financial services market.The creation of a European retail financial services market would indeed have positive economic repercussions, in particular for SMEs which could see easier access to finance.But before reaching this objective, the text rightly insists on the need to strengthen consumer confidence in retail financial services by guaranteeing the transparency of these products and by facilitating their understanding and comparison between the different States.members of the European Union.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.The objective of this Green Paper is to launch a debate on how the European market for retail financial services (current accounts, retirement savings solutions, financing of real estate projects, personal and personal insurance)ownership) can guarantee the free activity of companies in their cross-border activities.We therefore oppose these proposals, which are at odds with the banking sovereignty of the Member States and constitute a threat to Europeans if the euro disappears.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the resolution. This report is in response to the Commission's Green Paper on Financial Services in the Retail Market, with a view to launching a debate on the possible opening of the European financial services market. Markets across the European Union are very different in nature due to regional and national specificities, and this is also the case for financial services within the EU. I agree that better coordination and exchange can be very useful, and I welcome the fact that the rapporteur has produced a fairly balanced report, which has taken into account many proposals from other political groups. Some of the proposals that I support and that have been included are a reference to the common tax identification number, alignment of the summary of the prospectus with the basic information document for retail investment product packages and insurance-based investment products (PRIIP), the European Supervisory Authorities authorities to step up their activities on issues related to consumers and retail investors, as well as a call for intensified work against blocking on a geographical basis, implemented by a legislative proposal aimed at the financial sector.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- We are voting against the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services because we oppose cross-border investment with all the necessary immigration policy requirements.Especially for our country, the fiscal situation and the exclusion of the public sector from the markets create insurmountable obstacles for the issuance of green bonds, which strengthen the power of supervisory authorities.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It is essential for my constituents in Wales that we have effective rules that protect consumers and ensure transparency.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: this single market wants to give itself the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer, but it is above all an additional channel that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not tonot leave the euro zone or the European Union.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing.- This initiative, apparently aimed at improving users' conditions, represents, in practice, another element of harmonization, of deepening federalism, which will serve the interests of large financial groups, facilitating the concentration of wealth and the centralization of financial power.and economic.This initiative will lead to the liquidation of smaller companies and the promotion of pan-European banking oligopolies, with an increase in the profits of the major EU banks, namely through the reduction in operating costs, which include the dismissal of workers, processes facilitated by the aspectand reducing the physical deployment of companies.We will have less transparency, more fraud and tax evasion and an aggravation of the problem of companies "too big to fail".We can only reject this path.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe it is an important stimulus for the discussion on the creation of a single market for retail financial services to continue fruitfully.I also consider the content of the report to be relevant as regards the need for better communication on essential financial products, on efforts to simplify existing legislation and on the beneficial effects that digitization could have in removing cross-border obstacles.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - I welcome the European Commission's initiative in the field of retail financial services.In order to move forward on the existing agenda in the future, we need to face a number of challenges.We will have to work together to find a way to build a more efficient and effective system for data collection and analysis at European Union level.Creating a well-functioning single market for retail financial services is a major project.At the same time, such a project is definitely worth the effort.It is a clear case of the European Union creating real added value.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I vote against, some points could be shared but it remains a generic and incomplete text, with strong unconditional support for the work of the Commission.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, as I oppose cross-border investment with all the necessary immigration policy requirements.Especially for my country, the fiscal situation and the exclusion of the public sector from the markets create insurmountable obstacles to the issuance of green bonds, which strengthen the power of supervisors.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Further developments of the single market for retail financial services in a digitalised world would only work if we ensure a sufficient consumer protection level through better information and more transparency. Thus, I support the call for the Commission to propose a consistent action plan including concrete legislative proposals to create a EU market in which well protected consumers have equal opportunities and access to transparent and well-valued products. I consider important the need to ensure a right balance between consumer protection and the development of the single market for retail financial services. Therefore, I believe that the scope of the future Commission action plan should equally focus on consumer protection measures and the development of cross-border opportunities.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement.
