Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report, bearing in mind that the Green Paper focuses on a number of elements for which it could be advantageous for the legislation, currently in the implementation phase, to be completed in the coming years. For most retail financial products, we continue to face 28 divergent national markets and not as competitive as you might expect. Due to a multitude of barriers, cross-border activities remain limited. This is not good for consumers, not good for innovative companies, not for the overall functioning of the European economy. There is enormous potential that we have not yet exploited. The Green Paper is also timely because digitization is opening up new possibilities at a fast pace. If addressed properly, digitization could provide exactly the necessary impetus to start removing cross-border barriers. We now have a real opportunity to link established financial players across Europe with consumers residing across the continent. This represents a new opportunity for the single market that must not be missed.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services - drawn up with the Commission - as it proposes various measures to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved to end the cancellation of payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State and limit abusive commissions at ATMs. On the other hand, the euro is defended as the main currency in the financial services market. It is, therefore, a very progressive and pro-European report that can decisively influence the Commission's forthcoming legislative proposals on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, albeit without success.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up with the Commission, as different measures are proposed to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved, to end the practice of canceling payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State, limit abusive commissions at ATMs, and in defense of the euro as the main currency of the financial services market, so it is a very progressive and pro-European report, which can have a decisive influence on the next legislative proposals of the Commission on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove, both in committee and in plenary, the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, but I am congratulated that this has not been successful.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- Improving the functioning of the internal market for consumers and professionals is a central objective for the recovery in Europe.I therefore strongly supported this report, which responds to the Commission's Green Paper, with a view to regulatory proposals expected for 2017. I share the priority of breaking down the remaining obstacles to access (especially digital) for customers to financial products and services, in particular the requirements of consumer protection, transparency, cost containment and the right of withdrawal, the improvement of the digital market (a truly priority point for the S & amp; D Group).

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the Green Paper on financial services, because I believe it is of fundamental importance that Parliament, in view of new legislative proposals from the Commission, expresses its opinion on the issue of retail financial services at EU level, a market still underdeveloped and very fragmented particularly in the case of cross-border retail financial services. There is legislation on the subject, but given the fragmentation it is not sufficient and above all not adequate to the current needs of the development of the Single Market and in the interest of consumers and therefore of European savers. Correct and far-sighted information to savers gives savers awareness and accountability in their investment choices, while at the same time enhancing the social, albeit economic, function of savings, and greater strength in the single market for financial institutions specialized in savings. The EU needs a long-term investment strategy capable of mobilizing European savings to SMEs first and foremost, as part of an enhanced European-level oversight of ESMA and national competent authorities, to respond to the challenges of FinTech, namely the ever-increasing digitization of financial services, and the increased role of trading platforms that are often the source of fraud.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on the Green Paper on retail financial services because I believe it is important and right that we do even more in the European internal market to ensure the security and transparency of retail financial products.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The Green Paper on Retail Financial Services is a valuable first step in the implementation of a functioning and globally competitive market.This should aim at ensuring that there are no exclusions or differences between the euro area and the other member states.In addition, a level playing field for private customers must be created in all Member States of the European Union.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. You could say this report forms part of the Capital Markets Union, which is illusionary, as a result of vastly different legal systems across the EU. It calls on the EU Commission to become further involved in consumer protection in financial services.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ President, I voted in favour of this report which constitutes an important step towards creating a stronger single market for retail financial services which puts the consumer first.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - Retail financial services still represent a market that is too compartmentalized, too national. Retail services are the money of ordinary citizens: their current accounts, their retirement savings, their real estate loans, their insurance ... The aim here is to encourage the creation of a single market for these services, and encourage cross-border shopping, which is too rare. The Commission emphasizes that the IT tool now allows better information, that competition will lower prices (a refrain often used but rarely verified), that European regulations allow effective consumer protection ... On the one hand, I doubt that citizens who already take a critical look at their own country's banking services are willing to blindly trust a foreign bank and embark on an adventure the tax treatment of which they will not know. On the other hand, I believe that this project hides behind fallacious arguments to promote an increased interdependence of state economies, making any exit from the EU or the euro more complex. This interdependence will also promote national and European regulatory inflation and, to be honest, an implacable surveillance of everyone's bank accounts. I voted against.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted against this proposal for the liberalization of retail financial services.Although the objective of giving more power of choice to consumers, and lowering the price of products may seem laudable, the legislation moves towards deregulation that favors the single market but does not offer guarantees of standardization and transparency of the products thatthey are put on the market.In this way we can hope that the large multinationals can sweep away the smaller suppliers, and that derivative financial products whose risk is very difficult to assess will be imposed on safer products.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Green Paper as it will strengthen the position of consumers in terms of their protection in financial services.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- The Green Paper does not simplify, let alone abolish the various complex "products" with which multinationals and banks promote casino capitalism.These are the "products" with which they are profiting at the expense of the people and, since they are not being fought, we could not support the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Green Paper on Retail Financial Services that calls on the removal of unnecessary barriers in the European retail financial market. The aim of this report is to improve choice, transparency and competition in the retail financial services sector to the benefit of European consumers through true cross-border supply of these services, so that financial firms can make the most of the economies of scale in a truly integrated EU market. Furthermore, the report took into account the impact of digitalisation on retail financial services with a view to allowing for growth of innovative solutions in this area in the EU.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ This report is a response to the Commission Green Paper on Retail Financial Services with an aim to launch a debate on the possible opening of the European market in financial services, in particular retail services, i.e. savings accounts, mortgages, pensions, insurance, etc. At the moment national markets in financial services across the EU remain very fragmented and the reasons for this are varied. The aim of the report is to look ahead at what could be done to make a European market in financial services happen. I voted in favour, as the rapporteur delivered a rather balanced report trying to take on board many suggestions from other political groups.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of European market integration for services. This is especially true today when it comes to promoting the cohesion of countries inside and outside the euro area and avoiding the emergence of unions within the Union. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the developments of the single market for retail financial services in a world which undergoes constant digital innovation would truly work if we ensure a sufficient consumer protection level through better information and more transparency. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Green Paper Report on Retail Financial Services because I believe it is important that the new proposals benefit all EU consumers to ensure that the retail financial services market works for everyone.This market is still quite underdeveloped and highly fragmented in the EU, which is why effective measures need to be taken to unlock its full potential of the single market and facilitate innovation beneficial to end-users.It is the Green Paper Report, which I voted for, that talks about financial services offered to citizens in search of cross-border services, especially in relation to the rapid changes caused by digitalisation and innovation in financial technologies.There is great potential here to create new and better financial products, reduce transaction costs, facilitate access to finance, security and data protection.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it removes unnecessary obstacles for consumers and businesses and stimulates finance for sustainable and green investments. I am also glad that it encourages retail financial service providers to finance projects associated with innovation and the environment. I believe that unlocking the full potential of retail financial services has a key importance for the dynamics of our internal market.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Olle Ludvingsson on the Green Paper on financial services.The report underlines that there are still many barriers to the creation of a European market for retail financial services, which can only be overcome by the digitization of services.I support this initiative, which should be progressive and benefit consumers, SMEs and industries.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, the objective of which is to decide how the European market for retail financial services (insurance, loans, payments, current and savings accounts, etc.) can be improved for consumers and businesses.Parliament's contribution to the consultation process opened within the framework of the Green Paper seems to me to be well aware of the new challenges, particularly insisting on digitization, the simplification of legislation or even the reduction of geo-blocking practices, for example.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - The Commission proposal is indeed moving in the right direction and shows the significant work that has been done so far to achieve a harmonized system of retail financial products and services. However, the problem is still obvious and the fragmentation shows that, in order for the efficient allocation of funds to work in the European Union, the differences between Member States must be removed, especially now that we are in a process of gradual transition to digital financial services.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting for this own-initiative report.It is to be welcomed that customers have better access to financial products - in compliance with the advisory and transparency obligations.It is also worth supporting the demand to give consumers the opportunity to invest their money more easily in financial products from other EU countries and to be able to lodge reliable and consistent legal remedies if they have knowingly been given incorrect advice.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which is an important step for creating a stronger single market for retail financial services and one which puts the consumer first.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against, since the Green Paper represents the interests of multinational companies rather than the interests of the people. Although digitalisation brings many benefits, our role is to foresee also the side-effects of this process, e.g. increased unemployment caused by the closure of physical shops, and address them by introducing simple and sound legal framework.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing. - The essence of the report is largely correct, as financial exclusion is a widespread and serious problem across Europe, making it difficult for people to live because they do not have adequate access to the most basic financial services. The material should be supported in detail, as it is a welcome goal to enable consumers to identify and compare safe, sustainable and simple products in the range available to them. However, the report as a whole is not acceptable because, as Brexit has shown, unjustified integration has its limits and can even lead to disintegration. The power-hungry centralization efforts of the Brussels bureaucracy, coupled with a complete lack of responsibility, proved to be a dead end, as expected. On our necks is a plethora of unresolved social and economic problems, primarily in peripheral countries: unemployment, falling living standards, indebtedness, and so on.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services because I believe that differences in tax, social, legal, health, contractual and consumer protection systems, as well as different national specificities, cannot to be overcome only with the means of digitization. I consider it extremely important to promote the positive development of the retail financial services market by creating and maintaining a level playing field between all participants in compliance with rules that are as neutral as possible in terms of technology and business models. In order for Europe to be a leading market for innovation, as well as to enable consumers to make better choices at lower prices, it must place a strong emphasis on creating an EU market in which well-protected consumers have equal opportunities and access to products at good value for money.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because the objective of the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services is to consult on the next steps toward creating a more integrated European market for retail financial services for both consumers and businesses. Thus, the Green Paper in the EU works in the interests of consumers and gives them the best deals, better products, more choice, and greater opportunities regardless of their age, skills and country of residence. In this context, I would like to note that the Green paper comes at the right time because digitalisation is now opening up new possibilities for consumers, investors, SMEs and other companies in terms of competition and cross-border activities. Therefore, I urge the EU to coordinate the Green Paper with the process of digitalisation, because this in practice represents a golden opportunity to link financial actors established all around Europe to consumers residing all around Europe. In a long term perspective, such a link between Green Paper and digitalisation could foster job creation, sustainable growth, financial stability and the role of the consumer in the European economy.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- With the report approved today, we want to make it easier to offer retail financial products in other Member States, giving consumers the possibility to choose from a variety of products, and to be able to transfer the latter if they decide to work,study or retire in another country.Cross-border access would therefore be useful in helping citizens in their decision-making processes and in the possibility of choosing competitive products offered by Europe in relation to their needs and budgets, aiming at the inclusion of these services because the impossibility of accessing them makesall the more complicated.I believe that we must work to ensure that this proposal is able to fully satisfy the needs of the community and I vote in favor.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the report on the Green Paper on retail financial services. These include current accounts, retirement savings solutions, real estate project finance, and life and property insurance. For the moment, cross-border purchases of these services remain very limited and most of them are already available in national markets. However, the European Commission wants to encourage financial companies to offer their products in all countries, and citizens to make cross-border purchases. This is a bad idea. The establishment of the single market has proven to bring more problems and disadvantages than advantages, in particular because of economic, cultural and regulatory disparities. The single market for retail financial services could cause serious damage to our national economy, and future market disparities will be corrected by even more technocratic administration and control in Brussels. This single market wants to give itself the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer but it is above all an additional channel that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not to leave the euro zone , or the EU.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The aim of this Green Paper is to launch a debate on how the European retail financial services market could be opened up further.For the moment, cross-border purchases of these services remain very limited and most of them are already available in national markets.The main recommendation is therefore to establish reciprocal trust, in particular by ensuring the protection of consumers and the free activity of businesses in their cross-border activities.This single market wants to give itself the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer but it is above all an additional channel that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not to leave the euro zone., or the European Union.I voted against this idea of a green paper.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written. - The European Parliament today adopted by a large majority a report calling for greater efforts in the field of cross-border consumer financial services. The European market and the national markets for, among other things, pensions and insurance and investment products are still too often characterized by fragmentation and poor competition. As a result, consumers sometimes pay too high a price for their products or are unable to take full advantage of offers abroad. On the other hand, companies also encounter many obstacles when trying to find their way to the foreign customer. This report therefore calls on the Commission to pursue opportunities to encourage cross-border supply and demand of financial services for consumers. It is important that the Commission must respect the social and fiscal competences of the Member States. That is why the N-VA MEPs voted in favor of this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up with the Commission, as different measures are proposed to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved, to end the practice of canceling payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State, limit abusive commissions at ATMs, and in defense of the euro as the main currency of the financial services market, so it is a very progressive and pro-European report, which can have a decisive influence on the next legislative proposals of the Commission on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove, both in committee and in plenary, the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, but I am congratulated that this has not been successful.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up with the Commission, as different measures are proposed to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved, to end the practice of canceling payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State, limit abusive commissions at ATMs, and in defense of the euro as the main currency of the financial services market, so it is a very progressive and pro-European report, which can have a decisive influence on the next legislative proposals of the Commission on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove, both in committee and in plenary, the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, but I am congratulated that this has not been successful.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it represents a continuation of the financial deregulation that prevails in the financial system of the Union.This Green Paper presents the initiative to regulate retail financial products at the transnational level.Instead of seeking greater transparency and security for potential consumers, the report leaves the creation of all kinds of products in the hands of the financial system.Rather than simplify, it is left to be done, allowing a diversity and complexity of financial products that can undermine the interests of European consumers, as has happened in the past with preferred shares.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - This report seeks to overcome the barriers that exist today in retail financial services, while developing them in the coming years. The Union must meet the challenge of creating and maintaining a level playing field. Any new legislative initiative based on this document must be based on technology and business model neutrality. The legislator, in the face of a rapidly expanding market, is responsible for creating a regulatory framework that allows, without manipulation, to create an environment for safe and lasting growth, and then, it is the consumers who decide who wins or loses in this market. It is equally important to highlight the challenge of ensuring that there are no unfair or unnecessary differences between euro area member states and those outside the euro area and that no one is left out. Financial exclusion is a serious problem that affects the whole of Europe, and for the single market to be truly effective, it must also preserve its integrity in this fundamental respect.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which considers the simplification of legislation to make it easier to compare financial products in all Member States.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission Green Paper on retail financial services and stated that its publication is timely, given the need to work proactively at all stages of the policymaking process in order to respond efficiently and adequately to developments in such an innovative and fast-changing market.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - This book, published by the Commission last December, is a means of gathering and obtaining information on the financial market situation.The financial market is an organism that is constantly changing and evolving, with a wide scope and impact on consumers.Therefore, for its proper and effective functioning, it is necessary to continuously monitor and evaluate it.From a thorough analysis of the data, proposals for legislative and other necessary measures governing the financial market can be drawn.The Commission and the Member States must remove obstacles to the functioning of an efficient market and improve access to basic financial services so as to eliminate unnecessary and disproportionate differences between countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 21 November 2016, and because this report is not substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.The green paper on retail financial services aims to develop the European market in this area, in particular for current accounts, retirement savings solutions, financing of real estate projects and personal or property insurance..We oppose this desire to further enlarge the single market, which has continued to demonstrate its ineffectiveness due to economic, cultural and regulatory disparities.In addition, our banking sovereignty is threatened by cross-border purchases of retail financial services and, if the euro were to disappear, retail financial services contracted in other countries would be subject to currency exchange risk.Many households would see the amounts of loans to be repaid vary enormously.This system is, among other things, a means of blocking the exit of Member States from the euro zone.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- I agree with the paper because the better access of customers to financial products, better / more competent advice on them and the possibility of easier appeal are to be welcomed.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I support the EP's position on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.I hope that this set of proposals will bring real added value to consumers, ensure competition, more choice, more access to financial services and products, and lower prices.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - The report aims to establish a European market for retail financial services (including insurance) in the context of the digital boom in the banking sector. As always, it is about working towards "the removal of barriers and the mitigation of existing protectionist tendencies", which would allow "stronger competition at the national level". All this supposedly to facilitate consumer choice. However, the variety of products on the EU market and their complexity may make it very difficult to compare the financial services offered. The report insists that the new rules "do not act as a brake on innovation". But he is not worried about the consequences of the disappearance of “physical” agencies for the elderly or those who do not have access to digital. Finally, the report supports the changeover to the euro for all member states! Beautiful optimism. This time he claims "that the adoption of the single currency by Member States without exception would improve the efficiency and coherence of the single market for retail financial services". The dream! I am voting against this report which in no way seeks to protect consumers but on the contrary favors the speculative banking sector.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The objective of this Green Paper is to further open up the European market for retail financial services including current accounts, retirement savings solutions, financing of real estate projects, personal and property insurance.Europe's desire to further expand the single market, by including retail financial services, will not escape the many problems revealed by the establishment of the single European market, in particular because of economic, cultural and economic disparities.regulatory.This will have serious consequences for our national economy and will result in strengthening technocratic control of Brussels.The establishment of a single market for retail financial services therefore represents a real danger for our national sovereignty, especially banking.This is why I opposed on this file.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- The dynamics of retail financial services, characterized by the combination of relatively high concentration and insufficient competition, can result in limited choice and low cost-benefit ratio, as well as significant disparities between Member States.A European market for retail financial services is only viable if it represents real added value for the consumer, ensuring effective competition, accessibility and consumer protection, particularly in relation to products that are actually necessary for participation in economic life.The Green Paper initiative is timely, taking into account the need to work proactively at all stages of the decision-making process, in order to respond effectively and appropriately to developments in such an innovative and fast marketmutation.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. This sector is crucial for continued growth in the EU and this green paper will help those dependent on the sector.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- I would like to welcome the Commission's Green Paper on Retail Financial Services as it allows for fruitful debate as well as public consultation of the various stakeholders involved, which will allow better products, more choice and more opportunitiesfor consumers and businesses.Indeed, the Green Paper seeks both to determine how to improve the offer, transparency and competition in the retail financial services sector in the interest of European consumers, but also how to enable businesses to offer these services.financial directly in other countries.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the green paper on retail financial services, which emphasises how timely the green paper is, points out that the European Union is lagging behind other global financial centres in some areas, and urges the Commission to come out with legislative proposals to strengthen the sector. I support such initiatives in the area of financial services and believe in a strong Capital Markets Union. Furthermore, this is all the more important in the current context where the United Kingdom, as Europe’s leading financial services provider centre, is leaving the European Union.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- On 10 December 2015, the Commission published its Green Paper on Retail Financial Services: Better Products, More Choice and More Opportunities for Consumers and Businesses.The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs states that the creation of a well-functioning single market for retail financial services is a major project, but it is a project that is worth the effort.He proposes that Parliament take a position: the Green Paper was presented at the right time, the Commission took the right steps and the procedure chosen was the right one.It also takes into account the challenges ahead in order to advance the retail financial services agenda.I supported the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The aim of this Green Paper is to launch a debate on how the European market for retail financial services could become more open, in particular by ensuring the free activity of businesses in their cross-border activities. We oppose this desire to further expand the single market. First of all, the establishment of the single European market has proven to bring more problems and disadvantages than advantages, in particular because of economic, cultural and regulatory disparities. We therefore fear that the establishment of the single market for retail financial services will cause serious damage to our national economy, and that future market disparities will be corrected by even more administration and technocratic control in Brussels. Moreover, cross-border purchases of retail financial services are a serious threat to our banking sovereignty and the future of our citizens if the euro disappears. This single market wants to give itself the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer but it is above all an additional chain that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not to leave the euro zone. , or the European Union.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text proposes the establishment of a single market which wants to give the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer, but it is above all an additional channel that the Commission wants to throw onMember States to force them not to leave the euro zone, or the European Union.I therefore oppose this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ This report is an important step for creating a stronger single market for retail financial services, which puts the consumer first.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this Green Paper report on retail financial services.This text constitutes Parliament's response to the Green Paper presented by the Commission in December 2015 on the feasibility of a European retail financial services market.Such a market would present many advantages for European citizens: access to all retail financial products and services regardless of the Member State in which the citizen resides, a possibility of increasing competition between banking institutions, which will lead toincreased innovation, increased product diversity and lower prices.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing.- The aim of the report is to decide how the European market for financial services, such as insurance, loans, payments, current accounts and other retail investments, can be further opened, bringing better results for consumers and businesses,while maintaining an adequate level of consumer and investor protection.The Green Paper comes at the right time also in view of the fact that digitization currently offers new possibilities at a fast pace.If managed correctly, digitization could create the momentum needed to start removing cross-border barriers.Right now we have the opportunity to connect financial players and consumers across Europe.This is an unmissable opportunity for the single market.Therefore I expressed myself in favor of the provision.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Further efforts are needed in order for retail financial services to be bought and sold across the European Union’s borders without any barriers. I have voted for this report on this consultation document of policy proposals that will be open to debates and discussions and will try to build a stronger EU level capacity for data collection and analysis. This initiative is a dynamic approach to policy making which is necessary in this field.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - The EU retail financial services sector is currently underdeveloped and highly fragmented. This is clear from the amount of financial and technological funding in Europe, which amounts to only $ 348 million. In comparison, in North America and China, which are direct competitors of the EU in this sector, financial and technological financing numbers 1.8 and 2.6 billion, respectively. Against this background, I advocated this resolution because it focuses on digitalisation as a way to develop the retail financial services market in Europe. It can help unleash the potential of this sector by making it more attractive to European consumers through easier product comparisons, better access to cross-border investment and faster registration and payment processes. I supported this resolution because I believe that the use of personal data and large data sets by financial service providers must be strictly limited to the data needed to improve retail financial services in the EU.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - This initiative, the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, comes at the right time, given the need to act proactively at all stages of the policy-making process, in order to respond effectively and adequately to developments in such a market. innovative and changing so quickly. We emphasize the importance of promoting positive developments in retail financial markets by creating and maintaining a level playing field for all stakeholders, including traditional and new entrants, with technology and business model rules that are as neutral as possible. Such an approach is also needed to support the growth of innovative SMEs and start-ups. We call on the Commission to ensure that the same service is governed by the same rules, in order to avoid distortions of competition, in particular with the emergence of new retail financial service providers. This initiative will only be successful if it places a strong emphasis on creating an EU market in which consumers are well protected and have equal opportunities and access to cost-effective, simple and transparent products.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that the retail financial services market is not sufficiently developed in the European Union and that it can be beneficial for consumers.In this regard, the report adopted today encourages the promotion of the retail financial services market by creating a level playing field between traditional and new entrants, which is important in order to support and create new SMEs.Last but not least, I welcome this report, as it calls on the European Commission, together with the Member States, to promote national one-stop shops, which would provide assistance to retail financial services companies wishing to make the most of cross-border opportunities.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the report, which rightly mentions the benefits of digitization for retail investors, such as easier product comparability, better and easier access to cross-border investment, fairer competition between providers and a faster and easier registration and payment process and reduced transaction costs.In addition, it points to the need to strengthen consumer confidence in financial services, especially for financial products with high exchange rate risks.The Commission should contribute to improving financial literacy and information in order to enable consumers to make informed choices, increase the transparency of these products and remove obstacles to consumers switching.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because the report speaks out for the consumer and calls for better access to financial products for the customer.Furthermore, it is demanded that customers should be better advised and given the opportunity to appeal more easily.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- This report proposes to simplify and unify the rules relating to the retail market, in order to create a European market in this area and to allow price balancing on the continent, when the differences are today too great- car insurance can cost from simple to double for the same person depending on the country.However, I decided to vote against this proposal, which is mainly based on the establishment of a large digital market with various negative consequences: first of all by excluding people without internet access as well as by promotinglarge players in the sector compared to small ones, without offering adequate protection to consumers.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.In the retail financial services market, Member States are not very competitive with each other due to cross-border barriers.The Green Paper provides opportunities for opening up markets and better intermediation of services.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I support the report. Retail financial services are very important in the daily lives of EU citizens. It is therefore necessary to step up efforts to develop the retail financial services market and to address the challenges facing consumers and industry in this area. It is essential that the proposed initiatives are in line with increased international efforts to combat tax fraud, tax evasion, tax evasion and money laundering. Therefore, a common taxpayer identification number should be used throughout the EU. However, I do not believe that the introduction of a single currency in all Member States would increase the efficiency and coherence of the single market for retail financial services. On the contrary, a single currency would have extremely negative consequences for consumers and the market as a whole. The measures set out in the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services must bring tangible benefits to EU consumers. Consumers must be adequately protected and service providers must be financially sound and reliable.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. Building a functioning single market in the retail financial services sector is an important undertaking. This is a typical case of the creation of real added value by the European Union. The presentation of the Green Paper comes at the right time for at least three reasons: First, if we want to have effective legislation in such a rapidly changing market, we must intervene immediately now, in the final stages of the policy cycle. We need to monitor implementation closely at national level. We must prepare from the outset for an adequate evaluation. It is important to identify the real problems and real opportunities as soon as possible. Secondly, it is clear that, despite the significant progress made in recent years, much remains to be done. The construction of a single market for retail financial services has not progressed much to date. Thirdly, the Green Paper is additionally relevant, because digitization today opens up new perspectives at a rapid pace. With the right approach, digitization can create exactly the impetus needed to begin removing cross-border barriers. There is currently a real potential for connecting financial institutions and an opportunity to create a single market. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that, although the work done by the Commission in recent years has been intense, we can still improve as cross-border activity has limitations and this does not only harm individual innovative companies but alsoto consumers.Furthermore, the moment must be exploited, above all, since we are in the era of digitization that would allow us to break down cross-border barriers, in order to more easily connect financial actors and consumers and, at the same time, allow fulldevelopment of the single market.However, all this must be guaranteed while maintaining a high level of protection for consumers and investors.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – This report is the Parliament contribution to the consultation process opened with the Commission Green Paper. The objective is to decide how the European market for retail financial services – namely insurance, loans, payments, current and savings accounts and other retail investments – can be further opened up, bringing better results for consumers and firms whilst maintaining an adequate level of consumer and investor protection. As a member of the IMCO and substitute member of the ECON Committees I fully support the digitisation and portability of services, issues which have been taken on board in this Report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Retail finance provides a range of services that are important to citizens: current accounts, pensions and savings, mortgages and financing of other purchases, insurance against health problems or accidents and property insurance. The Green Paper explores the current state of the single market for retail financial services, as well as the recent trend of digitalisation, and the need to act in the EU or nationally to overcome obstacles that currently stop consumers and businesses from crossing the border. The Green Paper is an opportunity to create a proposal for a European market for financial services such as insurance, credit, electricity and savings payments and other retail investments - and how to open up to these services, thereby creating better conditions for consumers and businesses. , while maintaining the level of consumer and investor protection. It also explores the barriers that consumers and businesses face in using the single market. Because of all of the above, I supported the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - The establishment of the single European market has shown that it brings more problems and disadvantages than advantages, in particular because of economic, cultural and regulatory disparities. I therefore fear that the establishment of the single market for retail financial services will cause serious damage to our national economy and that future market disparities will be corrected by even more technocratic administration and control in Brussels. Moreover, cross-border purchases of retail financial services are a serious threat to banking sovereignty and the future of our citizens if the euro disappears. Indeed, when the euro disappears, retail financial services contracted in other countries will be subject to currency exchange risk and many households will see the amounts of loans to be repaid vary enormously. Not to mention the administrative complexity that such a situation will bring for these same citizens. This single market wants to give itself the appearance of a means to offer more freedom to the consumer but it is above all an additional chain that the Commission wants to throw on the Member States to force them not to leave the euro zone. , or the European Union. I therefore vote hanger.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - Effective measures need to be taken to unlock the full potential of the single market - namely, the EU retail financial services market is still quite underdeveloped and fragmented. The existing level of ambition to break down barriers and limit existing protectionist efforts to prevent innovation in retail financial services needs to be maintained. Only in this way can we turn the EU into a hub of innovative financial services. I welcome the holding of a public consultation on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, during which all stakeholders had the opportunity to express their views based on the specificities of their actions. Rapid changes caused by digitalization and innovation in financial technologies have the potential to create new and often better financial products. The Green Paper initiative can only succeed if it is firmly focused on creating an EU market in which well-protected consumers will have equal opportunities and access to transparent products whose quality matches the price. In all the measures we take in the field of retail financial services, we must keep in mind the aspect of inclusion. Financial exclusion is a widespread and serious problem throughout Europe. Life becomes very difficult without reasonable access to at least the most basic financial services. I want to emphasize the importance of financial education as a tool for consumer protection and empowerment - we must make access to independent financial education easier for everyone.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing.- This initiative, apparently aimed at improving the conditions of users, represents, in practice, another element of harmonization, of deepening federalism, which will serve great financial interests, facilitating the concentration of wealth and the centralization of economic power.An initiative that will lead to the liquidation of smaller companies and the promotion of pan-European banking oligopolies, with an increase in the profits of large EU banks, namely through the reduction in operating costs, which include the dismissal of workers, processes facilitated by thedigital aspect and reduction of the physical implantation of the companies.We will have less transparency, more fraud and tax evasion and an aggravation of the problem of companies "too big to fail".We can only reject this path.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The retail financial services market has been significantly affected by the digitization process. The potential to create and improve current financial products and meet consumer needs has increased. At the same time, however, there was a need to increase their protection and trust. I voted in favor of this Green Paper because, in addition to supporting market development, the document contains several very important points. The first is the fight against discrimination and financial harm to citizens. It is unacceptable for consumers throughout the Union not to enjoy the same legal protection or to be provided with accessible and independent advice. The second is raising awareness and improving citizens' access to financial education. The third is the protection of consumer data of a financial and non-financial nature, which should only be used in accordance with the applicable legislation. I called on the other relevant institutions to monitor the situation on the retail financial services market on a regular basis. I also voted in favor of the Commission establishing a framework for simple, transferable and, in particular, secure financial products and addressing the problem of inappropriate sales of financial products and services. Given that Europe still lacks sustainable and green investment, as Vice-Chair of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I am very pleased that the Green Paper encourages a much more proactive approach to finding and using capital markets for investments of this kind.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- I am pleased that the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services was adopted today.It focuses primarily on cross-border trade, which should work for the benefit of all EU citizens, no matter where they live.The market for retail financial services will only be viable if it is fair and credible.That is why it is important to maintain a level playing field and strengthen consumer confidence in basic services.There is also a need to increase their financial literacy and awareness.At the same time, we must not forget that consumers throughout the EU enjoy the same legal protection.Small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and the engine of employment, which is why the Green Paper focuses on their specific characteristics.I believe that effective regulation of retail financial services will contribute to the creation of a single European market.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The aim of the report is to make proposals so that the European market for financial services, ie insurance, loans, payments, current accounts, savings accounts and other retail investments can be further competitive. It seeks to identify the specific barriers that consumers and businesses face in using the single market and the ways in which these barriers can be overcome. The Green Paper addresses several strategic aspects. I believe that the Commission's initiative represents a dynamic approach to the development of the new policies required by this sector. For the single market to be truly efficient, its integrity must be maintained, as the ultimate challenge is to ensure an efficient social market economy. Creating a well-functioning single market for retail financial services is a critically important project. For all these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- The report focuses on a wide range of issues relating to financial services in general, and more specifically on how the sector can be improved to the benefit of consumers and SMEs by providing an environment of healthy competition.Mainly highlighted the need for better information on major financial products, emphasized the positive effects of digitalisation, called for simplification of rules while avoiding duplication, underlined the importance of financial education, called for improved competition and further support for financial dispute resolution networks.That is why I supported this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- To contribute to the reflection on the creation of a European retail financial services market, the Commission published in December 2015 a Green Paper to assess the feasibility of this market.I voted in favor of this report which deals with the contribution of the European Parliament to this reflection.It seems important to me to be able to identify the advantages of these financial products and services for consumers, investors and SMEs, as well as the difficulties in setting up such a market.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The Union's retail financial services market still needs to develop further, in particular in view of the small number of cross-border transactions, so it is necessary to take steps to fully exploit the potential of the single market and to facilitate innovations for the benefit of end users. A European market for retail financial services must represent real added value for consumers, in terms of accessibility and protection of their legal sphere, while ensuring effective competition between the various players. In this sense, it is important to foster a competitive environment and maintain a level playing field for all stakeholders, namely established operators and operators to be established. To this end, the applicable rules must be based on a model that is as neutral as possible, both at a technological and business level. In a word, the approach mentioned in the Green Paper is important for promoting the development of start-up companies, as well as new and innovative SMEs. I therefore voted in favor of this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Calls on the Commission to become further involved in consumer protection in financial services, accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - This Green Paper represents an opportunity to reflect on the possibility of further opening up the European market for retail financial services - namely insurance, loans, payment accounts, current accounts and savings accounts and other retail investments - producing better results for consumers and businesses, while maintaining an adequate level of protection for both the consumer and the investor. It seeks to identify the specific obstacles that consumers and businesses face in order to make full use of the single market and possible ways of overcoming those obstacles, including taking better advantage of new technologies, provided that appropriate safeguards are applied. It makes perfect sense, in a Union that wants to be cohesive, to allow: companies based in one EU Member State (MS) to find it easier to offer retail financial services in other MS; that consumers can buy retail financial services offered in other MS; that citizens can continue to enjoy their financial services products if they move from one MS to another, whether for the purposes of study, work or retirement (called "portability").

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which reflects Parliament's position on the Green Paper on retail financial services drawn up with the Commission, as different measures are proposed to increase transparency, consumer protection and the elimination of access barriers, including those of a cross-border nature. Also included is a proposal on the creation of a European savings account aimed at increasing the financing of green and sustainable investments. In addition, several amendments promoted by the Spanish Socialists have been approved, to end the practice of canceling payment cards for transfer of residence to another Member State, limit abusive commissions at ATMs, and in defense of the euro as the main currency of the financial services market, so it is a very progressive and pro-European report, which can have a decisive influence on the next legislative proposals of the Commission on the matter. It is regrettable that the European right has tried to remove, both in committee and in plenary, the paragraph on defending the rights of payment card users, but I am congratulated that this has not been successful.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the own-initiative report on the European Commission Green Paper aimed at tackling the fragmentation of retail financial products.It is indeed crucial to defend European consumers, in particular by ensuring that the products offered to them are transparent, simple and profitable.For my part, I had supported the amendment calling for work to create a European consumer protection authority, believing that this was a step forward towards better consumer protection.I therefore regret that this amendment did not pass, but I nevertheless decided to support this text, which contains some interesting elements.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- Regulation of retail financial services is a crucial area of banking activity, as this issue is directly linked to the services that every consumer receives.It is crucial to regulate the relationship between retail financial service providers and consumers, as the former tend to have more bargaining power and it is often the case that it is abused vis-à-vis consumers.The proposal under consideration is quite balanced.As far as I know, it takes into account our proposals to strengthen consumer protection.At the same time, it contains an important amendment that we are proposing, which calls for such investments to be encouraged to invest more in green priorities, to apply methodologies for assessing the 'greenness' of investments.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted against this proposal for the liberalization of retail financial services.Although the objective of giving more power of choice to consumers, and lowering the price of products may seem laudable, the legislation moves towards deregulation that favors the single market but does not offer guarantees of standardization and transparency of the products thatthey are put on the market.In this way we can hope that the large multinationals can sweep away the smaller suppliers, and that derivative financial products whose risk is very difficult to assess will be imposed on safer products.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted for the report on the Green Paper on retail financial services.The aim of the report is to decide how the European market for retail financial services can be opened even further, in order to achieve better results for consumers and companies while still providing an adequate level of protection for consumers and investors.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services because it specifically addresses a number of challenges for the further development of the retail financial services market at EU level.I consider it essential that the setting up and enforcement of a legal framework that ensures the necessary consumer protection be an integral part of the development of this market.I also consider it important to emphasize the fact that many services are switching to the Internet, and it is therefore important to ensure that no one is excluded from them.Access to these services must also be ensured in a non-digital way in order to avoid financial exclusion.This also applies to the use of ATMs - access to cash through ATMs is a basic public service which must be provided to consumers without any discriminatory or unfair practices and which must not be excessively expensive.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it represents a continuation of the financial deregulation that prevails in the financial system of the Union.This Green Paper presents the initiative to regulate retail financial products at the transnational level.Instead of seeking greater transparency and security for potential consumers, the report leaves the creation of all kinds of products in the hands of the financial system.Rather than simplify, it is left to be done, allowing a diversity and complexity of financial products that can undermine the interests of European consumers, as has happened in the past with preferred shares.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because it calls on the Commission to become further involved in consumer protection in financial services.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I would like to thank the rapporteur for the report presented, as the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services has provoked a lively and fruitful debate, which has allowed stakeholders to present their personal experiences and views. I supported the resolution because the Green Paper focuses on financial services for citizens and the proposals put forward can be of sufficient benefit to all consumers in the EU. Although a coherent approach to retail financial services could be counterproductive, given the diversity of actors and products, I consider the proposals to be important because I consider this EU market to be relatively underdeveloped and fragmented so far. I believe that effective measures to unlock the full potential of the single market in retail financial services and to promote end-user innovation will ensure stronger consumer protection and create more scope for healthy competition at national level. I am in favor of the European retail financial services market being more beneficial for SMEs, which should help them to improve access to finance and give them easier access to cross-border markets.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Retail financial services, which include personal bank accounts, payments, personal loans, mortgages and savings accounts, are part of the daily lives of European citizens. However, due to inefficient competition, which is particularly pronounced in the area of ​​payments and banking, there are large differences between Member States in consumer access to high-quality and equally affordable services. The European Union has not made significant progress in the past in completing the single market in retail financial services, and this Green Paper provides the necessary impetus to remove cross-border barriers and connect financial actors from all Member States with consumers across the European Union to ensure choice, value and value. quality for all consumers, thus strengthening their confidence in providers and the right decision-making according to individual financial circumstances. Parliament's report welcomes the Commission's initiative, which responds appropriately to the rapidly changing market environment by promoting integration and the cross-border provision of financial services. Among other things, the report points out that the EU needs a high level of consumer protection legislation and its consistent implementation, and in this regard calls on the Commission to investigate the misleading practices faced by consumers in card payments and ATM withdrawals through currency conversion. supported him in the vote.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Retail financial services (such as loans or insurance) are crucial for citizens, but there is virtually no Europe-wide market in this area.The coming digitalisation opens up new opportunities for cross-border activities and innovation.In creating a common market, care must be taken to ensure that these services are customer-friendly, fair and transparent, while ensuring that customers are informed.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This report is an important step for creating a stronger single market for retail financial services, which puts the consumer first.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I did not vote in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the Green Paper on financial services for private customers. The report calls on the Commission to ensure that the same rules apply to the same service, so that competition is not distorted, in particular by the emergence of new providers of retail financial services. The opposite is the case: the same rules prevent competition between legal systems. An open market relies on mutual recognition of the various products, not on their harmonization under one regime - which, at least that's how the EU is currently working, also comes across as excessively bureaucratic and overregulatory. In addition, the area calls for increased "efforts to develop a common tax identification number" in the EU or internationally. That speaks for itself. Taxes are a matter of national sovereignty and it has to stay that way.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- Digitalisation will increase the competitiveness, cross-border activity and innovation of financial service providers, and this will create new opportunities for consumers, investors, small and medium-sized enterprises and other types of enterprises.A functioning European retail financial services market cannot rest on digitalisation alone, as it is unable to overcome many obstacles on its own, such as different tax, social, legal and health systems, contracting mechanisms and consumer protection, as well as different languages and cultures.The comparability of financial products between Member States' markets, especially in the insurance sector, will be improved by simplifying and harmonizing their legislation.I support this Report because Europe needs a change of mentality and a rapid response from regulators to technological development and a significant increase in investment in financial technologies to become a leading market for innovation in this area.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.The European internal market has not yet reached its potential in many areas and is not working as it should.One of these areas is also the EU market for retail financial services, which is highly fragmented and rather underdeveloped.I support the Commission's Green Paper on Retail Financial Services, which has enabled a public debate with various stakeholders in the field of retail financial services.The report rightly notes that the Green Paper initiative was designed at the right time, especially in the light of proactive action at all stages of policy-making.Only in this way will we be able to respond effectively and appropriately to the rapid development we are witnessing.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- We voted against this Green Paper, because it does not simplify, let alone abolish the various complex "products" with which multinationals and banks promote casino capitalism.These are the "products" with which they are profiting at the expense of the people and, since they are not being fought, we could not support the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- We oppose cross-border investment with all the necessary immigration policy requirements.Especially for our country, the fiscal situation and the exclusion of the public sector from the markets create insurmountable obstacles for the issuance of green bonds, which strengthen the power of supervisory authorities.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - We must not underestimate the political importance of the European integration of the services market, especially today, when the unity of the Union, the promotion of cohesion within and outside the euro area and the avoidance of unions within the Union are important issues. The creation of a common market for financial services is a shared responsibility of all Member States. I am aware of the different situations in the Member States, the difficulties encountered in opening up the market and the importance of recognizing the progress that has been made. However, double standards and exceptions should not be allowed under any circumstances. Promoting the internal market in principle without practical action would undermine the confidence of European citizens in the EU's reform agenda. Most importantly, the members of the European Council and the Competitiveness Council must be entrusted with the task of keeping the internal market in services regularly on the political agenda, together with a clear timetable for removing obstacles to free movement. Ultimately, Europe can only embark on the path of growth if the Member States commit themselves to a truly free and open internal market for services for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services. I welcome the public consultation on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services. I welcome the fact that the report addresses the additional potential of digitalisation, which will also create new opportunities for consumers, investors and SMEs in terms of competition, cross-border activities and innovation. I also agree with the rapporteur that digitization alone is not enough to create a genuine European market for retail financial services. Many obstacles, such as different tax, social, judicial, health, contracting and consumer protection systems, as well as different languages ​​and cultures, cannot really be overcome by digitization alone. One of the most important points in the report, in my view, is that it points to the need for an appropriate legal framework for consumer protection and draws attention to the fact that consumers' financial and non-financial data collected from different sources are increasingly being used by financial service providers for various purposes. I consider it right that the report emphasizes that the use of personal data and large data sets on financial service providers must comply with EU data protection law.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - The EU retail financial services market remains underdeveloped and highly fragmented. We still have 28 different and not very competitive domestic markets. Effective action is therefore needed to unlock the full potential of the European Single Market and facilitate innovation for the benefit of end-users. The European Commission Green Paper is a step in the right direction. It is necessary to act as soon as possible and remove the existing barriers limiting innovation in enterprises and the functioning of the entire European economy. This is especially important in the context of such rapidly developing digitization of the world. Currently, there is a real chance to connect financial entities operating in various parts of Europe with consumers living throughout its territory. The further development of the retail financial services market at Union level within an appropriate legal framework ensuring the required consumer protection would not only facilitate intense and fruitful cross-border activity, but could also create more room for healthy competition at national level. I hope the Commission will take legislative action in the area of ​​retail financial services in the near future.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - In the context of discussing the digitalisation of all economic sectors, this initiative contributes to creating the framework for the proactive manifestation of those interested in creating a single market for retail financial services, a market characterized by transparency, beneficial to all. Clearly, the creation of a viable single financial market is an ambitious goal for the EU, with real opportunities to achieve, in the context of ensuring real competition in the retail financial services market, adequate consumer information, easy access and adequate consumer protection. consumers in these markets - the framework needed to facilitate retail financial services innovation with a positive impact on end-users. Also, for the EU to become a hub for innovative financial services, it is not enough for new actors and attractive financial products to emerge for consumers and companies, but for the challenges posed by the digital society to security, data protection, consumer protection, barriers through the provision of remote financial goods and services, taxation, fair and constructive competition, financial stability, etc.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
