text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the report which envisages a set of concrete proposals to ensure all consumers for retail financial services in the EU are well protected. We need to ensure consumers are well protected through further action to empower consumers to make informed decisions, to increase transparency of retail financial products, and to remove consumer barriers to switching and any unjustified costs relating thereto, or to withdrawal from a product. The Commission should take further initiatives, including a proposal for an EU savings account and encouraging finance for sustainable and green investments.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I spoke in favor of this green paper. We have to make sure that everyone is included. Financial exclusion is a serious and widespread problem in Europe. Life becomes very complicated for those who do not have at least access to the most essential financial services. We must keep the prospect of inclusion in mind in everything we do in retail financial services. A permanent general objective must be the reduction of exclusion. The new payment accounts directive, due to be fully implemented in the fall, will give every consumer the right to have a basic payment account. While this is a big step in the right direction, it is far from enough. A much bigger effort is needed. Major work awaits us. Building a functioning single market for retail financial services is a huge undertaking. At the same time, it is a worthwhile project. This is clearly a case where the European Union is creating real added value.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Green Paper on Retail Financial Services identifies and aims to remove existing barriers in market retail finance in order to unlock its full potential, leading to more and better consumer choices, without compromising the existing level of consumer protection. Consumer and businesses’ trust in the financial sector has lagged behind since the financial crisis of 2008. I voted in favour of the proposed Paper, as I believe that in order to restore consumer and business trust in the financial sector, there needs to be an initiative to create a regulatory environment within EU legislation that is more conducive to transparency, growth and innovation, elements which are all outlined in the Paper.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the Green Paper on retail financial services. I am of the opinion that the Commission should be called upon to intervene more decisively in the fight against discrimination based on a place of residence in the European retail financial services market and, if necessary, to supplement the general proposals to end unjustified denials with additional legislative initiatives targeting the financial sector. location-based approach, bearing in mind that the price of some products and some services is linked to a number of factors (regulatory or geographical) that differ from one Member State to another. This factor is especially important for realizing the full potential of Croatian retail actors in the European market. If one of the fundamental principles of the European Union, the principle of equality, is to be achieved, I believe that it is necessary to launch a mechanism to combat discrimination on the basis of permanent residence at the same time as legally repressive and preventive measures. Although this motion for a resolution has other qualitative aspects, I consider this to be its most valuable.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I believe that the European Union should have legislation adapted to rapid changes in the market, and Member States must implement these policies.This will facilitate cross-border activities, which will be of great benefit to consumers, investors and innovative companies.Although the report contains certain elements with which I do not agree, such as a review of the European Union Common Tax Identification Number, I believe that the report will bring new, positive opportunities for the overall functioning of the European Union economy, so I voted in favor.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services. The resolution is a first step towards improving retail financial services. But we still have a lot of work to do. Building a well-functioning single market in retail financial services is a big project that certainly pays off. This is an obvious example of creating real added value in the EU. The Green Paper contains a number of points where the current legislation could be further improved in the coming years. It came at the right time, as digitalisation is on the rise, offering new opportunities for the common market. There is also a huge potential in cross-border activities, which is not exploited due to barriers (problem 28 of non-competitive national markets). While many of the ideas in the Green Paper seem promising, most need to be backed up by extensive and relevant empirical data. The book also summarizes several challenges on how to approach data collection and analysis, how to implement identification in practice, how to maintain and create a level playing field, how to minimize disparities between Member States to make the single market truly effective, and how to ensure inclusion. all.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against this proposal for the liberalization of retail financial services.Although the objective of giving more power of choice to consumers, and lowering the price of products may seem laudable, the legislation moves towards deregulation that favors the single market but does not offer guarantees of standardization and transparency of the products thatthey are put on the market.In this way we can hope that the large multinationals can sweep away the smaller suppliers, and that derivative financial products whose risk is very difficult to assess will be imposed on safer products.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - The aim of this Green Paper is to launch a debate on how the European retail financial services market could be opened up further. Retail financial services include: current accounts, retirement savings solutions, real estate project finance, life and property insurance. However, considering that digital technology is a good tool to provide more and more information to consumers, to increase competition and lower prices, the European Commission wants to encourage financial companies to offer their retail products in all countries , and citizens to shop across borders. The main recommendation is therefore to establish mutual trust, in particular by ensuring the protection of consumers and the free activity of businesses in their cross-border activities. We oppose this desire to further expand the single market for the following reasons: firstly, the establishment of the single European market has proven to bring more problems and disadvantages than advantages, in particular because of economic, cultural and regulatory disparities. Moreover, cross-border purchases of retail financial services are a serious threat to our banking sovereignty and the future of our citizens if the euro disappears. I voted against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- This report is a reaction to the European Commission's Green Paper on Retail Financial Services and aims to initiate a debate on the possible opening of the European financial services market, in particular for retail services, i.e. savings accounts, mortgages, pensions etc. Currently national marketsFinancial services in the EU are still very fragmented and the reasons for this vary.The main aim of the report is to analyze the possibilities of completing the European market in financial services.I voted in favor of this document.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- In examining the retail financial services initiative, the rapporteur considers that the Commission has taken the appropriate steps and that the procedure chosen is the appropriate method.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against this proposal for the liberalization of retail financial services.Although the objective of giving more power of choice to consumers, and lowering the price of products may seem laudable, the legislation moves towards deregulation that favors the single market but does not offer guarantees of standardization and transparency of the products thatthey are put on the market.In this way we can hope that the large multinationals can sweep away the smaller suppliers, and that derivative financial products whose risk is very difficult to assess will be imposed on safer products.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I welcome the Commission's commitment to helping to promote the financing of sustainable and green investments and urge the Commission, in consultation and in close cooperation with the European Parliament, to play a more active role in supporting a growing market for sustainable and responsible investment through the Capital Markets Union.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services. The Green Paper mainly focuses on financial services for citizens who are looking for cross-border services. The Report stresses that a European retail financial services market must benefit SMEs in terms of both supply and demand. It takes the view that digitalisation will continue to create new opportunities for consumers, investors, SMEs and other companies in terms of competition, cross-border activities and innovation I voted in favour because I believe that simplification of legislation is crucial in efforts to make products more easily comparable across the Member States’ markets.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- This report is presented with the objective that, once approved, it is transmitted in the form of a resolution to the Council and the Commission.It deals with the axes of the current situation of the retail market for financial products and services, the factors that hinder its intra-community trade, the avenues of improvement for digitization in marketing and for increasing customer confidence towards the product or service thatIt comes from another Member State.It also advocates for progress in the design and guarantee of passport to specific types of retail products and services that meet the conditions that are established in a harmonized way.In the spirit of serving to improve and increase the use of retail financial instruments and services, I have cast a positive vote.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I voted against this own-initiative report which supports the Commission's strategy to create a single market for retail financial services and remove the remaining obstacles to the expansion of cross-border financial activities. Obviously, I share the objectives of facilitating competition and transparency in the sector, but I believe that the only way to pursue them is that of stronger financial regulation and supervision, certainly not that of liberalization, which would have harmful and counterproductive effects, especially in a banking and financial system which has not yet been secured and which is also heavily distorted by the single currency. Experience teaches what catastrophic consequences financial liberalization can lead to in an economic area characterized by strong distortions and imbalances. We saw it with Greece, which had become hostage to the German and French banks which had fueled, with easy loans, the excessive accumulation of private foreign debt. It is not difficult to predict how the single market for retail financial services will not at all increase competition and the protection of retail investors, as the report hopes, but will favor the concentration and oligopoly of big banking groups that are too big to fail and to amplify the already unsustainable financial imbalances in the Euro area. It is a story already seen.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted against this report, because it represents a continuation of the financial deregulation that prevails in the financial system of the Union.This Green Paper presents the initiative to regulate retail financial products at the transnational level.Instead of seeking greater transparency and security for potential consumers, the report leaves the creation of all kinds of products in the hands of the financial system.Rather than simplify, it is left to be done, allowing a diversity and complexity of financial products that can undermine the interests of European consumers, as has happened in the past with preferred shares.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it is an important step for creating a stronger single market for retail financial services which puts the consumer first. The report is also strong on financial inclusion e.g. by supporting the full inclusion of all retail financial services within the scope of the Directive on the accessibility requirements for products and services (the ‘European Accessibility Act’).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor, because a European market for retail financial services is only conceivable if it offers real added value for consumers by ensuring effective competition, accessibility and consumer protection, especially in relation to products that are actually needed to participate in the economiclife.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written.- The Green Paper on Retail Financial Services was, on the whole, balanced, but it stated that the EU market would work better if all Member States had a single currency.Because of this point, I could not support the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This initiative, apparently aimed at improving the conditions of users, represents, in practice, another element of harmonization, of deepening federalism, which will serve great financial interests, facilitating the concentration of wealth and the centralization of economic power.This initiative will lead to the liquidation of smaller companies and the promotion of pan-European banking oligopolies, with an increase in the profits of the major banks of the EU, namely through the reduction of operating costs, which include the dismissal of workers, processes facilitated by thethe digital dimension and by reducing the physical implantation of companies.We will have less transparency, more fraud and tax evasion and an aggravation of the problem of companies "too big to fail".We can only reject this path.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The idea behind the Green Paper on Financial Services is to take stock of possible regulatory measures, according to which service providers should be given the opportunity to react better to the rapid changes in the market.These include digitization measures that create new opportunities for customers and investors, fuel competition and create innovative financial products, the low interest rate environment and the greater integration of banks.It will therefore be necessary for customers to have equal access to financial services so that they can benefit from them everywhere.In order to achieve this, the report suggests that greater transparency should create information and comparability, and thereby create trust in financial services.I therefore approved the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the Green Paper on retail financial services, as it is now necessary to remove the cross-border barriers that harm consumers, hindering innovative businesses and the smooth functioning of the European economy.The Commission is moving in the right direction and our group has insisted on the need to ensure the right balance between consumer protection and the development of the single market for retail financial services.We believe that the scope of the Commission's future action plan should focus equally on consumer protection measures and the development of cross-border opportunities.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ This report is an important step for creating a stronger single market for retail financial services which puts the consumer first. It is an example of EU action making European citizens more prosperous by working together.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I support the improvement of advice and information to investors. In my opinion it is important that the Commission comes up with concrete proposals on eliminating identified obstacles and barriers to an internal retail finance market. As a Liberal I believe in transparency, so I support the call on the Commission to increase the consumer transparency framework, trying to reach a supervisory convergence between Member States. The establishment of a European Consumer Protection Authority can help in this task. I believe that there is a need to analyse the potentials of giving companies a greater regulatory flexibility in order to experiment and innovate, without disregarding consumer protection and safety.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up.- I voted on the report on the Green Paper on retail financial services.I agree with the rapporteur, who states that this procedure is an appropriate direction, with the Green Paper being presented in due course.The rapporteur insists that a European retail financial services market must be beneficial for SMEs in terms of both supply and demand.From a supply perspective, it should be a means of improving SMEs' access to finance, and from a demand perspective, it should enable SMEs to reach cross-border markets more easily.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - The approach of this report is very limited as it does not analyze the negative repercussions of the liberalization of this sector from a macroeconomic and financial stability point of view. It is shared the erroneous assumption that the creation of a single European market for retail financial services automatically leads to improved competition and increased innovation and benefits for consumers. On the contrary, this market will create standardized and increasingly complex tools that will be difficult to access for small investors and SMEs. This solution is therefore not the answer to the needs of the real economy. The amendments I tabled highlighted the enormous hidden risks behind the liberalization of retail financial services within a heterogeneous economic and financial area characterized by strong asymmetries and macroeconomic divergences between the Eurozone countries already heavily aggravated by the single currency. Such a solution would lead to further amplifying the existing macroeconomic and financial imbalances within the eurozone, especially if the conditions for investor protection are not created ex ante. In conclusion, the proposal on the single market for retail financial products and services is absolutely harmful and counterproductive, which is why I cast my negative vote.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I supported the resolution in response to the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.The aim of this resolution was, in particular, to launch a debate on the creation of a single European financial services market, which is currently highly fragmented.Instead of one market, we have 28 of them, which is not good for businesses or consumers.The resolution therefore sought to identify the logical steps that would lead to this goal.I agree that the main such steps should include better communication, simplification of legislation or very important financial education.And although, in my opinion, the proposal contained several elements with which I do not agree, such as the common tax identification number or the information document within the PRIIPs, I nevertheless decided to support it.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I support the Report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.I believe it is crucial that there are no significant barriers to retail financial services such as current accounts, pensions and savings, mortgages and financing other purchases, health or accident insurance and property insurance.These services are important in the daily life of citizens and there is often a need to use them.The Green Paper on Retail Financial Services provides an opportunity to make proposals for the creation of a European retail services market.At Union level, it is necessary to identify the obstacles faced by consumers and businesses and to standardize practices so that the obstacles create as little damage as possible to the overall economy and financial market.Less barriers in the market mean both easier and simpler access to services for citizens.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on the Green Paper on Retail Financial Services.The EU market for retail financial services is still quite underdeveloped and highly fragmented, especially as regards the low number of cross-border transactions.The Green Paper focuses mainly on financial services for citizens seeking cross-border services.It is important that the new proposals also benefit all consumers in the EU to ensure that the retail financial services market works for all.As I believe that the Green Paper proposes effective measures to exploit the full potential of the single market and stimulate innovation, I supported it.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - Today we ask ourselves how we are responding to the 82% of European citizens who are rightly afraid and who believe that the fight against terrorism is a common European priority. The time has come to choose the direction Europe should take. We have already tested cooperation that is sometimes strengthened, sometimes not, which doesn't work. If the future, after Brexit, must be more Union, then we need to support a common defense policy, which certainly does not mean having an army to wage war - we must be very careful about the messages we send to our citizens - but rather intervene in hot areas for prevention. After every tragic attack of which Europe has been the victim, everyone has stressed the absence of effective intelligence, of cooperation between Member States, an absence which unfortunately has cost us dearly. Europe has shown itself unprepared for an enemy that must be sought inside and outside the European borders and we can do this only if we aim for a common defense policy, because if the threat is to Europe, the answer can only be European.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I was reluctant to support this report, but in the end I supported it, because I am in favor of the individual states cooperating at the level of the defense industry, so that the armed forces can communicate with each other as much as possible. On the other hand, I am not a supporter of the European Armed Forces and of a united European army. I believe that we have NATO here as a clear component that works in this matter, and I find it useless to create competition for NATO organizations. As Recital D, which concerns the United Armed Forces in particular, did not pass, I finally supported the whole report. What I consider extremely important in this report is that we are calling on the Member States to raise defense money, to really invest 2% of their GDP in armaments and in their own defense, because we cannot rely on someone to defend us all the time. , for example, the USA, and that we do not have to spend our own money on it. That, I think, is the main message, to rely on one's own defense and put money into it.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - Today I read on one server that when the UK leaves the EU, 80% of all defense spending in the North Atlantic Alliance will be paid by non-EU Member States, especially the US, and only 20% by European members.I think this proves quite plastically the framework in which we move.I do not think that there is any reality here now to think about a common European defense.What is needed, and it is certainly good to support, is an appeal to increase defense spending in those states that do not comply with it, but to send a signal at a time when the new US administration is entering that the EU is perhaps considering some of its own defense capabilities,is unreasonable.Right now, we should make it clear that we stand for NATO as a fundamental and fundamental security pillar for both Europe and the EU Member States.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: - Mr President, it is a pity that the answer we intend to give to the break with England after Brexit is to imagine the preparation of a European defense community. The fear of others, the preparation for war as a binding force for the peoples of Europe, is absurd. We made Europe for peace and we are told the preparations for war, because that is what it is. When we arm and organize ourselves to be armed together, without designating an adversary, it is because we designate the whole world as a potential adversary. Are you talking about a defense? But against whom? It is not specified. There is no common European policy - as we know - in foreign affairs, so here we are back to the origins of Europe, since the first text that was submitted to the peoples of Europe in 1954 , was the European Defense Community. My country answered "no" as it would answer "no" again if asked. In reality, it is a division of roles between the United States of America and Europe, the United States of America turning to Asia while we are put in the hands of n any provocation that would come from Ukraine. I have only one word to say, Mr. President, to conclude: France has a defense system which is incompatible with this distribution of roles. It presupposes our independence and deterrence. No war, no war, peace!

name: Marek JUREK
text: - A year and a half ago, the European Council took a very important decision regarding our collective defense - a concrete decision to destroy the infrastructure of illegal immigration smuggling before it is used.During those one and a half years, not a single boat was damaged.Instead, we are in fact constantly hearing encouragements for illegal immigration, because this is the only way to interpret the announcements of opening legal routes to immigration, which is illegal today.You can always discuss the right to bear arms, the creation of new armed institutions, and borders when it is and when it is not needed.But one thing is certain: you cannot give weapons to people who, even unarmed, are dangerous to the environment.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Explanations of vote on the Paet report are closed.Mrs Macovei asked for the floor, but she was not present when her name was read.Mrs Macovei, from what I see, you have also asked for a vote on the Preda report.On the Paet report you can submit in writing the justification for the vote, which will be recorded in the Minutes.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: written. In-depth European defense co-operation with respect for defense policy as a national matter. This is my starting point in the view of the common defense and security policy, and consequently in the current resolution on "a European Defense Union". The Christian Democrats' European policy program advocates increased European operational capability in order to contribute to international peace efforts and that EU countries, in the wake of declining US involvement in the outside world, must take greater military responsibility for their immediate area. The Christian Democrats advocate coordination with NATO, but also state that the EU must create greater conditions for being able to act militarily on its own in cases where NATO cannot or should not intervene. The EU emphasizes that the EU Rapid Reaction Force should be able to be used. I voted in favor of the resolution as it strikes a good balance between European action and coordination with NATO, in line with what my party is advocating. I chose to vote in favor of the proposal for multinational forces, which is intended to be a replacement for and development of the rapid reaction forces, as increased ability to act quickly in crises in the immediate area has proved to be absolutely necessary. Based on my and the party's views on national sovereignty, I voted against wording on 'European armed forces' and the financing of military operations with EU funds instead of funds from national budgets.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report highlights the need to create a "Union for Defense" to ensure security throughout the European Union.Furthermore, the report insists on some controversial aspects, such as investing part of the multiannual financial framework funds for defense research, allocating 2% of member states' GDP to defense spending or supporting NATO initiatives.To express my perplexity linked to the inadequacy of the European defense measures contained in the report, I decided to cast a negative vote.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written.- Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War.We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face.That is why we support moving forward in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union.We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter.For this, we need the Member States to commit to advancing through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - The aim of this report is to develop common projects, and the money contributed is expected to mobilize up to € 5 billion a year from 2017. In addition, it is intended to promote research and development in military projects. Until now, community spending on innovation excluded military uses, but in 2017 25 million will be allocated and from 2020, 500 million a year are expected. I have rejected this report that seeks to strengthen the security and militarist perspective and, which requires States to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, when the European population sinks more and more into misery and unemployment (the data shows us they say that in the Spanish State 1 out of 5 households are below the poverty line, and unemployment is close to 4 million unemployed). What the States should do is increase social investment and job creation, not contribute to militaristic escalation. According to Article 41 (2) of the TEU there can be no military financing from the Union budget. My vote against this report from the opposite and militaristic line.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – Sinn Féin completely opposes the creation of a European Defence Union. We will continue to promote peace building and military neutrality for Ireland and the EU. Specifically, we opposed this report as it called for the following: the immediate creation of a European Defence Union with a military headquarters and a permanent EU Council of Defence Ministers, an EU defence budget in next MFF, cooperation and compatibility with NATO, closer transatlantic cooperation, 2% minimum defence spend, use of EU funds for military budget, the creation of a European military industrial complex and arms trade, EU military research funding, including drones and the creation of a ‘Defence Semester’.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text. Mr. Trump's isolationist orientation puts Europe up against the wall: we must take our security in hand! Voices in Germany call for the defense of the European continent. Let us seize this context in order to finally build a real European defense. I am in favor of the pooling of military resources between the Member States of the European Union. It would allow Europe to be stronger, while making significant savings. The 2013 European Parliament report estimated the cost of the absence of a European Defense Union at 26 billion per year! That is almost 15% of European defense budgets. Let's jointly analyze our needs and respond to them together. The citizens are in favor of a stronger military engagement of Europe. It is time to collectively give ourselves the means to protect Europeans, also to protect the values ​​and interests of the Union!

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it seeks to unite the defense efforts of EU Member States in order to respond more robustly and rapidly to emerging threats. I support the call for the European Council to initiate the creation of a European Defense Union, working in conjunction with NATO, and to provide additional funding for its implementation. I also agree that EU Member States have at least 2% its GDP for defense and for strengthening military cooperation between EU countries through the establishment of an EU Military Operations Command and a Multilateral Force. Cooperation and integration between the societies of the EU Member States, NATO and their constituent countries is particularly relevant in the context of today's challenges, such as cyber security. I am convinced that Europe's political will and determination, as well as closer military cooperation between EU countries and NATO, will make a significant contribution to better managing hybrid and conventional threats and increasing the resilience of EU citizens, while strengthening the security of us all.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union because I believe that the development of the EU's common security and defense policy is an important step in protecting its citizens and its values and interests, always with full respectin international law and human rights.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - This Parliament resolution calls for EU Member States to step up their security and defense cooperation against the background of an increase in hybrid threats, threats to energy security, cybersecurity or terrorism, thus opening the way for a European Defense Union. The resolution envisages spending 2% of GDP on defense, creating multinational forces and setting up an EU headquarters to plan and conduct joint operations. It also calls on the European Council to take the lead in drawing up a common defense policy for the Union and to provide additional funding for its implementation. Finally, Parliament calls for a revision of the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) and for the EU and NATO to work more closely together. I support the plan for the Union to expand its defense cooperation. Current developments present us with security policy challenges that we can only counter effectively together.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This is one of the many reports made to take advantage of Brexit in an attempt to revive European defense policy.European defense policy is a 15-year-old sea serpent which, by its own admission, is based on NATO.It should be remembered that it was the main cause recorded by N. Sarkozy for the return of France to the Integrated Command.This consubstantial link is moreover assumed by the text and betrays the real nature of the UED which is the supply of supplementary troops for those who have a military tool still suitable for other powers (which without Great Britainwill soon be the case of France with yet an army in disrepair).I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ As Britain is leaving the European Union, it seems to me eminently sensible that I should oppose measures related to the development of a European Defence Union – which could, over time, evolve into a European Army.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- The idea of a common European defense makes sense.Today, at a time when the heads of state and government are trying to preserve the illusion that they retain their prerogatives of sovereignty on a certain number of issues, I am happy to see that we are wonderingon a policy that could be more effectively exercised if sovereignty were shared.From a budgetary perspective, a more integrated defense framework could result in significant savings, additional capabilities and more sustained investment.I therefore voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ Recent years have shown a dramatic shift in the environment of security throughout the European Union and it has not been a shift for the better. These changes and current events call for a solution that would strengthen the EU’s defence policy and work hand in hand with NATO to secure Europe. This report does just that, but it clearly differentiates between the differences of simply pumping more money into European defence and actually using the funds created for implementation. Similarly to the agreements of NATO, EU Member States should look to provide 2% of their GDP for EU security. This report calls for greater interlocking and cooperation between the EU Member States; only through these methods will we be able to create a European Defence Union that successfully compliments NATO in providing a safer present and future for Europe.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union.In recent years, the security situation in Europe and neighboring countries has deteriorated significantly, creating complex and unprecedented challenges that no single country or organization can solve alone.In addition, Europe is more vulnerable than ever to the threat of terrorism on its territory.I therefore agree that the European Defense Union must start with a comprehensive overhaul of the common security and defense policy, based on the principle of strong collective defense, effective funding and coordination with NATO.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are concerned by the increasing move towards EU military capability and its potential negative impact on UK foreign policy interests. NATO is and should remain the primary guarantor of security in Europe. Any development of EU foreign policy or defence capability risks undermining this.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The Eurocrats seek to take advantage of Brexit to try to revive a so-called common European defense policy ... obviously based on NATO.This consubstantial link is moreover assumed by the text (points 3, 36, 37 and 38) and betrays the real nature of the “European Defense Union”: the simple supply of supplementary troops - for those who have a toolmilitary still fit - to an organization in the quasi-exclusive service of American interests.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- Faced with the different situations facing Europe in its surroundings, closer collaboration between the Member States in the field of defense is essential.I therefore approved this report, which encourages the European Council to be the driving force behind the gradual definition of the EDU and to provide financial resources to this end.The European Council is invited to take concrete measures aimed at the harmonization and standardization of the Union's armed forces in order to facilitate the cooperation of the armed forces under the aegis of a new European Defense Union.The Parliament, for its part, is encouraged to organize a fully-fledged committee devoted to security and defense in order to monitor the application of permanent structured cooperation.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - While in the last thirty years a large part of the Member States have decided to continue to adopt cuts in defense spending, the global challenges linked to the increase of phenomena such as international terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber insecurity have increased and energy and organized crime. I strongly supported the Paet report on the European Defense Union because I believe it is essential, at this historic moment, to step up efforts in this direction. Finally, multinational forces must be created within the permanent structured cooperation, making them available to the common security and defense policy. We need to reduce all those duplications, overcapacities and obstacles which in the public procurement sector today lead to an estimated waste of € 26.4 billion, by making joint purchases for resources and pooling non-lethal materials, such as vehicles and transport aircraft. The creation of a headquarters for the planning, command and control of joint operations, combined with a complete overhaul of the CSDP, are fundamental steps to guarantee the European Union a leading role in the global scenario, working in synergy with NATO and also taking into account the new political spaces.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against this report on the European Defense Union, because it proposes to give the Union greater strategic autonomy in defense policies and greater coordination, but it does so by proposing measures that in no way guarantee reaching solutions to problemssecurity that exist globally.The report calls for specific resources to be earmarked for military cooperation between member states, to create a European Defense Union, beyond the Common Security and Defense Policy, to convene meetings at European level of Defense Ministers, and to create a headquarters ofthe Union, among other measures.None of these measures is aimed at solving the causes that cause threats to security in the Union, much less contribute to generating a framework of stability, cooperation and peace between the countries.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: in writing. - 62 years ago, a first project for a European Defense Union was rejected by the vote of the Communists and Gaullists in the Parliament of my country. I regret this bitterly, because a common and independent European defense remains a beautiful dream which must be pursued, given the threats that we will have to face in the future. I therefore welcome the goodwill of the rapporteur, even though I am afraid that we should not be deluding ourselves. A DEU will not be for tomorrow. From the civil wars in the Balkans to the crisis in Ukraine to the conflict in Syria today, the facts are there: Europe does not manage to speak with one voice. The recent US presidential election is there to remind us of this and the first round of the Republican primary in France as well. Both elections saw the triumph of a candidate who wants to establish better relations with Russia. Was it then, albeit surreptitiously, at the turn of a sentence, to criticize Russia in this report? As if Russia were the first enemy of a future European Defense Union ...

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I supported the report of my group colleague Mr Paet.I support the creation of an army at European level, for which a balanced budget is needed;but I have not agreed with the fact that it is explicit in the text that what is allocated is 2% of GDP.We have to continue cooperating so that the European Army is a fact in the future.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I voted against the Urmas Paet report because it undermines the sovereignty of the Member States in areas which fall under sovereign powers: internal security, external security, foreign policy, defense research and industriesstrategic.European defense has remained a dead letter, rendered obsolete by the divergent interests of nations and dissimilar military cultures.It is time to take note.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Given the obvious inability of the EU to defend its borders, especially the southern ones from which thousands of illegal immigrants enter every day, it seems absurd to me that we want to impose the disastrous recipe of "more Europe" also in the defense sector.I believe that further transfers of our national sovereignty are unacceptable, especially in a sensitive and strategic sector for each Member State, such as defense.For these reasons, I did not intend to support this text with my vote.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written. - I have voted against this report, which I consider to be a militaristic armaments document. The EU is claimed to be a union for peace, but the proposals in the adopted report are the opposite of peace. I strongly dissociate myself from the demands for increased defense funding (two percent of GDP), the creation of multinational forces and the creation of an EU headquarters to plan and carry out military operations in crisis areas. I support the right of all military personnel to organize in a trade union, but in a partial vote on the report, the text on this was unfortunately linked to a text on the alleged need for a common European defense, which meant that I could not vote in favor. The EU should stop militarization and rearmament, and instead consistently work for peaceful political and diplomatic methods of resolving conflicts. I believe that Europe and the world today need dialogue, relaxation and disarmament. That is why I am voting against this report.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it expressed Parliament's position on the European Defense Union. In recent years, the security situation in Europe and neighboring countries has deteriorated significantly, creating complex and unprecedented challenges that no single country or organization can solve alone. Europe is more vulnerable than ever to the threat of terrorism on its territory, and the terrorism and ongoing violence that afflicts North Africa and the Middle East continues to spread. Solidarity and resilience therefore require the EU to speak with one voice, to act in a coherent manner and to do so together with its allies, partners and third countries. Parliament recalled that, in order to ensure long-term security, Europe must show political will and determination, based on a range of relevant policies, including a strong and modern military capability. It therefore called on the European Council to lead the gradual development of the Union's common defense policy and to provide additional financial resources to ensure its implementation with a view to its establishment.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the new challenges on an unprecedented scale alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported this report because I am aware of the fact that the security situation in and around Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent years.Deterioration means that we face serious challenges that no country or organization can face on its own.Security in Europe and its territory is thus threatened by terrorism, while continuing violence continues to spread in North Africa and the Middle East.We are also facing a serious migration crisis that has not yet passed.In view of all these facts, however, I think it is appropriate to adequately protect our citizens through defense policy measures.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Development and Security Policy Development Report, which is a step towards greater EU self-defense capacity to protect its citizens and promote its values and interests, in full respect of international law and human rights treaties.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Defence Union because I strongly believe that the widespread perception of insecurity by European citizens makes the European Defence Union a matter of urgency. In particular, considering the increase in conflicts at the EU’s borders I believe further integration with regard to defence policies at EU level is needed.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Due to duplication of administrative staff, overcapacity and obstacles in the public procurement and security sector, the cost of non-Europe is estimated at € 26.4 billion per year. Strategic and military analysts have established that if the European Union really integrated its defensive functions, it would double its defensive capacity in the event of an attack and would allow citizens to save. Today, with the progressive disengagement of the USA from the European and Mediterranean scenario and with the increase of threats in Eastern Europe and North Africa, the need for an autonomous defense of the European space and the need to develop a rapid intervention system that is resilient and effective in the face of the hybrid threats of the 21st century. The White Paper on the common defense must be a concrete act for the relaunch of European defense, it cannot be reduced to a register of good intentions but rather the first step for the realization of the common armed forces.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This report uses the deteriorating political climate in Europe and the current terrorist threat as a pretext to revive the idea of ​​a European defense policy. In particular, Member States are called upon to coordinate their investments in security and defense. We are extremely opposed to any European Defense Union which concerns strategic areas of competence falling exclusively under the sovereignty of the Member States. In addition, this common defense policy will be modeled on the NATO action plans which we want France to exit because of American hegemony. It is indeed astounding to see how much the European Union wishes to submit to American interests. On the contrary, we wish to maintain balanced diplomatic relations with all the international powers in order to bring about a multipolar world. This is the reason why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up.- Europe is marked by strong social, economic and security crises.Europe faces multiple terrorist threats, but also economic problems related to cyber and energy insecurity.All these threats require additional measures to ensure security and promote the principles of democracy.In order to ensure long-term security, it is necessary to develop strong policy instruments, supported by relevant financial resources and based on the principles of collective defense and, at the same time, on coordination with NATO.I spoke in favor of the report on the European Defense Union, because I believe that joint efforts are needed to be able to respond effectively to the challenges facing Europe and to deal with external crises, in order to ensure the common defense of the whole area of freedom.and security.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - The security environment around the EU is volatile, complex and insecure. In this context, security and defense should remain at the heart of the European agenda. Europe needs to be stronger, faster and more responsive in the face of real threats. It must assume its share of responsibility and act in accordance with its ambitions. I support the EP's motion for a resolution on the European Defense Union. A new European security strategy has been needed for a long time. We need a fresh approach, taking into account the radically changed security environment, to define the EU's political ambitions, but also to turn the EU into a stronger player in the field of security. We must make full use of the provisions of the Treaties in the field of the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP) and make operational the provisions of the Treaty of Lisbon. In order to put an end to isolated and uncoordinated islands of military cooperation, priority must be given to launching permanent structured cooperation (PESCO).

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: written.- I voted against paragraph 40 split2 because if we want to move towards a common defense policy, we must ask that Member States with surpluses contribute more than States with deficit problems.It is necessary to have a global vision of defense in Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report because I believe that a more ambitious security research program and a ready strategy are needed to proceed with the implementation of the European Defense Union. In recent years, the security issue in Europe and in the world has drastically worsened. The threats of terrorism, organized crime and climate change are the fears common to the entire world population. The EU therefore has a duty to commit itself to guaranteeing the safety of people and to place this question among the most important challenges for the immediate future. The commission needs to be effective with its European Defense Action Plan (EDAP) and make it a key strategic tool to foster industrial cooperation for the development of defense capability programs. Close cooperation between the Commission and the European Defense Agency (EDA) is needed to strengthen the industrial and technological base of the defense sector.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as I believe that in the current geopolitical context the EU needs to reflect on its defence policy in the long term. The progressive framing of a common European Union defence policy as part of the common security and defence policy (CSDP), which will lead to an EU common defence when the European Council so decides voting unanimously, should be done in accordance with their respective constitutional requirements.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because Europe needs much more developed and targeted cooperation in the field of defense and security.This is an ambitious text which notably sets up a research and development program in the field of defense.Furthermore, it is important to develop cooperation between the European Union and NATO, whose actions must be complementary.However, I spoke against the amendment on tax exemption to encourage the defense industry to cooperate.In my opinion, this idea is not the right one and I remain convinced that for the relaunch of defense Europe, we should first adopt a more inclusive approach.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- Long-term European security must be guaranteed.In the report we are discussing we emphasize the need for political will and determination based on strong and modern military capabilities.We need to define a new model of the Council of Defense Ministers to provide lasting political guidance.The Council of the European Union will have to establish a permanent meeting bringing together the defense ministers of the member states committed to better synergy between the states.The method to be followed is that of enhanced cooperation in the field of European defense which will mean greater effectiveness, unity and efficiency.The report rightly emphasizes defining a preparatory action for a future European defense research program as a priority and we look forward to its effective launch as soon as possible.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The multiple armed conflicts and tragic terrorist acts of recent years require the European Union to take concrete action and new defense strategies. Individual Member States cannot respond alone to such growing threats; EU states must therefore join forces to ensure security inside and outside their borders. The EU is called to play a greater role as a provider of security, promoting European values ​​in full compliance with treaties and human rights. In this regard, I believe that the Member States must exploit the full potential of the Treaty of Lisbon in relation to the European Defense and Security Policy (CSDP) and continue the path towards structured cooperation. Adequate common defense policies at Union level and the provision of the necessary resources are therefore needed to ensure their implementation. I hope that the report will positively encourage Member States to move forward in this direction and to commit themselves concretely to the achievement of the objectives defined by the CSDP. For these reasons, I decided to support the report.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report, which recalls that, in order to ensure its long-term security, Europe needs political will and determination, based on a wide range of relevant policy instruments.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing. - The report on the European Defense Union has been the subject of intense negotiations from the outset, as we are called upon to strengthen the Union's defense capabilities, while respecting a number of rights of both citizens and the Member States, while formulating a specific policy for the future of Europe. . I believe that this report promotes policies that burden the economy and the Member States, while taking no position on the desired reduction of armaments programs. That is why I voted against it.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Negative vote on this report concerning the creation of a common defense policy of the Union as foreseen by the Lisbon Treaty.I believe that the good intentions of peace and security on a global level are used as a pretext for the creation of a strong defensive instrument, which can be an added value in international negotiations with Russia and the United States.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - In the face of the continuous emergence of internal and external threats, the EU makes it a priority to adopt joint, coordinated and timely efforts for an optimal annihilation of the same, so I express my adherence to the report. That is, by implementing joint training and education activities, in addition to operational ones, cancers with countless metastases such as terrorism, information and energy insecurity and organized crime can be eradicated. This project, in order not to remain just a dream, but to turn into a powerful antidote, requires a revision of the common security and defense policy, it must be based on principles of strong collective defense by efficient functioning and coordination with NATO. By establishing, therefore, an innovative condition of interoperability, it will be possible, moreover, not only to reduce costs for individual states thanks to the sharing of platforms and materials, but also to increase technological innovation and improve the European defense industry by equipping it with primates. in global competitiveness. Consistent with the above, I invite you to establish a model of the Council of Defense Ministers and to create a permanent working group on the issues to be dealt with. By virtue of this, I fully share the launch in 2017 of a preparatory action in the field of common defense and security.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the Report on the European Defence Union due to Ireland’s position on neutrality.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The establishment of a European Defense Union, as a means of greater integration, is important and current. The international challenges facing the Union call for a fully realized and operational Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP). I believe that the EU should exploit all the potentialities of the Lisbon Treaty, such as Permanent Structured Cooperation or the Petersberg Missions. To this end, there is a need for financial commitment, in the MFF and annual budgets, in order to eliminate the cost of not -Europe in this area (26.4 billion euros / year). I welcome the initiative to draft a White Paper on Defense and the current consensus on further integration. I hope that these steps and political will will become concrete instruments. To this end, I believe it is urgent to implement the EU's Global Strategy action plan in this area. I highlight priorities such as cybersecurity, maritime security or hybrid war, as current challenges for European defense. In this context, I stress the importance of scientific research for an effective approach. I argue that a UED should represent an opportunity for young entrepreneurs, for European SMEs and for European public procurement in this area. For these reasons, I support this report.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report because we need to work better together on security and defense policy within the EU.The security situation in and around Europe has deteriorated considerably in recent years, and great and unprecedented challenges have arisen which no country or organization could tackle alone.We need a defense union in order to be independent from countries like the USA, Russia and China.The EU must therefore take on more responsibility in the areas of internal and external security and at the same time ensure the necessary stability in the world.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- To lay the foundations for a genuine Europe of defense, this is the precise request made by the European Parliament in the resolution on the European Defense Union voted this week.Finally, Europe has shown courage and dignity, calling for a substantial revision of the common security and defense policy.In fact, faced with the many threats to the freedom and serenity of our people, a decisive turning point is needed to make a decisive contribution to the security of the Union and to the management of international crises which can no longer be based on improvisation or actions of individual member countries.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: written. - We have today voted in favor of the report on a European Defense Union. On the other hand, we have not supported proposals for the EU to have its own military units, its own financing of military capabilities or to be able to make its own decisions on military operations. These are issues that are and will remain national sovereignty and an issue between Member States. On the other hand, we consider it important to safeguard solidarity between Member States and to develop defense cooperation between Member States. The common capacity to combat terrorism, disinformation, economic warfare and political destabilization must be strengthened, as must the capacity to lead military peacekeeping and peace-building operations - all without compromising NATO's common structure for the common defense of European territory and peace. We support the proposals to increase funding for national defense, but emphasize that it is up to each Member State to decide on its objectives and at what pace it wants and can achieve them.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing.- This report envisages the creation of a Defense Union aimed at strengthening European military capabilities.More particularly, it provides for the introduction of tax incentives (tax exemptions) in the defense field, with the idea of developing a European drone industry, thus allocating funds in the military field, about 500 million per year from 2021 and 2%of the GDP of each Member State.In addition, it is envisaged to support NATO initiatives for the deployment of battalions in member states when necessary.The above seems to me more than sufficient to understand my total dissent towards this report and my total dissent towards a militarization of Europe.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - The aim of this report is to develop common projects, and the money contributed is expected to mobilize up to € 5 billion a year from 2017. In addition, it is intended to promote research and development in military projects. Until now, community spending on innovation excluded military uses, but in 2017 25 million will be allocated and from 2020, 500 million a year are expected. I have rejected this report that seeks to strengthen the security and militarist perspective and, which requires States to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, when the European population sinks more and more into misery and unemployment (the data shows us they say that in the Spanish State 1 out of 5 households are below the poverty line, and unemployment is close to 4 million unemployed). What the States should do is increase social investment and job creation, not contribute to militaristic escalation. According to Article 41 (2) of the TEU there can be no military financing from the Union budget. My vote against this report from the opposite and militaristic line.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - According to Eurobarometer 85.1 of June 2016, around two thirds of EU citizens would like to see greater EU engagement in security and defense policy issues. Furthermore, the cost of non-Europe in defense and security is estimated at € 26.4 billion per year, due to duplication, overcapacity and obstacles in the defense procurement sector. This resolution aims to respond to the need to implement a European Defense Union, building on the unused instruments already provided for in the Lisbon Treaty. The treaty requires Member States to make adequate capabilities available for military and civilian missions and operations, under the common security and defense policy, through tools such as permanent structured cooperation and battle groups. I voted in favor of this resolution, because I believe it is necessary to fully exploit the advantages of European cooperation in order to respond to the context of interconnected crises and challenges facing Europe. In particular, I believe that it is necessary to focus on key elements such as constructive cooperation between the EU and NATO, the expansion of the Athena mechanism, the joint work between the Commission and the European Defense Agency in favor of the strategic autonomy and competitiveness of the defense industry. European.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - In recent years, the security situation in and around Europe has deteriorated significantly, leading to difficult and unprecedented problems that no country or organization can solve on its own. The European Union is facing a security crisis on its territory more than ever, and these threats are becoming increasingly complex. I voted in favor of a common defense policy for the Union, which must strengthen Europe's ability to promote security inside and outside its borders. The European Defense Union must be based on regular joint assessments of security threats made by Member States, but must also be flexible enough to deal with the security challenges facing each Member State, and to meet their individual security needs. The EU must remain a guarantor of respect for human rights, the spread of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - In recent years, the security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly and posed unprecedented challenges. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, organized crime, cyber attacks, and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle these challenges alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to ensure the security of its citizens. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy, in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. A meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to provide permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. I am convinced that the Union must take decisive action to protect the Union and its citizens, which is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the initiative to create a European Defense Union because I am convinced that defense policy must remain in the hands of sovereign states.The growing security threat facing Europe has motivated some circles to raise the issue of building stronger cooperation between states in terms of security.Some even argue that this cooperation should take the form of a formal defense union.Addressing issues leading to formal action in this regard is a violation of the fundamental principle of a democratic and sovereign state.The issue of security requires cooperation, so I believe that actions should be coordinated on the NATO forum.The proposal to create an EU army will weaken NATO and have a negative impact on relations with international defense partners.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The report in question deals with the creation of a European Defence Union in light of the security situations around Europe and the European neighbourhood region. The report however goes into detail about collective military spending, the control of Member States’ military assets by other Member States, and even goes as far as to call on Member States to dedicate a percentage of their GDP to military spending – all aspects I voted against. Finally, I abstained on this report as a whole as I believe that any establishment of a European Defence Union needs to have an opt-out and recognition of national cases of neutrality.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report, which proposes significant enhancements to the defence union. Whilst I am in favour of significant bilateral cooperation with EU Member States, NATO remains the anchor of British national security and our own defence policy should remain under British sovereign control.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - In an international geopolitical framework characterized by growing instability, an increase in threats, the scourge of terrorism and numerous attacks - cyber and not only - inside and outside our borders, the European Parliament today approved a resolution on the European Defense Union. A text that I fully supported and that lays solid foundations for the realization of a real plan for a common defense, which in the long term I hope will lead to the creation of a European Union army. In particular, among the proposals that I have supported, I emphasize the push towards the creation of multinational forces and an operational headquarters for military operations and measures towards the rationalization of spending, so as to eliminate unnecessary waste, duplication and overcapacity in the defence. The message we have launched is clear: on security and defense, Europe can no longer afford to move in no particular order, but must move towards greater integration, assuming those responsibilities that are now more than ever necessary to contribute decisively to the legitimate security needs of European citizens and the management of international crises.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- In this motion for a resolution, we call on the Member States to step up defense cooperation.In view of the growing security threats within the European Union and in its neighborhood, in particular the threat from the Islamic State, close cooperation between the armed forces of the countries of the Union is considered essential.Among the flagship proposals, MEPs recommend spending 2% of GDP on defense, in order to establish multinational forces and an EU headquarters to plan and command crisis management operations.Supporting these goals, I voted for the resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are concerned by the increasing move towards EU military capability and its potential negative impact on UK foreign policy interests. NATO is and should remain the primary guarantor of security in Europe. Any development of EU foreign policy or defence capability risks undermining this.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text which calls for progress towards the European Defense Union.The recent news with the vote for Brexit and the election of Donald Trump as President of the United States has only consolidated our desire to continue to strengthen the defense capabilities of the European Union and cooperation between theMember States in this area.It seems obvious to me that in the face of a strongest terrorist threat, the risk of hybrid threats, or even organized crime, our work towards a Europe of defense must be made a top priority.This text therefore emphasizes the need for the European Union and its Member States to provide adequate financial resources for this purpose.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the unprecedented challenges alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy, in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a defense union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, and I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- I support the report because I believe that closer cooperation on defense is one of the priorities of the Member States.Indeed, an increasing number of European citizens would like a greater effort by the Union for common security and defense policies.Europe is surrounded by threats which also need to be addressed through better collaboration with NATO.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing.- After Brexit, the terrorist attacks and lasting destabilization in Europe's neighborhood, defense and security issues have never been so topical.The Union must equip itself with a common headquarters and must be the crucible for pooling efforts in terms of budget and equipment.In a world made less secure, this is what European citizens expect of us.This report supports the idea of a progressive construction of the European Defense Union and proposes some tools.For my part, I would like to reiterate my wish to see defense spending not enter into the calculation of the debt.For historical reasons, in line with the peaceful and neutral nature of certain Member States, France almost alone assumes Europe's military presence in the world; it must be able to be supported in one way or another in this effort..

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- I voted against this report.It aims to revive European defense policy from its ashes, in the wake of Brexit.The integrated European defense policy is supported by NATO: it was one of the conditions for France's reinstatement of the integrated NATO command.This objective is, moreover, fully assumed by the text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - The new conditions and the constant threats to security in Europe have sparked a new debate among European politicians. Against the background of the new debate, two main lines emerged. The first is for those who want "more Europe," or in other words, the Federalists.
