The second is what my group and I consider to be right, namely that security and defense are the most important sign of sovereignty and must be the competence of nation states. I believe that, first of all, the countries in Europe must fulfill their commitment to NATO and start investing 2% of GDP in defense and security, and then we can build a new defense alliance. That is why I voted against the report on the European Defense Union.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- Negative vote for the report as a whole.Once again, the EU is showing its allegiance to NATO and the United States by faithfully following their mandates, which are against the interests of the peoples and nations of Europe.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the new challenges on an unprecedented scale alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, so I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I am opposed to any militarisation of the EU. I believe the EU has huge potential to become an international force for peace and reconciliation and that a defence union is the wrong choice. In addition, the report talks of defence spending, weaponry and the development of a European drone industry. Wales is used for testing drones and there is huge opposition to this amongst my constituents.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: European defense policy is, by its own admission, based on NATO.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report reflects the ongoing process in the EU of strengthening the security perspective at home and from a militarist perspective at the external level. The report argues that the EU must develop its military capabilities so that it can be prepared to intervene in any situation inside or outside its borders. The report considers that the so-called European Defense Union will contribute to the strengthening of NATO itself and to further strengthen collaboration with this organization. The report proposes cooperation and development in the industrial and military research sector. It is intended to strengthen funding and support for this sector. It promotes the definition of a common armaments policy. Proposes the realization of a White Paper on defense issues. It advocates increasing spending on defense budgets. It defends the establishment of European Armed Forces. It advocates the deepening of the Common Security and Defense Policy. It defends the EU's autonomous actions and the development of the EU's military capabilities to act where NATO cannot act. It advocates that the parliamentary defense subcommittee (SEDE) be transformed into a full-fledged commission. Finally, the report unravels an entire dark militaristic menu that can only have our vote against.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - There is no doubt that the overriding task of the European Union is to ensure the security of its citizens, which should be supported by a strong military force.However, I do not agree with the European Defense Union's proposal, because most EU member states are members of NATO, where they still do not pay mandatory contributions, and I see no reason for a parallel structure that will cost taxpayers in Europe billions of euros.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report because, although I agree on some issues, I am skeptical about how it works.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the European Defense Union as a whole.Once again, the EU is showing its allegiance to NATO and the United States by faithfully following their mandates, which are against the interests of the peoples and nations of Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The report backs the idea of progressing in the direction of a European Defence Union and for such a structure to represent an ‘umbrella’ for military capabilities at the disposal of the European Union. It proposes the activation of permanent structured cooperation, it proposes setting up an EU Operational Headquarters, it encourages fostering the EU defence industries. I strongly support the developments in the field of CSDP and encourage the steps towards a substantial autonomous defence capacity for the EU, aiming at protecting its citizens and promoting its values and interests, with full respect for the Treaties, international law and human rights. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which once again recalls the European Parliament's call to give the EU the means to meet citizens' security expectations. The report rightly points out that the level of ambition needs to be raised significantly, given the growing instability and unpredictability in our neighborhood, and now given the outcome of the US presidential election. It is high time that all the possibilities offered by the Treaty of Lisbon were exploited to guarantee more coherence and effectiveness of the Union in the field of defense. Moreover, the report shows that more defense autonomy will only strengthen NATO's credibility. In addition, the report devotes particular attention to research and industrial base issues, for which it is urgent to mobilize adequate resources. Finally, the European Defense Union must be placed in the context of the common defense and security policy and the coherence of internal and external policies, in a world where security threats find their source both within the EU. 'Union only outside its borders.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the new challenges on an unprecedented scale alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy, in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, so I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report fully convinced of the need to equip the Union with the necessary elements to face the challenges in the field of defense. Currently, cooperation between member states is occasional, and Europe continues to rely heavily on NATO and the solidarity of the United States. Faced with the deterioration of security in recent years, in Europe and beyond its borders, due to terrorism, hybrid threats and cyber and energy insecurity, the Union must rise to the occasion and take decisive steps towards a defense union , since no single country can face the challenges that lie ahead. The Union must be able to respond faster and more firmly to threats, which requires the armed forces to improve their cooperation. It is especially important to study the possibility of undertaking joint purchases of military material, as well as having an operational headquarters in the Union to plan and direct crisis management operations.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. ‒ This is a very important report given that the security situation in and around Europe has considerably worsened in recent years. Threats like terrorism and conflicts in our neighbourhood are threats that no single country is able to face alone – this requires a European response.  The current financial constraints from austerity and the increased security threats require European armed forces to collaborate more closely and for them to train and work better in unison. The Union defence policy provided by the Council is a first step but it requires more financial resources for its implementation. Key objectives for European defence in the future are joint procurement and other forms of pooling resources; this could provide a much-needed boost to Europe’s defence industry. Another key objective is the launch of an EU-funded defence research programme; this should be launched at least by the next MFF – sufficient funding for this programme is key to ensuring the sufficient future defence capacities of the European Union.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I strongly supported the EP resolution on the European Defense Union, because I am in favor of this very important proposal inspired by the Italian government for the creation of a European Defense Union, a historic objective pursued since the start of the integration process of the European states after the end of the Second World War. The times are now ripe, and the challenges that history poses to Europe concern its very survival. I am therefore in favor of the EU's common foreign policy being enriched with a new piece, by equipping itself with a military umbrella that supports NATO's role in protecting EU Member States. The Defense Union would also represent a further stimulus for cooperation between Member States in the fight against terrorism and intelligence-sharing, and would allow the European defense industry to be strengthened and interesting collaborations and joint initiatives to be launched. I therefore hope that the concerns of some countries will be overcome and that, by activating the instrument of structured cooperation, the Council can take rapid steps forward in this direction, as hoped for by the Italian government.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I consciously voted in favor of the idea of a European Defense Union - not because I consider it a conceivable replacement or future competitor for NATO.I think it is an opportunity and a necessity for Europe to face the task of defense and global peacekeeping together.So far we have done this far too little and in an uncoordinated manner.Given the current global political situation, we have to make up for what has been missed.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written. - The security situation in and around the European Union has worsened considerably in recent years. Not only is the EU being threatened by international terrorism in an unprecedented way, but it is also facing violence in Ukraine, North Africa and the Middle East. No country or organization can meet these challenges alone. Rather, the European Union must continue to develop its common security and defense policy and grow together into an effective European defense union. We owe this not only to the citizens of Europe, but primarily to the many civil and military members of the armed forces stationed there. By bundling capacities, as is already the case in the EU battlegroups, we are strengthening the cooperation and defense strength of all member states while at the same time reducing the cost of the member states' defense budgets. In order to achieve this goal, it is first necessary to implement permanent structures at the European level. These structures include a European defense headquarters. With a permanent European defense structure, the European Union will in future be able to react to security crises in its immediate vicinity to a greater extent and thus meet its historical responsibility as a peace project. In a world with global challenges for our security situation, we must not think in terms of national answers. We can only meet these challenges in the future with bundled forces.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. Immediately following Brexit, the EU Commission and several key Member States began preparations for the further integration of EU Member States’ military policies. This has given further impetus for more areas of integration in defence and industrial policy; ultimately leading to a defence union. This report is full of calls for more financial spending, greater use of existing tools, and the creation of EU strategic autonomy. The final article lists 21 new policy initiatives the Parliament wants the Commission to pursue.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: in writing.- The idea of a common defense for the European Union is symbolically disastrous: it undermines all sovereignty by pooling sovereign competence and putting us in serious danger, at a time when States need to be able to defend themselvesindividually when faced with a threat.The pretext of terrorism in no way pleads for such a policy, the limits of which have been clearly seen in this area.For these reasons, I opposed this report.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - Many speakers said yesterday that the isolationist tendencies displayed by Mr. Trump made European defense more necessary than ever. But a European defense against whom, against what, in the service of what diplomatic and strategic interests? Paradoxically, always at the service of American interests. On the one hand, there is no coherent foreign policy of the European Union, as the interests and traditions of the Member States diverge. On the other hand, the rapporteur does not plan to stop including European security within the framework of NATO. A "European" army would therefore have "European" only in name. Deprived of its British component by Brexit, it would be reduced to a French army, hampered by budget cuts, supported by a few disparate units from other countries, engaged in external theaters of operations very far from the North Atlantic but determined in Washington. Committed against whom, moreover, in the future? The rapporteur is careful not to spell out his thoughts: vague humanitarian or peacekeeping missions, vague definitions of threats which do not incriminate anyone in particular. So I voted against it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted against this report on the European Defense Union, because it proposes to give the Union greater strategic autonomy in defense policies and greater coordination, but it does so by proposing measures that in no way guarantee reaching solutions to problemssecurity that exist globally.The report calls for specific resources to be earmarked for military cooperation between member states, to create a European Defense Union, beyond the Common Security and Defense Policy, to convene meetings at European level of Defense Ministers, and to create a headquarters ofthe Union, among other measures.None of these measures is aimed at solving the causes that cause threats to security in the Union, much less contribute to generating a framework of stability, cooperation and peace between the countries.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - As the shadow rapporteur in the IMCO Committee on the Opinion on the European Defense Union, I consider this report to be very important for the common security and defense policy under the Lisbon Treaty, according to which the EU must promote global peace and security. Enhanced European defense cooperation would lead to greater effectiveness, increased EU assets and capabilities, as well as possible positive effects on defense research and industry. Developing the EU's capabilities through joint public procurement could provide a boost for Europe's defense industry, including SMEs, which boost growth and jobs. It is important to encourage a functioning, accessible and transparent European defense market that supports SMEs and aims to enable Member States to maximize their defense and security budgets.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as it offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO or interfere in an area of Member State competence.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which aims to strengthen Europe's defense autonomy. Europe must be able to better guarantee the security and protection of its citizens and to stabilize its external environment. For this, common funding mechanisms must be developed and the use of EU battle groups must be more flexible. It is also planned to share non-lethal material (transport vehicles, etc.) and to develop a common defense research program. It is essential to consolidate the European industrial, technological and research base in defense and to encourage investment in new technologies. Now that Donald Trump is at the head of the United States, the European Union must more than ever prove that it is capable of autonomously facing threats to its security interests, of providing assistance to its partners and to protect its territory and its citizens in complete independence from NATO.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written. - The deteriorating security situation in the EU's immediate area has raised the issue of the development of the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP). We Swedish Social Democrats believe that we need an active and united EU to be able to meet the foreign policy challenges we face today and are very positive about the streamlining of the CSDP and increased cooperation between the Member States on these issues. Security and defense policy is one of several important tools the EU has at its disposal to help create a more stable and secure environment. We would therefore have liked the report to take a broader perspective on the concept of security in order to better reflect the priorities of the EU Global Strategy (EUGS). It would have been desirable to have a greater focus on the important balance between civilian and military capabilities in order for the EU to be able to effectively provide crisis management, stabilization efforts and conflict prevention measures. Several of the proposals presented in the report, including increased funding through EU funds, targeted support for defense research and the defense industry, as well as the stated demand for the establishment of a European Defense Union, are more far-reaching than we would like to see. We believe that decision-making competence in security and defense policy should continue to be a national competence. For that reason, we chose not to support the report in its entirety.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic insecurity, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State can tackle the unprecedented new challenges alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination for long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative assessment of risks and threats makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - The report follows the logic of the militarization of the European Union. It promotes the goal of the European Union developing its military capabilities so that it is ready to intervene in any situation inside or outside its borders. The European Defense Union also seeks to contribute to strengthening NATO's work. In addition, it calls for the creation of a start-up fund for pre-military operations, as well as for strengthening the European Union's cooperation with NATO. For these reasons we voted against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as I felt that it went too far in terms of harmonising security and defence policy at EU level. I also believe that for neutral countries, such as Ireland, an EU Defence Union undercuts this long-standing policy. Finally, I do not believe that it is in the interest of the EU to use funds in the budget on defence spending.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation in the field of defense at European level.The EU member states should cooperate more closely, spend more money on defense and launch new security and defense initiatives on the part of the EU.In the opinion of the ECR Group, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures within the framework of the Common Security and Defense Policy of the EU (CSDP) is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully applied within the framework of a European super-state.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Iris HOFFMANN
text: written. - In principle, I support the call for better coordination in the common security and defense policy, especially for reasons of cost and because of the resulting synergy effects. As much as I can understand the deepening of the CSDP as a long-term strategic goal, I would like to accompany this process critically. Overall, the entire project is still too vague. However, I consider the approach for the report to be fundamentally wrong because there is no concrete structural or substantive basis. Before we agree to such an ambitious project, the Member States must first be prepared to make these funds available additionally. In addition, I expect the European Council to submit a content-based security and defense strategy to Parliament at the same time. This then requires a broad parliamentary debate about the goals of such a project and its implementation. I therefore reject the report.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: written. - We have today voted in favor of a report on a European Defense Union. On the other hand, we have not supported proposals for the EU to have its own military units, its own financing of military capabilities or to be able to make its own decisions on military operations. These are issues that are and will remain national sovereignty and an issue between Member States. On the other hand, we consider it important to safeguard solidarity between Member States and to develop defense cooperation between Member States. The common capacity to counter terrorism, disinformation, economic warfare and political destabilization must be strengthened, as must the capacity to lead military peacekeeping and peacekeeping operations. All this without interfering with the fact that NATO is the common structure that stands for the common defense of European territory and peace. We support the proposals to increase funding for national defense, but emphasize that it is up to each Member State to decide on its objectives and at what pace it wants and can achieve them.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the new challenges on an unprecedented scale alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, so I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the development and fostering of the EU’s autonomous defence capacity. The European Defence Union should be supported in order for the EU to have its own common military capability.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union (2016/2052 (INI)), given that there are clear needs to change the current model as the security situation in Europe and its neighborhood has deteriorated significantly in recent years and created new challenges that no one the earth cannot bear it alone. Military threats, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic instability, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime are the main security threats in an increasingly complex and connected world. The cost of a non-united Europe in the field of defense and security is estimated at € 26.4 billion a year. In order to achieve its long-term security, in addition to political will, Europe needs a number of concrete instruments, including the formulation of a common defense policy, and additional funds for the realization of modern military capabilities. A Council of Defense Ministers needs to be established to enable sustainable political leadership and coordinate the formation of the European Defense Union. Although NATO must remain the foundation of collective defense in Europe, the political priorities of NATO and the EU do not always have to be the same, and the EU must be more prepared to insure itself against possible threats. A strategy needs to be adopted as soon as possible, outlining the steps to be taken to establish and implement the European Defense Union.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing.- The security situation in the European Union has become less predictable and stable.The EU must take appropriate measures to achieve maximum control over its external borders.Only by increasing investment in defense will it be possible to respond fully to the concerns of the citizens of the EU Member States arising from the distrust of the Union's ability to act in this area.I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union because it is a step towards more systematic military cooperation between Member States.The main recommendation is to increase Member States' defense spending to 2% of their GDP.There is also a need to adapt the activities of EU battlegroups and to further develop the arms industry.All in full compliance with NATO.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Urmas Paet on EU defense cooperation.In view of the security situation inside and outside European borders, I support the strengthening of military cooperation at European level in collaboration with NATO.This initiative will not lead to the creation of a European military contingent but to a rationalization of costs, thus avoiding the duplication and overcapacity which causes the Member States to lose millions of euros.I am delighted that this text was adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which aims to reflect on and imagine a new European defense policy in the face of the current security challenges facing our States.A reformed CSDP (Common Security and Defense Policy) based on a solid defense principle, more efficient funding and coordination with NATO are three priority areas.The creation of a European Defense Union must go through permanent cooperation, which is why I agree with the proposals of this report: creation of a standing committee of defense ministers, permanent units,'' a military start-up fund, reinforcement and expansion of the Athena mechanism (community financing of military security and defense operations).

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Mr Paet’s approach as it becomes more and more necessary for Europe to articulate a strong position when it comes to defence. We are experiencing very challenging times in a changing political environment. Europe should be able to respond to those challenges. However I need to stress the importance of cooperation with NATO so as to avoid duplication and to make sure that our resources are used in the most efficient way.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I reject the proposal for a defense union.The planning of such a defense union would amount to a future EU army and represents a big step towards a curtailment of the member states with regard to their military sovereignty. Furthermore, in my opinion, it is questionable, like a country like Austria, whose military neutrality is highly regarded in politicsand enjoys society, could belong to such an alliance, which is closely linked to NATO.With regard to the important EU-Russia relations, this report can also be understood as a provocation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as it offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO or interfere in what should be a Member State competence.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing.- In respect of the Danish defense reservation, we have voted against the initiative report on a European Defense Union.For the Social Democrats, NATO is, and will be, both Denmark's and the EU's primary and most important security guarantor.That is why it is also crucial for us that the measures towards increased defense cooperation that other EU countries may wish to participate in are fully compatible with NATO cooperation and its structures.We do not support the idea of an EU army, but of course we would like to see the possibility of better coordinating the procurement of materiel, as well as other practical measures that can lead to lower costs across countries and that are not subject to the defense reservation.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - The report by Urmas Paet as a whole is a challenge to build a joint intervention army of EU countries. It will be difficult to find in it a demand for a radical solution (understand the liquidation) of weapons of mass destruction at European and global level. According to this report, the European Defense Agency is to cooperate significantly in preparing EU aggressions against third countries. Apart from the Islamic State, Russia is also considered to be a great danger. The proposals aim, in addition to a significant increase in the financial resources spent by the nation states on the army, towards the specialization of the armies of individual countries, as well as the pooling of joint purchases and the maintenance of forces and materials to ensure compatibility. The European Parliament is called upon to set up a new Committee on Security and Defense, in the context of which is the creation of a joint industrial and technological military complex. The proposal also requires that part of the expenditure on operations in this area be borne by the EU budget. Although in many places the proposal lays down NATO as the foundation of collective defense in Europe, it calls for accelerated force generation for CFSP missions. As there are no references to territorial defense throughout the report, but apparently the whole defense strategy is geared to interventions outside the EU, I am forced to reject the report in its entirety. Defense and security cannot be based on the preparation of interventions outside the EU.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation in the field of defense at European level.The EU member states should cooperate more closely, spend more money on defense and launch new security and defense initiatives on the part of the EU.In the opinion of the ECR Group, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures within the framework of the Common Security and Defense Policy of the EU (CSDP) is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully applied within the framework of a European super-state.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I believe that we live in a world that raises new security issues before us, and it is our duty as directly elected representatives to respond to them. However, I am afraid that a common European army would be a step in the wrong direction if it were only a kind of NATO complement that does not work anyway. Given that the EU Battlegroups, which reached full operational capability in 2007 and whose mission is to deploy military operations of a humanitarian, peace and peace-building nature, have not yet been used due to procedural, financial and political obstacles, despite the opportunity to do so. and it was necessary, we see that the EU is not able to agree on the deployment of a small number of combat troops, and now it wants to build a common European army. I was somewhat taken aback by the European Parliament's view that, with the growing integration of internal and external security, it is essential that the common security and foreign policy go beyond external crises, truly ensure common security and defense, and enable the Union to engage in all phases of crises and conflicts. using the full range of tools at his disposal, as I personally see this as a call to arms, which should supposedly be foreign to the peaceful European project. So I voted against.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the new challenges on an unprecedented scale alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, so I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against since this report leads Europe to re-militarisation, wasting hundreds of millions of EUR in the EU’s budget on defence research programme.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- The report specifically interprets the provisions of Article 41 (2) TEU on the EU budget, which prohibits the use of the EU budget to cover expenditure arising from military or defense-related operations.There is clearly strong lobbying for the adoption of an annual defense research program of EUR 500 million and an increase in Member States' defense spending to 2% of their GDP.But why would all this be in the interests of EU citizens at a time when there is very little effective action against trained and battled terrorists, who are currently the biggest security threat from the war zones in the Middle East?The enemy is already within boundaries, you don’t have to look outside.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because I believe that the time has really come to put in place a common defense policy of the Union capable of promoting the rule of law, peace and security globally. However, to ensure long-term security, Europe needs political will and determination based on a wide range of relevant policy instruments. Therefore, not only an arms race, not only a militarization in a European key of our borders, but rather a recourse to the permanent structured cooperation already defined in Article 42 of the TEU and a reference to the activities listed in Article 43. I refer in in particular joint disarmament actions, humanitarian and relief missions, military advisory and assistance missions, conflict prevention and peacekeeping missions and peacekeeping and stabilization operations at the end of the conflicts. This too is European defense and all these actions can also contribute to the fight against terrorism, including by supporting third countries to fight terrorism on their territory.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because nowadays the EU and the Member States face many complex and interconnected security threats such as terrorism, violation of international law by third countries, energy insecurity, cyber attacks and hybrid warfare. Undoubtedly, the current state of the CSDP does not allow the EU and the Member States to address effectively these security threats. The inefficiency of the CSDP can be regarded as one of the reasons why approximately two thirds of EU citizens would like to see greeter EU engagement in matters of security and defence policy. We should not turn a blind eye to the fact that in times of rising euroscepticism and nationalism, EU citizens increasingly regard security as a high priority and want the EU to show greater leadership. Offering our citizens security makes the establishment of the European Defence Union (EDU) a matter of urgency. I strongly believe that the establishment of EDU starts from a thoroughly revised CSDP, based on a strong collective defence principle, efficient financing and coordination with NATO. In a long term perspective, the establishment of EDU will foster the process of European integration, the EU’s role in world politics, safety and security of EU citizens.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. –According to recent statistics, 85.1% of our citizens would like the Union to engage more in matters related to political security and defense, finding efficient solutions that guarantee a protected society. In fact, the security of our States is now threatened by emerging phenomena including terrorism, economic, information and energy instability, organized crime, and ultimately climate change. These challenges cannot be addressed individually but, on the contrary, require the collaboration of all Member States and the adoption of systematic and joint programs. Consequently, the Parliament's report stresses the need to ensure long-term defense policies through the creation of a European Defense Union, and calls for a review of the EU's overall strategy. Security is undoubtedly a major concern of European citizens and it is our obligation to do everything possible to achieve concrete results for their benefit.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this own-initiative report, which gives new impetus to the European Defense Union project.While real threats exist and grow, it is necessary that the Member States of the European Union step up their efforts in the field of security and defense cooperation, in order to effectively fight terrorism in particular.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the European Defense Union.This is one of the many reports made to instrumentalize Brexit in order to strengthen the European Union, if necessary by attempting to revive European defense policy.European defense policy is a 15-year-old sea serpent which, by its own admission, is based on NATO.This consubstantial link is also assumed by the text (points 3, 36, 37 and 38) and betrays the real nature of the UED.In any event, the European Union has no political, organizational or other legitimacy to claim defense competence from member states.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing. - The European Defense Union is an innovative solution to the important and growing problem of the European Union's defense capabilities. This is the first practical but important step taken in increasingly complex circumstances and at a time of increasing dangerous signals and behavior emanating from Eastern Europe. Additionally, the behavior of the new Washington administration is ambiguous. It should be emphasized that the adopted proposal is to ensure that each country fulfills its obligation to spend 2% of GDP on defense purposes. Poland is meeting this commitment. Additional resources for building the European Defense Union should be provided for in the new multiannual financial framework, but not only in terms of cohesion policy. Each country's budgetary effort must be taken into account. Development in the field of CSDP must be encouraged and further steps encouraged to enhance the EU's defense capabilities in full respect of treaties, international law and human rights.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- I voted against this text, which takes advantage of the post-Brexit hesitation to try to relaunch European defense policy, a sea serpent defended tooth and nail by NATO.As our group does not approve of France's return to the integrated NATO command, confirmed by Nicolas Sarkozy, and the Alliance's consubstantial link with this idea of a European defense policy, I opposed this report.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - The aim of this report is to develop common projects, and the money contributed is expected to mobilize up to € 5 billion a year from 2017. In addition, it is intended to promote research and development in military projects. Until now, community spending on innovation excluded military uses, but in 2017 25 million will be allocated and from 2020, 500 million a year are expected. I have rejected this report that seeks to strengthen the security and militarist perspective and, which requires States to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, when the European population sinks more and more into misery and unemployment (the data shows us they say that in the Spanish State 1 out of 5 households are below the poverty line, and unemployment is close to 4 million unemployed). What the States should do is increase social investment and job creation, not contribute to militaristic escalation. According to Article 41 (2) of the TEU there can be no military financing from the Union budget. My vote against this report from the opposite and militaristic line.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - We are facing a challenge that has proven to be transcendental in recent times and that is security in Europe. In order to protect the Union and our citizens, the cooperation of the Union and its Member States is essential, starting with the implementation of the provisions on defense, provided for in the Lisbon Treaty. This report highlights the importance of exploiting the full potential of the Lisbon Treaty, in particular the permanent structured cooperation provided for in Article 42 (6) TEU, and the establishment of practical provisions and guidelines for the future activation of Article 42 (6) 7, of the TEU, on aid and assistance to a Member State victim of a terrorist attack. Nor does it forget the cooperative relationship between NATO and the Union, adding that the Union must be prepared to act alone in the event that NATO does not. I vote in favor because joint action will improve safety, as well as contribute to reducing costs.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation in the field of defense at European level.The EU member states should cooperate more closely, spend more money on defense and launch new security and defense initiatives on the part of the EU.In the opinion of the ECR Group, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures within the framework of the Common Security and Defense Policy of the EU (CSDP) is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully applied within the framework of a European super-state.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The security situation in Europe and its neighborhood has deteriorated significantly in recent years and created a number of new challenges, so an organizational review is needed to exploit the full potential of the European Defense Agency and prove that it creates added value.To guarantee its long-term security, Europe needs political will, determination, strong and modern military capabilities.The European Council should lead the gradual development of the Union's common defense policy.Overlaps in the application of NATO and Union instruments need to be avoided, and the EU must strive to be able to act independently in defense, taking greater responsibility by improving equipment, training and organization.Member States must strive to achieve the goal of spending 2% of GDP on defense and to spend 20% of their defense budgets on equipment whose necessity has been determined by the European Defense Agency.I believe in the importance of cooperation in defense policy, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The cost of non-Europe in defence and security is estimated at EUR 26.4 billion annually, as the result of duplication, overcapacity and barriers to defence procurement. It is the good platform for cooperation that can reduce unnecessary spending. But I am against imposing an obligation on Member States to spend 2% of GDP for defence.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - Terrorist attacks in Europe demonstrate the need for enhanced Union cooperation in the field of defense and security.In addition to coordinated and more effective cooperation, the common defense policy also eliminates duplication of EU and national costs for certain activities.I supported the proposal to establish a European Defense Union, which should be built on the basis of existing law, mutual cooperation, respect for the rights of the Member States and cooperation with the international defense communities.I consider the strengthening of the Union's security and defense capabilities to be a priority which will also increase the people's reduced confidence in the Union's ability to act.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- Terrorist attacks, the destabilization of countries neighboring the Union and cybernetic insecurity are all factors which make better cooperation in the field of security and defense necessary within our Union.This report supports the idea of a progressive construction of the European Defense Union, in particular through the introduction of a “European Defense Semester”, the creation of a Union headquarters in order toplan and order crisis management operations or better investment in defense research.In order to build a European area that is ever more secure and capable of responding to current challenges, our armed forces must work together more closely;that's why I support this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the European Defense Union, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 21 November 2016, and because this report is not complete and well-documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This text aims to develop European defense policy.He is taking advantage of Brexit to try to breathe new life into this project, which has nevertheless demonstrated its effectiveness, and which itself recognizes that it is based on NATO.This European Defense Union actually makes it possible to provide troops, from the Member States which still have a military tool, to the Member States which do not have one.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on European Defence Union. Security and defence are key topics that require the EU’s utmost attention. The proliferation of terrorist organisations in the Middle East and North Africa is posing a security threat to the European continent, and, therefore, requires cooperation from all Member States as terrorism cannot be tackled effectively by one country only.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- This report promotes the reinforcement of a security perspective at home and a militarist perspective at the external level of the EU, that is, a common armaments policy.In particular, it proposes to increase military spending, using 2% of GDP for that purpose and 20% of its defense budgets identified as necessary, which violates Article 41 (2) TEU.What this report advocates is the (re) militarization of Europe, based on a security and Europe-fortress view.I voted against.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The long-term goal of a defense union is to build an EU army, which is the first step towards the permanent abolition of the sovereignty of the member states.The envisaged close cooperation with NATO and the attempted saber-rattling against Russia on the one hand and loyalty to Austrian neutrality on the other hand are the reasons for voting against this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament report.Given the difficult geopolitical situation, we must make every effort to ensure our security and to strengthen cooperation and mutual understanding between European Member States in this area.However, I believe that European initiatives in the field of defense should not duplicate the functions performed by NATO structures.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report attempts to revive the European defense policy, a chimera based on NATO and aimed at providing troops to certain powers by states with a still capable military tool.Which, without Great Britain, could soon concern only France despite an army in the process of decay.I therefore opposed this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- To guarantee its long-term security, Europe needs political will and determination sustained by a wide range of relevant policy instruments, including strong and modern military capabilities.The creation of the Union's common defense policy constitutes progress in the implementation of the Common Security and Defense Policy of the Treaty of Lisbon, which is subject to international law and is effectively indispensable to allow the EU to promote the rule of law, peace andsecurity worldwide.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because a European Defence Union will improve Europe’s defence in the face of unprecedented security challenges. It is not a question of impinging on States’ neutrality but a matter of facing common challenges together.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - Today, European security is more and more threatened. The surveillance of our borders poses many problems and uncertainties. However, the Union is not equipped to deal with this range of defense threats. The last thirty years have been characterized by constant cuts in the defense budgets of MS and occasional cooperation. There is no community of destiny without a common defense. There can be no foreign policy without a Union defense policy commensurate with its economic capacity. We need to be more consistent and bring our military personnel together. We need to implement a new approach that takes into account the profoundly changed security environment and make the Union a more important player in the security field. Europe can no longer rely on the US strategic shield. It must develop a defense and be the armed wing of NATO. According to the European Parliament's study on the cost of non-Europe 2014-2019, the potential gain in efficiency from better coordination at European level in the field of security and defense could reach 26 billion euros.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - The current tense security situation in Europe and the world requires the EU to stick together and act together and systematically. To this end, the European armed forces need to work more closely together and for military personnel to train more and better together. According to a Eurobarometer from June this year, up to 2/3 of EU citizens want the Union to become more involved in security and defense policy. Article 42 of the Treaty on European Union provides for the possibility of establishing defense institutions as well as the definition of a European capability and armaments policy. A common defense union would strengthen Europe's ability to promote security on its territory and beyond, as well as a partnership with NATO, leading to even more effective territorial, regional, but also global security and defense. The first step towards launching a European Defense Union should be to activate permanent cooperation structures as well as to implement an action plan for the EU's global strategy. I think that the current security conditions and challenges call for a strong Europe in the field of defense. The Union should realize its potential and take a strong position on security at global level.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ In the current global geopolitical situation with an increase in security threats in Europe and in our neighbouring countries, such as human trafficking, arms trafficking, terrorism attacks and wars, I support the idea of progressing in the direction of a European Defence Union and EU actions for the creation of good governance structures, respect for rule of law and human rights, and the prevention and fight against radicalisation. I agree that the CSDP has a key role to play in conflict prevention as well as in post-conflict capacity and peace building in ensuring a global stable environment. CSDP missions and operations can be an integral part of preventive engagement and crisis response mechanisms especially if activated in a timely and effective manner. Having said that however, I also disagree with a number of paragraphs in the report, such as putting binding commitments on Member States concerning how much they need to spend from their GDP to sustain the increase in the defence industry and on creating a European Defence Research programme with a total budget of at least 500 million per year. Therefore, I abstained at the final report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - My party, the Democratic Coalition, is thinking in the long run of transforming the European Union into a federation, of creating a United States of Europe. It is clear that the creation of the European Defense Union is an essential step in this. However, the establishment of a Defense Union is also needed in the shorter term. It is becoming increasingly clear that the migration crisis can only be tackled effectively through a common policy - including its protection aspects. The Union must also assume its responsibility in dealing with the hotspots that threaten world security, which again presupposes the development of a common defense policy. Nor can it be maintained indefinitely that the security of the Member States of the European Union is guaranteed primarily by NATO, but the burden of this falls disproportionately on the United States. The election of Donald Trump as President predicts that the United States will end this unilateralism quickly, and that any such move should not be unprepared for the European Union. Moreover, the United States will obviously be more willing to take more prudent steps in this direction if the EU is more willing than ever to play its part in defending itself and its security. Finally, the imminent secession of the United Kingdom from the EU, the main opponent, provides a better opportunity than ever to take more decisive steps towards the creation of a European Defense Union. I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- This is one of the many reports made to take advantage of Brexit in an attempt to revive European defense policy.European defense policy is a 15-year-old sea serpent based on its own confession about NATO.It should be remembered that it was the main cause approved by Nicolas Sarkozy for the return of France to the Integrated Command.This consubstantial link is also assumed by the text (points 3, 36, 37 and 38) and betrays the real nature of the UED which is the provision of supplementary troops for those who have a military tool still suitable for others.powers (which, without Great Britain, will soon only be the case with France, despite an army in the process of decay).I vote against.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- Defense policy is perhaps the most crucial for a state.Without its own defense, the state is not one.Any desire to federalize defense must therefore be seen for what it really is: a desire to create a European state against the will of the people.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as it offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO or interfere in what should be a Member State competence.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text which pushes the establishment of a European defense.While I am in favor of in-depth cooperation between European armies, I am attached, as a Gaullist, to the sovereignty of States in military matters.Indeed, I consider that the interests of the Member States of the European Union are not always the same.From this observation, the establishment of a European defense is not conceivable today.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - The international geopolitical situation requires a common defense policy. The fragmentation of EU defense systems costs almost € 26 billion every year. The change of scenarios in the East and South calls for the thinking of integrated defense mechanisms, complementary to NATO. Horizontal coordination of the Member States is of fundamental importance so that resources are not wasted and better results are guaranteed. Among other things, it is necessary to increase investment in defense, reaching the NATO target of 2% of GDP, also to have a stronger European position in the Atlantic framework. At the same time, part of the European budget could be devoted to defense cooperation, including with specific requirements in the multiannual financial framework. Creating a sort of defense Schengen has the objective of avoiding that EU policy depends only on some member states, or that it is not a major player in NATO's choices. A European defense commissioner, more regular meetings of European defense ministers, structured cooperation mechanisms also for the dispatch of multinational forces, a framework for technological research in the defense sector that guarantees strategic autonomy and enhancing European excellence in the sector: these are the last steps to create a true European common defense.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing - Strengthening the EU's defenses is the right idea, but this message came at a very inopportune time.The EU must concentrate its defense forces on NATO, which will sooner or later establish a common defense policy and an army.However, in the context of the US presidential election, this signal may be misunderstood and weaken NATO.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Due to the latest developments, Europe’s security environment is facing new challenges thus calling for the revival of European security cooperation and integration. I voted for this report that stresses the need for a broad set of relevant policy instruments as well as strong and modern military capabilities in order to ensure long-term security in Europe.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union, because there is a need to promote wider and more systematic European cooperation in the field of defense, in order to ensure the availability of key capabilities. A common defense policy of the Union should strengthen Europe's capacity to promote security inside and outside its borders, as well as strengthen its partnership with NATO and transatlantic relations, and therefore make possible a stronger NATO, thus promoting further effective security and defense at territorial, regional and global levels. We encourage the Commission to work with the European Defense Agency to strengthen the industrial and technological base of the defense sector, which is essential for European strategic autonomy. Research carried out in collaboration with the European defense industry in all Member States can help reduce the fragmentation of the sector and increase its competitiveness.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of this report because it proposes a framework of realistic measures for the actions to be taken to establish a European Defense Union. The document emphasizes the importance of the continued development of European cyber defense policy, with a view to increasing the cyber defense capabilities available to Member States, as well as operational cooperation and the exchange of information. With regard to the legislative component, the report calls on the European Parliament to set up a stand-alone Commission for Security and Defense, with the aim of monitoring and implementing permanent and structured cooperation in the field of European defense. Also at institutional level, I share the vision of the reform proposed by the rapporteur, by requesting the Council of the European Union to establish, as a first step, a permanent format for meetings bringing together the defense ministers of the Member States in a decision-making and consultative forum.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the European Defense Union because I believe that, given the existing risks and threats in Europe, a European Defense Union should be created, especially because of the deteriorating security situation at the European Union's borders, especially in the Eastern and Southern neighborhoods. That is why I am glad that this report has been discussed and has received clear support. I believe that the European Defense Union should be based on a regular joint assessment of security threats by the Member States, but at the same time flexible enough to address the individual security challenges and needs of the Member States. All available instruments, including the involvement of European budget resources, should be used to strengthen European defense cooperation between Member States, which I consider to be a priority agenda today (including structured cooperation based on the principle of voluntariness).

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because the planning of a defense union is aimed specifically at a future EU army.This would be a first step towards finally abolishing the military sovereignty of the member states.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Given the deteriorating security situation in Europe, it is high time to build a well-functioning European defense cooperation, as the European neighborhood has become more unstable and unpredictable in the last few years.The report aims to spend 2% of Member States' GDP on defense, EU support for NATO infrastructure such as barracks, roads, etc., and the creation of a Schengen defense force.This is the right time to build a well-functioning European defense cooperation.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I do not support the proposals to establish a European Defense Union as soon as possible, a joint EU military operation headquarters and a multilateral force. The goal of each Member State should not only be to strengthen its armed forces, but also to pursue a much broader political and diplomatic dialogue. In particular, the measures set out in the report show distrust of NATO. Furthermore, in order to build a multilateral force, we reaffirm that mistrust, while at the same time denying the fundamental principles of the autonomy of the members of the community. I do not support the proposal that EU funds be used to shape a common defense policy. Each Member State should be encouraged to make appropriate efforts and demonstrate its determination to defend its borders and its citizens. New arms races or new military formations are by no means an escape from ever-increasing tensions. They can only become catalysts of higher voltages. I do not think it is appropriate to run a European Defense Semester to assess Member States' progress in defense efforts in terms of fiscal efforts, as well as to draw up an EU White Paper on defense and to give a major role to the European Defense Agency.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The security situation inside and outside Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent years, due to challenges that no country can meet on its own, such as terrorism, cyber threats and security breaches and energy. These challenges leave the EU with no choice but to step up co-operation between their national armed forces, paving the way for the creation of a European Defense Union. For reasons of solidarity and resilience, the EU must remain united, but also act united and systematically. Through the European Defense Union, it is proposed to establish a "European Defense Semester, in which each Member State will consult the planning cycles and procurement plans of the other states", as well as to strengthen and expand the role of the European Defense Agency. This resolution calls on the European Council "to lead the gradual delimitation of a common defense policy of the Union and to provide additional financial resources to ensure its implementation".

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that over the past few years the internal security situation of the European Union has been severely tested and has given rise to difficult and difficult challenges for individual countries or individuals to bear. organizations. Today, Europe is threatened by terrorism and consequently the European Union is asked to adopt positions which are directed, through the mutual exchange of information, to fight against the violation of human rights. Already in 2007, at the time of the formulation of the Lisbon Treaty, the possibility was foreseen for the Member States to make means available for possible military and civil operations under the CSDP and the possibility of establishing a European Union of security and defense, which would have led to the establishment of the European Armed Forces. The security and defense White Paper alone would strengthen the CSDP and increase the capabilities of the European Union, as well as being cost effective. I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The EU needs to reflect about its defence policy in the long term. I supported this report, due to the fact that current increasing security challenges and complexities make this defence policy a more pertinent task. The level of EU ambitions in the area of defence need to significantly increase and be coupled with political will at the highest level to unleash the potential of the Treaties (i.e. permanent structured cooperation) in this regard. This will help to ensure long-term security of the EU and its citizens.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support the report on the European Defense Union and I believe that the time has come for the Member States to sit down and agree and define a clear position on this issue. Without repeating the danger and importance of a coordinated approach to security challenges, which I consider to be well defined in the text, I must point out one important item that I consider to be clearly defined, and that is the institution building of failed states. The European Union must define clear foreign policy objectives and act accordingly. Our mission must be to build post-conflict societies, mediate between warring parties and promote European values ​​of democracy and respect for human rights. I think that part should be incorporated into the text of the report. The growing instability and insecurity of the European Union's alliance with the great world powers calls for the necessary revision not only of defense policy, but of the Union's wider foreign policy, which is incoherent and inconsistent. The establishment of the European Defense Community is a clear and important step forward in strengthening the independence and capacity of the European Union in the field of defense and security, and I welcome what has been said in this report.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- The European defense policy is a sea serpent of European construction which is based, by its own admission, on NATO.It should be remembered that it was the main cause recorded by Sarkozy for the return of France to the Integrated Command.This consubstantial link is also assumed by the text (points 3, 36, 37 and 38) and betrays the real nature of the UED which is the provision of supplementary troops for those who have a military tool still capable ofother powers (which, without Great Britain, will soon only be the case for France, although it has an army in disrepair).I defend the national independence of my country, which has gone through total control of its defense policy.I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - I supported this report because the European Union must develop cooperation in the field of the common security and defense policy and equip itself with an autonomous defense capability, to be able to protect its citizens and promote its values ​​and interests, in the full respect for treaties, international law and human rights. In recent years, the security situation on Europe's borders has deteriorated considerably, giving rise to crises that no Member State is capable of facing and managing alone.
