The external action of the Union to prevent and put an end to armed conflicts and continuous violations of human rights, to spread democracy and the rule of law, to effectively combat terrorism, also requires the possibility of rapidly deploying military contingents , as required by Article 42 of the TEU. This development of EU capabilities must be achieved in a way that is complementary and compatible with NATO's objectives, resulting in mutual reinforcement and more effective joint action. Finally, overcoming the duplication due to the existence of 28 national armies and obstacles in the defense procurement sector would free up economic resources estimated at € 26.4 billion per year, which could be better used elsewhere.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The creation of a common Union defense policy is essential for the EU to promote the rule of law, peace and security at global level. I therefore call on the Member States to unleash the full potential of the Lisbon Treaty in terms of defense and security policy, especially in terms of permanent structured cooperation. A truly strong European Defense Union can offer Member States guarantees and capacities greater than they have, which is particularly necessary due to the deteriorating security environment at the European Union's borders. The Agency's strong role is essential for the effective coordination of programs and projects and the establishment of a common European capacity and armaments policy, avoiding duplication and reducing costs. I welcome the joint statement of the President of the European Council and the European Commission and the Secretary General of NATO from July 2016, which emphasizes the need for cooperation in the field of security and defense. I call on the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to launch a White Paper on EU security and defense based on the EU's global strategy. I therefore ask the Council to assign the task of drafting that document without delay. I would also like to emphasize cybersecurity - cooperation and integration are crucial here, not only between EU Member States, key partners and NATO, but also various social actors, because it is not just about military responsibility.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The report defends the development of its military capabilities to intervene in any situation inside or outside the borders, under the pretext of the deterioration of security in Europe, the fight against terrorism and the “threats” that come from the south (radical Islamic groups) and east (Russia). The report also consolidates the EU as NATO's European military pillar, contributing to its strengthening and cooperation. But the intention to assert itself as a military bloc with aspirations to replace NATO in certain circumstances is still evident. He defends the increase in defense budget expenditure, dedicating 2% of GDP to this end. Further cooperation and financing is proposed for the development of the industrial sector and military research, promoting a common armaments policy. It advocates the creation of a European army, the deepening of the Common Security and Defense Policy and the deepening of the European Defense Agency. A brief summary of the intentions that the majority of the right and social democracy in the EP approved, reinforcing the EU's security and militaristic vision, and its aggressive, warlike, interventionist and predatory character. Policies that impose fear, war and destruction, contrary to peace and cooperation policies between sovereign states. We voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- Security is currently the number one issue in Europe.Following the conclusions of the Bratislava Summit, this report supports the idea of creating a European Defense Union so that Europe can respond quickly and effectively to threats and protect the interests of its citizens with sufficient vigor.This report supports the launch of permanent structured cooperation between EU countries in the field of defense, supports the creation of an EU operational headquarters, increases support for the defense industry.At the same time, Member States should commit to spending at least 2% of GDP on defense.I believe that there is a need to face the growing threat of terrorism and the deteriorating overall security situation in and around Europe.We cannot ignore geopolitical developments.In my opinion, the creation of a European Defense Union is the right step, although there will certainly be far-reaching debates about its implementation and final form.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- This report highlights the importance of the White Paper on security and defense based on the EU global strategy.Finally, within the EU it seems that we are realizing that without a common defense policy we would not be able to implement a foreign policy capable of fully defending European interests on the international stage.To achieve a common defense it is first of all necessary to promote and strengthen a common defense industry on a continental scale.Only in this way could we reach the highest technological standards, compete with the new emerging military forces, such as China, and equip ourselves with operating systems independent of the American ones.In this sector, Italy can play a leading role and in my opinion it should, together with France, lead the European Defense Union.I voted in favor of adopting this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- The growing and unprecedented security threats facing Europe have led to growing voices in some quarters calling for closer defense cooperation between EU Member States and some arguing that this cooperation should take the form of a formal uniondefense.I believe that defense cooperation and cooperation in the development of defense capabilities in the EU should remain voluntary and not lead to duplication of NATO defense planning.This applies in particular to the issues of defense planning, sustainable development of defense industry cooperation and building defense capabilities in all Member States.That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- The European Union is under constant threat from terrorism and attacks of all kinds.In the face of this climate of insecurity, we have no other choice but to act to strengthen cooperation between states in matters of security and defense.That is why, I have come out in favor of this report, it is important that the armed forces of the Member States collaborate more closely on this matter.Parliament is now calling on Member States to devote 2% of their GDP to defense in order to consolidate our forces to act faster and more firmly against real threats.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing.- The security situation in the Union and neighboring states has worsened significantly and created difficult challenges that cannot be tackled in isolation.Thus, the principle of solidarity requires the EU to act in concert with our allies and partners and third countries.I recall that cybersecurity is also an area of action in which cooperation and integration are crucial, not only between Member States, but also within NATO, and also between different actors in society, since it is not a question ofonly military responsibility.According to Eurobarometer 85.1 of June 2016, around two thirds of citizens would like to see greater EU involvement in security and defense policy issues, with internal and external security increasingly blurred.For the above, I support this report.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up.- I believe that the establishment of a European Defense Union in the current political context in which the EU finds itself is not an effective security solution.On the contrary, it involves huge logistical costs.At the same time, its objectives do not coincide with the reality facing the EU.The only politico-military concept that can provide real guarantees of security is the North Atlantic Treaty.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. We are concerned by the increasing move towards EU military capability and its potential negative impact on UK foreign policy interests. NATO is and should remain the primary guarantor of security in Europe. Any development of EU foreign policy or defence capability risks undermining this.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - With 369 votes against, 255 votes in favor and 70 abstentions, this afternoon, Parliament asked the Council for the means of a genuine European defense policy. The current geopolitical situation, terrorist threats, but also the cost of non-Europe in this area (26 billion euros per year) make a Defense Union more necessary than ever. A recent poll shows that 66% of Europeans (63% of Belgians) want the Union to do more in this area. Three weeks before a European summit devoted to this issue, the report voted on today gives very clear directions to the Council. Member states should devote at least 2% of their GDP to defense, and establish multinational forces and a European headquarters to plan and command crisis management operations. Equally important, especially in terms of employment and economies of scale, is to create the conditions for a Schengen military area and to develop a European defense industry. The Union must also work to better complement NATO's action, and be prepared to take its place when it does not wish to engage. All of this is essential and should give rise to an in-depth review of the common security and defense policy.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- I am skeptical about the proposal to establish a European Defense Union.Primarily because this alliance is seen as an alternative to NATO.Unfortunately, any deeper analysis will show that we have no alternative to NATO and the transatlantic partnership.Neither technological nor military.I would like to remind you that a similar initiative more than 60 years ago ended in a fiasco.Instead of building new and dubiously effective structures, I would suggest investing more in strengthening existing transatlantic ties and increasing my military capabilities.To do exactly what my country, Lithuania, is doing at the moment.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - This report deals with the need to strengthen European defense cooperation, an old dream of the European Union (EU) since the Pleven Plan. Insecurity in Europe and in neighboring countries has deteriorated exponentially in recent years, creating a set of new challenges that need to be tackled collectively. I therefore endorse the need to strengthen collaboration and cooperation between the European armed forces, in particular through some of the recommendations presented with a view to combating terrorism and the various daily threats to the security of citizens more effectively. The proposals for the creation of a European headquarters, a European defense semester, a minimum investment of 2% of GDP by the Member States for Defense are somewhat controversial and do not generate unanimous opinion within the European Parliament. However, all of them are ambitious proposals, which deserve reflection, being the subject of negotiations until we reach a more consensual result, which favors collective security in Europe. I also endorse the idea of ​​carrying out a thorough review of the Common Security and Defense Policy, which will allow the EU and the Member States to contribute more to the security of the Union as a whole, affirming its strategic autonomy in this area.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which calls for greater EU defense cooperation. The Union needs to react faster and more firmly to current threats. For this, the European armed forces must cooperate more closely. Cyber ​​insecurity and terrorism are forcing the States of the Union, now more than ever, to step up their cooperation efforts in the field of security and defense. This text therefore calls on states to devote 2% of their GDP to defense as well as to the establishment of a European headquarters in order to plan and order crisis management operations. The Union and NATO must also cooperate more to combat hybrid threats and to develop defense capabilities. On the other hand, the Union must be able to act autonomously in cases where NATO is unable to respond to security crises. Finally, I supported this text because it calls for the establishment of real European support for defense research. The European Union urgently needs to adopt a stronger common defense policy with greater resources in order to guarantee European citizens their security.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted against this report on the European Defense Union, because it proposes to give the Union greater strategic autonomy in defense policies and greater coordination, but it does so by proposing measures that in no way guarantee reaching solutions to problemssecurity that exist globally.The report calls for specific resources to be earmarked for military cooperation between member states, to create a European Defense Union, beyond the Common Security and Defense Policy, to convene meetings at European level of Defense Ministers, and to create a headquarters ofthe Union, among other measures.None of these measures is aimed at solving the causes that cause threats to security in the Union, much less contribute to generating a framework of stability, cooperation and peace between the countries.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on roll-call votes on the European Defence Union report, and voted against the overall report for this reason: Malta is a neutral country. Its Constitution prohibits participation in military alliances and in international cooperative efforts promoting warfare capabilities and exercises, unless backed by the UN. The report is based on premises for EU action that contradict this commitment. Moreover, I disagree that, at this time especially, the EU should reinforce a military dimension to its character. This move might appear suitable to counter the supposedly disintegrating effects of Brexit. It could have the opposite effect. There is no popular constituency for a European Union that morphs into a military coalition, funded from EU budgetary resources. Again, we see the old ‘business as usual’ methods by which ‘small’ steps ‘forward’ are cumulated and then presented as requiring further integration, failing which disaster would ensue. This is not an acceptable way in which to forge unity in Europe. I abstained on all subsidiary roll-call votes because it would not have been coherent to vote one way or the other on different aspects of the issues at hand, while voting against the overall concept.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted for the report on the European Defense Union.The report is based on an initiative of the EPP and is the follow-up report in the field of defense to the global EU strategy.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - The aim of this report is to develop common projects, and the money contributed is expected to mobilize up to € 5 billion a year from 2017. In addition, it is intended to promote research and development in military projects. Until now, community spending on innovation excluded military uses, but in 2017 25 million will be allocated and from 2020, 500 million a year are expected. I have rejected this report that seeks to strengthen the security and militarist perspective and, which requires States to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, when the European population sinks more and more into misery and unemployment (the data shows us they say that in the Spanish State 1 out of 5 households are below the poverty line, and unemployment is close to 4 million unemployed). What the States should do is increase social investment and job creation, not contribute to militaristic escalation. According to Article 41 (2) of the TEU there can be no military financing from the Union budget. My vote against this report from the opposite and militaristic line.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this, as this is a blatant plan to start an EU Army.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - The current situation in Europe and its close neighborhood, as well as the rapidly advancing globalization, force a change of approach in many areas, including the area of ​​external and internal security. This applies to both the common foreign and security policy and the protection of external borders. The proper functioning of the EU internal market and responsible behavior of the Member States obliged to implement common provisions are of great importance for the proper functioning and implementation of tasks assigned to the CSDP. It should be emphasized that the defense market in Europe is very heterogeneous and fragmented, and most contracts are still concluded at national level. In this context, small and medium-sized enterprises have a lot to gain from a more transparent and open market, allowing them to participate in clearly structured tenders also in other Member States than where they are established. Better cooperation in the fight against terrorism and information sharing are also essential. Given the differences in defense capabilities, EU countries should all the more work to agree on a common approach in the context of hybrid threats, trafficking in human beings, intelligence, cybersecurity and customs controls. Security determines not only the inviolability of borders, but also the proper functioning of an integrated Europe.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing - I do not currently consider the creation of a European army to be entirely realistic, but I am in favor of strengthening defense cooperation within the EU, the capacity of which could be used to protect the external borders and thus deal with the migratory waves we face in Europe.Above all, however, I am in defense policy for continuing cooperation within NATO.I think that the EU Member States should retain a certain national sovereignty when it comes to defense policy.I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - The Union's security is one of the five top priorities of the EU's Global Strategy for Foreign and Security Policy. As the security situation in and around Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent years, I think it is right for the EU to become more involved in security and defense policy matters. Although I believe that the European Defense Union (EOU) is essential for the EU to be able to uphold the rule of law, peace and security globally, I did not support the motion for a resolution because the amendments passed to move defense and security funding from Eurofunds for regional development. I agree that the EU, in situations of real threat, should act more vigorously and swiftly in cooperation with our allies and partners and third countries. I believe that by gradually shaping the common defense policy and modern military capabilities, we will ensure the long-term security of Europe. I expect that, in the interests of the current financial and security situation, the EU will make a much greater effort to ensure that the European Armed Forces cooperates more closely and that military personnel train and cooperate more and better. I will also expect the European Council (ER) to advocate for the progressive framing of a common defense policy and to provide additional financial resources for its implementation from sources other than the Structural Funds.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's own-initiative report on the European Defense Union, whose rapporteur was former Estonian Foreign Minister Urmas Paet. I believe that security and defense are precisely the common task that citizens expect the European Union to fulfill. At the same time, it is the area that is most sensitive to Member States due to many factors. Given the current security threats in the European neighborhood, it is therefore more than necessary to address the issue of common defense. The possible weakening of NATO due to a change in priorities by the new US administration also encourages us to think more about its military capabilities and budgets (the goal is a level of defense spending of 2% of GDP). The legal basis for the Defense Union is provided by the Treaty of Lisbon, with the possibility of permanent structured cooperation and funds that have not yet been fully utilized. The resolution recalls most aspects of defense policy, from the institutional framework, to strengthening the interoperability of the armed forces, to previously marginal but now important elements, such as defense against cyber attacks. He also does not forget NATO's key role, although he is working with the idea that Europe will have to take more care of itself in this regard. The resolution clearly calls for the strengthening of mutual defense and overall solidarity in the event of an attack.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing.- I do not think that this report has the most systematic approach to the European Defense Union.The rapporteur could be more systematic in terms of taking into account the things that have been achieved and done in this area so far.As an example, the report does not even provide a precise definition of what the European Defense Union is and what it means in the light of developments in this area in 2016. I see the report as a kind of list of everything that can be linked and associated with military and defensetopics at European level.Among other things, the report provides a concept for the development of territorial defense policy at EU level and a European army to be supported and financed by all Member States.In addition, the report touches on drones and funding for military research at EU level.As I find this problematic and the report covers too many aspects that are not actually within its remit, I abstained from voting on the report.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - A common security and defense policy (CSDP) is high on the European agenda, but it is difficult to reach agreement between the different Member States and political families. Every report on this gets bogged down in an endless enumeration of everything that has to do with military or defense affairs from close or far. It looks like a letter to Sinterklaas. Sometimes we see the contours of a European army emerging, then the desire to increase the defense budget so that there is money to invest in drones or military research. However, there is always no clear vision of defense and security for the outside world or the foreign embassies. It is therefore difficult to agree to such a report. Green wants a common security and defense policy to focus on humanitarian missions, peacekeeping and crisis management, rather than warfare and the defense of our homeland. Instead of increasing the budget for defense, we would look more closely at how we can use the annual 200 billion euros more efficiently: by jointly procuring, conducting joint military research and above all increasing transparency in the 'military market' by to respect European public procurement rules. But this falls on deaf ears for many.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation in the field of defense at European level.The EU member states should cooperate more closely, spend more money on defense and launch new security and defense initiatives on the part of the EU.In the opinion of the ECR Group, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures within the framework of the Common Security and Defense Policy of the EU (CSDP) is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully applied within the framework of a European super-state.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - In the context of a deteriorating geopolitical situation, Europe needs to cooperate more in the field of security and defense policy.Apart from the creation of the European Defense Agency (EDA), little has been done under the EU's common security and defense policy.Parliament therefore calls on the Member States to make commitments that would lead to the gradual formation of a European Defense Union.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - This report came from the Subcommittee on Defense and Security, of which I am Vice-Chair. It defines the essence, legal context and future steps towards the gradual creation of a European Defense Union. I support this idea. I am convinced that it will significantly strengthen Europe's ability to promote security within and outside its borders. Taking more of the responsibility for one's own security is crucial at a time of new global challenges surrounding us. The strategic independence of the EU requires, in addition to a range of policy instruments, a strong and modern military capability. The imperative is to create a framework for a European Defense Union in full cooperation with NATO. It must lead to more effective cooperation, fair burden-sharing and a meaningful division of labor between NATO and the EU. The Defense Union will not be born overnight. I consider the immediate steps in this direction to be immediate: the launch of a proper White Paper on Security and Defense process, the establishment of a permanent Council of Defense Ministers format and a review of the Athena mechanism so that the EU mission funds the Union from common resources. Member States should, in the framework of permanent structured cooperation (PESCO), establish a multinational force to be available for CSDP purposes to maintain peace, prevent conflicts and strengthen international security. The level of defense spending should reach 2% of GDP, of which 20% is the equipment budget. A permanent headquarters for the command and control of military CSDP operations should be established.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report as it offers ideas which could duplicate the work of NATO or interfere in what should be a Member State competence.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- The EU is to be upgraded to a military power under Brussels high command.The EU army is coming.That was decided by the EU Parliament in this resolution.While the community managed without its own army in the decades of the Cold War, the "EU Peace Project" is now rattling its saber and gearing up for its own EU army at the very moment when the designated US President Donald Trump settles the Cold War andstrives for a compromise with Russia.The EU cannot agree on the simplest things, but Commander-in-Chief Juncker should command an intervention army?May Heaven save us from that!I voted against this resolution.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The EU needs to think about its defense policy in the long run.A step-by-step strategy is needed to establish a European Defense Union.The European Council is called upon to take concrete steps towards the harmonization and standardization of the European Armed Forces with a view to better cooperation within the new European Defense Union.A permanent Council of Defense Ministers needs to be established and the concept of EU battle groups needs to be reformed with a view to establishing permanent units that are independent of any leading country and have systematic joint training and exercises.The strategic autonomy and shaping of the European Defense Union must be achieved in full synergy with NATO and must lead to more effective cooperation, a fair burden-sharing and a productive division of labor between NATO and the EU.I support this Report because the deterioration of the security environment at the eastern and southern borders of the European Union requires the urgent establishment of a European Defense Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union.In Europe, we have recently been confronted with rapidly changing security conditions both inside and around us.With the deterioration of the security situation, we have thus faced new challenges to which we must find the right answers.I support the development of a common Union defense policy and the provision of additional funding for its implementation.I support the opinion of the Committee on Budgets, which calls for more ambitious civilian missions that are better integrated into the policy cycle and available instruments and aligned with the overall objectives of EU foreign policy, while promoting EU values such as peace, security and respect for human rights.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I supported today's European Parliament report on the European Defense Union, as I believe that, in the current context, further work is needed on the Common European Defense project to move towards a much greater contribution to global security and strengthening its capabilities in terms ofgreater capacity for action of its units, but also in terms of cooperation in science and research.If these efforts are rightly emphasized to be fully compatible with NATO, it will not be a weakening of NATO, but rather a strengthening of NATO.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The report follows the logic of EU militarization. It promotes the goal of the European Union developing its military capabilities so that it is ready to intervene in any situation inside or outside its borders. The European Defense Union also seeks to contribute to strengthening NATO's work. It also calls for the creation of a start-up fund for pre-military operations, as well as for strengthening the European Union's co-operation with NATO. For these reasons we voted against the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- Once again, the EU is proving its allegiance to NATO and the United States by faithfully following their mandates, even when they run counter to the interests of the peoples and nations of Europe.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the unprecedented challenges alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. To guarantee its long-term security, Europe needs political will and determination. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, so I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the decision based on the parliamentary report in favor of the creation of a European Defense Union. I believe that there are objective conditions for creating a greater degree of defense autonomy for Europe: the EU could, in principle, be the strongest defense alliance in the world, adding together the existing capabilities of each Member State. And from a military and economic point of view, the mass of overlaps and parallels would clearly require the coordination of capabilities and assets, with the goal of “more security for less money”. The series of political decisions taken under the Lisbon Treaty and the CSDP also provide the necessary legal basis for the completion of EU solidarity in the field of defense, including in the framework of the CSDP and the EDU. The political and military necessity of EDU was created by the deteriorating security environment of the EU over the years, new types of security challenges, terrorist, cyber and hybrid threats, and above all the military-political threat in our immediate southern and eastern neighborhood. I believe that, in addition to setting out these reasons, the report also contains useful organizational and legislative proposals for the creation of a Defense Union. I am convinced that the current resolution and further political and legislative activity of the EP will make a decisive contribution to building the political will needed at EU level.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - In recent years, the level of security in the vicinity of the European Union has deteriorated significantly. In the face of so many threats, no country or organization is able to ensure the security of its citizens on its own. It is high time, then, for the Community to start building its own defense system. The results of the presidential elections in the USA and calls for increased involvement of other member states within NATO have made the even more urgent need to build European defense capabilities. In order to build a defense union, it is necessary to better coordinate the military capabilities of individual countries, increase defense funding or involve the EU budget in financing joint armed forces or defense research and development. The report rightly notes that the next financial framework after 2020 should include financial support for the creation of the European Defense Union. Stepping up European defense cooperation would contribute to increasing effectiveness, unity and efficiency, as well as increasing EU assets and capabilities, and would have a potential positive impact on defense research and the EU industry. Undoubtedly, the establishment of permanent structured cooperation within the Union would give impetus to the search for new opportunities for joint purchases, maintenance and maintenance of armed forces between Member States.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: written.- I voted against the report on the European Defense Union.European countries need to step up cooperation in the EU's foreign and security policy, including in the fight against terrorism and the development of a common defense equipment market.I supported these issues when voting on the report.The proposals in the report went too far in many respects.I believe that the Member States must be free to choose their own defense solutions according to their own starting points, and the EU must not take steps towards a common defense union.This takes decision-making power away from the Member States and does not contribute to Finland's overall security.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - In the context of certain negative phenomena, such as terrorism and illegal immigration, increasingly threaten the security of the European Union, and their sources are to be found in conflicts near Community borders, there is a need to strengthen the Security Policy and Common Defense (CSDP). This is all the more so as the new Washington administration could change the support it currently gives to European defense, which would be a critical vulnerability for Member States. In these circumstances, coordinated measures to strengthen security, including military security, should be adopted at Union level. One of these measures could be to activate Permanent Structured Cooperation, including by setting up a stand-alone committee on security and defense in Parliament. An EU operational center could also be set up and the European defense industry could be encouraged. In this way, existing EU missions could be better coordinated and the necessary action taken more quickly and efficiently. However, all this must take into account the European treaties, as well as the rules of international law and human rights. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for the Paet report.I also think that a European defense is a good thing to bring more coherence and also to allow certain Member States to lower their military budgets in favor of an efficient Union army.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ As of recent, the EU has committed to establishing a European defence dimension. This recent development, after years of indecision, is the result of the growing instability and threats both from outside and within the EU borders. I voted in favour of the report on the EDU, which will produce the early steps toward a military union. I strongly believe that 2016 was a trying year for Europe and it is now time that the EU commits itself to developing the competences required to autonomously defend its territory and those surrounding it from threats such as illegal migratory flows, terrorism and human smuggling, among other nefarious threats.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - This report takes place against a background of strong and pressing tensions at the gates of the European Union. The world is more unstable than in previous decades and austerity policies have reduced the leeway of national budgets. We must re-examine our defense policies. As in other areas, the cost of non-Europe in terms of defense - that is, the lack of pooling and coordination at European level - is high. It is valued at 26 billion euros per year. An integrated defense policy would be more relevant to protect Europeans. This report proposes progress in the direction of pooling and European cooperation, such as the creation of a military and civilian headquarters and the development of permanent structured cooperation in the field of defense. It also establishes lines of convergence between national defense policies. I approved this report, which marks a step forward for Defense Europe.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- The European Union is facing the threat of terrorism on its own soil and in the rest of the world and the growing instability in Africa and the Middle East is increasingly evident.I believe that collaboration with third countries on sensitive data, energy and cyber security, the fight against organized crime and cooperation between the armed forces are the great challenges facing the European institutions.According to recent studies, two thirds of the European population is asking for a greater commitment of the institutions in the common security and defense policy.I believe it is important for the European Council to promote the definition of a defense policy at Union level, as required by Article 42 of the TEU, for the safety of the citizen but also to respond to today's challenges.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: in writing. - The security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly in recent times. Currently, terrorism, hybrid threats, economic volatility, cyber and energy insecurity, organized crime and climate change are the main security threats. No Member State or organization can tackle the new challenges on an unprecedented scale alone. In this situation, the EU must do everything in its power to find the means to guarantee security. The report emphasizes that Europe needs political will and determination to guarantee its long-term security. It also urges the EU Member States to make use of the possibilities offered by the Lisbon Treaty with regard to the Common Security and Defense Policy (CSDP), in particular with regard to permanent structured cooperation. The Defense Union must receive effective funding and coordinate it with NATO. In addition, a meeting of defense ministers should be set up within the Council to ensure permanent political leadership and coordinate the establishment of a European Defense Union. The increasingly negative perception of risks and threats in Europe makes the creation of a European Defense Union urgent. This is particularly due to the deteriorating security of the European Union's borders, especially at its borders with its eastern and southern neighbors. This report is in line with the Hungarian position, so I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the Motion for a resolution on the European Defense Union. I am of the opinion that Europe needs a strong European Defense Union that will offer Member States guarantees and capacities greater than they have. The European Union should devote its own resources to supporting stronger and more systematic European defense cooperation among its Member States, including ongoing structured cooperation. I am convinced that the use of EU funds would clearly demonstrate cohesion and solidarity, thus enabling all Member States to improve their military capabilities through more intensive joint efforts. In addition, the activation of the military industry for the purpose of creating a European Defense Union would activate the rise of economic development of all member states by employing the population in various manufacturing sectors. In addition to bringing security, which is essential in today's modern world, the European Defense Union would also contribute to the economic progress of the Member States.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I voted against, because I firmly believe that competence over defense policy must always be and remain within the competence of nation states as the foundation of national sovereignty.In this regard, I support NATO as the basis for defense and security cooperation between the European Union and the transatlantic allies.Therefore, I strongly oppose the proposals, which are becoming louder at the level of the European Union, and which call for the establishment of the European Union army and, in this connection, expensive military structures.In my opinion, the above proposal, apart from the financial loss, could only result in an irreparable loss of trust of the former NATO allies and thus significantly weaken ties with our international defense partners.All the more so as we live in times of extreme insecurity, constant terrorist threats and regional conflicts around the world.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the European Defense Union. The resolution takes note of the fact that the security situation in and around Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent years. Terrorism, hybrid threats, economic fluctuations, lack of cyber and energy security, organized crime and climate change are more security threats. Article 42 of the EU Treaty requires the gradual development of a common Union defense policy within the framework of the common security and defense policy, which will lead to a common EU defense (this article also provides for the establishment of defense institutions and a European capability and armaments policy). To date, none of the other missing elements of the EU's Common Security and Defense Policy have been designed, concluded or implemented, with the exception of the establishment of the European Defense Agency. The EU-level White Paper on Security and Defense will further strengthen the CSDP Common Security and Defense Policy and the EU's capacity to provide security under the Lisbon Treaty, and could be a useful reflection on a future and more effective CSDP, but could also be a unique opportunity to propose additional measures.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report on the European Defense Union, because it proposes to give the Union greater strategic autonomy in defense policies and greater coordination, but it does so by proposing measures that in no way guarantee reaching solutions to problemssecurity that exist globally.The report calls for specific resources to be earmarked for military cooperation between member states, to create a European Defense Union, beyond the Common Security and Defense Policy, to convene meetings at European level of Defense Ministers, and to create a headquarters ofthe Union, among other measures.None of these measures is aimed at solving the causes that cause threats to security in the Union, much less contribute to generating a framework of stability, cooperation and peace between the countries.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation in the field of defense at European level.The EU member states should cooperate more closely, spend more money on defense and launch new security and defense initiatives on the part of the EU.In the opinion of the ECR Group, defense is a matter for the individual nation states.In addition, as a defense alliance, NATO ensures the security of Europe.A competitive situation with new European security structures within the framework of the Common Security and Defense Policy of the EU (CSDP) is to be rejected, especially since the decision-making powers at the CSDP are unclear and - if they are to work - could only be fully applied within the framework of a European super-state.For this reason I reject the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the vision of a European Defence army. I believe that it makes sense in a global world to have  a strong European voice, it will be more cost-efficient than national army structures.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This is one of the many reports made to take advantage of Brexit in an attempt to revive European defense policy.European defense policy is a 15-year-old sea serpent which, by its own admission, is based on NATO.It should be remembered that it was the main cause approved by Sarkozy for the return of France to the Integrated Command.This consubstantial link is also assumed by the text (points 3, 36, 37 and 38) and betrays the real nature of the UED which is the provision of supplementary troops for those who have a military tool still capable ofother powers (which without Great Britain will soon only be the case for France with an army in the process of decay).I voted logically against this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The idea of creating the so-calledThe European Defense Union should be subject to deeper discussion and reflection.I have argued many times that prejudices against the European Defense Union must be overcome, but it should deal with a few fundamental issues, such as strengthening the industrial base, improving the mobility system for military personnel, equipment, etc. It is good that these matters are addressed in the text of the resolution.Unfortunately, on the other hand, the proposal includes unnecessary demands, leading to the EUO indirectly taking over NATO's competences.The European Defense Union should be established on the basis of the troops or services of the Member States, so that it still guarantees the sovereignty of the Member States.I therefore abstained from voting on this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- In recent years, the security situation, both within Europe and in the surrounding region, has deteriorated significantly, presenting difficult, unprecedented challenges that no country or organization can face alone.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against this report on the European Defense Union, because it proposes to give the Union greater strategic autonomy in defense policies and greater coordination, but it does so by proposing measures that in no way guarantee reaching solutions to problemssecurity that exist globally.The report calls for specific resources to be earmarked for military cooperation between member states, to create a European Defense Union, beyond the Common Security and Defense Policy, to convene meetings at European level of Defense Ministers, and to create a headquarters ofthe Union, among other measures.None of these measures is aimed at solving the causes that cause threats to security in the Union, much less contribute to generating a framework of stability, cooperation and peace between the countries.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I believe that more European defense cooperation would lead to greater efficiency, unity, efficiency, as well as an increase in the EU's defense assets and capabilities, and could have a positive impact on the aspects of defense research and industry.I emphasize that only through such enhanced cooperation, which should gradually develop into a genuine European Defense Union, will the EU and its Member States be able to acquire the technological and industrial capabilities needed to respond more quickly, autonomously and effectively and to address today's threats in a targeted and effective way.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the European Defence Union. Terrorism, hybrid threats and cyber and energy insecurity leave EU countries no choice but to step up their security and defence cooperation efforts. The security situation in and around Europe has worsened significantly in recent years, due to challenges like terrorism, hybrid threats or cyber and energy insecurity, that no country is able to tackle alone. The EU has to respond faster and more robustly to real threats, which demand that Europe’s armed forces work together better. I voted in favour because I believe that solidarity and resilience require the EU to stand and act together.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - This report is part of an initiative of the PPE group in the Security and Defense Subcommittee in response to the degradation of security that is taking place in our neighborhood, which obliges the Member States to take joint actions, especially in the fight against terrorism. For these to be effective, it is necessary to alleviate the shortcomings in the development of security and defense capabilities and deepen the possibility established by Article 42 of the TEU, which provides for progress towards a common defense of the Union. The text considers that all resources should be mobilized to make defense cooperation systematic, in particular through Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO). In relation to EU-NATO cooperation, the document highlights the need for it to be closer, as this will improve synergies and the compatibility of both frameworks and will allow more benefit from investment in defense. In the belief that the Union must provide a more solid framework for its defense policy in the long term, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - Europe faces unprecedented threats and challenges since the end of the Second World War. We Socialists have supported the Union's continuous progress towards integration, security and defense being one of the main challenges to face. For this reason, we support progress in the direction of a European Defense Union, as an "umbrella" structure to bring together, improve and coordinate the preventive and reactive military capabilities available to the Union. We defend a European Defense Union that guarantees the maintenance of peace, the prevention of conflicts and the reinforcement of international security, in accordance with the principles of the United Nations Charter. For this, we need the Member States to commit to moving forward through permanent structured cooperation, ensuring reactive capacity and trained personnel, as well as sufficient means. Our main objective is clear: the security of our citizens, but not only with a security vision, but through a global approach of respect for fundamental rights and the fight against social and cultural inequalities.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - The aim of this report is to develop common projects, and the money contributed is expected to mobilize up to € 5 billion a year from 2017. In addition, it is intended to promote research and development in military projects. Until now, community spending on innovation excluded military uses, but in 2017 25 million will be allocated and from 2020, 500 million a year are expected. I have rejected this report that seeks to strengthen the security and militarist perspective and, which requires States to allocate 2% of GDP to defense, when the European population sinks more and more into misery and unemployment (the data shows us they say that in the Spanish State 1 out of 5 households are below the poverty line, and unemployment is close to 4 million unemployed). What the States should do is increase social investment and job creation, not contribute to militaristic escalation. According to Article 41 (2) of the TEU there can be no military financing from the Union budget. My vote against this report from the opposite and militaristic line.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: in writing. – The ECR Group is firmly against EU ambitions for separate and duplicative defence structures that would not only be a dangerous distraction from the revitalisation of NATO but would also send confusing signals to our potential enemies. This is reflected in our votes against the Report on European Defence Union. We only voted in favour of paragraph 36 of the report because if its central message concerning the need for more national investment in defence and defence industrial capability. We do not agree with any language in this paragraph that supports CSDP or other such EU political ambitions.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor because the security situation in and around Europe has deteriorated significantly in recent years, creating difficult and unseen challenges that no country and no organization can face alone.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written.- I voted against the report on the European Defense Union.European countries need to step up cooperation in the EU's foreign and security policy, including in the fight against terrorism and the development of a common defense equipment market.I supported these issues when voting on the report.The proposals in the report went too far in many respects.I believe that the Member States must be free to choose their own defense solutions according to their own starting points, and the EU must not take steps towards a common defense union.This takes decision-making power away from the Member States and does not contribute to Finland's overall security.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - This resolution on the European Defense Union is in line with the current trend of the Union to strengthen security and interventionist policies. In a way, this is the continuation of the responses announced by certain Member States, including France after Brexit. The text calls for strengthening the links between the "European Defense Union" and NATO with a view to remilitarization through massive investments in armaments. While the needs are increasingly glaring for investments especially in the social field, it seems to me aberrant to encourage a militarist policy for the benefit of the armaments industry. This is not the answer that European citizens expect. So where have the original aspirations of the Union to promote peace gone? There is more to be done and more urgent than fueling international tensions through rearmament. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This report confirms the militaristic and warlike nature of the EU. The justifications, the usual. Insecurity on European soil or the alleged fight against terrorism, without any reference to the absolute failure of integration policies, or to what were and are the EU's responsibilities in aggression against countries in North Africa and the Middle East, as well as in promoting , financing, training and armament of extremist groups. Nor are the supposed threats from the East lacking to justify the siege of the Russian Federation. Subservience to NATO and its objectives, such as raising Member States' military budgets to 2% of GDP, and increasing funding for military research and the military industry on European soil, does not hide the pretensions of having a large military bloc, with its own operational capabilities, namely through a European army. Whoever makes war and feeds his industry neither wants nor can defend peace.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written. - The report relates to the creation of a common European defense union, which is to come into effect within the framework of the CSDP, which was laid down in the Lisbon Treaty. In doing so, the defense forces of the member states are to be provided through financial upgrading B. be prepared for these within the framework of the European Semester or in the research area by EDA funds. The program should also appear in the MFF and be taken into account. More intensive cooperation with NATO and s. G. Peace missions are designed to strengthen the experience of the troops. The European Defense Union is to start from a fundamental revision of the CSDP, which is to be determined by the principle of a strong collective defense and to go hand in hand with "efficient financing and coordination" with NATO. It is certainly desirable to have an efficient and powerful defense force, which is deployed primarily at the borders and thus means overall coordination of all European armed forces. The drawback, however, remains that it is unclear who will actually be in command of this armed force - NATO, Commission? I find the close ties (also financially) to NATO very questionable. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Defense Union.I believe it is necessary to support developments in the field of the common security and defense policy and encourage the achievement of autonomous defense capabilities for the EU, in order to protect its citizens and promote its values and interests in full compliance with the treaties, the lawinternational and human rights.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted against the report as it strays into Member State competence. Whilst European defence cooperation is increasingly important given the turbulent geopolitical environment we find ourselves in, we must remember that the EU is above all a project of peace.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that in Europe a stronger security must be ensured. I agree with the idea of creating a recurrent Council-type meeting between the Ministers of Defence from each Member State, in order to sustain and coordinate better the Defence Union. Given the recent terrorist attacks, citizens in Europe are feeling more threatened than before. That is why the creation of a European Defence Union becomes very urgent.  The creation of this Union could also benefit SMEs, Europe’s defence industry and capabilities, allowing positive consequences for growth and jobs. I believe that key EU stakeholders and companies will have to be involved in the European defence industry. Since I am a strong supporter of research, I support the plan of creating an EU defence research programme. Technological innovation is fundamental in this context in order to reach a more efficient and effective use of the defence and security budgets of each Member State.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing - First of all, it must be borne in mind that the report adopted does not constitute a common army of the European Union, but is merely a necessary framework to guide such an initiative and to prepare the ground for the feasibility of such an intention in the future. I do not think that the EU is currently ready to have its own army, because the European identity of EU citizens is not at such a level that it can be a unifying element. The citizens of each Member State must first and foremost feel like the citizens of the European Union before the idea of ​​building a common European army makes sense. I supported this report because the common defense policy is extremely important today. The Union faces a number of internal as well as external challenges and unprecedented challenges. The countries' common position on defense is one of the answers to this situation. It is clear that the EU's long-term security cannot be done without political will. The Member States must make full use of the potential of the Treaty of Lisbon, especially in the area of ​​the common security and defense policy. To this end, a Council of Defense Ministers of the individual Member States should be set up to politically lead and coordinate the formation of the European Defense Union. Coordination with NATO, of which most member states are members, is also important.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I support this report because I believe that the European Union needs a common approach to defense policy.However, the governments and Member States have the main say and responsibility in this area.I therefore appreciate that the European Parliament is trying to put pressure on them and calling on them to keep the level of defense spending at 2% of GDP.I think that in the near future we should focus on the revision of the CSDP, which will be based precisely on better funding and better coordination between Member States.Personally, I also consider it important to improve cooperation with NATO, which should continue to be seen as a major pillar of collective security.I am convinced that, at the moment, there is not enough determination and will among the states to witness the creation of a European army in the near future.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - Faced with today's challenges, it cannot simply be said that Europe should cooperate better in the area of ​​defense and security - Europe must do so! The geopolitical situation forces the European Union countries to bear the burden of responsibility for their own security, and not only count on the help of the allied powers. We have to become one ourselves. We are an economic leader, but military strength must follow this. Mr Paet's report shows many good ideas on how to deepen defense cooperation in Europe within the European Union. The Treaty of Lisbon offers many solutions in this respect, such as the possibility of joint armaments planning or permanent structured cooperation (PESCO). The report also calls for better use of existing structures, such as the EU's Battle Groups or the European Defense Agency. These are initiatives worth supporting. The EU must not be afraid to take responsibility for security and the development of defense capabilities. The low level and unsatisfactory efficiency of defense spending in Europe indicate the need for change and a more collective approach to these important issues. Opinion polls show clearly - citizens want closer defense and security cooperation in Europe. This report is a signal that we want to move in this direction.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing.- I support the report on the European Defense Union.This is due to the fact that the European Union must react more decisively to emerging threats, such as terrorism, cyber attacks and energy security.What would be needed here would be not only better coordination of operations, but also the establishment of a joint operational command in order to use military resources more efficiently in the hands of individual Member States.A desirable solution is also the earmarking of funds for defense research in the EU budget.Unfortunately, this is not possible in the current legal model.This is one of the reasons why military technology in Europe is increasingly lagging behind countries such as the US and Russia, which spend billions of dollars on gaining a technological advantage.The proposed changes go in the desired direction, which is why I support this report.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I did not support the report on the European Defense Union. I understand that in the current growing security threats and ever new and new security challenges within the European Union, but especially in its neighborhood, there are strong voices calling for the creation of a formal security union. I can also identify with the calls for a more coordinated security policy or increased funding, and I am in favor of discussions on this issue. However, I think that the report presented goes too far. It calls for a definition of a defense union, a series of proposals that address a wide range of issues, from the movement of security equipment to calls for a White Paper on European Security and Defense. However, the report somehow does not mean that security and defense policy is and should always be the responsibility of the Member States. I am also more in favor of strengthening cooperation with NATO, rather than weakening it at the expense of a parallel defense structure.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Paet report, as I agree with the proposals made in the field of the common security and defense policy.I highlight my support for the development of an autonomous defense capacity on the part of the EU, with the aim of protecting its citizens and promoting their interests always in full compliance with the Treaties, international law and human rights.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written. - Strengthening the position on the need to create a European Defense Union comes at a time when the international foreign and security situation and the environment of the European Union are going through crises and instabilities that may result in a wider wave of destabilization. A coordinated approach to the many security challenges facing Member States in the immediate neighborhood, but also on their own territory, is crucial to ensure stability and a level of security throughout the Union. Reconsideration of European security and defense policy is important in light of recent events, especially the results of the US presidential election. The European Union must be able to defend itself against military and non-military threats. I support this report and hope that it will be a good basis for a future constructive discussion on the direction in which European defense and security capabilities will be developed. The European Union needs to develop a clear, consistent and consistent foreign policy, and the creation of a European Defense Community is one of the key steps in this process.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on the European Defense Union.The security situation in Europe and elsewhere has deteriorated sharply in recent years due to challenges such as terrorism, hybrid threats or a lack of cyber and energy security, to which no country can adequately respond alone.I agree that, in order to ensure long-term security and peace at global level, the EU needs the political will and determination to develop and implement a common security and defense policy in accordance with the Treaty of Lisbon, which is bound by international law.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, waterborne transport plays a central role in the development of a more efficient and sustainable European transport sector. I therefore support the recommendations of this report, given its identification of the extraordinary opportunity the geography of our Member States presents. In the combination of our common policies of safety, environment, trans-border cooperation, competition and accessibility, we may bolster more sustainable mobility across our Member States. I particularly appreciate that this would have a significant effect on the social and economic welfare of our citizens, whilst laying the ground for further development and innovation in this sector, and also with innovative developments help us in moving towards a low-carbon transport sector. This is vital in all areas: road, sea and air.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, as I mentioned in the debate in the Committee on Transport and Tourism regarding this report, it is a first step that has some positive points, but leaves unresolved some elements that are essential when building a good tourism policy. transportation. First, it doesn't specify; And it is not the same to speak of a mega cruise for mass tourists than to speak of a short-haul ferry that citizens use, that unites the territory and that energizes the local economy. Secondly, it is not the same to promote natural gas in producing countries as in Member States that not only do not have this resource, but would have to bring it across thousands of kilometers, building huge infrastructures and spending millions of public money that could be used in promote renewable energies of local generation and thus reduce the enormous energy dependence of the European Union. However, this report affects the introduction of gas in ports, without taking these considerations into account. For this we have voted against.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report focuses on water transport and presents some very interesting points.We are well aware that the Italian maritime transport system needs to be improved in some aspects and in the report, in fact, it is proposed to boost competitiveness and improve infrastructure.Furthermore, special attention is paid to environmental sustainability, promoting compliance with the objectives of COP21 and encouraging the decarbonisation of transport.Since the environmental aspect is a very important and sensitive issue to which a lot of attention needs to be paid and since the report presents many good ideas, I decided to vote positively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report because it does not add any political priority in the field of passenger transport by inland waterways, and furthermore, it reinforces the presence of unsustainable resources such as liquefied natural gas (LNG).The report does not include specific references to the role that the public sector should play in the development of these communication channels, maintaining a market approach that to date has only inhibited their development.However, despite little clarity, what it does make a clear reference to is the transport of LNG by these routes, consolidating the great commitment to this fossil resource and the strong impact that it has on extraction or storage areas such asThis is the case of the Doñana Natural Park.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.Transporting passengers by sea can be an environmentally friendly and consumer friendly mode of transport, as well as an essential service for tourists and people in remote or coastal areas.Further measures must be taken to promote this mode of transport, which can have a positive effect on economic development along coastal areas and also alleviate land congestion.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – The report did not give any real direction on how to unleash the potential of passenger transport. There is no differentiation between small regular ferries (playing a key role a sustainable public transport alternative for citizens in their daily travels such as for Ireland’s islands) and huge cruises for recreational mass-tourism. Neither between the strategic collateral impacts, such as its contribution to social and territorial long-term cohesion, decentralised local economy or a higher overall environmental performance. Nor there is a calling for proper social, economic and environmental assessment – including strategic alternative-analysis – when planning and funding new related infrastructure.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the use of passenger waterborne transport. Nowadays, many commuters in Europe travel on the roads, causing congestion, congestion and delays on European city routes. Better use of passenger water transport capacity could not only reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services in general. There are many places in Europe where traveling by ferry or cruise ship would be much more economical, easier and faster, while protecting Europe's environment and the health of its citizens. More than 400 million people use EU ports every year. people, and 120 million. passengers are transported to ports of the same Member State. And while waterborne transport is already one of the most sustainable modes of transport, it is still possible to make ships less polluting and more energy efficient. This requires the use of research and innovative technologies, such as solar and wind energy, onshore electricity and alternative fuels, while respecting the principle of technology neutrality. I agree that the development of passenger waterborne transport requires improved access to and use of EU funding, such as cohesion, structural, regional, INTERREG, Horizon 2020, CEF and TEN-T funds.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on exploiting the potential of inland waterway transport, because I believe that these passenger services are environmentally friendly and that they provide vital services to tourists traveling to remote coastal areas.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- Developing passenger transport by water is relevant.However, the ecological-European-integrationist shortcomings, with the declared desire to create an additional unique space for travelers by waterway and its almost inevitable risk of harming what remains of the French commercial fleet makes this report unacceptable..So I opposed it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The UK is an island. The only cross-border co-operation required here is between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland. This does not require action to be taken at European Union level, and seems to me to be the very definition of subsidiarity: a matter which could be better be decided by the United Kingdom than at a European Union level. Indeed, the UK already has a well-established waterborne passenger transport system. Consequently, I voted against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- Improving the use of available passenger transport capacities by water would not only reduce congestion, but also reduce CO2 emissions and improve air quality as a result.It is for these reasons that I voted for this resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on exploiting the potential of passenger water transport.Europe's geographical structure is rich in rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coastlines and islands, making it extremely easy for passengers to travel by water.In addition, European urban routes create congestion, congestion and delays.I therefore agree that better use of passenger water transport capacity could not only reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services in general.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the EU is once again trying to adopt a one size fits all policy. The UK as a island nation has considerable expertise when it comes to issues relating to shipping and passenger transportation on the sea. The report does touch on some very relevant topics such as reducing fossil fuel requirement, however it goes too far by calling for decarbonisation but does not provide any alternative. The report also goes on to claim that the EU is responsible for facilitating Search and Rescue operations through the introduction of the EU passenger ship safety legislation, however, the UK has had Search and Rescue operations in place since the 1920’s. It just goes to show that this report is both inaccurate and misleading and in addition to the reasons already mentioned I felt that I should vote against it.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- The rapporteur wants the creation of a "single space for the transport of passengers by water", which the FN-RBM MEPs have always opposed.This creation would inevitably accelerate the replacement, at least partially, of French buildings by foreign buildings and personnel.The interest in developing passenger transport by water is obvious.However, the ecological-European-integrationist shortcomings - with the declared desire to create an additional unique space for travelers by waterway and its almost inevitable risk of harming what remains of the French commercial fleet -make this report unacceptable.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this report which recalls that the transport of passengers by water in the context of coastal or maritime navigation constituted a great potential in view of the available infrastructures and that it was an important factor in strengthening cohesion betweenthe various regions of the European Union.In particular, the Commission is invited to finance better organized and more efficient integrated transport service projects in order to ensure intermodal and efficient management of passenger transport.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The transport of passengers by water already plays a fundamental role in the connections between the different regions of the European Union, an area which, due to its geographical characteristics, the presence of many rivers, islands and coasts, still has enormous potential for the growth of sustainable transport systems. I voted in favor of the Taylor report because I share the idea of ​​investing in policies that aim to create a truly single space for the transport of passengers by water. The action of the Community institutions must now aim to develop policies that address the aspects of safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness, as well as the quality of services, passenger rights and accessibility without barriers.
