The transport of passengers by water is a great opportunity for the future, Europe will have to make the most of it to guarantee not only vital services to remote communities, but to relaunch the tourist potential of many areas of our continent.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I voted against this report because, although it has interesting elements, it lacks critical focus on fundamental issues to build a good long-term transport policy. For example, the evaluation of alternatives during the planning and management of infrastructures or the differentiation of types of ships and lines according to their social function or their environmental performance. It is not the same to maintain and improve the secondary port network than to build industrial mega-ports that then remain underused. A regular ferry that boosts the local economy and improves citizen mobility is not the same as a mass tourism macro-cruise. In addition, the report advocates the introduction of gas infrastructures in TEN-T ports, which is a red line for us. In Spain we cannot afford to spend millions of public money on infrastructure and gas transportation that could be used to promote locally generated renewable energy, create long-term sustained employment and reduce our enormous energy dependence.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I would like to thank Mr Taylor for his work on the agreement on unlocking the potential of inland passenger transport services.I have supported this report but have not followed the line of my group regarding the mention of the limits applicable to sulfur emissions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report concerns the development of passenger transport on the rivers and seas of the Union. I share the observation that European geography is well suited to river transport and that it is a mode of transport to be developed because it is too under-exploited for the benefit of road transport. He wants the creation of motorways of the sea and the development of inter-modality, which I consider positive, but the creation of a "single space for the transport of travelers by water" bothers me. This creation would inevitably accelerate the replacement, at least partial, of French buildings by foreign buildings and personnel. On the other hand, the report is riddled with words from the perfect right-thinking MP. If, overall, I wish to develop passenger transport by water (and by going further river freight as well), here the text, with this desire for an additional single space, may well harm that there is still the French commercial fleet and we lose a little more of our sovereignty. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The text on the importance of passenger transport on inland waterways seems well thought out.I believe it is essential to guarantee our citizens the possibility of using river and sea transport as a means of communication.An improvement in this type of transport would favor the activity of many of our companies, for example in the shipbuilding and tourism sectors.For these reasons I intended to support the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Passenger transport by sea and inland waterways offers great potential in terms of utilizing excess available capacity, both in terms of infrastructure and vessels, and plays a key role in connecting EU regions (especially those in the EU). outermost) being an important factor of cohesion. Likewise, cruise and ferry activity encourages coastal tourism, which is one of the main maritime activities in Europe. This report encourages Member States, regional and local authorities and the Commission to take into account passenger transport by sea and inland waterways and, in particular, to improve the associated infrastructure, both in the core network and in the global network, within the framework of the TEN-T and the MCE, reinforcing its interconnection with inland railway infrastructures, among others, as well as through the provision of infrastructures and information that meet the mobility needs of all passengers. It also proposes a set of measures to achieve a more competitive and cleaner sector, such as improving connections with urban centers, reducing the environmental impact of ships or updating passenger ship safety regulations as well as connectivity with other modes and regions. . For this reason, I have voted in favor.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it spoke in favor of Parliament exploiting the potential of passenger water transport. Waterborne passenger transport, including sea ferries, inland waterways, barges and cruise ships, play a key role in making the European transport sector more cohesive and efficient, based on policies addressing safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness and quality of service. , passenger rights and barrier - free accessibility. Many commuters in Europe travel by road, causing congestion, congestion and delays on European urban routes. Better use of passenger water transport capacity could not only reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services in general. Europe's geographical structure is characterized by an abundance of rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coastlines and islands, which offer enormous opportunities for passenger waterborne transport. There are many places in Europe where traveling by ferry or cruise ship would be much more sustainable, easier and faster, thus increasing the socio-economic well-being of the regions and at the same time protecting Europe's environment and the health of its citizens.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union, in an environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient way, in which the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can also take place. I would emphasize that making better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. A form of transport can emerge that is also conducive to tourism because it allows tourism to flourish on river and water banks. In this way, even a lesser-known region can start an economic recovery. It is very important to me that the majority of passengers on domestic voyages travel on ships that meet common EU safety standards, and there is some training for crew. Overall, I view the importance of the report as positive, which is why I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the proposal because I think it is important to make good use of the potential offered by watercourses and sea areas.Europe is known to offer many opportunities with its unique geography.It is therefore important to realize that long coastlines, many islands and rivers offer exceptional opportunities for sustainable waterborne passenger transport.We have also recently witnessed the rapid development of various vessels, and it should be taken into account that, thanks to technological developments, waterborne transport can prove to be an alternative to congested road transport.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on the realization of the potential of passenger transport by water.Water transport of passengers can be an environmentally and consumer-friendly mode of transport, as well as an important service for tourists and travelers in remote / coastal areas.Further measures can be taken to promote this mode of transport, which can have a positive effect on economic development along coastal areas and relieve congestion on land.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on unleashing the potential of waterborne passenger transport because I think that this kind of transport policy shall overcome the administrative burden arising from cross—border shipping in order to increase the efficiency of the sector, obviously by bearing in mind the need to reduce the environmental impact.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - A large number of commuters in Europe travel by road, creating traffic jams, congestion and delays on the urban roads of our continent. Better use of available waterborne passenger transport capacities could not only help reduce congestion and carbon dioxide emissions, but also improve air quality and the overall supply of transport services. Passenger ships play an important role in the mobility of EU citizens: over 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports in the same Member State. The EU has contributed to improving safety on passenger ships and facilitating search and rescue operations through a significant improvement in regulations, however there are still areas for improvement that can be exploited to strengthen the application of existing rules and to simplify them. where possible, in order to eliminate obsolete or redundant requirements and to ensure the level of excellence of passenger safety in transport on the waterways of the European Union.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report aims to develop river transport in favor of travelers.Based on the observation that European geography is particularly suited to this and that this mode of transport is under-exploited in favor of road transport leading to an increase in traffic jams and pollution, the rapporteur recommends creating a single space for passenger transportby water.Although I am in favor of the development of this mode of transport which will contribute to the dynamism of tourism and our economies, I voted against this report which risks harming companies specializing in this activity.The text places particular emphasis on the development of low-polluting fleets, staff training and general access for people with reduced mobility.With these types of environmental constraints, the transport of passengers by water may not go beyond the embryonic stage.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - Naval passenger transport has a key role to play in ensuring the sustainability of the European transport sector, and it is necessary to harness the potential through innovative technologies so that ships become greener and more energy efficient. At present, there are a large number of people commuting in Europe choosing road transport, which causes congestion and blockages on the main arteries of Europe. Given that Europe's geography benefits from a number of waterways, it would be appropriate to use them both to reduce congestion and CO2 emissions and to provide better and faster transport services. I am in favor of this initiative because I believe that shipping is one of the most sustainable modes of transport and it is necessary to exploit the potential that this type of transport offers in accordance with environmental standards.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - Transport is the foundation of any economy. Market integration, economic growth and transport are closely linked activities. In the EU, effective transport links have facilitated the creation and integration of the internal market. However, further efforts are needed to capitalize on the potential of passenger shipping in order to achieve a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. I support the EP's resolution on the report on harnessing the potential of passenger shipping. Waterways are the only mode of transport that offers a large available capacity. Accidents are very rare, which makes this mode of transport an ideal environment for passenger shipping. To this end, we need a review of legislation at European level, which will improve the way existing rules are implemented. It could also simplify the current regulatory framework to eliminate obsolete requirements or overlapping provisions.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report, which calls on the Commission to work towards the development of waterborne passenger transport (TPVA) in view of the enormous benefits it can deliver. The report indicates how better use of TPVA can make the European transport sector more efficient and sustainable. A reduction in passenger transport by road and a fair increase in passenger transport by water can not only moderate traffic congestion, but can reduce CO2 emissions by improving air quality. Among the incentives to be adopted, investments in innovative technologies and research, improvement of fuel quality and engine efficiency. It is necessary to integrate TPVA into information systems in order to further develop the tourism sector and increase the quality of public services. The numerous presence of waterways is a great opportunity to improve the social and economic well-being of the whole continent.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the EU is once again trying to adopt a one size fits all policy. The UK as a island nation has considerable expertise when it comes to issues relating to shipping and passenger transportation on the sea. The report does touch on some very relevant topics such as reducing fossil fuel requirement, however it goes too far by calling for decarbonisation but does not provide any alternative. The report also goes on to claim that the EU is responsible for facilitating Search and Rescue operations through the introduction of the EU passenger ship safety legislation, however, the UK has had Search and Rescue operations in place since the 1920’s. It just goes to show that this report is both inaccurate and misleading and in addition to the reasons already mentioned I felt that I should vote against it.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – Technological developments have once again made waterborne transport an alternative to congested access roads to city centres. Whilst waterborne passenger transport and waterborne freight transport face different challenges and have different needs in terms of infrastructure, environmental challenges, operational issues, security and port-city relations the integration of waterborne passenger hubs into European policy on interconnecting infrastructure, as already implemented through EU will provide further European added value. This could be enhanced through the possibilities for loans and guarantees for waterborne projects under the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) as a complementary instrument to the traditional grants. I voted in favour.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Inland waterway passenger transport is an important strategic sector in transport and tourism, on which it is necessary to create harmonized legal bases which do not hinder its development. This is a fundamental transport for the peripheral regions, often made less accessible and interconnected due to a transport system that is not adequate to their territorial structure. Enhancing waterborne transport also means compensating for a competitiveness deficit that affects specific areas located at a great distance from the main administrative and economic centers. It is therefore necessary to shorten the distances through a structural strengthening of the connections in order to increase the opportunities for development, growth and employment. I voted in favor of this report because I believe it is essential to support an economic development model that takes into account the specific needs of these territories, which are disadvantaged due to a still uncompetitive transport system.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and highlight the potential and feasibility of integrating inland waterway transport into a multimodal mobility framework, with an emphasis on public transport in large urban areas, for both mobile workers and tourists.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- The report on exploiting the potential of water passenger transport aims to develop an industry that in recent years has not been a priority for citizens and the business world.Despite the positive ideas it contains, the report fails to focus on the needs of small and medium-sized enterprises, creating favorable conditions for stronger companies.Therefore, I decided to abstain.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- I cast a positive vote for the report in question.This is a non-legislative text which aims to draw the attention of the European Commission to the priorities of passenger transport on waterways, whether it concerns the sea or inland waters.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - There is no place in our Union where it is not possible to enjoy the presence of rivers, lakes or coasts. On the other hand, it is the history of the world itself that teaches us how the greatest civilizations developed in areas rich in water and since our historical and cultural heritage deserves a worthy continuation, vote in favor of the provision. The conformation of the EU offers an exceptional opportunity for sustainable transport by water, therefore making it imperative to use the excess capacity existing today in terms of infrastructure and boats. Likewise, the fundamental role of connections represents a significant factor of territorial cohesion, as well as a tourist opportunity to be fully exploited. Therefore, it is intended to simplify the administrative burden for cross-border shipping. The goal is, of course, to open a space for a boost in competitiveness. Together with this, we are well aware of the environmental impact of water transport, so we intend to set precise rules for sustainable tourism. First of all, Eurostat is invited to include data related to water tourism and its impacts. Secondly, local authorities must operate a functional and efficient integration between water transport and public transport on the mainland.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on unleashing the potential of waterborne passenger transport and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - Passenger transport by inland waterways plays a key role in building a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. The EU's objective in maritime transport is to become a world leader in maritime research and innovation, as well as in shipbuilding, with a view to improving the energy efficiency and intelligence of ships, reducing environmental impact, minimizing the risk of accidents and improve the quality of life at sea. It is necessary to eliminate bottlenecks in the connections between the expanded system of inland waterways in western Europe and the current system in eastern Europe, whose degradation is notable and, in some places, total. The Commission should develop a harmonized system for collecting statistical data on accidents and incidents for inland waterway vessels, including cross-border traffic. Member States should promote and support local initiatives to activate inland waterway transport and as a means of meeting the needs of urban agglomerations. For this reason, I supported this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the measure as I am convinced that the transport of passengers by water (TPVA), including sea ferries, inland waterway ferries, barges and cruise ships, plays a very important role in development of a more efficient and sustainable European transport sector, assisted by policies that address the aspects of safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation, competitiveness as well as quality of service, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility. Today there are still many commuters traveling by road, creating traffic jams, congestion and delays on the urban roads of our continent: a better use of the available capacity for transporting passengers by water could not only help reduce congestion and emissions. pollutants, but also to improve the overall offer of transport services for European citizens.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Overcoming seasonality in remote and peripheral regions of the Union such as coastal, island, lake and rural regions is a priority in most of our regions.  I agree that SMEs should be a focal point for the promotion of tourism services and support the call on the Commission, the Member States and local and regional authorities to make fullest possible use of EU funding opportunities for SMEs, including subsidies for local communities in the aforementioned outlying regions. We need a proper framework for providing connections with islands, island regions and remote areas which would be promoted with measures to facilitate better-quality ferries and appropriate terminals. By making better use of available capacity of waterborne passenger transport we could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report because it does not add any political priority in the field of passenger transport by inland waterways, and furthermore, it reinforces the presence of unsustainable resources such as liquefied natural gas (LNG).The report does not include specific references to the role that the public sector should play in the development of these communication channels, maintaining a market approach that to date has only inhibited their development.However, despite little clarity, what it does make a clear reference to is the transport of LNG by these routes, consolidating the great commitment to this fossil resource and the strong impact that it has on extraction or storage areas such asThis is the case of the Doñana Natural Park.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing.- Waterborne passenger transport is among the most sustainable modes of transport and better utilization of its capacities could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality andoverall offer of transport services.There is certainly further scope for making ships cleaner and more energy efficient through investment in research and innovative technologies, for example in solar and wind energy, shore-side electricity supply and alternative fuels.In this sense, the use of EU funds, such as the Cohesion, Structural, Regional, Interreg, Horizon 2020, CEF and TEN-T Funds and EFSI funding can be the key to strengthening thepotential of the reference sector.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - Naval passenger transport plays a crucial role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, in synergy with safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness. Due to the large number of people transiting Europe daily, road traffic is experiencing many traffic jams and congestion. If the available capacity of naval passenger transport were used more efficiently, then we would not only reduce carbon dioxide emissions and traffic congestion, but also improve the transport system at Union level. The geography of Europe offers extraordinary opportunities for the development of shipping. I voted for the development of this enormous potential offered by passenger shipping. Every year, around 400 million people pass through EU ports. EU legislation on the safety of passenger ships has led to improved passenger safety.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing.- Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union, in an environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient way, in which new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can be used, so more emphasis should be placed on waterborne passenger transport.In line with the COP21 agreements, it is important that better use of available passenger capacity in waterborne transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.Furthermore, it can help the tourism boom on rivers and waterfront and thus even lead to the economic boom of a lesser known region.I voted in favor of the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I abstained on the report on the issue of unlocking the potential of waterborne passengers.I believe it is important to improve the common rules for the safety of ships carrying passengers in EU waters.In the context of the current situation of uncontrolled flows of illegal immigrants to Europe by sea, there is a need to increase the safety of ship's crew and passengers.I also see the need for further improvement of systems in the case of large agglomerations to improve the quality of services and the comfort of people traveling by public transport.However, the proposed provisions fall within the scope of competences that should lie with the Member States, which is why I abstained from voting.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Waterborne passenger transport has the potential to provide an alternative to land transport and thus relieves congestion on land. This type of transport can be environmentally and consumer friendly, while also providing services to the increasing tourism industry. In order to have an effective waterborne passenger transport system we need to improve the current infrastructure and support local initiatives. We need to also encourage cleaner fuels to lower CO2 emissions. I voted in favour of this report as all these aspects are covered in the report.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report as, whilst I fully agree that this sector plays an important role in connecting people and has great potential within and outside the UK, I cannot support all the recommendations within the final report. It makes some valid points on improving enforcement of passenger ship safety, but it fails to recognise the needs and differences of smaller operators or to address the unequal restrictions on sulphur emissions for British North Sea operators in comparison to their Mediterranean competitors.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I support the rapporteur's position on the need to integrate naval passenger transport into urban, regional and cross-border public transport networks, which will make mobility more efficient and better protect the environment, in line with increasing decongestion of land transport networks and comfortfrom cities.On the other hand, it is beneficial for Member States to promote and support local initiatives aimed at activating inland waterway transport as a way of supplying congestion, including through the development of distribution centers in river ports and the development of passenger transport, infirstly to make the areas concerned more attractive to tourists, as well as to move to more environmentally friendly and energy-efficient, lower-emission vessels.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the EU is once again trying to adopt a one size fits all policy. The UK as a island nation has considerable expertise when it comes to issues relating to shipping and passenger transportation on the sea. The report does touch on some very relevant topics such as reducing fossil fuel requirement, however it goes too far by calling for decarbonisation but does not provide any alternative. The report also goes on to claim that the EU is responsible for facilitating Search and Rescue operations through the introduction of the EU passenger ship safety legislation, however, the UK has had Search and Rescue operations in place since the 1920’s. It just goes to show that this report is both inaccurate and misleading and in addition to the reasons already mentioned I felt that I should vote against it.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on harnessing the potential of passenger transport by water.While more than 400 million people pass through EU ports each year, passenger water transport remains under-exploited.Faced with the need to reduce our greenhouse gas emissions, it is imperative to change our transportation habits.Transporting passengers by water is a credible option.This mode of transport is more environmentally friendly and promises economic development, especially in the tourism sector.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union, in an environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient way, in which the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can also take place. I would emphasize that making better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. A form of transport can emerge that is also conducive to tourism because it allows tourism to flourish on river and water banks. In this way, even a lesser-known region can start an economic recovery. It is very important to me that the majority of passengers on domestic voyages travel on ships that meet common EU safety standards, and there is some training for crew. Overall, I view the importance of the report as positive, which is why I voted in favor of the report!

name: Isabella DE MONTE
text: in writing.- Inland waterway transport is more sustainable for the environment as it offers opportunities to reduce pollution.The ferry and cruise sectors represent an important part of the European economy also for tourism with 400 million citizens passing through EU ports every year and providing jobs for around 161 000 people.The sector ensures important connections in coastal regions and traffic on rivers.I therefore urge the EU to continue its efforts to improve ferry safety performance and to develop technologies that contribute to energy efficiency.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This report aims at the development of passenger transport on the rivers and seas of the European Union.Indeed, while the European geography lends itself ideally to river transport, it is under-exploited.The interest in developing river transport is obvious.However, the Front National opposes the creation of a single river area in Europe, because such a measure would result in the replacement of French buildings by foreign buildings and personnel.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I welcome the report and the Commission's new legislative proposals to simplify and improve the general rules on the safety of ships carrying passengers in EU waters, in order to increase safety and competition, clarifying and simplifying the rules and taking into account legal and regulatory requirements. technological advances. However, there is still an additional need to simplify the existing regulatory framework to remove outdated or overlapping requirements. Greater attention needs to be paid to the safety of the crew and passengers of coastal vessels in the context of the uncontrolled flow of illegal immigrants to Europe by sea. I believe that further improvements are needed to develop integrated ticketing schemes and to increase reliability and frequency. A framework for providing connections to islands, island regions and remote areas, with measures to facilitate better quality ferries and appropriate terminals, should be promoted. All this is well described in the report, and that is why I supported it.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- My vote for the report is positive, because the full exploitation of all waterways is needed to help many areas financially, but at the same time there needs to be increased safety measures for both people and the environment.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union, in an environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient way, in which the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can also take place. I would emphasize that making better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. A form of transport can emerge that is also conducive to tourism because it allows tourism to flourish on river and water banks. In this way, even a lesser-known region can start an economic recovery. It is very important to me that the majority of passengers on domestic voyages travel on ships that meet common EU safety standards, and there is some training for crew. Overall, I view the importance of the report as positive, which is why I voted in favor of the report!

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written.- Passenger transport by sea and inland waterways plays a key role in connecting the different regions of the Union.Therefore, it is an important factor in improving cohesion, both economically and efficiently.Cruise and ferry activity, on the other hand, greatly encourages coastal tourism, one of the main maritime activities in Europe.On the environmental level, inland waterway transport is an environmentally friendly mode of transport included in the White Paper recommendations.Considering the convenience of these precepts, from the European Parliament we support the release of the potential of passenger transport services by inland waterways.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report by my colleague on the Transport Committee, Keith Taylor. I believe Wales has great potential for development in this area, given the nature of our coastline. This report could help move the discussion forward.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: the interest of developing passenger transport by water is obvious.However, the almost inevitable risk of harming the remainder of the French commercial fleet makes this report unacceptable.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The development of transport via inland waterways - maritime and inland - is a very important issue in relation to the mobility of passengers and goods, with enormous environmental and economic benefits. The operation of this transport system requires the adaptation of natural conditions and infrastructure. In recent years, the disinvestment in equipment and infrastructure, as well as job insecurity in this system, have jeopardized many services. This report is based on a good principle, which is the development of transport on waterways, as a factor of territorial, social and economic cohesion; as a factor in meeting the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and increasing the environmental sustainability of transport; as a safer and more controllable medium. However, the way in which the sector's development objectives are achieved are the same that have led this and other transport systems to privatization, deregulation, loss of quality of service and, in certain cases, abandonment - the precepts of the Book Transport Whiteboard, the Connecting Europe Facility, the Trans-European Transport Network and, as a form of outstanding financing, the ESIF. Recognizing the importance of the sector, we cannot support this report.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report as I believe it meets the need to simplify and improve the common rules on the safety of ships carrying passengers in EU waters.In particular, the report has the merit of addressing two important issues such as the safety of personnel and passengers on coastal vessels, and the integration of maritime transport in a context of multimodal mobility, particularly in islands, island regions and remote areas.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - There is no doubt that the European Union is under-exploiting the potential of passenger water transport. Road infrastructure in Europe has been congested for a long time, so we need to look for ways to ease it while helping the environment by reducing greenhouse gas emissions. Europe's geographical conditions include many rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coasts and islands, which offer extraordinary opportunities for water transport. There are many areas in Europe where ferry or cruise travel would be more sustainable, easier and faster, while increasing the social and economic well-being of the region, protecting Europe's environment and the health of its citizens. That is why we should invest much more financial resources in research and innovative technologies in the field of shipping in the future and use the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds and also the Regional Funds.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report to underline the importance of waterborne transport for both tourism and economic development and transport in general.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report on exploiting the potential of water passenger transport, because the full exploitation of all waterways is needed to help many areas financially, but at the same time there needs to be increased safety measures for both people and the environment.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ This INI report makes recommendations to improve ferry, barge and cruise services for passengers, including proper integration of waterborne passenger transport into existing public transport networks and improving integrated ticketing. The use of existing EU funding should be fully exploited to develop further the inland and coastal waterborne transport routes. Waterborne passenger transport can be an environmentally and consumer friendly transport mode, as well as a vital service for tourists and commuters in remote/coastal areas. Further measures can be taken to promote this mode of transport which can have a positive effect on economic development along coastal areas and relieve congestion on land. I supported the report in the plenary.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing.- Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the regions of the European Union.In this more environmentally friendly and energy-efficient mode of transport, the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy may also gain ground.I would emphasize that making better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.A form of transport can emerge that is also conducive to tourism because it allows tourism to flourish on rivers and waterfront.Overall, therefore, I view the report as positive, which is why, as a member of the FIDESZ People's Party delegation, I voted in favor of its adoption!

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report, bearing in mind that passenger transport by sea and inland waterways plays a decisive role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector.Better use of available capacity for passenger transport by sea and inland waterways could contribute not only to reducing congestion and CO2 emissions, but also to improving air quality and providing better transport services in general.Although sea and inland waterway transport is already one of the most sustainable modes of getting around, there is still more potential to make ships less polluting and more energy efficient through investments in research and innovative technologies.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- Strengthening the development of alternative transport, such as that by sea, would be an excellent opportunity for the Union to bet more effectively on fundamental objectives for Europe such as sustainable development, the input to growth through the relaunch of newopportunities related to tourism and concrete contributions to the reduction of CO2 emissions for an effective improvement of air quality.For these reasons, I supported and promoted with my vote the report "unleashing the potential of passenger transport by waterways", convinced that the future of European transport must be based on integrated multimedia, social and environmental sustainability and the resources put in place.from new technologies.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I supported the EP resolution on "Unleashing the potential of passenger transport by waterways" because it is an environmentally friendly and environmentally friendly mode of transport. Inland waterway passenger transport also plays an important role in coastal and remote areas and is linked to the great issue of exploitation of inland waterways. In a continent populated by many rivers, lakes, streams and navigable waterways, I find it essential that transport on these waterways goes alongside and possibly exceeds road transport, helping to reduce CO2 emissions and decrease the traffic problem. urban. As the centuries-old experience of Venice demonstrates, the integration of maritime transport into the public transport system is therefore possible and indeed a duty. To this must be added the potential of maritime transport for the development of tourism, for the increase in freight traffic in some areas of Europe, for the mobility of people with disabilities, for the connection between urban areas and the periphery and for travel of commuters. I therefore think that Europe must encourage this mode of transport, also looking at the Juncker plan and the EFSI to finance projects with high European added value.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- My home region Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania has one of the largest densities of navigable inland waterways in Europe.Because of this, too, I voted in favor of the report on unlocking the potential of waterborne passenger transport.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The transport of people and goods by water is essential in some regions of the European Union.The North Sea islands are another example.From a pan-European perspective, however, there is still further potential in the transport of people and goods.For example, it is important to implement common safety and environmental standards for ferries and watercraft and to strengthen passenger rights.Furthermore, accessibility on ferries and watercraft should be an approval criterion.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this. Commuters in Europe travel by road, creating bottlenecks, congestion and delays on Europe’s urban routes. Making better use of available capacity of waterborne passenger transport could help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. The provision of statistical data on the number of cross-border ferry, cruise and maritime services, would be crucial. Provisions on interconnectivity with other transport modes, integrated ticketing and information systems are needed, taking into account the needs and rights of all travellers, including people with reduced mobility, commuters and tourists. The EU passenger ship safety legislation has been put in place over a period of 15 years and mainly in response to accidents. It resulted in improved safety of life on passenger ships sailing in EU waters and facilitated search and rescue operations. It is proposed that vessels be cleaner and more energy efficient through investment in research and innovative technologies, e.g. with regard to solar and wind energy, onshore electricity and alternative fuels, while applying the principle of technology neutrality. Connected to this is the availability and use of EU funding such as the cohesion, structural, regional, INTERREG, Horizon 2020, CEF, TEN-T and EFSI funds.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given that passenger ships play an important role for the mobility of EU citizens – more than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports of the same Member State. This report increases the importance and the potential of a sector that is one of the most sustainable ways to travel and is constantly increasing in consumer demand. Making better use of available capacity of WPT could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it continues the positive series of decisions to take measures to reduce CO2 emissions in line with the COP 21 agreements that we have all supported. Promoting the mobility and interconnection of the infrastructures of all European regions is now an essential priority in order to give cohesion to the Union project that we painstakingly build every day. With this objective in mind, the proposal highlights some critical issues that must certainly be resolved. First of all, it would be essential to have statistical data on water transport, especially if they allow cross-border connections by uniting different European regions. With careful monitoring, we could know which ones have real added value and enhance them. Furthermore, uniformity and simplification of the legislative framework are a necessity to improve the safety of people and to increase tourism which will use inland waterway transport.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of this report, given the importance of passenger shipping. This sector has great potential to use the surplus capacity available for both infrastructure and ships and plays a key role in connecting the different regions of the European Union, thus being an important factor in developing cohesion. This report emphasizes the importance of encouraging the development of motorways of the sea, including by third countries, to promote efficient multimodal transport, facilitate the integration of this mode with other networks and modes of transport, eliminate bottlenecks in key network infrastructures and ensure territorial continuity. Blockages in the links between the extended inland navigation system in Western Europe and the existing system in Eastern Europe need to be removed. I believe that the European Commission must be fully committed to supporting investments in quality infrastructure in the hinterland, which can help reduce local traffic congestion, and ensure that locals are not affected.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as passenger ships play an important role in the transportation of EU citizens, This report will help increase the importance of a sustainable sector, improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing.- Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union.Furthermore, waterborne transport is an extremely environmentally friendly and energy-efficient passenger transport alternative, in which the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can also gain ground.It is crucial that better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also contribute to improving air quality.A form of transport can emerge that is also conducive to tourism, as it allows tourism to flourish on river and water banks.This could trigger the economic recovery of even a lesser-known region.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- The Greens' own initiative report touched on the issue of water transport rather superficially, leaving behind a number of other important issues.Therefore, we voted against it.This was also the position of the shadow rapporteur of our group.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as waterborne passenger transport plays a crucial role in connecting the different regions of the European Union especially in areas such as shipping, inland and maritime ferries, urban and peripheral mobility, cruises and tourism. I welcome the efforts of the WPT sector to switch to cleaner, energy-efficient ships with lower emissions, developed as part of a European framework aimed at making waterborne transport greener.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR Group welcomes this report and the Commission’s new legislative proposals to simplify and improve the common rules on safety of ships carrying passengers in EU waters, with a view to enhancing safety and competition and to making the rules clearer, simpler and up-to date with legal and technological developments. However, there still is a further need to simplify the current regulatory framework in order to remove outdated or overlapping requirements. Greater emphasis should be placed on the safety of the crew and passengers of coastal vessels in the context of uncontrolled flows of illegal immigrants to Europe by sea.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Small and medium-sized enterprises in transport play a significant role in European road traffic and make a significant contribution to the EU economy and job creation. The report that has just been voted on is about the opportunities and challenges facing these companies, so it is very important that it is on the plenary agenda. Unfortunately, however, I feel contrary to this positive line in paragraph 37 of the report, which questions the derogation for passenger cars, claiming that their presence in international traffic is unjustifiably high. However, we must point out that there is no reliable data on this, and that if these carriers were also to comply with all the requirements for vehicles over 3.5 tonnes, this could impose a disproportionately high additional financial and administrative burden on them. Therefore, I cannot support this point in the report. Overall, however, I agree with the report and voted in favor of it.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ This type of transport can be an environmentally and consumer friendly as well as a vital service for tourists and commuters in remote or coastal areas. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on realizing the potential of passenger transport by water, as this improves various aspects of passenger transport within the Union.Namely, it increases the safety of passengers on ships sailing in EU waters, revitalizes the tourist potential of remote local communities while increasing environmental efficiency, and thus the quality of life.This also reduces CO2 emissions and congestion on the roads, and it is important to note that waterway traffic is not only used for inland navigation, but increasingly also along the coast.Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to ensure better quality of mobility services in order to strengthen their reliability, comfort, accuracy and frequency in the form of reducing the pressure on logistics chains and attracting passengers.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because I am in favour of boosting the possibilities of using the waterways in Europe. I am of the view that the potential of Europe’s waterborne transport can be further exploit and can play a more important role in the mobility of EU citizens. It stands for a more ecological and safe means of transport compared to traveling by roads.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleague Keith Taylor's report on the operation of passenger water transport.I support this initiative, which is part of the desire to develop alternative modes of transport.Waterways are also the means to revitalize an entire economy and to rediscover the waterfront in an urban landscape.The report also highlights the interoperability of this network with the trans-European transport network by strengthening the connections between the seafront and the hinterland.I am delighted that this text was adopted by a large majority

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because maritime passenger transport plays a crucial role for the emergence of a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, with policies focused on safety, environmental standards,cross-border cooperation and competitiveness, quality, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - Water passenger transport, including sea ferries, inland waterway ferries, barges and cruise ships, play a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, with the support of cross-border cooperation and competitiveness as well as the quality of services, passenger rights and unhindered accessibility. Although water transport is already one of the most sustainable modes of transport, there is further potential for ships to become cleaner and more energy efficient by investing in research and innovative technologies, for example in the field of solar and wind energy, terrestrial electricity. and alternative fuels, while applying the principle of technological neutrality. Related to the above is the availability and use of European Union funds, which come from the Cohesion Fund, the Structural and Regional Funds, the INTERREG and Horizon 2020 programs, the DSE, the TEN-T and the EFSI. I therefore voted in favor of Mr Taylor's report.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am abstaining on this report.Calls for a reduction in bureaucracy, more interconnectivity and the creation of motorways of the sea and the removal of bottlenecks between the developed systems of Western European inland waterways and the less developed Eastern European systems are welcome, but the potential of passenger transport is too low to make a significant contribution to sustainable developmentand efficient transport sector.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Passenger ships play an important role for the mobility of EU citizens – more than 400 million people pass through EU ports each year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports of the same Member State. This report increases the importance and the potential of a sector that is one of the most sustainable ways to travel and is constantly increasing in consumer demand. Making better use of available capacity of WPT could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - On 22 November 2016, the EP plenary voted on exploiting the potential of passenger water transport. Passenger water transport plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. A large number of Europeans commuting travel by road, causing congestion, congestion and delays on Europe's urban roads. Better use of available passenger water capacity could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services in general. Although I see potential in water transport, I could not support the report on this issue. In my opinion, the report is very low profile without any critical policy approach. The report does not distinguish between small regular ferries, which play a key role in the sustainability of public transport as an alternative to the daily travel of citizens, and large ferries for mass tourism. The report also does not call for alternative strategic analyzes. Last but not least, the report contains several controversial topics, such as the development of the sea lanes or the promotion of liquefied natural gas (LNG). For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Waterborne transport plays a key role in connecting the various regions of the European Union, in an environmentally friendly and more energy-efficient way, in which the use of new, innovative technologies such as solar and wind energy can also take place. I would emphasize that making better use of the capacity available for waterborne passenger transport can not only help reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. A form of transport can emerge that is also conducive to tourism because it allows tourism to flourish on river and water banks. In this way, even a lesser-known region can start an economic recovery. It is very important to me that the majority of passengers on domestic voyages travel on ships that meet common EU safety standards, and there is some training for crew. Overall, I view the importance of the report as positive, which is why I voted in favor of the report!

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- A balanced report on the current situation and opportunities for a truly somewhat neglected sector, waterborne passenger transport, with a view to the deployment of electric and natural gas vehicles.River shipping has greatly declined in my country as well, and its development is timely.Environmental considerations have been given due prominence in the material, which is also justified as ships bollarding in urban ports cause a serious burden on the environment.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from voting on unleashing the potential of waterborne passenger transport since while I do recognize that EU’s inland waterways and sees have potential to alternate land and air communication in the areas where applicable, the report lacks in-depth and balanced analysis on the subject.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on harnessing the potential of passenger transport by water, as water passenger transport, including sea ferries, river ferries, barges and cruise ships, plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. Most commuters travel daily to Europe by land, which creates congestion, congestion and delays on urban routes in Europe. Making better use of available water passenger transport capacity can not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but can improve air quality and provide better transport services in general. In view of Europe's geographical characteristics, which include many rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coastlines and islands, exceptional opportunities for water transport are created. There are many areas in Europe where water travel would be more sustainable, easier and faster, which would increase the region's social and economic well-being, while protecting the environment and the health of European citizens.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Waterborne passenger transport (WPT) is a very important transport sector for the EU and Member States. The importance of the WPT sector comes from the fact that some ferry connections are lifelines – vital for territorial, social and economic cohesion in the true sense – connecting outermost regions to the mainland and the economic and industrial growth areas, thus contributing to European cohesion and integration. In addition, the WPT sector plays a crucial role in development of tourism, in particular in remote and peripheral regions of the Union such as coastal, island lake and rural regions. Looking from this perspective, I supported the resolution because the WPT sector is sustainable and efficient mode of transport for EU citizens. Importantly, we should support the WPT sector by making policies that address safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness as well as service quality, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility. In this sense, we should put the WTP sector at the top of the EU’s maritime transport policy strategy to 2018.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The European territory, mostly occupied by rivers, long coasts and islands, presents various possibilities for the transport of passengers by water. Despite this, traffic jams, congestions and delays characterize the roads of our continent that many commuters use daily. For these reasons it is important to invest more in the capacities available for waterborne passenger transport (TPVA), which could contribute to the reduction of CO2 emissions and to the improvement of air quality. If assisted by safety policies, environmental standards, quality of service and passenger rights, the TPVA could represent the main path towards a more efficient and sustainable European transport sector. EU legislation has, to date, increased safety on passenger ships while harmonizing safety rules across all EU Member States. Nevertheless, there is still a need for a strengthening of the implementation of the rules in force, a simplification of the regulatory framework and greater investment in research and innovative technologies.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the report on harnessing the potential of passenger transport by water. This own-initiative report aims to send a resolution to the Council and the Commission in order to develop passenger transport on the rivers and seas of the Union. The report starts from the double observation that, on the one hand, the European geography with its rivers, its coasts and its islands lends itself particularly well to river, sea and lake transport. On the other hand, this mode of transport is under-exploited in favor of road transport, resulting in traffic congestion and increased pollution, especially in cities. The rapporteur wants the creation of a "single space for the transport of passengers by water", which I have always opposed. This creation would inevitably accelerate the replacement, at least partially, of French buildings by foreign buildings and personnel. The interest in developing passenger transport by water is obvious. However, the declared desire to create an additional single space for water travelers and its almost inevitable risk of harming the remainder of the French commercial fleet makes this report unacceptable.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The stated objective of this report is laudable: it is to develop passenger transport by sea and / or inland waterway.Nevertheless, this report is innervated by ecolo-European-integrationist crosses, in particular with its desire to create an additional single space for travelers by water.Finally, such a resolution runs the risk of harming the remainder of the French commercial fleet, which I cannot support.So I voted against it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - The report requests that the transport of passengers by navigable and maritime routes become more important in the political agenda. The report lists a series of measures to promote this mode of transport which, although it is a minority compared to the plane, train and bus, is key for certain regions, in particular the islands. The proposed measures seek to make the sector as a whole more competitive, but also cleaner and greener, and range from improving connections with urban centers, statistics, the environmental impact of ships, updating passenger ship safety regulations, as well as, connectivity with other modes and regions. It recognizes the importance of this mode of transport for certain islands that have no other alternative mode of transport, especially the contribution to territorial, social and economic cohesion that it represents for the outermost regions. Specifically, it regrets the lack of development of certain areas in the coastal regions and islands due to the lack of connectivity and calls for an improvement in passenger terminals (especially for those with reduced mobility), as well as measures to achieve better quality ferries.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report because it does not add any political priority in the field of passenger transport by inland waterways, and furthermore, it reinforces the presence of unsustainable resources such as liquefied natural gas (LNG).The report does not include specific references to the role that the public sector should play in the development of these communication channels, maintaining a market approach that to date has only inhibited their development.However, despite little clarity, what it does make a clear reference to is the transport of LNG by these routes, consolidating the great commitment to this fossil resource and the strong impact that it has on extraction or storage areas such asThis is the case of the Doñana Natural Park.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This report recalls the fundamental role that passenger transport by sea and inland waterways plays in connecting the different regions of the Union, and is therefore an important element in improving cohesion.In this regard, it emphasizes that more than 400 million people pass through the Union's ports each year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports in the same Member State.The report seeks to take advantage of the great opportunities offered by this means of transport.It should not be forgotten that transport by sea and inland waterways can be an alternative to the congested access roads to urban centers.I vote in favor of the report, since by favoring a means of transport that has proven to be efficient we will favor European integration.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which acknowledges the importance of waterways as a mode of transport in Europe.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Waterborne passenger transport has a key role to play in creating a more sustainable European transport sector. Better utilization of available capacities for passenger transport by waterways would reduce road congestion and CO2 emissions and improve air quality and provide better transport services in general. There are many European regions where ferry or cruise ship transport would be more sustainable, easier and faster, increasing their social and economic well-being while protecting the environment and the health of Europe's citizens. In addition to the potential that small vessels have to significantly improve environmental efficiency, it could also be used to provide transport services of key importance to remote local communities and revitalize their tourism potential. Passenger ships play an important role in terms of citizen mobility, with more than 400 million people passing through EU ports each year. EU legislation on passenger ship safety has been introduced for a period of 15 years, resulting in greater passenger safety and easier search and rescue operations. However, there is additional room for better implementation of existing rules and simplification of the current legislative framework, and therefore more use should be made of available EU funding. Because of all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the efforts of the waterborne passenger transport sector to switch to cleaner, energy-efficient ships with lower emissions, developed as part of a European framework aimed at making waterborne transport greener.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - The intensification of passenger water transport has positive effects on several levels.In addition to the financial benefits, congestion on European roads will be reduced, passenger safety will be increased, the use of modern technologies and fuels will improve air quality and increase environmental protection.At the same time, the labor market in the area of passenger water transport operations and related services will be revived, which will help the regions belonging to water transport.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on exploiting the potential of water passenger transport, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 21 November 2016, and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This report aims to encourage the development of passenger transport by river, sea and lake, an under-exploited area in Europe.The interest in developing passenger transport by water is obvious, but this report gives rise to our greatest reservations.We fear that the creation of a "single space for the transport of travelers by water", as well as the creation of "motorways of the sea", reforms both desired by this report, will inevitably accelerate the substitution of ships.French by foreign ships, which we strongly oppose.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted positively for the report on unleashing the potential of waterborne passenger transport. Supporting the report means paving the way for reduction of CO2 emissions and improvement of air quality and betterment of aquatic transport systems. By contributing to this project, European citizens can look forward to enjoying from even more sustainable, easier, and quicker maritime transport that protects both their environment as well as their health. Furthermore, improving waterborne transport will result in an increase of mobility of European citizens, which in turn will boost the economy in the maritime sector.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The call for a reduction in bureaucracy in cross-border passenger shipping, more interconnectivity and the creation of “motorways of the sea” must be approved.The straightening of existing waterways and the associated ecological problems are not mentioned in the report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I welcome the EP report on exploiting the potential of waterborne passenger transport.The report discusses important measures to ensure competitiveness, safety of services, quality and environmental standards.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- Europe's geography, characterized by its extensive coastline, numerous islands and multiple rivers, offers extraordinary prospects for the sustainable transport of travelers by water.This report could have seized the opportunity to propose an ambitious plan to extend ecological transport capacity by water.But the report does not distinguish between small regular ferries (playing a key role as a sustainable public transport alternative for citizens in their daily journeys) and cruises for mass recreational tourism.The strategic impacts in terms of long-term social and territorial cohesion, on the decentralized local economy or overall environmental performance are also ignored.Under these conditions I abstain

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report aims to send a resolution to the Council and the Commission for the development of passenger transport on the rivers and seas of the Union.The rapporteur's wish is to create a single space for the transport of travelers by water, which would accelerate the disappearance of French buildings and be replaced by foreign buildings and personnel.Even if this report is common sense, it is unfortunately marred by the usual arguments of environmentalists and highlights their Europeanist excesses.I therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Passenger transport by inland waterways, including sea ferries, river ferries, barges and cruise ships, plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, supported by policies that addressaccount safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness, as well as the quality of services, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility.Better use of available waterborne passenger transport capacities could not only help to reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services in general.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because waterborne passenger transport plays a critical role in connecting the European Union’s regions and is vital to increased cohesion across Europe.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - The geography of Europe is characterized by relatively large bodies of water, thus offering extraordinary prospects for water transport. Whether they are ferry vessels or cruise ships, these play an important role for the mobility of Union citizens. No less than 400 million people pass through Union ports each year, 120 million of whom are transported between ports in the same Member State. The passenger water transport sector, however, faces multiple challenges and needs in terms of infrastructure, environment, operational processes, security and links between ports and airports. cities. I therefore welcome this report, which aims to give passenger transport by water, in the transport policy agenda of the Union and its Member States, more attention in terms of environmental sustainability, safety and and safety as well as in terms of the quality and accessibility of services.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - Europe's geographical conditions offer great opportunities for water transport. Passenger ships play an important role in the mobility of EU citizens, with more than 400 million people passing through EU ports every year. Effective use of available water transport capacity would have several positive effects. Not only would it reduce traffic congestion, but it would also reduce CO2 emissions, improve air quality and thus ensure better transport services in general. It is a great positive that EU legislation on passenger ship safety has been introduced in recent years, especially in response to accidents, which has made it possible to improve the protection of the lives of passengers in EU waters and to facilitate possible rescue operations. Safety has also been strengthened through the introduction of common EU safety standards - which are now met by most national passenger vessels. However, room for improvement is still open to simplifying the regulatory framework, removing obsolete requirements. Although shipping is one of the most sustainable modes of travel, there is further potential, such as the production of more environmentally efficient vessels, through investment in research and innovation. I support the proposal with my voice.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because I believe that waterborne passenger transport can be an environmentally and consumer friendly transport mode, as well as a vital service for tourists and commuters in remote/coastal areas. Further measures can be taken to promote this mode of transport, which can have a positive effect on economic development along coastal areas and relieve congestion on land.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The draft resolution of the Committee on Transport and Tourism assumes that the majority of commuters in Europe travel by road, causing bottlenecks, congestion and delays on the roads of European cities. All this is happening despite the fact that Europe offers extraordinary opportunities for waterborne transport due to its geography, numerous rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coastlines and islands. There are many areas in Europe where traveling by ferry or cruise ship would be more sustainable, easier and faster, increase the social and economic well-being of the region, and protect Europe's environment and the health of its citizens. Waterborne passenger transport therefore plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, making better use of available capacities could help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, improve air quality and, on the whole, provide better transport services. I supported the adoption of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The rapporteur wants the creation of a "single space for the transport of passengers by water", which the FN-RBM MEPs have always opposed. This creation would inevitably accelerate the replacement, at least partially, of French buildings by foreign buildings and personnel. It calls for the creation, as for the transport of maritime freight, of motorways of the sea intended for travelers by water, with the development of adequate infrastructures allowing intermodality with in particular land transport, and thus calls on Member States to develop initiatives in this direction. Obviously, the usual doxa of the perfect right-thinking MEP runs through the entire report: the emphasis is on the development of low-polluting fleets, with personnel trained to ensure maximum safety, general access to people with reduced mobility. , and even taking into account the needs of cyclists. The politically correct shortcomings of the report, with the declared desire to create an additional single space for water travelers and its almost inevitable risk of harming what remains of the French commercial fleet, makes this report unacceptable.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- The interest of developing passenger transport by water is obvious.However, the ecological-European-integrationist ways, with the stated desire to create an additional unique space for travelers by waterway and its almost inevitable risk of harming what remains of the French commercial fleet makesthis unacceptable report.I therefore vote against.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Passenger ships play an important role for the mobility of EU citizens – more than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports of the same Member State. This report increases the importance and the potential of a sector that is one of the most sustainable ways to travel and is constantly increasing in consumer demand. Making better use of available capacity of WPT could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on harnessing the potential of passenger transport by water.While Cop 21 has just ended and Cop 22 is already in preparation, it is essential to reduce air pollution linked in particular to the saturation of certain means of transport such as road transport.Promoting passenger transport by water will also have the effect of making local transport networks more fluid in certain areas where tourists saturate the networks.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- Waterborne passenger transport is an area that has yet to be explored in Europe, where we need to recognize its potential.While most travelers travel from one point to another on public roads, often causing traffic jams, the potential of passenger transport by water remains untapped.Waterborne transport offers a safe, environmentally friendly and energy-efficient alternative for which Europe has all the necessary geographical and natural conditions.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ A crucial role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector is played by waterborne passenger transport, which includes ferries, inland ferries, barges and cruises. I have voted for this report that will enhance efficiency, environmental performance, quality of life and will provide lifeline services to remote communities.

name: Momchil NEKOV
