text: In written form. - I gave my support to this resolution because it emphasizes a measure that would not only benefit the development of river tourism in my country, but I also believe that it will improve the daily lives of many of my fellow citizens. In its resolution, the EP called on the Commission to support infrastructure investment in the transport of passengers by water, in particular in the hinterland of populated areas. I believe that such investments are of great benefit to Bulgarian citizens who live near the banks of the Danube and other rivers in the interior of the country. First of all, they help reduce congestion in large riparian cities, improving their environmental performance and increasing their comfort and quality of life. Secondly, through such infrastructure can be provided services to provide remote areas, as well as to develop the capacity of river tourism in the country.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - Passenger transport in the context of coastal transport (short sea shipping), inland and inland waterway ferries, urban and peripheral mobility, cruises and tourism, has great potential to use the surplus capacity available, both in in terms of infrastructure as well as in terms of ships and plays a key role in connecting the different regions of the European Union. We call on the Member States to promote and support local initiatives aimed at activating inland waterway transport as a way of supplying congestion, including through the development of distribution centers in river ports and the development of passenger transport, primarily for the areas concerned. to become more attractive to tourists. We welcome the efforts of the passenger shipping sector to make the transition to greener, more energy-efficient, lower-emission ships, developed as part of a European framework for greening shipping. This would lead to cheaper solutions that are sustainable, more attractive and thus more competitive from an economic perspective.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because, first of all, it proposes to remove the existing bottlenecks between the extended inland navigation system in Western Europe and the existing system in Eastern Europe, the links between which are currently in a state of.Secondly, the report calls on the European Commission to integrate the NPT into its EU mobility strategy and to take steps to reduce CO2 emissions in line with the COP 21 agreement. Last but not least, I support this report because it reiterates the EC andMember States' commitment to comply with environmental regulations to reduce air pollution, to monitor the quality of fuels and engines, with a view in particular to the use of those with more efficient fuel consumption.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- In my opinion, progress in the transport sector is necessary.The report also supports renewable energy sources as well as solar and wind energy for seagoing ships.I voted in favor of this report on the basis of the above points.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.It is important to develop the area of transport policy for more sustainable passenger transport and better waterway connections.The report calls for improved competitiveness through better infrastructure, environmental sustainability and quality and accessibility of service.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I support the report. It is necessary to make proper and efficient use of the potential of passenger water transport in order to make this sector cheaper, cleaner and greener. In particular, special attention must be paid to inland waterways in Eastern Europe. It is necessary to improve their quality and infrastructure, increase their competitiveness and connect them to the inland waterway system of Western Europe in order to create a common area for passenger water transport. It should be noted that waterborne shipping is an environmentally friendly mode of transport. Therefore, greater efforts are needed to improve environmental sustainability in order to move towards less polluting and energy efficient ships. Sustainable, attractive and economically competitive solutions are needed. Safety, quality of service and accessibility need to be improved Particular attention must be paid to Baltic Sea standards, fuel quality and more fuel-efficient engines. Greater efforts and progress are needed in research and innovation, with a special focus on the practical application of renewable resources, solar and wind energy in the passenger water transport sector.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report which makes recommendations for improving inland waterway transport services, including sea ferries, inland waterway ferries, barges and cruise ships, and the proper integration of inland waterway and of the ticketing system. Large numbers of workers in Europe travel by road, creating bottlenecks and delays in Europe's urban areas. Making better use of the available capabilities of water passenger transport could help not only to reduce traffic congestion and CO2 emissions but also to improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. The use of existing European Union funding should be fully exploited for the further development of inland and coastal water transport.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal as I believe that waterborne passenger transport (TPVA), including sea ferries, inland waterway ferries, barges and cruise ships, play a key role in thewithin the European transport sector of greater efficiency and sustainability.They are means of transport that not only do not damage the environment but also protect the passengers themselves.Unfortunately, to date, a large number of people travel using road transport, increasing city pollution, while the use of these maritime means of transport would reduce CO2 emissions, but also improve the quality of theair.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – Waterborne passenger transport, including maritime ferries, inland ferries, barges and cruises, plays a crucial role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, assisted by policies that address safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness as well as service quality, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility. As a member coming from a country with access to the River Danube, I support this report because I believe that a better and more efficient framework for travelling on waterborne passenger transport will be beneficial to the Member States economies and the cities with access to major rivers.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported this report because we have multiple benefits from using maritime transport for passenger transport purposes. Today, 75% of European trade with other countries and 40% of freight transport within Europe is done by water, and we must add passenger transport to these transport statistics precisely because of its cost-effectiveness and minimum CO2 emissions. Due to its geographical features, Europe has great potential for the establishment of a quality network of water transport of passengers, whether it is the sea or rivers, and if we achieve it, we are making progress in achieving more European goals. First of all, we make transport easier for passengers and make it more economically accessible. Such passenger transport could have a particular impact on tourism, especially in Croatia, which has an indented coastline with a large number of larger and smaller islands that are often not well connected. Apart from tourism, the development of such traffic would increase the quality of life of the islanders themselves, who today have to travel 3-6 hours to cover a distance of 94 km (example: Split-Lastovo), whether they have to go to the doctor or to the bank. We must also take into account the goals we have set for ourselves in terms of reducing environmental pollution, to which this report is in line. By encouraging people to use this type of transport, through reasonable costs and quality of service, we would reduce the daily use of cars and thus air pollution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- The interest of developing passenger transport by water is obvious.However, the ecological-European-integrationist ways, with the declared desire to create an additional unique space for travelers by waterway and its almost inevitable risk of harming what remains of the French commercial fleet,make this report unacceptable.I therefore vote against.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The geography of Europe offers extraordinary opportunities for water transport, thanks to the presence of many rivers, waterways, long coasts and islands. The transport of passengers by water (TPVA) represents, in many cases, a valid alternative to road transport, and would allow to limit congestion and delays on urban routes which, unfortunately, we all know very well. It could contribute to the improvement of environmental well-being, thanks to the reduction of CO2 emissions and other pollutants harmful to our health. Finally, the development of water transport, both for inland and coastal routes, would represent a valid tool for the promotion of tourism, even in areas outside the traditional routes. I therefore share the recommendations made in the report for the enhancement of passenger transport services on ferries, barges and cruise ships and for their integration into existing public transport networks, also improving the integrated ticket system. European funds should fully contribute to the development of new waterborne passenger routes and new technologies that further improve their safety, energy efficiency and accessibility for people with reduced mobility.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The geographical features of Europe, its long coasts and the many islands and rivers offer excellent opportunities for sustainable waterborne passenger transport and must be given more attention in the framework of the EU's transport policy agenda. Efforts should focus on creating a "single waterway area". Waterborne passenger transport offers great potential for the use of available surplus capacity both in terms of infrastructure and vessels and plays a key role in connecting different regions of the European Union, making it an important factor in improving cohesion. The inclusion of water passenger transport in urban public transport networks could significantly improve efficiency in terms of mobility, environmental protection, quality of life, affordability, relief of land transport networks and comfort in cities. The Commission should also take into account that tourism in coastal regions and islands is underdeveloped due to a lack of connectivity. There is a great demand for quality transport services in these areas. The water passenger transport sector is also important in areas where there is currently no economic justification, such as less populated remote islands. A framework for ensuring connections with islands and island and remote regions should be promoted, with measures to enable better quality of ferries and suitable terminals.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The development of transport via inland waterways - maritime and inland - is a very important issue in relation to the mobility of passengers and goods, with enormous environmental and economic benefits. The operation of this transport system requires the adaptation of natural conditions and infrastructure. In recent years, the disinvestment in equipment and infrastructure, as well as job insecurity in this system, have jeopardized many services. This report is based on a good principle, which is the development of transport on waterways, as a factor of territorial, social and economic cohesion; as a factor in meeting the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions and increasing the environmental sustainability of transport; as a safer and more controllable medium. However, the way in which the sector's development objectives are achieved are the same that have led this and other transport systems to privatization, deregulation, loss of quality of service and, in certain cases, abandonment - the precepts of the Book Transport Whiteboard, the Connecting Europe Facility, the Trans-European Transport Network and, as a form of outstanding financing, the ESIF. Recognizing the importance of the sector, we cannot support this report.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ Waterborne passenger transport is an environmentally and consumer friendly transport mode, and a vital service for tourists and commuters in remote and coastal areas. I firmly believe further measures can and should be taken to promote this mode of transport which can have a positive effect on economic development along coastal areas, while also relieving congestion on land. I am pleased that the report makes recommendations to improve ferry, barge and cruise services for passengers, including proper integration of waterborne passenger transport into existing public transport networks and improving integrated ticketing. Our group stressed an emphasis on safety and security, with a focus on developing environmentally friendly services, services for people with limited mobility, and the promotion for tourism in addition to commuters. I think the use of existing EU funding efficiently contributes to developing further the inland and coastal waterborne transport routes to benefit both tourists and commuters.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - Through this own-initiative report, Parliament has the possibility to provide the necessary inputs to move towards the modernization of the existing fleet and port facilities. We have to set ourselves the ambitious goal of helping to make the EU the world leader in maritime research and innovation, and to do so, I believe that public institutions must work closely with European shipowners and industry and in particular with those sectors. , such as that of cruising, which have been able to grow and innovate despite the persistence of the economic crisis. We must support efforts to switch to the use of "cleaner" ships, within a European framework aimed at making waterborne transport more environmentally friendly, including through the adoption of tax incentives for boat builders as well as that the fixing of certain times. Through my work as EPP shadow rapporteur, I have brought the following issues to the attention of the rapporteur: fleet conversion and energy efficiency policies; cooperation with shipowners; policies for improving dockside services and their technological upgrading; reorganization policies of travel tickets and creation of unique digital travel cards and pollution abatement policies. I voted in favor of his approval.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- I support the proposals to simplify and streamline the common safety rules for passenger ships in EU waters with a view to improving safety and competitiveness, and to clarify, simplify and update the rules taking into account legal and technical developments.However, in view of the call for decarbonisation and the promotion of non-fossil fuels, I abstained from voting.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which calls on Member States and the Commission to organize more maritime passenger transport (in particular sea and inland ferries, barges and cruises).The enhancement and strengthening of the accessibility, safety and sustainability of the maritime transport sector will significantly improve the efficiency of mobility, environmental performance, quality of life, affordability, decongestion of land transport networks and the comfort of cities.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Passenger ships, including sea ferries, river ferries, barges and cruise ships, play an important role in the mobility of Union citizens. Over 400 million people pass through EU ports each year and 120 million passengers are transported between ports in the same Member State. Passenger transport by inland waterway plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector and should be supported by policies that take into account safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness, as well as service quality, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility. EU legislation on the safety of passenger ships has been adopted over a period of 15 years. This legislation improved the safety of human life on passenger ships operating in EU waters and facilitated search and rescue operations. In order to increase the potential of this type of means of transport it is important to reinforce the application of existing rules and to simplify the current regulatory framework, in order to eliminate outdated or overlapping requirements. I therefore voted in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the EU is once again trying to adopt a one size fits all policy. The UK as a island nation has considerable expertise when it comes to issues relating to shipping and passenger transportation on the sea. The report does touch on some very relevant topics such as reducing fossil fuel requirement, however it goes too far by calling for decarbonisation but does not provide any alternative. The report also goes on to claim that the EU is responsible for facilitating Search and Rescue operations through the introduction of the EU passenger ship safety legislation, however, the UK has had Search and Rescue operations in place since the 1920’s. It just goes to show that this report is both inaccurate and misleading and in addition to the reasons already mentioned I felt that I should vote against it.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- Passenger transport by inland waterways, including sea ferries, river ferries, barges and cruise ships, plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, supported by policies that addressaccount safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness, as well as the quality of services, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The transport of passengers by sea and inland waterways offers great potential in terms of the use of excess capacity available both in terms of infrastructure and ships, it plays a fundamental role in connecting the different regions of the Union (especially the outermost) and is an important factor to improve cohesion. Likewise, the cruise and ferry activity encourages coastal tourism, one of the main maritime activities in Europe. This report encourages Member States, regional and local authorities, and the Commission to take into account passenger transport by sea and inland waterways and, in particular, to improve the associated infrastructure, both in the core network and in the network. global, within the framework of the TEN-T and the MCE, reinforcing its interconnection with inland railway infrastructures, among others, as well as through the provision of infrastructures and information that satisfy the mobility needs of all passengers. It also proposes measures to achieve a more competitive and cleaner sector, such as improving connections with urban centers, reducing the environmental impact of ships or updating passenger ship safety regulations. For this reason, I have voted favorably.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on harnessing the potential of water passenger transport as passenger water transport plays a key role in strengthening the sustainability and efficiency of the European transport sector. In fact, improving the use of available passenger transport capacities by water would reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and transport services. The development of innovative technologies based on solar and wind energy would also make ships cleaner and more economical. In addition, the measures provided for in this legislation would revitalize the tourism potential of many regions of Europe. Finally, this legislation also provides for strengthening the safety of passengers carried by ships by ensuring that these ships meet the Union's common safety standards.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- Waterborne passenger transport can become a sustainable alternative to road transport, which has reached the limits of its development in many cities.I wholeheartedly welcome the idea of promoting the development of this transport and the document before us.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I voted against this report because, although it has interesting elements, it lacks critical focus on fundamental issues to build a good long-term transport policy. For example, the evaluation of alternatives during the planning and management of infrastructures or the differentiation of types of ships and lines according to their social function or their environmental performance. It is not the same to maintain and improve the secondary port network than to build industrial mega-ports that then remain underused. A regular ferry that boosts the local economy and improves citizen mobility is not the same as a mass tourism macro-cruise. In addition, the report advocates the introduction of gas infrastructures in TEN-T ports, which is a red line for us. In Spain we cannot afford to spend millions of public money on infrastructure and gas transportation that could be used to promote locally generated renewable energy, create long-term sustained employment and reduce our enormous energy dependence.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted for the report on unlocking the potential of waterborne passenger transport.Water-based passenger transport plays an important role in achieving a sustainable and efficient European transport sector.With so many rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coastlines and islands, Europe has great potential for water transport, which is more sustainable than other modes of transport in many areas.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report because it does not add any political priority in the field of passenger transport by inland waterways, and furthermore, it reinforces the presence of unsustainable resources such as liquefied natural gas (LNG).The report does not include specific references to the role that the public sector should play in the development of these communication channels, maintaining a market approach that to date has only inhibited their development.However, despite little clarity, what it does make a clear reference to is the transport of LNG by these routes, consolidating the great commitment to this fossil resource and the strong impact that it has on extraction or storage areas such asThis is the case of the Doñana Natural Park.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - Taking into account the geographical set-up of Europe: greater development of the inland waterway passenger transport sector in the European Union would, for example, make it possible to offer connections with island regions and isolated areas, would facilitate the use of public transport in coastal areas, inland waterways and large urban agglomerations and would reduce pollution. Already 400 million citizens pass through the ports of the European Union every year and 161,000 people directly employed in the sector. In order to achieve a more efficient and sustainable European transport sector, I believe that the approval of this report represents a step forward for the simplification and improvement of common rules, as well as for the implementation of future policy initiatives in this sector. Competitiveness, environmental sustainability, safety and cross-border cooperation and quality of services, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility are the key aspects of this initiative. I have therefore decided to vote in favor.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this because the EU is once again trying to adopt a one size fits all policy. The UK as an island nation has considerable expertise when it comes to issues relating to shipping and passenger transportation on the sea. The report does touch on some very relevant topics such as reducing the carbon footprint, however it goes too far by calling for decarbonisation but does not provide any alternative. The report also goes onto claim that the EU is responsible for facilitating search and rescue operations through the introduction of the EU passenger ship safety legislation, however, the UK has had search and rescue operations in place since the 1920s. It just goes to show that this report is both inaccurate and misleading and in addition to the reasons already mentioned I felt that I should vote against it.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing - Passenger ships play an important role in the mobility of EU citizens.More than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers carried between ports in the same Member State.I still see potential, for example, in the use of shuttle ferries, which could be used more in busy urban and interurban areas.I also consider it necessary to further reduce CO2 emissions in this mode of transport as well.I voted in favor.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - Water passenger transport is an ideal alternative to solving the growing problems of congested roads throughout the European Union. It is the most sustainable way to travel, and its inclusion in the city's public transport networks would significantly improve efficiency in terms of mobility, environmental protection, quality of life, affordability and comfort in cities. Although the Republic of Croatia is primarily an Adriatic and Mediterranean country facing the sea and maritime transport, an extremely favorable geographical position of inland waterways plays an important role, with emphasis on the Danube River, which gives Croatia a geostrategic position in enabling intermodal transport . However, this sector in Croatia has a number of weaknesses that need to be addressed as soon as possible. Systematic work is needed to address shortcomings within the sector in terms of organization, fleet modernization, education, infrastructure construction, improving cooperation with surrounding countries, and taking into account the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which guarantees unhindered access for passengers with disabilities. reduced mobility. I supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and the Council bearing in mind the above factors as well as the objectives achieved at the COP 21 conference in terms of reducing CO2 emissions, all in order to contribute to water transport sustainable solutions for cheaper, cleaner and greener transport sector.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - I supported the motion for a resolution on unleashing the potential of passenger water transport, because I already consider passenger water transport to be one of the most sustainable modes of transport of any kind, and I think that this form of transport deserves to be at the forefront. The importance of passenger water transport is also evidenced by the fact that more than 400 million people pass through EU ports each year, with 120 million passengers carried between ports in the same Member State. I am convinced that Europe's geographical conditions, with its long coastlines, many islands and rivers, create extraordinary opportunities for sustainable passenger water transport, and I believe that they will play an even more important role in connecting the different regions of the EU in the near future. Although in recent years there has been an intensive development of vessels designed for different modes of navigation (eg river-sea vessels, which are able to navigate even in shallow waters) and interconnections between coastal regions and islands, it is essential to strengthen enforcement within the EU. existing rules and the current regulatory framework has been simplified to address existing shortcomings in passenger water transport.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The European Union, with its long coastlines, islands and many rivers, offers excellent opportunities for the development of sustainable waterborne passenger transport, which plays an important role in connecting European regions and can make a significant contribution to strengthening cohesion. Due to its intensive technological development, e.g. development of vessels for transport by river and sea, water passenger transport has long been offered as a more environmentally friendly mode of transport and an alternative to congested road transport in the direction of urban centers. Greater use of water passenger transport capacity would make a significant contribution, in particular to reducing road congestion and emissions and improving air quality. Parliament's report rightly points out that waterborne passenger transport should play a greater role in EU and Member States' transport policy, and encourages the Commission and the Member States to improve their infrastructure by strengthening transport links and developing motorways of the sea. Among other things, the report proposes better integration of water passenger transport into urban and regional public transport networks in order to improve mobility and quality of life and relieve land transport networks. Based on the above and the fact that the report strongly emphasizes the key importance of water passenger transport for the development of sustainable tourism in coastal, island and lake regions and its connection to the trans-European cycling network to enhance the attractiveness of European regions, I supported the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - The geography of Europe offers great potential for passenger water transport.Better use of vessel overcapacity and infrastructure will help connect and develop regions, the environment and facilitate land transport.Therefore, a framework needs to be designed that also ensures quality, safety and environmental sustainability.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ Passenger ships play an important role for the mobility of EU citizens – more than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports of the same Member State. This report increases the importance and the potential of a sector that is one of the most sustainable ways to travel and is constantly increasing in consumer demand. Making better use of available capacity of WPT could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the European Parliament on unlocking the potential of passenger transport by water.The report calls on the Commission to take measures to reduce CO2 emissions in accordance with the agreement reached at the Paris Climate Conference (COP 21).I refuse.The report calls for photovoltaic systems on the buildings of the port terminals.The report welcomes the Commission's proposal to establish harmonized standards for the qualification of crew members and masters.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The geographical features of Europe, its long coasts and numerous islands, rivers and canals offer excellent opportunities for sustainable water transport.The inclusion of water passenger transport in urban public transport networks could significantly improve environmental protection, relieve land transport networks in cities and employ excess capacity of water infrastructure and vessels.Eurostat is invited to include in its statistics on passengers on sea cruises passengers embarked or disembarked from ships in each transit port.We welcome the Commission's new legislative proposals that seek to simplify and improve common rules on the safety of passenger ships in EU waters.I support this Report because it shows the great potential of using busy waterways as excellent alternatives to congested roads leading to city centers.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on unlocking the potential of waterborne passenger transport.Thus, for those of us who use shipping services mainly for holiday purposes, and even more so for those who depend on them on a daily basis, the availability and good connection of shipping services with other transport connections is important.Adequate involvement of passenger transport in projects that promote transport multimodality, such as the integrated European ticketing system, the trans-European transport networks and the Connecting Europe Facility, is important.I welcome the report, which draws attention to a series of necessary changes in shipping, which would increase its use with a number of positive consequences, such as less road congestion.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- Today, I supported the report on harnessing the potential of passenger water transport, which aims to simplify and improve common rules for the safety of ships carrying passengers in EU waters in order to increase safety and competition.The report supports not only the quality of services, but also the rights of passengers and barrier-free accessibility in passenger water transport, including sea ferries, inland ferries, boats and cruises.It also supports the development of sustainable tourism, for example in overcoming seasonal fluctuations, especially in remote and peripheral regions of the Union, such as coastal, island, lake and rural regions.Better use of available passenger water capacity could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions from road transport, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services in general.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - Water passenger transport plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. However, the process that has been done so far is minimal. The report does not differentiate between small regular ship services and huge leisure cruises, nor between strategic implications, such as their contribution to social and long-term territorial cohesion or to higher overall environmental performance. Nor is there a call for proper social, economic and environmental assessment in the design and financing of new related infrastructure. In general, the report touches on the issue of water passenger transport and that is why we abstained.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- It is necessary to fully exploit all waterways to help many areas financially, but at the same time there must be increased safety measures for both people and the environment.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because I agree that waterborne passenger transport, including sea ferries, inland ferries, barges and leisure cruises, play a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. I agree with the author that by making better use of the capacities available in waterborne passenger transport and by making further improvements, it can not only help reduce traffic congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. The report describes that waterborne transport is already one of the most sustainable travel options and I agree that we have further potential to make ships even more environmentally friendly and energy efficient. However, I believe that this can only be achieved through research into innovative technologies, in areas such as solar and wind energy, shore-side electricity and alternative fuels. The report also offers a solution, naming the EU funds available for them, such as the Cohesion, Structural, Regional Funds, INTERREG, Horizon 2020, the European Networking Facility, TEN-T and the ESF.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing.- Despite the negative effects of the financial crisis, the ferry and liner industry has consolidated in recent years and its importance has grown significantly.Today, the sector employs around 160,000 people and offers important connections in coastal, inland and urban areas and is particularly important for peripheral regions.At the same time, water transport is widely regarded as one of the most sustainable modes of passenger transport.Attention should be paid to the potential efficiency gains from the strengthening of passenger waterborne transport and the possibility of introducing integrated ticketing to increase coordination between the different modes.Our goal should be to create a single area for waterborne passenger transport within which it would be possible to simplify the administrative burden for cross-border passenger transport.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report.I also voted in favor of environmental standards, for example, following the example of the Sulfur Directive.For, although Finland negotiated its position poorly on the sulfur directive, efforts must also be made at EU level in environmental regulation, for example in accordance with the Paris Climate Agreement.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - Unlocking the potential of passenger shipping contributes to achieving the EU's goal of becoming the world leader in maritime research and innovation, set out in its maritime transport policy strategy by 2018. The growth-enhanced development of passenger shipping exponential development of technological developments, as an alternative to road transport, is an ecological mode of transport, with beneficial effects on the environment and on the quality of life of citizens. Also, a capitalization of the potential of the NPT, based on an adequate infrastructure, achieved also through the development of projects co-financed from EU funds, generates the development not only of tourism, but also of other sectors of the European economy. I agree that an analysis of all NPT projects co-financed by EU funds, as well as a summary of the implementation of EU NPT strategies, in conjunction with the proper dissemination of all this statistical information, is needed to address harnessing the potential of passenger shipping, as this sector has important added value for the European economy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The success of European transport policies will largely depend on how the European Union succeeds in redirecting transport flows in all existing ways, as well as on the quality of the services provided. Against the background of a growing demand, but also in the context of a growing concern for reducing emissions, water transport can be the solution of a sustainable and safe transport, which will give a new impetus to economic development in riparian and coastal areas. . This report recommends that the Member States and the Commission pay more attention to passenger water transport, starting with the rehabilitation of the necessary infrastructure and ending with rigorous training of staff in this sector. Better use of this mode would have significant effects on connectivity, especially in remote areas, and would also contribute to the development of the tourism industry, providing improved access to European tourist destinations. At the same time, Parliament calls on the European Executive to step up cooperation with the Member States in order to attract European funds, especially those for SMEs and cohesion policies, in order to draw up a transport strategy appropriate to the needs of each region. TEN-T network.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for the report.Even if waterway transport is already one of the most sustainable modes of transport, it is possible to make ships cleaner and more energy efficient through investments in research and innovative technologies, for example in this way.which concerns solar and wind energy, terrestrial electricity and alternative fuels, while applying the principle of technological neutrality.This goes hand in hand with the availability and use of Union resources, such as cohesion, structural and regional funds, Interreg, Horizon 2020, CEF, TEN-T and EFSI.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Although waterborne passenger transport is essential for the connectivity of certain European regions, very little attention is devoted to it in EU transport policies, resulting in a lack of statistics, investment and integration within the transport chain as a whole. The report, which I supported, advises the EU to work towards the establishment of a single area for waterborne passenger transport with the aim to simplify administrative procedures in cross-border passenger shipping and overall to offer a better quality of services.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. - The issue of climate change caused by anthropogenic activity represents a threat that must be dealt with promptly by Europe. River transport of passengers represents a low environmental impact sector, which contributes to employment and which is recording a significant increase in demand, especially in the regions of Central and Eastern Europe (+ 17% in 2015). Given the potential of the sector, I believe that the European Parliament should move along two legislative lines: on the one hand, work on proposals that benefit the safety of citizens on river transport; on the other hand, to encourage research funding to modernize the sector and contribute to the reduction of air pollution. I believe that the equalization of fares and travel documents and the easing of administrative burdens on the sector are essential for this modernization process. It is our duty to support European transport networks which have the least impact on the environment and to make choices in the interest of citizens to develop the economies of peripheral regions, primarily by improving the quality of public transport services.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written. - I support the Motion for a resolution to realize the potential of passenger transport by water. This resolution will enable better use to be made of the available water transport capacity, of which there are many, given the European geographical features, which include numerous rivers, waterways, estuaries, long coasts and islands. In addition, it is an alternative to crowded city roads, increases traffic safety and lays the groundwork for reducing car emissions. Of particular importance is the call to the European Commission to emphasize the importance of the water passenger transport sector in developing sustainable tourism and addressing the seasonal nature of tourism, especially in remote and peripheral regions of the Union such as coastal, island, lake and rural regions. Tourism in coastal regions and on islands is underdeveloped due to a lack of connectivity and the Commission should take into account that there is a greater demand for quality transport services in these areas.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - The report on the realization of the potential of passenger transport by water is a step towards simplifying and improving the rules of the Member States on passenger transport by water. Namely, the report promotes the development of motorways of the sea with the aim of achieving the integration of this type of transport with other transport networks and types of transport and the removal of obstacles to unhindered passenger transport, the so-called bottlenecks. I particularly support the recognition of the importance of this sector in developing sustainable tourism and tackling the seasonal nature of tourism, especially in remote and peripheral regions, and calling on the Commission, Member States and local and regional authorities to make the most of EU funding opportunities. offers small and medium-sized enterprises as focal points for the promotion of tourism services, including subsidies to local communities in peripheral regions. As this report provides a framework for more effective links between islands, island regions and remote regions, I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on unlocking the potential of passenger transport by water. Waterborne passenger transport, including sea ferries, inland waterway ferries, barges and passenger ships, plays a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector. A large proportion of daily migrant transport takes place by road, creating bottlenecks. Greater use of passenger water transport would facilitate this and reduce CO2 emissions. Most of Europe is characterized by navigable rivers, and in many areas of Europe, travel by ferry or passenger ship would be more sustainable, easier and faster, which would increase the social and economic well-being of the region. Water passenger transport could also be used for tourism purposes. Passenger ships play an important role in the mobility of European citizens, with more than 400 million people passing through EU ports each year, of which 120 million are passengers between ports in the same Member State. EU legislation on passenger ship safety has been slowly introduced over the last 15 years, mostly in response to accidents, which has improved the safety of waterborne passenger transport. Although waterborne passenger transport is already one of the most sustainable modes of transport, it can still be improved, especially in the field of innovative technologies for cleaner and more energy-efficient vessels.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - I voted against this report because, although it has interesting elements, it lacks critical focus on fundamental issues to build a good long-term transport policy. For example, the evaluation of alternatives during the planning and management of infrastructures or the differentiation of types of ships and lines according to their social function or their environmental performance. It is not the same to maintain and improve the secondary port network than to build industrial mega-ports that then remain underused. A regular ferry that boosts the local economy and improves citizen mobility is not the same as a mass tourism macro-cruise. In addition, the report advocates the introduction of gas infrastructures in TEN-T ports, which is a red line for us. In Spain we cannot afford to spend millions of public money on infrastructure and gas transportation that could be used to promote locally generated renewable energy, create long-term sustained employment and reduce our enormous energy dependence.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - The report starts from the double obvious observation that, on the one hand, European geography with its rivers, coasts and islands lends itself particularly well to river, sea and lake transport. On the other hand, this mode of transport is under-exploited in favor of road transport. This leads to traffic congestion and increased pollution, especially in cities. The rapporteur wants the creation of a "single space for the transport of passengers by water", which the FN-RBM MEPs have always opposed. This creation would inevitably accelerate the replacement, at least partially, of French buildings by foreign buildings and personnel. It calls for the creation, as for the transport of sea freight, of motorways of the sea intended for travelers by water, with the development of adequate infrastructure allowing inter-modality with in particular land transport, and calls for thus the Member States to develop initiatives in this direction. Obviously, the emphasis is on developing low-polluting fleets, with personnel trained to ensure maximum safety, general access for people with reduced mobility, and even taking into account the needs of cyclists. All this should allow the development of tourism, "sustainable" ... I voted against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution is positive and important, but some important issues have been overlooked, including the need to simplify the current regulations and the emphasis on the safety of the crew and passengers of inland vessels, which becomes particularly important in the context of the immigration crisis.A great opportunity could be the inclusion of passenger waterborne transport in the framework of systems allowing for the use of two or more modes of transport, which may be especially important in large agglomerations.The lack of these demands made me abstain from the vote on the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Waterborne passenger transport, including sea ferries, inland waterways, barges and leisure cruises, play a key role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, backed by safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness,and supported by policies on quality of service, passenger rights and accessibility.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I voted against this report because, although it has interesting elements, it lacks critical focus on fundamental issues to build a good long-term transport policy. For example, the evaluation of alternatives during the planning and management of infrastructures or the differentiation of types of ships and lines according to their social function or their environmental performance. It is not the same to maintain and improve the secondary port network than to build industrial mega-ports that then remain underused. A regular ferry that boosts the local economy and improves citizen mobility is not the same as a mass tourism macro-cruise. In addition, the report advocates the introduction of gas infrastructures in TEN-T ports, which is a red line for us. In Spain we cannot afford to spend millions of public money on infrastructure and gas transportation that could be used to promote locally generated renewable energy, create long-term sustained employment and reduce our enormous energy dependence.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- Welcomes the Commission's new legislative proposals to simplify and improve common safety rules for ships carrying passengers in EU waters in order to increase safety and competition by ensuring that the rules are clearer and simpler and in line with legal and technological developments.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on unleashing the potential of waterborne passenger transport. Waterborne passenger transport, including maritime ferries, inland ferries, barges and cruises, plays a crucial role in achieving a more sustainable and efficient European transport sector, assisted by policies that address safety, environmental standards, cross-border cooperation and competitiveness as well as service quality, passenger rights and barrier-free accessibility. A large number of commuters in Europe travel by road, creating bottlenecks, congestion and delays on Europe’s urban routes. Furthermore, excess capacity of waterborne passenger transport vessels and infrastructure should be considered in the field of tourism. I voted in favour because I believe that even though waterborne transport is already one of the most sustainable ways to travel, there is further potential to make vessels cleaner and more energy efficient through investment in research and innovative technologies.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written. - Community legislation on safety in maritime traffic has been applied for a period of 15 years, having improved the safety of passengers and facilitated search and rescue operations in the event of an accident. However, there is still scope to intensify the application of the current rules by the Member States and to simplify the current regulatory framework with the aim of eliminating overlapping requirements. In this sense, what this report proposes is a set of measures in terms of competitiveness, environmental sustainability, safety, protection and quality and accessibility of services. In Europe, geography offers extraordinary opportunities for passenger transport by inland waterway. In fact, annually more than 400 million people pass through the ports of the Union. In order to support all those proposals that contribute to the development of this type of transport and that advance along the path of greater intermodality, social cohesion, improvement of the environment and more sustainable and efficient socioeconomic development, I have supported this text with my vote.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted against this report because it does not add any political priority in the field of passenger transport by inland waterways, and furthermore, it reinforces the presence of unsustainable resources such as liquefied natural gas (LNG).The report does not include specific references to the role that the public sector should play in the development of these communication channels, maintaining a market approach that to date has only inhibited their development.However, despite little clarity, what it does make a clear reference to is the transport of LNG by these routes, consolidating the great commitment to this fossil resource and the strong impact that it has on extraction or storage areas such asThis is the case of the Doñana Natural Park.This is why I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted with my Socialist colleagues in favour of this report because passenger ships play an important role for the mobility of EU citizens – more than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports of the same Member State. This report increases the importance and the potential of a sector that is one of the most sustainable ways to travel and is constantly increasing in consumer demand. Making better use of available capacity of WPT could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor, because in recent years there has been a trend of intensive development of ships for various waters, for example ships for rivers and for the sea, which meet the requirements for sea-going vessels and can also sail in shallow water.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The development of transport via waterways, maritime and inland waterways, has potential economic and environmental benefits in terms of mobility of passengers and goods.It is relatively safe and controllable, it can be a factor inducing territorial, social and economic cohesion, in addition to helping to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.It is not understood, therefore, that, in recent years, the disinvestment in equipment and infrastructure and job insecurity in this sector have jeopardized so many services.Of course, this implied public investment to stimulate, guide and frame private investment.The option was quite different: privatizing and sterilizing public investment with austerity, condemning the sector to a vegetative state, to the disgrace of the populations and workers and the delight of big capital.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The rapporteur calls for the reduction of bureaucracy in cross-border passenger shipping, more interconnectivity and the creation of motorways of the sea (also through third countries).The "bottlenecks" arising in this context between the developed system of Western European inland waterways and the existing - less developed - Eastern European system must be eliminated.In my opinion, the potential of passenger transport by ship is too small to be able to make a significant contribution to the sustainable and efficient transport sector.Since the EU has already adopted several macro strategies for the Danube region, the Adriatic Sea and the Ionian Sea and for the Baltic Sea region, and the present text does not call for the straightening of existing waterways, but the need for action for the Austrian system is rather small, I have abstained.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report aimed at unlocking the potential of inland waterway passenger transport.Considering that the geographical layout of Europe, with its long coasts and its numerous rivers and islands, offers extraordinary opportunities for the sustainable transport of passengers by water and considering that this type of transport in the cabotage, ferrymaritime and inland, cruise and tourism offers plays a fundamental role in the connections between the different regions of the European Union, I believe it is a fundamental factor for strengthening cohesion.The S & amp; D group has managed to place an emphasis on safety, the development of sustainable environmentally friendly services and the provision of more efficient services for people with reduced mobility.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Passenger ships play an important role for the mobility of EU citizens – more than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year, with 120 million passengers transported between ports of the same Member State. This report increases the importance and the potential of a sector that is one of the most sustainable ways to travel and is constantly increasing due to consumer demand. Making better use of available capacity of WPT could not only help reduce congestion and CO2 emissions, but also improve air quality and provide better transport services overall. As a small island with a long coastline and many ports, this report is of particular significance to Britain although Brexit negotiations may present many challenges in fully realising the potential of WPT.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I supported the report on unlocking the potential of passenger water transport.This report dealt with new legislation which proposes, in particular, the simplification and improvement of common rules on the safety of passengers carried by ships in European waters.I think that the issue of passenger water transport is very interesting at the moment and we should think of it as one of the sustainable and environmentally friendly options for relieving very busy road transport.However, this requires an interconnection of different modes of transport and that the legislation reflects the latest technological developments with a strong emphasis on safety.I also appreciate the articles calling for consideration to be given to including water transport tickets in integrated schemes.I also think that exploiting the potential of this type of transport would be very helpful to the inhabitants of islands or remote regions.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - Water transport is not only cheap, fast, but also environmentally friendly means of transport. Its importance in creating a single European transport network is extremely important. Unfortunately, in many Member States there are significant disparities in the level of infrastructure development, the number of available connections or the variety of offers. In Poland, inland transport, also in the passenger dimension, has been neglected for many years, despite the fact that its potential in our geographical conditions is very large. It is not only about communication possibilities, but also about the chance to create many jobs in shipyards and in modernizing infrastructure. The importance of this means of transport for the development of the tourist offer is also invaluable, which in many regions of Poland already includes the use of passenger water transport. For the Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship it is a key topic and a chance for development by creating new communication opportunities for investors. The strategic location of my region means that it could be an important junction for water transport not only from the point of view of Poland, but the entire Central and Eastern Europe. However, a huge financial effort is needed to thoroughly modernize the existing infrastructure. Such an effort is impossible to bear without the support of the European Union. The report we are voting on today is an important step towards restoring the proper place of passenger water transport on the communication map of Poland.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Taylor report for agreeing with the proposals presented to explore the potential of passenger transport by inland waterways. This mode of transport has the potential to contribute to the decarbonisation of the sector, to serve as a reliable alternative for the consumer and to promote the decongestion of land roads in coastal areas. I underline that more than 400 million people pass through EU ports every year and around 120 million passengers are transported between ports in the same Member State, so I support proposals to invest in less polluting and more energy efficient technologies . In this context, I would like to highlight that I presented as a rapporteur for the European strategy for LNG, within the framework of the Environment Committee, a proposal for the use of liquefied natural gas to decarbonize the maritime sector and heavy transport. I also emphasize the need to make funds available to boost projects in this regard.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- I support my colleague Taylor's report on the potential of water passenger transport.Due to all development perspectives, water transport is of great importance for tourism, the economy and the quality of everyday life of citizens, especially those living on remote islands with difficult access to basic services such as medical treatment or banking and education.Water passenger transport is also environmentally friendly because it is cost-effective and emits a minimum amount of carbon dioxide.The European potential in the development of passenger transport is quite large, both due to the branched river network and due to the long coastline and indented coastline.The establishment of a quality waterway network is a precondition for the economic development of those parts of the union which, due to the lack of transport (road or railway) infrastructure, do not have the same development path.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the Report on unlocking the potential of waterborne passenger transport.The geography of Europe with its long coasts and many islands and rivers offers exceptional opportunities for sustainable water passenger transport.Water passenger and water freight, however, face different challenges and have different needs related to infrastructure, environmental challenges, operational issues, security and connections between ports and cities.Given the great potential and desirability of integrating water transport into the framework of multimodal mobility, I agree that there is a need to invest in improving the infrastructure of water networks, in developing expertise in the maritime sector in the EU.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Poverty reduction is a fundamental objective of European development policy, as also written in article 208 of the TFEU.A key aspect in development cooperation is the involvement of civil society, specifically citizens, local communities and religious organizations as their contribution in promoting and implementing the aid effectiveness agenda.I believe that a further effort must be made by the Member States to make existing programs, such as the GPEDC, even more efficient, as the European Union is the main donor of development aid.These are the reasons why I voted in favor.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted against this report because it frames and legitimizes development cooperation within the market logic, reinforcing the role of companies within development cooperation mechanisms. The call included in the text for aid recipient countries to undertake "the introduction of market economy mechanisms", "the opening of their markets to global competition" or "the mobilization of private capital" is a conditioning and an attempt to use development cooperation to interfere with the sovereignty of each country when organizing and regulating its economy. I reject cooperation designed to open the door to business for European companies in impoverished countries. And therefore, we reject this report that demands and conditions - in pursuit of the "effectiveness" of the aid - that third countries enable the private sector to do business with basic services such as infrastructure, health or education. On the contrary, I understand that the effectiveness of aid passes through cooperation and the reinforcement of the role of the States of these impoverished countries, through the development of public services and through public control of strategic economic sectors.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted for this report.The European Union must ensure that aid is more effective for cooperation and development if we are to have a real impact on poverty alleviation in a context of growing humanitarian and development crises and of scarcity of resources..

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation. 2016 December. the fifth anniversary of the adoption of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation will be commemorated. On this occasion, it is important to assess the implementation of global commitments on aid and development effectiveness. The EU has taken important steps to increase aid transparency, improve joint programming, address conflict and vulnerability, and measure results. Here, we must acknowledge the progress that is currently being made in joint programming in more than half of the partner countries receiving EU development aid. However, further efforts are still needed to ensure effective coordination of development assistance, with clear and enforceable rules on issues such as democratic accountability of countries, alignment with country strategies and systems, predictability of funds and mutual accountability. We would like to hear from the European Commission what has been done in this area. It is also important that more needs to be done, both at EU and global level, to make aid and development cooperation more effective.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation, because it identifies a number of issues that could help promote the agenda on development effectiveness.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - The aim of this report is to help make development cooperation more effective. It is requested that all development actors - building on the commitments of the Paris to Busan agreements - make their efforts as effective as possible with a view to the ambitious goals of the 2030 Agenda and further promote the optimal use of public and private funds for development. As the world's largest development aid donor, the EU has a particular responsibility to improve the effectiveness of EU aid around the world and to make that aid more accountable. I share the rapporteur's view that the EU should take the lead in the global effort to advance the Aid Effectiveness Agenda and ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law remain central to developing countries.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- I abstained from this report which, although positive in that it aims to rationalize and make more effective development aid, also aims to pool cooperation actions, that is to say to avoid thiscompetence of the Member States to benefit the Commission, which is unacceptable.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text because it is necessary to make development cooperation as effective as possible.The aim is to meet the ambitious expectations set out in the 2030 agenda by making the best use of both public and private resources allocated to it.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: written.- The VVD has abstained in the final vote on the report on the effectiveness of development cooperation, because it is not up to the EU to oblige Member States to spend 0.7% of their GNP on development cooperation.In addition, Member States should retain the freedom to use funds earmarked for development cooperation to deal with acute crises such as the refugee crisis.The VVD supports proposals to spend development money more effectively by ensuring greater transparency and by fighting corruption in developing countries.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- - I voted in favor of the report on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation.The principles of aid effectiveness have made a clear contribution to progress towards the Millennium Development Goals in many countries, but progress remains uneven and development actors have not always fully implemented the principles in all countries.I therefore support the calls for all development actors to build on their commitments and to renew and step up their efforts to make development cooperation as effective as possible in order to achieve the 2030 Agenda.and make the best use of public and private development resources.We must use all development policy instruments to eradicate poverty and promote the goals of sustainable development.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The initiative sets out positive goals such as reducing poverty and inequality, supporting third world countries. To achieve these, it calls for the most efficient allocation of development resources. The draft rightly emphasizes that, in order to do all this, it is important that the governments, parliaments, multilateral organizations, civil society, trade unions and the private sector of some countries also take part in these tasks. Despite all these positives, one of the recitals formulates proposals that do not serve the interests of developing countries, but would enable their vulnerability and exploitation by recommending harmful economic policy measures. Given that the exception to the said paragraph was not supported by Parliament, I could not support the proposal despite its positive suggestions, I abstained during the vote.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The EU does not have the legitimacy to order countries, whether they are Member States or third countries, how or when they may use their foreign-aid budget, how much to spend or where it goes. UKIP does not support this growing influence and power of the EU and therefore voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This report points out the improvements to be made to the development aid programs offered to "developing" countries, particularly in Africa.European aid is the victim of a dispersion since nearly 75% of it is allocated by the Member States according to national procedures in order to maintain a strong link with former colonies (France, the Netherlands, Spain, etc..).It is a recurring problem in this committee: the need for increased coordination with national policies is never taken into account.I abstained on this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - The report, which I approved, recalls that the principles of aid effectiveness have clearly contributed to the progress made towards the Millennium Development Goals in many countries, but that this progress still remains uneven. It also stresses that official development assistance can help implement the principle of democratic ownership of aid by the countries concerned. MEPs also call on all development actors to implement the commitments of the Paris Declaration. These are based in particular on sufficient financing of the development policy which must be put at the service of the eradication of poverty and the promotion of the Goals for sustainable development. But to get there, donors must honor their commitments because there is a shortage of more than $ 2 trillion in aid to be provided to developing countries in order to achieve the Millennium Development Goals. The report also insists on improving the transparency of development aid and the fight against corruption in recipient countries, which constitutes a serious threat to democratic legitimacy and public support for development aid in donor countries. .

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I think it is important that within the framework of the GPEDC 2HLM process we carry out a self-criticism about the poor results obtained in comparison with the effort used.I voted in favor of this report because it seems to me to be balanced and correct.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the Dan Preda report on improving the effectiveness of development cooperation. Since 2011, with the commitments made in Busan, the EU has moved by defining four principles to assess aid effectiveness: ownership of the development priorities of developing countries; focus on results through actions that sustainably reduce poverty and inequalities in developing countries; inclusive development partnerships based on mutual respect and transparency and shared responsibility. They are effective standards that have helped countries achieve the Millennium Development Goals and gain broad public support in donor countries. In the wake of this work, the second meeting of the GPEDC, the global partnership for effective development cooperation, will also have to move. On that occasion, the European Union must be able to prove itself up to the challenges, increasing its commitment both in the creation of rules to increase the effectiveness of aid and development and in the adoption of the 2030 agenda. The EU must continue to take effective measures to increase aid transparency, improve joint programming, tackle the problem of conflicts and fragility and quantify the results.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the full relevance of the Principles of Development Effectiveness. I consider it essential that the effectiveness agenda is a key pillar of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The resolution highlights the importance of all development policy complying with the principles of appropriability and alignment with the national development strategies of the different countries, emphasizing the need to decouple aid and the importance of making use of the systems of public procurement from partner countries as a first option. The resolution also states that private sector agents must adhere to the principles of development effectiveness and adhere to the principles of corporate social responsibility throughout the project life cycle and highlights the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social and environmental norms, as well as the United Nations Global Compact on Human Rights, the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the fundamental norms of the ILO on labor matters and the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: in writing. - I've had the opportunity to say this in the past. Too much humanitarian aid kills humanitarian aid, just as too much tax kills taxes. There is no point in increasing the budgets allocated to humanitarian aid for developing countries if the corruption and embezzlement, mismanagement and nepotism that too many of these countries suffer from are not eradicated. The facts are glaring in this regard. Sadly, half a century of development aid and tens of billions wasted have not improved the lot of the people in need. Europe has too often turned a blind eye to the massive embezzlement committed by gerontocrats, whether they are Mobutu or Mugabe, by abusing the pity, generosity and naivety of Europeans. Yes, in this report we must welcome the appeal that asks the recipients of our aid for greater transparency, democracy and good governance. All that would be missing is that. But how many decades have lucid politicians launching this call? One can fear that these words of good will will remain, once again, a dead letter.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I have supported this report on making development cooperation more effective.It is necessary for each administration to allocate 0.7% of its budget for this objective.The role played in development by citizens, local communities, elected representatives, confessional organizations, civil society organizations ... these actors must participate in the promotion and implementation of the program for the increase ofeffectiveness at various levels.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This report on improving the effectiveness of development cooperation highlights the improvements to be made to the development aid programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa. The EU is the world's largest donor (68 billion euros in 2015, i.e. 0.47% of GNI while the target is 0.7% of GNI) but aid is the victim of dispersion because it is managed still 75% by Member States. There is this problem of coordinating European policies with national policies. Unfortunately, the radical clarification of the fields of EU and state development aid policies goes against my philosophy. This would give more powers to the Commission. Some interesting avenues are however proposed: include all participants, eradicate corruption and waste ... with the aim of reducing dependence on development aid. I have decided to abstain from this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Although the report presents some passages that can be shared, yet another demagogic appeal to help third countries remains, without adding anything about a more rational and effective management of this aid.For these reasons I expressed myself with an abstention.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I have abstained.The report deals with aid effectiveness, the follow-up to the Paris summits in 2005, Accra in 2008 and Busan in 2011. It contains many good articles on the inclusion of NGOs, poverty reduction initiatives, the importance of human rights and support for the new development goals.However, the report lacks clear criticism and condemnation of the fact that the EU, even with aid funds, uses third countries to close the borders of people on the run.The report also lacks references to the EU's increased militarization policy, which in turn contributes to more war and international insecurity.What also shines with its absence are women's rights, SRHR and the rights of LGBTQ people within the framework of development cooperation.With that motivation, I chose to abstain.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
