text: written.- I voted in favor of this report which assesses the implementation of the global commitments on the effectiveness of development aid, the realization of the sustainable development goals and the Action Agenda on Financing.All Member States are requested to implement plans for development cooperation, to increase their contributions, to fulfill their commitments and to make information and different data more accessible, in addition to that, together with the Commission,inform national Parliaments and local and regional authorities, encourage coordination and publish evaluations of development cooperation and calls for projects and public contracts.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report because it spoke in favor of making development cooperation more effective. The EU has a long-standing commitment to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation. During the previous legislature, the European Parliament took the position on the need to increase aid effectiveness, which is now part of the broader concept of development effectiveness, and contributed to the preparation of the Fourth High Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness. Five years on, it is important to assess the implementation of global commitments on aid and development effectiveness. It is also a good opportunity to analyze how aid and development effectiveness can contribute to achieving the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Addis Ababa Development Finance Agenda. In the context of the new Agenda 2030 and the need to do more at lower cost, and more effective aid and development cooperation remains crucial to reduce poverty, strengthen national resilience and empower local communities.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process, including planning, implementation and accountability. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve their access to funding. The report highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for development aid, which will eradicate corruption once and for all. Finally, I strongly agree with the rapporteur's position on the private sector that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. I consider it essential to create the right environment for businesses in the partner countries, and above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems. In view of the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agree on the need to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation.The principles of aid effectiveness have clearly contributed to progress towards the Millennium Development Goals in many countries, but there are still differences in progress, and not all countries and all development actors have fully implemented all the principles throughout.I therefore agree on the need to call on all development actors to build on the commitments made from Paris to Busan and to renew and strengthen efforts to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation in order to achieve the ambitious goals of the 2030 Agenda and make the most of public and privatedevelopment funds.In this way, we will be able to support development, better eradicate poverty, reduce inequalities and support the provision of basic public services.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on the effectiveness of development cooperation.I believe that the EU needs to ensure more effective development cooperation if the desired effect is to be achieved in alleviating poverty in the context of the escalation of the humanitarian and development crisis and the scarcity of resources.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation because it pushed development actors to improve their efforts aimed at achieving the 2030 Agenda’s targets. Moreover, it called on the EU Member States to publish their Busan implementation plans and report their efforts prior to the Second High Level Meeting of Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation, which will take place from 28 November to 1 December 2016.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - "Doing more with less" is one of the cornerstones of the new 2030 agenda with which we Europeans intend to achieve greater effectiveness in the delivery of aid and development cooperation for countries in poor areas of Africa, Asia and the South America. In fact, specific interventions remain crucial in order to help alleviate poverty, strengthen national resilience to environmental and health problems, as well as confer autonomy to local communities. However, developed countries need to be more aware that legitimate, inclusive, rule of law and respect for human rights governance in developing countries is an indispensable element for development assistance to properly play its role in reducing poverty and improving people's situation and prospects. Ethical and sustainable development, including environmentally, is therefore of fundamental importance for the effectiveness of development and must be considered a priority over any trade agreement. The EU, as the world's largest donor of development aid, has a particular responsibility to improve the effectiveness and accountability of assistance around the world: transparency, good governance and the rule of law in the developing world development must remain our central concern.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report aims to improve the effectiveness of development aid programs.The rapporteur suggests interesting avenues for reflection, in particular on the fragmentation of aid and the lack of coordination between donors and States.Of course, better coordination between the European Union's common multiannual programming framework and national policies would help to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation.However, this would amount to giving new prerogatives to the European Commission to the detriment of our national sovereignty.Moreover, this report recommends eradicating corruption and waste in recipient countries in order to ultimately reduce dependence on development aid.This is the reason why I abstained on this text.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - The EU has long been committed to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation. December 2016 will mark the fifth anniversary of the adoption of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation, a political commitment also made by the European Union, which aims to improve the quality of implementation, management and use of official development assistance, in order to maximizing its impact. To this end, the Commission and the Member States should develop new initiatives to strengthen flagship South-South and Tripartite cooperation projects, involving new emerging donors and other middle-income countries, based on addressing global challenges of mutual interest, without losing sight of the eradication of poverty. I support this report, as it is absolutely necessary to fully exploit the potential of decentralized cooperation in order to promote the development effectiveness agenda, while respecting all guarantees of transparency, effectiveness and coherence and avoiding further fragmentation of the international aid architecture.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report because it offers valuable suggestions for improving the effectiveness of development aid. The EU, as the largest donor, must continue to engage and maintain leadership on these issues, addressing them with due responsibility, to lead global efforts. Furthermore, it has a duty to ensure that transparency and the rule of law in developing countries remain a topical concern. The report reveals the contribution the EU can make in fighting poverty and promoting development, especially in the countries most in difficulty. All the tools available for development must be used in order to overcome poverty, reduce inequalities, provide essential public services and support good governance, pursuing the goals of sustainable development and, based on certain results, measuring the effectiveness of funding .

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The EU does not have the legitimacy to order countries, whether they are Member States or third countries, how or when they may use their foreign-aid budget, how much to spend or where it goes. UKIP does not support this growing influence and power of the EU and therefore voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. – I agree on the importance of official development aid and sustainable financing for development, while promoting an approach that goes beyond aid and aid-providing agendas. The report calls for a better articulation of the global development architecture and better coordination between all stakeholders, with a strong emphasis on monitoring, transparency, accountability and a shared responsibility for development results.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which reiterates that the European Union, as the world's largest donor of development aid, must step up and improve its efforts in this area.Under Article 208 of the TFEU, which sets the reduction and eradication of poverty as the main objective of European development policy, I believe that it is our duty to respect the commitments made, especially since development assistance can play a crucial rolein achieving the objectives of the 2030 agenda.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The report, for which I voted in favor, assesses the effectiveness and transparency of the European Union's development cooperation policies. I believe that the Union, which today represents the largest donor of development aid on a global scale, must verify through appropriate monitoring that the funds it disburses are used effectively in order to maximize its contribution to the eradication of poverty. Ensuring that resources are allocated to populations in need seems to me an even more necessary imperative in the light of the current world scenario characterized by an increase in humanitarian crises and a shortage of resources. I stress that greater transparency on the use of funds will help to eradicate corruption in recipient countries and in the long run to reduce dependence on aid. I am also convinced that sustainable development policies must be implemented through cooperation with local actors in order to promote good governance and to make the institutions of partner countries responsible. Finally, I believe that the European Union must promote innovative models of cooperation involving new middle-income countries as well as emerging donors from civil society and the private sector.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and recall the European Union 's long - term commitment to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- The report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation aims to review the strategy of the states regarding the development programs they draw up.As this is a report that works for the benefit of the states, I voted in favor.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Abstention vote for this report as there do not seem to be any concrete signs of a real turnaround on the effectiveness of EU cooperation.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - In reality, therefore, it is important to remind them of their role in development cooperation and that is what I intend to do by expressing my favorable vote. This measure requires, five years after the commitments made in Busan, a renewal of the same in conjunction with the intensification of efforts to increase the quality of the implementation of the global partnership and the achievement of the objectives of the 2030 agenda. Since December 2011, however, many assets and certainties have failed at the hands of the crisis, therefore it is a priority to defeat growing poverty in Europe, as well as in the rest of the world. In fact, the continuous and merciless increase in social inequality due to the combined effect of the crisis is then reflected in the formation of social environments disillusioned with the future, in which the total remoteness of the Member States and the Union is perceived, opening the doors to degradation. Obtaining this is only possible through governance policies based on the no-one behind model. Parliament plays a key role in democratic control over EU-led development activities, recommending transparency and equity in aid and the adoption of best practices.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - Enhancing aid and development effectiveness has been one of the EU's main concerns over these years. As the second High Level meeting of the World Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation approaches, an assessment of the implementation of global commitments on aid and development effectiveness needs to be made. I believe that the EU must continue to play an important leading role in these matters and be a major contributor to the reflection and enforcement of development standards. We must not forget the fundamental role of public aid for development, recalling that most providers have not fulfilled their commitment to affect 0.7% of the Gross National Income; we must strive for greater coordination and transparency, demand improved management of public finances and absorptive capacity in beneficiary countries and greater cooperation with national parliaments in third countries. I call attention to the fact that only by guaranteeing peace, respect for human rights and the rule of law, as well as independent judicial systems and the safeguarding of minorities, can these development goals and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals be achieved.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report as it reaffirms the importance of development aid and sustainable financing for cooperation, while also promoting an approach that goes beyond aid itself. The text focuses on the need for a better articulation of the global development architecture and better coordination between all stakeholders, with a strong emphasis on monitoring, transparency and shared responsibility for results. In my opinion, it is necessary that in order to achieve concrete aid effectiveness, the following must never be lost: ownership of the development priorities of the countries concerned, attention to results through actions that reduce poverty and inequalities in the developing countries, inclusive partnerships based on mutual respect and ultimately transparency and shared responsibility for the results achieved. It is necessary to continue along the path initiated by the EU so that increasingly innovative approaches to sustainable development are identified, together with the definition of the roles and responsibilities of the various actors.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that effectiveness of development funding should be assessed based on concrete results and its contribution to development policy. I agree with the rapporteur that the effectiveness principle, ‘Leave No-one Behind’, acknowledges the importance of placing a strong focus on poor, vulnerable and marginalised groups.  While this principle would correspond to the general philosophy and the overarching commitment of inclusiveness, I firmly believe that the private sector is an important partner in achieving the SDGs and mobilising further resources for development. In this sense private-sector actors must align with development effectiveness principles and abide by the principles of corporate accountability throughout the whole lifecycle of projects. Finally, I agree to ensure that companies operating from tax havens do not participate in ODA-financed projects.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing.- I was in favor of the Preda report, as it recognizes the great role of the European Union in the field of development aid and the need to increase efforts in this area in order to respect the commitments made as required by both Article 208of the TFEU and in order to work harder to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals.Improving our efforts in this area would mean preparing and responding more effectively to the challenges that the near future holds, as improving development brings mutually shareable benefits and helps prevent new problems from arising.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted against this report because it frames and legitimizes development cooperation within the market logic, reinforcing the role of companies within development cooperation mechanisms. The call included in the text for aid recipient countries to undertake "the introduction of market economy mechanisms", "the opening of their markets to global competition" or "the mobilization of private capital" is a conditioning and an attempt to use development cooperation to interfere with the sovereignty of each country when organizing and regulating its economy. I reject cooperation designed to open the door to business for European companies in impoverished countries. And therefore, we reject this report that demands and conditions - in pursuit of the "effectiveness" of the aid - that third countries enable the private sector to do business with basic services such as infrastructure, health or education. On the contrary, I understand that the effectiveness of aid passes through cooperation and the reinforcement of the role of the States of these impoverished countries, through the development of public services and through public control of strategic economic sectors.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - As the world's first donor of development cooperation aid, the European Union has a responsibility to improve the effectiveness of its action through more effective cooperation that has a real impact in alleviating poverty in a context of growing crises humanitarian and resource scarcity. The forthcoming second high-level meeting of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC) offers the opportunity to overcome the problems encountered so far and identify innovative approaches to sustainable development, clearly addressing the issue of the roles and responsibilities of the various actors development in a differentiated way. In this context, I believe that the EU, which has played an important role both in creating the current rules for aid and development effectiveness and in adopting the 2030 Agenda, should continue to take the lead on these issues and contribute to the reflection on the articulation and synergies between these two elements, especially in the current implementation phase.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up. - The commitments made in Busan for effective development cooperation have contributed to the definition of an international standard on aid effectiveness applicable to all development actors. The Busan Partnership Agreement has been approved by 161 countries and territories and 54 international organizations. The European Union plays an important role in both the development of current aid effectiveness standards and the adoption of the 2030 Agenda. Joint programming currently applies in more than half of the partner countries receiving EU development assistance. I voted in favor of continuing this path, but also of stepping up efforts on aid effectiveness and development cooperation. More active involvement of civil society and elected representatives in the implementation of the development effectiveness agenda is a priority.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on making development cooperation more effective. An extremely important aspect is striving to improve development aid for the Member States. I believe that measures should be taken to improve the quality of implementation of development aid, which combats countries' problems related to poverty and inequalities. In the context of implementing the development strategy, cooperation between the private and public sectors is important, which will contribute to sustainable and inclusive development. The implementation of the strategy beyond the goals must also take into account the fact that the development challenges have changed their nature with the emergence of new global challenges such as migration, food security, peace and stabilization, and climate change. I believe that the development efforts of the Member States are a priority for the EU community, and that is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union has a central role in providing aid to countries which are experiencing humanitarian or developing crises. As the biggest development aid donor, the Union needs to improve the effectiveness of its development tools to ensure more effective development cooperation aid to really and truly have an impact on alleviating poverty. I am in favour of the new mechanisms suggested in this report, as it is high time to develop an effective agenda and for the EU to act as a global actor.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- I support the rapporteur's view on the need for the European Parliament to be informed regularly and in a timely manner of the position adopted by the Commission in the GPEDC Steering Committee in order to play its key role in democratic scrutiny of European Union policies.At the same time, I consider the progress made to be beneficial and support the need to ensure access to information for all partners on funding mechanisms and transparency of programming, as well as possible projects and aid flows for development cooperation, especially in the context of the International Aid Transparency Initiative.and the establishment of the "EU Aid Explorer" site.Proper monitoring, analysis and exchange of information and experience on development progress in beneficiary countries are also needed.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The EU does not have the legitimacy to order countries, whether they are Member States or third countries, how or when they may use their foreign-aid budget, how much to spend or where it goes. UKIP does not support this growing influence and power of the EU and therefore voted against.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- This report on strengthening the effectiveness of development cooperation rightly reminds the European Union and its Member States of their commitments in terms of development aid consisting in devoting 0.7% of their GNI (gross national income) to development aid.I supported this text which underlines that while official development assistance plays a key role in the eradication of poverty and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs), progress in its implementation remains to be seen.produce.It seems to me particularly relevant to stress the importance of the transparency of tax systems and of these financial flows.The ongoing corruption in many recipient countries is a major obstacle to achieving our development goals.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation. I agree with the rapporteur that the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development needs to be strengthened; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process, including planning, implementation and accountability. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve their access to funding. The report highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for development aid, which will eradicate corruption once and for all. Finally, I strongly agree with the rapporteur's position on the private sector that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. I consider it essential to create the right environment for businesses in the partner countries, and above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: written.- Today the N-VA delegation voted in favor of increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.Since we see that valuable resources are being lost at a large number of levels, we argue for less capital-intensive and more efficient development cooperation.However, in order to achieve this, our delegation believes it is essential that all cash flows, both direct and indirect, are clearly identified.We can only look for economies of scale and other optimisations if we get a complete picture of the financial support for all countries involved.Our party is therefore of the opinion that the ODA (Official Development Assistance) calculations should not be limited to direct cash flows, but should also reveal indirect cash flows.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This report deals with the improvements to be made to the development aid programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa.Indeed, the European Union is the largest donor at the global level, with 68 billion euros of development aid in 2015. The main problems highlighted are: the fragmentation of aid, the lack of coordination between donors, aid agencies and donor countries.This report provides interesting avenues for reflection, in particular concerning the accountability of states receiving financial assistance and a requirement for program transparency.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I supported Mr Preda's report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The EU and its Member States could work on new initiatives to develop tripartite cooperation projects, attracting new donors and middle-income countries. The EU could be more active in involving national parliaments, local authorities, as well as private individuals in programming and financial commitments related to development aid, by publishing country-specific views on development cooperation. I support the logic of the draft report, as more needs to be done (with less financial resources) both at EU and global level to increase the effectiveness of development aid. He endorses all the proposed policy principles - especially the need to partner with the private sector through mixing and public-private partnerships.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- We are voting against the report of the Committee on Development on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation, as we oppose a single market for cooperation with third countries.The economic performance so far has shown that the lack of transparency from local communities and elected representatives does not ensure the actual taxation of profits where the activity is carried out, resulting in illegal financial flow.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation. I agree with the rapporteur that the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development needs to be strengthened; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process, including planning, implementation and accountability. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve their access to funding. The report highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for development aid, which will eradicate corruption once and for all. Finally, I strongly agree with the rapporteur's position on the private sector that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. I consider it essential to create the right environment for businesses in the partner countries, and above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained in the final vote on this report because although the content was acceptable, it does not address the violation of development effectiveness principles in terms of EU migration policies. I visited the camp in Calais with a Welsh MP colleague to see at first-hand how refugees were having to live. The EU should set a good example.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Abstention: a clear request is made to the Commission to promote access to transparency of programs, to obtain more frequent reports on the efforts made, to inform national parliaments but also local authorities and civil societyon financial commitments.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Discussions in the European Parliament on the effectiveness of development aid are recurrent. Rarely do the reports that address it get to the bottom of the issue - rather, they take advantage of it to try, as often as cynically and hypocritically, to condition developing countries by imposing models of state political organization on them, namely with regard to modes of organization economic and social. This is what happens again with this report. We defend the saving market economy, the private sector, the opening to world competition of the economies of these countries. Finally, the typical neoliberal prescription that has caused the economic and social disasters that are in sight (namely as a result of interventions by the IMF and World Bank). Without prejudice to agreeing with several fair observations contained in the report, namely with regard to the need to increase Public Aid for Development, the criticism of non-compliance with the established goals, among other aspects, what prevails is a certain neocolonial vision - evident in the references to corruption, limited to references to countries that receive “aid” - and make the EU and its policies unaccountable. Not a word about the harmful effects of trade deregulation and liberalization, for example.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report as I believe it is important to improve aid effectiveness through development cooperation.The report identifies innovative strategic approaches and principles to encourage sustainable development and clearly address the question of the roles and responsibilities of the various actors involved in cooperation projects.Furthermore, I believe that the involvement of local authorities and private actors in development assistance and respect for the democratic ownership of the beneficiary countries are key strategic elements for fostering the efficiency and effectiveness of aid and development cooperation.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as it will help the most vulnerable.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing - The European Union, as the world's largest provider of development aid, has a special responsibility to improve the effectiveness of EU aid worldwide and increase the responsibilities associated with it.At the end of 2016, 5 years will pass since the adoption of the so-calledBusan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation.It is therefore very important for the European Union to look to the future and prepare a thorough program for development aid by 2030. I therefore welcome the fact that the European Union has taken significant steps to increase aid transparency and improve joint planning, as well as more accurate measurement of results.The European Union must also strive for greater involvement of civil society in the implementation of development effectiveness programs.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I abstain as there do not seem to be any concrete signs in this report of a real turnaround on the effectiveness of EU cooperation.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report of the Committee on Development on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation, as I oppose a single market for cooperation with third countries.The economic performance so far has shown that the lack of transparency from local communities and elected representatives does not ensure the actual taxation of profits where the activity is carried out, resulting in illegal financial flow.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe the EU should ensure a more effective development cooperation aid if it wants to have a real impact in alleviating poverty in a context of increasing humanitarian and development crises and scarcity of resources. The EU, as world’s biggest development aid donor, has a special responsibility to improve the effectiveness of and bring more accountability to EU assistance. The EU should lead global efforts in advancing the development effectiveness agenda. In the previous mandate, Parliament took a stance on the issue of improving aid effectiveness by providing its input in view of the Fourth High Level Forum on Aid Effectiveness. Five years later, it is important to take stock of the implementation of the global commitments achieved then.  The report is thus a good occasion to analyse how aid and development effectiveness could contribute to implementing the SDGs and the Addis Ababa Agenda on Financing for Development. Our amendments achieved to defend a stronger Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC), more inclusive of civil society organisations and with a larger mandate, mainly by ensuring a better south-south and triangular cooperation and more transparency in access to information.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this excellent report, which contributes to a clear and precise positioning of the European Union in the process of implementing the 2030 agenda and achieving the sustainable development goals. While reiterating the importance of the commitment to allocate 0.7% of GDP to development aid, the report encourages an innovative and pragmatic approach, also aimed at mobilizing private investment. In addition, the report particularly emphasizes the importance of inclusiveness and partnerships with all actors to achieve the SDGs. I am also pleased that the report takes into account the role of women and the importance of gender equality in ensuring the effectiveness of development cooperation. Finally, the report has the merit of recalling the extremely close link between improving transparency, good governance and the rule of law in developing countries and the effectiveness of development cooperation.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation. I agree with the rapporteur that the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development needs to be strengthened; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process, including planning, implementation and accountability. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve their access to funding. The report highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for development aid, which will eradicate corruption once and for all. Finally, I strongly agree with the rapporteur's position on the private sector that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. I consider it essential to create the right environment for businesses in the partner countries, and above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report considering the Union's commitment to aid and development cooperation. Commitments based on the acquis of the 2005 Paris Declaration and the 2008 Accra Program of Action have contributed to establishing an international standard on aid effectiveness applicable to all development actors, moving from effective from aid to development effectiveness and from a North / South, donor / recipient perspective to a model that also emphasizes partnerships and non-aid financing modalities. However, much remains to be done, both at Union and global level, to increase the effectiveness of aid and development cooperation. The Union, as the world's largest donor of development aid, has a special responsibility to improve the effectiveness and make its aid more accountable around the world, promoting development effectiveness and ensuring transparency, good governance and the State of Right.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the effectiveness of development cooperation because I believe that official development assistance can play a crucial role in achieving the goals of the 2030 Agenda in low-income countries, and in the fight against extreme poverty and to inequality. Nevertheless, it is of fundamental importance that it is oriented towards the principle of effectiveness. In other words, development cooperation must be based on the democratic ownership of the countries directly concerned, alignment, capacity building at local level, transparency and democratic accountability, monitoring of the results achieved, on inclusion, to allow aid conditionality to respect the principle of democratic ownership. Poverty reduction necessarily implies the use of all the instruments of development policy, however it has long been clear to this part that other development policy instruments are also needed in addition to aid and cooperation for development, and above all that the The EU and its Member States respect their historic commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to aid, by boosting their development aid, including through the Union budget and the European Development Fund (EDF), as well as implementing a clear and effective roadmap to deliver on commitments.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- As the coordinator of my ECR group for the EU-ACP delegation, I see the major deficits and inefficiencies of our EU development policy in my daily work and the dialogue with the emerging countries.That needs to be changed - also in our own interest.That is why I voted in favor of the report on making development cooperation more effective.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The agenda on the effectiveness of development cooperation that has been implemented so far must be strengthened in the future and linked to the global development architecture in an even closer relationship.The European Union must also submit to self-imposed mechanisms that guarantee fair, targeted and project-related development aid.

name: Nathan GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. This is a non-legislative report, which looks at increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. Calls on the EU Commission to increase transparency and accountability of all actors involved in spending and receiving aid funds. However, it urges the EU and its Member States ‘to meet the longstanding commitment to devote 0.7% of GNI (Gross National Income) to aid and to step up their development assistance.’ The EU does not have the right to tell any nation state on where and how they can spend their money. In addition to this, the report is asking for more resources to put in place a permanent secretariat for the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC).

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which sets out the steps the EU should take to meet the Busan commitments on aid effectiveness and to reach its development targets, whilst attempting to ‘do more, with less’. The report outlines how the EU can maximise the effectiveness of its development aid and meet its development targets agreed in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - December 2016 will mark the fifth anniversary of the adoption of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation. It is necessary to take stock five years after the final document of 2011, which marked a very significant turning point and sanctioned the definitive transition from the concept of aid effectiveness to that of development effectiveness, reaffirming the need to fulfill the commitments deriving from the Paris declaration of 2005 and the Accra Agenda for Action of 2008. With the context of the 2030 agenda in mind and the scarce resources available given the unfavorable economic situation, it is now necessary to verify the application of some principles and the achievement of the objectives established at that time: ownership of partner countries, results-based development, inclusive partnership for development, transparency and shared responsibility of all actors of cooperation. I therefore voted in favor of this report because it indicates precise criteria for doing so and because I believe that our role as MEPs is essential for keeping these objectives among the priorities of national parliaments and our territories.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the full relevance of the Principles of Development Effectiveness. I consider it essential that the effectiveness agenda is a key pillar of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The resolution highlights the importance of all development policy complying with the principles of appropriability and alignment with the national development strategies of the different countries, emphasizing the need to decouple aid and the importance of making use of the systems of public procurement from partner countries as a first option. The resolution also states that private sector agents must adhere to the principles of development effectiveness and adhere to the principles of corporate social responsibility throughout the project life cycle and highlights the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social and environmental norms, as well as the United Nations Global Compact on Human Rights, the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the fundamental norms of the ILO on labor matters and the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on making development cooperation more effective. Five years after the adoption of the Busan Partnership, the time has come to take stock of the implementation of the then commitments on effective development cooperation. The anniversary also provided a good opportunity to analyze in depth and identify ways to increase aid and development effectiveness to contribute to the Sustainable Development Goals and the Addis Ababa Action Plan for Financing Development. In the context of the new 2030 Agenda and the need to deliver better results with less funding, developing more effective delivery modalities and development cooperation remains essential to help reduce poverty, increase national resilience and empower local communities . In my opinion, it is important to constantly develop new, effective methods of support also with the participation of the private sector, for example within the framework of private-public partnership.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which sets out the steps the EU should take to meet the Busan commitments on aid effectiveness and to reach its development targets, whilst attempting to ‘do more, with less’. The report outlines how the EU can maximise the effectiveness of its development aid and meet its development targets agreed in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which aims to strengthen and improve development aid in emerging countries.It is about providing support that effectively meets the needs of populations in difficulty.Therefore, our efforts should focus on building effective and responsive institutions, sound policies, open democratic governance, and measures to protect against corruption in these countries.In a time of climate challenges and rapidly growing demographics in developing countries, Member States must respect their commitments and establish a precise agenda for actions so that these developing countries can meet their own needs in the future.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process during planning, implementation and accounting. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve access to funding. The report also highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for developments that will eradicate corruption once and for all. The private sector part of the report should also be highlighted, pointing out that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. It is essential to create the right environment for small and medium-sized enterprises in the partner countries, but above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - The European Union has made a long-term commitment to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation, and December will mark the 5th anniversary of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation. In this context, this report highlights the key role of Formal Development Assistance. It also emphasizes the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social environmental standards. For these reasons we voted in favor of the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support this motion. I support the call on development actors to build on the commitments made from Paris to Busan, and to renew and reinforce their efforts to make development cooperation as effective as possible with a view to achieving the ambitious goals and targets set out in the 2030 Agenda and making the best use of public and private resources for development.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour since I have no objections

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The ECR Group supports the logic of the draft report as more needs to be done (with less financial resources) both at EU and global level to increase the effectiveness of development aid. It endorses all suggested policy principles – especially the necessity to partner with the private sector through blending and public-private partnerships. I voted in favour.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on enhancing the effectiveness of development cooperation. I agree with the rapporteur that the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development needs to be strengthened; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process, including planning, implementation and accountability. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve their access to funding. The report highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for development aid, which will eradicate corruption once and for all. Finally, I strongly agree with the rapporteur's position on the private sector that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. I consider it essential to create the right environment for businesses in the partner countries, and above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report, which seeks to have a real impact on reducing poverty and to ensure more effective development cooperation aid in the context of growing humanitarian crises.The EU is a major donor for development, being responsible for improving the effectiveness of cooperation.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Report on Increasing the Effectiveness of Development Cooperation because I believe that it has a key role in eradicating poverty, reducing inequality, providing essential public services and supporting good governance.Official development assistance is more flexible, predictable and accountable than other flows that can contribute to development.This Report, which I support, encourages the EU and all Member States to fulfill their long-term commitment to allocate 0.7% of their GNI to aid, to increase development aid, inter alia through the EU budget and the European Development Fund, and to adoptan effective plan to achieve the objective of the commitment in a transparent, predictable and accountable manner.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing.- I supported this report because I agree with the tools and procedures it highlights.It underlines the key role of Official Development Assistance (ODA) in meeting the stated objectives of the 2030 Agenda. It emphasizes adequate financing of development policy and the efficient use of public and private resources.The private sector has significant potential for achieving sustainable development goals, especially in the areas of respect for human rights, social inclusion and project sustainability.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleague Christian Dan Preda's report on improving the effectiveness of development cooperation.In order to respond to the need to "do more with less", the report highlights the means to improve the effectiveness of development aid allocated to countries in difficulty.As the world's largest development aid donor, it is important for the Union to equip itself with effective tools to help eradicate poverty and promote the goals of sustainable development.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which takes stock of the effectiveness of development cooperation five years after the adoption in Busan of the partnership for effective action and before the second Summit of the global partnership for effective cooperation indevelopment to be held in Nairobi in December.Recalling both the importance of official development assistance and the requirement to “do more with less”, the report advocates impact measures, better coordination or even the involvement of local actors and society.civil.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - The European Union is the largest provider of development aid in the world. It has committed and set priorities in relation to development strategic goals, and therefore it is necessary to examine the effectiveness of the practices we have followed in relation to the goals we have set so far, as well as, given the current economic constraints, to find ways continuous evaluation of the impact of our practices on development, so that we do not retreat as a European Union to our international development role, but at the same time use the resources we have more intelligently and better.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I support the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.This report has a balanced objective and will hopefully improve the efficiency of development cooperation.The proposals contained therein aim not only to ensure that developed countries have to give more, but also make developing countries an obligation to assume more responsibility.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as part of the EU’s commitment to improving the effectiveness of development aid to make sure aid spending is as effective as possible and reaches its intended targets.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - The EU's long-term commitment is to improve aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation. That is why I voted in favor when it came to increasing the effectiveness of development aid. ODA plays an important role in combating poverty, eliminating inequalities, promoting development, especially in the least developed countries, and promoting the access of the most disadvantaged and vulnerable groups to quality public services, education and health. More flexible and predictable development aid is a way to reduce illegal financial flows, to promote cooperation in order to increase the transparency of tax regimes and financial flows more generally. Multinational companies and financial institutions will certainly play a key role in this regard, and they must be aware of their responsibility in this area. It is now up to the parliaments of the recipient countries to adopt national development aid policies to improve donor and recipient government accountability, strengthen public finance management and absorption capacity, streamline tax systems and improve the conditions for obtaining budget support, and reduce their dependence in the long run. to help.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - I agree with the rapporteur on the need to strengthen the role of citizens, local communities, religious organizations, scientific institutes and trade unions in development; and I consider it important to fully involve actors in the development process, including planning, implementation and accountability. I think it is right to state in the report that civil society organizations must act as independent development actors and that the Commission must improve their access to funding. The report highlights that development aid cannot be effective where there is a lack of peace, respect for human rights, the rule of law, an impartial, efficient and independent judiciary; where the necessary environmental, social and labor standards are lacking. There is a need for transparency and public support for development aid, which will eradicate corruption once and for all. Finally, I strongly agree with the rapporteur's position on the private sector that businesses are important partners in achieving sustainable development goals. I consider it essential to create the right environment for businesses in the partner countries, and above all to create transparent legal and regulatory systems.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ Although the EU is the world’s biggest aid donor, many problems still exist concerning the effectiveness of delivered development aid. I voted in favour since the report urges the EU and its Member States to keep the promise about devoting 0.7% of their GNI to development aid, empowers civil society organisations in third countries, makes a principle of ownership more achievable and prevents involvement of offshore companies in the project implementation process.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I supported the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation, as it supports the EU's long-term commitment to developing standards for the effectiveness of development aid, as well as to the adoption of the 2030 Agenda. The EU is a major financial donor in support of the development of countries experiencing financial difficulties, as well as a major factor in the fight against poverty eradication by 2030. I welcome the idea of ​​a global partnership and the joint prioritization of sustainable development and the effectiveness of development cooperation between international donors, national governments, the private sector and civil society. International cooperation will help make aid more effective where it is most needed. I believe that the EU must play a leading role in international efforts to make progress on the development efficiency agenda. At the same time, the EU must be the guarantor of peace, respect for human rights and the rule of law as key prerequisites for the transparent management of the resources provided to the beneficiaries. For their part, the main commitment of these countries is to pursue a transparent and targeted policy to meet the goals of sustainable development of the Program until 2030.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. - Development aid plays an essential role in the fight against poverty and the elimination of inequalities; however, these aids cannot effectively achieve their purpose if used in contexts lacking peace, respect for human rights and the rule of law, an impartial judicial system, social, environmental and labor standards and safeguards, inclusive decision-making processes. For this reason, we call on all actors in the public and private sectors to multiply their efforts in promoting progress in a context of legitimate and inclusive governance, based on the rule of law and respect for human rights. The EU and the Member States must undertake to fulfill their commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to aid, to enhance their development aid, including through the Union budget and the European Development Fund. We also call for an effective roadmap to be implemented to deliver on commitments in a transparent and accountable manner. The European Parliament should be guaranteed the ability to play its democratic oversight role for all EU-led policies, including development policies.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution because the EU is the world’s biggest development aid donor and as such it has a special responsibility to improve the effectiveness of aid and development cooperation. In fact, this is necessary because aid and development effectiveness can play a crucial role in implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and the achievement of the SDGs. In this context, the EU should enhance the accountability, transparency and visibility of EU aid in order to improve its quality and thus help developing countries achieve the Millennium Development Goals. The EU has played a major role both in building the current standards for aid and development effectiveness, and in the adoption of Agenda 2030, therefore I believe it should continue to assume leadership on these issues. Last but not least, aid and development effectiveness is in the interest of the EU because the fragmentation of the aid effort means an additional cost of between EUR 2 and 3 billion a year for the EU. Certainly, with more effective aid delivery and development cooperation the EU can ‘do more, with less’.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - It is the EU's job to improve aid and development effectiveness through long-term programs. December 2016 will mark the fifth anniversary of the adoption of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation and the definition of common principles for development effectiveness, including inclusion, transparency and shared accountability, and the '' adoption of targeted policies. In parallel, the second high-level meeting of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC) will be held in Nairobi at the end of November 2016, which has the task of monitoring the implementation of the commitments agreed in Busan. The report approved today reaffirms the importance of official development aid and sustainable development finance, making a successful analysis of the implementation of these global commitments. The report calls for the EU to continue to play a leadership role by strengthening efforts in the field, better articulating the global development architecture and promoting better coordination. In this context, the importance of applying the common principles for development effectiveness defined above is constantly emphasized.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I abstained on the report entitled “Improving the effectiveness of development cooperation”. This report highlights the improvements to be made to the development aid programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa. It addresses both issues such as aid fragmentation, and the lack of coordination between donors, aid agencies and donor countries. Indeed, the Union is the world's largest donor. European aid is the victim of dispersion, since nearly 75% of it is allocated by the Member States according to national procedures in order to maintain a strong link with former colonies (France, the Netherlands, Spain, etc.). The Commission wants to play a more important role, to the detriment, as always, of the Member States. However, the report provides some interesting leads such as the need to include all participants (including local actors, civil society, the private sector, national parliaments, trade unions) with the corollary of greater accountability. Recipient countries are encouraged to adopt national development policies, consolidate public finances and eradicate corruption and waste, in order to ultimately reduce dependence on development aid.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- This report highlights the improvements to be made to the development assistance programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa.European aid is the victim of a dispersion since nearly 75% of it is allocated by the Member States according to national procedures in order to maintain a strong link with former colonies (France, the Netherlands, Spain, etc..).It is a recurring problem in this committee: the need for increased coordination with national policies.I abstained on this text.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report because it assesses the implementation of the global commitments on aid and development effectiveness, as well as the proposal for the realization of the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and the Adís Action Agenda Abeba on Financing for Development. It emphasizes that much remains to be done, both at Union and worldwide, to increase the effectiveness of aid and development cooperation. Member States are asked to put implementation plans in place, to increase their contributions and to fulfill their commitments through a roadmap that ensures predictability and transparency. All donors are encouraged to do more to make information and data more accessible. Finally, it calls on the Commission, the Union delegations and the Member State agencies to inform national parliaments and regional and local authorities, as well as private actors and civil society, on programming and commitments. financial in relation to development aid.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - I voted against this report because it frames and legitimizes development cooperation within the market logic, reinforcing the role of companies within development cooperation mechanisms. The call included in the text for aid recipient countries to undertake "the introduction of market economy mechanisms", "the opening of their markets to global competition" or "the mobilization of private capital" is a conditioning and an attempt to use development cooperation to interfere with the sovereignty of each country when organizing and regulating its economy. I reject cooperation designed to open the door to business for European companies in impoverished countries. And therefore, we reject this report that demands and conditions - in pursuit of the "effectiveness" of the aid - that third countries enable the private sector to do business with basic services such as infrastructure, health or education. On the contrary, I understand that the effectiveness of aid passes through cooperation and the reinforcement of the role of the States of these impoverished countries, through the development of public services and through public control of strategic economic sectors.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This report highlights that legitimate and inclusive governance, based on the rule of law and respect for human rights in developing countries, constitutes an indispensable element for development aid to adequately play its role in reducing thepoverty and the improvement of people's situation and prospects.The Union, as the world's largest donor of development aid, has a special responsibility to improve the effectiveness and make Union aid more accountable around the world.Furthermore, the Union should lead global efforts to advance the development effectiveness agenda and see that transparency, good governance and the rule of law in the developing world remain a primary concern.I vote in favor of this report for agreeing with these objectives.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ The EU has a long-standing commitment to development cooperation. I voted in favour of this report encompassing the sustainable development goals.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The EU, as the world's largest donor of development aid, has a special responsibility to improve efficiency and increase accountability for the assistance it provides worldwide. The report emphasizes the need for the EU to become a leader in global efforts to foster the implementation of development efficiency programs and to ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law are a top priority in developing countries. The Global Partnership is based on the Busan Partnership Agreement of December 2011, which was supported by 161 countries and territories and 54 international organizations. One of its main features is inclusiveness, as it brings together a wide range of stakeholders, in order to encourage and support effective development cooperation. The report emphasizes that the EU, which has played a key role in preparing current standards for aid effectiveness and development and in adopting the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, should continue to be a leader in these areas and contribute to considering their interconnections and synergies. The EU has taken important steps to increase aid transparency, improve joint programming, address conflict and instability, and measure results. I supported this report, which also emphasizes the need for development aid beneficiary countries to respect human rights and have legitimate and inclusive governance, so that the development aid they receive can help reduce poverty.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the efforts made to ensure that all actors concerned have access to information on transparency of development cooperation programming, funding mechanisms, projects and aid flows, in particular in the context of the International Aid Transparency Initiative and the setting-up of the ‘EU Aid Explorer’ website. Major steps still need to be taken in this regard, and called for further significant efforts be urgently made by all donors to make information and data more accessible, timely and comparable.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing - the Union is one of the main players in development aid.It is part of development policy, which, when implemented effectively, is a way of solving many of today's world's problems.When it works properly, it helps to address not only poverty but also instability and conflict in the regions.Its implementation requires a high degree of responsibility from both the Union and the Member States, as it is also a means of resolving democracy, the rule of law and a functioning public administration.In order to prevent abuse, it must be provided in a targeted, effective and, above all, transparent manner.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 21 November 2016, and because this report is not complete and well-documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I abstained for this text. The objective of this report is to improve the system of distribution of financial aid to developing countries, especially African countries. The rapporteur notes that European aid is largely wasted because of its fragmentation and the lack of coordination between aid agencies and donor countries. The report therefore encourages donor countries to increase the level of coordination, and recipient countries to adopt national development policies, consolidate public finances and fight corruption and waste. These measures aim to reduce, in the long term, dependence on international aid from developing countries. However, this text remains very integrationist. He criticizes the current system in which member states have great freedom in allocating aid to countries of their choice (for example, former colonies with which economic ties remain strong). On the other hand, it envisages increased coordination at European level, which we are opposed to.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. Supporting the aforementioned section will contribute to the EU’s long-standing commitment to development in the form of alleviation of poverty and empowering of local communities in third-world countries. A number of issues have been identified, and, therefore, by supporting the report those issues will gain importance and will comply with development effectiveness. Development includes properly reducing poverty, securing the rule of law and the protection of human rights in those countries. Hence, my vote in favour.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing.- This report proposes measures to enhance the effectiveness of development cooperation in all countries, based on the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC).Among the various measures proposed, the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social and environmental standards, with a view to ensuring that the European Commission ensures that companies operating from tax havens do not participate in projects financed byPublic Development Aid.I voted in favor.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this EP report.Improving the effectiveness of development cooperation aid is essential.The EU is the largest donor of development aid, so we need to ensure that funding mechanisms are transparent at all stages of projects and aid flows, contribute to poverty reduction and empower local communities.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - In the face of growing global challenges such as migration, including climate-related, food security and peace, this report encourages better cooperation and coordination of development assistance at the international level. It recalls the States' commitment to devote 0.7% of their national income to official development assistance. He stresses that any development and poverty eradication policy must be carried out by promoting state services and providing the means to produce and consume locally. On the one hand, he therefore notes that "strengthening national public procurement systems is an essential element". But on the other hand, it conditions aid on opening up to global competition. It underlines the obligation for the private sector to respect international social and environmental standards. But on the other hand, it encourages him to participate in the formulation of development policies. Finally, he warns, quite timidly, against the current European policy which siphons off development aid for the benefit of migrant return operations. Under these conditions, I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report aims to improve aid programs for developing countries, particularly in Africa.Indeed, several problems are highlighted such as the fragmentation of aid and the lack of coordination between donors.Note that the European Union is the world's largest donor (68 billion euros in 2015).The necessary coordination between Europe and national policies to clarify the scope of development policy will only strengthen the power of the European Commission.It is therefore for this reason that I abstained on this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The EU has a long-standing commitment to improve aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation. The EU, which played an important role both in creating the current standards for aid and development effectiveness, and in adopting the 2030 Agenda, must continue to take the lead on these issues and contribute to reflection on articulation and synergies between both, now that we have entered the execution phase. The EU, as the world's largest donor of development aid, has a special responsibility to improve efficiency and ensure greater accountability for EU assistance worldwide. In addition, the EU must lead global efforts to advance the agenda for development effectiveness and ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law in the developing world remain a fundamental concern. Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because, amongst others, it will make EU development aid more efficient with measures to combat corruption, it emphasises the importance of civil society organisations, it increases the complementarity of different aid packages and it also collaborates with the private sector to identify other development resources.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - The European Union is the leading contributor to development aid. By voting in favor of strengthening the effectiveness of development cooperation, we are once again showing the importance that we attach to our commitment, which is to contribute to the achievement of the sustainable development goals (SDGs) as set out in the Agenda. 2030. We recognize that eradicating all forms of poverty begins with a cooperative approach with disadvantaged countries who bear primary responsibility for achieving these goals. Our commitment made in Busan reminds us that the effectiveness of this cooperation is also based on the inclusive aspect, involving international and regional organizations, but also national bodies (parliaments, civil society, and the private sector). This aspect should be strengthened by mobilizing more actors around the development issue who are fully capable of recognizing their responsibility in order to improve this area in an environment of peace respecting human rights and the rule of law. .

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing - The second meeting of the High-Level Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC) will take place in Nairobi at the end of November 2016, to review the global commitments on aid effectiveness and development made in Busan. More effective aid delivery and more effective development cooperation remain key to contributing to poverty alleviation, strengthening national stability and the role of local communities, especially as we strive for more results with less effort. One of the main features of GPEDC is inclusiveness, as it brings together a wide range of stakeholders. At this meeting, it is necessary to identify innovative approaches to sustainable development and to clearly define the roles and responsibilities of the various development actors. One of the areas in which the GPEDC could make a significant contribution is the responsibility for development effectiveness aimed at implementing the sustainable development goals. However, it also has the potential to provide ways to work with non-OECD donor countries. As the world's largest provider of development aid, the EU has a particular responsibility to improve the effectiveness of EU aid worldwide and increase the responsibilities associated with it. It should be at the forefront of global efforts to advance the development effectiveness agenda and ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law are at the forefront of efforts.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, because I agree that the EU should ensure more effective development cooperation aid if it wants to have a real impact in alleviating poverty in the context of increasing humanitarian and development crises and scarcity of resources.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The Committee on Development's draft resolution states that the Union has long been committed to improving the effectiveness of aid and development through development cooperation. At the same time, as the world's largest donor of development aid, it has a key responsibility to improve efficiency and increase the accountability of distributed EU aid worldwide. In addition, the Union must lead global efforts to advance the development effectiveness agenda and ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law remain central in the developing world. December 2016 will mark the fifth anniversary of the adoption of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation. At the same time, the second High Level Meeting of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC) will meet in Nairobi, Kenya, at the end of November 2016, to monitor the implementation of the Busan commitments. The draft emphasizes that, after five years, it is important to take stock of the implementation of global commitments on aid and development effectiveness.
