He also sees this opportunity as a good opportunity to analyze how aid and development effectiveness can contribute to the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals and the Addis Ababa Agenda for Financing for Development. I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - This report highlights the improvements to be made to the development assistance programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa. European aid is the victim of a dispersion since almost 75% of it is allocated by the Member States. This is a recurring problem: the need for increased coordination with national policies. There is indeed a common multiannual programming framework between the Union and the Member States, in a certain number of beneficiary countries of European aid, and some wish to radically clarify the fields of the Union's development aid policies. and Member States. And, of course, this goes against our philosophy, since implicitly, it means giving more powers to the Commission. This report provides some interesting avenues such as the need to include all participants (including local actors, civil society, the private sector, national parliaments, trade unions), with a corollary of greater accountability. Recipient countries are encouraged to adopt national development policies, consolidate public finances and eradicate corruption and waste, in order to ultimately reduce dependence on development aid.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text offers some interesting reflections, in particular on better cooperation between donors and the fight against corruption, but it would have the effect of increasing the powers of the Commission.I therefore abstain on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ The EU is committed to improving the effectiveness of development aid to make sure aid spending is as effective as possible and reaches its intended targets. I voted in favour of this report as it sets out the steps the EU should take to meet the Busan commitments on aid effectiveness and to reach its development targets, whilst attempting to ‘do more, with less’. The report forms a good outline on how the EU can maximise the effectiveness of its development aid and meet its development targets agreed in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing.- The European Union has made a long-term commitment to improve aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation.I voted in favor of the provision hoping for better articulation of the global architecture and better coordination between all stakeholders, with a strong emphasis on monitoring, transparency, accountability and shared responsibility for development results.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I support the report.As set out in the UN World Summit on Sustainable Development, entitled "Transforming our world: a 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development", all countries must pay close attention to sustainable development policies and their implementation.Financing development projects is our common task, we must fulfill them together.I am pleased that the report deals with private sector actors and that it draws attention to the need for private sector actors to take responsibility for achieving sustainable development, such as compliance with ILO core labor standards or the human rights guidelines for business.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ In 2011 the Busan Partnership was agreed upon in South Korea by a wide range of governments and organisations for effective development cooperation. I voted for this report that will advance development effectiveness by increasing aid transparency, improving joint programming and addressing the issues of conflict and fragility.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - I supported Mr Preda's resolution, as I believe that the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation must be seen in the context of the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the Addis Ababa Program of Action. Account must be taken of the fact that the emphasis is shifting from "aid effectiveness", which refers to traditional public development aid, to the notion of "effectiveness of development cooperation". Development aid and cooperation are necessary but insufficient factors for the effective eradication of poverty and the promotion of sustainable development goals. That is why I believe that the EU can learn from the experience of countries such as China, Brazil, Russia and India, which have development expertise and technology. Given that development aid plays an important role in combating poverty, as well as in improving access to quality public services for the most vulnerable, I support the idea of ​​codifying and strengthening mechanisms and practices. I believe that this would contribute to better complementarity and effective coordination of development aid among countries.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of this report, which ambitiously proposes that all development actors coordinate in line with the commitments made in Paris and Busan to achieve the objectives of the 2030 Agenda for the optimal use of public and private resources for development. . The report also emphasizes the key role of ODA (official development assistance) in eradicating poverty, reducing inequalities, providing essential public services and supporting good governance. Another factor that led me to support this report is that it calls into question the long-standing commitment of EU Member States to allocate 0.7% of GNI to aid and to strengthen their development assistance, including through through the EU and EDF budgets. This report recalls the important role it plays in the development of the society in which we live, both citizens and local communities, elected representatives, faith-based organizations, trade unions and academia.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- The report rightly notes that the effectiveness of financing for development should be assessed on the basis of concrete results and its contribution to development policy as a whole.It is clear that one of the preconditions for effective development cooperation is sufficient funding, but most ODA providers have not met their commitment to provide 0.7% of their GNI for development aid by 2015.The EU and its Member States should meet their long-term commitment to devote 0.7% of GNI to aid to increase their development aid, including within the EU budget and the European Development Fund (EDF).In order to achieve the capacity of developing countries to stand on their own two feet, it is important to encourage the participation of all Member States in the Addis Ababa Tax Initiative in order to double technical assistance by 2020 and strengthen the taxation capacity of partner developing countries.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because it contains goals which help to improve development aid.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The EU is the world's largest donor, so it is important that this aid is effective, targeted and transparent.Cooperation at all levels is needed, and respect for human rights, the rule of law and anti-corruption measures are important elements in the effective allocation of development cooperation funds.Member States should aim for 0.7% of GNI and contribute more to the EU budget and the European Development Cooperation Fund.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report. In order to achieve their goals, all stakeholders need to live up to their commitments and increase their accountability for budget support. Particular attention must be paid to the global partnership for effective development cooperation and its benefits. In order to eradicate poverty and achieve the goals of sustainable development, all development policy instruments must be used effectively. In particular, the delivery of assistance should be accelerated and an effective plan adopted to ensure that the objectives of the commitments are met in a transparent, predictable and accountable manner. The effective implementation of the development effectiveness agenda requires the untying of development aid, not only at EU level but also at global level. In addition, the effectiveness of development finance should be assessed on the basis of concrete results and its contribution to development policy as a whole.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The European Union has played an important role in developing existing standards for aid and development effectiveness. On the part of the European Union, significant steps have been taken to increase the transparency of aid, to improve joint planning, to address the issue of conflict and instability, and to measure results. I voted in favor of the report, which points out that more needs to be done, both at European and global level, to increase aid effectiveness and development cooperation. The European Union and its Member States could work on new initiatives to develop tripartite cooperation projects, with the participation of emerging donors and middle-income countries. The European Union and its Member States could act more proactively and systematically to ensure the involvement of national parliaments, local authorities and civil society in development aid-related planning and budgetary commitments by publishing specific country reviews of development cooperation. Further involvement of civil society and elected representatives in the implementation of the development effectiveness agenda should continue to be a priority.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of my colleagues' proposal because I believe it is important to improve aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation.But, I believe that the European Union should further improve the articulations of the global development architecture and, at the same time, ensure greater coordination between all the parties involved.I therefore voted in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The EU has a long-standing commitment to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation. I voted in favour of this report because it reaffirms the importance of official development aid and sustainable financing for development, while promoting an approach that goes beyond aid and aid-providing agendas. Placing the UN SDGs at the centre of the development cooperation global framework, the report insists on the need for a concrete and measurable impact of development policies. To this end, they should be coherent and ensure domestic ownership. In this regard, the involvement of local actors and civil society is imperative.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this report because the European Union has long committed itself to improving assistance and efficiency through the development of cooperation, which is clearly visible in this report. It reaffirms the importance of development assistance and sustainable development financing while promoting an approach that goes beyond aid alone. Given that resources are limited and we are forced to use the principle of “doing more with less”, efficiency is the primary problem that this report seeks to address in order to move closer to the goals of poverty alleviation, community empowerment and national resilience. Also, I think that the transparency of giving help is an extremely important factor so that we can monitor who gives help and, more importantly, who gets how much help. Here, the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation should play a key role in terms of transparency, but also the principles of effectiveness in achieving the goals of sustainable development and supporting their implementation by all actors at the state level. This will enable better development cooperation and more transparent monitoring of aid delivery.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - This report highlights the improvements to be made to the development assistance programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa. This report points to issues such as the fragmentation of aid, the lack of coordination between donors, aid agencies and donor countries. Indeed, the Union is the largest donor at the global level (68 billion euros in 2015 or 0.47% of GNI while the target is 0.7% of GNI). European aid is the victim of dispersion since almost 75% of it is allocated by the Member States according to national procedures in order to maintain a strong link with former colonies (France, the Netherlands, Spain, etc. .). It is a recurring problem in this committee: the need for increased coordination with national policies. There is indeed a common multiannual programming framework between the Union and the Member States, in a certain number of beneficiary countries of European aid and some wish to radically clarify the fields of the Union's development aid policies and Member States. Once again, the report therefore proposes to increase the powers of the Commission. Thus, despite the interesting leads and remarks it contains, I cannot support it and I abstain.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The European Union is the world's largest donor of development aid and therefore also has a particular responsibility in improving its effectiveness and transparency, if it really wants this assistance to have an impact in the fight against poverty, in a context characterized by humanitarian and economic crises and growing scarcity of resources. The report offers a good analysis of the progress made in the five years following the commitments made by the European Parliament, at the fourth high-level forum on aid effectiveness. It also contains suggestions on how to continue efforts to make European development cooperation ever more effective and achieve the Addis Ababa Sustainable Development Goals and Action Program. The institutional mechanism of the "Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation" (GPEDC), developed five years ago, has given good results. As we request with this report, new practices should now be developed to further improve aid effectiveness, such as triangular cooperation projects, greater involvement of national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and the private sector.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - All the high-level political promises from previous declarations, concluding with the Fourth Forum on Aid Effectiveness in Busan, have the same goal, ie to improve the overall effect of state aid for development. The principles of aid effectiveness have contributed to progress towards the Millennium Development Goals, although this progress remains uneven. I call for the use of all development policy tools in eradicating poverty and promoting the goals of sustainable development. The effectiveness of development funding should be assessed on the basis of concrete results. I call on the GPEDC parties to consider establishing a more independent permanent secretariat with more appropriate resources and building on the work of the joint support group. Recipients' parliaments should adopt national development aid policies to increase the accountability of donors and recipient governments, including local authorities, improve public financial management and absorption capacity. The role of citizens, elected representatives, religious organizations, civil society organizations, academia, trade unions and the private sector in development must not be diminished - therefore all these stakeholders must be involved in promoting and implementing efficiency programs. Joint programming would reduce aid fragmentation and transaction costs, increase complementarity through better division of labor, and increase accountability and predictability of development cooperation, which would be obvious benefits for both the EU and partner countries.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Discussions in the European Parliament on the effectiveness of development aid are recurrent. Rarely do the reports that address it get to the bottom of the issue. Rather, they take advantage of it, as often as cynically and hypocritically, to try to condition developing countries, imposing models of state political organization on them, namely with regard to the modes of economic and social organization. This is what happens again with this report. We defend the saving market economy, the private sector, the opening to world competition of the economies of these countries. Finally, the typical neoliberal prescription that has caused the economic and social disasters that are in sight (namely as a result of interventions by the IMF and World Bank). Without prejudice to agreeing with several fair observations contained in the report, namely with regard to the need to increase Public Development Aid and criticizing the failure to meet the established goals, among other aspects, what prevails is a certain neocolonial vision - evident in the references to corruption, limited to references to countries that receive “aid” - and make the EU and its policies unaccountable. Not a word about the harmful effects of trade deregulation and liberalization, for example.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The current refugee crisis has convinced us quite clearly that the European Union cannot afford not to respond to conflicts, which in many cases are unleashed by poverty. Armoring with walls does not always work as effectively as we would like. On the other hand, I am well aware that the budgets of developed countries, if they have to deal with several urgent problems at the same time, are considerably limited. That is why I voted in favor of the report, which calls on the European Union to develop development cooperation and aid more effectively. I consider it necessary for aid to be better aligned with national development plans and internationally agreed sustainable development goals. Furthermore, there is a need for domestic actors to be involved as much as possible in the implementation of development programs. We have already learned in the past that when there is a lack of ownership, development aid does not have the desired effects. I joined the call for the Member States to start fulfilling their budgetary commitment made at the United Nations and for the European Commission to be more active in monitoring development progress. It is necessary to align the action plans of the Member States and the European Union as much as possible and to make development policy more transparent. I have therefore also supported OECD initiatives to reduce illegal financial flows and put multinational companies under greater control.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - The EU is the largest contributor to development aid. As a Social Democrat, I believe that development aid plays an important role in the fight against poverty, but only if it is managed effectively. It is therefore our duty to improve the effectiveness of this assistance and thus ensure the desired development. The Social Democratic Group advocated a revision of the report aimed at strengthening the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation, greater involvement of civil society and elected representatives in the implementation of the development effectiveness agenda and, last but not least, greater transparency in access to information. . I have recently addressed the effective use of development and humanitarian aid in my report to the Committee on Budgetary Control. I consider the effective linking of development aid with humanitarian aid to be one of the key elements for increasing efficiency. At the same time, the EU must strengthen its control mechanisms, require timely and full reporting, and insist on the link between development aid and compliance with human rights commitments, in particular by its recipients.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- In the new context of the 2030 Agenda, and given the need to "do more with less", greater effectiveness in aid delivery and development cooperation remain crucial in order to help alleviate poverty and combat root causesof emigration.The report identifies a number of important issues.The EU and its Member States could, for example, work on new initiatives to develop triangular cooperation projects with the involvement of emerging donors and middle-income countries.I agree with the rapporteur where he stresses that governance based on the rule of law and respect for human rights in developing countries is an indispensable element for development assistance to play its role correctly in reducing poverty.I voted in favor of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- I support making a long-term commitment, which is to allocate 0.33% of GNI to development aid in the case of the new member states, and 0.7% in the case of the "old Union" countries.Over the past 7 years, my country has spent about 0.09% of GNI, ie ¼ of the declared amount, on development aid annually.This is due to the lack of funds, but of course we are committed to achieving this goal.Nevertheless, we are currently unable to live up to the commitment, although we fully support it.That is why I abstained from voting.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- In the framework of the meeting of the global partnership for effective cooperation for development to be held at the end of November in Nairobi, it was important that the European Union, as the world's largest donor in development aid, adopteda strong position by insisting on the need to improve transparency, good governance and the rule of law in developing countries.I therefore voted in favor of this report, which recalls that development effectiveness cannot be guaranteed without peace and respect for human rights, which are essential conditions for achieving the sustainable development goals.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The European Union has been committed for a long time to developing a model of development cooperation. The Union, which plays an important role both in creating the current standards for aid and development effectiveness, and in adopting the 2030 Agenda, must continue to take the lead in these matters and contribute to the reflection on articulation and synergies between both. In this context, remarkable steps have been taken. Indeed, the launch of the results-based Union framework in March 2015 represented a step forward in strengthening the accountability, transparency and visibility of EU aid. I agree with colleague Cristian Dan Preda, when he says that legitimate and inclusive governance, based on the rule of law and respect for human rights in developing countries, is an indispensable element for development assistance to adequately play its role in reducing poverty and improving citizens' perspectives. I voted in favor.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against the non-legislative report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The EU does not have the legitimacy to order countries, whether they are Member States or third countries, how or when they may use their foreign-aid budget, how much to spend or where it goes. UKIP does not support this growing influence and power of the EU and therefore voted against.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - A few days before the conference of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Co-operation, Parliament has sent a clear message of support for this OECD initiative. By 545 votes in favor, 39 against and 92 abstentions, MEPs voted in favor of strengthening the aid effectiveness of the Global Partnership and Member States. Founded in 2011, this forum brings together the different actors (beneficiaries, donors, private sector, civil society) to boost development policies. While welcoming the efforts made, the report underlines that civil society and the private sector are essential partners, that transparency is essential and that there is a need to adopt national policies relating to development assistance in recipient countries. The text emphasizes in particular the 2005 commitment of the Member States to devote at least 0.7% of their gross national income to development as of 2015. Although last year the EU was the largest donor of development aid to the world with 68 billion euros, only 5 countries have actually succeeded in meeting this target: Sweden (1.4%), Luxembourg (0.93%), Denmark (0.85%), Low (0.76%) and the United Kingdom (0.71%). We are therefore far from the mark.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- The European Union, as the world's largest donor of development aid, has a responsibility to improve the effectiveness and accountability of its assistance programs.Hence the usefulness of all mechanisms that can contribute to advancing the development effectiveness agenda, such as triangular cooperation projects, the involvement of national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and the private sector.The European Union must ensure more effective collaboration for development if it is to have a real impact on poverty reduction in a growing context of humanitarian and development crises and scarcity of resources.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- I voted in favor of this Report which assesses the implementation of global commitments on the effectiveness of development aid, the realization of the sustainable development goals and the Action Agenda on Financing.All Member States are requested to set up and implement plans for development cooperation, to increase their contributions and to fulfill their commitments, in addition to making information and different data more accessible, in addition to that,together with the Commission, inform national parliaments and local and regional authorities to encourage coordination and publish evaluations of development cooperation and calls for projects and public contracts.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of strengthening the effectiveness of development cooperation, as a premise of the high-level meeting of the global partnership for effective development cooperation, to be held next week in Nairobi. The European Union, a true pioneer in development, must strengthen existing strategies and orient them towards convincing results by complementing national actions. Inclusive partnership, transparency and mutual accountability are “driving forces for the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals”. We must achieve our commitment objective and ensure the quality of the aid provided and the monitoring of the actions carried out, with regard to the implementation of the 2030 Agenda. For this, we must rely on the national forces of countries, but also involve civil society and all front-line actors. This also requires respect for governance, democratic values ​​and fundamental rights.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: in writing.- Development cooperation is not only an important instrument for aid to developing countries, but also an important tool in the EU's external relations.It is very good that we are paying enough attention to helping third countries.It is not so good that the European Commission is avoiding the wider application of the conditionality mechanism in this area, which is to link EU support closely to the progress of the recipient state in establishing good governance and strengthening the protection of human rights.Nevertheless, I support this resolution as a good tool for finding more effective use of EU development cooperation aid.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the full relevance of the Principles of Development Effectiveness. I consider it essential that the effectiveness agenda is a key pillar of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The resolution highlights the importance of all development policies complying with the principles of appropriability and alignment with the national development strategies of the different countries, emphasizing the need to decouple aid and the importance of making use of the systems of public procurement from partner countries as a first option. The resolution also states that private sector agents must adhere to the principles of development effectiveness and adhere to the principles of corporate social responsibility throughout the project life cycle and highlights the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social and environmental norms, as well as the United Nations Global Compact on Human Rights, the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the fundamental norms of the ILO in labor matters and the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Aid Effectiveness Report because the EU has an obligation to improve aid effectiveness and make it more effective.In the context of the new 2030 Agenda, assistance and development cooperation still play an important role, particularly in combating poverty, stabilizing local communities and strengthening national resilience.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted against this report because it frames and legitimizes development cooperation within the market logic, reinforcing the role of companies within development cooperation mechanisms. The call included in the text for aid recipient countries to undertake "the introduction of market economy mechanisms", "the opening of their markets to global competition" or "the mobilization of private capital" is a conditioning and an attempt to use development cooperation to interfere with the sovereignty of each country when organizing and regulating its economy. I reject cooperation designed to open the door to business for European companies in impoverished countries. And therefore, we reject this report that demands and conditions - in pursuit of the "effectiveness" of the aid - that third countries enable the private sector to do business with basic services such as infrastructure, health or education. On the contrary, I understand that the effectiveness of aid passes through cooperation and the reinforcement of the role of the States of these impoverished countries, through the development of public services and through public control of strategic economic sectors.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - I have decided to cast my vote in favor of this report, considering it essential that the EU and the Member States commit themselves to work on new initiatives for achieving more effective development cooperation. Firstly, I agree with the importance of more funding for cooperation policies, hence the need for Member States to honor their commitment to allocate 0.7% of their planned gross national income to development aid. I also share the need for greater transparency from the EU, national parliaments and private actors on programming, for example through reporting that makes data, information and action plans more accessible, timely and comparable at EU level. In this sense, adequate support should be given to the parliaments of the beneficiary countries as assistance can only be effective if the recipients are committed and responsible and guarantee the full participation of local actors in the implementation and monitoring of development programs.

name: Jill SEYMOUR
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I do not wish for the EU to start dictating to the UK how they use their own budget.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing - The EU is the world's largest provider of development aid, so it must also have a special responsibility to improve the effectiveness of EU aid worldwide.I think that more needs to be done at both EU and global level to increase aid effectiveness and development cooperation.In order to increase aid effectiveness, it is essential that recipient countries cooperate and pursue growth-friendly economic policies in their countries in parallel with the adoption of development aid.I voted in favor.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing - In December 2016, five years will have passed since the adoption of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation. I agree that it is important to assess this period in terms of the implementation of global commitments on aid and development effectiveness and, in the context of the new program, to take measures to help meet the 2030 targets. I supported the resolution because I believe that only more effective Development aid and development assistance can ensure better delivery in the fight against poverty, the elimination of inequalities, especially in the least developed countries, better access for the most deprived and vulnerable groups to quality public services, and other key systemic factors. As I consider financial resources to be a basic precondition for more effective development cooperation and the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals, I expect all ODA providers who have not yet fulfilled their commitment to allocate 0.7% of GNI to development aid by 2015 as soon as possible. At the same time, I join the call for development actors to build on the commitments made between the Paris and Busan forums and to step up their efforts to develop development cooperation as effectively as possible.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the own-initiative report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation in the final vote. The report is based on the forthcoming second meeting of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC), a multilateral forum of 161 countries, to be held from 28 November 2016 to 1 December 2016 in Nairobi, Kenya, to monitor the current development of the common objectives adopted at the Busan (Republic of Korea) Forum in 2011. In its report, the European Parliament emphasizes its role of democratic scrutiny of all EU policies, including development policies, while drawing attention to the need to respond to new development challenges stability, food security). I consider it necessary for the Commission to monitor how effectively financial aid is used and not misused for other purposes. I join the report in calling for the Member States to be even more active in the future in cooperating with the national parliaments of countries in need of development aid. A good example in this respect is, for example, the work of the Czech Development Agency, which was very positively praised in a recent OECD study.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - I believe that the principle of aid effectiveness has clearly contributed to progress in achieving development goals in many countries. It is true that there are still obvious differences between countries in terms of progress, but if the development agenda continues to be supported, these differences may narrow and blur over time. In addition, ODA can play an important role in implementing the 2030 Agenda, especially in low-income countries, as well as in combating extreme poverty and inequality. It should be noted here that it must be better targeted and respect the principles of effective development cooperation, democratic accountability of countries, coordination, local capacity building, transparency and democratic accountability, focus on results and inclusion. Using all available development policy tools is good for eradicating poverty and promoting sustainable development goals. However, I believe that the effectiveness of development finance should be assessed on the basis of concrete results and its contribution to development policy as a whole. Considering that development cooperation is an important element in meeting the agenda for development efficiency, eradicating poverty and reducing inequality, I voted in favor of the resolution and also supported it.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - The European Union has a leading role in development cooperation. While many positive things are already being done in this regard, more can be done to increase the effectiveness of aid and development, both at EU and global level. By focusing on greater involvement of national parliaments, civil society and citizens of the countries that receive aid, their democratic contribution will increase and the path to greater independence will open. The Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC), which oversees the Busan Accords, will meet at the end of November to take the lead in improving development cooperation. According to the rapporteur, this meeting can only be successful if it produces new ideas for sustainable development and there is transparency around the concrete contribution of each participant. As far as we are concerned, the report is good, but the European Union is losing sight of important principles by increasingly spending money for development on reception for refugees. This expenditure is not a structural and sustainable solution that contributes to socio-economic development. The financial capacity for development cooperation is also declining, making the seriousness of the matter very clear. We deeply regret this and for that reason we will abstain.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - Development aid has made a significant contribution to the Millennium Development Goals, but some countries are still lagging behind.Development aid must continue, in particular, on issues such as the eradication of poverty and the achievement of the sustainable development goals.In addition, some aspects will need to be improved, such as corruption, transparency, partnership with the private sector and the transfer of responsibility from sender to shared responsibility.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the European Parliament on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.Development aid should be a matter for the Member States.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The EU is committed to improving the effectiveness of aid to developing countries and their progress through development cooperation in the long term.The report calls for better coherence between global actors in international aid and fostering development.Strong emphasis is placed on monitoring results, transparency and the shared responsibility of donors, but also the local community to achieve results.The local government must take part of the responsibility.That is why it is important to involve local participants and society in the implementation of projects.Without peace, respect for human rights and the rule of law, effective implementation of development projects cannot be achieved.I support this report because it calls for the use of all development policy tools in eradicating poverty and promoting the goals of sustainable development, and emphasizes that the effectiveness of development funding should be assessed on the basis of concrete results.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.If we want to follow the commitments and goals of the 2030 Agenda and thus use public and private funds for development, then we must step up our efforts to increase the effectiveness of development cooperation.We are still facing differences in progress, as not all countries and other actors have regularly implemented all the principles.I support the call for the use of all development policy tools to eradicate poverty and promote the goals of sustainable development.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I supported today's draft report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation, as I believe that the European Union, as the world's largest provider of development aid, must constantly evaluate the procedures for achieving the most effective development aid.The report rightly points out that "legitimate and inclusive governance based on the rule of law and respect for human rights is an essential element of development aid in developing countries in order to properly fulfill its role in reducing poverty and improving the situation and future of the people".In providing development assistance, it is also necessary not only to rely on the activities of governments, but also to involve non-governmental organizations and other parts of civil society, which should be assisted even if their governments pursue a policy of non-respect of human rights.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The European Union has made a long-term commitment to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation, and December will mark the 5th anniversary of the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation. In this context, this report highlights the key role of Formal Development Assistance. Notes its concern that only 5 Member States had published Busan implementation plans in 2015, and called on Member States to publish implementation plans and report on their efforts. It also emphasizes the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social environmental standards. For these reasons we voted in favor of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- We oppose a single market for cooperation with third countries.The economic performance so far has shown that the lack of transparency from local communities and elected representatives does not guarantee the actual taxation of profits where the activity is carried out, resulting in illegal financial flow.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - The report highlights the Union's long-term commitment to improving the effectiveness of aid and development through development cooperation. Accordingly, the European Parliament has already taken a position on improving aid effectiveness in the previous cycle, which is now included in the broader concept of development effectiveness. The report points out that, after five years, it is important to take stock of the implementation of global commitments on aid and development effectiveness, and that this opportunity also provides a good opportunity to analyze how aid and development have contributed to sustainable development. and the implementation of the Addis Ababa Agenda for Financing for Development. I think it is important to note that the Union has played a key role both in setting current standards for aid and development effectiveness and in adopting the 2030 Agenda, and now that we have entered the implementation phase, we must continue to take the lead on these issues. An interesting detail is that the European Union and the Member States have previously committed to dedicating 0.7% of their gross national income to aid. All this through the European Development Fund (EDF), so in a transparent, predictable and accountable way. I believe that through this, we can effectively help developing countries with innovation and technology.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - The European Union has for many years been committed to improving the effectiveness of aid and development. This December marks the fifth anniversary of the Busan Partnership on Effective Cooperation. After five years, it is therefore important to take stock of the implementation of the global commitments. It is also a good opportunity to analyze how increasing aid and development effectiveness could contribute to the UN Sustainable Development Goals and the Addis Ababa Action Plan for Aid Funding. As the world's largest donor, the Union has a special responsibility to improve development efficiency and accountability worldwide. At the same time, we must promote integrated governance based on the rule of law and respect for human rights in developing countries. We should strive to develop new initiatives to develop tripartite cooperation projects involving new donors and middle income countries. The Union and its Member States need to be more proactive and systematic in involving national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and private actors in programming.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report.I place particular emphasis on keeping religious communities among development actors, as I see their role in this context as globally significant.Among development aid communities, religious organizations are one of the largest actors and should not be excluded from this listing.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - The common approach, in the sense of global partnership, in terms of increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation is necessary if we really want to transform the world we live in, ie implementing the 2030 Agenda. It is time to take responsibility (obviously differentiated) to those who receive help. The shift from "aid effectiveness" to "development cooperation effectiveness" is welcome in this context, but insofar as it is based on concrete results in terms of contributing to sustainable and inclusive development. The principle of "leaving no one behind", in line with the general philosophy and primary commitment of the 2030 Agenda, is the essence of increasing the effectiveness of cooperation for the development of society at global level. But the process of applying this principle efficiently and effectively requires indicators of operationalization and monitoring, exchange of best practices and substantial evaluations, dissemination of results and progress, so that accountability and the impact of development cooperation increase, not just at Member State level. . It also requires well-founded national policies on adequate development aid in order to increase the accountability of all those interested in development.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - As the main source of development aid worldwide, the European Union also has a great responsibility to properly regulate this sector. The main problems in this regard are the effectiveness of aid and the transparency of Union funding for developing countries. Following the Fourth High Level Forum on Development Aid Effectiveness, an institutional mechanism for monitoring this area was established in 2011 in the form of the Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC). It is intended to be a platform for dialogue at international level and to ensure the fulfillment of the commitments made by the participating States. The ultimate goal is to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) adopted by the UN General Assembly and to implement the Addis Ababa Agenda for Action, documents adopted in 2015. In order to achieve these goals, the EU supports a number of innovative approaches to each of the relevant actors to achieve its mission, as well as to adopt new mechanisms, such as triangular cooperation projects, with the involvement of national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and the private sector. It is a commendable initiative and I therefore support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I expressed myself positively when voting on this report.The European Union, as the world's largest donor of development assistance, has a particular responsibility in improving aid effectiveness and accountability around the Union's support around the world.Beyond this aspect, the Union should lead global efforts to advance development effectiveness and ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law in developing countries remain at the heart ofconcerns.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The Busan Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation is the multilateral agreement between civil society organisations, as well as partner governments, traditional donors, BRICS and private donors. In the aim of increasing aid and development effectiveness, the Busan Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation is now being reviewed, ten years on, in order to scrutinise implementation of the global commitments regarding aid and development effectiveness. I voted in favour of the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation because I believe the aid-monitoring framework that was established ten years ago has to be built upon to be further strengthened and adjusted for maximum success.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing. - I believe it is important to focus on the quality and effectiveness of the resources allocated. In fact, development aid is made up of many items, including financing for international agencies, development banks, aid credits. They are all useful components, but we must not lose sight of the central objective, namely the fight against poverty by supporting in countries the definition of policies to support the population and the implementation of effective interventions within the framework of the 2030 Agenda. Member States are invited to work on new initiatives to develop triangular cooperation projects with the involvement of emerging donors and middle-income countries. The EU, including at delegation level, and its Member States could be more proactive and systematically involve national parliaments, local authorities, civil society and private actors in programming and financial commitments related to development assistance, by publishing aid analyzes for country-specific development cooperation. It is also essential to reduce the administrative costs that involve too high a percentage of public development aid.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: written.- I support the Motion for a resolution to increase the efficiency of development cooperation.I believe that the motion for a resolution is a kind of follow-up to the acquis of the Paris Declaration of 2005, the Accra Action Plan of 2008 and the G20 meeting in Busan in 2010. Since the European Union has committed itself tothis resolution is an indicator of the consistency of the Union's path.On the EU side, important steps have been taken to increase aid transparency, improve joint programming, address conflict and instability, and measure results.In particular, progress should be noted on joint programming, which now covers more than half of the partner countries receiving EU development assistance.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I supported Cristian Dan Predo's report because the European Union, the world's largest donor of development aid, has a special responsibility to tailor and deliver useful aid.I support the idea of seeking innovative approaches to sustainable development around the world.I agree that in order to deliver aid as effectively as possible, we must be guided by four principles: a stronger focus on aid results in reducing poverty and inequality in developing countries, transparency and shared responsibility, accountability for development priorities and support for donor societies.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- Although development aid has contributed to the progress of many countries, progress is still uneven because the principles of its implementation are not respected equally in all countries.That is why the European Union and the Member States must work to develop more flexible, predictable and accountable projects that contribute more to development.I believe that the goal of sustainable development, which refers to peace, justice and strong institutions, is of the utmost importance for the effectiveness of development aid, since the rule of law and respect for human rights in developing countries are necessary elements for providing development aid and reducing poverty.I particularly support the view that more needs to be achieved at European Union and global level with less funding in order to increase the effectiveness of development aid, and I believe that this can be achieved through public-private partnerships with the private sector.That is why I voted in favor of the report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.The EU is the largest donor of development aid in the world and is therefore particularly responsible for improving the effectiveness of its aid and increasing the responsibility associated with it.In addition, the EU should be at the forefront of global efforts to advance the Development Effective Agenda and ensure that transparency, good governance and the rule of law in developing countries remain at the center of attention.The EU has a long-term commitment to improving aid effectiveness and development through development cooperation.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the full relevance of the Principles of Development Effectiveness. I consider it essential that the effectiveness agenda is a key pillar of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The resolution highlights the importance of all development policy complying with the principles of appropriability and alignment with the national development strategies of the different countries, emphasizing the need to decouple aid and the importance of making use of the systems of public procurement from partner countries as a first option. The resolution also states that private sector agents must adhere to the principles of development effectiveness and adhere to the principles of corporate social responsibility throughout the project life cycle and highlights the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social and environmental norms, as well as the United Nations Global Compact on Human Rights, the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the fundamental norms of the ILO on labor matters and the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report and the objective of increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. In particular solving the root problems of migration in Africa will help Europe’s current dramatic issues linked to migration. Fighting against poverty and under-development in our Southern Mediterranean is in our own interest.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - This report highlights the improvements to be made to the development assistance programs offered to developing countries, particularly in Africa. This report points to issues such as the fragmentation of aid, the lack of coordination between donors, aid agencies and donor countries. Indeed, the Union is the largest donor at the world level (68 billion euros in 2015). European aid is the victim of dispersion since almost 75% of it is allocated by the Member States according to national procedures in order to maintain a strong link with former colonies (France, the Netherlands, Spain, etc. .). This is a recurring problem in this committee: the need for increased coordination with national policies which goes against our philosophy, since implicitly, it means giving more powers to the Commission. This report provides some interesting avenues such as the need to include all participants (including local actors, civil society, the private sector, national parliaments, trade unions) with a corollary of greater accountability. Recipient countries are encouraged to adopt national development policies, consolidate public finances and eradicate corruption and waste, in order to ultimately reduce dependence on development aid. I chose abstention on this file.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The main thrust of the draft report should be endorsed, as it is important, both at EU and global level, to help more effectively with the commitment of financial resources, to improve the quality of our development aid.An interesting solution is cooperation with the private sector through combined instruments and under public-private partnerships.All the negotiated compromises are remarkable, with the exception of compromise # 2, which concerns the weakening of the ODA criteria.As a whole, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The Union has long been committed to improving the effectiveness of aid and development through development cooperation.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the full relevance of the Principles of Development Effectiveness. I consider it essential that the effectiveness agenda is a key pillar of the implementation of the Sustainable Development Goals. The resolution highlights the importance of all development policy complying with the principles of appropriability and alignment with the national development strategies of the different countries, emphasizing the need to decouple aid and the importance of making use of the systems of public procurement from partner countries as a first option. The resolution also states that private sector agents must adhere to the principles of development effectiveness and adhere to the principles of corporate social responsibility throughout the project life cycle and highlights the need for the private sector to respect the principles of international law and social and environmental norms, as well as the United Nations Global Compact on Human Rights, the United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights, the fundamental norms of the ILO on labor matters and the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Abstained as although not against whole content of the report do strongly regret that it does not address the current blatant violations of development effectiveness principles by the EU in the context of its migration policies.

name: Viktor USPASKICH
text: in writing.- I welcome the progress made and recommend that the Commission continue its efforts to ensure that all relevant actors have access to information on the transparency of development cooperation programming, financing mechanisms, projects and aid flows, in particular in the context of the International Aid Transparency Initiative.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The EU has a long-standing commitment to improving aid and development effectiveness through development cooperation. The commitments taken in Busan, building on the acquis of the 2005 Paris Declaration and 2008 Accra Agenda for action, have helped define an international standard on aid effectiveness applicable to all actors of development. The EU, which has played a major role both in building the current standards for aid and development effectiveness, and in the adoption of Agenda 2030, should continue to assume leadership on these issues and contribute to the reflection on the articulation and synergies between the two, now that we have entered the implementation stage. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that more needs to be done, both at EU and global level, to increase the effectiveness of aid and development cooperation.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- This text is presented for the second high-level meeting of the Global Partnership for Aid Effectiveness, to be held in Nairobi from November 28 to December 1, as a continuation of the one that took place in MexicoDF in April 2014. With its sights set on Nairobi, the European Parliament hopes to contribute to the achievement of a common Union position on the trend to send national comments to the drafters of the Final Document.Thus, in order to support the principle of aid effectiveness from a European position, I voted in favor.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written. - I voted against this report because it frames and legitimizes development cooperation within the market logic, reinforcing the role of companies within development cooperation mechanisms. The call included in the text for aid recipient countries to undertake "the introduction of market economy mechanisms", "the opening of their markets to global competition" or "the mobilization of private capital" is a conditioning and an attempt to use development cooperation to interfere with the sovereignty of each country when organizing and regulating its economy. I reject cooperation designed to open the door to business for European companies in impoverished countries. And therefore, we reject this report that demands and conditions - in pursuit of the "effectiveness" of the aid - that third countries enable the private sector to do business with basic services such as infrastructure, health or education. On the contrary, I understand that the effectiveness of aid passes through cooperation and the reinforcement of the role of the States of these impoverished countries, through the development of public services and through public control of strategic economic sectors.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it sets out Parliament’s position on the principles of effective development cooperation and how they can contribute to implementing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), particularly in the context of ‘doing more, with less’ i.e. increasing development to meet the SDGs without dramatic increases in overall aid levels.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted to emphasize the encouragement of recipient country parliaments to adopt national development aid policies, to increase the accountability of donors and recipient countries, including local authorities, to the financial management of public resources andabsorption capacity, eradicate corruption and all forms of aid fragmentation, make tax systems effective and improve the conditions for eligibility for budget support and to reduce dependence on development aid in the longer term.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written.- I was involved in drafting this report on improving the effectiveness of development cooperation as the shadow rapporteur for my group.I will seek to include in the report a broader perspective on how development can be effectively promoted.In addition to development aid and cooperation, other development policy instruments are needed to effectively eradicate poverty and promote other sustainable development goals.I voted in favor of the outcome.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - In 2002, the Monterrey Conference was supposed to take us from the era of worrying about the volume of development aid to that of questioning its quality. In 2005, the Paris Declaration promised alignment of donor countries with the development goals of recipient countries. In 2011, the Global Partnership was to work to untie the provision of this aid from any conditions imposed by the provider country. We are in 2016 and the failure of these ambitions is obvious. Not only has the volume of aid not reached the level requested since 1970, but, far from aligning itself with local needs, aid is increasingly used to serve the interests of European companies, including included as part of the fight against climate change, when it is not diverted for the purposes of migration control. This report only partially accounts for this reality. It also adopts a contradictory posture with the principles it sets out by claiming to decide what the aid should be primarily intended for. I abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This discussion is not without some hypocrisy.At the same time that some here unravel a list of pious concerns, they forget that it is the policies that are decided here that, to a large extent, hinder the development possibilities of the least developed countries.Deregulation and liberalization of international trade and tax havens are privileged instruments designed to favor the drainage of resources from poor countries to rich countries, and not the other way around.Covered by these concerns, what some want is to impose on the developing countries the sacrosanct market economy - erected as a panacea for all the ills of humanity - the role of the private sector and the opening of markets to world competition.The solution is to change policies and not to insist on the same paths that have brought us here.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The report aims to improve coordination among different donor countries, calling on the member states of the Union in particular to cooperate better with nations such as Brazil and Russia.Further aspects are the strengthening of the fight against corruption in the recipient countries and the involvement of private actors.Overall, the report does not rule out a financial increase in development aid, but rather focuses on optimizing the use of funds (“doing more with less”).Since this use of funds in development aid is an objective worth supporting and in its present form does not create any additional burdens for the Member States, I approved the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on improving the effectiveness of development cooperation. Considering that the EU is the world's largest donor of development aid, we have an important responsibility and should be able to lead global efforts to boost development worldwide. The report recalls that the EU is committed to untying its aid and recognizes the progress made in this area; calls on all development aid providers to step up efforts to accelerate the untying of aid globally. The EU, which played an important role in adopting the 2030 Agenda, should continue to take the lead on these. The Addis Ababa Action Program led to the creation of a United Nations ECOSOC Forum for Development Financing, as well as the biennial ECOSOC Development Cooperation Forum which aims to be a global forum for sharing knowledge on trends and advances in international development cooperation. The GPEDC, on the other hand, offers a particular perspective in that it focuses on the relationships between development actors and monitors the progress made in applying the principles of aid and development effectiveness.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As the largest development aid provider in the world, the EU is committed to improving the effectiveness of development aid to make sure aid spending is as effective as possible and reaches its intended targets. This report sets out the steps the EU should take to meet the Busan commitments on aid effectiveness and to reach its development targets, whilst attempting to ‘do more, with less’. The report forms a good outline on how the EU can maximise the effectiveness of its development aid and meet its development targets agreed in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In order to make development policy truly effective, we must make sure we have policy coherence for development, and make sure we apply our values consistently to trade, economic and foreign policy. We must also properly recognise the role of culture as a powerful catalyst for development. This is an example of why EU action on this is so important.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up. - I voted on the own-initiative report of my colleague Cristian Preda on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. The report calls on all development actors to build on their commitments, as well as to renew and intensify their efforts to make development cooperation as effective as possible, in order to achieve ambitious goals and targets. set out in the 2030 Agenda and make optimal use of public and private resources for development. It also calls for the use of all development policy instruments to eradicate poverty. As rapporteur for the EU Regulation on Minerals from Conflict Areas, I am a supporter of more effective development cooperation, because only by stepping up efforts to eradicate poverty and the exploitation of people and communities in conflict areas can we truly the EU's mission to promote democracy and human rights worldwide.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing - It has been 5 years since the EU adopted the Busan Partnership Agreement to ensure more effective development cooperation. This agreement has been approved by 161 countries and 54 international organizations. It is an inclusive agreement that brings together not only state actors but also international and regional organizations, the private sector and civil society. The EU has made a long-standing commitment to making development aid effective. The Global Partnership for Effective Development Cooperation (GPEDC) monitors the implementation of the commitments of the said agreement. It must be borne in mind that the EU is the largest provider of development aid and therefore has a great deal of responsibility for improving its effectiveness. The GPEDC, which focuses not only on monitoring the implementation of the principles of aid effectiveness and development, but also on the relations between the various actors, can provide added value for the Development Finance Forum, which is involved in implementing and monitoring the 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: in writing. - The ECR Group unreservedly supports the report presented. We agree that "more needs to be done with less," and the current migration crisis we are facing in the EU is just a picture of poverty and the absence of any economic or social perspective in many of the world's developing and poorest countries. In particular, I would like to emphasize the following three principles, which I consider to be fundamental vectors for increasing the effectiveness of our development policies: 1. The role of the private sector is crucial. In addition to traditional governmental and non-governmental development organizations, the private sector is a real and effective partner in our development strategies and is a new source of financing for development aid in general; 2. The European Union cannot bear responsibility (and consequences) for the failure of global development policies and ongoing armed conflicts. New actors in development aid, such as China, Brazil, Turkey, Russia or India, need to be more involved, not only because of their geographical proximity, their historical ties, but also because of their recent or current experience with their own development; 3. Last but not least, it should be recalled that the effectiveness of development aid depends to a large extent on developing countries themselves. At the same time, recipient countries must pursue pro-growth economic policies that introduce market economy mechanisms, the mobilization of private capital and the gradual integration into the world economy.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - Development cooperation is one of the European Union's long-term commitments, which is why I support this report, which looks at ways to make it more effective. As one of the largest providers of development aid, the EU has a special responsibility to improve aid effectiveness worldwide and should therefore lead by example to other actors. I believe that it is important not only to support development aid and its financing, but also to promote an approach that goes beyond this aid. I am thinking, for example, of steps to increase the transparency of aid, to improve joint planning or to ensure good coordination between stakeholders - especially in the areas of monitoring, transparency and shared responsibility. In promoting development policy, I consider it essential to involve all important actors - national parliaments, local authorities, the private sector, but also local actors. Only in this way can development cooperation be effective.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing - I supported Mr Predo's report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation. Development cooperation plays an important role in achieving the goals of sustainable development. I agree that the traditional concept of development cooperation needs to be changed and adapted to the new conditions, and I believe that in order for development cooperation to achieve its goal, efforts are needed on both sides. Aid must be effective, proactive and at the same time accompanied by effective development policies. On the other hand, it is necessary to abandon the perception of development aid on the donor-recipient principle. It is also important that countries not only commit themselves to contributing to development aid, but also that they actually meet their 2015 commitments and contribute the promised 0.7% of GNI. Only by responsibly fulfilling the commitments that the states have made in the field of development cooperation can the European Union maintain its global leadership.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Preda report, as I agree with the need to make the best use of public and private resources for cooperation and development in order to achieve the ambitious goals and objectives defined in the 2030 Agenda. I highlight the fundamental role of public aid to development in meeting the agenda for development effectiveness, in eradicating poverty, in reducing inequalities, in providing essential public services and in supporting good governance. To this end, it is necessary for the European Union and its Member States to honor their commitment to allocate 0.7% of gross national income to development cooperation and adopt an effective roadmap to achieve the agreed target in a transparent, predictable manner. is responsable. I also highlight the importance of placing a strong emphasis on poor, vulnerable and marginalized groups, taking due account of gender equality and situations of fragility and conflict, in the context of the development effectiveness agenda.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: written.- One of the key models of assistance that the European Union provides to other countries is development cooperation.I support this report because it clearly emphasizes the importance of development aid and sustainable development financing, but also calls for an upgrade of the existing approach.This is based on encouraging efficiency and strengthening local communities and national resilience to all generators of instability in the economic development path.On the other hand, it is necessary, on the other hand, to ensure the greatest possible transparency and information on aid flows in order to ensure maximum effectiveness in achieving the goals of sustainable development.Cooperation with actors at the state level, but also at the levels of regional and local government, is key to bringing programs and funding closer to goals such as poverty reduction, ensuring equal access to services, especially education, and establishing a model of community self-sustainability.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Report on increasing the effectiveness of development cooperation.Development challenges have changed with new global challenges such as migration, food security, peace and stability, and climate change, and we need strong approaches and cooperation to address them.The report confirms the importance of ODA and sustainable development financing, while also promoting a self-initiative approach that goes beyond assistance provided by ODA.I believe it is important that all development actors approach the eradication of poverty and the promotion of sustainable development goals through closer cooperation and awareness of shared responsibility for development results.The effectiveness of development cooperation cannot be ensured without peace, respect for human rights and the rule of law, and international principles and standards of law.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: Explanations of vote are closed.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria (2016/2933 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, thank you all for keeping a constant focus on Syria in your plenary debates. I am really sorry I could not be with you in person last month, but I believe this is the fourth or fifth time this year that we have had a plenary debate on our work on Syria. Last month I was in Brussels for the Afghanistan conference, another important file in which the European Union has a very important part to play, but the Slovak Presidency briefed me on your October exchanges, and they also provided a very important input for the discussions we had at the Foreign Affairs Council both in October and last week.  We have discussed Syria again, as I mentioned, in the Foreign Affairs Council both in October and last week, on Monday to be precise, and I have engaged in a number of meetings with both Syrian, regional and international actors, so for me this debate is a very precious opportunity to update you with the most recent initiatives and contacts and work we are carrying on, starting from the work on the humanitarian side that, together with Christos Stylianides, we have carried out relentlessly, I would say, in these last months.  Over the last few days, there has been a new escalation of violence against the eastern neighbourhoods of Aleppo. The resumption of airstrikes has worsened the humanitarian situation even further, particularly because it has left hundreds of thousands of besieged civilians without access to functioning hospitals. Together with Christos and his team, whom I would like to praise, and together with the United Nations, we are working literally day and night to create the conditions to let the humanitarian aid in, and to let the wounded out, of East Aleppo, as as well as to other besieged areas all across the Syrian territory.  To reach this goal, we are engaging both internationally with all relevant actors, and on the ground. We are in constant contact with the city council of eastern Aleppo, as well as with civilian administrations in several parts of Syria. We are helping them provide services to the local population in the areas where this is possible. Our activity on the ground is increasingly recognised, first of all by the local players, by the Syrians themselves, and this is for me – and I can speak also on behalf of Christos and all the people who are working with us on this – the number one priority, that our work reaches the Syrians on the ground. Believe me when I tell you of our frustration at not managing to do more, but all the humanitarian work that is done is basically thanks also, I cannot say all, but almost all, to the funding, the work, the support, the logistics, the commitment of the European Union. Here again, I would like to thank our team, both on the ground and in Brussels, which has been working really at an incredible rhythm on this, in full coordination always, with the United Nations.  Our work, as I said, is increasingly recognised inside Syria but also internationally. The contacts and the channels we have developed in this field will be crucial also to any settlement and to the transition.
