As you all know, the delivery of humanitarian aid is proving to be a very difficult exercise, given the lack of a broader political agreement on the cessation of hostilities, and we have realised very clearly in these last couple of months that the military-to-military work on the cessation of hostilities is more and more difficult in the absence of a wider political understanding on the future of Syria. So what we risk is a vicious circle.  This is why, after having discussed this with the Foreign Ministers and with the Heads of State and Governments in the Foreign Affairs Council and in the European Council, I have started to reach out to the key regional actors on the future of Syria. This means that in the last weeks I met and had talks with the foreign ministers or leaders, presidents, of different countries of the region on a clear agenda. In the name of transparency, and also in sharing with you this work, let me go into a rather detailed list again. I know this is not the politics we need to talk – we would also need to talk politics, but I think it is also important for you to know exactly what this regional outreach is meaning by now.  Meetings with Foreign Minister Al Thani of Qatar in Brussels. Then I headed to Tehran where I met President Rouhani and Foreign Minister Zarif, and two days later to Saudi Arabia to see King Salman. Last week I discussed this in Brussels with Foreign Minister Bassil of Lebanon. Over the weekend I met with Emirates Foreign Minister Sheikh Abdullah and Foreign Minister of Jordan Nasser Judeh. Contacts with others, notably Turkish Foreign Minister Çavuşoğlu and Egyptian Foreign Minister Shoukry will also follow. And on Friday, just a few days ago, we hosted a meeting with the Syrian opposition groups, the leaders of different groups that I met at length in Brussels to share this process with them, to listen to their views to ensure full ownership and an active participation on their side. And obviously all of this is done in constant contact with Staffan de Mistura and his team, both in Geneva and in the United Nations headquarters in New York.  So now to content. The focus of this outreach is on the future of Syria, looking in particular at the post-conflict end state. What I am trying to do is identify areas of common ground and possible elements of a positive agenda with all the key actors. The issues that we are discussing in the framework of this outreach include political accountability, decentralisation or devolution, participation and protection of all components of the very diverse Syrian society. I know that this Chamber is particularly attentive to the situation of Christians in the region; this is also part of our outreach. Reconciliation, especially the local exercises of reconciliation, and economic reconstruction. On the latter let me be extremely clear: the European Union is and will be ready to engage in the economic reconstruction of the country, together with other partners. But, let me stress as I stress it to our partners in the region, this will only happen once a political transition has begun under the framework of UN Security Council Resolution 2254.  This work aims at improving the chances for the success of the UN mandate and the UN Special Envoy for the intra-Syrian talks. Our regional outreach can help create some space and some confidence for the talks to start because of course it is, as I said, for the Syrians to decide the future of the country in direct talks under UN auspices, but in the meantime, if as the European Union we can provide some space regionally to accompany this process, it could only be useful. In six years of war we should have learned something about the conflict in Syria. At times, an agreement between global powers could not hold, even if it was found, because the situation was out of control on the ground. In other cases, local ceasefires did not hold even if they were reached, because there was no agreement on a broader political level, either in the region or internationally. As I said, sometimes it is a vicious circle. Things locally do not hold because the international regional framework is not accompanying; at some other times you find an agreement on regional and international level and you do not have the local actors on your side.  So peace in Syria will require at the same time an agreement among world powers, the UN framework, among regional actors, the work we are trying to do, and all local players. I understand that it might sound strange to talk and to work on post-conflict at exactly the moment when war still rages on, and yet, talking about reconstruction, reconciliation, post-conflict, the system of governance, that could ensure Syria future a way, is a way of maybe opening the door for a process of peace. Because only if we start putting all the pieces together and to create some kind of consensus among the regional actors and among the citizens will we contribute to building peace in Syria.  Now as you know very well, and as I repeated many times, the European Union is not militarily involved in this war. This is the result of a political decision, one that was taken years ago, that I fully share and that unites us all in Europe. We are not a party to the conflict. But this is not a constraint on our diplomatic action. On the contrary, this puts us in a privileged position as we work for peace. From our position, we understand better than others that there is no military solution to the war. We see that every escalation leads us further away, and not closer, to peace. We are in a privileged position as we can talk to everybody, we do talk to everybody, we are trusted by everybody, and I am convinced that the European Union will be, and is becoming, an indispensable force to make peace in Syria possible and to achieve it concretely on the ground.  I can only ask you, this Parliament, to keep supporting, as you have done constantly this year, our work on humanitarian grounds for creating the political space for peace in Syria and for all the people of Syria, to benefit from a brighter future in their country.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Madam High Representative, during our last debate on Syria, I described the humanitarian situation as being dramatic and today I have the impression that words fail me to describe the horror of this war that continues. As you very well know, the population is trapped between the Russian bombs and those of the regime. According to UN figures, 1 million people are under siege in Syria. The humanitarian aspect must remain the Union's priority and, in this sense, I would like to salute your work, Madam High Representative, and that of Mr Stylianides with a view to facilitating the delivery of aid to Syria. As for the political aspect, we are forced to note the paralysis of the international community. This paralysis has a responsible and that responsible is Russia, because Russia is there, it throws bombs and, at the same time, blocks any significant decision at the level of the Security Council of the United Nations. Russia will pay for this position and will not be able to avoid the price of this situation for some time. Before concluding, I would like to say that the position we have taken, namely to support humanitarian aid and not to engage militarily, must be maintained over the next period.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy that, in six years of war, the world has been repeatedly appalled by the atrocities against civilians carried out in Syria by Isis, Daesh and other terrorist groups. At the same time, the heavy, indiscriminate aerial bombardment of eastern Aleppo by Russia and the Assad regime has killed hundreds, and continues even as I speak today. The S&D Group condemns in the strongest terms the widespread violation of human rights and international humanitarian law and the deliberate continuous targeting of civilians, humanitarian workers and medical facilities by the parties involved in Aleppo. We call on the armed parties to the conflict, both state and non—state, to allow an immediate cessation of hostilities so as to pave the way for the resumption of negotiations, thereby ensuring that humanitarian assistance reaches all people in need throughout Syria, and immediately to allow medical evacuation and the delivery of emergency goods. We are deeply concerned about Russia heavily reinforcing its military navy in the eastern Mediterranean and about the renewal of large—scale airstrikes on Aleppo, which can only bring further death and suffering to the Syrian people. Watching this disaster, it is our impression that even dictionaries no longer have words to describe the atrocities and the slaughterhouse of Aleppo. We urge you, Ms Mogherini, the Member States and the international community, to use all diplomatic tools and pressure necessary to urge those involved, including the Russian-backed Syrian regime, to stop attacks on Aleppo and to ensure that all those responsible for war crimes and crimes against international humanitarian law are prosecuted under appropriate, impartial criminal justice.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, nearly six years on since the start of the civil war we find ourselves in a position where Syria has become an almost accepted item or piece of intractable, insoluble foreign policy and a tragic killing field. Like so many others in the House, I also advocated a no-fly zone five years ago before Russia entered the conflict, which would have limited the loss of life and would have prevented us reaching this stalemate we now see today. But I do of course recognise and thank the High Representative for the excellent and fantastic job she is doing to try and re-engage and resume talks. The atrocious siege of Aleppo by Assad’s army with the support of Russian bombers continues. UN special envoy Stephen O’Brien has described the situation as being one of a deliberate tactic of cruelty by Assad and Russia. We wait now to see what the Trump administrative policy will be with regard to Syria, but his comments regarding a deal with Russia over Syria and Ukraine leaves little room for optimism, both by betraying Ukrainian sovereignty and turning a blind eye to war crimes carried out against innocent civilians. We can draw some comfort that evil Isis is now being squeezed in Raqqa, but my fear is that they will regroup and re-emerge elsewhere, including in our cities in Europe.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, on Friday the world was an eyewitness to babies being bombed out of their incubators, and as the last hospital in Aleppo was targetedly pounded we must ask ourselves: why were we, those who promised ‘never again’, unable to prevent or stop these crimes against humanity from happening? It fills me with unspeakable shame.  The Syrian war has now lasted longer than the Second World War, and the Council still does not have a common position even while the impact of the war in Syria continues to shake the EU at its core. It is beyond comprehension, and particularly Prime Minister Renzi’s veto, preventing sanctions on Russia for the role that Putin’s army plays in bombing children, is a disgrace. Putin has taken maximum advantage of our absence.  So we do need an EU strategy, not on paper but one that leads to meaningful action, otherwise our negotiating position or persuasion towards third countries is far too weak. And while the EU and Member States are the main humanitarian donors, two thirds of Syrians do not have regular access to water and six million children need life-saving assistance. We are clearly not doing enough. Starvation is used as a war crime; look at Lebanon to draw your own conclusions. Declaring the statement with Turkey on migration as the Holy Grail will not solve our problems, especially when the EU is not delivering its part by ensuring relocation. My Group calls again for sanctions to be put in place against Russia’s role in committing war crimes, and the EU should lead broader efforts towards accountability and ending impunity. That includes ensuring that the hundreds of thousands of people being tortured and killed in prisons in Syria are not forgotten. Let there be no confusion: the hunger, despair, torture, bombardments and repression are causing people to flee. Assad’s barbarism is also directly leading to radicalisation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, High Representative, there is too much propaganda in everything that is happening in Syria. It has a double standard that does not help at all. For example, news that does not appear in the mainstream media and, therefore, is not in our interventions. On November 17 and 18, 2016, moderate al-Qaeda rebels shot down demonstrations in the eastern neighborhoods of Aleppo, demanding to leave through humanitarian corridors opened by Russia and the Syrian government. On 30 October, there was a chemical weapons attack in eastern Aleppo. On 13 November they launched a chlorine attack that killed 28 people. We could also talk about the response that US State Department spokesman John Kirby gave to a journalist, accusing Russia of certain attacks on hospitals. When we go to the source - a Turkish NGO - that NGO says it does not accuse Russia of bombing Aleppo hospitals; nor the WHO, to which it belongs; not even the regional office of the International Committee of the Red Cross, in Damascus, which says it confirms the attacks, but cannot know who carried them out. So let us leave that Manichaeism. We have demanded that all parties comply with international law, but only together can we reach peace. So let us not continue to call the terrorists “opposition”: they are the same ones who attacked in Brussels or in Paris; they are the same ones from Al Qaeda, who attacked my country on March 11th.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, dear High Representative! The news that we receive from Syria every day is extremely gruesome, and the situation in Aleppo, in particular, has deteriorated dramatically again in recent weeks, mainly due to the brutal air strikes by the Syrian army and Russia. Here the EU must continue to exert diplomatic and economic pressure on the conflicting parties and their allies in order to achieve a ceasefire and a return to the negotiating table. Likewise, the EU must do more to end human rights violations against prisoners. People are tortured, tortured and killed in both government prisons and detention centers, which are run by armed groups. According to Amnesty International, more than 17,500 people have died in prisons of the Syrian regime alone since the beginning of the conflict. The EU must urgently work here to ensure that prisoners are adequately treated, that those arbitrarily detained are released and that international and independent observers have access to prisons and other detention centers in Syria. The Syrian regime is responsible for the majority of the crimes committed in the conflict. But other parties to the conflict, particularly the so-called Islamic State, are also committing brutal crimes. For a lasting solution to the Syrian conflict, it is essential to hold those who have committed serious crimes accountable. Anything else would be a mockery of the victims.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Madam High Representative, the tragedy caused by the stalemate in Syria shows precisely the importance of mediation and diplomatic sophistication. That the international community has let this brutal civil war carry on for so long not only highlights its failure, but also displays an incredible lack of capacity in negotiation. That was often a role played by Great Britain, and it is my hope that our imminent diplomatic independence will allow us to fill this mediation gap, helping to assist the international community in working for the benefit of people trapped in these awful conflicts. We may not like everybody who we have to deal with on the international stage, but we cannot continue to allow conflicts to carry on over what ultimately boils down to disagreements between great powers. We must put these differences aside and return to sensible geopolitics, including the work towards a genuine sustainable peace in Syria.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I believe there is a consensus here in this House that resolute action should be taken against all military activity. But with the Syria conflict in particular, I have the impression that the two great powers - the Americans and the Russians - are not acting in concert to eradicate the actual aggressor, namely the Islamic State, but rather that this conflict is used to geopolitically screw up a conflict situation between the Americans and the Russians. That's the wrong way. We now have a new President of the United States of America and I have the impression that there is more will here, more willingness to work together to neutralize this real aggressor - the Islamic State. The sooner it is possible to neutralize this conflict, the sooner all those people who have come to Europe can go back to their homeland in order to help stabilize and rebuild their country.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, the High Representative is to be commended for the humanitarian aid that the Union is providing and has provided to the war-torn population of Syria.The ultimate goal must be to establish a peace of arms, peace and a stable state.This requires the cooperation of two great powers, the United States and Russia.Relations are now at a low point in the Cold War.The election of Donald Trump gives hope that this relationship can become constructive, and the European Union must also play a positive role in this.It has been said here several times that there is a need for accountability for crimes against humanity.I fully agree with this, but this cannot be started with a preconception, we can only talk about one side, but in this multi-participant war, the crimes committed by all parties must be fully exposed.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank Ms Mogherini for updating us and for her efforts to achieve something which seems to be impossible. But we need to continue our efforts, because the situation is deteriorating and peace negotiations are still at an impasse. We know that one million people are under siege, 200 000 are detained by the Assad regime under inhuman conditions. So I think our goal has still to be to achieve a ceasefire and to stop this massive violence against the civilian population for which both the Assad regime, backed by Russia and Iran, and Islamist extremists are responsible. And I support our colleague Schaake’s conclusion that Mr Putin has taken maximum advantage from the weakness and inactivity of the EU. I think what is most important is to end this climate of impunity for people who are daily committing war crimes. And the second problem is that the EU should finally have a common EU/Syria strategy to facilitate political achievement. But I very much support your approach that we must be prepared for post-conflict reconciliation and reconstruction. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), blue card question.- In principle, I will not disagree at all with the negative of the intervention and Russia in the region.But I do not think it is right to talk about the responsibilities of other countries, such as the United States and the United Kingdom, given that the evil started with the invasion of Iraq..So I wanted to ask if you can take a more holistic approach to this issue.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: blue-card answer. – I think we should appreciate actors by their deeds. While the United States and others are trying to avoid loss of civilian life, Russia, together with the Assad regime, is indiscriminately bombing the civilian population. This has been proved, and our first attention should go to those who are committing violence and war crimes against the civilian population, whoever they are.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Madam President, the humanitarian catastrophe in Syria is the combination of at least three factors. The first of these is the continued failure or inability of the global actors of the United Nations Security Council to prevent a conflict or to guarantee international peace and security in a conflict that has lasted for more than six years. The second element is the permanent violation of fundamental rights and international humanitarian laws, through the continuous bombing of schools, hospitals, and the civilian population: the violation —as I say— continues of the most fundamental rights. The third element is the involuntary impotence of humanitarian actors to be able to access the place where their activity is needed to alleviate suffering and to guarantee the survival of these punished populations. Faced with this situation, the European Union must support the global humanitarian plan proposed by the United Nations, which, after all, is the same proposal put forward not long ago by the High Representative and by Commissioner Stylianides. And that plan must have three fundamental elements: guaranteeing the medical withdrawal of the wounded, guaranteeing access to medical supplies and also allowing food to a besieged population.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, I can still see Chechnya and Grozny: total destruction and atrocities committed for the sake of maintaining geopolitical influence with total impunity for the perpetrators. The same is happening to Aleppo for the sake of maintaining, or regaining, influence by Vladimir Putin, Bashar al—Assad or the Iranian regime. There are crimes against humanity being committed there. Do we learn the lesson of history?

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: - Madam President, Madam Mogherini, quite frankly and respectfully, I honestly do not know whether we are talking about the same planet or whether the European Union and the European Commission are in complete denial. I didn't want to believe it when I heard about starting to move into this new post-conflict language. The conflict is far from over. It will not end tomorrow or, perhaps, in the coming years, and it will not end tomorrow or in the coming years because we are co-responsible for this situation. As long as the European Union continues with this Manichean view of the conflict, as long as it continues to ignore that people continue to die every day, that there is a dispute in the territory that goes beyond all this and that has to do with resources and geostrategic positions, while to ignore that there is an arms business behind all this, while ignoring the role of Turkey and the Gulf countries, Saudi Arabia, while ignoring all of that and trying to tell a story in black and white, while still being part of problem and not the solution, there may not be a solution at all. But to speak of a solution to conflicts, Ms. Mogherini, is really a state of denial, it is not to learn anything rigorously from the past.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, we are all stunned every day by the images we see, especially in Aleppo. We know the war crimes, we know the crimes against humanity, we know the responsibility of the Assad regime and its accomplices, namely Russia, Iran and maybe tomorrow the United States of Mr. Trump. For my part, I am still amazed to see in this hemicycle the complacency of a certain number of politicians towards Putin. It is the same in our European countries. I see it in the French presidential campaign, and even in the primary of the right in France with the candidate Fillon. This complacency is a political corruption that is totally unbearable today. So, as we will not go to war in Aleppo, the means at our disposal are sanctions against individuals and groups, economic sanctions against Putin's regime. Call for a boycott of the World Cup in Russia! We are not going to play football in Moscow while Russia is bombing Aleppo. Let us take this responsibility on the sanctions! This is a means of action for the European Union.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Madam President! The bombings in Aleppo continue. In the conflict, a total of over 300,000 people have died and millions are on the run. The EU has received many migrants while the Gulf states in the vicinity do almost nothing. This is despite the fact that in many cases they share the same culture and language. What is going in the right direction in this conflict, however, is that the territory is shrinking for the killers in IS. The offensive in Mosul and in several other places is going in the right direction, and I am glad to see that several villages have been liberated from this terrorist group. However, there is still a long way to go before the fighting ends. We in Europe must be more prepared than ever for new terrorist attacks to take place here, given that it will be more difficult for Islamist terrorists to join IS. However, I would like to emphasize the failure of the EU's common foreign policy in this conflict. EU Member States are welcome to sit on the sidelines and watch as the non-democratically elected European Commission sets the agenda. What has this led to? Well, to the fact that Europe's role in the world has been reduced to waiting for what the United States and Russia are doing, and then standing here and voting on resolutions. The role of Europe and especially my country in the world was much stronger before the EU existed. I do not want to stand here in a year and vote on another resolution. If you in the European Commission have intended to manage our foreign policy, we want to see results as soon as possible.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, it is clear that the de facto sovereignty of Syria has been seriously violated. It is a torn territory in which, in various areas, different factions exercise their authority. Foreign military interventions have made this situation worse. Again, it is clear that after so many years of civil war in which violence and cruelty have led to huge loss of life, a national reconciliation will last at least 20 years. The prolongation of the war will lead to the prolongation of this period and / or to the division of the current Syrian state into several political entities. Analyzes show that, lately, the actors involved are intensifying their military operations in order to occupy a better place at the negotiating table. However, this intensification of operations is being paid for by the Syrian people. The European Union could have played a much more important role in resolving the conflict and blocking terrorist organizations. Unfortunately, he did not do enough, and the involvement was rigid. Or European security depends significantly on stopping the war and post-conflict arrangements in Syria. I call on the European Council, the Commission and the High Representative to consider, in addition to humanitarian interventions, a more active and flexible policy to achieve these goals.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Mr President, the horde of fanatical terrorists that the West has created, equipped and continues to support will soon disappear. You feel embarrassed and try by all means to prevent the crash of the mercenaries who have bloodied Syria for the last six years. The future of the Syrians is now being decided on the battlefield and you will soon have to adapt to new facts. Because we have to put an end to fanatical Islamists and hypocrisy, one can answer the questions: where was Europe's sensitivity when Turkey invaded Syria illegally? Did you upgrade the Al Nusra Front from an al Qaeda affiliate to a respected interlocutor simply because it changed its name? From the European Union media you continue the daily propaganda and deliberate misinformation about how bad the Syrians and the Russians are in Aleppo and how good the insurgents, the opposition or the democratic army, as it is called, are. Fortunately, these plans failed and soon this will be an official event. A new country may be found in the future to be destroyed by the West, but know that the days when you could determine the fate of peoples according to your interests are now irreversible.

name: David McALLISTER
text: - Dear Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues! I can only agree with the previous speakers: the situation in Syria is appalling. Words are lacking, as my colleague Preda put it. This conflict, or more precisely, this humanitarian catastrophe, cannot be resolved militarily, it must be resolved politically. Despite differing views, the debate this afternoon showed that we in the European Union can do our part to ensure that the peace negotiations of the United Nations end the killing in Syria. Madam High Representative, I would also like to thank you - also personally - for going to Tehran and Riyadh at the end of October, for example, in order to once again work towards a peaceful solution to the conflict in Syria. Without the involvement of regional actors, there will be no peace in Syria. Indeed, Russia must finally live up to its responsibilities. I share the criticism of Moscow that was presented today. In all efforts to bring about a peaceful solution to the conflict, one thing must also be clear: the inhuman attacks must not remain without consequences, and those responsible must be held accountable.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in recent days there have been indiscriminate attacks on schools and hospitals, including through the use of chemical weapons. The population is exhausted by the severe shortage of basic food and medical supplies in the cities controlled by the warring parties. Syria, it was said, has been worn down by six years of conflict and urgently needs a serious political solution involving all parties concerned. Of course, the European Union and the United Nations itself must play a mediating role to relaunch the peace process and guarantee humanitarian access. But here's the thing: if we do not want chaos and the balance of power on the ground to bring about a new balance in the region, then I ask you, Mr High Representative, if the time has not come to make some political choices that go beyond the humanitarian and that produce a real European point of view on which this new balance must be, avoiding leaving the field, on the one hand, only to Russia, or to the intentions of the new American administration.

name: Bas BELDER
text: Under the umbrella of the Russian Air Force, the Islamic Republic of Iran is gradually expanding its military influence on the Syrian battlefield. Under the supervision of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard and its willing Lebanese instrument of the Hezbollah, separate brigades with tens of thousands of Shia Pakistanis and Afghans are also operating there today. There is also talk of the Shia of Syria. The geopolitical and hegemonic goals of the Ayatollah regime in Iraq, Syria and Lebanon are easy to guess. This is also the case with the acute alarm among the Sunnis in the region. Not to mention the state of Israel, the impending destruction of which is continually being proclaimed by political and military leaders in Iran as a follow-up to the deployment in Syria. High Representative, how do you view the scenario of a regional escalation of the Syrian battlefield and Iran's driving role in it? Is prevention with European input still possible? I am extremely pessimistic and I think sadly the Irandeal has a share in that too.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: - Madam President, the new President of the United States has recognized the terrible responsibility of his predecessors in the emergence of the Islamic State. His election at the head of the world's leading power should therefore finally change the situation, especially since he clearly announced that he was going to join forces with the Russians. Alongside the Syrians, they are indeed the only ones to fight effectively against the Islamist barbarians who have ravaged this country for more than five years now. The situation would obviously be worse today if the Americans had left MM. Hollande, Valls and Fabius do in Syria what MM. Sarkozy, Fillon and Juppé have done in Libya: the total destruction of the country, delivered today to the followers of the Sharia. We must indeed give ourselves the means to eradicate the Islamic State as well as the other jihadist groups which are committing equally heinous horrors. We must help the populations on the spot who have been the targets of these abuses, starting of course with the Christians of the East, because the best way to help them is to allow them to continue living on their ancestral lands. Helping them does not mean pushing them into exile and uprooting by making promises that we cannot keep because we cannot afford them.

name: Udo VOIGT
text: - Madam President! Yes, we are indeed here for the fourth or fifth time to discuss the situation in Syria. We keep talking about resuming the bombing. Why is that so? It is clear that these people are only waging this war because they are being given weapons. And the terrorists in East Aleppo receive these arms deliveries via a corridor that still exists in the north to Turkey in order to fight against the corresponding government troops. I was pleased that Mrs Mogherini spoke to precisely those who are responsible for this, including Turkey, the foreign ministers of Saudi Arabia and Qatar. Did you, Mrs Mogherini, also negotiate and talk about the suspension of the arms deliveries to the terrorists? I ask all colleagues here in these 28 European Member States: which country in Europe or in the world allows an armed opposition in one's own country? It is the right of Syrians to defend their own sovereignty.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, yesterday the Head of UN International Aid reported that the number of people living under siege in Syria has more than doubled over the last year. We are talking about one million people living under the most horrendous circumstances: isolated, starving, denied all humanitarian and medical assistance. Recently I travelled to Syria myself. I was invited by the Patriarch of the Syrian Orthodox Church, His Holiness Ignatius Aphrem. He took me to meetings with internally displaced persons (IDPs), with former hostages of the Islamic State and with leaders of the vulnerable Christian minorities. The overall message from all these suffering groups was very clear: please do not forget us, help us halt the violence.  The attacks on innocent civilians must stop. There is only one alternative to fighting to the bitter end. This only alternative is negotiations where all sides have to make concessions. Let us step up our efforts from the European side to make this possible. Let us increase our political pressure, on Russia especially, and on the regional actors feeding this very conflict.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Shame is what I feel as a European for returning to debate Syria, without having changed anything. Aleppo, hell on earth, confronts us with cruelly bombed men, women and children, schools, hospitals, aid workers and refugee camps deliberately attacked. The UN High Commissioner for Human Rights has called for restrictions on the P5 veto against war crimes, against humanity or genocide, to overcome the Security Council's paralysis and bring those responsible for the carnage in Syria to the International Criminal Court. Why don't we listen to the European Union to support this call, Mrs Mogherini? The European Union and its Member States have been unable to act strategically, with sanctions, humanitarian corridors, in fly zones, or whatever makes a difference for peace in Syria. We thus allow Putin to fill the void in support of Assad's murderous regime and for terrorist groups like Daesh to continue to slaughter the Syrian people with direct consequences for European security as well. When will we realize that if we do not wage war in Syria, we are not only manufacturing more refugees, but also handing over lost generations to terrorist recruitment?

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: -  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The same terrorists are being fought in Aleppo as they were in Paris, Brussels and other European cities. Given the so-called successes of European foreign and military policy in recent years, it is somewhat presumptuous to believe that the European Union could be part of the solution - this time in Syria. Assad is a dictator - no question about it. But the attempt to eradicate it has plunged Syria into chaos, triggered a wave of refugees in the direction of Europe, washed terrorists into Europe and at the same time helped to initiate a migration movement from Africa and other parts of the world to Europe. Mrs. Mogherini! Turkey is part of the problem - Turkey, which was previously a partner of the European Union. The US is part of the problem. And yes, Russia will certainly have to contribute to the solution. But it is not enough to hit Russia at this point.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - Madam President, we can rightly say that the war in Syria before our eyes caused the worst humanitarian crisis in World War II. since World War II. Despite international efforts, wars in the country are not going to end, the brutal treatment of the civilian population is continuing, and its suffering includes women, children and the elderly. Aleppo's situation is particularly tragic. Syria's former economic center is in ruins, and total airstrikes against it do not spare the vulnerable population or even health care facilities. At the same time, the Islamic State is rampant across the country, committing a series of massacres against indigenous humanities and war crimes against indigenous Christian and Yazid minorities. The unsustainable situation could ultimately only be resolved through full international cooperation. Without it, the crisis will deepen further and there will be no chance of lasting peace. The European Union must play a greater role than before in resolving the Syrian crisis and, later, in the return of refugees, the reconciliation of society, the opposing parties and the reconstruction of the country.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the last time I spoke about Syria I called for a no-fly zone against Syrian Government planes. I repeat this plea again as an urgent and necessary measure to ensure civilian protection. The need to protect civilians is paramount to any political process. Residents of Aleppo are at risk of extermination if we do not act now. If we cannot trust Assad and Russia to stop bombing hospitals and schools how can we trust them to engage with them and implement a political solution? All EU states should develop and implement mechanisms to ensure that war criminals from the Syrian conflict are held to account. This is especially critical in light of Russia's veto of any accountability mechanism through the UN Security Council. I welcome the recent decisions to review EU sanctions against Syria. However, more needs to be done in this regard. Europeans want sanctions against the Assad regime, Russia and Iran.

name: Mariya GABRIEL
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, first of all, on the humanitarian level, we must relentlessly continue our efforts to secure humanitarian aid, protect civilians and in particular facilitate a general truce around Aleppo. Our action at local level, as you rightly pointed out, is essential. Then, Madam High Representative, you deserve our congratulations and all our encouragement in the mediation work you are carrying out in trying to create the conditions favorable to the resumption of an intrasyrian political process under the aegis of the United Nations. Under your leadership, the Union can find its place as mediator. Contacts in the diplomatic world are essential with regional players, but at other levels too, the Union must anticipate its actions, including in matters of reconciliation. Which actors from civil society, academia, religion and economics do you plan to work with? The inclusiveness of the process is essential for a lasting political solution. Finally, the Union will have to help rebuild the country. We must anticipate the immense work of physical reconstruction, the return of refugees, the re-establishment of economic infrastructure and the creation of employment. It will not be for us to create or implement a post-war strategy, but for the Syrians. For our part, if we want to be a credible and reliable partner for the Syria of tomorrow, we must make sure that we will be there at the right time, without delay and without delay. You answered in your introduction to my question "how are we preparing with regional partners?", And I encourage you to continue in this direction.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, Ms. Mogherini, High Representative, after six years of war in Syria we continue to see how Al-Assad, Russia, regional powers or Islamic extremism continue to splash under the blood of hundreds of thousands of Syrian civilians and that our strategy of Support for de Mistura, on the territory, to find a negotiated solution for the special envoy, supporting the special envoy, is being insufficient. Because there is a blockade on the territory of Damascus and there is a blockade, in the same way, in the Security Council of Russia. And at the same time, during the last weeks and months the attacks were intensifying, especially in eastern Aleppo, attacks undoubtedly committed in the form of war crimes. For this reason, it is absolutely necessary that we raise our voices, that we use all our tools in matters of foreign policy so that humanitarian aid arrives, which, to this day, we are not capable of sending. Because in the end nothing will be left about that country.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Madam President, allow me to congratulate you. I am very happy with what you said. He was talking about the future here, and there are those who have resented it. I think that, yes, we also need to talk about the future here, especially in the context of not having an army and seeking a political solution. The group, the European People's Party, is trying to find out about the Middle East from authentic sources. We have made a number of fact-finding trips and are constantly listening to leaders of local religions and ethnic groups, be they Christians or Muslims. Clear proposals from leaders must be heard in Europe. Reconciliation, the establishment of a secular state in the Syria of the future must be preserved. International relations with extremist actors must be suspended. We have done very little in this. The centuries-old balances of a diverse society must be maintained. You have to be very careful about that. And most importantly, do nothing without the locals, instead, because then we will only use their own short-term political goal again, if from another perspective.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President! The Syrian civil war is arguably the most tragic chapter of this decade. Almost half the population has been displaced - within Syria, to neighboring countries and to Europe -, over 400,000 people have been killed, unimaginable atrocities have been committed, cities have been bombed and starved, and hundreds of thousands have no access to medical care. Peace is further away than ever, and more necessary than ever. It is not enough to hope that the process will eventually get underway, and there is no room for mutual blame. It's about short-term measures, about humanitarian measures. It is good to know that Europe is leading the way: the delivery of food and medical care, the evacuation of the most vulnerable and, finally, support for the liberated areas where there is no more fighting, such as in Rodschawa. In the medium term, however, new engagement in the peace negotiations is needed. Europe is not directly involved in the conflict. That can be interpreted as a weakness, but it also means an opportunity, and Europe should seize it, albeit together and not as a solo run by individual member states. The mandate of the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy should be generously and comprehensively extended and we have seen that she is a very reliable and important person in these negotiations. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Weidenholzer!We all know the situation in Syria and the confrontation that is currently taking place with Turkey.Do you think that it is possible to protect the refugees not only in Turkey, but above all on their own territory?And what humanitarian services can we provide here to facilitate and enable the refugees to return to their homeland?Do you think that the activities of the self-employed and of small and medium-sized enterprises could also help to better supply the local population?

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- The High Representative has already spoken of the fact that we also have to think about afterwards.It is important to allow people to return to those areas where there is security.I know a lot of people who want to return to the Rodzhava region and are waiting for it, but currently cannot.In this context it is also important - because the small and medium-sized enterprises were touched upon - that people who are now in the diaspora are encouraged to take action and support the development process.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, many believe that Russia has become involved in Syria in order to divert attention away from the conflict in Ukraine.  Ukraine today represents the failure of the Kremlin’s imperial policy, because this country has become one of the most hostile to the Russian state. Russia is experiencing international isolation and sanctions, and all this raises serious political and economic problems inside the country. The Russian people did not need another war in distant Syria. Moreover, the Syrian conflict has not weakened western attention to Ukraine. It seems that, by bombing civilians in Syria, Putin is trying to prove that Russia is more than a regional power, as President Obama called it. The Kremlin has achieved this goal, at least temporarily, as the Syrian conflict can no longer be solved without Moscow’s participation. The Kremlin becoming a serious player in Syria and the whole Middle East has its price. One should not forget that the Kremlin considers the United States of America as its most important rival in the world. Never, even in the Cold War years, has the world been so close to uncontrolled serious military conflict as now, so finding a ceasefire in Syria is of crucial importance.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Madam President, after six years of war in Syria, we have immunized ourselves from the horror.Well no: we cannot become immune to the killing of children.The words begin to sound hollow before the images of so much pain;and we are no longer credible, because we are unable to stop the suffering of millions of Syrians, who look towards us hopefully.We have to find an urgent political solution.We have to force those who bomb to an immediate cease-fire because, as they have said, humanitarian aid is not coming, and that is a shame.And we also need that, for a true peace that is born of justice, those who have committed these war crimes be prosecuted by international tribunals.(She agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), blue card question.- As you may know, occupying a residential area, such as Aleppo, is militarily difficult and time-consuming and may take a long time, how would you view the European Union's proposal to take action to evacuatethe eastern side of Aleppo by the civilians, so that they are not used as a human shield and there are no casualties among the civilian population, especially children?

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: "blue card" response.- Yes, of course that would seem like a good solution.What we are talking about is opening corridors, of course, corridors so that humanitarian aid can enter and the wounded are healed and hospitals are not bombed, but also to let civil society and the victims, the most vulnerable, out.as are children, the elderly and women.And of course the European Union should get involved.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure.I have numerous reports.I will take one or one from each group and two from the two largest groups.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - Syria's future is increasingly uncertain as attacks on Aleppo and other parts of Syria intensify.The attacks on the civilian population and the lack of access to much-needed humanitarian aid for the people of Syria, as well as the attacks on humanitarian aid convoys, must be strongly condemned.Thus, the biggest victims - women, children and the elderly - were left without access to humanitarian aid, food, water and medical care.I welcome the European Union's cooperation with the United Nations, which is trying to resolve the problem in this area.The conduct of Putin, Russia and the Assad regime must be strongly condemned.The European Union must continue its efforts to achieve peace and play a more important, mediating role in reaching a peace agreement for Syria.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, Madam High Representative, it so happened that I had the opportunity, with Paul Rubig besides, to visit a Syrian refugee camp in Turkey, about a hundred kilometers from Aleppo, and I 've measured the distress of these women and men who, no longer able to live in their country, their region, their city, have decided to leave, quite simply to save their lives. They just want to go home. Of course, this is not possible while there is war. They are begging us Europeans to do something to allow them one day to regain their soil. It is a complicated war where the bellicose actors become entangled, each bringing its share of misfortunes: the great nations, with Russia in mind, which you have mentioned several times, but also the neighboring countries and, of course, Bashar Al- Assad as well as the Daesh terrorists. In this context, I believe that the European Union has a double duty: first, to do everything to end the war and obtain a ceasefire, then to deliver humanitarian aid. Mrs Mogherini, you have worked a lot. We are counting on you to continue on this path.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, the European Union is constantly discussing the situation in Syria and most agree that the situation is critical. In practice, however, it is other forces that are fighting and giving way to a war that, as we know, started with the blessings of some European powers. Neither Daesh nor any other fundamentalist group should prevail in any way, anywhere in Iraq or Syria. At the same time, the factor of Turkish expansionism, which, under the pretext of fighting terrorism, is trying to break the united front created by the Kurds against Daesh, must be tackled recently. The European Union must therefore keep Turkey away from these areas and call on it to respect international law and its commitments to find a viable solution to Syria, but also to tackle the expected influx of refugees. to intensify again. That is why the European Union, the United States and Russia need to work together to fight Islamism in the wider region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, Madame Mogherini, this war has been going on for too long.I completely agree with you that Europe should make every effort, I can agree with you that Europe and you personally have credibility in the negotiations, but this war is taking too long.As if he may not even want to finish.I do not believe that this part of the world will be peaceful if there are great winners in that war.An agreement should be reached as soon as possible because of the suffering of all innocent people in that war.Please do not agree and accept solutions, as it is said that it could be, following the example of what happened in Bosnia and Herzegovina.Not only because it will be a dysfunctional state, but because it will be a possibility of a constant new war conflict.And in the Middle East, as we unfortunately know, this is an everyday case.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, today we tackled the issue of managing post-war reconstruction but, in reality, they seem to me to be distant mirages, given that we still hear the whistling of bombs in the background and we see before our eyes a humanitarian drama for which everyone is responsible , not just certain geopolitical actors. And to this day many of these players still delude themselves that they can win on the pitch or, at least, that they can snatch as much advantage as possible in view of the negotiating table. The reality is that before us there is a scenario in which we could, as the European Union, be overtaken by the choices and agreements of the new American administration, of Russia, of other regional actors - I will mention for example the rapprochement between Turkey and Israel. , but the same rapprochement between Russia and Turkey. The priority is to obtain a real, stable and credible truce. And this can only start from a realistic and pragmatic proposal, for example with a large autonomy of the regions, a federal or in any case a tripartite Syria. I do not believe that the Manichean visions and attacks will help us to get out of this humanitarian drama and, if we are not the protagonists, as realistic and pragmatic actors, I fear that instead we will be spectators of the choices of others.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Madam President!Even if some in the house do not want to or cannot understand it: Syria clearly shows what happens when you blindly support Islamists, so-called freedom fighters.If Russia had been involved right from the start instead of Saudi Arabia and Iran being waged by proxy wars, hundreds, millions of people would not now be living under constant siege, thousands would not have died and millions would not have fled.Actually, Mrs Mogherini, there should be an immediate goal for us, namely a goal to make the Aleppo region a demilitarized zone, controlled by the UN, with no local military, without the intervention of Turkey and Saudi Arabia, without militias andwithout the alleged so-called freedom fighters who, as cowardly marauders, take the population as a protective shield and hide and hide behind these people.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Madam President, after the election of Trump in the US, the review of NATO's strategic approach, the revelation of Erdogan's real intentions in Turkey and Russia's support for the official government of Syria, I hope that the situation in the region will finally be resolved. It is time to change Europe's approach. Stop supporting the so-called moderate Syrian opposition, which is in fact slaughtering, looting, raping, smuggling oil with Turkey, promoting extreme Islam and killing Syrians, Yezidis, Peshmerga and Christians. Political defenders of human rights and the rule of law pretend to be deaf and dumb to the cries of agony and the dying snorts of innocent people, women and children in Syria. As Europeans, we must join forces with the Islamic State in Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) and stop the danger of the enemies of civilization and Christianity spreading.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - War is always bad and I, Commissioner, thank you for making an effort to end it.The war in Syria is a challenge for us all.Who imagined 6 years ago that this war would really last that long and that the parties that seemed to sit at the negotiating table never sat at the negotiating table or never sat at the negotiating table.My question is, Commissioner, what are you doing to ensure that the fighting we are seeing in Syria today does not spill over?It is a question not to move to Egypt, for example, so that ISIS members do not move to Libya or other unstable countries, for example.I think this is an important issue in resolving conflicts, not just in Syria.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Syria is today at the center of a humanitarian tragedy, the consequence of a war that is perhaps in its most bloody and delicate phase in this period. The resumption of air raids by Russian and Syrian forces could generate a huge humanitarian catastrophe in Aleppo. Oxfam, the Syrian American Medical Society and the Big Heart Foundation have launched an appeal for a complete cessation of the ongoing conflict, declining the drama of the humanitarian framework with over 250,000 people trapped in the city, who are preparing to face the winter with food supplies and running out of water and collapsing health facilities. There is no possibility of resolving the Syrian crisis with weapons: the military solution does nothing but cause more suffering. A diplomatic effort must be made today more than ever. This option remains the only way out of the Syrian crisis and stop the horror that this war is bringing with it. Thank you, President Mogherini, for what you are doing.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: - Madam President!I am listening to the far right, with a cynicism that still surprises me and still outrags me, praying about what is unbearable.Mr Obermayr, for example, said that Russia should have been involved earlier.Do you believe, Mr Obermayr, that the current bombings by Russian planes against hospitals in East Aleppo are still necessary to underline that Russia should have been involved in good time?That is the most absurd cynicism that can be articulated here.Shame yourself!You cannot speak for European values!

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, last month you adopted a resolution on Syria clearly asking the European Union – which means in this case me personally – to play a more pronounced role as a European Union. So collectively, all our institutions together, all our Member States together –  the institutions together means also Parliament – were called on to play a more pronounced role in mediating a peace deal for Syria. I remember very well, during the State of the Union speech in September, not only President Juncker but many of you called for a pronounced work of the European Union on the future of Syria. This is why it is quite surprising for me to hear some of you say that we should not focus on the future of Syria. I would invite some coherence here in what we ask ourselves to do.  I heard very clearly the first two interventions here, by Mr Preda and Mr Boştinaru, prioritising the two key elements of our work: first, delivering humanitarian aid and making sure this can happen; second, using all the diplomatic tools we have to find, or rather to build, a political solution to put an end to the war in Syria. This is exactly the work we are doing: providing humanitarian aid, together with the UN, together with international agencies, together with international NGOs, with our people on the ground, still. You cannot imagining how difficult the conditions are, or maybe you can, and talking to all relevant players in the region to try and open ways for the political solution to the crisis. So if we are the ones, not some of them, but the ones financing humanitarian aid and making sure it can be delivered –obviously this does not depend only on us – but if we were not there, for sure there would be no humanitarian aid at all in the country.  Secondly, if we are the ones today still keeping open the talks, the dialogue, in a situation that otherwise is rather stalled, then I am sorry: I do not share the views of the few of you who have said that Europe should be ashamed. I believe we are not the ones who should be ashamed about Syria. We are doing our job, finally, maybe, but we are. The point is, this is not enough. We need the unity of the international community, so this is also part of our work. Six years of war; five years of polarisation in the international community. You remember that very well. This year for the first time, thanks in part to our work in the international support group, we managed to have unity in the Security Council for the first time ever – even though we are not a member of the Security Council. You know that very well, but we managed to facilitate consensus in the Security Council twice, and those were the only weeks where aid was delivered, Syrians were getting out into the streets, trying to live a normal life again. These are the efforts we have to make in order to continue to build the unity of the international community. Otherwise, our efforts alone will be necessary and indispensable. We will continue to do that, but doing so alone would not be enough. We have to be a key player, but we cannot pretend we will be the only player. We have to build alliances, starting with those we have worked with well these past months.  We have our role to play, and we are now playing it fully. This was maybe not necessarily the case in past years in the first years of the conflict, but here, now, the European Union is there, politically and from a humanitarian perspective – not from a military perspective. This is not because we do not have a European army, but because of a clear political decision that was taken and I am sincerely proud that we are not a military player on the ground. We are not part of the war in Syria. Having said that, why focus on post-conflict? Some of you asked this and some others explained why, but let me say a few words on that.  Firstly, many conflicts in the past were solved exactly when the parties started to see the endgame shaping up. Sometimes it works, sometimes it does not, but we are facing a war and a crisis that does not allow us to leave any of the possibilities untried. When you start shaping the endgame, the parties would feel more confident engaging in direct talks, so this is a contribution we can make to the UN efforts to restart direct talks and find common ground. Secondly, we need to be ready for the construction – the reconstruction – of Syria. At a certain moment, it will come; it will cost an enormous amount of money. How many conflicts in our region have faced the problem of nothing following the end of the conflict and have thus fallen back into conflict after maybe a few months or a few years? Working on post-conflict reconstruction today is fundamental so as to be ready at the moment when arms are finally laid down. Thirdly, to give hope to the Syrians – not only to the refugees, but also to the internally displaced people and those that are still living in Syria in their own communities; to offer positive incentives; to offer the dividends for peace that make it possible for the parties to engage. Last but not least, you mentioned empowering the local players that can still be a force for good in their country – the women, the small experiences of civil society that are still struggling, the churches, the communities that are taking care of their own everyday lives, the children, and the women. This is work that the European Union does, but does not expect any of the big military players to do on the ground. We can be – and we are – a force for good in Syria. Others are not, true – definitely true! We cannot delete this issue, but we can maybe compensate, maybe engage, or maybe encourage a more positive dynamic on the ground and diplomatically. This is the work we are doing. I thank you for the support in this effort. It will be needed, because it will not be something that we will solve in one week or one month. I am sure that we are now on the right track as regards what the European Union can and should do, and what it finally is doing.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: To wind up the debate, eight motions for resolutions have been tabled under Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday 24 November 2016.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- We are baffled by the continuing violence that continues to harass the Syrian people.We strongly condemn the attacks on humanitarian aid convoys, the grave violations of international humanitarian law and probable war crimes.Respect for human rights and for religious minorities, including those of Christians, are very important.It is necessary for the Syrian people to continue to live peacefully in the territories that historically and traditionally are part of their country, in dignity, equality and security, and to practice their religion and belief.The European Union and the Quintet States (United States, France, Germany, Italy and the United Kingdom) play an important role in identifying a political solution to the Syrian conflict.It is important to support timely concrete action that urgently involves the General Assembly and the work of the United Nations Special Envoy.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I supported the resolution.The fighting must stop immediately.Only then can the way be paved for the resumption of negotiations on political change in the country.As MEPs, we can only use our resolutions to appeal to all those involved to allow emergency humanitarian aid for the whole of Syria and to stop killing civilians immediately.The widespread and systematic violation of human rights must stop!This also applies to Russia's blockade policy in the UN Security Council.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The situation in Syria is tragic, the protection of civilians and children must be a priority! At the same time, we must not forget that the causes of the flight will disappear one day and then it is in our common interest that Syrian refugees will be able to return to their homeland. We must therefore strive to help countries neighboring Syria, such as Turkey, Lebanon or Jordan, which are home to large refugee camps. It is important that people forced to flee can live in suitable living conditions in camps close to their homeland. If we cannot provide this for them, more masses could leave for Europe at the risk of their lives. It is also important to provide children with adequate education in refugee camps, which is essential for their healthy development, but also for the future of their own community, as a whole generation cannot be left out of education. Since the beginning of the crisis, Hungary has been of the opinion that refugees should be helped close to their country and has therefore set aside significant sums for humanitarian aid and the cost of educating hundreds of children living in refugee camps in Lebanon, Jordan and northern Iraq.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: in writing. - The information that has been reaching us continuously from Syria since the conflict in this country began is terrifying and tragic. Human rights are violated, civilians are killed every day, and hospitals are bombed. Fanatical terrorists have no inhibitions and scruples, and the people of Syria live in fear and fear that they will survive until the next day. While the European Union provides the Syrians with all the humanitarian aid they need, it is unfortunately still not enough. It should also be noted that Russia and Turkey support the regime of Bashar al-Assad. Weapons are being delivered to Syria, and it is obvious that these countries are involved in this practice. The European Union cannot accept support for terror, our decisions should be stricter than, for example, imposing sanctions. Discussions on further policy towards al-Assad's allies are needed. The Union absolutely cannot be passive in this matter, and its representatives should not only use empty words. What Syria now needs is swift and decisive action to end the conflict.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written.- Madam High Representative, when it comes to Syria - we have failed.We have spent so many words on the war and the humanitarian crisis in Syria and on the establishment of global agreements that have not been effective.For the genocide of Christians that has happened there and is still happening, the EU is responsible because it trades with those who fund Islamist terrorists.Thousands of people need our help in Aleppo, 250,000 people have been killed since the start of the war, and 11 million Syrians have been displaced.There are 8.4 million children in Syria and neighboring countries who need help.The people of Syria are helping each other as we discuss how to help them.Persecuted Muslims take refuge in Christian churches and there receive help from Christians who are left in insignificant numbers in Syrian cities.An urgent agreement needs to be reached on the delivery of humanitarian aid to Aleppo so that it reaches those who need it.And it is important to ensure peace, so that Syrian children can grow up in their homes.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – As the Syrian warplanes renewed their bombing on Aleppo on 15 November and the Russians started new offensives against rebels resolute to resist in their strongholds, one thing is sure in this prolonged chaos: The fighting will lead to even more death and destruction in a region already utterly devastated by war. The Russian and Syrian air strikes have already killed hundreds of civilians, and destroyed neighbourhoods, hospitals and schools. Witnessing all this, I do not doubt that Ms Mogherini agrees with me that the EU needs to upscale its diplomatic role in the Middle East, especially considering that besides Russia wreaking havoc in the region, the uncertainties brought by the result of the US elections are now also on the cards. It is extremely important that we do all that we can so that hostilities stop, humanitarian aid is delivered and post-conflict discussion starts as fast as possible.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on EU-Turkey relations (2016/2993 (RSP)).

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, once again we gather here to discuss Turkey, and rightly so. I see that the other group leaders – most of them – are present here in the Chamber. Our relationship with Turkey is at a crossroads because Turkey itself is at a crossroads. On the night of 15 July – we discussed it in September, I remember it very well – during the attempted coup d’état, we stood on the side of Turkey’s democracy and the democratic institutions. We stood on the side of the Turkish people who took to the streets and bravely confronted the tanks. We stood on the side of the over 200 innocent people who were shot down that night. We stood on the side of the Parliament as it was being bombed and of the Turkish parties – all of them that spoke against the coup and in support of democracy – all of them. We supported Turkish democracy on 15 July and it is precisely Turkish democracy that we support today as we see the leaders of the People’s Democratic Party (HDP), a legitimate party in the Turkish Parliament, arrested and imprisoned. The arrest of the co-chairs of HDP, as well as the detention of several of its deputies, adds to a long list of extremely worrying developments. These include the consideration of the reinstatement of the death penalty, continued restrictions on freedom of expression, the closure of media outlets and the arrests of journalists and academics, the suspension of thousands of civil servants with a very worrying situation for the judicial system. We have always been clear that the Turkish authorities have a legitimate right to hold the perpetrators of the coup and of terrorist attacks accountable for their actions. We have also called on all political parties to unequivocally condemn terrorist violence. At the same time we know that the respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms is the strongest antidote to extremism and terrorism. Any allegation of wrongdoing must be established via transparent procedures in all individual cases. Individual criminal liability can only be established with full respect for the separation of powers, the independence of the judiciary and the right of every individual to a fair trial. We all agreed on this opposition in the Foreign Affairs Council just one week ago, on Monday. All Foreign Ministers have agreed on the importance of maintaining a unified and clear European Union position in line with our declaration on behalf of all 28 Member States issued earlier in November. Our relations with Turkey have reached a crucial point. I believe the best way to strengthen Turkey’s democracy – the most effective way – is by engaging with Turkey and by keeping channels open. The accession process has achieved important results in many fields, from the energy sector to both our economies and businesses to the talks on Cyprus. Let me stress today how important the talks on Cyprus are for us all. Turkey seems to be heading towards constitutional reform, and I would like to stress that this reform should serve as a platform to strengthen checks and balances, strengthen participatory democracy and address the Kurdish issue effectively. As we have made clear on many occasions, the European Union stands ready to fully support the country to achieve these goals. The work goes on and I recently met Turkey’s Europe Minister, Omer Celik, and also with the Secretary—General of the Council of Europe, Jagland. This cooperation with the Council of Europe is particularly important and I really hope Turkey will address the concerns of the Council’s Commissioners for Human Rights. What is crucial in the short term is a swift, fair and independent domestic redress mechanism to be in place. Failing this, we are going to see a flood of cases before the European Court of Human Rights. I know talks are ongoing with the Council of Europe, of which Turkey is a member, to address this issue. I hope this work will bring results. This much the European Union and Turkey can do together starting, as I said, with Cyprus, but also our fight against terrorism, our economies, our businesses, refugees and the future of Syria which we have we just discussed, and the stability of the Caucasus. In all these fields we both need constant and reciprocal dialogue. I always say that foreign policy is about building win-win solutions. If the accession process came to an end, I believe we would both find ourselves in a lose-lose scenario. Europe would lose an important channel for dialogue and leverage with Turkey, Turkey would lose a lot, and we would all lose an opportunity for greater friendship and cooperation among our peoples. In this spirit, we should also ask ourselves which tools and which instruments we have at our disposal in order to increase, and not to reduce, our leverage on Turkey’s reforms and on its society as a whole. In order to do so we need full clarity from our Turkish partners on what they want. In that regard, it is clear that moving from rhetoric to action on the issue of the death penalty would be a signal that Turkey does not want to be a member of the European family – neither a member of the Council of Europe, which it is now, nor of the European Union. Membership means, above all, sharing the values Europe stands for, and capital punishment is certainly not one of them. (Applause) It is good to see that at least here in our Chamber we do. Some say that Turkey has to choose between the West and the East. Personally, I do not agree. Turkey can – and should – stay true to its nature as a bridge between worlds and cultures. But if Turkey moves further away from our European Union and from democracy, it would lose part of its own heritage, its own identity, its own culture and also its own power. This would be in no—one’s interests and certainly not in the interests of the Turkish people, all of them. The last time I was in Turkey we all agreed that we need to talk to each other more – which we are doing – and a little bit less about each other. Sometimes we are doing that. I believe that this is the attitude we need both on the part of the Turkish Government and inside our Union. We are looking forward to hearing your views. Both Commissioner Hahn and I will be listening very carefully to your interventions. Again, let me thank you all and especially, as I said, noticing the presence of so many group leaders for a debate that I believe will be essential to shaping the future of our relations with Turkey.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. –Mrs. President, Commissioner Hahn, my dear colleagues! We had the attempted coup in July, and it was impressive to see in Turkey how civil society stood up, how civil society fought, in partnership with the politicians in Turkey for the rule of law, for democracy, for a world without military leadership . Turkey can be proud of having successfully defended democracy and the rule of law against the military. Incidentally, we can self-critically say that we may have said too little about that in this phase: the support for the forces in Turkey. But if you defend the rule of law, you have to implement it now: this is exactly where we are now. For us as the EPP Group, one thing is clear: we respect Turkey. We want a stable Turkey, we want a democratic Turkey. In my speech today I would like to remind you of a great Turk, namely Ataturk. Peace at home - peace in the world, was one of his sentences that he coined. Another sentence from Ataturk was “Sovereignty should not be built on fear. The sovereignty that rests solely on arms cannot be maintained. ”That is actually the message for Turkey, not to argue with our European values ​​first, but to use internal Turkish arguments to advertise what Turkey is traditionally. Respect is a key concept here, respect for one's own people. The coup was a crime against the Turkish people and the masterminds must be convicted. But the coup must not be abused now. Respect for other opinions. Turkey was always strong when it was tolerant. However, since the coup, 110,000 Turks have been removed from their posts in politics and administration, 36,000 people have been arrested and 138 MPs were deprived of their immunity. Today, according to the Rule of Law Index, Turkey has fallen behind Iran and Myanmar in terms of the rule of law. 170 media outlets were closed. Respect for the partners: Turkey is a reliable NATO partner, which is why we are counting on partnership on these issues too.
