It is also a reliable trading partner, which is why it comes as a surprise when threats are now being made that Turkey can build partnerships with China and Russia and thus play Europe off. Respect for partners looks different. Last but not least: respect for your own long-term interests. Turkey needs Europe. The EU wants good relations. There are ten times more Turkish exports to Europe than to China and Russia combined. The European Union is today paying EUR 650 million to the Turks to support the local economy and administration. Now we see that Turkish growth is effectively stalling. That is the record of the last few days, the last weeks, the last months, and it is a shocking record. Commissioner Mogherini, our Vice-President and High Representative, said that too. But now it is up to us to use clear wording. For us, of course, that means that we can't just watch the development. There cannot be business as usual. That is why my group supports the call for the existing accession talks to be frozen for the time being, not to be broken off - I would like to emphasize: not to break off - but now to send the signal that we are not currently holding any further talks with a Turkey in such a state can. The signal must also be clear: anyone who decides to introduce the death penalty cannot become a member of the European Union. That has to be expressed clearly on our part to be brought.My aim is not to accuse first and foremost.My concern is that we appeal to Turkey as a friend, as a partner, not to continue on the path it is taking today, in the interests of its own Turkish citizens, not primarily in the interests of Europe, but because it is for Turkeywrong way is.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I greet Vice-President Mogherini, some figures have already been mentioned by my colleague Weber. These are aberrant, chilling figures: forty thousand people arrested without charge; one hundred and thirty thousand people fired for no reason; 145 journalists in prison, the highest number of journalists in prison in the world; one third of jailed judges and prosecutors; eleven thousand suspended teachers; ten deputies thrown in prison, followed by 36 mayors, replaced by state commissioners. Now, all this is not justified even in the light of a coup d'état, which we immediately challenged and condemned. It is not justifiable! It is a dramatic situation, with respect to which even a group such as the Socialist and Democratic Group, which has always been and remains in favor of Turkey's accession, cannot fail to raise the issue of a freeze on accession talks; not of an interruption but of a freezing which is a strong political signal, on the one hand to Erdogan: do not proceed on this path! Do not proceed on the path of political repression of rights! You go back in the interest of your people, who want a modern democracy anchored in Europe. And for this we must send a precise signal with the freezing of the talks but we must leave the door to dialogue open so that we can, in the future - I hope in the near future - resume the discussion and work together for a full democratization of the Turkey, which represents a partner which, for geopolitical, geostrategic and in my view also religious reasons, is fundamental for the European Union. But truly the measure is full! We democratic socialists would never have reached this point if we had not really been confronted with an aberrant and dramatic reality. We cannot remain silent! We do not accept any blackmail! The European Union cannot accept any blackmail when the values of democracy and respect for human rights are at stake and I am pleased that this Parliament can express, as I am sure an overwhelming majority of colleagues will do, on this situation, firm positions on the freezing oftalks but also positions open to dialogue for the future.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, whatever our personal views, the time has come for us all to be honest and open with Turkey – a country that has seen remarkable economic growth, thanks to increasing economic freedom, under a governing AK Party that has married Islam with democracy and economic liberalisation. There are many who had hoped it could become a model for a new form of Muslim democracy in countries across the Middle East and North Africa, just as Christian democracy developed in Europe. I am confident that many members of the AK Party still share this vision. But we all have concerns over the actions of President Erdogan. Had he simply been content to be elected as a ceremonial President, rather than seeking more power as an executive President, there might be a little less criticism. But what we have seen recently raises serious concerns: opponents being arrested, media being closed, minorities being persecuted. Across this Chamber today, I believe many of us are now united in saying ‘Enough is enough.’ I fully understand why some politicians here, and in our national capitals, are reluctant to criticise Erdogan. I appreciate that there are much wider geopolitical factors at play: sustaining the EU-Turkey migration deal, after Turkey’s generosity in hosting three million refugees; security cooperation – for Turkey too has suffered from terrorist attacks; and not wanting to push Erdogan into Putin’s arms or into a corner. However, we need to be honest with each other, and, in wanting to be honest with Turkey, we need to be honest with ourselves. For far too long, we have dishonestly dangled the prospect of EU membership in front of Turkey. You and I know there are so many reasons why it may not happen in our lifetimes: prejudice against a predominantly non-Christian nation, whose land mass is mostly in Asia; fears over Turkey’s future voting weight in the European Parliament and Council; concerns over borders with Iran, Syria and Iraq as the EU seeks to extend its Common Security and Defence Policy – to name just a few reasons. But the EU continues to pretend that it is ‘business as usual’ in relations with Turkey. Yet more sticking plaster across growing cracks! In common with other parliamentary Groups, the ECR has members who are for, against, and agnostic on, Turkish membership of the Union, but we can all see that the current relationship is not working. So, instead of ‘business as usual’, let us build a new relationship based not on false promises but on honesty. Let us build a new relationship based not necessarily on EU membership but on real cooperation. Let us build a new relationship based not on just fighting today’s fires and problems but also on preparing for the challenges we will all face for decades to come.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, for a moment I thought Mr Kamall was saying let’s merge the Brexit and the Turkish files, but I do not think that is what he was saying. Ms Mogherini, you are saying that we need to know what the Turkish authorities want. I think we all know what the Turkish authorities want. They want accession to the European Union; they want a visa-free regime as quickly as possible; they want additional money, because of the deal we did on migration; and they certainly want no interference and no criticism from our side on what is happening, this shift to an autocratic system in Ankara and in Turkey. That is what they want. But let’s not fool ourselves anymore. We all know that this is not in compliance with European values, that it is not in compliance with European principles and that it shows, I would say, a lack of courage not to see that President Erdoğan is for the moment closing the opposition media, jailing journalists and at the same time also criminalising a number of members of the Turkish Parliament. That is the reality. So instead of pretending ‘oh! we still have an open channel if we continue these talks’, I think in such circumstances we are fooling ourselves, we are fooling our citizens and also fooling the Turkish citizens – because many Turkish citizens think that Europe is their future and they do not find a future in these circumstances with a regime that is becoming more and more autocratic. So instead of continuing the illusion of accession talks with a regime that is becoming more and more authoritarian, I think we would lose credibility to do so, and you have heard it, there is in my opinion in this House, unanimity – or close to unanimity, there is never unanimity in a House such as the European Parliament – but nearly I think, a broad majority, to say you have to freeze the accession talks for the moment. You have put a number of conditions on the restarting of these accession talks once Turkey complies with them. That brings me to the broader picture because, let’s be honest, there is a broader picture. Something is happening in our neighbourhood. It was Solana I think who said in 2003 ‘well, everything is okay in our neighbourhood, there is a ring of friends around Europe’. I can tell you today that it is more like a ring of autocrats around Europe – Erdoğan, Putin... I am not going so far as to put Trump on that little list, but they are all doing one thing: bashing Europe, bashing our values, bashing and fighting against our European democracy. Let’s be honest, let’s face it, you have to face it, we have to face it: what is happening is that Erdoğan is against every Turkish movement in whatever country of the European Union which is not in line with him. Putin is directly financing even groups here in this Parliament – always nationalists, populists and anti-Europeans. And let’s face it, Mr Trump is not much better than that. His most important strategic advisor, Bannon, wants to launch an extreme right-wing website – Breitbart – he has done it already in the US but he wants to do it also in Paris and Berlin to influence the German elections, and to influence the French elections. Mr Trump even wants to take over the task of Her Majesty The Queen by appointing the future ambassadors of Britain. Mr Farage is not here, but it would be interesting if he could tell us if that is ‘taking back control’ in Britain. I think one clown in Washington is more than enough. We do not need more than that, dear colleagues. (Applause) So, in a certain sense Ms Mogherini, that is what I hope, with the Foreign Ministers and with the leaders, and you are aware of this. There is a fifth column active in Europe for the moment and the fifth column are not the refugees coming in from Syria, as Le Pen and Farage are saying. No, the fifth column are the cronies of a number of autocratic leaders, be it Putin, be it Erdoğan – I hope it will not be Trump tomorrow – who want to undermine the European Union. It is time to fight back and make it not happen. And if our European leaders do not do it, then we in the European Parliament should do it. I think it is now or never. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: question "blue card".- Hallelujah, there was a miracle, Mr. Verhofstadt.For the first time, we hear you on Turkey.So hit Russia, hit the National Front, hit the populists ... In fact, you are intervening on Turkey to talk about Russia and the National Front.You are really a balancing act and I would even say that you are an opportunist, Mr Verhofstadt.You talk about Turkey when there has been a problem with Turkey for years.Are you only opening your eyes now?I come to my question: you are asking to suspend negotiations with Turkey.We are in the 17th chapter out of 32. But are you also asking for the end of the negotiations with Turkey?

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: answer "blue card".- I have always been an ardent defender of Turkey's entry into Europe, because I have always believed that European civilization should not be defined on the basis of religion, but on the basis ofour values and other criteria.However, I am not crazy.I also see what is happening in Turkey.What I see is not a change in my position, but a change in the position of your group which is starting to have a lot of sympathy for Mr. Erdoğan, because the more he becomes authoritarian, the more you find that it is.is a good ally for the future.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I think that our Parliament would have lost the last trace of dignity if it had not taken the step it seems to be taking. I will not repeat what is happening today in Turkey, as I have only one and a half minutes. But I will focus on the arrest of the leader of the third largest party in the country, who represents at least six million voters. We, dear colleagues, have nothing against the Turkish people, who are suffering from a deep division, which does not bode well for the people themselves. Information that Turkey put pressure on the Parliament not to pass this resolution, because this would affect - supposedly - the talks on the Cyprus issue, move, I think, only in the realm of impressions despite the truth. Despite the crisis in the Cyprus talks, I welcome the Tsipras-Erdogan agreement for a meeting to discuss the issue of security in the post-settlement era, which I hope is not far off. I also welcome your petition, Mrs Mogherini, in favor of the need for a speedy solution to the Cyprus problem. And I would like to close with the following: the convergences that have been achieved are a very important foundation, which we must not allow to be lost. And you have a share of responsibility to help things in this very critical point where the talks are after yesterday's negative result. We all have a role to play and we have a responsibility to contribute so that the European Union can at least achieve this great success. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- I have just heard that you are right to criticize the fact that representatives of the third largest party in Turkey have been arrested.But I did not hear your voice - because Turkey does not belong to Europe - that here in one Member State, namely in Greece, 18 members of the third largest party were arrested last year.I didn't hear you about that.How do you explain that?

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), "blue card" answer.- I think it is very unfortunate to compare the arrest of democratic people, the leader of the largest party, with allegations against the party you are referring to, which unfortunately have to do with serious criminal offenses.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Before we start negotiations on this very difficult resolution today, after many debates with representatives of the Turkish Parliament, I would like to say one more thing: I and my group and the majority of this House want the coup in Turkey to be cleared up, and we are for the constitutional punishment of those who are found to be responsible for fair trials. What is unreasonable for us is that we are now being asked to take mass persecution, mass arrest, and disproportionate action against all Kurdish politicians, against everyone who is somehow close to the Gülen movement, against judges who make independent judgments , against liberal journalists, against writers who form a free opinion in this whole dispute, as part of the enlightenment. I believe that the developments in recent weeks have been such for all of us that we have said that relations with Turkey cannot go on as they did before this crash into a situation that no longer has anything to do with the rule of law. And that is why the majority of this House has taken the view that freezing negotiations with Turkey on membership is an appropriate response. I have to tell you: I've been to Turkey a lot recently. I'm always scared. Most recently the arrest of Ahmet Türk, a highly respected man who stands for the peace process and who is the mayor of this multicultural, multilingual, multi-religious, wonderful city of Mardin. I am really shocked by what is happening. And yet it is difficult for me to imagine the future. So I am in favor of the signal that we are sending to Turkey with this resolution. But at the same time - addressed to former President Gül, for example, Addressed to the former Prime Minister Davutoğlu, addressed to all our colleagues in the Turkish Parliament - to say: What has guided us in Turkey policy, namely that we wanted to achieve peace and security and democracy for the European citizens and for the Turkish citizens still guides me. And I want us not to stop looking for dialogue and understanding with Turkey. This is the last time I am telling you this in my role as chairman of the Greens / EFA group, and I would be very sad if, after twelve years of involvement in Turkey policy, we lost all bridges to Turkey. It would also be very sad for me because in all the talks that I have had with Turkish oppositionists and dissidents in recent weeks, the following appeal has been made: keep the dialogue open! Thank you for your attention and look forward to working with my colleagues in the front row in a different role. (Applause) (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" question.- Like the other group chairmen in this Parliament, Ms Harms started off by telling us all again about the horrific acts that Mr Erdogan has been taking recently.Speakers before her have also emphasized this time and again.But then it sounds again: “We want dialogue and so we are going to freeze”.What dialogue is there?Mr Erdogan is deaf to Europe, goes his own way, arrests whoever he wants, puts minorities away.I was in Mardin just as much as you and I was told in Mardin: "This man has to go".So my question is, why not quit this entry?

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- At the moment, I don't trust myself to describe the perspective for the EU-Turkey relationship.But you also have to be able to think into the future.And I insist that it is really in our interest that Turkey should develop according to the rule of law, that we should have democratic states in the neighborhood there, but also in other parts that Mr Verhofstadt mentioned, becauseThis always guarantees greater security for us and our people because - for example in the case of Turkey, if you think in terms of the larger region, you think in the neighborhood of Turkey - a democratic Turkey actually has a different stabilizing effect in the entire regionwould have.And therefore: Dialogue and understanding must never, under any circumstances, be given up or left untried.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Turkey is further and further away from Europe. Erdogan's counter-coup is bolstering his authoritarian power and legitimate parliamentary and civil society opposition to his government, as well as the freedom of expression of the press and citizens, are being stifled. With endless purges, a systematic repression of the opponents of the Turkish government is taking place, particularly ferocious against the Kurdish minority: it is carried out through a disproportionate number of arrests, dismissals, expulsion of university professors, public and private employees, members of the judiciary and of Parliament, and the closure of newspapers, to which is added the chilling hypothesis of the reintroduction of the death penalty and legislative interventions damaging the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights. The news released by the press states that Erdogan would now have the numbers for a constitutional reform in the "hyper-presidentialist" sense, to grant himself even more authoritarian power in the form. There is also talk of a reprehensible bill, presented by the president's party, in order to decriminalize the abuse of minors and which would further aggravate the serious phenomenon of child brides. This situation contrasts not only with Turkey's commitments to join the European Union, but also with international obligations to protect human rights. The condemnation of these actions cannot stop at words alone. We strongly call for the immediate suspension of the accession negotiations concerning Turkey and the European funds allocated to it. The circumstances are such, however, that the suspension of the immigration and asylum agreement is also required. The European Union and all Member States must strongly condemn what is happening in Turkey and prevent that his authoritarian turn produces even more serious results.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it takes a lot of courage and a lot of unscrupulousness to put us in the dock as friends of Erdogan, who from these banks, in recent years and especially in recent months, have groaned to draw the attention of the latter. Hypocritical Europe, which has totally entrusted itself, or rather, has entrusted the poor Syrian refugees to a satrap like Erdogan, to the pro-European democratic Erdogan, a very good friend of yours until yesterday or the day before yesterday. Today it seems to me that he is no longer your friend but from the sweetened words of the High Representative, who is not clear what he wants to do with Turkey, we have heard that in any case what must be saved, etc. etc., we have also heard that Turkey is important because it is a pillar of NATO: however, it did not tell us that some Turkish NATO officials are asking for political asylum from Europe because they think that at any moment they could be jailed and maybe, one day, shoot yourself. This is the situation of a country that is outside the rules, as well as the moral and historical vision of our European democracy. It is a country and a regime against which we, unlike other situations, should have already adopted sanctions and then definitively stopped the negotiations. And, if anything, measures had to be taken against the Syrian refugees, who are not dangerous, but against the very dangerous men of Turkey, among us, in Germany and you do not realize it! Clean up in Germany the men and spies of the Turkish regime who are ready to devastate our democracy! But it is not the state by doing, bad Germans, that you do not liberate your country. It takes nothing but a clown, it would take the Trump cure to free Europe from certain dangers, the Trump cure! I tell you right away that I do not accept the blue card, because you have no right to talk about democracy ... .. (Il President cut off the speaker)

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). Madam President, as we all know, Turkey is a country that has never been governed democratically. In fact, the recent coup of July 15th gave President Erdogan the alibi to turn the country into a dictatorship. The Turkish President constantly accuses the European Union of not accepting his country as a full member for fifty years. Of course, it does not refer to the fact that she has made no effort to meet all the required conditions. In addition, it threatens the European Union to overwhelm it with millions of illegal immigrants, threatens Greece with war, maintains occupation troops on 37% of the territory of Cyprus, has invaded Syria and also persecutes with medieval methods any of its political opponents, over which the threat of the death penalty is pending. It also applies principles and methods of genocide to the Kurds living in the eastern part of Turkey. His latest achievement is that, in an interview with NATO representatives, he threatened that Turkey would join the Shanghai Pact, a military alliance controlled by Russia and China. As you can see, such a country has no place in the European Union. Turkey's accession process must be stopped immediately. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: question asked by raising a blue card. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, do you not think that the behavior of the Turkish President is much more dictatorial and much more unacceptable than ever for the principles that are declared in this Union? Don't you think that the illegal occupation of Cyprus, that the intervention in Syria is also incompatible with democratic principles, with the government that must be part of the European Union? Don't you think that the persecution of people, that the closure of newsrooms is an expression of a dictatorship that should be punished? Do you not think that this country should be punished by the termination of membership negotiations and by financial sanctions?

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), "blue card" answer. - Thank you very much for pointing me out, colleague. Of course, I totally agree with all your positions. But the way Turkey is treated by the European Union also shows the extent of the hypocrisy of some who are here, say what they say and have the audacity to appear as democrats at a time when they tolerate the violation of democracy in European countries as well. Union, as in my country, Greece, as Mr. Voigt pointed out. I completely agree, I repeat, with you and I consider it a disgrace and a shame the way in which Mr. Hatzigeorgiou and everyone else behaved here in Parliament today.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, colleagues! Objectively, Turkey is an important partner for us and we should not lose sight of that. A democratic and constitutional Turkey is of great importance to us. But at the same time we have to see that the development is going in a different direction, and we see that the coup that we condemn - including the participation of the Gülen movement - is being used by the current government to an extent that is not proportional to it is. As for the arrests of MPs, the deprivation of immunity, the issues related to the rights of journalists, the dismissals to an extent that is really no longer understandable, all that is, I believe, a development that makes it clear that the negotiation should be temporarily suspended until this issue has been clarified. I think everything else can no longer be explained. We should also make it clear that the introduction of the death penalty means that the event is over. But at the same time we should also see that we have instruments. We are not dependent on Turkey. The customs union is one such example. The economic development of Turkey has to do with the customs union and with the fact that two thirds of the direct investments in Turkey come from the European Union. It is important that it also becomes clear that the refugees are not just about the interests of the European Union, but about our support for the refugees, whom we do not want to withdraw. That helps the people, the three million who have been taken in Turkey, that the refugee agreement is an important thing. I believe that we should therefore take a sensible middle path that makes it clear that accession is further away than ever. That has to be made clear by suspending negotiations. For this Basically, you should apply the appropriate pressure and show other instruments.But overall, I believe it is important that we make it clear with Turkey on this issue that we will not allow ourselves to be insulted.For example, the EU sees the PKK as a terrorist organization and the claim by Turkish ministers that we support terrorists is an incredible insult to the European Union that we would not accept.But on the other hand, a colleague mentioned Cyprus here.It would be nice if the agreement in Cyprus could be reached between the various parties.You should keep that in mind for a moment.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: I wish to give you some information. I will not be giving a blue card to those who are on the speaking list.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, the Turkish population is going through a difficult time. There is a serious threat of terrorism, both from ISIS and PKK, the war next door in Syria resulting in three million refugees and, on top of that, the coup attempt last summer. Unfortunately, the actions taken under the state of emergency have further aggravated the situation. Many people live in fear for their loved ones, who have been dismissed or arrested without any legal proceedings taking place even four months after the coup attempt. Tens of thousands of families are directly affected by the purges, including 145 journalists and 10 of our colleagues – parliamentarians – who are in jail. We acknowledge the importance of good EU—Turkey relations and remain committed to keeping Turkey anchored to the EU. During the last decade it has been this Parliament that has consequently each year called for the chapters on the rule of law and democracy to be opened because we take the process seriously. The current situation, however, leaves us with no other choice than to call for the temporary freezing of the accession talks. It does not mean we should stop our dialogue, but we have come to the point where a meaningful negotiation on EU integration is not credible. We are not abandoning Turkish citizens – they believe in the same values as us – nor are we abandoning the vibrant civil society that is today under so much pressure. Our doors remain open. We are merely reacting to what is happening in a country that says it wants to join the European Union. If we take our values seriously, we must send a strong political signal and we expect our European leaders to do the same in December.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - "Enough, enough, enough!". It is the cry of Turkish-European associations defending minorities, democracy and human rights in Turkey. It is the cry they sent me in response to the attempted arson attack last week in Brussels at the Kurdish Institute, an NGO that has always called for dialogue and a peaceful solution to the Kurdish problem. Of course we know the underlying reasons all too well: the harsh repression of Erdogan, his purges, prosecution of opposition to MPs, persecution of journalists, his brutal development of power in Turkish Kurdistan, the ambiguous role in the fight against IS. Erdogan's Turkey is clearly no longer a democracy and he shows this abundantly at home and abroad. "Enough, enough, enough!": It should also be the conclusion of Mrs Mogherini and yours, Commissioner Hahn. But unfortunately I have not heard that. You will not get much further than expressing your concern. I no longer believe in it. Surely it cannot be that a state whose leader has already discarded the principles of freedom, democracy and tolerance can maintain the prospect of EU membership. Stop those negotiations and the funding. Or are we throwing our basic principles completely overboard? (The speaker addressed a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question.- I listened carefully to your speech, in which you said many times that the European Union must sever all relations with Turkey.So do you not support this initiative, which has been widely accepted here, to freeze the negotiations at the moment and to send a signal that Turkey needs to take care of human rights developments and cooperate better with its citizens?

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: "blue card" answer.Madam, you have not listened carefully.I didn't say we should cut all ties.I just said that we must finally stop the accession negotiations.No more waving an EU membership card.Stop those negotiations and stop funding.That is the only language this dictator understands.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: - Madam President! We were right to hear here that the most important thing about membership in the European Union is shared values. Does anyone here in this house believe that our values ​​are currently being lived in Turkey - freedom of the press, the rule of law, freedom of research and teaching? Does anyone here believe? Is it really necessary to pass the death penalty to put an end to these negotiations, which have been deeply dishonest for many years? We like to forget that the immunity of the 138 MPs was lifted before the coup, that Turkey was already moving away from Europe before the coup. After the attempted coup, the whole thing just happened much faster, and a lot more people looked and realized: We are completely diverging. But this process was conducted in a deeply dishonest way on our part even before this coup attempt. Basically, it's like a failed relationship in which each of the two tells the other: You have to break up. President Erdoğan tells the Europeans: You have to explain if you do not want to negotiate with us. We say: Turkey should declare that it no longer wants to negotiate with us. The negotiations are dishonest. Incidentally, the height of dishonesty can also be seen in the beautiful, confused contribution by our otherwise highly valued colleague Elmar Brok. I mean: what was that? Where is the German CDU, for example? The leader of this party is against Turkey's accession to the European Union. The whole CDU is against it. Mrs. Merkel is the chairwoman of the party. As Federal Chancellor, Ms. Merkel suggests that we open a few more chapters in order to promote accession. The Turkish friends say: What is your position really now? The European attitude towards Turkey is also deeply dishonest. So please: let's stop this dishonest process - there will be no accession;85% of the people in Germany and 80% of the people in France are against accession - and let's replace this dishonest process.Let's replace it with a new framework for better constructive relationships.I reject what the High Representative said here: it is not about breaking bridges.It's not about ending the dialogue.The point is to put him on an honest footing with an important neighbor who will remain Turkey forever.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), "blue card" question.- I would like you to tell me how you comment on the redemptive aspirations of Sultan Erdogan against Greece, who has now opened a debate to challenge the Treaty of Lausanne, while the Turkish consulate in Komotini is taking anti-Greek actions trying to createfrom Greece and accession to Turkey.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I have also heard these statements in relation to the Lausanne Treaty, and they must make you worried because they reopen the territorial question, which has been finally settled since 1923.But a counter-question to you: Why does the Greek government not support the government of the Republic of Austria in taking a new step in the relationship, ending the negotiations?Greece wants to continue negotiating.I can not understand this.For me, the back and front of what is being done in Athens in terms of politics do not fit together.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! What has the EU done to stop Turkey from drifting into a dictatorship? The Commission and the Council have cultivated looking the other way, garnished by critical progress reports. Why? The premium partner in matters of EU isolationism policy - the NATO partner Turkey - should be kept happy. No EU member state has ever stopped arms deliveries to Turkey. The time for appeals and concerns is over. Freezing accession negotiations is only one step. But I call on the Council to finally end the lazy refugee deal and free itself from Erdoğan's political imprisonment. Otherwise we will have the Turkish and Kurdish opposition on our conscience alongside the dead in the Mediterranean, alongside refugees without protection and hope. At the end of the day, Sakharov prizes to Kurdish opposition leaders cannot make up for the EU's political failure. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- Madam President!We are dealing here with the most radical voice in this debate.While we all agree that Turkey has no prospect of accession, I would like to ask: in the name of what values would we break the refugee and immigrant agreement, which has worked and works well?What is the value here?

name: Martina MICHELS
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I can tell you: Because this refugee deal was a lazy deal from the start, which, at the expense of the refugees, so to speak, put Turkey in a position in which we made it clear that we are becoming dependent on Turkey.And that was a baseless undertaking from the start.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: - Madam President! The best way to support democracy, improve respect for human rights and the rule of law and pursue peace talks with the Kurds is accession talks. That is what we Greens have always been behind, and in principle we have not changed our minds. However, there must be someone to negotiate with, which has turned out to be no longer possible with President Erdoğan. Instead, everything is going in the wrong direction for a rapprochement with the EU in what the president is pursuing. If the proposal to introduce the death penalty were to pass, it would be, as Mrs Mogherini said, "the nail in the coffin" for membership. At present, it is very difficult to see any other way than to temporarily freeze the accession negotiations. However, that is not enough, we should also freeze the Turkey agreement. I am not saying that we should stop contributing money to the refugees, but that we should stop sending refugees back to Turkey instead of making ourselves dependent on a man who uses the refugees as blackmail against us. If all Member States take joint and several responsibility for the refugees who come here, then we have no major problem. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I have a question for you.You talked about ending refugee funding.Have you ever been to Turkey, in refugee camps to see?Did you see how those refugees live?Did you really see what is financed from that money?What do you want to stop?What will you earn by stopping aid to refugees and stopping the agreement with Turkey?Who makes money on it?Will you punish Erdogan or will you punish those people who need that help the most?

name: Bodil VALERO
text: answer (“blue card”).- I actually said the exact opposite, namely that we should not stop sending money to the refugees in Turkey.There are different parts of the refugee agreement with Turkey.What I am talking about is that we should stop sending refugees back from Europe to Turkey.Turkey is not a safe country for refugees to come to, so we should put a stop to it.But, of course, we must ensure that money goes to the refugee camps in Turkey, in Jordan, in Lebanon, in all the countries that today receive the largest group of refugees.Only a small, small part of them come here.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I want to start with a warm good morning to many colleagues who have finally woken up. I wonder where they were while we denounced, over the years, the very long list of authoritarian and liberticidal actions carried out by the government of Erdogan and by the current Turkish executive. Well, do we perhaps want to recall the ambiguities in the fight against terrorism, which for years have made it the highway of international jihadism? Yet there, perhaps, no one complained or perhaps few, because it was convenient. We also want to recall the territorial, neo-imperialist ambitions towards Aleppo, Mosul, Syrian Kurdistan, the intention to question decades-old treaties, the will to deny the right to self-determination of the brave Kurds of Rojava, to intervene with the operation "Euphrates Shield" to fight their advance, rather than to face Daesh? Or do we still want to repeat what many have said, namely the continuous denial of human rights, civil and political liberties, the arrest of twelve parliamentarians like us, who have lost immunity and are now in Turkish jails? Or do we still want to remember the arrest of 142 journalists, the latest Akin Atalay on 11 November? Not to mention the prescriptions, purges of tens of thousands of officials, teachers, judges and policemen. And finally the proposal to decriminalize sexual violence against minors thanks to the shotgun marriage. Not to mention the extension of the mandate, perhaps to 2029, without going through the elections. Democracy in Turkey no longer exists and this is a fact of which we must take note and react accordingly. We are calling for an immediate suspension, sine die, of the membership process and of the funds for membership. We demand the immediate rejection of the illegal immigration agreement and the rejection of migratory blackmail. Because Europe cannot be paralyzed by Merkel's fears ahead of the upcoming German elections.Turkish civil society is asking us today to give a strong response and, without a strong response against Erdogan, we will abandon the Turks to their fate.This is what we must do today.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 149 (8)))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much Madam President. Dear colleague, you mention the immediate suspension of the process of accession of Turkey, and I agree with lots of things that you said. But at the same time don’t you think this is going to have a counter-productive effect on Europe, with no positive results on developments taking place nowadays in Turkey? At the same time we would be abandoning democratic forces in Turkey for whom the EU still plays an important anchoring role. Last but not least, are we are losing any leverage on Turkey by proceeding in this way?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- Thanks for the question, Hon.Frunzulică.I can tell you that, so far, the strategy of closing your eyes and carrying out negotiations, regardless of what is happening, has not paid off, because Erdogan has continued in his project constantly and therefore, at this moment, perhaps the only onethe possibility of resuming a serious dialogue is to show us credible interlocutors, who in the face of these violations know how to make strong decisions and know how to implement them.Then we will be able to sit down at a table and then we will see if there will be an awareness on the Turkish side.If we continue to look away from the other side, if we continue to close our eyes, I think there will be no hope of recovering an at least decent diplomatic relationship with the Turkish interlocutor.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: - Commissioner Timmermans should have been here, as he recently said that there are indications that Gülen is involved in the unfortunately failed coup attempt in Turkey. He refers to an American report for this. On August 16, Turkey stated that it had not provided evidence to the US of Gulen's involvement when it requested his extradition. Then where does this claim come from? Does that report exist? Does the Commission agree with Mr Timmermans? Did Mr. Timmermans possibly receive this information via Inovo BV? This is the Turkish AKP lobby company co-founded by ALDE MEP Marietje Schaake and which pays tens of thousands of euros to influencers and decision-makers for advice. What involvement does Timmermans have with Inovo BV? Incidentally, if Timmermans cannot substantiate this claim, then he must resign, because let's be honest: you only say such a thing when you want to condone the hold on Erdogan's dictatorship, if you want to leave Turkey to the EU at all costs. if you want to keep visa liberalization going. That must absolutely stop.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, we have discussed Turkey several times in recent months, but I believe that today's debate will mark relations between the Union and Turkey because, this time, we are asking for something very strong thing. The words we have used, "freezing of negotiations", "postponement of negotiations", "moratorium" - we will find the consensus formula - are very strong. We do ask that the negotiations do not continue. We must be very nuanced in this approach, and our political group insists that this freeze, this postponement, be temporary. We must not be understood as a Parliament asking that the negotiations be over, over forever. The temporary nature should be emphasized. In that sense, we need a list of criteria that will allow us a recovery later, if that recovery is of course on Ankara's agenda, because, indeed, it is possible - let's be aware of that, let's take also our responsibilities - that Mr. Erdoğan decides following our gesture to finish everything. But, at least, let's remain nuanced and responsible.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President! We really only want to suspend accession negotiations - even if not everyone likes it - not break them off! Our friends in Turkey should know: We still believe today in the possibility of a common European future. So what we are proposing is not a law on blocking contact. There will also be dialogue in the future. I expressly agree with the Commission and the Council on how good it would be to find this attitude elsewhere as well. But one thing is not possible: while the Turkish president wants to develop Turkey away from democracy, away from the rule of law and away from the simplest freedoms, we are also negotiating accession. This is not serious. That is also not serious towards the people in Turkey, not even towards our fellow citizens, it is mutual hypocrisy. Then better take a break, which gives you time to think. Let us also use it for many talks with the many democrats who live in Turkey, who want a different Turkey: a democratic and constitutional one. Today we say to you from here: We won't let you down. We are by your side. We still have a lot to do together.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, I have had concerns about the direction of travel of Turkey for many years, particularly since the AK Party took power in 2003, Following his inauguration as President and the subsequent attempted coup, we find President Erdoğan on an increasingly authoritarian trajectory, now with the arrest of journalists and opposition MPs. His latest comments suggesting that Turkey, a NATO member state, could join the non-democratic China and Russia-led Shanghai Cooperation Council, highlights my concerns. And this coming so soon after he railed against inaction at the UN Security Council over Syria, where he supports Jihadi insurgents. Let us remind ourselves that it is his friend Russia, Mr Putin, and China that have done most to prevent any action on Syria at the UN Security Council. It is clearer than ever that President Erdoğan does not seek to lead a Turkey that is capable of meeting the democratic and rule-of-law criteria for EU membership. Bearing in mind the crucial relationship that exists between Turkey and the European Union, it is perhaps now time that a new framework for relations be considered. Sadly, the EU- Turkish relationship was a key issue during the Brexit referendum campaign and helped to deliver a Brexit result – very sad indeed.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, over the past days a lot of people in Turkey, who are desperately seeking a democratic anchor to hold on to, have asked me why this House is calling for freezing accession negotiations. As a friend of Turkey, I wish that I would never have had to answer that question, but the violations of the rule of law and human rights are too severe to continue as if it is business as usual. They directly violate the framework of accession negotiations and the Copenhagen criteria. Hundreds of thousands of people have been fired, mass arrests have taken place, journalists are imprisoned and NGOs are closed amid a climate of fear and self-censorship. So we have no choice but to respond to the disproportionate measures. After the despicable coup took place it has known only losers. Therefore, we call for the freezing of talks. They could be reviewed when the lifting of the state of emergency takes place and when measurable fair trial and due process standards are met. Turkey needs to return to a democratic path and respect the rule of law. Furthermore, principles such as the presumption of innocence, freedom of expression, separation of powers and fair trial should have meaning. Frankly, the EU is already losing credibility when it comes to being a community of values, and that is unacceptable. The statement or deal or whatever it is called on migration with Turkey is a case in point. Our vote to freeze negotiations is intended to emphasise that the democratic principles that the EU cherishes are more than a dead letter.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Madam President! Erdoğan's prisons are being filled with political prisoners, the media are being shut down and NGOs are being banned. LGBTQ people are exposed to more and more hate crimes. Our colleagues in HDP have been imprisoned. I want to tell you, my colleagues in the HDP, that you stand for hope, for democracy, for peace, for the future. And you have all our solidarity. What are we going to do now? What is required of us? First of all, I would like to say: end the shameful agreement with Turkey to stop refugees. It is hypocrisy to cooperate with Erdoğan in this way. The European countries themselves must handle refugee reception in a responsible and dignified manner. In addition, as many have said here, we should freeze membership negotiations with Erdoğan's regime. However, negotiations will be resumed when the rule of law is complied with. Last but not least: Give support to all democracy fighters in the HDP, in women's organizations, in the media, among journalists and to all those who stand up for democracy in Turkey.

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Madam President, a lot of Members have said that we should use our various tools, and look for tools to use, in order to send a strong signal to Turkey, and I agree that we should indeed send such a strong signal. I think we have the tools with which to do so. There is the customs union. The Commission says that it wants, this year, to propose an enlargement of the customs union. I think now is the completely wrong time – when we have so many human rights violations and so many people who have been imprisoned – to talk about enlargement of the customs union. We really should not do that, and we, as Parliament, can say that we will not agree to it. Secondly, the Turkey deal is not so much an instrument which we possess but, rather, one which we have given to Erdoğan potentially to use against us. I think that was a very wrong decision – in terms of human rights, of course, and also because it makes us and the Member States dependent on Erdoğan’s goodwill. We should absolutely stop sending people back to Turkey. We need to have an EU pact instead, because the answer to that question can only lie within the European Union.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Madam President!The Turkey agreement would never have been concluded.It was only one way for Turkey to blackmail the EU.Both I and many other EU critics have constantly said that.The € 3.9 billion that has been paid out so far could have been incredibly much more useful in the immediate vicinity of the conflicts.Instead, credit cards should be distributed in Turkey - unconditionally.This means giving an economic stimulus package to Erdoğan in this very sensitive time.Ever since the agreement was concluded, Erdoğan has threatened that if he does not get through his demands, he will once again let through migrants who want to get to Europe.Europe cannot cope with another stream of migrants.The only solution right now is for each Member State to get its borders and asylum policy back, so that we can signal to migrants that our Member States are full.It is not enough to freeze these negotiations, it is a matter of throwing them in the rubbish and putting on the lid.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Madam President, the European Parliament is clearing its conscience by protesting against the human rights violations committed by Turkey, but these protests are only intended to mislead public opinion, because the European Union is is submitted to Turkey by accepting the shameful immigration agreement of March 18, 2016. Erdoğan mocks the Union and every day plunges his country more into Islamist obscurantism. He has just claimed Greek islands on the grounds that they are home to Turkish mosques and, as we speak, he is proposing to the Turkish Parliament to pass a law which will exempt rapists from punishment once they marry their victims, even minor. Rape and pedophilia will thus be legalized. Despite everything, the Union continues to accept Turkey's membership. She has denied European values ​​so much that she is no longer even able to defend women and children. She submits to radical Islam. I call on France and invite other European nations to draw the consequences, as the United Kingdom has already done.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: - Madam President! Should we finally break off the Turkish negotiations and thus follow these pseudo-arguments of the right-wing bloc and also of colleague Lambsdorff, who is abusing it for domestic political purposes? That would be exactly what President Erdoğan wants. He wants us to turn our backs on Turkey once and for all, because then he could blame the EU for the fact that Turkey is slipping away more and more, being downright run down. Tourism has already collapsed, the climate of fear will continue to deter investors from abroad, the country is being run down. On the contrary, we must now make it very clear that this is Mr Erdoğan's fault alone. He abuses the state of emergency to realize his very private dreams and thus brings disaster to his country. And so we must act wisely now. We really need to keep channels of conversation open. Freezing the negotiations is now the correct means and not the final breakdown. And if necessary - that has already been said - there is also the possibility of thinking about pre-accession funds or the customs union in the future.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - I welcome the work of our rapporteur, Kati Piri, who is following the situation in Turkey very responsibly.Turkey is an important strategic partner of the Union.We have common challenges and opportunities and I would like us to talk differently today.Unfortunately, this is not the case.The image is black.The number of imprisoned politicians, journalists and academics is unacceptable.Every day we get reports of alleged suicides in prisons.The number of victims is growing.My colleagues were not allowed to visit the imprisoned opposition leader these days.They also did not allow their colleague Piri to enter the country.And all these facts call into question the state of democracy in Turkey.We cannot act as if it is a state of business as usual.Respect for human rights, the rule of law and democracy is not the subject of negotiations, nor is the introduction of the death penalty.I therefore strongly support the temporary freeze on the accession negotiations and I hope that the next debate will take place in a better atmosphere.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: ECR). - Madam President, those who care so much about Cyprus should know that what Turkey is asking for in order to accept the settlement of the Cyprus problem violates and will continue to violate the human rights of the Cypriot people. Another ongoing crime of Turkey is taking place in Cyprus. The cleansing of the Cypriot people continues and the Republic of Cyprus is in danger of turning into a Turkish protectorate. The European Union tolerates this situation and fortifies itself behind the talks, which have already collapsed, without taking any action against Turkey. It continues to fund Turkey, but does not impose sanctions, as it did with Russia. Ladies and gentlemen, none of you who speak vaguely about a solution to the Cyprus problem would accept Turkey's terms for its own people. He would not accept his children having to go to a Turkish school. You do not know what the solution required by Turkey is. You do not know that Turkey will control the European Union through the veto of the federal government of Cyprus, which it will fully control. We ask you to finally support the implementation of the principles and values ​​of the European Union, to support the implementation of all the goods enjoyed by your own people and for the Cypriot people, by imposing sanctions on Turkey.

name: Nedzhmi ALI
text: – Madam President, Mrs Vice-President Mogherini, Commissioner and dear colleagues, Turkey’s integration in the European structure started a long time ago but unfortunately we still do not see conclusive results. Turkey is not just a candidate country, it is also a geo-strategic partner for the EU and we should support the positive development in the area of mutual beneficial cooperation. Together we experienced so many challenges that could be overcome only in close partnership. Turkey has a robust functioning market economy and it is the fifth largest trade partner of the EU, while the Union is its main trading partner. There is also a big untapped potential for further development in this area. The recent coup d’état attempt created turmoil in the society that could be overcome not least by the sincerest European support for Turkey’s democratic institutions, including the Government, opposition parties and the civil society organisations. In this regard, a suspension of the negotiation process will be counterproductive. If we interrupt this process, how will we ensure continual support to civil society and the inflows and acceleration of the necessary reforms? As part of the accession negotiations, if we have succeeded to open Chapters 23 and 24 using the administrative capacity of the European institutions, it would have been possible to synchronise the legislative framework of Turkey with the European one. We consider that this is the way to continue working with a democratic, inclusive and stable country. Otherwise, by suspending the negotiating process will contribute to the weakening of civil society and the pro-European path of the people of Turkey.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, Mr Hahn, for once, this Parliament's position is clear: freeze, but not break. In any case, in Turkey things have reached a limit that, indeed, makes it impossible to look the other way. Parliament, however, proposes; the Commission manages a day to day more and more complex; and the Council, as always, will decide in the last instance. What we know is that we cannot continue to be installed in the useless game of rudeness, statements, last-chance warnings. In the foreground we have the Turkish civil society and the Kurdish people, the only and authentic victims, and in the background the refugees who, thanks to our refusal to assume the responsibilities that correspond to us, have become the protective shield for the president's impunity Erdoğan and his Government. Perhaps, then, freezing is useful, this clearer and more forceful message that Parliament sends, but it will only be useful if the Commission and Council know how to administer it; also to open the frank and direct dialogue, without taboos or self-restrictions, that Mrs Mogherini proposes, the dialogue that allows us to know where we are both - the European Union and Turkey - so that we can make the right decisions conscientiously and without haste. Does Turkey want to keep its European claim alive? Does the European Union want to act with the determination and clarity necessary for Turkey to retrace the path that leads to disaster?

name: Raymond FINCH
text: – Madam President, the fact that you consider yourselves advocates for human rights across the world but support the principle that a Turkey, led by Mr Erdoğan, can become members of your club, smacks of hypocrisy. This is a regime that persecutes its citizens, imprisons journalists, covertly supports Islamic State, and has even considered legalising child rape as long as the rapist then marries the child. I am relieved to see that the Turkish Government appears to be backing down from this, but to have ever even considered it is a disgrace. You spend EUR 650 million a year to support this junta. Do you think that this is a responsible way to spend taxpayers money, or that the 40 000 people who have recently been arrested are grateful for your support of this dictator?

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! In any case, one thing becomes very clear if you listen to today's debate here in this House, namely the extremely strange ethical and moral approach and also the dishonesty of the politically responsible in this Union when it comes to this matter. How long does the list - Ms. Mogherini read it herself - have to be before the matter is finally dealt with here? Ms. Merkel is afraid of Donald Trump when it comes to human rights. We spend hours and days discussing human rights here. This is one of the most important issues for you here, and you are not ready to finally intervene in Turkey? Turkey - and this is a very important point - has occupied territory of the European Union for over 40 years. You don't seem to care at all either. Why don't you try to be honest - with the Turks and also with the Europeans - and let's say: break off the negotiations, suspend all payments, which does not mean that the dialogue has to be broken off.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: – Madam President, I would firstly strongly condemn the accusations that Mr de Graaff makes about, among others, our colleague Marietje Schaake, but I do believe – and I say this to the Commission – that there is some need for clarification. I will give you the exact quote that the first Vice—President of the Commission gave to the Belgian magazine ‘Knack’. He said, ‘On the basis of American research, there are indications that the Gulen movement did play a role in the coup in Turkey’. That is quite a statement, and it caused quite a stir in Turkish communities, including in my country. My time is limited, so I will ask the Commission only one question: can they clarify whether this is the position of the Commission? What research are we talking about because, until now, this research was unknown to the Parliament? However, the main issue is this: is it the Commission’s position that the movement itself was behind the coup? Thank you for shedding light on this matter.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Madam President, we have to take very seriously the grim news which comes every day from Turkey about one more merciless violation of human rights, in prisons or elsewhere. And the latest messages coming from social media are an even stronger warning because there are signals on social media about a planned massacre in the prisons in Turkey under the pretext of planned unrest. This could seem like fantasy, but for us – people who know well the history of Stalinism – it is a familiar pattern. Provocations of this kind and fake trials are part of a well-known pattern. It is important that the EU and you personally, Ms Mogherini, should do everything possible to ensure that we have an objective international team to investigate the situation of prisoners in Turkish jails, the situation with regard to torture, and the 21 suicides, or alleged suicides, and so on. In this situation we really have no other option: if we want to be taken seriously as a guardian of human rights all over the world, then we have to react and we have to give Erdogan the clear message that he has stepped across all the red lines. There is a way back – and that is why we want to freeze the talks, not to finish them. There could be a way back for the Turkish people, the Turkish nation, and we must do all we can so that the Turkish nation will have this way back.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: – Madam President, many of us have long pointed out that if, over many years, we treated Turkey with disrespect and disdain, we should not now be surprised if she should give up her Western orientation of the past century and head off in a different direction. I have just returned from Istanbul where I was attending the NATO Parliamentary Assembly. I can tell you that many Turks are angry and disappointed at what they see as lack of support from those who say they are her friends. Turkey sees how she stood firm throughout the Cold War at the borders of the Soviet Union. She is now at the heart of this arc of crisis in the Black Sea and Middle East region, she has suffered perpetual terrorist attacks over decades – particularly from the Soviet-created PKK – she is now hosting nearly three million refugees, costing her USD 25 billion, she is in the front line of the fight against Daesh, and she has suffered an attempted coup. It could well be the case that Turkey, in due course, will seek a relationship with the EU different from full membership. That should be her decision. It would be a gross strategic error for the EU itself to slam the door in the face of Turkey, a country of crucial geo-strategic importance, a staunch NATO ally for 64 years, a crucial partner in combating jihadists, and with so many positive links to Western Europe. Don’t forget that for many good people in Turkey the journey is perhaps more important than arriving at the destination ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, it is clear to us, and I hope to the Turks as well, that the restriction of civil liberties and violations of the rule of law and human rights are not consistent with the commitments of a country aspiring to EU membership. Nevertheless, we should not take hasty decisions: we should think, instead, about how to maintain our relations rather than cutting Turkey off. Suspending the negotiations will probably only worsen an already tense situation. What should be our next step? We might use our ability to support any democratic developments in the country, as most of them are linked to the process of Europeanisation. We will also have to be ready to reopen many related economic and security issues. We face a difficult decision, however we should not shut the door on Turkey because, when we want to open it again, we could get an unpleasant surprise.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, we are watching with great concern President Erdoğan's attack on the rule of law and civil liberties. So I would expect a European counterattack in support of the persecuted Turkish society. I would expect us to finally open the chapters on the rule of law and fundamental rights and to declare that this is the European way and it is non-negotiable, a door that does not close, that freedoms and rights are the prerequisites for closer relations, without limit, those that will multiply 140 billion in trade and make them much more. But what do Turkish citizens see? They see us abandoning them, abandoning or freezing - besides them - and the most important tool of cooperation and dialogue with the pro-European part of Turkish society, they see us offering Erdoğan the alibi to plunge his people into a blind anti-Europeanism and win conservative majority. Closing the door on Turkey's European perspective, we are putting additional obstacles in the already difficult talks on the Cyprus issue, with a risk, extreme but real, to reach the Turkish border in Nicosia. After Libya, Egypt, Syria and Ukraine, it is time to fail in Turkey as well.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: - Madam President! Europe itself is in a serious crisis. Europe is old, inflexible and falling. It suffers from centralization and over-regulation and so on and so on. This decline of our continent means that we ourselves are no longer taken seriously. Turkey is currently breaking with all democratic values ​​and is becoming an Islamic dictatorship. Nevertheless, the German government remains silent out of consideration for the refugee pact. This refugee pact negotiated by Ms. Merkel is Erdoğan's most important vehicle in the process of transformation to dictatorship and the brutal oppression of minorities. The refugee pact protects Erdoğan from sanctions and even from mere criticism. How much Ms. Merkel criticized the new US President Trump and dictated the Western and European values ​​that should be a prerequisite for cooperation! How submissive is the German Chancellor to Erdoğan! Here we tolerate that these common values ​​are simply ignored and trampled underfoot. The number of Turkish citizens who have applied for asylum in Germany has skyrocketed. Kurdish ones will follow, and we should urgently set an example here.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Turkey has huge problems and yet I say that Turkey is a key partner for us in the fight against illegal migration. He is our partner for the return of refugees and this agreement, which has been concluded, is being implemented. Turkey is part of the alliance necessary for a peaceful solution in the Middle East and is also our ally in NATO. Today, we are talking about Turkey again because we are disturbed by the development of President Erdogan's policy. Turkey is moving away from European standards. This is also evidenced by the fact that our EU-Turkey delegation has not met here in the EP for a year and a half. This is understandable, apparently the Turkish representation is not interested in explaining some of its repressive steps. At this point, I would like to call on the High Representative to stand up for two Czech arrested citizens who are to be tried for belonging to Kurdish militias and to be accused of terrorism. I ask that she stand up for their proper trial and investigation and that they be released.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Madam President, this is a plenary session, a debate, very sad. Because those of us who have always defended the need for Turkey to advance on its path of accession to the European Union today we have to ask that these negotiations be frozen. And one of the unfortunate side effects of Erdoğan's policy is that it is giving force to the arguments of those who have always been enemies of Turkey. From the position of those of us who have always defended Turkey, today we want to send the message to the Turkish people that from here we want to defend their freedoms, their dignity, the dignity of women, freedom of expression, freedom of political exercise, and that , because we want to do that, and because that is the Turkey we believe in, today we ask that the talks be frozen, in the hope - we and the Turkish people - that those negotiations can be opened the day freedoms reopen and democracy in Turkey. But today, Madam President, is a sad day for those of us who believe in Turkey.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). - Madam President, today all political groups rightly stigmatize Turkey's attitude and behavior towards human rights violations and contempt for principles and values. However, I must point out that this behavior of Turkey is not current. This is a timeless behavior that has been tolerated and impunity, even by the European Union, with the result that Turkey is intimidated and provoked. We all know that Turkey, for forty-two years, has been violating human rights in Cyprus on a daily basis, that it has invaded and occupied an EU country, that it continues to provoke and offend the feelings of all of us. I must emphasize that the President of the Republic of Cyprus, Nikos Anastasiadis, did his best to find a solution to the Cyprus problem. However, he encountered, during the talks in Switzerland, the unacceptable refusal of Turkey to disengage from offensive positions because it wants to remain a guarantor power in a country that is a member of the European Union, in a modern country. I must emphasize that it is the responsibility of the European Union to support the solution of the Cyprus problem towards a Turkey that continues to challenge even Greece by challenging international treaties. In conclusion, many here pointed out that Turkey is a strategic partner. I hope he retires because he is neither a strategic partner nor a reliable partner.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, like many of you, I look with great concern at the recent events in Turkey. The attempted coup of last July remains an undemocratic act to be condemned, which would have had to correspond to proportionate countermeasures. Unfortunately, this was not the case. In a country that has long been a candidate for accession, we cannot accept the repeated violations of the rule of law, mass arrests and failure to protect human rights, as well as the possible reintroduction of the death penalty. Europe is not just an economic union, but above all a community of values. In recent weeks, in the Committee on International Trade, we are evaluating proposals for the renewal of the European Union-Turkey trade framework and to modernize the customs union with Ankara. In this perspective too, we need to be consistent with our values: either Turkey will step back or we will have to change its attitude, including through strong signals, such as the freezing of the accession process.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D). - There are currently 2300 judges and prosecutors in Turkish prisons, 150 journalists, more than 31000 citizens and 10 members of the Turkish parliament, including Mr. Demirtas. At the same time, 129,000 civil servants have either been fired or are on leave. These elements are of pharaonic proportions. Mr Erdoğan addresses the coup attempt against the Turkish Republic with another coup against the rule of law and human rights. He blackmails with the agreement on the refugees without considering their drama. It raises border issues that have been closed for a hundred years by the Treaty of Lausanne. All of the above show a leader who does not serve the public interest of his people but the plan of his personal survival and personal hegemony. He wants us to keep a guilty silence. That is why our answer today must be loud and clear: if it continues on the same path, then it will not be considered a credible partner, the accession negotiations will be put in the freezer and the pre-accession financial assistance that Turkey is receiving will stop.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: S & amp; D). - I think the time has come to answer two very basic questions. The first question is "What Turkey do we want?" The second question is "Has our attitude so far helped us to have a democratic Turkey?" Yes, we want a democratic Turkey that respects the rights of its citizens, that respects the sovereignty of its neighboring states, we want a Turkey that does not have other small states in its territory. Can Europe's attitude towards Turkey so far be considered successful? I answer clearly "No". I will remind you that, in response to the resolutions we have issued so far on Turkey, Mr Erdoğan said that they would be thrown away. This morning, Turkey proved its stance, effectively torpedoing talks on resolving the Cyprus issue.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, yesterday I returned from my second visit to Turkey in less than a month, and I can report that the climate of state repression continues unabated, particularly against HDP political opponents and civil society. Erdoğan’s forces are cranking up the level of fear and intimidation amongst the population, using the smokescreen of a state of emergency to carry out a policy that looks very much like ethnic cleansing in Kurdistan. Having bombed and cleared whole neighbourhoods in Sur and Nusaybin, parents are now denied the right to bury their children killed in the process. The shutting-down of media outlets reporting from the ground means that the world does not know what is happening. Turkey is fast slipping into a fascist state, and we must rethink our relationship with our European neighbour, because European values of democracy and human rights are being sorely tested. When an elected member of the AKP ruling party can bring forward a bill that legalises the rape of a minor by means of child marriage, we should all worry about how things will end.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - Insofar as the proponents of European enlargement with Turkey had credibility until 2012, 2013, then that credibility began to decline.Today, however, they are becoming completely unreliable.I think it is necessary to say that Europe simply cannot and must not accept Turkey as it is today into the framework of the European Union, because this is not a country that respects our values.I myself also wonder very much whether Turkey wants to enter and respect such values as we have in Europe today, or whether it imagines that Europe will adapt to their needs.So I think it is the right decision to freeze these negotiations.At the same time, I think we need to think very seriously about how we will protect our interests, European interests, in Cyprus as well as in Greece.Above all, I am afraid of preparing for a new wave of refugees, because the measures that Erdogan will take may be the strongest for him in this area, but also very controversial and difficult for us.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Madam President, MEPs are being barred from visiting fellow Turkish parliamentarians in prison, 10 from the HDP plus the seven mayors of Kurdish cities are jailed besides thousands of journalists, judges, teachers, officers, alleged to have links with the July coup. The EU should be alarmed and warn against a mass murder likely in preparation of prisoners whom Erdoğan considers linked to the Gulen Movement. Already 20 appeared to have been suicides, certainly to hide traces of torture. Already pro-government media report on mass escape plans by jailed prisoners, a convenient excuse to execute them. The EU must ditch any pretence that the accession negotiations are still possible with the repressive regime of Erdoğan in his latest crazy power grab. Let’s instead, Ms Mogherini, engage and support all those brave men and women in Turkey who fight for democracy and human rights, and resist. We cannot be friends with a regime that brutally attacks the Kurds and oppresses the Turkish people.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - The time has come to put an end to the great mockery of Turkey's accession process and to permanently suspend Turkey's accession negotiations with the European Union. For more than ten years now, the European Union has tolerated the continuing violations of international law by Turkey and the neo-Ottoman aspirations of the Erdoğan government. The European Union is closely monitoring the Islamization of world cultural monuments, such as the Hagia Sophia, Turkey's interventionist policy in Syria and Iraq, and Turkey's cooperation with ISIS. The European Union is idle monitoring the violations of Greek sovereign rights in the Aegean and Thrace and, of course, forgets the ongoing occupation of 37% of Cyprus by Turkish troops. In the area of ​​the refugee problem, Turkey is sending thousands of refugees and illegal immigrants to the Aegean islands, where the inhabitants can no longer stand it. So here and now, we must finally close the door on Europe for Turkey and Erdoğan.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, when I was in the college in 2004 we debated the report on Turkey.
