Probably, the priority of managing the economic and financial crisis has since distracted us from security issues. I believe that now is the time for us to get serious and work effectively in this direction, and I expect the European Parliament to keep supporting and contributing to this process, as it has been doing, in a very useful manner.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would first like to thank on behalf of the EPP, of which I was the shadow rapporteur, our colleague Paşcu who has produced an excellent report, an annual report - it must be remembered - but which is obviously topical especially today after the decisions that you recalled, Madam High Representative, and which are important. Unfortunately - and I am not speaking for you, Madam High Representative - it took Brexit and the election of Trump so that, in many European countries, we remember that defense and security should be a priority for the Europeans themselves. We could have wished that this awareness came earlier because of the conflicts and crises that surround us and which have such a dangerous impact. But still, better late than never. European defense policy must be ambitious, of course, but it must be realistic, pragmatic, flexible, and I think that you have outlined a certain number of avenues that will have to be implemented. Many things - we have been saying this for years here - are already in the treaty and deserve to be implemented before we create - forgive me the expression - "new gas factories". Allow me to recall three points that seem to me to be very important politically. First, a European defense policy must distance itself from two myths, that of the common European army, which does not help to move forward concretely and pragmatically, but also that of competition with NATO, because it is absolutely not what it is. We are talking about complementarity and not competition. Second, the transatlantic link: it is strong, but it is not an eternal achievement. What just happened on the other side of the Atlantic reminds us very well that if we do not take our own safety into our own hands, we risk one day having very bad surprises.We must therefore invest more in our defense and carry out more industrial investments and in truly operational systems.Third, NATO: it remains a major player in our collective security, that is obvious.But in the end, NATO cannot, with its decision-making table on which Mr. Erdoğan and soon Mr. Trump sit, be the security guarantor of Europeans.We need to take charge, and it's time to turn good intentions and good words into concrete action.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, the report we adopted today on the European Defense Union and this one by Ioan Paşcu, on the Common Security and Defense Policy, complement each other in the face of a challenge that will determine whether the European Union is built or allowed to be destroyed. There is an urgent need to rethink Europe's defense and security in the face of ongoing strategic changes, in a world in disarray in which Brexiters, Putin, Trump and others will tend to sow paralysis in the Security Council and weaken NATO. Europe must wake up, it must organize. The approved global strategy and a white paper may be useful, but nothing substitutes for political will and democratic control - which today are clearly insufficient in most Member States - which must now exercise their commitment to invest in research and technology jointly. , in interoperability of equipment and forces, common financing and an integrated view of the internal and external dimensions and the civil and military aspects of defense and security for all of us. The Union must make use of the tools it has created, of tactical groupings on CSDP missions, supporting Member States, both in combating terrorist forces where necessary, and in neutralizing aggressions and hybrid threats, including in cybersecurity of critical infrastructure. It takes time to establish a permanent headquarters, as Ms. Mogherini said. The Union must be able to intervene and make a difference in crises and conflicts, many at the door, others already at the door, with an impact on the security of our citizens, our interests, the defense of international law and global security.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I am tempted to spend my time replying to Ioan’s question about what went wrong with the EU. Well, maybe not listening to our citizens, maybe the euro, maybe migration policy... What about misguided notions about EU defence? The security and credibility of the West rests on the combined strength of the democracies. We always knew that whoever became the next President of the United States, he or she would have demanded that the Europeans carry more of the defence burden. But I would suggest that this is done by the nations spending more on defence and showing more capability and revitalising the NATO alliance, not creating alternative structures. Unlike the EU, NATO is an intergovernmental organisation. It does not undermine national sovereignty, and above all, it has the enormous advantage of binding the United States to the security of Europe. That is the great combined power that our potential enemies take seriously. Russia would be delighted if Europe was to develop its so-called ‘strategic autonomy’ separated from the United States – I mean, what’s that all about? It is a dangerous fallacy for the European Union to imagine, and I am quoting here from the report, that it can ‘intervene across the whole spectrum of crisis management’ – that includes war fighting, by the way – and that the EU should aim for a ‘common defence’. I thought you said you were not aiming for collective defence – ‘common defence’ is the same thing. Which immediately casts doubt on the continued relevance of NATO. How on earth would the EU protect its non-NATO members? It is just disingenuous for the EU to talk about complementarity with NATO when the aim is to set up a different military structure.

name: Jozo RADOŠ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr President, first of all, on behalf of the ALDE Group, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his good cooperation, and as a result of that cooperation for his good report. The report discusses the significantly deteriorating security situation in Europe, states that European security and defense policy is far below public expectations, emphasizes the importance of a thorough revision of that policy in such circumstances and calls on the Council to work to ensure that European security and defense policy writes in the treaties establishing the European Union, grows into a common defense. After such clear and serious wording, the report itself should be just as serious, concrete and very precise, following the implementation plan presented by the High Representative to the Council of the European Union and at the level of the report on the European Union adopted by the European Parliament today. which speak of the need to establish a permanent command, a joint command, to reform the concept of battle groups, to reform the Athens mechanism for financing the European Union's military operations and to establish a start-up fund, also to finance these operations. These are therefore very clear objectives mentioned in the documents, including this report of ours, and therefore the ALDE Group will not support those amendments that weaken the European Union's determination to strengthen the common security and defense policy, such as those deleting the provision on the need to create a joint command and relativize the European defense research agenda.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mister President! In Europe and around the world, poverty, social division and injustice are growing. For many people, the rulers and their policies rightly only represent the interests of economic and political elites. The consequences are social crash or the fear of it - and the abuse of these problems by right-wing parties and movements. The trumps - and what they are called here - send their regards. This is neither surprising nor by chance. Instead of investing in poverty reduction, advocating for social justice and effectively protecting people fleeing war, poverty and terror, you are wasting tax money on armories and research for war equipment, arming Europe's borders and forcing people into poverty and impoverishment . Linking development aid to the terms of this policy and making deals with governments that do not care about human rights - that is a shame for a Union that invokes its great values. This report and the report on the Defense Union again contain 90% gifts and concessions to the elites, to murderous arms and arms companies. These will be the beneficiaries. But none of these measures will create stability and more real security. There is no alternative. Ms. Thatcher's much-quoted stance on social cuts and poverty also characterizes the stance on the EU military union. There is then no need for any debate. But there must be an alternative to armament and military intervention.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President! Today, we have endorsed a report on the Defense Union, and now we are discussing another report that has many similarities. In general, our recent discussions here in Parliament are moving more and more in the direction of our desire to create a common military capability or a common army, and these are wish lists for all kinds of military activities paid for with EU funds. Not least since the Brexit vote, it is as if some in this House have really gained a new hope of being able to deepen cooperation in the field of defense as well. I have absolutely no problem with cooperation but think that cooperation is very good - cooperation and coordination. The world also looks different than it did just ten years ago. Our security situation is also different. We must, of course, adapt to the fact that these are new times and a completely new world we live in. However, this does not mean that I see the same solutions as those in the report, and which I think also go beyond what Mrs Mogherini just said. . For example, I do not believe that the solution is for future security and defense policy to be based on a common territorial defense, including nuclear weapons. Another strange idea is that the EU should be able to enter member states in the event of a riot. I do not think that this is contained in Article 43 of the Treaty of Lisbon, which lists the military activities that are allowed to take place. Then we would need a treaty change, which is something that takes a very long time, and which I do not think is on the doorstep right now in any case.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, here we have in black and white the dangerous fantasy that Nick Clegg tried to trick voters with in 2014, when he said there were no plans for an EU military. Whilst the UK Government dithers over invoking Article 50, and pro-EU MPs and lords plot to overturn the will of the people, the EU is busy putting in place plans to spend British taxpayers’ money on an EU military which many here hope will replace NATO. Except that this scheme will not just focus on martial law, but also seeks to encroach on civil liberties – and I would like to bring to MEPs’ attention the fact that this report wants EU troops to combat subversion. Subversion actually covers everything from threats to the state to political opposition, books, films and even comedians. This is an attack on free speech and, because it comes from a place like this, an attack on those who oppose the EU project. This report has huge implications for the sovereignty of the UK and its ability to control its own military, and those implications must serve as motivation for all Brexiteers and those who believe in democracy to ensure that the will of the people is served. We cannot afford to be trapped in this bloc, which so shamelessly uses crises of its own making, such as the migrant crisis, to further its political aims. The terrorist attacks in Brussels and Paris have been directly linked to the stupidity of the EU’s migration policy, which, had that policy been carried out by an organisation with any level of accountability, would have resulted in senior figures being unceremoniously fired. To make the most of this opportunity, we need to invoke Article 50 as soon as possible and revitalise the UK armed forces, including by increasing defence spending and investment in our troops and in the industries needed to have a strong engineering and defence sector in the UK.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, Mrs Mogherini, you are talking to us about European defense. European defense would require European sovereignty. This sovereignty does not exist. The only one that exists is that of our States, which can certainly cooperate, but which cannot dissolve into the European entity, which only exists through the will of nations and through their free cooperation. European defense would involve common interests. Where are they? What interest does France share with those who have chosen to be subject to NATO, but also to be in a spirit of revenge, while wanting their revenge and resentment to be carried out by others because they can't afford it? European defense would imply a common foreign policy. What little common foreign policy is dictated by the United States, which changes. We see it with Russia. We are ridiculous. European defense would imply a controlled armament and strategic research sector. You have chosen complementarity with NATO, that is to say technological submission and external domination, again. In reality, European defense is a myth to use the nations still able to defend themselves and to keep their own capabilities.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Mr Chairman! They talk about defense and security, while the European Community at the beginning consisted of six countries, adopted twenty-two more, and no one is shouting about aggression. Meanwhile, five countries have declared their will to join the Russian Federation: Transnistria, South Ossetia, the Republic of Lugansk, the Donetsk Republic and the Crimea. Russia has only admitted one of these five countries. If we are talking about the threat, it is enough to look at whether Russia is surrounded by NATO bases or Europe is surrounded by Russian bases. Of course, Russia is afraid of NATO, not of the European Union, because who is afraid of the European Union? If we are talking about detachment by force, I would like to recall that American planes bombed civilian cities in Europe, taking Kosovo for the first time. And this is the first tearing away by force of the territory of another state, not the Crimea. Also the detachment of Montenegro - a very nice country, otherwise, which was given much more help than the little green men gave help in Crimea. If we are talking about a threat, the countries that are much closer to Russia than Brussels, namely Bulgaria, Moldova and Estonia, have recently chosen quite pro-Russian governments. I suspect that Ms Lösing is right that it is about bribes for armaments, and the whole story is only there to be able to bribe armaments. Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! I listened with fascination to the last speeches from the far right and far left, which had a great deal of agreement with each other and in which all speakers are in great agreement with Mr Putin, against whom one should not defend oneself. When I hear that collective security in Europe is stupid anyway - and the British are defending themselves on their own anyway, if I have understood correctly, and Mrs. Lösing, who says: "But please don't protect the borders" - then I have to say: What is the concept here? Madam Vice-President, High Representative! I would like to congratulate you on the step that you took at the Foreign Ministers' Conference on the basis of your proposals with the implementation plan. It does not go far enough for us on some points - it is Parliament's job to keep pressing. But I believe that we have to make progress institutionally with regard to permanent structured cooperation, headquarters, battle groups and many other things, we have to have the financial resources for it, we have to have new ideas about what can be done with the existing foreign and security policy . I also believe that we have to go much further when it comes to research and procurement. These are all ways of saving money, Ms. Lösing. We are spending 200 billion euros with a negative effect! And I believe that we can achieve a great deal more with the same amount of money if we go along these lines. And I believe that in view of the world situation, which you have described positively, but which is realistically there with Mr Putin and with Crimea, and whatever else we could possibly meet with regard to the uncertainty in NATO, it is important is that we make our citizens an offer for internal and external security, as far as we can manage, with all the weaknesses that we have.And this is - it must also be made clear, Mr Hookem - that the NATO Secretary General supported the idea of the European Union at the meeting of defense ministers in Bratislava, because he says that a strong European Union in security and defense policy produces a strong oneNATO.That is why it is in our interest - and we must have our capabilities, in Africa and other places where NATO is not available - that we can fight for our security and for better living conditions, for human rights.I wish you every success on this path and thank you for the report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, the election of Donald Trump has been a wake-up call for us, even though the US has long urged Europeans to take more responsibility for their own security. European defence structures, require attention, as Ms Mogherini has said. Our spending is 50% that of USA, yet our achievement is 15%. There are clearly issues we need to attend to. The goal of 2% of GDP, to which NATO allies committed themselves in 2014, has so far been reached by only four Member States. Reports also show how duplication and inefficiency eat into the EUR 200 billion annual defence spend of EU Member States. Lack of interoperability also remains a major problem affecting military cooperation. What we need is a serious effort from Member States to invest more, and more efficiently, in military capabilities. It is time to demonstrate the political will to take action, as opposed to issuing declarations. The implementation plan on security and defence approved last week by all 28 Member States represents an important step forward in European security and defence. We must rethink the EU’s defence role and enhance its capacity to act in the changing global strategic environment. We have to be a more independent and resilient actor, less reliant on the US and working more closely with and complementing NATO, as agreed during the summit in Warsaw. If Europe is to remain safe and secure, defence cooperation among Member States must become the norm.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! I represent one of the four countries mentioned by the previous speaker that are fully meeting their obligations towards common security. Because you have to clearly distinguish between two things: common security and a shared policy that aims at it. This is, for example, the participation of the vast majority of our countries in the Atlantic Alliance, that is, keeping the European dimension of NATO up-to-date, of course, specific political decisions or diplomatic initiatives that implement this common responsibility. But everything that aims to build a European army is something else. Of course, Mrs Mogherini spoke about the fact that it is unreal that it will not happen, but we all know very well that this is an old dream, which Romano Prodi, for example, spoke about quite recently. Articles 12 to 14 of this report are not really reassuring, although there are many good observations in it. Article 38, what goes next also. Let us really remember one thing: Europe is made up of the states of the peoples of Europe. When these states change specter, Europe will actually cease to exist.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: - Mr President, Mrs Mogherini! We knew even before Donald Trump that the EU's external security would require us to make more efforts. But the complete revision of the ESDP, as the report suggests, is wrong and unnecessary. I warn against overstretching ambitions: if the eyes are bigger than the stomach, it rarely goes well. Mr Van Orden has already said that so-called strategic autonomy is still a stupid idea. The territorial defense the report speaks of is an empty, unsubstantiated promise. Giving the ESDP a role inside against subversion is an attack on freedom. To talk analytically about an output gap and then to say that we have to spend more money senselessly and inefficiently is illogical. The height of the insolence is that now military subsidies must be raised to US levels. If you react with hectic and hysteria to the fact that you slept too long, then it won't work, and love service in the military lobby doesn't make it any better. The need for greater European cooperation, a defense union, is undeniable. But that's the wrong way.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt that we live in dangerous and uncertain times. Perhaps we should start by congratulating French security forces this week on apprehending those who seemed set on terrorist activity, and express our solidarity with the city of Strasbourg, where heightened security measures have once again been deemed necessary in the run-up to the celebration of Christmas. However, I also want to make it clear this evening that defence policy is not something that can be auctioned off to the highest bidder. It is the age-old right of sovereign nation states to keep their people safe. Many in these institutions are talking nonsense about an EU army and an operational headquarters. The United Kingdom has always shown itself willing to come to the aid of our allies. We will retain the right and the capacity to defend ourselves and also our closest neighbours inside and outside the European Union. The reality is that, while Brussels panders to federalist ambitions, it sacrifices the positive role that it can play. The EU must support NATO, not compete with it; foster national cooperation, not seek to replace it; and respect the indelible rights of governments to protect their citizens.

name: Michèle ALLIOT-MARIE
text: - Mr President, after having congratulated Mr Paşcu on his report, I will repeat your remarks, Mrs Mogherini. You told us that the next US administration might place more responsibility on our shoulders. You are quite right. You said that about relations between Israel and Palestine. I believe that is true in a much more general way, and in particular in matters of security and defense. This is in line with Mr. Trump's commitments, who ultimately advocates a certain withdrawal into itself by the United States and a disengagement, in any case, from the major conflict zones where the United States has worked a lot during these last years. It is also in the logic of what was also said by his predecessors. The only difference is that he risks putting it in place. It is also in line with its fiscal commitments. He will have to find the money, and I am convinced that this will be taken from American defense spending, which represents an extremely important budget, as you recalled. So to say as I have heard sometimes here that in the midst of the current crises which threaten us all, any European country, whatever it is, is able to protect itself - I do not even speak of protecting the others - , this is something totally wrong and totally irresponsible. We have, we, today - you recalled it - industries of a European defense, and I am not speaking of the fantasy of the European army - Arnaud Danjean very well said that it was not so . It is true that we have these instruments, but on one condition, that is that everyone actually participates in them. However, we see today that the European countries are making a per capita effort for their security and their defense, which goes from around 1 to 10. Do you think that we can effectively make a European defense while remaining in this? current system or will you entice and push some and others to make efforts that come together?

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President Czarnecki, thank you for the invitation in Spanish. I would like first of all to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Paşcu, on the excellent report, which opens precisely many questions but, at the same time, raises exciting issues; and, of course, to the High Representative, who is almost faster than this Parliament in areas so complex and so full of taboos, but so important for European defense and for Europe as such. Because Felipe González already said it: "Europe will not be Europe until it has a European defense policy." In this sense, I wish to tell you that, as a Spaniard and as a European, I know, unfortunately, that democracy sometimes has to be defended with arms. That is why it is even more important at this time that we in Europe take responsibility. However, I have three small - let's say - elements. One is financing - you have been told several times. We would like the funding not to come from somewhere else: from refugees, students or farmers or from cohesion. We therefore need a new, fresh defense budget. And that's where I address Mr Brok and Mr Gahler because in Germany, right now, they are talking about increasing the defense budget to 15%. And I understand that, from there, they should also be generous with the European sphere and open the doors and the possibility of the European budget, if it also has to cover the needs - and I think so - of defense European security has to be a bigger budget. And I also wanted to say that it is important that we take the military into account, even if there is still no talk of an army as such, but the Eurocorps is there. And finally the democratic control by this Parliament and the national parliaments.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Mr President, at a time when there are multiple threats facing Europe it is right for the EU to look at improving its level of intergovernmental cooperation in terms of the Common Security and Defence Policy. As ever, the proposals have been met by some in this House with false accusations that they amount to the creation of an EU army and a concerted effort to undermine the role of NATO. The CSDP has always been rooted in absolute respect for the Member States’ sovereignty in this key area of national policy, and on acknowledging NATO as the mainstay of European defence. The conclusions of the most recent Foreign Affairs Council uphold these key principles. Its support for strengthening Europe’s industrial defence base, eliminating duplication and waste in certain areas of procurement, and exploring the possibility of greater levels of integration militarily for those Member States willing to take such action under the Permanent Structured Cooperation (PESCO) mechanism is to be welcomed, and also respects the principles of sovereignty. The EU NAVFOR Atalanta mission stands out as a strong example of what cooperation at EU level can achieve. Bringing together Member States’ defence capabilities alongside the EU’s unique soft-power and hard-power capabilities, it was able comprehensively to defeat piracy in the Indian Ocean, and, most importantly, NATO welcomed this cooperation. It was, of course, commanded by the Royal Navy, based in my London constituency, but that is an aside. Ultimately, and this is the point I want to make to the High Representative today, the United Kingdom after Brexit must stay plugged into the CFSP and the CSDP. That would be my lifelong ambition post-Brexit.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: – Mr President, political developments in the last six months have compounded the challenges to European security and defence significantly. Some would argue that they have compounded these challenges to the degree that, today, the fundaments of the European security structures are called into question. I am not among those who would seek to raise false alarms, but there is much that we need to rethink. The reports tend in that direction, but with all the failures which have already been mentioned. We need, I believe, a robust military capability; we need substantial power projection capability; we need credible power in order to be able to engage in conflict prevention successfully. But – allow me to use another comparison on relative defence spending – we spend 2.5 times more per year on defence than Russia. Let me be blunt: I believe we need more efficient and coordinated spending, and not more money.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Paşcu on his report. It includes important objectives of this Parliament in matters of security and defense. As has already been pointed out in this debate, our security environment is progressively deteriorating. We are facing an unprecedented level of threats, including terrorism. The complex scenario in our neighboring eastern and southern regions, terrorism, instability in the Middle East, in the Sahel, possible changes, already mentioned, in the foreign and defense policy of the United States, should respond to advances in the European security and defense dimension, which, in addition, Brexit is likely to make less difficult. Those advances require ambition and realism. Ambition, which translates into a significant effort of political will, and realism, which involves being aware of the means available, as well as the current economic and budgetary difficulties. But the potentialities contained in the Treaties in matters of security and defense must be implemented. I am thinking, in particular, of permanent structured cooperation and also of the rest of the measures and possibilities detailed by the Council of Defense Ministers last week: from the inclusion of a research program in the next multiannual financial framework, to the reinforcement of the European Defense Agency, until the gradual development of the industrial and technological base of European defense. I conclude: I hope that NATO will continue to be a key pillar of our security structure, but we Europeans must do more of our part. As I have been repeating for a long time, soft power is not enough to face our current challenges and threats.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Mr President, Madam High Representative, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, dear Ioan, and thank you also for accepting changes in Article 48. The key phrase for me as a housekeeper is: Call on the Member States to provide the necessary additional financial resources. The budget is already underfunded, and I am telling you that as rapporteur for the EU budget for 2017. We were just able to finance the pilot project for cooperation between the arms industry, but not much is possible behind it. So let us be cautious about calling for additional measures if funding is not secured, or just asking for funding from the EU budget in general. Our aim must be to obtain additional financial resources from the Member States to finance the common security and defense policy under the next multiannual financial framework, because this budget does not give much more.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: -  Mister President!The last thing we need is a European army.NATO saved Western Europeans the fate of Eastern Europe, and it was NATO that ended the bloodshed in ex-Yugoslavia.If Putin soon realizes that, in the event of a defense, this Parliament must first be asked for permission whether the European army may intervene, then not only would the security of Eastern Europe be jeopardized.Of course, Trump cannot continue to expect his voters to bear the main financial burden of NATO.So we have to do three things.First, we need to make it clear who is the aggressor in Europe and who is not.Second, we must meet our defense financial commitments.And thirdly, we have to make it clear to Mr. Trump that NATO is also defending his own country.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, many thanks to Mr Paşcu for his excellent report. Very briefly to colleague Henkel: There is nothing in this report about a European army. We limit ourselves to what is possible with this contract and we say that clearly in this annual report. This is our contribution to the discussion about the CSDP. In principle, we support the most recent decisions of the Council of November 14, which is preparing the defense summit in December. But we cannot stop here. In view of the increasing imponderables on the other side of the Atlantic, the critical developments in southern and eastern Europe, we are not satisfied with the ambitious decisions of the Member States. Instead of glossing over the Member States' lack of ambition, I would ask this House to stick to our parliamentary demands. I would remind Mrs Mogherini that we are calling for an EU inventory of existing capabilities and a white paper on security and defense in order to move towards a European Defense Union and to combine strategic orientation with capability developments. Mrs Mogherini, please finally take the lead and convince the Member States of the need to activate permanent structured cooperation. Only a strong, united Europe can guarantee the security and defense of our citizens in the long term. The key to planned and coordinated military and armaments cooperation lies in this permanent structured cooperation. I ask you to ensure that the security and defense implementation plan is incorporated into a white paper process. In your role as Vice-President of the Commission and Head of the EDA, please ensure that existing resolutions from the European Defense Summits in 2013 and 2015 are passed by the Commission and EDA will also be implemented.Please spare us in the announced defense action plan of the Commission from just selling old decisions in a new guise.We now need an active commission to monitor the European internal market for defense equipment.We want clarity about the European design of security of supply - and EU-funded defense research.Letting go is not an option.If you lead, many Member States will follow you.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Mr. President, Honorable High Representative, I congratulate my rapporteur, my colleague Paşco, on his excellent report, as he has largely moved away from routinely recording weaknesses and vague messages when it comes to a common security and defense policy. The general assessment is that this dimension of the European Union's action has always been more preventive than defensive, remaining forever under construction and constantly unfinished, as well as the weakest element in the process of European integration. I also agree with the assessment that a large number of protracted regional crises and new asymmetric and hybrid threats today constitute a security context that imposes very serious challenges on the very stability of the European Union. We should also take into account the latest political developments such as Brexit or the results of the US presidential election. We must not allow our security to depend on political processes that are not in favor of strengthening the European community. In short, this is a time of challenge for the European Union on much of its 15,000-kilometer-long external borders, but also a period of serious re-examination within the European Union of how to give our citizens a sense of security. The answers of 2016 can only be common - European.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Mr. President, Madam High Commissioner, there are many countries, our members, who are afraid that by building a common European defense and security policy, they will lose their sovereignty.It is time for these myths to be dispelled, so there is no European army - that is what we are constantly talking about and we are compatible with NATO.This is what needs to be mentioned and what everyone needs to know.So we are not building any European army, there is no fear of that.But there is fear of Brexit, of Putin, of the new situation in the United States.In these new security conditions, we must strive to preserve our internal and external borders, and I therefore advocate interpreting Article 45 of our Treaty in a way that makes it equivalent to Article 5 of NATO on the principle of "One for all, all for one".That is the only way to really put Europe at the center, to start thinking about ourselves and to run our own security policy on our own.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as a convinced European federalist, I can only be happy that we are finally talking seriously about concrete steps towards a common European defense, as Parliament has been asking for many years. Of course, it took disruptive events such as Brexit, Trump's victory in the United States, the deterioration of security in the geopolitical theaters close to us, even the challenge of the refugee crisis, to show even more clearly that the Union cannot pursue. completely its external interests and work for peace, security, if it does not equip itself with precise tools. I am thinking in particular of the multinational forces, achievable thanks to permanent structured cooperation, which can be made available to the common security and defense policy, as is already foreseen by the Treaty of Lisbon. Perhaps the current global security framework pushes in this direction, and we have now reached greater agreement to fully implement the provisions of the treaty, towards a full revision of the common security and defense policy in cooperation and complementarity with NATO, to transform finally the European Union in a subject capable of assuming its responsibilities to guarantee the safety of its citizens, its neighborhood and the world.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - I join in congratulating my colleague Pascu and the shadow rapporteurs on a clear report.Clearly, soft power is not enough to enforce peace.That is why I have long supported a stronger defensive identity for the European Union, and I do not see the danger of duplication with NATO in this.However, our problem is not technical or organizational in nature.Our key challenge is political support for the defense strategy, which requires a comprehensive political strategy of the European Union, which can only help to implement the European defense strategy.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! Mr Rapporteur! I would like to thank you for the report and say that what unites the European Union is an increasingly scarce commodity. At the same time, about 80% of Europeans consider security to be an important problem, and this can bind us together, be the engine of integration going beyond the economic aspect. The security and defense challenges must be viewed broadly, and the key element is, of course, the harmonization and adjustment of various policies, including economic policies, as defense capabilities are a function of economic development: the better the economy, the better defense capabilities. It is therefore about the industrial policy of the Union, the policy of reindustrialisation, but also innovation and research, that is, everything that we have included in the Horizon 2020 program, as well as energy independence and cybersecurity. I would also like to draw your attention to the military aspect, border protection, and at the same time the Union-NATO relations, which were also confirmed by the declaration from Warsaw in summer 2016. This is also the element that should be emphasized here. Coordinating proposals, such as the global strategy of the European Union or the European Defense Union, which may replace the security and defense policy discussed today, are to be welcomed.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: - For the first time we see how softpower exceeds in effective influence hardpower. In the face of this new reality, both the Union and the Member States are unprepared and vulnerable. This report, together with the Commission's efforts, will increase the Union's capacity to act in this regard. Member States must engage in a profound and rapid rethinking of the common security and defense policy. This also means honoring the commitment to allocate 2% of GDP to defense. At this time, the Union cannot ensure the protection of citizens and institutions against manipulation or cyber attacks. We still need collaboration and complementarity with NATO. In the same register, the Transatlantic Partnership must be exploited, especially in the context of limited resources. More than ever, the Union must support the strengthening of the defense and research industry, and this must be reflected in the financial distribution for the remainder of the current multiannual financial framework. I want to congratulate Mr Paşcu and I support a positive vote and I hope that the indicated directions will become an institutional practice as soon as possible.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - I would like to point out that during this session we have some very good documents, important debates, important discussions on security.Yesterday, Mr. Urmas Paet, today Mr. Paşcu, in a moment - also crucial from the point of view of security - the report of Mrs. Anna Fotyga.There is one common denominator for all debates - they are critical, they critically assess the state of affairs, but this is the only good news, because all the recommendations in this House have, however, diverged individual political groups.The diagnosis of the left, right and middle part of the room is identical and consistent.On the other hand, the chances of getting out in order to make Europe safer, however, are not too much in these documents, because the room differs in terms of forecasts of the situation, readiness for specific defense spending.And this, unfortunately, worries me, I wanted to draw your attention to it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the security environment in Europe has significantly worsened in recent years, becoming more unstable and complex. Against this, the reaction of the Member States appears to be uncoordinated and fragmented, complicating and often hindering the adoption of a uniform approach. I support the introduction of coordination mechanisms, such as the creation of a permanent Union headquarters for civilian and military missions and operations, from which the entire planning cycle can be overseen, from the initial political concept to the detailed plans. However, all Council decisions concerning future missions and operations should prioritize intervention in conflicts that directly affect the security of the Union or the security of partners and regions in which it plays the role of security guard. The decision to intervene must be based on a common analysis and understanding of the strategic context, as well as on the strategic interests shared by member states, bearing in mind the actions of other allies and organizations such as the UN and NATO.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, interest in the European Union's common security and defense policy has been rekindled by the slap in the face of the Euro-Atlantic building with Brexit and the results of the US election. The objectives of this policy are to serve the invasive actions of some Member States of the Union in the Middle East and Africa. On the other hand, I do not see any common security and defense policy of the European Union against Turkey, which daily violates Greek sovereign rights in the Aegean and illegally holds 37% of the territory of Cyprus. Nor do we see any solidarity with Greece when Albania raises the issue of Tsamuria and threatens the property of the recognized Greek national minority of the Northern Epirus, as I have informed you in a letter sent to you, Mrs Mogherini. The common security and defense policy, then, is a fennel. The Greek people will not consent to any fenaki that aims to serve the invasive interests of the powerful of Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - I would first like to thank Mr Paşcu for his excellent report. Mrs Mogherini, I am very pleased with your concrete proposals and the steps forward you want to take in this European Defense Union and the drive with which you have defended them here today. What I don't understand, however, is why you don't want to go a step further. Personally, I really think there is momentum to take the leap, the leap to a European army, the leap to integrated forces. Why? We have Brexit, the election of Trump, the statements related to NATO, the budgetary constraints in the national armies. That is why I think we need to follow the Eurobarometer. In it, 75 percent of Europeans said: “We want European defense”. By the way, we commissioned a study in Belgium showing that 26 billion euros would be saved annually if we took the step towards European defense. Mrs Mogherini, you have my support. Use this momentum, jump that step further and ensure our security with a European defense.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - (PT) Mr President, the European Union pursues its immense intention of asserting itself as a military bloc, promoting its belligerent, militaristic and external interference. Submissive to NATO's strategy, defense budgets are reinforced, investment in research and military industry is increased, but imperialist ambition motivates the creation of a European army to carry out criminal war actions, such as those this parliament approved on Libya and how this parliament is preparing to approve on Syria. A policy of blood and death, of war and destruction, to which all those who promote and approve it are associated. A policy that fuels the arms race, not forgetting nuclear, increasing world tensions, contradicting commitments made with the Non-Proliferation and Disarmament Treaty - a policy that opposes and compromises peace, and that does not disconnect from the policies of exploitation and impoverishment of workers and peoples.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, Mr Paşcu remembers selectively. I point out to the rapporteur of the report that inaccuracies in the European Parliament report should not be mentioned. He owes it to him as an MEP and as a former Romanian Minister of Defense. In particular, the report states that for the first time since World War II, Europe's borders were forcibly changed, that is, in Ukraine, and underlines the international impact of the military occupation. I would therefore like to remind him of the illegal invasion of Turkey and the military occupation and settlement of 37% of the territory of Cyprus. A military occupation that continues despite the condemnation of all international organizations. Also the violent dissolution of Yugoslavia, the secession of Kosovo and more. Or is it skipping them, because Germany and America are involved? In order to restore truth and justice, the rapporteur of the report must include the above in his report, because, as it turns out, the common security and defense policy is a farce.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Mr President, High Representative, colleagues, I would like to begin by emphasizing that, due to the security situation at the EU's borders and the asymmetric threats within Europe, security and defense will be increasingly in the public spotlight. There is therefore a need for stronger action at the level of the EU institutions. Due to the nature of modern threats and challenges, security and defense are increasingly interacting with the economies of the Member States and will have a significant impact on the economy. It is therefore necessary to review, refine and align the EU's common security policy with the real situation and needs. After that, it is necessary to ensure the implementation of the common security and defense policy as soon as possible. It is necessary to adopt a strategy as soon as possible, to establish joint political and administrative bodies and permanent structural cooperation. It is very important to develop the capacities of the military industry, developing as much dual use technology as possible. It is important to keep in mind that the equipment of the security and defense forces of the EU member states is very diverse. Consequently, the abilities are also diverse. In some equipment cases, equipment incompatibility can still be determined. That is why it is necessary and important to work on smarter investment in the defense industry, and especially, as I have already pointed out, dual use technology where, for example, fleets protecting EU borders, including Croatia's on the Adriatic, can focus on equipping, search and rescue, for medical transport operations, prevention of marine pollution, and modular upgrades in a very short time can become combat fleets. No member state, including the strongest ones, can respond to security threats alone today, so we need to support the report, refinement and implementation of the common defense and security policy and action plan. The time ahead requires common well-designed and effective action, and ultimately and very importantly, action on time.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, the security situation in Europe and neighboring regions is becoming increasingly alarming, so it is clear to everyone that we must do more to protect our citizens and interests.Some see this as an opportunity to turn our backs on our transatlantic partners who, together with us, side by side, have been defending our common interests and values for decades.There were also great omissions due to which the lives of our soldiers and citizens were unnecessarily endangered, and our reputation in the world was damaged.One should not run away from failure, but face it.I am aware that some colleagues in Donald Trump’s election see an opportunity for the much-desired move away from America, but that is not the right path.The United States believed in a democratic Europe when it was in ruins.Let us also believe in our overseas partners and together with them build a better, more efficient and even more important NATO for world peace.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Mr President, in order to increase the security of the EU Member States, it will be necessary to diversify the forms of European defense cooperation in the future. This is true even if NATO's defense capability and resources as a military alliance are irreplaceable. At the same time, defense cooperation could contribute to the further development of full European integration, as it would expect cooperation and openness between Member States in one of the most sensitive areas. The development of the defense industry, cyber defense cooperation, joint defense research are opening up a whole new field for integration, and that is exactly what Europe needs today, which has cut so many fault lines. Building trust between Member States in this important area can benefit the EU as a whole. It is important to stress that military-industrial cooperation is for peace, as a continent that is unable to respond to the challenges of the age will be weak and vulnerable, and this can lead to internal tensions.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Mr President, we are facing new threats and challenges to our security. These are interconnected and no threats are isolated. The current Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) needs to reflect this change and to be responsive to the hybrid challenges the EU faces. Let us be honest: no Member State can deal with the current security challenges alone. Cooperation is extremely important. We need a pragmatic way forward. The Member States need to do more on the European defence front, which means not only that they commit verbally but that they honour their commitments with financial contributions as well. We should recall the need for a strong collective defence principle. We have a number of CSDP tools and instruments which need to be put to more effective use. We also need a concrete permanent structure like the EU headquarters for civilian and military operations. Following these principles, a synergic effect could be created, contributing to a more genuine CSDP. I would like to thank Mr Paşcu for a good, responsible report.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Mr President, I would like to point out that, as with the common foreign policy, there is a contradictory philosophy with the defense and security policy. On the one hand, Mrs Mogherini told us that we are not a defense agency; on the other hand, we are seeking to build defense capabilities. We want to increase the capabilities of the defense industry through research and production of powerful weapons systems. But we do not answer the question against which powerful enemy these means will be used. Also contradictory and confusing is the position we are taking after Britain's exit from the European Union, Brexit, but also the election of Trump in the United States. Trump has declared that he will try and succeed in cooperating with Russia. This will reduce the tensions and, possibly, the risk of a threat. So there is a contradiction here too. The only real danger facing the European Union is that which comes from international terrorism and the potential it can develop, such as cyber attacks. This risk can be addressed by the cooperation of the security and defense authorities of the countries of the European Union.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: - Mr President, the European Union should have done a lot more for its security a long time ago. This is the expectation of the majority of European citizens, as well as the expectations of our partners in the United States. We must not duplicate our capacity with that of NATO, but complement it. Total purchase of equipment, total investment in research and development in the defense sector, joint training of our servicemen, joint command, as well as general defense against hybrid attacks. These are concrete steps that need to be taken, and for the foreseeable future, Madam High Representative. If we really want to play a role in the world, not to be marginalized - we are 7% of the world's population, we have over 25% of the gross domestic product held by the European Union, and we distribute over 50% of all social goods so that we can to defend this, we must invest in our security, Mrs Mogherini, and I welcome what you have proposed. However, it must become a fact, and not just remain in words, which we have been hearing for decades on our continent. We need a common defense, a common security for European citizens.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I would also like to express my support for Commissioner Mogherini, because I view her activity very positively.I think that EU citizens expect us above all to give them a sense of security.This security concerns the protection of external borders, the sea, protection against terrorists and the spectrum of other terrorist or other security threats.I think we need to respond to this, and I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Paşcu, for the report presented, because I consider it to be balanced.We should strengthen the multiannual financial framework precisely in the budget for defense and security policy and, of course, in the budget for individual years.In this regard, I feel that we are on the right track, including today's approved report by my colleague, on security and defense policy.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, I think I can raise a point of order myself. I am entering my seventh hour in this hemicycle today. This is a very important debate so I am glad to hear everyone’s views, but if you take all the catch—the-eyes at the end and all those who come into the room speak, it is not fair – not only for me, because the President changes but I am here for seven hours in a row, but it is also not fair for the following debate, which is a very important one. I apologise, but this might mean that at a certain point in the next debate – which is very important, Mrs Fotyga’s report on EU strategic communication – it will obviously be squeezed a bit. I do not think this is fair to our way of working.  First, I would like to stress the fact that the report is excellent. The work we are doing on the common security and defence policy is not being done, because of the UK referendum. I understand that our friends from the UK might think that everything revolves around this, but the global strategy was prepared and presented during the previous year and presented just the day after the result of the referendum. It has been done and it is work we have to do because it is necessary for the security of our citizens, and, as long as the UK is in the European Union, this work will go on with the 28 all together. It also strikes me a bit that precisely those of our colleagues who have indicated that their country will be leaving the European Union are the ones who feel so strongly about the future of European defence cooperation. I also understand that some would like to stay plugged in – you will sort out amongst yourselves what you want to do in the future, and then we will discuss it together. But the European Union will certainly continue to implement the decisions we have already taken with the 28, as I said – and I am glad about that – on concrete ambitious steps to strengthen the common security and defence policy. It is not about the EU army, and it is not about duplication with NATO. NATO is perfectly happy with what we are doing, because this is also a way of strengthening NATO. We are working—hand—in—hand together. It is not about building new, big headquarters; it is about being effective with the instruments we could have tomorrow if the political will is put in place and the financial resources are dedicated. It is not necessarily about spending more; it is about spending smarter, because in times of budget constraints – and some of you mentioned this – the only way for Europeans to invest smartly in defence is by doing it together. So, as the European Union helps, supports and accompanies Member States in many fields to the advantage of European citizens, from agriculture to infrastructure (I don’t want to go into other issues here), we can do the same on defence and make it more effective, more constructive and easier for Member States to work effectively in defence. No Member State alone – some of you mentioned this – can face security challenges today if not in cooperation, and our security is interconnected. We have seen it in recent months and in the last year and a half. Whenever we face a serious security threat in one of our Member States, all European citizens can be targeted, so we have a collective responsibility to work on our security together.  The integrated approach – soft power and hard power together, the European way – is what will be done more and more, so it is not about choosing hard power versus soft power. The European Union is the only player in the world that can use both hard power and soft power instruments in an integrated manner. Again, NATO is the first to recognise that we have instruments that NATO, as a military alliance, does not have.  I will continue to work in a very committed way, together with Parliament, to advance this agenda in a very pragmatic, but also very ambitious, manner. For me, this is also a test of the Lisbon Treaty. Some say I have two hats, but I actually have three, and I will use the three of them in this work, with the support, I hope, of the European Parliament, as head of the European Defence Agency, Vice—President of the Commission for Commission competences on the industrial and research part of it, and certainly as High Representative and as Chair of the Council, both in the foreign affairs and defence ministers formations.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would say that whatever the High Representative says about the European army is not feasible; it is not on the radar. Whatever you would say, for instance about the headquarters, does not matter. Some people want to refer to this because this is the only way to attack. So I sometimes wonder whether we are really sending the right message. Well what kind of a message should we transmit, because the right one, the most explicit one, is not taken seriously? Mr Van Orden, who is a convinced pessimist with respect to European defence and will remain like that until the end, is somehow ignoring the fact that we also fought in Mali, for instance. In the future, Africa will probably be an area of responsibility where we will have to fight, so from this point of view I would not be so dismissive of this possibility.  Our friend from UKIP is trying to tell us, or to tell me as the author, what I did not say and is attacking me on that. Well, I am not a British citizen to be told the reasons why we should leave the European Union with lies, for instance that subversion is fought with European soldiers. It is not fought like that. Subversion is fought with the means there, that there are military who counter the propaganda which is used for subversion. That is a different story, but I would say that, from this point of view, many things have to be accepted as inevitable.  I am very glad that Mr Bütikofer, who has been my, shall we say...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: You have to come to the end Mr Paşcu.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: rapporteur. – Please allow me to conclude.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Sorry, we are running very late and I am asking you to finalise, Mr Paşcu. If you can finish in 20 seconds that is fine. (Interjection) No, it is not enough for me. I have a list here of how much time is given to each Group and to each MEP and we are running very late with the time. If my predecessor does not stick to the time that is not my fault. I try to adhere to the time that is given to each speaker. So you no longer wish to have the floor? OK. I will switch to German.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The deterioration of the European security environment, generated by the increase in the number of threats, whether conventional or hybrid, has led to an increase in the feeling of insecurity among European citizens. According to the 2016 Eurobarometer 85.1 survey, about two thirds of them want the EU to be more involved in security and defense policy issues. In this context, I believe that measures must be taken to enable both the more efficient use of existing CSDP instruments and the creation of new, relevant instruments that will enable the European Union to intervene in any type of crisis management action, starting with the prevention of and until their settlement. European foreign and security policy also needs to be unified, and there needs to be better cooperation and coordination between Member States. Only in this way, together with effective funding, will there be an increase in the effectiveness of the CSDP, as well as a strong collective defense. Last but not least, I think it is wrong to rely solely on US investment. The United States must be seen as a partner, not just as the sole provider of security and stability in various parts of the world, including Europe. These are the reasons why I welcome this initiative.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The European Union accentuates its militaristic escalation. All pretexts will do. The objective is to consolidate the EU as an imperialist political-military bloc. Defending a path of submission to NATO's strategy, voices are multiplying - from the right to social democracy - calling for strengthening defense budgets, increasing investment in research and the military industry. What is more: the creation of a European army is advocated, carrying out criminal war actions, such as the one that this Parliament endorsed over Libya, and as it is now preparing to do again in relation to Syria. In an irresponsible and criminal way. A policy of blood and death, aggression and interference, war and destruction, to which all those who promote and approve it are associated. A policy that fuels the arms race, not forgetting nuclear, increasing world tensions and contradicting commitments made with the non-proliferation and disarmament treaty. A policy that opposes and compromises Peace, and that does not disconnect from the policies of exploitation and impoverishment of workers and peoples. A policy that deserves our firm opposition and combat!

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. Chairman, Europe is in a unique position in terms of the number of conflicts and potential hot spots on our borders, well identified by the rapporteur. It goes without saying that in order to deal effectively with present and future threats - both external and internal - the defense capabilities of individual Member States must be strengthened. Intensifying cooperation also at the EU level may bring benefits, provided, however, that it is done in a complementary way to NATO, which is and will remain a fundamental pillar of European security. In this context, it is particularly surprising that the report requires greater strategic autonomy for the EU - it is hard to imagine that this would happen without prejudice to NATO. The most important task currently facing the countries that are also members of the EU and the North Atlantic Alliance is the full implementation of the provisions of the Warsaw Summit and the fulfillment of the demand for the level of 2% of GDP spent on defense. The EU must focus primarily on implementing the Warsaw Declaration on EU-NATO cooperation. This declaration should constitute the core of all activities related to the implementation of the European Global Strategy in the field of defense. Finally, we must not forget what is happening in the east and the material support for the Ukrainian army, which is actively resisting the hybrid war waged by Russia.

name: Soraya POST
text: in writing. – The ongoing and escalating militarisation of our policies and the ‘machoisation’ of our politics is quickly turning the geopolitical situation in Europe into a nightmare as vile as the current public discourse, only much more dangerous. Our already very unstable geopolitical situation will not be improved by sabre-rattling where everyone plays follow-the-leader.  As we in Europe would most probably find ourselves, literally speaking, in the line of fire, should a major conflict break out involving Russia, we ought to tread very lightly now that the fundamentals of our security structure is in shatters. The military escalation between Russia and NATO on the former’s borders is a historically well-known recipe for disaster. Instead of directing our scarce resources towards military defence and cooperation with NATO, Europe should focus on de-escalation, diplomacy and dialogue and empowering democrats in the European neighbourhood with whom we can forge new alliances for peace and true stability.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - I agree with the need for an effective security and defense policy. Until now, the EU has dealt mainly with economic affairs, opening the common market for goods and the movement of people. Now it is equally important to ensure security, especially the fight against terrorism and reducing the scale of illegal immigration. Putting security and defense issues higher among the EU's priorities also forces individual member states to increase defense funds. Military spending in Europe has been reduced over the past 30 years and today it averages 1.4% of GDP. This long-term underinvestment has severely reduced the defense capabilities of individual states and of the Union as a whole. Therefore, not only NATO, but also the EU should put pressure on states to increase defense spending to 2% of GDP. Only these additional funds would create opportunities for the technical modernization of the army, improving cooperation and gaining new capabilities, e.g. to fight in cyberspace. Due to the deteriorating security situation around Europe, we should analyze the actual situation in the field of defense capabilities of individual states throughout the EU more often in the EP.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Anna Elżbieta Fotyga, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the EU's strategic communication to counter third party propaganda (2016/2030 (INI)) (A8–0290 /2016).

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, it is my pleasure and privilege to present the report on the EU’s strategic communication to counteract the propaganda against it by third parties. I consider it a matter of the utmost importance that Parliament expresses its stance on an issue so pertinent and timely. Allow me first to strike a very personal note, because this issue is also important for me personally. My whole public life – a large part of it under communist rule and afterwards – has been dedicated to countering the narrative exerted first by the Soviet Union and then by the Russian Federation of its special traditional sphere of influence. I always considered it very dangerous for our joint sovereignty because this same issue refers to many nations of Central and Eastern Europe, so I am very privileged to present it here today before Parliament. I also have very personal experience in observing, with my own eyes, the rise of radical Islamism throughout the years. It was very important for me to monitor the elections in Lebanon in 2005 after the assassination of Rafic Hariri and to see the influence of StratCom at that time. We have, of course, now seen many transformations of the strategic communications and propaganda in these countries. The assignment from the enlarged Bureau of the Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) was very clear. I was given the task of describing the hostile propaganda from both state and non-state actors. It was decided that I present in my report, together with my co—workers and experts and after consideration and joint elaboration with excellent shadow rapporteurs from the political groups, the view of two directions from which we are facing hostile propaganda. In terms of the Russian Federation, the situation is somewhat clearer now, because, after the the annexation of Crimea and the aggression by the Russian Federation in the eastern part of Ukraine, many countries in the Western world – Western democracies – are fully aware of the proceedings of disinformation, manipulation and propaganda.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission. –Thank you, Madam President. Last week, the Oxford Dictionary named ‘post-truth’ the word of the year 2016. ‘Post-truth’ describes a situation – and I quote from the dictionary – ‘where objective facts are less influential in shaping public opinion than appeals to emotion and personal belief’. This phenomenon has always existed, for sure, but it has become even more relevant in the age of internet. We know that the quality of the information is not always what makes content go viral. Social media and search engines tend to promote contents that confirm the user’s views instead of challenging them, and we all understand how relevant this can be in political terms, including for our European Union. So I am glad that the report we discussed today has given this Parliament the opportunity to reflect on such a delicate and crucial issue, where not only security has to be taken into account, but also everyone’s freedom of expression. As the report states, exposing this information is an important task and I am glad that the report commends the work carried out by our East Stratcom Task Force. It is clear from the Task Force’s work that the challenge coming from this information is not receding. Let me thank the Parliament for its close interest and support for the work we have been doing with the Task Force over the past year, as well the Member States who have contributed to the team. I can only welcome the proposal that this Parliament this advanced to strengthen both our East and South Task Forces on strategic communication. As I mentioned, both of them – Stratcom East and South. Let me stress that our work on this information is very different and depends on a case-by-case scenario. This information can be contrasted with fact-checking and rational arguments. The propaganda of terrorist groups, like Daesh, needs instead to be confronted first and foremost by taking down illegal content from the internet. To address the issue of the accessibility of terrorist materials, the Commission has established an Internet Referral Unit at Europol that actively scans for terrorist content online and refers it to the internet companies. So far we are still in the initial phase; we have referred over 15 000 pages, and in 90% of cases the material has been removed. Yet we know that this part of our work, however crucial, cannot be enough. What matters even more is to explain what the European Union is doing and how it is making a real and positive difference to the lives of so many people inside and outside the European Union. Now the report tackles with the issue of propaganda by third parties, but let me say that this is an issue that would be interesting to see inside the European Union, starting maybe from this very Hemicycle. We need to give voice to the people who have benefited from our policies, amplify the positive stories, simplify the messages and talk about real life. The truth – to the East, to the South and inside our Union – is that this positive added value of the European Union has to be more visible. This is why we have put public diplomacy among the key areas of implementation of our global strategy. So the East Stratcom Task Force is doing this, providing expert guidance to our delegations; working closely with governments in the Eastern Partnership Region and with the Commission; reaching out to a Russian-speaking audience that want better access to information about the European Union in real time in Russia and from a source they can trust. Similarly, the Task Force South is addressing Arabic-speaking communities in North Africa and in the Middle East together with our delegations. In particular, it is engaging with young people, working closely with the Anna Lindh Foundation, talking to the youth of the region, but also listening to their concerns and their aspirations. Last but not least, we need to engage with civil society, young leaders, independent journalists and NGOs – credible voices that often lack the skills or the financial resources and sometimes the space – the freedom – to express themselves. So our policies are also aimed at improving media plurality, both to the East and to the South, helping journalists get the training, the networks and the quality information they need to do their jobs. Our new young Mediterranean voices, for instance, will twin young journalist with more senior professionals and reach out to the media industry.  So to conclude, in this post-truth era, the European Union must stick to objective facts and at the same time appeal to emotions, personal beliefs and motivations. We have so many stories to tell that are positive. Stories of reform against corruption or innovative start-ups, stories of reconciliation or economic growth, and the future of our Union will also depend on our capacity to tell these stories, explaining the facts and reviving the passion for our European project. We can start in this Parliament.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Disinformation and propaganda is as old as war conflicts as wars. Hybrid wars and conflicts, on the other hand, as well as what is happening with terrorism, have only exposed the destructiveness of disinformation. Unfortunately, Europe is weaker in this matter. Europe must not respond to disinformation with disinformation, it must respond with information, it must respond by promoting and promoting these values ​​and information that is important to us. On behalf of the Committee on Culture, we tabled a number of complementary amendments that were adopted, for which I would like to thank. They mainly concerned strengthening independent media that operate outside of Europe, carrying out activities that are decidedly long-term rather than short-term, appreciating the importance of information and promoting it, as well as everything related to social media. This is an important report by Mrs Anna Fotyga, a report that has aroused positive reactions, and we should thank you for that.

name: Traian UNGUREANU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - This report is a warning that comes in time. The battle for people's minds and souls is no longer an open debate, but a dirty war well funded and technologically advanced. It is the rapporteur's merit, Mrs Fotyga, that she addressed this urgent and delicate issue before the effects of hostile propaganda became irreversible. Russia and ISIS are investing heavily in this campaign, which aims to instill fear, discredit the EU and compromise the democratic idea. What can the EU do? The report proposes solutions with precise reference to the European External Action Service and the Eastern Partnership states. There are, however, things that cannot be legislated. In their absence, hostile propaganda thrives. That means we can't defeat propaganda through propaganda. We can only overcome it by truth. Our politicians must have the courage to give up clichés. The media, which recently lost credibility in the US elections, must return to solid news journalism, otherwise public distrust will increase and propaganda will find enough room for maneuver. Adopting this report is a step forward. Critical thinking, honest education and the courage of politicians must be the next steps.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Madam President, I would like to express my sympathy to the High Representative for the ordeal that she has to go through down there. I will speak in German now. - The new media environment, which is no longer so new, ammunitioning the opponents of democracy and freedom of the press. These activities are clearly visible throughout the Western world: through spreading lies, falsehoods, or manipulating opinions. Of course, there is not just one country that uses these methods. We have just seen this during the election campaign in the USA during these weeks. We see this daily in the reports of the Turkish media loyal to the government. Yet this report focuses on one country, Russia. What I find even more worrying: Despite our fierce resistance, it also includes IS. It certainly uses similar methods, but of course it is not a state, and that is where the big problem lies. Contrary to the well-founded thesis of the EU and many other states, a terrorist organization is raised to the same level as a state.
