Something that we have been expressly preventing for years, namely viewing ISIS as a state, is being wiped away as a secondary issue in this report. We have crossed a red line. ISIS or IS or Da‘esch is not a state and should never be treated as such. It is undisputed that Russia, by spreading falsehoods, nurturing doubts and many other questionable media activities, both tries to divide the member states and drives a wedge between Europe and the US. We were of the opinion that there are other countries that could have been included in this report, if only to achieve a greater balance. That and the undeniable problem of including the IS here has led to that we will not be able to approve this report tomorrow, but will abstain.At the same time ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - I receive the newsletters from the East StratCom Task Force of the EU in my mailbox twice a week and when you read them do you realize to what extent and in what sophisticated way our open society is the target of a policy of damaging the Kremlin . The goal: to question our democratic values, divide Europe and find as much support as possible for it. All too often I see with sorrow how the disinformation from the Kremlin also seeps through social networks and other channels in our low countries. Responding to that information war is critical to our security. The strategic communication task force succeeded in pointing out the disinformation with a limited team of people and answering it with correct information. Mr Fotyga's report rightly argues for the task force to be strengthened, because in my opinion we must also understand and tackle the disinformation and radicalization methods of IS. My government already started a project on countering IS propaganda last year. A high-performance StratCom Task Force for the south can certainly arm us better in this regard.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, 6 000 EU citizens recruited by, and fighting for, Daesh means that targeted propaganda focused on a particular individual proves more than successful. Equally successful, the Kremlin’s propaganda operates in a different way: it tries to reach out to as many people as possible, with as many different stories. It is in the Kremlin’s playbook to deconstruct the truth and to spread the lies around widely – an approach first tested by the Kremlin on its own people, citizens of Russia. It was proven back in Soviet times that the moment the TV set wins over the fridge the regime can start feeling quite secure. To build on that further, however, it has to start gaining minds outside. The EU, the West, and our values have been chosen as a strategic target. Suddenly, Europeans who are used to information being free and based on facts become consumers of fake information and lies. The challenge is how to explain to Europeans that stories such as those of the crucified boy in Ukraine or the girl named Lisa kidnapped and raped in Germany have nothing to do with reality. I am more than convinced that setting up the East StratCom Task Force within the European External Action Service was the right and timely response to those massive campaigns of anti-EU propaganda. I must highly commend the East StratCom Task Force team: it is extremely professional and is doing a great job. However, as we initiate a proposal to increase the budget allocation to that team, I would ask the High Representative’s office to ensure that sufficient resources are made available to guarantee that the East StratCom Task Force delivers more in operational costs than is already covered in the 2017 budget.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, this is an insane report that fuels anti-Russian paranoia and the European neo-Machartist virus: the worst cartoon of the Cold War. Looking at reality with these delusional glasses awakens the European Union, even more so, in the geostrategic field. It is a dangerous report, it goes towards confrontation and it is an attack on freedom of information. Putting a terrorist group like Daesh on the same level, which in its videos carries out killings and torture live, with a country that is a member of the Security Council and other multilateral organizations, which is also a neighbor with whom we have exchanges of all kinds , is an insult to the intelligence of Europeans. To approach journalism from a military perspective with the nonsense of hybrid warfare is very dangerous for the freedom of diverse information and for the safety of journalists. Calling for the creation of pro-European propaganda media, calling them independent, must be a joke in itself. To ignore the related propaganda, such as the one developed by all the great American press in the Iraq lie, is, to say the least, suspicious. And finally, deciding what we Europeans should see, blacklisting supposedly propaganda media, is an attack on the freedom of information that citizens have. I'll watch Russia Today and watch Fox. And you won't stop me.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! Colleague, nobody is stopping you, you have spoken. A preliminary remark on the report and its structure: The report in no way equates ISIS with the Russian state. The report deals with two challenges posed by propaganda and therefore has two differently structured chapters. So the challenge posed by Russian propaganda and the challenge posed by what IS is doing on the internet are handled completely separately. Second, I believe that it is high time the European Parliament really looked at the challenges of the war for information and came to good and wise conclusions. I think that is very correct, especially after we were able to observe again in the United States during the election campaign or earlier in the Brexit campaign how propaganda influences and how propaganda aims to weaken connections within the European Union. My group and I are convinced that the main messages of the report are very good, namely that we need to recognize propaganda, that we need to recognize lies, that we need to recognize systematic spread of lies. Stratcom is good for Ms. Mogherini's. But it is not strong enough to do what it has to do. That needs to be discussed. We don't want to deal with the lies with our own propaganda, but rather we want to promote quality and independent journalism in order to provide information and clarification against propaganda.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, after decades of relative peace in Europe – with the exception of the Yugoslavian civil war – this report is worryingly reminiscent of the Cold War. The breakdown in relations between the West and Russia, of which both parties are guilty, has produced far more insecurity in Europe; we know that. Diplomacy and deterrents are delicate mechanisms. When used correctly, they help guarantee security for our citizens, but when it goes wrong there is hell to pay. Escalation can spiral out of control and lead us to places that, I trust, nobody in this Chamber wishes to go. You have to stop your neo-colonialism and your justifications for more European Union and remember the hard-learned lessons of the Cold War – careful deterrents, sophisticated diplomacy, and cooperation where possible.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report is a joke! Yes, a farce! Russian communication, which is based on the reality of the facts of our foreign policy, the lie in Iraq, the action outside the United Nations mandate in Libya, the destruction of the Syrian state with also the coup d'état in Ukraine and the extension of NATO against the word given with this logic of union without borders, becomes propaganda. The false European propaganda denounced by the European and even American peoples, on the other hand, is becoming the truth. It is also a farce with regard to democracy and the law. The facts are external propaganda according to good Bolshevik logic. Just as dissidents were once American agents, now they are Russian agents. The parallel between Russia and Daesh, moreover, is a stupid provocation, a shame! But this farce will turn into a tragedy by your vote. This denial of reality by your propaganda destroys all legitimacy in your assembly.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). - Madam President, the report "EU Communication Strategy for Countering Propaganda against Third Parties", a delusion of the most vulgar anti-communism, literally a gift to the Nazi criminals, is a monument and proof of the reaction of the Union and the European Parliament, which, distorting history, equates fascism with communism. It does not target the Islamic State, which is supported by the United States, NATO and the European Union. Under the pretext of competing with capitalist Russia, you bring out something you claim to have won definitively, but - justifiably - you are still afraid of: the ghost of communism, of work, of education, of health, of social rights for all. By distorting the notion of "radicalization", you are proposing networks of traitors, targeting them as agents and putting up against the wall millions of unemployed and poor people who are challenging the European Union, its bourgeois governments and their system. You call for the restriction of democratic rights and freedoms by criminalizing thought, speech and political action. You are poisoning the youth in schools, in culture, with media funded and controlled by the Union. Rest assured: whatever you do, the future of humanity is not the rot of your system, but its overthrow.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, this report was drawn up on the initiative of the PPE Group and we are very happy because Mrs Fotyga, who had the report on behalf of the Conservative Group, did very well. Discussing now this counter-propaganda that we all have in sight, except the extremes, left and right, is important because we are at a time when many voices are talking about a normalization of relations with Russia. This idea of ​​normalization is quite out of place when we see what is happening in reality: the manipulation of the media by the Russians, the blackmail with the energy charter and the illicit financing of organizations and political parties, including in this Parliament. In the face of Russian propaganda, we need a clear strategy, but also more money for the action plan on strategic communication. The Foreign Affairs Committee has also approved, for next year's budget, the provision of additional resources for the implementation of this plan. It's also important to understand the importance of freedom of the press, because what the Russians don't like, what our extremists don't like, is freedom. They want coercion, they love Putin's dictatorship and they are fascinated by this control from a strong man. Therefore, the real answer to these people, to Putin and his friends on the left and the right, here at extremes, is freedom, that is the word.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: - Madam President, we have just heard how Russian propaganda works in this House. It is strong evidence. Allow me now to speak in Romanian. Russian propaganda and Daesh propaganda are obviously different in working methods, but the goals are both toxic and, I would say, deadly, for the European project first and foremost. In Ukraine, Russian propaganda covered and justified the occupation of Crimea, used large-scale cyber attacks, and finally sought to divide positions among EU member states. For those wondering if Russian propaganda is real or not, I invite them to read a famous book, La France russe, published by a highly respected journalist from Le Monde, and to listen to the German Secret Service chief's assessment of the risk be adversely affected by Russian intervention. I have two proposals, Madam President, ten seconds. I think we need to practice identification ... (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Yana TOOM
text: - Ladies and gentlemen. I was born and educated in the Soviet Union, and reading this resolution and listening to some of the speeches, I was struck by the thought of being acquainted in advance. Have we really played ourselves in the corner where we introduce the rhetoric of the totalitarian regime? Are we really in favor of censorship? Are we contributing to the production of anonymous authors, which in journalism is the same propaganda that it is fighting? And are we really, being sane, putting an equal sign between the Kremlin and ISIS? A month ago, in my home country, Estonia, the last two Russian-language pages were closed by the big owner, which means that their readership is moving smoothly into the orbit of the Russian media, and today's or tomorrow's vote will not change that. In the Committee on Culture, we took a constructive approach to the issue of solving the problems of journalists, but the document that is on the table today is aimed more at focusing on propaganda or counter-propaganda. It's a dead end. In a democratic world, politicians do not direct the media, even for a sacred purpose, let us think about it.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the great respect of anyone who cares about freedom and history and the cult of history for the sacrifice of those who, as the rapporteur reminded us, fought for freedom and against the tentacles of communism international at the time of the Cold War, however, it must not prevent us from realizing something anomalous in this relationship, which unexpectedly puts propaganda on the same level - because there is certainly propaganda from the Russian Federation - and the activities of Daesh. So, if anything, two very distinct reports had to be made, in which to talk about one thing - and we would have voted for it - that is, the danger of Islamic propaganda that is everywhere (with the consent of those who have always minimized the danger of mosques and who now suddenly they realize it). As for the invitations to consider this report as a report that defends our freedoms, I wonder why, from this Parliament, those gentlemen are not asking us to check the propaganda of the large multinationals, banks and lobbies, which are masters in this Parliament and that every day they make propaganda against the interests of our people.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Madam President, I would like to praise Vice—President Mogherini for the great work done by the small team East StratCom in the External Action Service. I would also like to praise Ms Fotyga for her excellent report. I believe that the very small amount of money spent on the work of the team is some of the most efficiently used in the EU budget. However, the strategic communication efforts remain seriously underfunded and understaffed. Countering the hybrid information operations is critical for preserving our democracies, and indeed our Union. I therefore call on Vice—President Mogherini immediately and significantly to increase the resources allocated to this task, particularly to the task of countering the billions of propaganda dollars spent by Putin’s agencies.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Madam President. Dear colleagues! So far, I think that the European Union has a firm moral position that propaganda can be fought with facts and objectivity. When I saw this report, I realized that I was wrong. That's what real propaganda looks like! In one report, the amalgamation of a terrorist organization with a particular country is a vivid propaganda technique. The main goal is clear - to show that Russia and Daesh are almost the same. Another method of propaganda is to show that there are problems in only one country. With the exception of Daesh and Russia, no other example is mentioned, although the title of the report refers to third parties. Does this mean that no one in the world is using propaganda anymore? I very much doubt it. Consequently, this report cannot be described as objective and comprehensive. We are being offered a low-quality propaganda product that, if adopted, will discredit the European Union. And if Parliament votes in favor, then in the next report among those who use propaganda, we can certainly mention the European Union.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in recent years we have seen, unfortunately, aggressive attempts to call into question the democratic foundations of the European Union and to undermine our political unity. Manipulations, half-truths, outright lies are spreading. The Internet, social media and media trolls, information and more precisely disinformation agencies are used, which constantly instill hatred towards the EU. I will give two examples from my side. At the beginning of the year, several sites, part of the hybrid war against the EU, and there are dozens of them in my country, spread the information that the European Court has banned and declared the baptism of children in church a crime. This week, the report we are currently discussing has given rise to a new attack on the European Union, with such media claiming that the European Parliament is preparing a last-minute secret amendment to the report to ban Orthodoxy. These are two classic examples of hybrid information warfare and show why the European Union must counter propaganda, and today's debate is absolutely timely and necessary. I am very sorry to hear from my colleagues in the European Socialists and Democrats that they will abstain. If we are not united on this issue, we will not be effective. The most sinister encroachments on media freedom and religious freedom in Eastern Europe were carried out precisely by the communist regimes, which tried to impose communism as the state religion, following the Kremlin's instructions. The European institutions need to monitor and analyze disinformation campaigns against the EU. I therefore welcome the East StratCom Task Force within the European External Action Service (EEAS) to analyze and oppose anti-EU propaganda and disinformation. Report… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: – (begining of the speech without microphone) ... and honest about is that there will be no successful EU global strategy and European Neighbourhood Policy if we do not have a credible and effective EU strategic communication. If we look at the Russian disinformation warfare in the Eastern Partnership countries – and not only those countries – I think we have sufficient reasons to feel nervous, and if you want to see how propaganda has already translated into political gain, just have a look at the presidential elections in the Republic of Moldova. I believe that we must first address the visibility of what the EU does. If we do not explain our work and our achievements, we only provide fertile ground for propaganda. Less visible means more vulnerable. Second, we need to work on the framework and the legal deficits that allow propaganda to flourish. This means added funding to support media freedom and pluralism. Third, we must ourselves counterbalance disinformation with impartial and objective information. For this, we need a stronger and reinforced EU Strategic Communication Task Force.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - We're at war.We are at war with the Russian Federation.We do not realize that the word can be stronger than missile systems or Su-25 fighters.It is a hybrid war that the Kremlin is waging against us, against the EU.It is a war in which the Kremlin is winning.Anna Fotyga decided to take a strong defensive stance against Russian enemy propaganda.Her report makes it clear that Russia's strategic communication is part of a subversive campaign.I would like to warn you, Commissioner, that your defense in this information war is weak and ineffective, and not only that, I think it is also punishably underfunded.How do you, Commissioner, want to resist your tiny team of the millions of dollars that the Russian secret services fund agencies such as Russia Today or Sputnik?Let us recover, ladies and gentlemen, losing this information war marks the beginning of the end of the EU.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, I am happy that Madam Mogherini started her speech with an idea from my draft, namely the ‘post-truth era’, where the line between what is false and what is true is being deliberately blurred. This report brings home the alarming fact that, parallel to Daesh, the Russian leadership is engaged in a full-scale disinformation and propaganda war to undermine the EU democratic narrative and to separate Europe from its main democratic ally. And may I say that the irritation shown in this Hemicycle by the far left and far right is proving that Madam Mogherini’s message has reached its targets. It is working. The EU, its institutions and Member States now need to recognise that information warfare is in full swing and requires immediate widespread and comprehensive reforms, and I would like also to support the idea that East StratCom needs a serious boost in its financing and role.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: (The President speaks without a microphone) ...... more speakers on the catch-the-eye list than I can take based on the advanced time.I will let one person speak from every group where someone has spoken.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: – Madam President, tonight we are discussing how vulnerable democracies are – or could be – in the age of networks and networking, freedom of speech and the right to information. This is a timely and extremely important report, Ms Fotyga; thank you very much. According to many experts, the Baltic States are expected to be the next hotspot for Russian information warfare. We, in the Baltics, have a substantial Russian media presence that has long targeted Russian-speaking audiences with false narratives and propaganda. Simultaneously, this propaganda tends to stoke anxiety among Lithuanian audiences over the country’s perceived security and economic weaknesses. Finally, the work of StratCom is of high value, and cooperation among Member States’ intelligence services should be enhanced, though it should not mean that the autonomy of national intelligence services is lost.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, as a member of the Culture and Education Committee, I believe that support for independent media and promotion of the freedom of the press, recognising the role of education and media literacy and the need for putting in place a strategic cultural diplomacy platform at EU level must be the pillars of EU actions aiming at countering propaganda. Supporting freedom of press and independent media must, in my view, include actions of support for imprisoned and persecuted journalists and human rights activists. On top of promoting media literacy and critical thinking, which are really the keys to many of the challenges we are facing, we need further regulation of hate speech online, including a greater collaboration with online platforms and social media. Finally – and most importantly for me – I want to emphasise further the role of intercultural dialogue, people-to-people contacts and encouraging the EU communication strategy to include local populations and civil society.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, my colleague Fotyga has brilliantly recognized all forms of propaganda war being waged against Europe and the West in general.Today, it is easier than ever to place fake news or distorted information that then travels the world in a matter of seconds and attracts the attention of millions of people.I fear that there is no universal cure that, in this time of information technology boom, will be able to effectively suppress hostile propaganda.The surest step in the right direction is certainly to increase the transparency of the European institutions and governments of the Member States, open partnerships between members without a fig in their pockets and making decisions important to the lives of citizens as close to them as possible.Propaganda against Europe and the West is falling on fertile ground as citizens have less and less trust in those who lead them and make important decisions for them.Rebuilding that trust is the most effective way to fight propaganda.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - As so many times in the past, we do not pay attention to the essentials at all. The problem, after all, is that EU citizens have less and more confidence in the European institutions, because they do not think that the European project benefits them. They often solve very complex personal and family socio-economic problems and yes, they are therefore prone to anti-European sentiments. So what to deal with rather than propaganda? How to really help our citizens. How about trying to involve them more in the decision-making process, reflecting on their topics and concerns? In recent years, we have only shown them that the rich are getting richer and that the Presidents of the Commission have luxury in business after leaving the EU's top positions. Citizens do not want such a Europe. We do not give them the alternative they are so desperately calling for. One last thing, let's trust people. They know what they are reading and they know how to work with it. People are not stupid, stupid are those who deal with topics that will definitely not help them in life.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: – Thank you Madam President. In my opinion, all red lines are crossed in the texts under discussion here. The enormous number of resolutions adopted by this Parliament critical of Russia and the Russian people has remained in my memory. But a resolution so offensive in both form and content is a new development for the European Parliament. The very principle of freedom of expression and information is challenged in this resolution. Russia is accused of – and I quote – ‘aggressively employing a wide range of tools and instruments, such as think tanks and special foundations [...], special authorities [...] multilingual TV stations [...]’ – end of quote. But every state has its think tanks, special foundations, special authorities dealing with compatriots living abroad, and its TV stations. It is impossible to understand what happens if you watch only channels like CNN, BBC, Euronews, TDF and France24. For example, the coverage by those channels of events in Aleppo and Mosul is based on evident double standards, so the Russia Today channel effectively contributes to the principle of media pluralism.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, propaganda is an activity that has its roots in antiquity and is still practiced today. Its principles and goals are still valid today. But in this day and age, when the world has great access to the media, we must be very careful in dealing with any hostile propaganda. The European Union must tell its people the truth. It is not possible to put Russian and ISIS propaganda on the same level and wait for this to be accepted by the world. It is not possible to target groups or political parties in different countries and expect not to be accused of being undemocratic. No matter how much money we give, no matter how much effort we put in, no matter how many journalists we hire, we will not be able to do anything if we do not first pass on, above all, to the young people the principles on which the European Union is based, so that we are invulnerable to ISIS propaganda.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like, also on behalf of High Representative and Vice-President Mogherini, to thank this House again for its support. We are all in the process of developing our capacity to communicate in a more strategic and more focused way. To do this we need to work together across all institutions and in partnership with Member States so that our messaging on what we are doing within the European Union and externally strikes a deeper resonance.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, in the course of its preparation this report was also the target of hostile propaganda. I would like to thank Madam Mogherini and the whole team of East StratCom for their work in this respect, as well as the European Endowment for Democracy and the secretariat of the Committee on Foreign Affairs for their contributions. Last, but absolutely not least, I wish to thank my personal co-workers and excellent shadow rapporteurs for their contributions and ability to strike a consensus, making a very valuable contribution to this report.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 23 November 2016.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- Ms. Fotyga's report on ISIS and Russian propaganda against the EU is counterproductive material.It is inadmissible to equate ISIS and Russia regardless of the topic.There is no doubt that both ISIS and Russia use many propaganda channels to harm the EU, Member States and individuals, but to equate them in this situation as well is politically completely unacceptable.In addition, our relations with ISIS and Russia must be completely different.ISIS is a terrorist creation that threatens a large part of humanity and directly affects many negative phenomena in the world and in the EU itself.They cruelly manage the so-calledIslamic State and encourage terrorism in Europe.On the other hand, Russia is a permanent member of the UN Security Council and with enormous influence and strength that everyone respects.I insist that the current EU-Russia relations should be changed and built on partnership and cooperation in our mutual interest.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - This report is nothing more than an element of deepening the reactionary and anti-democratic character of the European Union. Starting from the values ​​it claims to defend, it extends its scope to the freedoms of communication, information and expression, values ​​that the European Union's policies contradict and compromise, of which the humanitarian refugee crisis is the most crass example. There would be many examples and, for the rest, you wouldn't even have to leave this house to give them. This is followed by a victimization strategy which is not lacking in retrograde and breathtaking anti-communist rhetoric. The EU is the victim of a powerful media offensive, it is said, compromising its integrity - arguments used to move towards the limitation and more control of the media, the Internet, school programs and even political parties. The EU's information is made absolutely true, distinguishing between propaganda and criticism, marking what is acceptable criticism. Thus, the doors of censorship are opened, which so many black pages wrote on European soil. Practices worthy of authoritarian and dictatorial regimes.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The EU needs a clear information policy. It already disposes of huge soft power. Otherwise, why would irregular immigrants and refugees wish to reach its territories to live and find refuge there? The European Union is now finding that its presence, policies and achievements are being countered by manipulative propaganda programmes. However, the best way to counter them is not by developing similar mechanisms, even if we wrap them in highly virtuous declarations of intent. Even less should they be meant to contain the aims of this or that power, no matter how antagonistic it may seem to have become. This is especially so given the fact that the EU’s soft power is still very effective.  What we need is a sober assessment of the current scope and reach of the EU’s soft power, not least in its impact on societies outside the EU, and in whether it is projecting distorted images of the European reality. Secondly we need a revamp carried out in good faith of the EU’s information and dissemination policies that projects a no-holds-barred view of the European reality, both for internal and external consumption. This report does not provide adequate basis for such an exercise.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on the introduction of a skills guarantee by Thomas Handel on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (O-000133/2016 - B8-1808 / 2016) (2016 /2799 (RSP)).

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: deputising for the author. – Madam President, in an increasingly digitalised world, less—qualified persons have reduced employment opportunities, are more vulnerable to long—term unemployment and have more difficulties in participating fully in society. According to the OECD, having a high proportion of adults with low proficiency in basic and digital skills is linked with lower levels of productivity and lower prospects for growth and competitiveness. This is detrimental to the individuals concerned and also costly to the economy and society as a whole. Nevertheless, the development of new ways of working and future—oriented sectors has a key role in relation to the types of skills needed. Skills mismatches and skills shortages can negatively affect not only productivity and growth but also the social situation within and across Member States. The Commission proposal recommended that Member States build on existing initiatives or policies and set up a Skills Guarantee, allowing those who have left the education system without completing upper secondary education or equivalent, and who are not eligible for support under the Youth Guarantee, to access upskilling pathways. Against this background, I have a number of questions for the Commission. The Commission calls on Member States to draw up, within one year of the adoption of the proposal, an action plan for implementation. Has the Commission proposed a mechanism or a body to support them in the preparation and monitoring of this plan? Various stakeholders should be associated in the preparation of the plan: how will Member States be encouraged to involve civil society, education providers, trade unions, employers, businesses and industry in the decision—making process? Does the Commission believe it is possible to cover this initiative without additional funding? The use of different EU funds, like the European Social Fund and Erasmus Plus, has been mentioned. Does the Commission envisage the introduction of appropriate procedures to enable the combination of different funds without creating red tape? What strategy will the Commission use for the involvement of Member States in this non—legally-binding initiative? Lastly, one of the main reasons for illiteracy is school drop-out. How does the Commission envisage tackling this issue through its recommendation?

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the figures on adult skills levels in the Union are striking. For both economic and social reasons, we urgently need to act. Weak reading and writing is a problem for one fifth of European adults, while another quarter has difficulty with numeracy, and – even in this digital age – up to 40% of adults have low or no digital skills. They are effectively cut off from the digital age, unable to find information online or to buy a train ticket on the web, for example. Because of their low skills levels, their chance to have a job is lowered, their income is lower and their livelihood and health are at risk. This is why we must show our determination to help the most vulnerable in society. They need a strong foundation of basic skills and the opportunity for a true second chance. This is why we propose the Skills Guarantee, a skills guarantee for adults to develop their basic skills and progress towards higher qualifications. At the heart of this initiative is the idea that adults need flexible pathways which allow them to combine learning with their other – sometimes complex – responsibilities.  I welcome the fact that, yesterday, ministers reached a political agreement on the Commission proposal – and this in less than 6 months. I regret, however, that our proposed title has been diluted by the Council, which decided to call this now Upskilling Pathways: New Opportunities for Adults. The core elements of our proposal have been preserved. As you know, these are built on three practical steps and a strong partnership approach.  Turning to the questions you raise on the action plan for the implementation, our original proposal required each Member State to draw up a detailed action plan for implementing the recommendation. During the negotiations in the Council, this was replaced with a more general text, but also invited Member States to outline appropriate measures for implementation at national level by mid-2018 at the latest. I hope that Member States will attach the appropriate importance to its implementation. We stand ready to support them and will take stock of national implementing measures by the end of 2018. The Advisory Committee on Vocational Training will work with the Commission to follow up this initiative, and this tripartite body brings together government and social partners and representatives from all Member States.  Regarding funding, as you know, the provision of basic skills is – and remains – a national competence and should be funded first and foremost by national sources. This should be prioritised in national budgets. The recommendation does not require Member States to start from scratch; our proposal builds on their existing policy and practices. The Commission has made clear from the start that there is no additional EU funding. Nevertheless, considerable EU funds are already available for use by Member States on education and training, employment and social inclusion. We have EUR 27 billion of ESF funding that will be invested in education, training skills and lifelong learning from 2014 to 2020. In addition, EUR 21 billion is available for social inclusion, and EUR 30 billion for sustainable and high-quality employment, which can also support the integration of people with low skills.  I also want to use the opportunity to thank Parliament for having defended so effectively the budget increase of the Erasmus+ programme for 2017, as well as the youth employment initiative. It demonstrates that political priorities are not only based on words: to make a real change, policies need to be transformed into concrete actions and be supported by adequate funding. In fact, most Member States have already prioritised low—skilled adults in their ESF operational programmes, including supporting adult learning in libraries, in community centres, and, among others, on the factory floor.  Regarding the Commission’s strategy to involve Member States, at European level there is already a forum that can follow up the initiative, as mentioned already: the tripartite Advisory Committee on Vocational Training. The adult learning strengths of the Erasmus+ programme will support suitable projects on peer learning between Member States. We will work closely with Member States in supporting as needed ESF interventions targeting low—skilled people. We will also continue through the European semester to emphasise the importance of upskilling and reskilling adults. As you remember, in 2016 not less than 10 Member States received country—specific recommendations in this area. Education, training and skills will continue to be covered in the detailed report on each country and therefore provide a regular opportunity for the Commission to highlight the issues raised by this initiative, whether or not they lead to a country—specific recommendation.  Regarding literacy as a reason for school dropout, this initiative complements the extensive work carried out by the Commission together with Member States and stakeholders to prevent early leaving from education and training. As you know, we aim to reach the European benchmark of 10% or less of early leavers from education and training by 2020. We are already supporting mutual learning among Member States and improving the evidence base, thanks to the expertise of Cedefop and Eurydice.  This new recommendation focuses on addressing the consequences of early leaving by providing a second chance to adults who were failed in previous decades and left school without acquiring a sound level of basic skills or qualifications. This must be part, too, of our shared commitment to fight inequalities in society, to combat poverty and to help break the cycle of inter-generational poverty, including by giving parents opportunities to improve their skills. The adoption by the Council of this recommendation and the agreement reached yesterday is just the first step. Now the main challenge is translating this political commitment and ambition into concrete measures for citizens which make a difference in their lives. We are ready to work together to make this happen.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Before I turn to the speakers from the political groups, I would just like to announce that from now on I will no longer take any catch-the-eye reports on this item on the agenda or on the last two that are still to come.We are already very late in time.We'll be here around midnight.I would like to announce that now.If you can make a contribution in writing, then you can.It just can't have more than 200 words.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the world of work is rapidly changing before our eyes. Large shifts in trade patterns and technology and the increasing sophistication of industry, as well as the overall decline of industrial employment, are having profound effects on Europe’s working population. Jobs, often elementary in nature, are ever fewer, and jobs of low qualification are becoming more and more demanding. With the decline of traditional manufacturing in many places in Europe, low-skilled workers are the ones who tend to lose out. It does not help that more than a quarter of EU citizens aged between 25 and 64 have not gone beyond lower secondary education and, as the OECD survey of adult skills shows, a similar share of people perform at the lowest level in literacy, numeracy and problem-solving skills.  This is why I welcome the Commission initiative on the skills guarantee, because of all the initiatives put forward in the new skills agenda it deals with the most vulnerable people within the labour market, and I believe that, if properly implemented, it could help deal with long-term unemployment too. What I would like to know from the Commission is how it plans to ensure that, when implementing the programme, Member States target systematic measures that address the specific needs and issues they are faced with and base their programmes on well thought—out strategies instead of financing ad—hoc measures which have a lot less of an impact.

name: Emilian PAVEL
text: on behalf of the S & D group. - About 70 million Europeans, ie almost the entire population of France, do not currently have basic knowledge of writing, reading or calculating. I've heard about digital skills before. This reality is extremely worrying and I feel that the Member States are not fully aware of this. This huge population, and not just them, over the age of 25, is at constant risk of unemployment, poverty and exclusion. They need urgent support. For this reason, I support your initiative and that of the European Commission. I am aware that this initiative has not been received with the same enthusiasm by all European institutions or by all Member States. I think this is due to a misunderstanding of the purpose of this recommendation. It wants, in fact, to provide additional support and guidance to Member States in improving or, in some cases, even setting out national strategies for developing the core skills needed for the labor market. Despite the difficulties raised by the fact that this program is not mandatory for the Member States and the lack of additional European funding, I am glad that yesterday the European Council reached an agreement on this recommendation. Following the evaluation received, the European Commission must now re-evaluate the implementation strategy and, in my view, it must ensure at least three things. First of all, all stakeholders in society, in the public sector, but also in the private sector, must be involved in the implementation of this strategy. Secondly, the Commission must provide good training to Member States' governments in accessing and interconnecting existing European funds. Last but not least, the European Commission, together with the Member States, must identify the best ways to inform data subjects, as they often they do not have access to the necessary information and, in fact, to the information intended for them.This initiative can be extremely useful to all Member States, including my country, Romania, and I believe that, after such a painful economic crisis, people need an extra guarantee, security and new opportunities.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: on behalf of the ECR Group - Although Slovakia is one of the countries in the European Union with a relatively low number of early school leavers, the trend is unlike in other EU countries and this is not good news. Because people without a secondary education are among the most vulnerable groups. In Slovakia, only 34% of them can be employed, and therefore we must set the conditions of the education system so that these people also have the opportunity to acquire qualifications and skills in secondary education. The guarantee of acquiring skills should follow on from the guarantee for young people, whose potential, unfortunately, we have not yet been able to make full use of in Slovakia. I therefore hope that, also on the basis of good experience from other Member States, as well as the Commission's recommendations, the skills guarantee will bring more tangible results. Because behind every single issue of statistics on the number of early school leavers is the fate of a particular person and everyone has the right to a second chance.

name: Renate WEBER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the European labour market faces challenges like never before. In a digitalised world, the skills demand is constantly shifting towards new jobs, making low skilled jobs as well as traditional jobs obsolete, outlining the flaws of the educational system and leaving a big segment of the workforce unemployed. The Commission proposal considers that something must be done for those with low proficiency in basic skills, literacy and numeracy and digital skills and recommends a set of policies and initiatives to support them. The proposal limits itself, however, to addressing only the effects of a wider problem without questioning why these individuals lack basic skills. Is school drop—out one of the reasons? Is poverty a possible answer? I would welcome more Commission research into the causes of this lack of skills, be they poverty, unsustainability of educational systems or the need for mentality change, rather than seeing that the EU is once again focusing on patching up only the damaging effects of a problem. If this phenomenon is not tackled appropriately, the number of people without basic skills will simply repeat itself. Therefore, I urge the Commission to have a holistic vision towards the labour market and address its issues with strategies aimed at repairing its faults.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the skills guarantee intends to target those people who are most in need of training and upskilling or who have a low proficiency in basic literacy and numeracy and digital skills, and there is a definite need for training and upskilling for those who, for whatever reason, have difficulty with literacy, numeracy or digital skills. The skills guarantee, when established, must seek to do that in a holistic manner so that not only do these people develop and hone new skills, but so that they also become critical, confident and independent individuals and achieve their full potential. It is also important that the skills guarantee involves civil society, education providers and trade unions in order for it to be successful, as these are the organisations that know how to reach out to the people who will benefit the most from upskilling pathways.  But to conclude on a slightly less positive note, the skills guarantee comes under the new skills agenda, which is a Commission initiative that seeks to get European educational institutions to do the bidding of private interests, creating insecurity in the labour market while calling it ‘flexibility’, and compromising education systems with demands of private industry interests. It is imperative that the skills guarantee does not follow the trend of submissively adapting education and training to the labour market.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, as a member of the Committee on Culture and Education, I can only be delighted that the major problem of the acquisition of fundamental knowledge is mentioned. Its consequences on youth employment are particularly disastrous. Indeed, as I recalled in numerous amendments in committee, the indicators of the report "Education at a glance 2015" show that an individual with good reading and writing skills will have 4.2 times more chances of find a job as an individual with low skills in this field. At a time when many pseudo-pedagogists want to ignore this basic knowledge of reading, writing and mathematics for the benefit of sometimes nebulous subjects, it is good to recognize its essential character. However, in this oral question, it seems that my colleagues are once again caught in amnesia and forget Article 6 of the TFEU, which leaves the Member States with competence in matters of education and training. For once, the Commission, in suggesting that the Member States build on existing policy initiatives at national level, seems to want to be reasonable. I invite my colleagues to do the same.

name: David CASA
text: - Anke jiena bħal ta 'qabli nilqa' din il proposta, li naturalment qed tassigura li l-investiment fl-educazzjoni huwa wieħed mill-objettivi tal-politika ta 'koeżjoni Ewropea. In the present case, the contract may be granted by the Member State of the Fund in accordance with the provisions of the Treaty establishing the European Union, and the Fund of the Fund shall be extended to the Member States. I would like to point out that there is no need for a different fund to r-requisite this and the same mandates as the diffuse and bureaucratic. In the case of all the flowers of the flower-flower of the red-flowered flower of the flower-red flower in the background of different fundamentals, and in the case of the aid of the aid? Aħna konxji wkoll li mhux kull pajjiż membru għandu l-istess riżorsi. In the case of all or part of the rubber products, it is necessary to add to the fruit of the flower or to the flower of the fruit of the fruit of the fruit of the year b'mod aħjar ub 'suċċess. Fl-aħħar nett, nixtieq nappella lill-pajjiżi membri sabiex jaħdmu ħalli jimplimentaw din ir-rakkomandazzjoni fl-interest taċ-ċittadini kollha tagħhom.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: - Madam President!I would also like to thank Commissioner Thyssen for his clarity.This is definitely a national task.It is a second chance for young adults and older adults.There is money at EU level in the form of Erasmus + but also elsewhere.I really hope we can use this money wisely, because it's good for all of us.We live in a time and a society that is almost breaking down.There are so many scared and unhappy and untapped people.I really think that these proposals are about, namely to get a chance to develop as a person and become a citizen and become someone who is part of society.I therefore think that it will be very exciting to work with this competence guarantee, with these chances, during the time we have ahead of us for the rest of the term.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Perhaps briefly to explain why Ms. Ulvskog has now spoken again: Originally, someone was intended to be different from the author.Ms. Ulvskog stood in for this person, but was on the list herself.So she had the floor again for a minute.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - The Commission reports that around 70 million Europeans - yes, 70 million Europeans - have insufficient literacy and numeracy skills and that 40% of the Union's population do not have sufficient digital skills. This is shocking data. If we were to apply more stringent criteria, for example, to examine functional illiteracy, the result would be even more terrifying. Even university students struggle to understand more complex press texts, let alone classical literary or philosophical texts. However, I have doubts whether another EU program, another guarantee, another framework, even with an additional budget, will be able to remedy this situation. Is it not so that we need to rethink the existing educational strategies, that we need to return to the old proven methods of literacy of society and educational methods, rebuilding the book culture, which is also indispensable in the digital age?

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, low qualifications are inextricably linked to issues related to conditioning and limiting social, educational and cultural rights. They do not disconnect from fundamental political options, the same ones that promote deregulation and precarious work conditions, and which have, among other consequences, the increase of inequalities, social exclusion and permanent poverty. We value initiatives that allow an increase in skill levels for those who have abandoned or were forced to abandon the education system at any level, and should involve civil society, education authorities and unions. Only in this way will it be possible to guarantee professional training dynamics that are not a mere social patch, aimed at manipulating and masking real levels of unemployment, disconnected from the needs of workers and the labor needs of a given region. Dynamics that demand and can only be truly realized if accompanied by social policies based on regulation and labor protection, in the defense of collective hiring, in the increase of wages and in the fight against precariousness.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: - Madam President, I enthusiastically support this establishment of a guarantee for skills, because it is an eminently modern concept which must adapt to all the evolution of professions. Today, everyone must have the right to an enrichment of their skills tree, because professions evolve and we must adapt each employee, each young person to the new skills that we need in the company and that we are going to need. , because the whole employment pyramid will move. It is not through initial training or diplomas, but only through the development of skills - this personal enrichment - that we are going to be able to follow this immense movement and prevent some from falling into unemployment. But I would like to add that there is another extremely important advantage. I would like to tell you about what is happening in the careers of women. The latter often have gaps in their careers, because they stop to take care of children, young children, disabled children, elderly parents and so what happens? They have a career delay which leads to the impoverishment of women. Thanks to the guarantee of skills throughout life, in my opinion we can rebuild curricula vitae, and we must have this will to keep up with modernity. I therefore urge the Member States in this direction.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: - It is vital that the EU remains at the forefront of education, skills and innovation.Especially in a world of far-reaching globalization and technologicalization.In addition, that skills guarantee should also be a tool for convergence.After all, as rapporteur for the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, I travel a lot to Eastern Europe, where my colleagues and friends understand the need for the revision, but are afraid of falling further behind, while in these countries the lack of skills is a major problem.is.Let us therefore use this skills guarantee to give these vulnerable but potentially very rich countries a great deal of support, with guarantees of sufficient resources, funds and commitment.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Today we are talking about part of the New Skills Agenda, called the Skills Guarantee. I would like to make two comments on this. Firstly, the Commission is making a proposal that is certainly sensible and worthy of support, namely to integrate people with little or no training into the labor market and thus into society. But I find the cost aspect of this proposal problematic. The Commission is making proposals here that others have to pay for, namely the Member States. They have to pay for the proposals and, as is well known, they are subject to agreed spending restrictions, for example through the Growth and Stability Pact. The Commission's proposal only states that the expenditure assumed complies with the Growth and Stability Pact, without any explanation as to how. I would like some information from the Commission on this. I would also like to make another point: we should be more careful about the names we give to our political initiatives. From my point of view, the word guarantee is currently being used inflationarily. We have a youth guarantee, now a competence guarantee, some even demand a child guarantee. From my point of view, such terms arouse too high hopes in the population and create frustration and a tiredness of Europe when we cannot deliver, for example with the competence guarantee. It carries the risk of arousing false hopes. No one can guarantee that education will be successful, and better education does not automatically lead to employment.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the skills guarantee is certainly a good idea, because it starts with identifying a very serious and at the same time very practical problem. Our societies are changing at a tremendous pace, driven by globalization and the evolution of new technologies. This phenomenon, which is displacing politics, which is struggling to govern it, is clearly turning into a displacement of the workforce, not only in terms of the skills necessary to carry out new types of employment, but also in the field of rights and working relationships. There is no doubt that there is a profound need to give guarantees to workers and aspiring workers today and the question of the Employment Committee tries to better understand what kind of guarantee the European Commission would have in mind, which ones and how many resources to use to make it work, what strategy to adopt to make it effective and flexible, but also binding in the Union and its Member States. I would sincerely like to see a real commitment in this instrument, which aims to enhance people, guaranteeing a minimum level of skills for all using European funds to the fullest.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, 70 million Europeans do not reach a basic level in reading and writing. At the same time, 40% of employers fail to fill their vacancies because they fail to find the necessary skills. A reflection on the adequacy of our training is therefore essential. Today, the goal of the skills guarantee is to ensure that as many low-skilled adults as possible acquire at least the basic reading, writing, numeracy and numeracy skills needed to find a job. For this guarantee to be effective, the focus must be on two important elements, from my point of view. First, you have to be able to identify people who do not have the skills and, in this area, many taboos still exist and sometimes people who can neither read nor write prefer to hide it. We must therefore change mentalities and lift inhibitions. It is also necessary to target the most disadvantaged areas and groups. Finally, we must encourage small and medium-sized enterprises to engage in work-study programs in continuing education. Above all, we have to move away from a logic that focuses on diplomas to finally enter into a logic of valuing skills, entering modernity, as suggested by my colleague, Ms. Morin-Chartier.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I welcome the creation of a Skills Guarantee as part of a lifelong learning approach and would like to emphasise some elements. We need to prepare learners of all ages and from all backgrounds so that they can be ready for a fast-changing, complex and hyper-connected world, ready for jobs and competences that do not even exist yet. That is why it is key to ensure that learners are equipped with transferable skills, among which media literacy and curiosity, critical and creative thinking and entrepreneurship are key. We must also equip learners with the necessary skills for a more open, sustainable and inclusive society. We therefore need to invest in their social skills, and in particular their intercultural skills. On top of guaranteeing a minimum level of literacy, numeracy and digital skills for all, those are the skills that we must invest in for learners to become not only fit for the labour market, but also true problem—solvers and responsible and active citizens.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I appreciate that the Commission is coming up with important measures to strengthen human capital, employment and competitiveness. Thank you also for the information that the Council has accepted your proposal. Although education is fully the responsibility of the Member States, the European institutions also need to respond at European level in order to respond to the fact that up to 25% of adults do not even have a minimum level of reading literacy, numeracy and digital skills. That there are 65 million people who have not even completed secondary education, which is simply essential. It is these people with insufficient qualifications who need to focus on this second chance. I appreciate the proposal, in which you focus on the assessment of the existing skills of these people, on the subsequent offer of education, adaptation to the needs of the labor market and also the individual, followed by validation and recognition of this education. I think it's a very good program. But what I would like to emphasize, and what I have reservations about, is that we are only dealing with the consequences of the school, the education system not being able to reduce the number of early departures, and we should focus on that. These schools and teachers support. Without the support of teachers, we will definitely not be able to improve the current situation, and I would also like to urge you to do so.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: - Madam President, I would also like to welcome the initiative of the Commission. This is an important initiative because it aims to take up a huge challenge, that of the 66 million people in Europe who have not gone beyond secondary education. This challenge of having, even today, one in five Europeans who have difficulty reading and writing. These are startling figures. But above all, behind these figures, there are human lives, vulnerable people, people in financial difficulty, isolated, who live it all in their flesh. This is why it is really important to adapt the training courses by giving all their value to training, to experience. The competence guarantee initiated by the Commission should first and foremost strengthen basic skills. It must be a helping hand to those who are currently excluded from the job market. How? 'Or' What? By offering them precisely this personalized learning, access to training, the possibility of progressing towards a recognized certification. We cannot afford to leave people by the wayside and it is essential to allow those who have not followed the most natural or the most obvious courses to have a second chance to exist in our society. This is a major responsibility for the Member States and I would once again like to underline the initiative of the Commission which, by doing this, builds bridges to ensure that the Europe of tomorrow is a more human Europe.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have taken note of your comments and your observations. I will not address every point you have raised here, but will focus on just a few points to conclude. The success of the skills agenda will depend on the commitment and active engagement of many players, as we have just discussed. We think first and foremost of Member States and regional authorities, and I am happy that just yesterday Member States confirmed their commitment. This is very important. We also need businesses, trade unions, education and training institutions and NGOs – as well, of course, as workers and learners themselves. The European Parliament has a key role to play in raising the political profile of this debate, both in Europe and in your home countries. You are indeed active and valued partners in shaping our initiatives, and I want to thank you again for your input and for your continued support.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place at a later part-session.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Young people today need general transversal skills such as critical thinking, responsible decision-making, conflict management and creativity that contribute to their active participation in society. Research shows that a high proportion of adults with low skills and basic digital skills can be attributed to lower productivity levels and weaker competitiveness prospects. This is not only a disadvantage for individuals, but also extremely costly for the economy and society as a whole. I welcome the Commission's proposal to set up a Skills Guarantee. Differences in skills supply and demand, as well as skills shortages, can adversely affect not only productivity and growth, but also the social situation within and between Member States. I support the proposal that the Member States should set up. the so-called A skills guarantee that would provide access to adults who have dropped out of the basic education and training system and are not covered by the Youth Guarantee. This would allow them to: acquire a minimum level of literacy, numeracy and digital skills and / or progress towards an EQF level 4 or equivalent qualification through a wider range of skills.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - To reduce the number of low-skilled adults in Europe, the Commission has proposed establishing a "Skills Guarantee". The initiative should help low-skilled adults acquire a minimum level of literacy, numeracy and digital skills. In my opinion, this proposal contains some gaps which should be filled. The Commission invites Member States to rapidly develop an action plan for the implementation of this "guarantee for skills" without providing for a mechanism or body to support Member States in developing and monitoring that plan. Furthermore, this initiative should be developed without additional funding, which seems to me very difficult. The Commission refers to the use of different EU funds, for example the European Social Fund and the Erasmus + program, but without defining appropriate procedures that allow the combination of these different funds without creating red tape. Another gap in the proposal that should be filled concerns the strategy that the Commission must adopt to involve Member States in this non-legally binding initiative. Without a clear strategy to help make the Skills Guarantee operational, potential benefits risk being compromised.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: in writing. - A significant barrier to growth in many Member States is the fact that a large part of the population does not have the necessary skills for the labor market. The problem is not only early school leavers, but the increasing secondary illiteracy. Many specialists point to the worrying phenomenon of losing reading comprehension skills, creating more complex written statements or making simple mathematical calculations. Therefore, I wholeheartedly support the European Commission's initiative to establish a Skills Guarantee. Experts agree that the traditional educational model, as we know from our own experience or the experience of our children, does not fully respond to the challenges of the 21st century. Until now, no country has created an ideal educational system from which everyone could draw. In order to make full use of already existing policies, instruments and funds, we should learn from each other and use ideas that are very successful in many Member States. When creating a Skills Guarantee, does the European Commission plan to focus on the exchange of good practice and to encourage countries to implement ideas that have already been proven and are bearing fruit?

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: written. - I encourage the Commission to look at competence-based examinations in the Member States. A demonstration degree is a flexible way of completing a degree specifically designed for adults. In demonstration examinations, professional skills are demonstrated in working life, regardless of whether the competence has been acquired through work experience, studies or other activities. All vocational undergraduate, vocational and special vocational examinations can be completed as a demonstration examination. A person who already has sufficient professional skills can complete a demonstration degree or part of it without attending training. The demonstration degree gives eligibility for studies leading to a university degree and general eligibility for polytechnic studies. Everyone should be treated as potential higher education students, so it is good to certify the paths in the most varied ways possible. One such means are adult demonstration qualifications, which can be used to verify the skills of those who have acquired their professional skills in working life. In the spirit of lifelong learning, an EQF-4 degree should also equip people to update their skills throughout their careers and, if necessary, to pursue higher education.

name: Verónica LOPE FONTAGNÉ
text: written. - First of all, I would like to show my full support for the Commission's proposal for a Skills Guarantee. If the proposal is implemented effectively in all Member States, if it is aimed at sectors with current and future potential and, above all, if it has the support and collaboration of the social partners, and in particular the education and We can enable millions of low-skilled European citizens to improve their employability and access the labor market more easily, thus promoting greater social cohesion. However, many European and Spanish rural areas, such as mine, Aragon, are regions with a strong problem of depopulation and population dispersion, which lack an adequate broadband network, which makes their business and economic development even more difficult. . I do not dispute the capital importance of digital knowledge, but I wonder if we have the necessary infrastructures for its training and business development. If we do not take into account these different territorial realities, we run the risk of turning a proposal aimed at improving the employability of low-skilled European citizens into the death sentence of many small European municipalities.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - The two main challenges for the Skills Guarantee are to fill the skills gaps among EU citizens and better match them with the labor market. In this context, I emphasize the enormous role of modern education systems, which should focus on shaping basic competences and a wider range of skills needed in the labor market now and in the future, including digital, transversal, technical and social skills. I am also asking the Commission to support the Member States in modernizing their education programs so as to identify, activate and develop the skills and qualifications of Europeans more effectively. Ultimately, I stress that skills can translate into better economic and social outcomes if they are clear to everyone and effectively used throughout the Union. In this context, we must ensure their quality, transparency and recognition in other Member States. I also draw attention to the importance of recognizing and confirming competences and qualifications acquired in non-formal education, which is especially important for people with lower qualifications, the unemployed, at risk of unemployment and for those who need to change their career path.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- I support the adoption of the Guarantee for skills that will help adults who left the education system too soon, for the most common objective reasons, to acquire basic qualifications and enter the labor market.Given the freedom they have in the way they are implemented, I call on the Member States to move quickly and decisively towards the implementation of this program.Unfortunately, no additional funds are allocated for it from the European budget, but it is eligible for funding from existing programs and ESI funds, so only effective implementation is important for success.This program will contribute to the strengthening of the whole society because the spread of basic skills to as many inhabitants as possible is a step towards a society of social justice, knowledge and competitiveness.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. - According to studies, 70 million Europeans do not have sufficient reading and writing skills and even more have inadequate arithmetic and digital skills. This puts them at risk of unemployment, poverty and social exclusion. According to the European Commission, 56% of people between the ages of 16 and 74 in Greece do not even have basic digital skills, while the corresponding figure in the European Union is 41%. Although 39.4% of Greeks aged 30-34 have received higher education, only 47.4% of graduates are employed, in contrast to the European average which is almost double (80.5%). The Greek labor market offers capable young people with minimal opportunities, forcing them to become self-employed or to emigrate. According to the data of the Bank of Greece, my homeland Greece holds the fourth place in the European Union in the mass of the emigration outflow in proportion to its labor force. In 2013 alone, more than 2% of the country's total workforce left to work abroad. Young people are our main guarantors for the future of the country. We must abolish the memoranda of misery that force our children to uproot themselves in search of a supposedly better life.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - There are many different qualifications and qualifications in the European Union today. This diversity, which constitutes an asset for each Member State, can sometimes appear to be an obstacle to recruitment. The recognition of this diversity led, in 2008, to the establishment of a "European qualifications framework for lifelong education and training". The objectives of this framework have not been met. It is therefore necessary, in the eyes of the Commission, to review this system with a new recommendation. However, in 2016 the Commission does not have any more studies than in 2008. It is unable to assess the value of general and vocational training from one country to another. However, it is in part this value that would guarantee equivalent skills. In the same sense, it cannot guarantee permeability between the different training systems. You use the term harmonization, but really you should be talking about leveling down! Indeed, the disparities are too great to proceed with such harmonization without lowering the qualification and skills criteria. In addition, certain national specificities are once again threatened by this system.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: signed up. - Today the main problem on the labor market is the level and type of qualification that European citizens have. The discrepancy between the training provided by schools and universities and the skills required of potential employees, the lack of guidance of young people in their professional careers, the lack of a transparent job market or the inability of the training system to develop the skills required by employers accentuate the crisis in the European work. In this regard, I support the move to create a skills guarantee at European level based on the Youth Guarantee model. This platform would ensure free access for a large number of Europeans to training compatible with the labor market, helping them to acquire the necessary skills in entrepreneurship. Every European citizen must feel protected by the European Union, we need those in difficulty to be able to recover and reintegrate into the labor market, and it is time for structural reform in the allocation of European funds to generate concrete results. for people.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – I have always said that we cannot guarantee jobs or income to our citizens. But today we are talking about equipping people with skills, and this is a very welcome development. With this, we are making a strong political commitment to support the relentless development of our creative people.  I welcome the Commission’s Skills Guarantee. Particularly, defining digital skills as basic capabilities marks a major development in mindset – being tech savvy is a key competence in life. In order to make the New Skills Strategy work, we should: create a culture of learning across Europe – individuals must feel disposed to learn throughout their lives and confident in doing so; ‘embed’ basic skills – integrating literacy, language and numeracy learning into other trainings for a holistic approach to learning; ensure collaboration with employers and businesses, demonstrating basic skills training is an investment rather than a cost; and, most importantly, develop a strategic perspective, bringing together an understanding of the wider context and awareness of the need to adapt or change previous practice. Following these steps, we can truly upskill our younger and older generations. Тhis is crucial, because skills are the currency of the 21st century, they are Europe’s strongest asset.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: written. - I welcome the competence guarantee, which emphasizes the further training of people and thus securing the future. 70 million citizens in the European Union have difficulty reading or writing. Even more people have fundamental deficits in arithmetic and in using digital devices. These deficits are real poverty traps. The digital change makes it necessary that we prepare our citizens better so that they can find their way in a rapidly changing world of work 4.0. Technological progress advances so quickly that the knowledge and skills acquired have ever shorter shelf lives. I am critical of the fact that investments in people's education are still booked on the expenditure side and are therefore often the first to fall victim to budget cuts in the Member States. We can only maintain the path of competitiveness and achieve the Europe 2020 targets if we get better at education. That is why I would ask the Commission and the Council to abandon austerity and return to intelligent and investment-oriented policies.

name: Romana TOMC
