text: in writing. - I believe that the Guarantee of Skills program will help the citizens of the European Union to acquire a basic level or to advance to a higher level of writing, numeracy and digital literacy. These are skills that are urgently needed in today's time when the labor market is changing rapidly and will enable our citizens an easier transition from education to employment, as well as a more independent life, if we are talking about adults. The program can have a very positive impact, as it will enable our citizens to acquire a wide range of skills that will be equally recognized throughout the EU. In Europe, almost 70 million people face a lack of reading and writing skills, and even more lack basic mathematical and digital literacy. Without these basic skills, the risk of becoming unemployed, poor or socially excluded is even greater. I believe that the new skills program is essential and that it will help our citizens to acquire basic skills and find employment more easily.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on sign language and professional sign language interpreters (2016/2952 (RSP)).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the challenges of the deaf and hard of hearing community do not yet get enough attention in the European Union, and I am therefore grateful to Members of the European Parliament, Helga Stevens and Ádám Kósa for constantly reminding us of what still needs to be done in order to ensure that all European citizens can participate actively in society.  Commissioner Tibor Navracsics recently took part in a conference on sign languages and human rights, organised by Helga Stevens, which showcased the challenges faced by the deaf and the hard of hearing on a daily basis. The Commission was impressed by the professional competence of the sign language interpreters, who were conveying the speeches in more than 30 sign languages. The Commission welcomes the political groups’ initiatives for a motion for a resolution, because we believe that more should be done to show respect for the deaf and hard of hearing community and its languages. The Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union explicitly excludes any form of discrimination, and the Disability Strategy 2010-2020 stresses the principle of social inclusion.  The Commission believes in, and promotes, inclusive education. Whenever possible, schools should open their doors to deaf children, ensuring that the conditions are met for their successful inclusion in the classroom. Sign language interpretation should be provided whenever possible for public services.  Education and language policy falls under the exclusive competence of the Member States. However, the Commission supports them through facilitating cooperation and exchange of best practices. The Erasmus+ programme already funds a number of partnerships and mobility projects that develop open educational resources and train sign language teachers and interpreters. For example, the research project Developing and Documenting Sign Bilingual Best Practice in Schools maps the situation of sign bilingual education in 39 European countries. The European Forum of sign language interpreters provides opportunities for meetings, conferences and exchange of experiences. We also have the toolkit Signs for Handshakes, Deaf—Youth—Meets—Employers, and the European Language Label. More support for sign languages is provided through the research programme Horizon 2020, and there again we have many examples: information technology is used for the early detection of and compensation for hearing impairment, and also to develop applications supporting the use of sign languages, for example. Another example is that a digital archive presenting the life narratives of elderly signers has developed. Remote communication between signing and speaking people through applications that translate text into sign languages is made possible, and another example under Horizon 2020 is an interactive digital atlas of the linguistic structures of the world’s sign languages. As regards the Commission, the Directorate General for Interpretation regularly provides sign language interpretation for EU—level meetings. To support the full participation of those using sign languages, interpreters tailor their services by discussing with participants whether international sign language is appropriate or whether a national sign language is needed.  As you can see, the Commission has come a long way since this House adopted its last resolution on sign language recognition in 1998, but we know we can and should do more to ensure our societies not only tolerate diversity, but also cherish and promote it. The Commission therefore welcomes this resolution, and will continue supporting sign languages, their users and their interpreters.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, sign language interpretation is not help, but a fundamental human right to full participation in the community. Accessibility is a precondition for people with disabilities to be able to live independently and participate properly in society. Please note that, at my request, the sign language interpreter did not translate my previous words, so that the Members present could not understand what I was saying. With this, I wanted to make sense of what it means to be unable to use my mother tongue freely and to express my thoughts in this way. Now I will repeat what I said. So, if one falls out of the triad of education, employment and accessibility, the deaf will continue to be disadvantaged. Interpretation and accessibility, as well as accessibility, play a key role in this. It is my belief that deaf, deafblind and hard of hearing students and their parents should be given the opportunity to learn the sign language used in their environment through pre-school services or school education. Finally, I call on the Commission to maintain in the long term the already completed INSIGN European pilot project, proposed by the European Parliament, which aims to ensure barrier-free communication between deaf and hard of hearing people and the EU institutions. I would also ask the Commission to examine in the Member States whether equal access to education for deaf, hard of hearing and deafblind children is being achieved.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Thank you very much, also for pointing out that the silence that we briefly heard had nothing to do with the interpreter, but was a sign from you, what it is like when you don't understand a language.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, deaf, deaf-blind and hard of hearing citizens must have access to the same information and communications as any other citizen, in the form of interpretation of sign language, subtitling, conversion of speech into text and / or forms communication alternatives, including interpreters. This is an inalienable right of over a million European sign language users, deaf and 51 million other hard of hearing citizens. We are talking about the possibility of leading an independent life, receiving an inclusive and quality education, increasing employability, having the right to health guaranteed, equal access to justice. We talk about the possibility of actively participating in political and democratic processes, as well as creating and exchanging culture. The EU motto is "United in diversity" and that is why we have always been committed to promoting richness and linguistic pluralism. It is time to go a step further: today we ask the EU and the Member States to recognize national and regional sign languages, recognize the professional figure of the sign language interpreter and provide this profession with training and quality framework.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - I would like to welcome the European Union of the Deaf, here at the visitor's gallery. For a long time, sign interpreters were considered to help deaf people. Often the deaf person's family acted as an interpreter, even during official affairs. This is still the case in many countries in the EU, but the situation is improving and sign language interpretation is gradually becoming a fully-fledged profession. This joint resolution is based on previous European Parliament resolutions of 1988 and 1998 and input from deaf and interpreting organizations. It is also a result of the conference I organized in Brussels on September 28, 2016, where for the first time all 24 EU spoken and 31 EU sign languages ​​were used. Sign interpreters are indispensable for ensuring equal participation of sign language users. The Charter of Fundamental Rights does not allow discrimination based on disability. We can only do this by working on accessibility and reasonable adjustments. I am also referring to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, which both the EU and most EU Member States have ratified. Everyone in this House knows that interpreters have a demanding job. This certainly also applies to sign language interpreters. Therefore, they deserve appropriate and equal pay for their work. There is still a serious shortage of interpreters in all EU Member States. On average, one sign language interpreter is available for 160 deaf people across the EU. But there are major differences between the different Member States, from one interpreter per eight deaf to one per 2 500. Just imagine. Providing training and education opportunities for future interpreters is an absolute priority. Within the EU institutions, there is an increasing demand for interpreters from deaf citizens. Given that there are not enough interpreters in the Member States, I would like to refer to the Commission ask how she will tackle this problem.Are there any plans to employ sign interpreters, bearing in mind that sign interpreters are also part of the International Association of Conference Interpreters (IACI)?This joint resolution, to be voted on tomorrow, is an important milestone for persons with disabilities and in particular for deaf sign language users.It is the first time that the focus is on sign language interpreters as a professional group.After 20 years, it is high time to take the next step and focus on professionalizing the sign language profession and the EU institutions must play an exemplary role here.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: (The President speaks without a microphone.) ... tried to convey to Mrs Stevens that she must come to an end, because it does not work with the hammer.But it worked fine.Thank you very much.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I am very pleased to be a co-signatory to this motion on sign languages and professional sign language interpretation. I applaud the important role of my colleagues, Ádám Kósa and Helga Stevens, in initiating this motion. It is, of course, a follow—on to Helga’s very successful event in the Parliament on sign language, where I had the opportunity to meet a number of Irish people from the deaf community. But tonight, the question is: how can we progress the initiative? One opportunity is the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, where the Convention elaborates on the need for reasonable accommodation. But we all know that there can be no reasonable accommodation without the provision of qualified and professional sign language interpreters. For this to happen, we need many things, but, crucially, we need to see official recognition of national and regional sign languages in Member States and in the EU institutions. I want to acknowledge the campaign that is underway in Ireland to achieve formal recognition of the Irish sign language. In Ireland, approximately 40 000 people use the Irish sign language, 5000 of whom are deaf and 35 000 are family and friends. At national and EU level, we must make the educational system, the health system, the judicial system, the political system and many other public systems as accessible as possible. Speaking of the education system, we must ensure that the deaf, hard of hearing and deaf—blind can access Erasmus.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I cannot continue in Portuguese sign language, because otherwise nobody would understand me here today. We come together, from all political groups, to defend a human rights issue. It is worth noting the work that has been done and, in particular, that of colleague Helga Stevens. I must say that discrimination is one of the most active forms of politics, that exclusion is one of the most active forms of politics. What we are asking for today is nothing very complicated, it is the recognition of national and regional sign languages, also here in the European institutions. It means having professional and qualified interpreters who are adequately remunerated. We know, Madam President, that in order to have a complete democracy, it is necessary to have a situation in which everyone can elect and be elected. This does not happen if we exclude one million citizens in Europe, because not everyone has access to information, nor can everyone be the same. The only thing that is missing here is, truly, political will, it is a matter of human rights, I repeat, therefore, that political will comes, Commissioner. We can't wait any longer.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- (The speaker speaks without a microphone.) ... because to learn sign language, I would have needed sign language teachers in school.Unfortunately, there was no such thing, and even today there is still far too little in the European Union.There are still far too few sign language interpreters.For 12,000 deaf people in my home country North Rhine-Westphalia, there are just 120 sign language interpreters to enable them to go about their everyday lives.That is still far too little.Because only if we can provide well-trained sign language interpreters nationwide can deaf people really fully participate in society.The European Union must do a lot more here to put pressure on the Member States so that everyone can finally participate fully in society.

name: David CASA
text: - Nixtieq nirringrazzja naturalment il-kollegi tiegħi, is-Sur Ádám Kósa u S-Sa Helga Stevens, għal din ir-riżoluzzjoni li għandna quddiemna. Naturalization of the interpretation of the professions of the natural and lingual bis-sinjali trid tiġi kkunsidrata sabiex nassiguraw aċċess ugwali għall-impjiegi, l-educazzjoni u t-taħriġ. L-iżvilupp u teknoloġija ġdida għal-lingwa tista 'tkun ta' benefiċċju għal dawk li jużaw il-lingwa tas-sinjali. In the present case, the Community has a special interest in the export of European Union, and all that is common to the European Union. Kif qalet il-Kummissarju, għal soluzzjoni ta 'suċċess fit-tul irridu insibu modi li bihom ninvestu min etāgira fit-tfal tagnana li għandhom diababilitá sabiex narmawhom bis-snajja' neċessarji sabiex ikunu jistgħu jistgħu . It is therefore possible for the party to take part in the preparation of a tax preparation to make a preliminary decision on the application of the application to the competent authority of the competent authority of the competent authority. li jaħdmu b'mod effettiv f'sistemi bilingwali u f'ambjenti inclussivi fl-ambitu perekattiv.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, making the world of knowledge, information and work accessible: this is an appointment that can no longer be postponed, if it is true as it is true that Europe has, among its aims, the breaking down of every barrier that stands in the way of the freedom of every person. Therefore, accessibility is the frontier of rights: accessibility in places of life, training, work, but also in digital spaces. To achieve this goal it is necessary to promote, on the one hand, the diffusion of new technologies but also to guarantee interpretation in institutions, precisely, in places of care, justice and training, guaranteeing the professional figures trained so that theirs is a job. of quality, not precarious, but recognized above all in the public administration chain. I conclude, obviously declaring my support with a wish: hoping that the European institutions will promote the teaching of sign language in schools of all levels, so that a new social accessibility can truly be achieved.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, cuirim an-fháilte roimh an rún tábhachtach seo agus mo bhuíochas le Helga Stevens as ucht é seo a thabhairt chun solais. Tá sé thar a bheith in am dúinn dul chun cinn le haitheantas agus comhionannas a bhaint amach dár gcearta teanga san Eoraip agus inár mBallstáit féin. Cuireann an rún seo na háiseanna ríthábhachtacha atá riachtanach don phobal bodhar san áireamh agus is maith an rud é sin. In Éirinn le déanaí, chuaigh bille tríd an Seanad a thug aitheantas do ISL, an teanga chomharthaíochta atá againn sa bhaile, agus tá sé práinneach aitheantas iomlán a thabhairt do phobal na mbodhar anois. Comh maith le Coinbhinsiún na Náisiún Aontaithe um Chearta na nDaoine faoi Mhíchumas a dhaingniú in Éirinn, táim ag seasamh go láidir ar son aitheantas do ISL a fháil ó stát na hÉireann. Tá an deis agus an dualgas orainne mar Fheisirí Eorpacha teacht le chéile chun comhoibriú ar son cearta teanga agus comhionannas do gach éinne.  Agus arís, mo mhíle buíochas le Helga as ucht é seo a thabhairt chun solais. Caithfimid, mar a deirim, seasamh i dteannta a chéile chun na cearta seo a aithint.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - This initiative represents a very important step in facilitating the integration of deaf and hard of hearing people into society and the labor market. Sign language is a basic right of deaf people and is also their first and official language, so it is very important that they have the opportunity to communicate in that language, both in society and in the workplace. I believe that access to information, communication, education and employment should always be guaranteed, which would, of course, also allow them to live independently. It is up to the Member States to ensure that all material is accessible to the hearing impaired in their institutions. As the European institutions should be an example of best practice, I believe that sign language should also become one of the official languages ​​of the European Parliament, and interpreters should be available at all committee meetings. At the end, I would also like to say that as part of my work, I will also enable internships and internships for people with hearing impairments, and I put this decision to the heart of my colleagues as well.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - People with hearing impairments face obstacles every day, even in such routine activities as visiting a doctor or office and many others. Many of these barriers would be removed by the assistance of a professional sign language interpreter, but there is an acute shortage of them in the EU countries, eg in the Czech Republic only less than a hundred of them work. Thus, there are about 140 clients per interpreter. Although this service is granted by law to the deaf, in practice it is difficult to access. Although sign language interpreters are fully comparable to interpreters of any foreign language, many countries do not recognize their profession and there are not sufficient standards for their formal teaching. A conference on sign languages, recently organized by our colleague Helga Stevens, has already been mentioned several times. Just as I was happy to support this conference and invite a delegation of the hearing impaired from the Czech Republic to it, I also fully support this resolution.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: - Madam President, access to sign language interpretation continues to be approached as if it were a luxury. I am very honored to have signed a motion for a resolution that argues that, if we want to guarantee integration conditions for European citizens with hearing impairments, we must provide them with efficient means of communication. First of all, each Member State must ensure that each hearing impaired child can fully interact with education professionals, from the earliest ages, using sign language interpreters from their country, and must also ensure access to bilingual education. in pre-school education and at school. But this duty to achieve greater integration must also be reflected in public services. It is not accepted that, today, a hearing impaired person cannot communicate with a doctor in the emergency services, in a public hospital or with the authorities and justice services. I also warn of the need to minimize discrimination against deaf people when accessing specialized knowledge, especially regarding higher education or postgraduate education, which today we all know is essential to combat unemployment, so it is urgent that we make every effort to that universities have sign language interpreters or online services that provide it. Let us be ambitious. As Helen Keller said, you can never agree to crawl when you feel like flying.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, I warmly welcome this initiative to promote sign language recognition and the availability of sign language interpretation. While the recognition of sign language has been increased in many Member States recently, across the EU deaf, deaf-blind and hard of hearing citizens still encounter enormous disadvantages in terms of access to information or employment. Only in my country, Romania, more than 23 000 people face difficulties on a daily basis in this regard. Knowing that the ratio of sign language users to sign language interpreters is 160 to 1 on average in Europe, it is clear that Europe needs a lot more qualified and professional sign language interpreters. Improvements in this field should also be accompanied by the promotion and uptake of new emerging technologies in the area of accessibility in order to promote the independent and equal participation of people with disabilities in society.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - Dear Members of the European Parliament, thank you for your debate. Thank you also for your valuable input into the efforts that we certainly need to step up to ensure that deaf and hard of hearing people have full participation and genuine equal opportunities. In my introduction I highlighted a number of commitments from the European Union and the European Commission, as well as commitments we have made, including under the UN Convention on the Fundamental Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I have also drawn you to a number of projects currently being funded with European funds. May I also remind you that we have expressed that same commitment in our proposal for a European accessibility law, which of course also involves offering people with disabilities a much better and fully-fledged participation in all aspects of our society. Honorable Members of the European Parliament, you have made a number of concrete suggestions for improvement. I am sure that tomorrow will also be clearly stated in the resolution you are voting for, and you can count on us to give you a detailed written response to those proposals. Then I will no longer take up the time that is scarce this evening. Thank you for your input, thank you for your effort and thank you, Madam President.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: To wind up the debate, two motions for resolutions have been tabled under Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 23 November 2016.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - Considering that disabled people have the right to a full life and to the same leisure activities, to the same education or professional integration as all, I would like to reaffirm my attachment with this declaration to a fight that affects too many people in the world. 'EU. In France alone, the LSF was signed by 100,000 people in 2014 and by around 169,000 people around the world. Since 2008 it has been an option at the baccalaureate and sign language courses are developing everywhere in the universities, demonstrating the solidarity of all with deaf people. This text, which goes in the right direction, should allow the official recognition of sign language interpreters, with in particular the attribution of a similar status, within the European institutions, to that of spoken language interpreters. This is a first step towards more social justice. The project remains vast for the successful integration of deaf people at all levels of society and I will not stop fighting to guarantee these same rights.

name: Algirdas SAUDARGAS
text: in writing.- Sign languages are the official languages of the states and must be given the same rights.Both in the Member States and in the European Union institutions, we pay too little attention to the problem of access to information for all, and that needs to change.Linguistic diversity must not only be tolerated but also nurtured, and the promotion of multilingualism in the Member States should include sign languages.In some areas, the development and use of language technologies would help reduce the exclusion of people with hearing impairments and increase their access to information.It is essential to ensure that the European Commission's programs, such as Horizon 2020, and at national level pay sufficient attention to the development of language technologies.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the question for oral answer to the Commission on the agreement on trade in environmental protection goods by Bernd Lange and Alessia Maria Mosca on behalf of the Committee on International Trade (O-000138/2016 - B8-1811 /2016) (2016/2980 (RSP)).

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: Author. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, trade and the environment are closely linked. The relationship between the two areas, however, is not unique. It could be argued that the expansion of international trade and growth is one of the causes of global warming. However, it is necessary to recognize globalization the great merit of having favored the diffusion of technologies with low environmental impact and better standards. This is why we believe the green goods agreement that is being negotiated between 17 parties, including the United States and China, as well as the European Union, is so important. The negotiations which, as far as we know, have had alternating phases of speed and success, but which could be concluded in December, have some critical elements. We have therefore put forward this question with which we ask for clarification regarding the Commission's strategy and the Union's offensive and defensive interests in the area of ​​environmental assets. There are two concerns underlying our request. The first, conceptual, concerns the nature of the agreement itself and, in particular, the objective of contributing to the fight against climate change. Indeed, we fear that due to the lack of a definition of "environmental good", the agreement could betray the results of the Paris conference. We wonder how the environmental credibility of the agreement can not be compromised by the inclusion of some products that can hardly be classified among those for environmental use or greater energy efficiency. Equally worrying is the choice not to consider the impact of production and the potential double use of the selected items. Increased imports from less heavily regulated countries could lead to higher emissions. In this regard, I would like to remind you that when we talk about dumping we are not referring only to the economic dimension but that we also think the social and environmental consequences. The liberalization of certain products such as bicycles, whose manufacturing process in Europe meets the strictest standards, could paradoxically have a negative ecological impact. A tonne of CO2 emitted in a country with less stringent regulations, as well as equally harmful, is also cheaper. Thinking of articles such as pipes, we ask the Commission how it intends to regulate its possible dual use. A pipe, in fact, could be used both for a water recycling plant and in the construction of an oil pipeline. The second concern is of an economic nature. Europe is a leader in environmental assets. Aware of the uninterrupted growth of the sector and the related employment fallout, we ask ourselves whether the European offensive interests are actually reflected in the agreement. In addition to duties, in fact, the major obstacles encountered by our companies are of a non-tariff nature. We fear that their exclusion could harm our interests. Europe cannot afford to increase its exposure to competition without gaining equal access to foreign markets. Another important exclusion concerns services. For example, the maintenance and repair of a wind farm can reach 40% of the total value of the sale: we therefore ask the Commission how the negotiations for the inclusion of both of these aspects are proceeding. In conclusion, the current state of the environment requires us to take concrete action against climate change. At the same time, this agreement could offer great economic potential for a fast growing sector. We cannot miss the opportunity to demonstrate how trade is also an instrument of sustainable development and can therefore contribute to improving the lives of people and the planet.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, the Environmental Goods Agreement (EGA) negotiations were launched in July 2014 and are today at a finalisation stage after two years of intense negotiations, comprising 17 rounds of talks involving 44 World Trade Organisation member countries, including the 28 EU Member States. Building on the strong political momentum that was created by G20 leaders in early September, to redouble efforts to find an agreement by the end of this year, we now have a unique window of opportunity to conclude a deal at the ministerial meeting that is scheduled for 3 and 4 December in Geneva. If we do that, we will send out a very strong signal that trade policy can contribute positively to environmental protection and fight against climate change by eliminating tariffs on a list of environmentally sound products. It is doable, but we still have a lot to work to do. So let me address some of the questions you have posed. First you ask whether the Commission can ensure that the EU is conducting these negotiations pursuing primarily environmental-protection objectives and not influenced by specific sectoral interests to reduce tariffs on a certain number of goods. Let me reiterate that the key guiding principle of the EGA negotiation is to eliminate tariffs on a list of goods that are environmentally sound and contribute positively to environmental protection and to fighting climate change. In the years of negotiations, EGA members have closely scrutinised all nominated products from the environmental perspective, with a view to removing those that raised doubts. On the EU side, we have supported products crucial for renewable energy generation, products that are energy efficient due to their particular role with regard to the implementation of the Paris agreement and the shared goal of limiting global warming to 2°. The negotiations also cover imported environmental products to contribute to clean air, soil and water, products that are used for waste management, environmental analysis and monitoring. In this process the negotiators have consulted relevant international organisations such as the United Nations Environmental Programme and the International Renewable Energy Agency and we have, of course, also sought the views of various national environmental agencies, environmental NGOs and industry. Furthermore, customs officials have helped to ensure that the environmental products are clearly defined and can be differentiated from other similar products in the customs nomenclature. Now, let me clarify too that, while environmental aspects are, of course, key in these negotiations, they are also trade negotiations, and these negotiations will be positive for us, especially for SMEs, which will be able internationally to trade environmentally sound products at less cost and with less burdensome procedures. The final agreement will need to be environmentally credible, commercially relevant and balanced so that we can have an acceptable deal for all the parties. Secondly, you asked how the Commission intended to tackle possible market imbalances for those European industries that would continue to face non-tariff barriers when trying to enter foreign markets. Non-tariff barriers and services related to trade in environmental goods do play an important role in the green sector and, on the EU side, we have been vocal on the need to address the market imbalances and to include a work programme to look into this. In the negotiations we, from the EU, strongly advocated a broader agenda but that has not received so much support from other parties. Efforts have now focused on crafting the list of which tariffs will be eliminated, but we have managed to obtain a commitment on a future-oriented agreement that will allow for a work programme, so we can start on non-tariff issues in the future, with a view to identifying non-tariff barriers and also related services in the green sector and consider ways to facilitate trade further. So that is where we are. I hope very much that we can conclude this in a couple of weeks and I am looking forward to the debate.

name: Christofer FJELLNER
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! Abbreviations are controversial in trade policy, we have learned, whether it is Ceta, TTIP, ISDS. Personally, I think that "USA" is probably the most controversial abbreviation of all. But the abbreviation EGA - Environmental Goods Agreement - should not be controversial. A green free trade agreement that combines free trade and sustainability should be embraced by all, but there are still threats to it. There are at least two threats that I am worried about. One is traditional protectionism, ie. all those who want to preserve the duties they are now protected by. This applies regardless of whether it is the car industries in Europe that do not want reduced tariffs on electric cars or whether it is train manufacturers who do not want reduced tariffs on trains. Although they occasionally come to me in my role on the Environment Committee and tell me that they are at least the most environmentally friendly in the world and the best in the world, they do everything they can to stay off the list of environmentally friendly products in this context. Or, for that matter, the 22 Member States struggling to maintain tariffs on bicycles, ie the means of transport with zero emissions. That kind of protectionism threatens this agreement. But also the supposedly green ones, those who are looking for the perfect definition of what is an environmentally friendly product, something that is so tight that almost nothing passes through. I think one should have a different definition. I think we should decide that everything that replaces something that we know is harmful to the environment, we should consider greener. Something that can substitute can be a small comparative advantage by lowering tariffs for what is only a little better, then we do something good for the environment. I believe that after Trump and after our own free trade negotiations with Canada, we really need success. This may be the success we need, but it requires that we now actually dare to invest in it in Europe and not let presumably green or for that matter protectionists put sticks in the wheels.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, these negotiations were born with very good intentions: to promote trade in goods and services capable of improving the environment and fighting climate change. I am aware of the efforts that the Commission has made, but the truth is that the news and the signals that arrive from the last rounds are very worrying. After two and a half years of negotiations, no agreement has been reached on what is meant by an environmental good, and I wonder how an agreement on environmental goods can be negotiated without reaching an agreement on what these goods are. The list of products has been progressively reduced. Now they are under 300. This list, as you have also pointed out before, is limited to goods and does not include services. Work is being done exclusively on lowering rates and the removal of tariff barriers cannot be incorporated at the moment. And the truth is that the contribution to the protection of the environment of the goods included in the list is being increasingly questioned. I wonder what a release of tariffs on vacuum cleaners or refrigerators, as one of the partners is proposing, could have to do with improving the environment. The truth is that I have the feeling that the negotiations have been abandoning the laudable objective they were pursuing, and that the environmental impact that this agreement seeks to achieve is being reduced to a smaller and smaller expression. I clearly defend that our trade policy is a fundamental instrument to face one of the great challenges we have, which is to combat climate change; but the truth is that the objective and the scope of it have been too decaffeinated. And I would like to ask you a specific question: considering the electoral result in the United States and the upcoming presidency of Mr. Trump, how does he think he can affect the outcome of these negotiations, taking into account what is the position that Mr. Trump defends regarding global warming and his little confidence in being able, really, to be effective in the fight against climate change?

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner Malmström, ladies and gentlemen, you are still here this evening. I would like to thank the Commission for its work during these negotiations, and I also welcome this issue to the Commission. I’m putting on glasses now because vision starts to bother me at this age so I can use this one and a half minutes on behalf of my group effectively. This agreement can also be an important factor in the European Union's economic growth. We have a high level of expertise in environmentally friendly products in Europe and we are also able to compete globally in this sector. I hope this has not been forgotten, despite the fact that several industries are pushing for just one product. Instead of guaranteeing market access for an individual product, we must prevent market imbalances and ensure that this agreement keeps pace with developments. Here, an effective re-evaluation clause is absolutely essential so that we can ensure that the agreement does not expire in a couple of years. This agreement can also serve as a tool to achieve global goals and is a good indication that trade and environmental friendliness are not mutually exclusive. The negotiations involve major economies and, with this agreement, we can take environmental standards forward at a global level. This objective should not be ignored just because of the speedy conclusion of the negotiations. I look forward to the outcome of the last round of negotiations and I hope that the outcome will be balanced and offer opportunities for environmentally friendly economic growth.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - (NL) Mr President, my colleagues Lange and Mosca ask whether the Commission is really pursuing the protection of the environment with this agreement on environmental goods and not the financial interests of certain sectors. They also ask whether this treaty is capable of preventing possible market disruption. Those are valid questions, but why do we still need to ask these questions at this stage? These questions should have been at the beginning of the whole procedure and not at the end. They should have been the alpha and omega of these negotiations. A trade agreement on environmental goods must pursue the protection of the environment. A trade agreement of any kind must ensure that trade between two or more parties leads to fair trade, to mutual benefit, and not to market distortions. If the Commissioner cannot promise that this treaty will live up to expectations on those points, will she submit it to us? Well, at this point we no longer accept just about every product and the list of environmental goods has become a bit shorter, it no longer contains every wild idea. Because how did you come up with putting asbestos on the list? In which world is that good for the environment? But this treaty is again a living treaty, which means that the rules can be changed again. The negotiations were again highly secret and are now again withdrawing from the public domain and from scrutiny. For example, how do we know that biodiesel will not simply be on the list again if we look the other way? Perhaps with the current snapshot of the treaty you are pursuing the protection of the environment, but who guarantees that it will stay that way? Moreover, trade agreements by definition cause damage to the environment. The purpose of free trade is to maximize comparative trade advantage ... (The Chairman cut off the speaker)

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, at this late hour I would indeed think that many people are interested in these negotiations, and it should be easy to support this. We are trying to show that trade policy can be value—based and that trade policy can make its contribution to the Paris Climate Agreement. It is absolutely unique and something that I think many support. It is good for the environment and it is good also for our green industries. It will not be a perfect agreement – absolutely not – but this is the first time we are trying to do something like this, and we are doing our utmost to ensure that it is environmentally credible and future-oriented. We have 44 countries – 28 EU and the others – and we need to find a balance. We are trying to learn from past successes and failures and base ourselves on the end—use of products that can be agreed by the members. There is no internationally—accepted definition of green goods. I deplore that, and, of course, it would have been much easier if there was. So we are trying to work ourselves through here, with the involvement of all the countries which are there, to try to establish a common determinator to agree on this. It is the first attempt ever in the World Trade Organization (WTO) to cut tariffs on products that contribute to environmental protection and climate mitigation. This will, of course, be a living agreement. We will have a review mechanism where we can add new things to the list and also, as I said, we are pushing very hard to add non-tariff barriers (NTBs) and services, the people who provide the services to these environmental agreements. It is not easy to speculate about the incoming presidential administration in the US. Everybody does that, but nobody really knows. What we do know is that the American current US chair will be at the meeting in Geneva at the beginning of December; we have had confirmation of this. He is very committed to finalising things, and from what we hear this is not something that the President-elect and his administration is opposing either. So we hope very much that we can have the US on board here, and hope also that other big countries, such as China, are willing to grasp this as an historic possibility to break new ground and to do something. It will not be perfect, as I said, but it is a start that we can build upon, and I hope very much for your support on this.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: I would like to thank you all for persevering - including the interpreters - and wish you a good night.(The sitting was closed at 11.30 p. M.)
